site_title: Huawei sees excitement for Mate 70 phone wane, analysts say
summary: Huawei's Mate 70 smartphone has seen a decline in consumer excitement in China, potentially impacting the company's overall shipments for the year. Analysts, including Jefferies, note that improvements over its predecessor appear to be limited, and the phone's sales volume may be below that of its predecessor, the Mate 60. This could benefit Apple and other Chinese brands, and Huawei's initial shipment forecast of 48 million phones may have downside risk. The decline in enthusiasm for the Mate 70 is seen as inevitable, but some analysts expect slight growth in sales volume compared to the Mate 60 series.

images.alt_text: People check Huawei's new Mate 70 mobile phone at a shop at the Wangfujing shopping area in Beijing, China, Nov 26, 2024.
The Mate 70 is set to be unveiled at a company launch event on Tuesday afternoon at Huawei's Shenzhen headquarters.

site_title: PBOC injects US$111 billion of liquidity as bond supply surges
summary: The People's Bank of China injected $111 billion of liquidity into the banking system via outright reverse repurchase agreements, exceeding last month's $500 billion injection. This move aims to ease funding pressure in the market amid a surge in local government bond sales. The central bank also bought a net 200 billion yuan of sovereign bonds from dealers to ensure plentiful cash supply. The injection is part of the PBOC's efforts to manage liquidity and support the economy, which is expected to achieve its 5% growth target this year despite longer-term challenges.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman walks past the headquarters of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), the central bank, in Beijing, China September 28, 2018. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: Brazil's finance minister, Congress leaders seek to calm markets on tax change concerns
summary: Brazil's finance minister and congressional leaders have sought to calm markets over concerns about a proposed tax change, which could slow down expenses to sustain a fiscal framework passed last year. The measures, announced by President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's administration, were met with skepticism from investors, who fear the government's ability to stabilize its growing debt. The Brazilian real rebounded from record lows after leaders pledged to focus on spending cuts, with the government stressing that fiscal commitment goes beyond a new spending cuts package.

images.alt_text: BYD sold 51,203 vehicles in Brazil during the first nine months of 2024, an increase of more than 700 per cent from the same period last year.
X was ordered to shut down in August after Elon Musk refused to remove dozens of right-wing accounts and failed to name a new legal representative in Brazil.
Moraes has repeatedly clashed with the Musk after making it his mission to crack down on disinformation.

site_title: Frequent fliers are rethinking loyalty programmes and setting themselves free
summary: Frequent flyers are rethinking airline loyalty programs due to changing schemes and increased costs. Many are questioning the value of maintaining status, with some considering canceling credit cards and switching to alternative strategies. Airlines are updating their programs to prioritize spending and flying, leading to increased costs for status. Some frequent flyers, like SuzAnn Brantner, are choosing to fly with alternative carriers for more convenient flights, while others, like Dan Daley, are employing a "mileage run" strategy to maintain status. The shift reflects a growing dissatisfaction with loyalty programs among travelers.

images.alt_text: Loyalty programmes getting better as airlines fight to keep customers

site_title: How to focus like your life depends on it
summary: Formula 1 drivers use mental techniques to optimize performance, which can be applied to everyday life. Key strategies include visualizing challenges, using self-talk to stay focused, and preparing for the unexpected. Drivers also practice mindfulness and shift focus without breaking concentration. Intrinsic motivation and flow states, where individuals work to their limits without feeling overwhelmed, can also improve attention and effectiveness. Additionally, taking intentional breaks to recharge can improve attention and learning, reducing stress and increasing mental resilience. By adopting these techniques, individuals can become more intentional and effective in their daily lives.

Rudy Carezzevoli/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Rudy Carezzevoli / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Brave new world: Creating a composable finance ecosystem
summary: A new "composable finance" ecosystem is emerging, where investment products are tailored to clients' needs through digitalisation. This shift from a client-driven to a client-centric approach enables comprehensive solutions that address complex financial goals. Digitalisation simplifies investment strategies, offers instant transactions, and streamlines asset management. Tokenisation, blockchain, and smart contracts facilitate a fully digital experience, reducing friction and increasing security. Regulatory support is crucial to the adoption of composable finance, which promises a fully client-driven industry.

images.alt_text: Among MAS' new initiatives is supporting industry efforts to build commercial networks for payments, capital raising, and secondary trading of tokenised assets.
Chia Der Jiun, MD, MAS
The hot areas in AI use crypto technology to build decentralised controls. At the same time, many crypto projects are exploiting AI to build complex structures out of decentralised parts.
Asia-Pacific banks need to learn from fintechs and evolve digitally

site_title: Caffeine high: How expensive can your cup of kopi get?
summary: Coffee prices in Singapore have reached record highs due to a tight supply of robusta coffee beans, used in traditional kopi. The shortage, mainly caused by weather conditions in Vietnam, has led to price hikes of up to 60% in the last year, with prices reaching US$5,413 per tonne. Businesses are struggling to absorb the cost increase, with some owners considering price hikes of up to 20 cents to maintain profit margins. Expanding their business and adjusting recipes are also being explored as alternatives to mitigate the rising cost of coffee beans.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan

site_title: North Korea's Kim, Russian minister agree to boost military ties
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met with Russian Defence Minister Andrei Belousov, agreeing to boost military cooperation between the two nations. This comes amid tensions between Russia and the West, with Kim criticizing Western powers' decision to allow Ukraine to strike inside Russia with their weapons. The two countries have strengthened their ties since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022, and Russia has offered access to vast natural resources, potentially bypassing North Korea's main trading partner, China.

images.alt_text: North Korean soldiers training at a base for the special operation armed forces of the Korean People's Army (KPA) at an undisclosed location in North Korea, Sept 11, 2024.
Tensions between the two Koreas remain high after the Kim Jong Un regime sent thousands of balloons across the border this year, dumping trash and propaganda leaflets.

site_title: Top UN court to open unprecedented climate hearings
summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) will begin unprecedented climate hearings next week, with lawyers and representatives from over 100 countries and organizations submitting submissions on how countries should protect the environment from greenhouse gases. The ICJ aims to provide a "legal blueprint" for climate protection, with potential far-reaching consequences for climate change. The hearings follow a failed climate deal at COP29, which failed to set a global pledge to move away from fossil fuels and meet a minimum of $300 billion in annual climate finance by 2035.

Renewable power and electric vehicle booms continued in China this year, but energy consumption is still growing rapidly.
A single cow will burp roughly 100 kilogrammes of the gas annually.

site_title: UK transport minister quits in new blow to PM Starmer
summary: Transport minister Louise Haigh has resigned from the UK government after pleading guilty to misleading police over a work mobile phone she claimed was stolen in 2013. Haigh cited the incident as a distraction from the government's work, but remains committed to the Labour Party's project. She is the first Cabinet minister to resign from Prime Minister Keir Starmer's government, which has seen its approval ratings plummet since taking power in July. Heidi Alexander, former deputy mayor for transport in London, has been appointed as her replacement.

images.alt_text: Keir Starmer, whose Labour party swept to power in July, accused the previous Conservative government of running “a one-nation experiment in open borders”, with regular migration soaring since Brexit in 2020.
The CBI wants the government to make occupational health tax-free, in a move it says will stop 34,000 people dropping out of the workforce.

site_title: Didi again records a profit while it prepares for Hong Kong IPO
summary: Didi Global reported its second consecutive quarterly profit, with a net income of 929 million yuan (S$172 million) for the September quarter. Revenue rose 5% to 53.9 billion yuan, driven by a 20% jump in gross transactions from its international business. The results reflect a steady recovery for the company, which has faced challenges after Beijing cracked down on its data-sharing practices. Didi aims to list on the Hong Kong stock exchange, though the timeline remains unclear.

site_title: 14 organisations find new home with launch of social impact hub The Foundry
summary: Singapore's former Elections Department building has been transformed into a social impact hub, The Foundry, which has welcomed 14 organisations. The $10.4 million project, led by construction firm Woh Hup and co-working brand JustCo, features a co-working space, event hall, and cafe. The hub aims to foster collaboration and provide resources for its partner organisations to develop solutions and build communities. President Tharman Shanmugaratnam and The Majurity Trust's CEO Martin Tan emphasized the importance of collaboration and creating change through the hub.

images.alt_text: Students from five local educational institutions have created artworks – including the one pictured above, by Shepherdson Cheryl Anne – to highlight social issues in Singapore.
Giving smaller charities a helping hand when the going gets tough

site_title: Unstoppable Liverpool ready to heap more pain on wounded Manchester City
summary: Liverpool is set to face Manchester City at Anfield on Sunday, with the Reds looking to extend their lead at the top of the EPL table. Liverpool has won 14 of its last 15 games, while Manchester City has struggled with an injury crisis and a recent 3-3 draw against Feyenoord. City manager Pep Guardiola has a poor record at Liverpool, losing five times and drawing three, and his team is eight points behind Liverpool in the EPL standings. A win for Liverpool could see them go 11 points clear of City and put pressure on the champions.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Indonesia in talks with US, Russia for nuclear power technology
summary: Indonesia is in talks with the US and Russia to acquire nuclear power technology to reduce its dependence on fossil fuels. The country aims to operate nuclear power plants as early as 2036, with the goal of cutting its reliance on coal and increasing renewable energy. Indonesia has received US$217.8 million in grants and loans for decarbonization projects, but funding remains a significant issue. The country plans to build 75 gigawatts of renewable power over the next 15 years, with international investors expected to play a key role in the development of nuclear power plants.

images.alt_text: Asean nations differ in where they stand on tapping nuclear energy. As of now, no Asean nation has reached commercial operations of a nuclear power plant.

site_title: Chinese EV makers slip further in Europe amid tariff tussles
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers, including Saic Motor's MG and BYD, saw their share of European EV registrations decline for the fourth straight month in October, falling to 8.2% from 8.5% in September. The decline comes amid ongoing tariff tussles between the EU and China, with discussions to replace tariffs with price undertakings remaining elusive. BYD outsold MG in October, with sales more than doubling to 4,630 vehicles, while MG deliveries fell 56% to 3,846 vehicles. The EU's added tariffs on Chinese-made EVs have stalled China's rapid gains in the European market since July.

images.alt_text: The EU is also proposing a derogation mechanism to allow EU central securities depositories to unfreeze some of the cash they hold in the face of increased litigation in Russia.
Beijing’s commerce ministry said that authorities have “decided to implement temporary anti-dumping measures in the form of a cash deposit or letter of guarantee” against European brandy products.
The EU launched an anti-subsidy investigation into imports of Chinese-made battery EVs last year and in October voted for tariffs on those vehicles.

site_title: Consortium aims to seal ESR buyout at more than US$7b: sources
summary: A consortium led by Starwood Capital Group and Warburg Pincus is aiming to finalize a deal to take ESR Group private, valuing the Hong Kong-listed real estate fund manager at more than $7 billion. ESR's founders and a unit of Qatar Investment Authority are also part of the consortium. Since the offer, the company's shares have risen 14.4% from their last trading price before the first take-private announcement in May. The deal, which includes the option for shareholders to roll over their holdings into the future private company, is expected to be finalized in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: The Reit attributeS the negative impact on its gross revenue and NPI to the divestment of 11 non-core assets conducted in FY2023 and 2Q2024, with the proceeds pending deployment.

site_title: ChildAid 2024 sees return of alumni, raises about S$2.1m
summary: ChildAid 2024, held on Nov 29 and 30, marked the 20th year milestone of the event, raising about S$2.1 million for two charities through ticket sales and donations. The concert featured 80 young performers, including alumni from previous events, and incorporated AI technology. The funds will go to The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, supporting children from low-income families and artistically talented youth. The event was organized by The Straits Times and Business Times, with a futuristic storyline that aimed to expose young talent to generative technology.

images.alt_text: Pianist Jessie Meng was only six when she was thrust into the limelight performing in ChildAid 2013. Now 17, she was earlier this year named Young Steinway Artist, making her the youngest pianist to be conferred the title.

site_title: Ferrari sees Asian growth potential as F80 supercar debuts in Bangkok
summary: Ferrari unveiled its 1,200-horsepower F80 supercar in Bangkok, marking the brand's first appearance outside of Italy and its entry into the Asian market. The hybrid coupe, limited to 799 units, sold out before its public debut and is priced at 2.9 million euros. Ferrari aims to capitalize on the growing importance of Asia, where the brand sees potential for significant sales growth. The company's chief marketing and commercial officer, Enrico Galliera, stated that the brand is looking to appeal to younger, tech-savvy Asian customers with its upcoming electric vehicle.

images.alt_text: From left: Kia's EV3, EV5 and EV4.

site_title: Singapore hotel performance slips in post-F1 October
summary: Singapore hotels experienced a decline in performance in October, with average room rates (ARR) dropping 12.9% to S$275.19, and revenue per available room (RevPAR) falling 14.4% to S$225.07. Despite this, international visitor arrivals grew 3.5% to 1.31 million, with China and Indonesia being the top sources of international visitors. Room revenue declined 13.3% to S$442.7 million, but year-on-year, it grew 8.8%.

site_title: Figma sues Singapore rival for copyright infringement
summary: Figma, a US-based cloud design software firm, is suing its Singapore rival Motiff for copyright infringement. Motiff, a startup established just over two years ago, offers similar collaborative UI/UX design tools. Figma claims that Motiff copied its source code, including error messages, instructions, and unique implementation details. The case could be costly, with millions of dollars at stake, and may take months or years to resolve. Motiff denies the allegations, stating that its features, designs, and functionalities were developed independently, and it has "great respect for intellectual property rights."

images.alt_text: The longtime leader in software for creative arts professionals has faced anxieties that new generative AI-based startups will cut into its market.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse’s deputy CEO Wilfred Yiu to retire
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) announced that Deputy CEO Wilfred Yiu will retire by year-end, stepping down from his positions as deputy CEO, CEO of the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong (SEHK), and CEO of the Hong Kong Futures Exchange (HKFE). Lau Bik Yun will succeed Yiu as COO of HKEX and take over as CEO of SEHK and HKFE. This move comes after Yiu was appointed as deputy CEO in March and CEO in February.

site_title: Boustead JV seen putting Como Orchard on the market, with S$680 million asking price
summary: A Singapore-led joint venture, Boustead JV, is expected to put Como Orchard, a 156-room hotel and retail building, on the market with an asking price of S$680 million. The property, which opened in September 2023, features a hotel lobby and check-in area on level six and above, with the rooms on levels seven to 18. The building is fully leased, with a medical tenant on level five and several retail spaces. The asset's appeal lies in its location in Orchard Road and income stability with a hotel management agreement.

The property at 301 Jalan Ahmad Ibrahim is near teh Second Link and Tuas Port; it also has significant redevelopment potentilal.

Sale of Fullerton Health draws eight non-binding bids in 1st round: sources

site_title: Wanda unit aiming to create fund of up to 90b yuan backed by malls: sources
summary: Dalian Wanda Commercial Management Group plans to establish a fund of 50 billion yuan to 90 billion yuan to pay taxes and debt, with a goal to complete fundraising by 2025. The fund will be backed by 50 malls and will allocate a portion to repay its 2026 US dollar bond. The move aims to alleviate financial stress amid China's economic slowdown and property market crisis.

images.alt_text: The company has so far met its payment obligations on the bond, according to filings and Bloomberg reports.
Investors led by PAG will hold a combined stake of 60 per cent in Newland Commercial Management, a newly formed holding company of Zhuhai Wanda Commercial Management Group.

site_title: Indonesia to raise minimum wage in 2025 by 6.5%
summary: Indonesia plans to raise its minimum wage by 6.5% in 2025, following a court decision that aimed to increase it by up to 10%. The average provincial minimum wage for 2024 is 3.1 million rupiah, and President Prabowo Subianto stated the increase is intended to boost workers' purchasing power while considering businesses' competitiveness. The move follows a constitutional court ruling that ordered changes to the 2020 Job Creation law, including the establishment of sectoral minimum wages.

images.alt_text: Almost all products and services are subject to VAT, but staple foods and some items and services related to education and health are exempted.

site_title: US firms flock to South-east Asia amid tariff turmoil – record business missions eye Vietnam, Indonesia
summary: US firms are flocking to South-east Asia amid escalating tariff threats, with a record 50 companies signing up for a business mission to Indonesia. This surge in business missions reflects the "China-plus-one" strategies of US companies, seeking to diversify their operations in the region. The US-Asean Business Council's president, Ted Osius, believes the best way for the US to compete for influence in Asean is to lengthen the economic leg of the relationship, with a focus on digital economy and artificial intelligence. Asean is also setting its own rules, with the Digital Economy Framework Agreement, and the US should pay attention to the growing influence of Brics, a bloc increasingly gaining prominence as a strategic counterbalance to the West.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
Veteran diplomat Ted Osius believes the best way for the US to compete for influence in Asean is to lengthen the economic leg of the relationship.

US president-elect Donald Trump, who will be inaugurated on Jan 20, said on Monday (Nov 25) he plans to sign an executive order to impose a 25 per cent tariff on imports from Mexico and Canada, as well as an additional 10 per cent on top of existing tariffs on China.
The annual Brics Summit was hosted in the Russian city of Kazan this year, under President Vladimir Putin's helm.
According to Boston Consulting Group, Asean’s digital economy is projected to triple by 2030, reaching almost US$1 trillion, up from the current US$300 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong October retail sales fall 2.9% y/y
summary: Hong Kong's October retail sales fell 2.9% year-over-year to HK$32.9 billion, marking the eighth consecutive month of decline. The decline was attributed to a change in consumption patterns, with the government attributing support to China's recent economic measures, including the introduction of a multiple-entry visitors' scheme for Shenzhen residents. In volume terms, sales fell 4.9% year-over-year, with the first 10 months of 2024 seeing a 7.1% decline in total retail sales value and an 8.8% decline in volume.

site_title: India’s economy slows more sharply than expected as manufacturing weighs
summary: India's economy slowed more sharply than expected in the July-to-September quarter, expanding by 5.4% year-on-year, its slowest growth in seven quarters. Manufacturing activity slowed to 2.2% growth, while private consumption, accounting for 60% of GDP, was hit by slower urban spending due to higher food inflation and borrowing costs. Economists predict full-year economic growth could be around 6.2%, lower than the RBI's estimate of 7%. Despite this, the government forecasts a potential regaining of momentum in the second half of the fiscal year.

images.alt_text: The average house price in top seven cities, including the capital New Delhi and the financial hub Mumbai, climbed 23 per cent from a year earlier to 12.3 million rupees (S$195,777) during the April-to-September period.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, November 29, 2024
summary: The Singapore market experienced a swing in equities on Friday, November 29, 2024, with the yen rallying on rate hike bets. In related news, the government announced a one-off property tax rebate for owner-occupiers in 2025 to ease cost-of-living pressures. Meanwhile, Nam Cheong surged 19.2% after securing RM1.2 billion in contract wins.

images.alt_text: The stronger yen weighed Japanese exporters and pushed Tokyo stocks lower on Friday.

site_title: Chinese food delivery giant Meituan beats quarterly revenue estimates
summary: Meituan, China's largest food delivery firm, reported a 22.4% rise in third-quarter revenue to 93.6 billion yuan (S$17.3 billion), beating estimates. The company's net profit increased to 12.86 billion yuan, driven by strong food delivery demand. Meituan's core local commerce revenue rose 20.2% and sales from new initiatives grew 28.9%. The company's 63% stock surge faces risks due to China's consumer malaise, but the strong quarterly performance suggests the firm's diversified business model is resilient.

images.alt_text: Meituan had flagged to investors on Tuesday that price guidance for the 3.5-year bond was three-year Treasuries plus about 145 basis points.
Meituan’s secret weapon is its cheaper, group-based Pin Hao Fan platform for ordering meals.
Meituan reported revenue of 82.3 billion yuan (S$15 billion) for the June quarter, compared to the 80.4 billion yuan projection.

site_title: Biden says administration working with FBI on hoax threats to lawmakers, Trump cabinet picks
summary: US President Joe Biden said his administration is working with the FBI to address "swatting" and bomb threats targeting lawmakers, including Rep. Seth Magaziner and several of President-elect Donald Trump's cabinet picks. The threats, made over the Thanksgiving holiday, were found to have no evidence of explosive devices. Law enforcement experts describe swatting as a form of harassment increasingly targeting prominent figures. Biden expects to speak with Trump again during the transition, following a series of violent incidents targeting Trump, including an assassination attempt in July and a man charged with attempted assassination in September.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden speaks to reporters as he visits the Nantucket Fire Department in Nantucket, Massachusetts on Nov 28, 2024.

site_title:
Hong Kong’s New World Development replaces 
CEO after just two months
summary: Hong Kong's New World Development has appointed CEO Huang Shaomei, also known as Echo Huang, after just two months, following the resignation of Eric Ma. Ma had taken over as CEO in September after the company reported a US$2.5 billion annual loss. Ma cited personal commitments as the reason for his departure. The company's share price fell 6% before trading was halted, and trading will resume on Monday. Huang will serve as CEO for a term of three years.

images.alt_text: New World had HK$123.7 billion (S$21.4 billion) of consolidated net debt as of June 30, according to its latest financial report.

site_title: Japan’s October factory output rises 3.0% month-on-month
summary: Japan's factory output rose 3.0% in October from the previous month, exceeding market forecasts. However, manufacturers predict seasonally adjusted output will fall 2.2% in November and 0.5% in December. This indicates a mixed outlook for the country's manufacturing sector.

site_title: Ng Yu Zhi trial: Defence accuses investor of caring only about revenue
summary: Ng Yu Zhi's trial continues with his defense accusing investor Veronica Shim Wai Han of prioritizing revenue over the legitimacy of the nickel-trading scheme. Shim, a private banker, denies the claim, stating she did sufficient due diligence and was convinced the deals were genuine. She also visited a warehouse where nickel was stored and raised concerns about the financial statements of Poseidon Nickel Limited. The defense seeks to establish Shim's credibility and whether she was deceived by Ng. The trial resumes in February 2025.

images.alt_text: Prosecutors alleged that Ng Yu Zhi’s Ponzi scheme, which promised attractive profits from nickel trading, was “pure fiction” that duped 947 investors of almost $1.5 billion.
Ng Yu Zhi’s billion-dollar nickel trading was ‘pure fiction’, prosecution alleges
BUSINESSMAN Ng Yu Zhi, who is allegedly involved in a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam, has been slapped with 105 charges.

site_title: Air cargo flights out of China soar to new peaks ahead of Trump return, tariffs
summary: China has seen a surge in international cargo flights out of the country, reaching a record 3,485 flights in the week ending November 29, driven by companies seeking to purchase goods before US tariffs are imposed. The value of shipments this year is expected to hit a record, with freight flights increasing 73% year-over-year and shipments up 8.3%. China has also extended tariff exemptions for US products until February 2025, which may help alleviate concerns of congestion and rate hikes.

images.alt_text: China's industrial profits in October fell 10 per cent from a year earlier, following a 27.1 per cent slump in September, while earnings slid 4.3 per cent in the first 10 months versus a 3.5 per cent decline in January-September, National Bureau of Statistics data showed.
China is on track for a record trade surplus that could reach almost US$1 trillion this year.
China's prospects may have dimmed further with Trump's election, as the unpredictable US leader increased tariffs on Chinese imports during a broad trade war in his first term.

site_title: ‘Black Friday’ deals target inflation-weary US consumers
summary: US holiday shoppers in 2024 are focused on finding value and discounts due to inflation concerns. Compared to previous years, consumers are more price-sensitive and responsive to deals. Retailers like Target and Best Buy are pulling ahead with Black Friday promotions, with some offering discounts in October. Despite inflation, consumer spending is expected to grow 2.5-3.5% this holiday season, with total spending projected at $989 billion.

images.alt_text: The company now expects fiscal 2024 net sales to rise between 14 per cent and 15 per cent, compared with its prior forecast of 12 per cent to 13 per cent growth.
Walmart joins at least 10 other companies from Deere to Boeing who have pulled back on their DEI commitments in recent months.

site_title: China Renaissance CEO resigns 10 months after star banker exit
summary: China Renaissance CEO Xie Yi Jing has resigned after less than 10 months, citing personal and family reasons. Xie replaced co-founder Bao Fan, a star banker who vanished from the public eye last year, and led the firm until January 2025. The departure follows a 31% drop in employees and a 60% decline in shares since trading resumed in September. Wang Lixing, a veteran investment banker, will succeed Xie as CEO.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company logo of China Renaissance Group, an investment bank led by one of the country’s most famed rainmakers, is shown on a presentation during a news conference on its IPO in Hong Kong, China September 13, 2018.     REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo

site_title: A vintage year for US stock markets that few people expected
summary: US stocks are on track for a record-breaking year, with the S&P 500 Index and Nasdaq 100 experiencing annual gains of over 20% and more than 20% respectively. Despite concerns over a potential economic slowdown and inflation, interest rates have decreased, growth remains robust, and earnings are rising, driving the market higher. The tech sector, led by Nvidia's triple-digit growth, has fueled the rally, with market volatility remaining subdued despite several risk events. Analysts predict a "US boom" scenario for 2025, with earnings growth forecasts of around 15%.

images.alt_text: Trump trades, essentially punishing tariff-sensitive assets from European exporters to Mexico’s peso and driving investment towards US stocks and the US dollar, proved successful.

site_title: Singapore needs to work ‘extra hard’ to maintain valuable ties with China amid uncertainty: SM Lee
summary: Singapore needs to work "extra hard" to maintain its valuable ties with China amid global uncertainty, Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong said. The US-China relationship is tense, with the new US administration's policies towards Beijing uncertain. Lee emphasized the importance of maintaining relations with all sides and having mutually beneficial relations. He noted that Singapore's relationship with China is particularly valuable, given China's giant footprint in the global economy and its presence in South-east Asia. Lee's visit to China comes after a working visit to the US, and he urged caution against being captured by immediate ups and downs in US-China relations.

images.alt_text: CMG20241129-ChuaKT01(OA) 蔡家增/沈泽玮/黎康 Singapore Media wrap-up  [ Shangri-La Hotel, Shanghai ]

site_title: DBS, EnterpriseSG, IMDA programme to help SMEs leverage generative AI
summary: DBS, EnterpriseSG, and the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) have launched a programme called Spark GenAI to help Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) adopt generative artificial intelligence (GenAI). The programme aims to reach 50,000 SMEs over two years, providing a structured approach to discover, identify, adopt, and secure GenAI solutions. The programme's four pillars include awareness, solution recommendations, financial support, and digital resilience. The initiative aims to enhance SMEs' competitiveness in the rapidly growing digital economy and drive innovation.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
IMDA said that while 44 per cent of larger enterprises implemented some sort of AI technology in 2023, just 4.2 per cent of SMEs had done the same.
In software development, AI-generated code promises substantial time and cost savings, yet it has become a top security concern due to potential vulnerabilities and quality issues.
The explosive growth of AI applications, particularly in generative AI, has profoundly changed what businesses, investors and consumers expect from technology.

site_title: The great-man theory of Wall Street
summary: Wall Street remains dominated by bold individuals, with the great-man theory of finance still prevalent. The collapse of Archegos Capital Management, led by investor Bill Hwang, resulted in an 18-year prison sentence. This phenomenon is exemplified by the industry's reliance on charismatic leaders, with firms often mirroring their leaders' styles. Despite increased risk management and diversification, finance remains vulnerable to the triumphs and failures of a small number of individuals. The industry's focus on hero worship and the importance of individual talent has led to the persistence of this dynamic, where firms are often defined by their leaders.

images.alt_text: Archegos Capital Management founder Sung Kook "Bill" Hwang leaves following his sentencing on a fraud conviction stemming from the 2021 collapse of his $36 billion private investment firm, at the United States District Court in Manhattan in New York City, U.S., November 20, 2024. REUTERS/Brendan McDermmid

site_title: JPMorgan agrees to drop lawsuit against Tesla over stock warrants
summary: JPMorgan Chase has agreed to drop its lawsuit against Tesla, seeking $162.2 million, after the two companies settled their claims in a Manhattan court. The lawsuit, filed in 2021, accused Tesla of breaching a 2014 contract related to stock warrants. The settlement terms were not disclosed. Tesla had countersued JPMorgan in 2023, accusing the bank of seeking a "windfall" when it repriced the warrants. The move marks a resolution to the dispute over the warrants, which were affected by a 2018 tweet by Tesla CEO Elon Musk.

images.alt_text: Trump Media & Technology Group, in which the former president owns a majority stake, soared about 30 per cent.
BYD is rapidly closing in on Tesla as the world’s biggest seller of pure EVs.

site_title: Jaguar’s rebrand: Bold move or a bridge too far?
summary: Jaguar, a 102-year-old British carmaker, unveiled a radical rebranding effort on November 19, featuring a 30-second video showcasing fashion models and abstract activities, with no cars in sight. The move was met with criticism and anger from netizens, brand loyalists, and the general public, who feel the company has forsaken its heritage and lost its emotional connection. The rebranding comes at a crucial moment for Jaguar, which has seen global sales decline from 180,000 units in 2018 to under 67,000 in 2023. The luxury market has shifted towards consumers seeking purpose and values-driven purchases, raising questions about whether Jaguar's rebrand is a necessary evolution or a misstep that risks its legacy.

images.alt_text: Tata Motors posted a profit of 33.43 billion rupees (S$523.5 million) for the quarter ended Sep 30, down 11 per cent on-year.
The Olympics start on July 26 with a spectacular opening ceremony along the Seine.

site_title: Business, labour opposition grows to Indonesia’s scheduled value-added tax increase
summary: Indonesia's scheduled value-added tax (VAT) increase to 12% on January 1 has faced opposition from businesses and labour unions, who argue the timing is not right due to a deteriorating economic environment. The government has said the VAT hike is needed to improve the structural health of the budget, but opponents claim it will hurt workers and deepen social inequality. Labour groups plan to protest if the hike goes ahead, while state lender Mandiri forecasts a minimal impact on GDP growth.

images.alt_text: Indonesian Retailer Association warned that the planned tax hike could hit the retail sector hard

site_title: Oil settles down as ease of supply risks drives weekly loss
summary: Oil prices declined by over 3% last week, with Brent crude falling 0.5% to $72.94 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling 1.1% to $68 a barrel. The decline was driven by easing concerns over supply risks from the Israel-Hezbollah conflict and the prospect of increased supply in 2025, with the International Energy Agency predicting over 1 million barrels per day of excess supply. Opec+ is expected to extend production cuts at its next policy meeting, with Brent crude forecast to average $74.53 a barrel in 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D printed oil pump jack is seen in front of displayed OPEC logo in this illustration picture, April 14, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
Brent crude futures edged up by 34 cents, or 0.5 per cent, to US$73.17 a barrel by 2026 GMT on Thursday.

site_title: Taylor Swift fans turn out early for book launch at Target
summary: Taylor Swift fans lined up outside Target stores in the US on Black Friday to buy copies of her new Eras Tour book, priced at $39.99. The book launch aimed to boost sales at the retailer, which has been experiencing slowing sales. Fans waited in freezing temperatures, with some queuing up as early as 5 am ET, to get their hands on the book, vinyl, and CD versions of her album. The event is seen as a response to "Swiftflation," a phenomenon where Swift's concerts have boosted local economies.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift is nominated in seven categories following the release this year of her 11th album The Tortured Poets Department.

Taylor Swift greets fans during the MTV Video Music Awards on Sep 12, 2023. The upcoming symposium explores themes such as the phenomenon of Swift fandom and the economic impacts of Swift’s touring and cultural prominence.

site_title: Bank of England warns of risks from rise in global trade barriers
summary: The Bank of England warned of potential risks from rising global trade barriers, citing the impact on global growth, inflation, and financial markets. Higher trade barriers could disrupt cross-border capital flows, reducing the ability to diversify risk and increasing volatility in financial markets. The BOE also expressed concerns about the potential for global fragmentation, with risks to the UK financial sector being particularly relevant due to its openness. The central bank plans to conduct full stress tests on UK banks every two years starting in 2025 to assess their resilience.

images.alt_text: The BOE came under intense political pressure during the crisis, which saw consumer-price growth hit 11.1 per cent at its peak.

site_title: US hits South-east Asian solar imports with duties up to 271%
summary: The US Commerce Department has imposed duties of up to 271% on solar cell and module imports from Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam, citing unfair trade practices. The move aims to protect US solar panel makers and their investments in domestic supply chains. The preliminary determination is the latest bid by US manufacturers to confront overseas rivals, following similar duties imposed on Chinese solar imports 12 years ago. The final decisions are expected next April, with rates potentially being raised or lowered.

images.alt_text: Drone Aerial view of Solar power plant  & Solar PV panels used for producing Renewable & Clean energy, which can later be utilized for producing Green Hydrogen or Green ammonia.

site_title: Thai economy improved in October on tourism, consumption and exports
summary: Thailand's economy improved in October due to tourism, exports, and private consumption, with a current account surplus of US$0.7 billion. Exports rose 14.2% from a year earlier, while imports rose 17.1%, resulting in a trade surplus of US$1.4 billion. Industrial production increased, and private consumption and investment also rose. The Bank of Thailand raised its 2024 GDP growth forecast to 2.7% and trimmed its 2025 growth outlook to 2.9%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cargo ships are pictured near the port in Bangkok, Thailand, March 25, 2016. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo
The Bank of Thailand will next review monetary policy on Dec 18.

site_title: PlayStation at 30: How Sony’s grey box conquered gaming
summary: The original PlayStation, launched by Sony in Japan on December 3, 1994, is celebrating its 30th anniversary. The console, known as the "little grey box," revolutionized the gaming industry with its CD-ROM technology, broadening its appeal to a mature audience. It went on to sell over 102 million units, launching beloved franchises and establishing Sony as a gaming heavyweight. Despite intense competition, the PlayStation remains a significant player in the industry, with recent updates and a new hand-held console in development.

images.alt_text: Sony already has a 2 per cent stake in Kadokawa and a stake in Kadokawa subsidiary FromSoftware, the developer of the hit fantasy role-playing game.

FILE PHOTO: PlayStation logo is seen on a smartphone in front of Destiny game displayed in this picture illustration, February 1, 2022. Picture taken February 1, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Sony PlayStation 5 Pro gaming console is retailing for US$699.99 in the US – US$250 more than the previous PlayStation 5 model.
Nintendo’s been expanding into new areas to capitalise on its intellectual property and reduce the ups and downs of an industry hostage to gaming hits.

site_title: China’s factory activity continues expansion in sign of recovery
summary: China's factory activity expanded in November, exceeding analyst expectations, according to both official and private measures. The manufacturing purchasing managers' index reached 50.3, surpassing forecasts of 50.2. The non-manufacturing measure slipped to 50, while the composite index remained unchanged at 50.8. This marks a tentative sign of recovery after stimulus measures were announced in September. However, China faces new challenges, including the threat of steep US tariffs under Donald Trump's presidency, which could impact the country's export sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker wearing a face mask works on a production line manufacturing bicycle steel rim at a factory, in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province, China March 2, 2020. China Daily via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Japanese banks sticking with Adani as Jefferies, Barclays review ties
summary: Japan's largest banks, including Mizuho, SMFG, and MUFG, plan to maintain ties with Adani Group despite US bribery charges, citing cash-generative assets and a long history of supporting emerging markets. In contrast, Barclays has suspended new loans or financing to the group, while Jefferies has not discussed new dealings after further accusations surfaced. Japanese banks view Adani as a crucial growth market and are unlikely to substantially reduce their overall India exposure, despite tightening processes or raising risk premiums.

images.alt_text: State Bank of India will not stop lending to ongoing Adani projects that are nearing completion, but will exercise caution when disbursing loans to ensure all terms and conditions are being met.
IHC stated that their partnership with the Adani Group reflects their confidence in the group's contributions to the green energy and sustainability sectors.
The Department of Justice’s indictment does not mention Gautam Adani (above), Sagar Adani or Vneet Jaain in any count related to conspiracy to violate the FCPA.

The Nov 20 bombshell indictment in New York accused billionaire industrialist founder Gautam Adani and multiple subordinates of deliberately misleading international investors as part of the bribery scheme.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals rose again ahead of Labour’s budget
summary: UK mortgage approvals rose to a two-year high in October, with 68,300 home loans approved, exceeding expectations. The increase was driven by buyers seeking to complete deals before tax hikes and rising interest rates took effect. Economists expect the housing market to slow down due to the chancellor's budget, which includes payroll tax increases and higher spending. Mortgage rates have also risen, with the average two-year fixed rate at 5.52%. The resilient mortgage approvals suggest stronger transactions in the coming months, with buyers rushing to complete deals before the stamp duty threshold is lowered next April.

images.alt_text: Thursday’s survey showed that optimism among consumer services businesses sank to its lowest since August 2022 at -55 in November, down from -19 in August, while among business and professional services sentiment fell to -29 from +9.

TOPSHOT - Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves poses with the red Budget Box as she leaves 11 Downing Street, in central London, on October 30, 2024, to present the government's annual Autumn budget to Parliament. Britain's new Labour government unveils its first budget on Wednesday, the highly-anticipated fiscal update, the first under the centre-left government after 14 years of Conservative rule. (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS / AFP)
Annual shop price deflation of 0.6 per cent in the 12 months to November followed a 0.8 per cent drop in the 12 months to October.
The CBI wants the government to make occupational health tax-free, in a move it says will stop 34,000 people dropping out of the workforce.

epa11666753 Shoppers on Oxford Street in London Britain, 18 October 2024. UK retail sales have shown modest growth for September. Retails sales grew by 0.3% in September, a slowdown from the 1.0% increase recorded in August.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Japan government approves US$92 billion extra budget
summary: Japan's government has approved a $92 billion extra budget to help boost the economy and address the country's shrinking population. The budget includes handouts of around 30,000 yen for low-income households, fuel and energy subsidies, and assistance to small businesses. The move aims to improve Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba's popularity, who has faced criticism for his gaffe-riddled start to office. The budget is expected to be approved in parliament by the end of the year and will be partly funded by issuing bonds worth over 6.6 trillion yen.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk down the high-street shopping area of the Ginza district in central Tokyo on November 22, 2024. Japan's minority government was expected on November 22 to approve a 140-billion USD stimulus drive aimed at putting more money in consumers' pockets after the ruling party's worst election result in 15 years. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Lady Gaga to hold free concert at Rio’s Copacabana Beach: sources
summary: Lady Gaga will hold a free concert at Rio's Copacabana Beach in May 2025 as part of the city's "Celebration May" initiative, boosting the local economy. The event is expected to draw hundreds of thousands of fans and follows the success of Madonna's 2024 concert, which attracted an estimated 1.6 million attendees. The concert is part of Mayor Eduardo Paes' efforts to bring international superstars to the city's events, which have previously included performances by the Rolling Stones, Rod Stewart, and Lenny Kravitz.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cast member Lady Gaga attends a premiere for the film"Joker: Folie a Deux", in Los Angeles, California, U.S., September 30, 2024. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni/File Photo
Joaquin Phoenix made headlines with the first Joker when he revealed that he had lost 52 pounds (23.6 kg) preparing for the role. He underwent a similar transformation this time around.
Taylor Swift merchandise on display at a Target store in New Jersey, U.S, November 29, 2024. REUTERS/Siddharth Cavale/File Photo
Taylor Swift is nominated in seven categories following the release this year of her 11th album The Tortured Poets Department.
Universal Music Group announced that the new operation, headquartered in Shenzhen, will focus on marketing and artist management, with the aim of developing local artists across the Greater Bay Area.

site_title: It’s bananas to regard art as an investment
summary: A banana sculpture by Maurizio Cattelan sold for $6.2 million at Sotheby's auction house in New York, with cryptocurrency entrepreneur Justin Sun purchasing the piece. The sale highlights the subjective nature of art value, with exclusivity, authenticity, and desirability determining an artwork's worth. Experts argue that art investing is a "floating crap game" with unpredictable prices, and most artworks eventually end up being destroyed or lost. The article concludes that art should be valued for its aesthetic and emotional significance, rather than as a potential investment opportunity.
