site_title: Eurozone consumers see inflation edge up slightly: ECB survey
summary: The European Central Bank's Consumer Expectations Survey revealed that Eurozone consumers' inflation expectations for the next 12 months rose to 2.5% from 2.4%, while expectations for three years ahead remained at 2.1%. Consumer expectations for growth fell to -1.1% from -0.9%, and nominal income growth expectations decreased to 1.1% from 1.3%. The survey also showed a steady decline in inflation expectations over the past three years, indicating that consumers largely believe the ECB's narrative that price growth is under control.

site_title: MUFG offers to buy WealthNavi for 99.7b yen in fintech push
summary: Japan's largest bank, MUFG, is set to acquire robo-adviser WealthNavi for up to 99.7 billion yen (S$890.9 million) through a tender offer at 1,950 yen per share. The deal aims to boost MUFG's financial-technology capabilities and cater to households investing more of their savings online. WealthNavi's shares jumped 28% after the announcement, and the company's market capitalization increased by 84% over the closing price. The acquisition is part of MUFG's strategy to create a comprehensive finance super-app.

images.alt_text: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, the top bank by assets, said second-quarter profit surged 90 per cent on higher interest rates and the sale of cross-held shares.
MUFG said net income came in at 555.9 billion yen (S$5 billion) for its fiscal first quarter ended in June, accounting for more than a third of its annual projection of 1.5 trillion yen.
MUFG said net income came in at 555.9 billion yen (S$5 billion) for its fiscal first quarter ended in June, accounting for more than a third of its annual projection of 1.5 trillion yen.

site_title: US Bitcoin ETFs head for record monthly inflow on Trump optimism
summary: US Bitcoin ETFs are on track for a record monthly net inflow of $6.2 billion, driven by President-elect Donald Trump's support for the digital asset. Bitcoin has more than doubled this year, surpassing global stocks and gold, and has recently reached $95,400. Trump's pledge to scrap a Biden administration crackdown on crypto and create a US strategic stockpile of the original cryptocurrency has boosted investor confidence. Market analyst Josh Gilbert expects continued inflows into ETFs under a Trump administration, which may pave the way for easier regulation of other digital assets.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has risen around 40 per cent as traders anticipate a more friendly regulatory environment for crypto with a president who has said he supports the industry.

site_title: Macquarie seeks Japan, India fund bets as China appetite cools
summary: Macquarie Group, a leading infrastructure investor, is shifting its focus away from China due to concerns over regulatory changes and macroeconomic risks. The firm is instead exploring investments in Japan and India, citing a revival in Japan's economy and India's rapid growth. Macquarie has over $16 billion managed under its Asia-Pacific infrastructure fund series and aims to balance its exposure between developing and developed markets. The company is also looking to invest in new areas, such as tertiary healthcare and education, and has recently sold assets to boost its cash reserves.

images.alt_text: Macquarie Bank received a A$5 million (S$4.4 million) fine last month after an ASIC disciplinary panel found it breached market integrity rules by failing to stop the trades by three clients from January to September 2022.
Renewable energy is attracting increasing investment as countries seek to meet climate goals and cope with growth in electricity demand.

Shares of Macquarie were down 2 per cent, against a 0.6 per cent gain on the broader market, as analysts noted a sharper-than-expected slump from the commodities unit but a headline result that was in line with forecasts.

site_title: Singapore’s strong brand name in China comes down to Singaporeans there: SM Lee
summary: Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized that Singapore's strong brand name in China is largely due to Singaporeans living and working in the country, which has added value to the relationship between the two nations. He highlighted the importance of these "ambassadors" in fostering cultural, business, and personal connections. Singapore's economic ties with Shanghai have grown significantly, with trade increasing 15% in the first half of 2024, and the city is now Singapore's largest foreign investor in China. Lee stressed the need for Singapore to maintain close collaboration with China, particularly in uncertain global times.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong (left) with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing on Tuesday (Nov 26).

site_title: Hot stock: Nam Cheong jumps 19.2% after RM1.2 billion in contract wins
summary: Nam Cheong, a Malaysian offshore support vessel provider, surged 19.2% after announcing a RM1.2 billion (S$360 million) contract win from regional and international oil majors. The company will charter 12 vessels, accounting for about a third of its fleet, with the charters set to begin in 2025 and last for three years. This deal is expected to positively contribute to the group's financial performance from the financial year ending Dec 31, 2025.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Nam Cheong's shares resumed trading on the Singapore Exchange after a four-year suspension.
Leong Seng Keat, Nam Cheong's group CEO.
Nam Cheong auditor issues disclaimer of opinion on FY2021 financial statements

site_title: UK government to review the BBC’s long-term funding
summary: The UK government plans to review the BBC's long-term funding, considering alternatives to the TV licence, which has seen a decline in payments due to online content shifts. The review, to be based on the Royal Charter, aims to secure the BBC's future with a sustainable public funding model. The current TV licence fee of £169.50 per year will remain in place until 2027, with the government committed to keeping the fee level with inflation. The review will determine the BBC's funding beyond 2027.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Pedestrians walk past a BBC logo at Broadcasting House in London, Britain, January 29, 2020. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

site_title: Dollar sees biggest weekly drop in a year as Trump trade stalls
summary: The US dollar is experiencing its biggest weekly loss in a year, falling 1.3% as speculation on Donald Trump's policies dissipates. The yen rose 3.5% against the dollar, while the euro gained 1.6%. Trump's nomination of Scott Bessent as Treasury Secretary is seen as a more traditional approach, reducing expectations of steep tariffs and inflation. The dollar's decline is attributed to traders cutting their bets on the greenback, following a sharp run-up fueled by Trump's election euphoria.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese 10,000 yen notes are spread out next to U.S. 100 dollar bills at Interbank Inc. money exchange in Tokyo, in this September 9, 2010 picture illustration. REUTERS/Yuriko Nakao/File Photo

site_title: WHO wants bird flu surveillance stepped up
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is urging countries to step up bird flu surveillance after the first human case of H5N1 was detected in a child in the US. The number of bird flu outbreaks has grown exponentially since 2020, with tens of millions of poultry and mammals infected. WHO director Maria Van Kerkhove emphasized the need for stronger animal surveillance to understand the circulation of the virus in animals, particularly wild birds, poultry, and mammals susceptible to infection.

images.alt_text: Oceania is the last region of the world free of the H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b avian influenza that has killed hundreds of millions of birds.
FILE PHOTO: A person holds a test tube labelled "Bird Flu", in this picture illustration, January 14, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A sign marks the headquarters of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) vaccine maker Moderna in Cambridge, Massachusetts, U.S., April 28, 2022.   REUTERS/Brian Snyder/File Photo

site_title: German government plans about two billion euros in new chip subsidies
summary: The German government plans to provide approximately 2 billion euros in new subsidies to chip companies to develop modern production capacities. This follows Intel's decision to postpone its 30 billion euros chip factory project in Magdeburg. The subsidies aim to strengthen Germany's semiconductor ecosystem and double its market share to 20% of global production capacity by 2030, as set by the European Chips Act.

images.alt_text: Consumer-price growth in Europe’s largest economy held at 2.4 per cent – below the 2.6 per cent median estimate in a Bloomberg survey. A moderation in food costs offset energy base effects.
FILE PHOTO: People walk on a shopping street in the southern German town of Konstanz January 17, 2015.REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: People walk on a shopping street in the southern German town of Konstanz January 17, 2015.REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Japan PM Ishiba faces first major policy test with stimulus plan
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba is set to unveil a 13.9 trillion yen stimulus package, aimed at boosting economic growth and addressing rising living costs, in a speech to parliament on Friday. The package includes 5.8 trillion yen for regional growth, 3.4 trillion yen for inflation response, and 4.8 trillion yen for security and social policies. Ishiba's government faces a minority administration, but a deal with the opposition Democratic Party for the People has provided stability, and he is unlikely to face challenges from within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party before the spring.

images.alt_text: Manufacturers surveyed by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry expect seasonally adjusted output to fall 2.2 per cent in November and drop 0.5 per cent in December.
Public opinion polls in Japan generally show support for more defence spending, although there’s far less support for tax increases to pay for it.
Japan’s property prices have soared, especially in metropolitan areas.

Japan's services producer price index, which measures the price companies charge each other for services, rose 2.9 per cent in October from a year earlier, BOJ data showed, accelerating from a 2.8 per cent gain in September.

site_title: Canada’s Trudeau arrives in Florida for meeting with Trump
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with President-elect Donald Trump in Florida on Nov 29, amid pressure to address US concerns over border security and defense spending. Trump has threatened to impose tariffs on Canada and Mexico unless they halt the flow of illegal drugs and undocumented migrants, potentially sparking a trade feud. Trudeau has assured Trump that the number of migrants crossing the Canada-US border is minuscule, and both countries are working together to combat the flow of fentanyl. Economists warn that tariffs could raise prices for consumers and redirect trade flows, posing a significant economic threat to Canada and Mexico.

images.alt_text: Grocery prices have jumped 20 per cent over the past three years, while wages have grown by about 12 per cent, according to Statistics Canada data.
An oil pumpjack in a farmer’s field near Kindersley, Saskatchewan, Canada, Sept 5, 2024. Canada is the world’s fourth-largest oil producer and sixth-largest natural gas producer.
Rents across Canada have been setting records in recent years as a surge in immigration boosted demand.

Condominiums stand along the shore of Lake Ontario in this aerial photograph taken above Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Monday, Oct. 2, 2017. Toronto housing prices fell for a fourth month in September as sales remained sluggish, particularly in the detached-home segment that has borne the brunt of the correction in Canada's biggest city. Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil up as Israel, Hezbollah trade accusations of ceasefire violation
summary: Oil prices rose as Israel and Hezbollah traded accusations of ceasefire violations, prompting Israeli tank fire on southern Lebanon. Brent crude futures increased 0.5% to $73.17 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 0.2% to $68.88. OPEC+ delayed its meeting to Dec 5, potentially extending production cuts. The delay has been factored into oil prices, which have been influenced by weak global demand and the US Thanksgiving holiday.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D printed oil pump jack is seen in front of displayed OPEC logo in this illustration picture, April 14, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
WTI was little changed, settling below US$69 a barrel. Brent also steadied to settle below US$73 on Wednesday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IHH Healthcare, Digital Core Reit
summary: IHH Healthcare reported a flat third quarter net profit of RM534 million, with earnings per share remaining unchanged at 6.06 sen, despite a 3% decline in revenue due to inflation. Digital Core Reit released a response to unitholders' questions regarding its acquisition of a larger stake in a data center in Frankfurt, Germany, with its shares closing 0.8% higher at US$0.63.

site_title: Issue 127: Sembcorp stays on transformation course; much ado about Adani Green
summary: Sembcorp Industries, a Singapore-based energy company, has announced significant investments in renewable energy, with seven-tenths of its capital expenditure in the first half of 2024 going towards renewables. The company aims to become one of the purest renewable energy plays on the Singapore Exchange, with a 2024-to-2028 roadmap that includes $14 billion of capital investment. However, the big bet on renewables comes with risks, including uncertain demand and potential short-term bumps. Sembcorp's gas and related services business remains its largest single segment, providing a buffer for the transition. The company is also set to divest its integrated waste management arm by the first half of 2025.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim

site_title: Ottawa must ensure Trump understands importance of Canadian oil to US, minister says
summary: Canadian Natural Resources Minister Jonathan Wilkinson stated that Ottawa must ensure President-elect Donald Trump understands the importance of Canadian oil to the US, amid Trump's vow to impose a 25% tariff on Canadian imports. Canada is the world's fourth-largest oil producer, with most crude exports going to the US, which would drive up fuel prices if tariffs are imposed. Wilkinson emphasized the need for effective communication to highlight the inter-related energy markets and the benefits of Canadian uranium and hydro exports to the US.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An oil pump jack pumps oil in a field near Calgary, Alberta, Canada on July 21, 2014.  REUTERS/Todd Korol/File Photo/File Photo
US President Joe Biden speaks to reporters as he visits the Nantucket Fire Department in Nantucket, Massachusetts on Nov 28, 2024.
Trump trades, essentially punishing tariff-sensitive assets from European exporters to Mexico’s peso and driving investment towards US stocks and the US dollar, proved successful.
Wired reported earlier that the US could come out with new export controls rules as soon as next Monday.
China has recently stepped up soybean purchases in Brazil, but it’s still picking up American cargoes for supplies that will be put in reserve.
While Donald Trump and Elon Musk have claimed that US$2 trillion could potentially be saved, most experts believe this is not realistic without cuts to crucial services or benefits.
Refining sources in Asia and analysts said they expect to see more Canadian and Mexican oil heading to Asia if Donald Trump imposes tariffs.

site_title: Revolut will let former staff sell stock in secondary sale
summary: Revolut, a London-headquartered fintech, is now Europe's most valuable fintech with a $45 billion valuation. Former staff can participate in a secondary share sale, allowing them to sell up to 5% of their vested shares, with a minimum of $100,000. The sale is conducted via Shareworks and Morgan Stanley's equity solutions manager. This follows a similar sale for current employees, allowing early investors to exit with at least $300 million. Revolut has not raised money in recent years, avoiding sharp declines in valuation like many peers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Revolut logo is seen in this illustration taken July 29, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Revolut said on Friday it had “signed agreements with a group of leading technology investors to provide liquidity to employees through a secondary share sale at a US$45 billion valuation.”
Revolut’s revenue almost doubled to a forecast-beating £1.8 billion in 2023, helped by interest income that soared to £500 million from £83 million in 2022, according to its annual report.
Revolut offers an array of financial services through its app, including payments, foreign exchange, loans and crypto trading, with the exact mix varying market by market.
Revolut Singapore is preparing to expand its footprint to India as remittances to that country account for roughly 14 per cent of the financial services app’s total.

site_title: IHH Healthcare’s Mount Elizabeth renovation ahead of schedule, the bulk to be done by Q3 2025
summary: IHH Healthcare's Mount Elizabeth Hospital renovation is expected to be completed by Q2-Q3 2025, ahead of schedule. The hospital is currently operating at half its usual capacity, but the group plans to add 25% of its beds back by Q1-Q2 2025. The renovation will result in "some margin pressure" until mid-2025, but the group expects its overall margin to return to around 29% by the end of 2025. The company remains bullish on India, where its facilities are running at 77% occupancy, and plans to expand bed capacity by 38% over the next five years.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Kenanga research analyst Raymond Choo said Island Hospital will be an integral part of IHH’s cluster strategy, with Penang already serving as the group’s second largest Malaysian cluster.
IHH Healthcare's Mount Elizabeth Fertility Centre and Haematology and Stem Cell Transplant Centre are located near Mount Elizabeth Hospital.
Affinity purchased Golden Fresh, one of Malaysia’s biggest seafood processors, for US$450 million.

site_title: Two investors in Ng Yu Zhi’s Ponzi scheme ‘died because of pressure from case’: Private banker
summary: Ng Yu Zhi, 37, is on trial for allegedly running a $1.5 billion nickel trading Ponzi scheme that duped 947 investors. Prosecutors claim the scheme was "pure fiction" and two alleged victims, including a former Singapore Airlines flight stewardess-turned-private banker, Veronica Shim Wai Han, testified that at least two investors died due to pressure from the case. Shim alleged that Ng's scheme destroyed 30 staff jobs and caused unnecessary scrutiny, and that she and her directors could face charges for failing to mitigate conflicts of interest.

images.alt_text: Ng Yu Zhi’s billion-dollar nickel trading was ‘pure fiction’, prosecution alleges
BUSINESSMAN Ng Yu Zhi, who is allegedly involved in a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam, has been slapped with 105 charges.
Ng Yu Zhi's unusually large cash transfers from his trading company to his personal account prompted OCBC to file suspicious transaction reports to police as far back as 2019,

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Friday amid cautious optimism; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.1% higher on Friday, with 269 gainers outnumbering 217 losers. Telecom group Singtel led the gains, rising 1.6%, while Nam Cheong jumped 19.2% after securing offshore vessel charter contracts. The three local banks ended the day mixed, with UOB declining 0.4% and DBS rising 0.4%. The announcement by the Monetary Authority of Singapore on standardized leverage limit requirements for S-Reits is seen as a marginal positive for the sector, providing more buffer and financial flexibility.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
Chloe Lim
Generic photo of Singtel
IHH Healthcare's earnings per share stood at 6.06 sen, also relatively unchanged from 6.04 sen.

site_title: Saudi-backed LIV Golf is said to weigh deal with DP World Tour
summary: Saudi-backed LIV Golf is considering a potential tie-up with the DP World Tour, which could lead to a merged schedule and shared events. The deal would give LIV Golf a stable source of funding and the DP World Tour significant financial heft. Talks with the PGA Tour are ongoing, with the Saudi wealth fund investing in PGA Tour Enterprises, a for-profit entity that houses the commercial assets of the PGA Tour and DP World Tour. A merger between LIV Golf and DP World Tour could end the animosity between the two leagues, sparking hopes for a more unified golfing calendar.

images.alt_text: Nelly Korda, 26, has claimed six victories and three additional top-10 finishes this season, including her second major title at the Chevron Championship.
A bird's eye view of Sentosa Golf Club's world-renowned Serapong course, which has played host to dozens of local and international tournaments over the years.

site_title: Gold set for weekly decline; market awaits more US data
summary: Gold prices are poised for a weekly decline due to upcoming US economic data influencing the Federal Reserve's monetary policy outlook. Spot gold fell 0.1% to $2,637.71 per ounce, with a 3% decline so far this week. The Fed's rate cut trajectory may be cautious, and a 25-basis-point reduction is expected in December, with a 62.8% chance according to the CME Group's FedWatch Tool. Geopolitical tensions, including the Israeli military strike on Hezbollah and Russia's attack on Ukraine's energy infrastructure, also affected gold prices.

images.alt_text: Gold is often regarded as a safe-haven investment during periods of economic or geopolitical instability, including trade wars.

site_title: RBA reforms raise uncertainties over rate path, economists say
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has passed legislation to split its board into two entities, potentially paving the way for more transparent monetary policy decisions. The new board will include a separate monetary policy committee, with its composition unclear. This change raises uncertainty over the RBA's future interest rate path, with economists warning that potential new board members could shift the stance of the central bank. The RBA has kept policy on hold since November, with its benchmark rate at 4.35%, and is unlikely to cut rates in the near term.

images.alt_text: Outside the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) building in Sydney. Photographer: David Gray/Bloomberg
Reserve Bank of Australia's governor Michele Bullock Michele Bullock stated that 3.5% core inflation exceeds their 2-3% goal, requiring restrictive policy until reaching the target.
An independent review of the central bank released last year had recommended scrapping Section 11, a power never used since the RBA was established in 1960.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow close at record highs on tech, retail in focus
summary: US stocks closed at record highs on Black Friday, driven by technology and retail stocks. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6% and 0.4%, respectively, with Nvidia and Tesla leading gains. Retail stocks, including Target and Macy's, also saw significant increases. Investors expect the US central bank to lower borrowing costs by 25 basis points in December, but may pause rate cuts in January.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 38.0 points, or 0.08 per cent, at the open to 44,760.05.

site_title: China resumes multiple-entry visas for Shenzhen to Hong Kong
summary: China has eased visa rules for Shenzhen residents traveling to Hong Kong, allowing unlimited visits within a year. Starting Dec 1, residents of the southern Chinese tech hub can apply for multiple-entry visas, restoring a 2009 policy that was replaced in 2015 due to complaints about parallel trading. The move aims to revive Hong Kong's stalling tourism industry, but its impact is uncertain due to economic slowdown and waning popularity among Chinese travelers.

images.alt_text: china visa Photographer: Yan Cong/Bloomberg

site_title: Two small nations, one big future
summary: Scotland and Singapore, two small nations, are poised to benefit from a "big future" thanks to the Brand Scotland initiative, launched by Secretary of State for Scotland Ian Murray. The initiative aims to boost trade links, promote Scottish goods and services, and help businesses export, with a target of five trade missions in the next two years. Singapore's accession to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) also presents opportunities for increased trade and closer business relationships between the two nations.

images.alt_text: Singapore's marine and offshore players can adapt to take part in constructing critical components in the wind energy value chain, such as offshore substations, support vessels, and mooring products.

site_title: Asia: Yen rallies on rate hike bets as equity markets swing
summary: The yen rallied on Friday, hitting less than 150 per dollar for the first time in a month, following Japan's forecast-busting inflation data and speculation of another interest rate cut. The stronger yen weighed on Japanese exporters and Tokyo stocks, while equity markets in Asia were mixed. Traders are also tracking developments surrounding US President-elect Donald Trump's plans, including tariffs on China, Canada, and Mexico. Expectations for a rate increase in Japan have risen to over 60%, and the yen's rally is seen as supported by forecasts of a US rate cut.

images.alt_text: Telecom group Singtel was the top gainer on the Straits Times Index, rising 1.6% or S$0.05 to S$3.10.
The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.46 per cent higher at 507.3 points on Thursday.

site_title: Europe: Tech surge propels Stoxx 600 to near one-week high
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6% on Friday, logging its first monthly gain since August, driven by a tech rally. The index rose 1% in November and is now pricing in an 80% chance of a 25 basis-point interest rate cut by the European Central Bank on December 12. Tech stocks gained 1.6%, while auto stocks fell and defence stocks rose. The European economy is seen struggling, with markets expecting a larger interest rate cut.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.46 per cent higher at 507.3 points on Thursday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 29)
summary: Singapore's owner-occupied residential property tax rates will increase annually starting Jan 1, 2025. A one-off rebate of up to 10% is available to owner-occupiers in 2025 to mitigate cost-of-living concerns. Singapore hotels experienced a decline in performance in October, following a high in September due to the Formula One night race. US companies are flocking to South-east Asia, particularly Vietnam and Indonesia, amid escalating tariff threats. IHH Healthcare's Mount Elizabeth Hospital renovation is ahead of schedule, with completion expected by Q3 2025.

site_title: Shiseido profit outlook squeezed by China downturn
summary: Shiseido, a Japanese cosmetics manufacturer, downgraded its profit outlook due to a downturn in sales to Chinese consumers. The company aims to lift its operating margin to 7% by 2026, despite initially targeting a 9% margin. Shiseido has had to rely on sales in Japan, boosted by foreign tourists taking advantage of a weak yen. The company plans to cut costs, focusing on Japan and excluding China, to achieve its new target. This move follows other luxury brands hit by slowing growth, increased competition, and weaker consumer confidence in China.

images.alt_text: Japan cosmetics giant Shiseido sees 2022 'turning point' in tourism sales

site_title: AI and sustainability: Tackling both, holistically
summary: Data centres are under pressure to be greener and smarter, but implementing realistic green policies and addressing AI demands may be challenging. Many facilities are decades old and lack the space and technical requirements to support AI workloads. A holistic approach is required, involving careful planning, recalibrating metrics, and collaboration between teams. Organizations should assess their AI and sustainability requirements in parallel, and consider training or engaging consultants to ensure compliance with evolving regulations. By tackling the impact of AI on green commitments, companies can pave the way for responsible AI development and sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: In supply chain management, companies can leverage GenAI's ability to analyse vast datasets, including location, price and performance metrics, to drive sustainable sourcing.
By aligning with global best practices and setting new benchmarks, the Republic is leading the international discourse on sustainable data centre development.

site_title: Taiwan lifts 2025 GDP forecast despite Trump tariff threats
summary: Taiwan has raised its forecast for economic growth in 2025 to 3.29% despite US President-elect Donald Trump's threats to disrupt trade with a 10% levy on Chinese goods. The country's economy has been driven by global demand for its high-tech products, with AI leaders turning to Taiwanese companies for chip fabrication and server production. The central bank is expected to keep interest rates steady in 2025 to manage financial stability, and Moody's Analytics warns of potential economic damage in Taiwan due to its heightened exposure to US and China trade tensions.

images.alt_text: The figures represent the fifth consecutive quarter of profit growth for the firm as it rides a wave of demand for generative AI – following the runaway popularity of products such as ChatGPT since it launched two years ago.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon Sugianto Kusuma eyes theme park, F1 race in US$16 billion project
summary: Indonesian billionaire Sugianto Kusuma is developing a US$16 billion project in North Jakarta, known as Pantai Indah Kapuk Dua, which includes a theme park, F1 race track, and a port. The project is a joint venture with Chinese and Singaporean partners and aims to promote tourism in Jakarta. Kusuma believes the project can become a major tourist destination, attracting foreign visitors who currently prefer Bali. The project's expansion plans include a global convention center and a five-star hotel, with a central business district and golf courses.

images.alt_text: Despite the sales ban, the Indonesian government still allows iPhone 16 to be carried into Indonesia if they are not being traded commercially.

site_title: One-off property tax rebate in 2025 for owner-occupiers to soften cost-of-living pains
summary: Singapore to offer one-off 20% rebate for HDB flat owners and 15% rebate for private residential property owners in 2025 to ease cost-of-living pressures. The rebate will be capped at S$1,000. Annual value bands for owner-occupied residential property tax rates will also be raised from Jan 1, 2025, with more than one million properties eligible for social support schemes. The measures aim to help households manage the cost of living, with rental prices still elevated compared to 2022 and 2021.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Ry-Anne Lim
Given the prevailing scarcity of housing in the rental market, the probability of a further substantial decline in rents is minimal.
More rental contracts were inked during Q3 with 23,422 transactions recorded, up 9.9 per cent from the year ago period.

site_title: WTO chief Okonjo-Iweala reinstated for second term as trade wars loom
summary: WTO chief Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala has been reappointed for a second term, coinciding with US President-elect Donald Trump's presidency. Okonjo-Iweala, a former Nigerian finance minister, has broad backing among WTO members and expressed eagerness to work with the incoming administration. Trade sources expect a challenging road ahead, characterized by trade wars, with Trump threatening tariffs on goods from Mexico, Canada, and China. Okonjo-Iweala plans to take a "constructive and creative" approach to addressing global trade issues.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: World Trade Organisation (WTO) Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala poses before an interview with Reuters at the WTO headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, April 12, 2021. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: HSBC pulling back from China credit card business after struggling to expand: sources
summary: HSBC is pulling back from its credit card business in China, eight years after its launch, due to struggling to expand and make the business profitable. The bank has stopped issuing new cards and is working towards winding down the service for most onshore customers. Only high-end clients may continue to receive credit cards. The decision underscores HSBC's challenges in growing its footprint in China amid a slowing economy and increased competition.

images.alt_text: Signage at a HSBC Holdings Plc bank branch in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, Oct. 25, 2024. HSBC is scheduled to release earnings results on Oct. 29. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: Europe: Tech stocks spark market rebound; inflation data looms
summary: European stocks rebounded 0.46% to 507.3 points on Thursday, led by tech stocks that rose nearly 1% after Bloomberg reported less severe US chip curbs. Defence stocks, including Airbus, also gained, while France's blue-chip index recovered 0.5% after sliding to August lows. Investors now focus on inflation reports, following strong US inflation data that may influence interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, October 18, 2024.   REUTERS/Staff
Trump trades, essentially punishing tariff-sensitive assets from European exporters to Mexico’s peso and driving investment towards US stocks and the US dollar, proved successful.

site_title: Americans celebrate Thanksgiving after bitter election
summary: US Americans celebrated Thanksgiving despite a bitter presidential election, with stormy weather and travel disruptions. A record 79.9 million people were expected to travel, and many families tried to avoid discussing politics. President Joe Biden spent his last Thanksgiving as president with family, while Donald Trump posted a message on social media criticizing the "Radical Left Lunatics." The holiday also featured football matches and parades, with many people focusing on family gatherings and feasts.

images.alt_text: Wired reported earlier that the US could come out with new export controls rules as soon as next Monday.
While Donald Trump and Elon Musk have claimed that US$2 trillion could potentially be saved, most experts believe this is not realistic without cuts to crucial services or benefits.
Trump trades, essentially punishing tariff-sensitive assets from European exporters to Mexico’s peso and driving investment towards US stocks and the US dollar, proved successful.
Meta's Mark Zuckerberg has been carefully trying to mend ties with Donald Trump.
US President Joe Biden speaks to reporters as he visits the Nantucket Fire Department in Nantucket, Massachusetts on Nov 28, 2024.

site_title: Renault goes on China hiring spree to bolster EV push at home
summary: Renault is expanding its presence in China to bolster its electric vehicle (EV) business, hiring 200 engineers in Shanghai to develop its sub-20,000 euros electric Twingo. The move aims to access new technology and learn how to make EVs faster. Renault plans to deploy the lessons learned in China in its home market, with CEO Luca de Meo aiming to make affordable EVs in France. The company's decision has been criticized internally, but it is betting on its electric 25,000 euros R5 city car to bolster sales in the near term.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Renault Clio E-Tech Hybrid car is seen at Brussels Motor Show, Belgium, January 9, 2020. REUTERS/Francois Lenoir/File Photo
Renault unwrapped the R4 E-Tech in Paris, a compact electric model expected to cost less than 35,000 euros, with a driving range of 400 kilometres.
Nissan plans to acquire around 195.5 million shares using its net cash position. The deal hands Renault additional funds for the development of electric vehicles.

FILE PHOTO: Renault Chief Executive Luca De Meo speaks during the French carmaker Renault's 2022 annual results presentation in Boulogne-Billancourt, near Paris, France, Feburary 16, 2023. REUTERS/Christian Hartmann/File Photo

site_title: Apollo sees US$50 trillion opportunity in energy transition
summary: Apollo Global Management sees a US$50 trillion investment opportunity in the energy transition over the next few decades. The firm's co-head of European credit, Leslie Mapondera, believes an "industrial renaissance" is emerging, with potential spending of US$1.8 trillion in Europe between 2025 and 2030. Apollo manages US$275 billion of investment-grade credit and has originated about US$100 billion in deals over the past four years, targeting 150-200 basis points of excess spread from large deals.

site_title: Thailand flooding kills nine, displaces thousands
summary: Flooding in southern Thailand has killed nine people and displaced over 13,000, with temporary shelters set up in schools and temples. The flooding, driven by heavy rains, has affected 553,921 households across eight provinces, prompting urgent assistance from agencies. The Thai government has deployed rescue teams and designated 50 million baht in flood relief funds. Climate change is exacerbating intense weather patterns, making destructive floods more likely, according to scientists.

images.alt_text: Palm oil production in Malaysia may slump as much as 10 per cent during the first 25 days of November from a month earlier due to rain.

The Bank of Thailand (BOT)‘s monetary policy committee voted five to two to reduce the one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 2.25 per cent, after the rate had been a decade-high of 2.5 per cent since September 2023.

site_title: Major Canadian media sue OpenAI in case potentially worth billions
summary: Canada's major news organizations, including The Globe and Mail and CBC, have sued OpenAI, accusing the AI chatbot company of using their articles without permission to train its ChatGPT model. The lawsuit seeks C$20,000 per article, potentially worth billions, and an injunction to stop OpenAI's "unauthorized misappropriation" of their work. OpenAI claims its chatbox is trained on publicly available data and collaborates with news publishers, but the media coalition says this is not enough to justify the use of their content without permission or compensation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: OpenAI and ChatGPT logos are seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: BOJ's Ueda says wage trends key to possible rate hikes: Nikkei
summary: Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda suggests the central bank will avoid rushing to interest rate hikes due to uncertainty surrounding US economic policy under President-elect Donald Trump. Ueda will closely monitor wage trends, particularly during the fiscal 2025 spring wage negotiation, before making a decision. The BOJ is set to review its policy at its Dec 18-19 meeting, with some analysts expecting a rate hike from the current 0.25%.

site_title: Multimillion-dollar hybrid dream machines bound for Singapore
summary: Multimillion-dollar hybrid hypercars are set to arrive in Singapore, boasting a combination of electric and petrol engines for exceptional speed. These high-end vehicles come with hefty price tags, reflecting their advanced technology and performance capabilities. The exact models and details about their arrival in Singapore are not specified in the article.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: Bank Negara Malaysia calls for fair insurance pricing as medical costs soar
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia has instructed insurance companies to reassess their repricing strategies to ensure fairer implementation for policyholders amid rising medical costs. The country's healthcare costs have increased substantially due to medical inflation and increased use of medical services. Insurers must manage premium increases carefully, considering their impact on policyholders, while offering viable alternatives to those affected by higher costs. The regulator aims to preserve continued access to medical and health insurance protection.

site_title: Australia bars everyone under 16 from social media
summary: Australia has implemented a nationwide ban on social media for children under 16, with the aim of safeguarding young people from potential online hazards. The law requires social media platforms to implement age verification measures, with corporations facing fines of up to A$49.5 million for "systemic" failures. The ban creates a new category of "age-restricted social media platforms" accessible only to those 16 and older, and does not require users to provide government identification for verification. The law takes effect after a 12-month implementation period, with the eSafety Commissioner overseeing its details.

images.alt_text: The recent flash rally in GameStop, when the stock rose by more than 70% in a day, before plummeting by over 50 per cent within a few days, illustrates the speculative dangers of social media chatter.

site_title: Paris clamps down on Airbnb to ease housing crunch
summary: Paris has introduced new regulations to combat a housing shortage by clamping down on short-term furnished rentals. The regulations, effective January 1, include fines of up to 100,000 euros for breaches, limiting primary residences to 90 days per year and requiring owners to declare properties on a national registry. The move aims to reduce the number of apartments being rented out illegally, estimated to be 25,000 in Paris, generating 1 billion euros in annual revenue. The regulations follow a decade-long push by Paris officials to tighten rules on short-term rentals.

images.alt_text: A taste of the high life with Airbnb Luxe
Airbnb's new luxe rentals include a US$1m Polynesian island

site_title: Core inflation in Japan’s capital accelerates in November
summary: Japan's core consumer price index in Tokyo accelerated to 2.2% in November, exceeding forecasts and staying above the Bank of Japan's 2% target, indicating broadening price pressure. The yen rose against the dollar, with market players bracing for a possible interest rate hike at the BOJ's next meeting in December. Another key index, excluding fresh food and fuel costs, rose 1.9% in November, driven by rising rent, utility bills, and food costs.

images.alt_text: Public opinion polls in Japan generally show support for more defence spending, although there’s far less support for tax increases to pay for it.

Pedestrians walk down the high-street shopping area of the Ginza district in central Tokyo on November 22, 2024. Japan's minority government was expected on November 22 to approve a 140-billion USD stimulus drive aimed at putting more money in consumers' pockets after the ruling party's worst election result in 15 years. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
In his new role that begins next year, Kanda will be tasked to navigate the ADB through fresh challenges such as helping Asia reduce poverty and mitigate risks from climate change.
Toyota’s domestic sales have fallen more than 20 per cent between January and October, while production fell 13 per cent.
The Japanese government will tap the additional revenues to fund part of a 13.9 trillion yen (S$123 billion) spending package aimed at cushioning the blow to households from rising living costs.
Manufacturers surveyed by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry expect seasonally adjusted output to fall 2.2 per cent in November and drop 0.5 per cent in December.

site_title: The perils in the search for the perfect GDP alternative
summary: A UK statistical agency has released alternative measures of national wealth, including gross inclusive income and net inclusive income, in an attempt to surpass the limitations of GDP. However, the results are "a bit of a mess," with some measures rising, falling, or staying the same. The agency acknowledges the difficulty in assigning financial values to non-market goods and services. Critics argue that ditching GDP would not necessarily lead to better national priorities, and that the task of weighing the values of good and bad in society is the role of democracy, not statistical agencies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk across London Bridge during the morning rush hour, with the City of London's financial district in the background, in London, Britain, April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: UK’s Starmer vows to slash net migration
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer vowed to slash net migration, citing a record high of 906,000 in 2023, as Labour party swept to power in July. The Office for National Statistics reported a 20% drop in net migration to 728,000 in the 12 months to June this year. Starmer accused the previous Conservative government of running "a one-nation experiment in open borders" and pledged to publish plans to cut migration numbers, aiming to take back control of Britain's borders.

images.alt_text: Dealmakers may be making a last push to secure fees before the end of the year.

epa11666753 Shoppers on Oxford Street in London Britain, 18 October 2024. UK retail sales have shown modest growth for September. Retails sales grew by 0.3% in September, a slowdown from the 1.0% increase recorded in August.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
The CBI wants the government to make occupational health tax-free, in a move it says will stop 34,000 people dropping out of the workforce.
