site_title: Hong Kong opens third airport runway with marginal gain in landing slots
summary: Hong Kong's third airport runway officially opened on November 28, but it will take at least another year for the airport to see a significant increase in flight capacity. The airport's expansion, valued at HK$141.5 billion, aims to boost Hong Kong's status as a regional hub, but its recovery is slow due to the pandemic's impact and competition from Singapore and Seoul. Aircraft movement is expected to grow only 4% next summer season, and Cathay Pacific Airways still needs time to ramp up its flights.

images.alt_text: Aircraft at Hong Kong International Airport in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, Nov. 1, 2022. Hong Kong International Airport opened a bridge connecting a terminal and satellite concourse on Tuesday, part of a wider HK$9 billion ($1.15 billion) upgrade even as a full recovery in air traffic remains far off. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg
Hong Kong's gross domestic product expanded 1.8 per cent in the three months ended September from the same period last year.

site_title:
Australia’s central bank overhaul revived 
in last minute talks
summary: Australia's central bank overhaul plans have been revived after last-minute talks between the Labor government and the minority left-wing Greens Party. The stalled legislation, which includes splitting the Reserve Bank of Australia's board, may move forward after the Greens agreed to drop their demand for the treasurer to immediately lower interest rates. The government is open to retaining the right to override policy decisions under Section 11, a power never used since the RBA's establishment in 1960. A deal with the Liberal-National opposition collapsed earlier, but ongoing talks with the Greens hold promise.

images.alt_text: Figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Thursday showed net employment rose 15,900 in October from September, when they jumped by a revised 61,300.
The Reserve Bank of Australia kept rates at a decade-high of 4.35 per cent, where they have been for the last year, and reiterated it was not ruling anything in or out on future policy.
The RBA is focusing on underlying inflation as government rebates are suppressing the headline figure.

site_title: New Zealand’s central bank to debate 25 or 50 basis points rate cut in February
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) will debate whether to cut interest rates by 25 or 50 basis points in February after a 50 basis point cut in November. Assistant governor Karen Silk stated that domestic inflation remains high, with non-tradeable inflation at 4.9%, and the central bank aims to sustainably bring core inflation back to its target mid-point. The RBNZ's rate projections do not favor a 100% weighting on either option, but policymakers will discuss the merits of both in February.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ has now lowered rates by 125 basis points in little more than three months, making it one of the most aggressive cutters among its western peers.
The RBNZ will publish its decision at 2 pm on Wednesday and governor Adrian Orr will hold a press conference an hour later.
The RBNZ’s downbeat view of the economy and concern over the impact of potential tariffs under Donald Trump’s administration spurred traders to bet on large rate cuts.
BNZ began easing monetary policy in August saying weak domestic demand gave it confidence that inflation was returning towards the middle of its 1 to 3 per cent target.

site_title: BlackRock has deal to buy private credit manager HPS: report
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, has a handshake deal to buy private credit manager HPS Investment Partners for approximately US$12 billion, a premium over HPS's post-IPO valuation of US$10 billion. The deal, expected to be announced after the US Thanksgiving holiday, aims to capitalize on investor demand for alternative assets. HPS manages over US$117 billion in assets, and the acquisition will expand BlackRock's presence in private credit. The final terms of the deal are yet to be confirmed.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 08: The BlackRock NYC headquarters is seen on August 08, 2024 in New York City.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
ETFs have steadily taken over vast parts of the securities business in part because they are easier to shift in and out of rapidly, making them a draw to individual investors.
BlackRock has been on an acquisition spree this year as it looks to become an all-in-one platform for investors by integrating public and private markets.
BlackRock is putting portions of about 300 first-lien loan positions into the deal, slated to be among the largest ever transfers of private credit into a so-called continuation fund.

site_title: Citadel, Pimco set to own stakes in Spirit Airlines post-bankruptcy
summary: Citadel Advisors and Pacific Investment Management Company (Pimco) are among the investment firms set to own stakes in Spirit Airlines after the budget carrier restructures its balance sheet in bankruptcy. The firms, along with Western Asset Management, own Spirit's 8% senior secured notes and are supporting the company's restructuring plan. The notes will be exchanged for equity once Spirit exits bankruptcy next year. Spirit will also raise $350 million through an equity rights offering. The company aims to exit Chapter 11 by early March with creditor support.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Spirit Airlines commercial airliners are shown at Las Vegas International Airport in Las Vegas, Nevada, U.S., February 8, 2024.  REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
Early-stage discussions between the air carriers involved working out terms that holders of Spirit’s roughly US$2.5 billion of debt would agree to.
Spirit is staring down a liquidity crisis after its earlier attempt to merge with JetBlue Airways was blocked on antitrust grounds.

site_title: China’s property slump may extend into 2025: Fitch Ratings
summary: China's property market is expected to continue struggling in 2025, with new home prices forecast to fall by 5% and new home sales declining by 10%, according to Fitch Ratings. Despite the government's recent stimulus efforts, the sector remains weak, and a turning point for the real estate market has not yet been reached. The uncertainty surrounding the sector's recovery is significant, with Fitch's managing director, Wang Ying, stating that the recent "warm-up" in the market may not be sustainable. This prolongs China's multi-year property crisis.

images.alt_text: Revenue from government land sales had fallen 24.6 per cent in the first nine months of the year.
Seasonal slowdown in construction activities amid colder weather throughout most of China is impacting steel demand.
China finance ministry will expand the eligibility for the 1 per cent deed tax to include apartments up to 140 square metres, up from the previous 90 square metres.

site_title: British insurer Direct Line rejects Aviva’s £3.3 billion takeover bid
summary: British insurer Direct Line rejected Aviva's £3.3 billion takeover bid, citing it as "substantially undervalued". The offer, which represented a nearly 60% premium to the stock's close, was made in November. Direct Line's board deemed the proposal "highly opportunistic" and declined further discussions. The decision comes after the company implemented aggressive price hikes and announced plans to cut 550 roles to mitigate rising claims costs. Direct Line shares jumped 36% on the news, while Aviva shares fell 2.7%.

images.alt_text: Aviva had a combined operating ratio in the first nine months of 96.8 per cent, compared with 96.3 per cent a year earlier.
FILE PHOTO: The Aviva logo on a window at the company's head office in the City of London, Britain, March 7, 2019. REUTERS/Simon Dawson/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: The Aviva logo on a window at the company's head office in the City of London, Britain, March 7, 2019. REUTERS/Simon Dawson/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: The Aviva logo on a window at the company's head office in the City of London, Britain, March 7, 2019. REUTERS/Simon Dawson/File Photo

site_title: Gold prices held steady amid growing tariff war fears
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $2,636.35 per ounce on Thursday, as investors assessed the potential impact of US President-elect Donald Trump's policies on the economy and trade. The US personal consumption expenditures price index rose 0.2% monthly and 2.3% annually, while the gross domestic product growth for the third quarter held steady at 2.8%. The possibility of higher tariffs under Trump's administration may limit the Federal Reserve's ability to implement interest rate cuts next year, fueling gold prices as a safe-haven investment.

images.alt_text: Gold is traditionally seen as a safe investment during economic and geopolitical uncertainty such as trade wars.

site_title: China’s EV boom threatens to push petrol demand off a cliff
summary: China's electric vehicle sales have reached a tipping point, accounting for over half of retail passenger vehicle sales in the first four months of the year, threatening to push petrol demand off a cliff. The country's oil demand from light vehicles is expected to fall from 3.5 million barrels a day to one million by 2040, with petrol consumption peaking before declining rapidly. The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts a 2.1% annual drop in petrol demand from 2023 to 2030, with some analysts forecasting a more rapid decline of 4-5% per year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A electric car charging station is pictured in a parking lot in Shanghai, China March 13, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song
Tesla plans to launch its full self-driving technology in China early next year, pending approval.
Sales of EVs – whether fully electric or plug-in hybrids – reached 1.72 million vehicles worldwide in October, Rho Motion data showed.

site_title: Judge denies Sean Combs bail for the third time: court order
summary: US federal judge Arun Subramanian denied Sean Combs' (Diddy) bail for the third time, citing concerns that the rapper and producer has contacted witnesses and used unauthorized communications platforms while incarcerated. Combs, 55, faces charges of sex trafficking and racketeering, alleging he sexually abused women and coerced them into drug-fueled sex parties using threats and violence. Combs has pleaded not guilty to all charges.

images.alt_text: Sean 'Diddy' Combs has been jailed at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn since his arrest.
Country singer Garth Brooks has dismissed the allegations, in which a former employee accuses Brooks of rape and repeated unwanted sexual advances, including exposing himself and groping.
Sean “Diddy” Combs was indicted last month on three criminal counts that allege he sexually abused women and coerced them into drug-fuelled sex parties using threats and violence.

site_title: Expensive climate policy is dead – and it could be an immense opportunity
summary: A recent climate summit has failed to deliver meaningful commitments, with most world leaders absent and promises of a $300 billion climate slush fund unlikely to materialize. Despite claims that green energy is becoming cheaper, fossil fuels have increased twice as much as green energy over the past decade. A more effective approach, according to climate economists, is to focus on investing in green energy research and development to drive down costs, making it possible for fossil fuels to become cheaper. This approach could help convince policymakers and drive global economic growth.

images.alt_text: The main problem is that wealthy countries want to cut emissions while poorer countries mainly want to eradicate poverty through growth that remains largely reliant on fossil fuels.
FILE PHOTO: A view of the turbines at Orsted's offshore wind farm near Nysted, Denmark, September 4, 2023. REUTERS/Tom Little/File Photo
The idea that there is only one correct policy – cutting carbon emissions to zero in a short timeframe – is absurd, and especially so when this sole policy is failing globally.
COP28 in Dubai, UAE, Dec 6, 2023. Despite 27 previous conferences with iterations of ominous speeches and bold promises, global emissions have inexorably increased.

site_title: Microsoft denies training AI models on user data
summary: Microsoft has denied claims that it uses customer data from its Microsoft 365 applications to train artificial intelligence (AI) models, saying the data is not used for this purpose. The company stated that the "connected experiences" feature, which requires users to opt-out, is used for features like co-authoring and cloud storage, not AI model training. Despite this, concerns about data usage remain on social media.

site_title: Hot stock: PEC rises 11.4% after talks of potential share deal
summary: PEC shares surged 11.4% to a record high of S$0.83 after a third party approached the company about a possible share deal. The counter rose as high as S$0.835 before ending the day at S$0.83, with 2.4 million shares changing hands. The company stated that no decision had been made and there was "no certainty or assurance" that a transaction would occur. This follows PEC's 56.6% year-to-date gain.

images.alt_text: Generic shots of SGX
Therese Soh

site_title: Bitcoin resumes advance, rekindles US$100,000 milestone optimism
summary: Bitcoin has surged around 40% since the US presidential election, driven by anticipation of a more favorable regulatory environment. The token is climbing back towards the $100,000 price level, with some analysts predicting it will break the milestone soon. This is despite a brief decline earlier this week caused by profit-taking among institutional investors. Experts attribute the recent price increase to the supportive stance of the new president and the market's desire to find a strong base of support before attempting to surpass the $100k level.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin tokens and a price chart are seen in this illustration picture taken November 21, 2024. REUTERS/Remo Casilli/Illustration

site_title: The evolving talent landscape
summary: CEOs' tenures have decreased by 20% since 2013, from 6 years to 4.8 years, as technological disruption and market changes require organisations to adapt and evolve. This shift demands a learning culture and investment in developing the right talent to navigate new business models. Companies must adopt a culture of continuous evolution to stay competitive, with the right leader significantly impacting long-term strategy, success, and operational outcomes.

images.alt_text: Walt Disney’s struggle to find a successor to Bob Iger as CEO is particularly tortured.

site_title: China keeps buying US soy in surprise move after Trump’s win
summary: China, the world's largest soybean importer, continues to buy US soybeans despite potential trade tensions. The Asian nation picked up at least eight cargoes last week and concluded two more this week, according to the US Department of Agriculture. The purchases are part of China's efforts to build national reserves, with US soybeans being stored for longer due to their low moisture content. Despite US President-elect Donald Trump's pledge to impose tariffs, China is expected to maintain its soybean purchases, as it seeks to diversify its supply sources and avoid a complete reliance on Brazilian soybeans.

images.alt_text: Used cooking oil the new black gold as it rides biofuel demand, limited supply
Oxford Economics expects international soybean prices to take a direct hit from the upcoming Trump presidency and ensuing trade war with China.
US soybean exports to China fell to about 26.4 million tonnes last year from 36.1 million in 2016 and 31.7 million in 2017, before the last trade war.

site_title: Uber faces FTC consumer protection probe over subscriptions
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is investigating Uber over its subscription service, Uber One, for potential violations of consumer protection laws. The probe focuses on enrollment and cancellation aspects of the service, which offers discounts on rides and delivery orders in exchange for an annual fee. Uber has confirmed receiving inquiries from the FTC and is cooperating with the agency's review. The investigation is ongoing, and the FTC may seek a settlement or monetary penalties, although enforcement actions are not always guaranteed.

images.alt_text: Founded in 2016, Pony AI develops and operates self-driving fleets in the US and China.
Uber has been investing into new areas across both its ride-hailing and delivery businesses in the US and internationally, where the company said it has seen stronger growth.

site_title: US Fed’s favoured inflation gauge picks up, backs cautious approach
summary: The US Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge, the core personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, increased 2.8% from October last year, supporting a cautious approach to lowering interest rates. The core PCE price gauge accelerated due to higher stock prices, while inflation-adjusted consumer spending edged up 0.1% after a 0.5% gain in September. The data backs recent comments from Fed officials, who prefer gradual interest rate cuts as long as the labor market remains healthy and the economy continues to grow.

images.alt_text: Officials’ estimates for the neutral rate have steadily climbed over the past year, but just how close rates may be to such a stance remains unclear.

By concentrating on the issues facing small, young businesses – as opposed to large, well-established corporations with a lot of lobbyists – the incoming administration could foster innovation and support business formation.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on optimism over rebound in real incomes and easing inflation; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.8% to 3,737.25, driven by a rebound in real incomes and easing inflation, according to preliminary estimates. The market's gainers outnumbered losers 249 to 245, with asset management group CapitaLand Investment leading the charge. Meanwhile, shares of engineering company PEC jumped over 11% after news of a possible share deal.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
Singapore stocks edge lower as tariff concerns weigh on investor sentiment; STI down 0.1%

site_title: UK car output drops for eighth straight month in October: data
summary: UK car production declined for the eighth consecutive month in October, with 77,484 new cars rolled off production lines, down 15.3% from last year. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) attributed the decline primarily to a decrease in exports. The UK's 2024 EV sales mandate, requiring 22% of new car sales to be electric vehicles, has led automakers to cut jobs in response to softening demand for EVs. The UK government has launched a consultation to review the targets amid industry warnings.

images.alt_text: Halifax said the average house in the third quarter of 2024 cost 6.55 times the mean annual full-time income, down from 6.62 in 2023 and a record high of 7.24 in mid-2022.

Thursday’s survey showed that optimism among consumer services businesses sank to its lowest since August 2022 at -55 in November, down from -19 in August, while among business and professional services sentiment fell to -29 from +9.
The CBI wants the government to make occupational health tax-free, in a move it says will stop 34,000 people dropping out of the workforce.

Three fifths of the UK workforce reported tight deadlines and two-fifths had to work at high speed, among the largest proportions in Europe, while only a third could choose the pace at which they worked, the report said

epa11666753 Shoppers on Oxford Street in London Britain, 18 October 2024. UK retail sales have shown modest growth for September. Retails sales grew by 0.3% in September, a slowdown from the 1.0% increase recorded in August.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
Britain is likely to miss the 2024 targets set by the ZEV mandate, a trade body warned last month.
Ford Photographer: Nic Antaya/Bloomberg
The Resolution Foundation said the ONS appeared to be underestimating growth in the number of people in work since 2019 by 930,000.

site_title: PEC says it has been approached by a third party over a possible share deal
summary: Engineering company PEC Ltd has been approached by a third party regarding a possible share deal, but no decision has been made and there is no certainty of a transaction occurring. The company's shares have gained 40.6% this year, with a significant increase in the past three months. PEC's disclosure may signal the entry of a new major investor, and the company advises shareholders and investors to exercise caution when dealing in its shares.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

PEC said that the increased focus on clean energy and sustainability are expected to impact Singapore’s traditional role as a refining and petrochemical hub with diminishing pipeline of projects in the near term, leading to intense competition.

site_title: US readies China chip curbs that stop short of earlier proposals
summary: The US is preparing to unveil new curbs on sales of semiconductor equipment and AI memory chips to China, escalating its crackdown on Beijing's tech ambitions. The measures, set to be announced as early as next week, would include some provisions around high-bandwidth memory chips essential to AI. The new rules would sanction Chinese companies, including Huawei suppliers, but stop short of stricter measures previously considered. American chip equipment makers have welcomed the partial win, while Japan and the Netherlands have resisted recent American pressure for tighter controls.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Flags of China and U.S. are displayed on a printed circuit board with semiconductor chips, in this illustration picture taken February 17, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
China has recently stepped up soybean purchases in Brazil, but it’s still picking up American cargoes for supplies that will be put in reserve.
Donald Trump said he would impose the tariffs until China stops the flow of illegal drugs, particularly fentanyl, into the United States.
Oxford Economics expects international soybean prices to take a direct hit from the upcoming Trump presidency and ensuing trade war with China.

site_title: First Sponsor to increase stake in Netherlands’ NSI for 18.9 million euros
summary: FIRST Sponsor is acquiring an additional 920,839 NSI shares for 18.9 million euros (S$26.6 million) to increase its stake to around 22% from 17.5%. The acquisition, funded by net proceeds from a rights issue, is seen as a strategic move to expand First Sponsor's long-term property holding business in the Dutch real estate market. The deal is estimated to result in an associate's share of profit amounting to 13.4 million euros.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
First Sponsor acquired the commercial component of a mixed-use development project in Sydney, Australia, for a consideration of A$24.7 million in September.
Artist's impression of First Sponsor's Star of East River project in Dongguan, China. The group had proposed a rights issue in August.
An artist's impression of First Sponsor's Star of East River project in China. Net proceeds from the rights issue will be used to fund the company's expansion plans.
Artist's impression of First Sponsor's Star of East River project in Dongguan, China. Pre-sales for the group’s China projects remained muted in the six months due to weak market sentiment.

site_title: SIM marks turning 60 with new S$60 million fund to benefit 10,000 learners
summary: The Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) is celebrating its 60th anniversary with the launch of a new S$60 million fund to benefit 10,000 learners over the next decade. The fund, which will start disbursements from 2025, is an increase from SIM's current annual disbursement of S$1 million. Chairperson Euleen Goh stated that SIM aims to "catalyse good" and "promote good" through its philanthropic efforts, as the institution turns over its profits back into society to provide accessible pathways for all.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue

Professor Wei Kwok Kee, SIM Provost for Global Education (left), Euleen Goh, SIM Board of Directors (center), and Singapore Ambassador to Indonesia Kwok Fook Seng at the MoU event in Jakarta on July 24, 2024.

site_title: US GDP grows at solid 2.8% pace, helped by consumer spending
summary: The US economy expanded at a 2.8% annualized pace in the third quarter, driven by a broad-based advance in consumer spending and steady business investment. Consumer spending advanced 3.5%, the most this year, while business investment in research and development was revised higher. The GDP report showcases the durability of an economic expansion despite lingering price pressures and high borrowing costs. The Federal Reserve has started reducing interest rates, and President-elect Donald Trump's economic agenda is expected to boost corporate profits, but some economists are concerned it may put upward pressure on inflation.

images.alt_text: Business investment in equipment has mostly held up despite tighter monetary policy from the Federal Reserve to combat inflation, supported by an artificial intelligence boom.

Job seekers register at a Disabled American Veterans (DAV) and RecruitMilitary LLC job fair in Detroit, Michigan, U.S, on Thursday, Oct. 31, 2019. The Department of Labor is scheduled to release initial jobless claims figures on November 7. Photographer: Anthony Lanzilote/Bloomberg via Getty Images
US united states housing Photographer: Rebecca Noble/Bloomberg
Inflation expectations over the coming year dropped to the lowest level since March 2020.

By concentrating on the issues facing small, young businesses – as opposed to large, well-established corporations with a lot of lobbyists – the incoming administration could foster innovation and support business formation.

site_title: Genting Singapore’s luck may turn in 2025
summary: Genting Singapore's casino license has been renewed for two years, starting February 6, 2025, after the Gambling Regulatory Authority deemed the company's tourism performance "unsatisfactory." The company's recent weak performance was attributed to reduced wagers and a lower "win rate" at its Resorts World Sentosa casino. Despite this, analysts expect Genting Singapore's luck to improve in 2025, driven by the addition of new attractions and hotel rooms, which could boost non-gaming revenue and attract more casino patrons. The company's shares have fallen 23.5% since the beginning of the year, but may recover as the RWS 2.0 expansion plan improves the IR's tourism performance.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Genting Singapore’s Resorts World Sentosa
The quarter-on-quarter decline in Genting Singapore’s performance was mainly attributable to lower VIP rolling volume and win rate, said the group.
Andrew MacDonald, former chief casino officer at Resorts World Sentosa, has stepped down effective Nov 1, 2024.

Resorts World Sentosa’s highly anticipated new waterfront lifestyle development is planned for a 2030 opening
and is envisioned to set a new benchmark for Singapore and the Sentosa, positioning both as an iconic, must-visit lifestyle hub for international and local visitors.
The shorter licence term comes after an evaluation panel appointed by the Ministry for Trade and Industry deemed RWS’ tourism performance from 2021 to 2023 as “unsatisfactory”.

site_title: UK services sector sentiment falls at fastest pace in two years, CBI says
summary: The UK's services sector sentiment has fallen at its fastest pace in two years, according to the Confederation of British Industry. Consumer services businesses reported the sharpest decline, with optimism dropping to -55 in November, down from -19 in August. Business and professional services sentiment also fell, from +9 to -29. The decline is partly attributed to tax rises in the finance minister's first budget, with large employers bearing the brunt of a £25 billion payroll tax increase.

images.alt_text: The CBI wants the government to make occupational health tax-free, in a move it says will stop 34,000 people dropping out of the workforce.

Three fifths of the UK workforce reported tight deadlines and two-fifths had to work at high speed, among the largest proportions in Europe, while only a third could choose the pace at which they worked, the report said

epa11666753 Shoppers on Oxford Street in London Britain, 18 October 2024. UK retail sales have shown modest growth for September. Retails sales grew by 0.3% in September, a slowdown from the 1.0% increase recorded in August.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

The retailers want the UK government to phase the introduction of the new lower earnings threshold for National Insurance, delay the introduction of packaging levies, and revisit and bring forward proposed changes to business rates.

site_title: Starbucks Red Cup giveaway gives coffee chain much needed jolt
summary: Starbucks has seen a 42% surge in daily customer visits following its Red Cup Day giveaway, surpassing last year's promotion and beating 2022 numbers. The company aims to reverse three straight quarters of same-store sales declines, with new CEO Brian Niccol pledging to simplify the menu, speed up service, and make cafes more welcoming. This boost comes after the removal of a non-dairy milk upcharge, providing a price cut to customers.

images.alt_text: starbucks Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust divests two warehouse properties in Japan for S$37.5 million
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has divested two warehouse properties in Japan for S$37.5 million, following its strategy of "selective divestments of assets no longer aligned with its strategy". The properties, Toki Centre and Aichi Miyoshi Centre, were sold for 4.25 billion Japanese yen, with prices 7.4% and 9.2% above their latest valuations. The divestment is expected to provide MLT with financial flexibility to pursue higher-growth opportunities, without impacting its net property income for FY2024 and FY2025.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Mapletree Yuyao in China's Zhejiang province. MLT’s portfolio achieved positive rental reversions across most markets, except in China.

site_title: Vietnam’s death-row property mogul seeks lifeline from Malaysian tycoon Vincent Tan and foreign investors
summary: Vietnamese real estate tycoon Truong My Lan, facing execution for embezzlement, may receive a lifeline from Malaysian tycoon Vincent Tan and foreign investors. Lan is willing to sell the Sterling Residence development, valued at 40 trillion dong, to raise funds to repay debts. Tan has agreed to purchase the asset, and Lan could retain a net 20 trillion dong to compensate defrauded bondholders and Saigon Commercial Bank. Lan's lawyers hope the deal could lead to a commutation of her death sentence, which prosecutors recommended be upheld due to the "unprecedented" losses caused by her crimes.

images.alt_text: Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan in a Ho Chi Minh City court on Thursday (Oct 17), when she was giving a life term following a related trial on money laundering charges.
Truong My Lan sit during her trial at the Ho Chi Minh City People's Court in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, 11 April 2024.
Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan is expected to appeal the verdict announced on Thursday.
Truong My Lan is the chairwoman of Van Thinh Phat (VTP) Group, one of Vietnam’s most influential real estate empires.

site_title: Musk to hold talks with Republicans on sweeping spending cuts
summary: Elon Musk, the incoming government efficiency chief, will meet with Republican lawmakers next week to discuss sweeping spending cuts. Musk's goal is to slash federal regulations and make major administrative changes, with estimates suggesting $2 trillion could be saved. However, experts believe this is unrealistic without cutting crucial services or benefits. The meeting will be led by House Speaker Mike Johnson and co-leader Vivek Ramaswamy, and will focus on regulatory rescissions, administrative reductions, and cost savings.

images.alt_text: It’s the latest tit-for-tat between the world’s two richest individuals, whose businesses compete in the commercial space industry.
XXXX

Elon Musk speaks with U.S. President-elect Donald Trump as they watch the launch of the sixth test flight of the SpaceX Starship rocket in Brownsville, Texas, U.S., November 19, 2024. Brandon Bell/Pool via REUTERS
Elon Musk has previously clashed with Australia’s centre-left Labor government over its social media policies and had called it “fascists” over its misinformation law.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop as budget battle sends French shares lower
summary: Europe's stocks dropped 0.2% as concerns over France's budget plan mounted. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index fell to 504.96 points, with financial stocks in France, particularly insurer Axa SA, suffering the biggest losses. Prime Minister Michel Barnier warned of a financial storm if the budget was rejected, while traders await interest rate cuts and US-EU trade talks. European stocks are also weighed down by tariff risks from the US, with the European Central Bank being cautious of cutting interest rates too far.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent lower at 44,722.06 on Wednesday.

site_title: Fifa launches 2022 World Cup legacy fund for initiatives with WHO, WTO and UNHCR
summary: FIFA has launched a $50 million legacy fund for social programs, partnering with the World Health Organization, World Trade Organization, and UNHCR to support initiatives on refugees, occupational health, education, and football development. The fund aims to help vulnerable people worldwide and is a significant step in fulfilling FIFA's promise to use 2022 World Cup proceeds for this purpose.

images.alt_text: “We are delighted to welcome Hisense, a global market-leading brand, as an official partner of the Fifa Club World Cup 2025,” Fifa president Gianni Infantino said.

site_title: US mortgage rates drop, easing pressure on potential homebuyers
summary: US mortgage rates have declined, easing pressure on potential homebuyers. The average 30-year fixed loan rate dropped to 6.81% from 6.84% last week, according to Freddie Mac. This marks a decrease from a two-month low of 6.08%. Despite higher rates, some buyers are forging ahead, with contracts to buy previously owned homes rising to a seven-month high in October. Declining yields on 10-year Treasuries are expected to continue putting downward pressure on mortgage rates, potentially benefiting the housing market.

site_title: Samsung gets first woman CEO outside founding family in 86 years
summary: Samsung Bioepis has appointed Kim Kyung-Ah, a 56-year-old doctor and neurotoxicology expert from Johns Hopkins University, as its first female CEO outside the founding family in 86 years. This milestone comes as part of Samsung's management reshuffle, and Kim will oversee product developments. Her appointment is seen as a step towards inspiring the next generation of female executives in South Korea, where women business leaders have long struggled to break into corporate boards and C-suites.

images.alt_text: The major reshuffle of Samsung's top rank comes as shares of the tech giant have steadily fallen since August on investor concerns that it keeps lagging its rivals in supplying high-end chips to Nvidia.
The appeal hearings, which wrap up on Monday, come as Lee Jae-yong faces growing questions about his ability to lead Samsung, as it grapples with slowing profits and falling stock prices.
Analysts expect the buyback to provide a catalyst for the stock, while some noted that it may also help the founding family tighten its grip.
Samsung logo is seen at the Paris Games Week (PGW), a trade fair for video games in Paris, France, October 27, 2024. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier

site_title: Standard Chartered mulls sale of wealth, retail operations in Africa
summary: Standard Chartered is considering the sale of its wealth and retail banking operations in Botswana, Uganda, and Zambia, as part of a broader restructuring to focus on affluent individual customers and international companies. The move aims to free up capital and rein in expenses, with the bank betting on strong economic growth in Asian markets. This shift follows a similar strategy by rival HSBC, as Standard Chartered seeks to optimize its business and improve profitability.

images.alt_text: StanChart CEO Bill Winters’ love-hate relationship with trade wars, conflict
The move is likely to speed up transactions at a time when foreigners are showing greater interest in India.
StanChart already has a relationship with Wise through its Hong Kong-based digital bank Mox, which was agreed earlier this year.

Standard Chartered's CEO of Singapore and Asean Patrick Lee (right) together with the bank's CEO for UAE, Middle East and Pakistan Rola Abu Manneh at the Investopia Global Singapore Conference on Oct 23, 2024.
StanChart is reviewing relationships with clients that have just one lending relationship with the bank in order to prioritise higher-returning customers.

site_title: Trump 2.0 and the Middle East
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's second term is expected to bring geostrategic challenges in the Middle East, where the US is now facing a weakened ability to assert its power. The region's balance of power has shifted with Russia's attack on Ukraine and China's growing involvement. Iran's nuclear ambitions and its proxies' capabilities pose a significant threat, but Trump's administration may be hesitant to use military force. Instead, they may push for a two-state solution and a deal with Iran, potentially normalizing relations with Saudi Arabia and Israel.

images.alt_text: A demonstrator in Israel calling for the release of hostages in Gaza. Various sources say Donald Trump wants to see the war in Gaza end and the hostages there freed before he assumes office in January.
Come January, we’ll find out if Trump’s fellow strongmen ask for permission from his White House as they make their moves in geopolitics.
Trump's campaign is proposing a second, much bigger hike in tariffs; lavish tax cuts; a labour-supply shock in the form of mass deportations; and attacks on the independence of the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Bridging ambitions and realities: the Johor-Singapore SEZ
summary: Malaysia and Singapore are set to unveil details of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) in December, aiming to create a seamless zone for goods, people, and businesses. The project builds on previous initiatives, including the Johor-Singapore Rapid Transit System and the Gemas-Johor Bahru Electrified Double Track. Despite challenges such as skilled labour shortages and border congestion, current leaders from both countries have vowed to deepen ties and tackle lingering issues. The JS-SEZ could transform regional integration and bolster growth, but businesses seek clarity, political will, and a focused commitment to overcoming key challenges.

images.alt_text: In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.
Anita Gabriel

site_title: US: Dow finishes lower on Wednesday, ending three-day streak of record highs
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.3% lower at 44,722.06 on Wednesday, snapping a three-day streak of record highs. The decline comes after inflation data showed an uptick, leading to a drop in stocks. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also fell, ending the week on a lower note. The sell-off follows a strong week, which saw the Dow and S&P 500 reach new records.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 22.6 points, or 0.05 per cent, at the open to 44,837.75.

site_title: Oil steadies in choppy trade ahead of Opec+ meeting, US holiday
summary: Oil prices steadied below US$69 and US$73 a barrel ahead of the Opec+ meeting, where production restart is expected to be delayed, potentially staving off a supply glut. The US Thanksgiving holiday and a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah also influenced the market. Inventories of petrol and diesel reached highs, while implied diesel demand plummeted, weighing on oil prices. The market remains uncertain due to geopolitical risks and the second presidency of Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: America’s top oil trade groups, meanwhile, said imposing the tariffs would be a mistake - exposing a rare moment of discord between the industry and Donald Trump.
Brent crude futures settled down 20 cents, or 0.27 per cent, to US$72.81 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Real estate worth 25 trillion yen puts Japan companies in spotlight
summary: Global hedge funds and private equity firms are targeting Japanese companies for their undervalued real estate, estimated to be worth 25 trillion yen (S$222 billion). This is due to an accounting quirk where Japanese companies record property value at book value, which may not reflect current market prices. Investors such as Elliott Investment Management and Goldman Sachs are focusing on companies in the railway, construction, and utility sectors, with potential unrealised gains ranging from 5% to twice the current market value. This trend is driving activist campaigns and mergers and acquisitions in Japan.

images.alt_text: Japan's services producer price index, which measures the price companies charge each other for services, rose 2.9 per cent in October from a year earlier, BOJ data showed, accelerating from a 2.8 per cent gain in September.
FILE PHOTO: Shoppers make their way at a shopping district in Tokyo, Japan March 19, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
The au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) slipped slightly to 49.0 in November from 49.2 in October.
Japan's core CPI, which excludes volatile fresh food prices, was down from 2.4 per cent in September and 2.8 per cent in August.

site_title: CICT’s Tony Tan on Singapore’s office and retail future
summary: CICT CEO Tony Tan attributes Singapore's thriving office market to its status as a major financial center and transportation hub, with a business-friendly environment. Despite the shift to remote work, Singapore offices are doing well due to factors such as limited supply, high demand, and government initiatives. Tan also discussed the outlook for Singapore's retail segment, stating that it will continue to evolve with the rise of e-commerce and changing consumer habits. The future of local Reits is expected to be shaped by these trends and the need for sustainable and adaptable investment strategies.

images.alt_text: Tony Tan, CEO, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust Management

site_title: Asia likely to benefit from cheaper Canadian, Mexican oil if Trump imposes tariffs
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is likely to impose 25% import tariffs on Canadian and Mexican oil, which could lead to cheaper oil prices in Asia. Producers in Canada and Mexico may reduce prices and divert supply to Asia, benefiting countries such as China and India. The tariffs could also affect US refiners, who may struggle to process heavy, high-sulphur crude. Analysts predict that Canadian and Mexican oil exports to Asia will increase, with China and India likely to benefit from the cheaper prices.

images.alt_text: WTI was little changed, settling below US$69 a barrel. Brent also steadied to settle below US$73 on Wednesday.

Smoke billows from the site of an Israeli airstrike on the Lebanese city of Baalbeck in the Bekaa valley on Sept 23, 2024. Israeli air strikes killed 274 people, including 21 children, in south Lebanon on Sept 23, the Lebanese health minister said, in by far the deadliest cross-border escalation since war erupted in Gaza on Oct 7.
America’s top oil trade groups, meanwhile, said imposing the tariffs would be a mistake - exposing a rare moment of discord between the industry and Donald Trump.

site_title: K-dining on a high
summary: K-dining has gained global recognition following the release of Netflix's "Culinary Class Wars," a reality cooking show that catapulted Korean cooking into the spotlight. The show has transformed the lives of featured chefs and their restaurants, now experiencing long waiting lists. This surge in popularity has redefined the Korean dining scene, with restaurants now drawing international attention. The show's success has also led to increased interest in Korean cuisine worldwide, solidifying its place in the global culinary landscape.

images.alt_text: Culinary Class Wars Cr. Sangwoo Kim/Netflix © 2024

site_title: Citi appoints ex-BlackRock portfolio manager Kate Moore as CIO
summary: Citigroup appoints former BlackRock portfolio manager Kate Moore as its chief investment officer for its wealth division, effective February 2025. She will oversee the bank's chief investment office, global investment committee, and sustainable investing team, leading the delivery of independent investment strategies for clients. Moore replaces interim CIO Steven Wieting, who will continue as chief investment strategist and economist.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Managers have been told that as many as 2,000 Citi employees could get promotions, with pay hikes limited to 15 per cent, in the next month.

site_title: US home-purchase applications rise to highest since February
summary: US home-purchase applications surged to 152.9, the highest level since February, with a 12.4% jump in the week ended Nov 22. This increase is attributed to a 6.86% contract rate on a 30-year, fixed mortgage, which dropped for the first time in nine weeks. Strong economic indicators and a greater selection of houses on the market also contributed to the surge. Despite this, mortgage rates remain about three-quarters of a percentage point higher than they were in mid-September.

images.alt_text: New home sales plunged 17.3 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 610,000 units last month, the lowest level since December 2022.

site_title: Lebanon ceasefire starts after Israel and Hezbollah reach deal
summary: A 60-day ceasefire between Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah began on November 27, following weeks of US-mediated talks. The agreement marks a first step toward ending a conflict that has killed thousands and displaced over a million people. US President Joe Biden hopes the truce calms the Middle East and paves the way for fresh peace initiatives in the Gaza Strip. The truce includes a 30km buffer zone along the Israel-Lebanon border, with UN peacekeepers and the Lebanese military to ensure no Hezbollah fighters return.

images.alt_text: Posters of hostages kidnapped during the Oct 7, 2023, attack by Hamas. Israel's response to the attack has weakened the ability of Iran to assert its position in the Middle East.

site_title: From White House to Mouse House, successions are a killer problem
summary: US President Joe Biden's botched succession planning has led to a second Trump presidency, illustrating the problem of succession failures in both human affairs and the corporate world. Companies like Disney, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, and GameStop have faced similar issues, with poor planning and expensive costs resulting from forced departures and unsuccessful grooming of successors. Experts suggest that better planning, including setting a hard limit on time in the top job and buffing up succession planning, can prevent botched successions.

images.alt_text: James Gorman will step down as executive chair of Morgan Stanley at the end of 2024 and become the chair of Disney in January.
“All of us have fought the battle, and we have to prepare for the new ground, to energise the organisation,” said Wee Ee Cheong, deputy chairman and chief executive of UOB.

Media mogul Rupert Murdoch (above) is trying to amend the family trust to give his son, Lachlan, control of his business after the former’s death. Three of Lachlan’s siblings are contesting this effort in court.

site_title: Mexico warns Trump's tariff would kill 400,000 US jobs
summary: Mexican Economy Minister Marcelo Ebrard warned that a 25% US tariff proposed by President-elect Donald Trump would lead to the loss of 400,000 jobs and slow US growth, particularly affecting the automotive sector. The proposed tariffs would also increase vehicle prices by thousands of dollars, primarily impacting top cross-border export firms like Ford, General Motors, and Stellantis. Mexico is considering retaliatory tariffs and has called for dialogue and cooperation to avoid a trade war, which could impact the North American free trade pact set to be revised in 2026.

images.alt_text: Mexican Minister of Economy Marcelo Ebrard speaks during a press conference next to Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum, after a meeting with business people from Mexico and the United States, in Mexico City, Mexico October 15, 2024 REUTERS/Raquel Cunha

US president-elect Donald Trump, who will be inaugurated on Jan 20, said on Monday (Nov 25) he plans to sign an executive order to impose a 25 per cent tariff on imports from Mexico and Canada, as well as an additional 10 per cent on top of existing tariffs on China.

site_title: US core capital goods orders unexpectedly fall in October
summary: US core capital goods orders unexpectedly fell 0.2% in October, marking a moderation in business spending on equipment this quarter. Non-defence capital goods orders excluding aircraft dropped 0.2% after a revised 0.3% increase in September, contrary to economists' forecasts of a 0.1% gain. Despite tighter monetary policy from the Federal Reserve, business investment in equipment has mostly held up due to an artificial intelligence boom, with shipments rebounding 0.2%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An inventory of manufacturing robots waiting to be shipped to customers from a FANUC American facility in Auburn Hills, Michigan, U.S.,  August 11, 2021. REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo
Job growth likely rebounded in November after abruptly slowing last month amid hurricanes and strikes.

site_title: US pending home sales rise for third straight month
summary: US pending home sales rose 5.4% from a year earlier, marking a third consecutive month of increases. The National Association of Realtors reported 77.4 pending sales contracts in October, the highest since March. Despite high mortgage rates and a growing inventory of properties, economists attribute the growth to a healthy job market and continuous job additions. The increase is seen as a sign of "homebuying momentum building" after nearly two years of suppressed sales, according to Lawrence Yun, the NAR's chief economist.

site_title: DBS inks MOU with Japan partner to help Japanese SMEs expand into Singapore, key Asian markets
summary: DBS has partnered with Japan Finance Corporation to help Japanese small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) expand into six key Asian markets, including Singapore. The partnership provides financing support through DBS' local expertise, digital cross-border payment capabilities, and trade financing, as well as access to professional services. Japanese SMEs can also receive standby letters of credit to secure long-term local currency-denominated funding. The partnership aims to enhance business connectivity between Japan and Asia, fostering a stronger presence for Japanese SMEs across the region.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The forum was held on the sidelines of the China International Import Expo held in Shanghai.

site_title: Sanofi boosts preparedness with S$800 million Singapore plant
summary: Sanofi has invested S$800 million in a new plant, Modulus, at Tuas Biomedical Park in Singapore, to manufacture vaccines and biopharmaceuticals. The facility, set to be operational in mid-2026, can produce up to four vaccines simultaneously and create 200 skilled jobs. Modulus can be reconfigured within days to adapt to different technological platforms, enabling the company to respond quickly to public health challenges. The addition ties in with Singapore's efforts to boost vaccine manufacturing capacity, following investments by other pharmaceutical companies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of French drugmaker Sanofi is seen a the Sanofi Genzyme Polyclonals in Lyon, France, September 30, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: The logo of French drugmaker Sanofi is seen a the Sanofi Genzyme Polyclonals in Lyon, France, September 30, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo
France seeks job guarantees from Sanofi over Doliprane painkiller production

site_title: UBS cuts four loan bankers in Singapore, Hong Kong as deal flow slows
summary: UBS Group has cut four loan syndication bankers in Asia due to slowing deal flow. The affected individuals, including two in Singapore and two in Hong Kong, left the bank on Monday. The move comes as elevated funding costs cast a pall over the market. The exits are part of the 2023 takeover of Credit Suisse, and the individuals who departed asked not to be identified. The cuts are seen as a response to reduced market activity and increased costs.

images.alt_text: UBS has vaulted back to the upper tier of Australian wealth managers after the merger of the two Swiss banks provided a pathway back into a market it had exited in 2015.

Young Jin Yee, co-head of UBS Global Wealth Management Asia Pacific and Country Head UBS Singapore, with Care Corner students and UBS staff volunteers embarking on the
60-metre long tapestry as part of the “Art for All” programme.
UBS last month posted results that topped expectations, driven by trading and progress on controlling costs after integrating Credit Suisse.
UBS is working to raise funds for a US$300 million debt swap for Barbados, which will focus on funding climate-resilient infrastructure.
UBS is pushing ahead with the integration of Credit Suisse.

site_title: US: Wall St subdued at open in run-up to key inflation data
summary: US stocks opened flat-to-slightly-lower on Wednesday as investors evaluated strong economic data and awaited a key inflation report that could influence the US Federal Reserve's policy stance. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 22.6 points, or 0.05%, to 44,837.75, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Investors are closely watching the inflation report, which could impact the Fed's interest rate decisions and the overall market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., November 22, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Nuclear attack unlikely despite Putin’s warnings, US intelligence says
summary: US intelligence suggests a nuclear attack by Russia is unlikely despite President Putin's threats, as Moscow doesn't see clear military benefits. The decision to allow Ukraine to fire American weapons deeper into Russia has not increased the risk of nuclear escalation. Instead, Russia is expected to expand sabotage campaigns against European targets to pressure the West. The assessment has remained unchanged despite President Biden's recent shift on US weapons policy.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin attends a signing ceremony following Russia-Kazakhstan talks in Astana, Kazakhstan November 27, 2024. REUTERS/Turar Kazangapov

site_title: US dollar drops as markets weigh Trump tariff vow, yen hits 5-week high
summary: The US dollar fell to a one-week low against its major peers, dropping 0.45% to 106.42 on the dollar index, amid concerns over President-elect Donald Trump's tariff pledges. Investors are cautious about Trump's plans for tariffs on Canada, Mexico, and China, and are rebalancing their portfolios before the end of the month. The yen rose to a 5-week high, while the euro gained 0.37% against the dollar. Other currencies, such as the Canadian, Mexican, and New Zealand dollars, also strengthened against the greenback.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. one hundred dollar notes are seen in this picture illustration taken in Seoul February 7, 2011. REUTERS/Lee Jae-Won/File Photo
The new twenty dollar bill is seen on the presses at the Bureau of Printing and Engraving in Washington, DC, August 21, 2003.  Photographer:  Dennis Brack/ Bloomberg News.
Investors have set aside expectations for another unusually large half-percentage-point rate cut by the Bank of Canada next month, after the central bank cut by that magnitude in October.

site_title: Air France-KLM shows 'interest' in Spanish airline stake
summary: Air France-KLM is considering taking a 20% stake in Spanish airline Air Europa, according to Globalia. This move comes after the Franco-Dutch group's talks with Air Europa on reinforcing commercial cooperation within the SkyTeam alliance. The estimated cost of the operation would be "well above" the $105 million IAG paid for a 20% stake in Air Europa in 2022. Air Europa operates 50 aircraft, transporting 11.7 million passengers in 2023 and posting 18% sales growth. The move is seen as a potential alternative to IAG's dropped bid due to regulatory concerns.

images.alt_text: IAG announced last August it had taken a 20 per cent stake in Air Europa after converting a loan.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 27)
summary: Singapore's financial institutions and companies have sufficient buffers to weather economic shocks, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) in its Financial Stability Review. Households have benefited from wage growth and increased financial assets, with low debt levels and strong credit quality. However, household debt is rising, but may be cushioned by wage and financial assets growth. The MAS also noted that Singapore Savings Bonds and Treasury Bills yields are unlikely to last, with a 10-year average return of 2.81% for the latest December tranche.

site_title: Adani says founder not named in US FCPA charge, shares rise
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani and his aides have not been charged under the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) despite a Department of Justice's indictment. The indictment mentions Gautam Adani, Sagar Adani, and Vneet Jaain only in counts related to securities fraud and wire fraud, which carry less severe penalties than bribery. Adani Green Energy shares rose following the clarification.

images.alt_text: The Nov 20 bombshell indictment in New York accused billionaire industrialist founder Gautam Adani and multiple subordinates of deliberately misleading international investors as part of the bribery scheme.
Electric power transmission pylon miniatures and Adani Green Energy logo are seen in this illustration taken, December 9, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
The majority owners of Adani Wilmar currently own a combined 86.8 per cent in Adani Wilmar, far above the maximum permissible 75 per cent.
Adani Group’s 10 listed stocks led by Adani Enterprises lost US$27.9 billion in market value over two sessions last week after the US charges.

Federal prosecutors in New York on Wednesday announced that Gautam Adani (pictured), the billionaire founder of the Adani Group, and seven other individuals had been indicted on charges of paying about US$265 million in bribes to Indian government officials to obtain contracts expected to yield US$2 billion of profit over 20 years.

site_title: SMEs can boost digital capabilities with free online programme held by Asean Foundation and Huawei
summary: The Asean Foundation and Huawei are launching a free online programme, "Empowering Digital Skills of Asean SMEs" (EDS-Asean), to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in 10 Asean countries enhance their digital capabilities. The virtual programme, running from March to May 2025, aims to equip SMEs with digital tools and strategies to optimize business operations, resulting in cost savings and increased competitiveness. 100 SMEs will be selected to participate in the initiative.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

Tan Su Shan, deputy chief executive officer and group head of institutional banking at DBS (left) and Kenzo Yoneda, senior managing director and general manager of Japan Financial Corporation's SME unit.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims decline further
summary: US jobless claims fell 2,000 to 213,000 for the week ended Nov 23, a seasonally adjusted drop from near 1½ year high in October. Economists forecast 216,000 claims, and the decline suggests low layoffs and employment rebound in November. However, continuing claims, a proxy for hiring, increased to 1.907 million, indicating many laid-off workers struggle to find new jobs. The unemployment rate, at 4.1%, is likely unchanged or rising this month, potentially keeping interest rates steady in December.

images.alt_text: Officials’ estimates for the neutral rate have steadily climbed over the past year, but just how close rates may be to such a stance remains unclear.

site_title: ECB rate stimulus no magic wand for structural faults
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) board member Isabel Schnabel expressed concerns that cutting interest rates to stimulate growth would not resolve the economy's deep structural faults. Schnabel urged caution, stating that gradual rate cuts are necessary and moving into accommodative territory would be premature. She also rejected calls for faster rate cuts and stimulus due to falling inflation, citing balanced risks and no significant risk of undershooting the target. Schnabel believes the ECB should maintain a neutral interest rate level to avoid squandering valuable policy space for future economic shocks.

images.alt_text: Vice-President of the European Central Bank (ECB) Luis de Guindos attends a press conference following ECB meeting in Brdo Castle, some 30 Km (18 miles) from Slovenia's capital Ljubljana on October 17, 2024. The European Central Bank cut interest rates again on October 17, 2024 upping the tempo at which it is lowering borrowing costs as inflation in the eurozone cools faster than expected. (Photo by Jure Makovec / AFP)

site_title: Poised to claim victory in Jakarta governor race, Pramono vows swift action on coastal sinking
summary: Pramono Anung, a former Cabinet secretary, is poised to become Jakarta's next governor, securing about 50% of the valid votes in the election. He has pledged to tackle the city's urgent challenges, including coastal sinking, within his 100-day action plan. The election, which marked a crucial stepping stone for politicians, holds historic significance as it may be the city's final gubernatorial race as Indonesia's capital. Anung's victory is seen as a significant win for the opposition Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle, and a potential challenge to President Prabowo Subianto's administration.

images.alt_text: Jakarta gubernatorial candidate Pramono Anung (2R) and deputy gubernatorial candidate Rano Karno (2L) speak to media after attending the drawing of ballot numbers for Jakarta gubernatorial and deputy gubernatorial candidates at the General Elections Commission (KPU) Jakarta provincial office in Jakarta on September 23, 2024. (Photo by ADITYA AJI / AFP)

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, November 27, 2024
summary: Asian markets experienced mixed trading on Wednesday, with traders closely watching fresh trade tensions. The Singapore Post rose 4.5% following reports of a potential Australian business sale. Meanwhile, the Euro's decline left global investors on edge, and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand announced another significant interest rate cut, its second half-point move.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks edge lower as tariff concerns weigh on investor sentiment; STI down 0.1%
Asian markets' stuttering performance on Wednesday followed a broadly negative day on Tuesday and came despite another record-breaking lead from Wall Street.
SingPost’s Australian business logged a revenue of S$574.8 million for the half year ending Sep 30, up from S$398.8 million a year earlier.
Rapid euro-dollar shifts affect multinationals’ earnings and impact growth and inflation for countries importing commodities and exporting dollar-priced goods.
The RBNZ has now lowered rates by 125 basis points in little more than three months, making it one of the most aggressive cutters among its western peers.

site_title: Hillhouse’s EZA Hill buys US$148 million Jakarta logistics portfolio from ESR fund
summary: EZA Hill Property Management, backed by Hillhouse Investment, has acquired a US$148 million logistics portfolio in Indonesia from ESR Group's LILV Portfolio. The three logistics assets, totaling 137,000 square meters, are located in Greater Jakarta and will be used to grow the portfolio. The deal marks EZA Hill's maiden acquisition in Indonesia and represents a significant milestone in its expansion into South-east Asia. The assets have strong demand from factories, e-commerce, and last-mile delivery tenants, with potential for further growth.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
A two-storey warehouse in Cileungsi that is one of three logistics assets acquired by EZA Hill.
Midea is looking to raise as much as US$3.5 billion in the Hong Kong share sale, sources say.

site_title: Singapore banks, insurers in ‘good position’ to withstand severe macrofinancial shock: MAS
summary: Singapore's banks and insurers are in a "good position" to withstand severe macrofinancial shocks, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The banking sector maintained or improved its performance across financial vulnerability indicators, with low liquidity and maturity risks. Insurers also showed resilience in a liquidity stress-simulation test, with most funds having sufficient liquid assets to meet redemption needs. However, MAS warns that sustained high interest rates, slower global economic growth, and escalating trade tensions could raise credit costs and dampen lending volumes, posing a risk to banks' profitability and capital positions.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The debt maturity profiles of Singapore-listed companies are stable, says MAS in its report.
Most households would be able to weather higher mortgage rates, even at higher interest rates and an income loss, says the Monetary Authority of Singapore.
Most corporates have low debt levels and overall bank credit quality is strong, says MAS in its Financial Stability Review report.
Broadly conducive economic conditions and the upswing in the tech cycle should support Singapore's growth, MAS says.

site_title: Apple misses out on big 2024 smartphone market rebound: study
summary: The global smartphone market rebounded 6.2% in 2024, with an estimated 1.24 billion units shipped, but Apple's growth was minimal, edging just 0.4% higher. Android-based rivals, particularly Chinese brands, outperformed Apple in regions with lower smartphone penetration. The market's uneven recovery is attributed to pent-up demand and the lack of significant impact from artificial intelligence enhancements on consumer demand. Apple remains the profit leader, but its market share is expected to grow in 2025.

images.alt_text: People check Huawei's new Mate 70 mobile phone at a shop at the Wangfujing shopping area in Beijing, China, Nov 26, 2024.
The Mate 70 is set to be unveiled at a company launch event on Tuesday afternoon at Huawei's Shenzhen headquarters.
Despite the sales ban, the Indonesian government still allows iPhone 16 to be carried into Indonesia if they are not being traded commercially.

site_title: Volkswagen to sell operations in China's Xinjiang
summary: Volkswagen will sell its factory in China's Xinjiang region, including its factory in Urumqi and a test track in Turpan, to a Chinese company due to economic reasons. The move comes as the German car giant has lost ground in China, its most important market, and faces pressure from the government and human rights campaigners over allegations of forced labor and human rights abuses in the region. Volkswagen has previously faced scrutiny over its factory in Xinjiang, and its decision to sell its operations is seen as a bow to public sentiment.

images.alt_text: Employees carry out quality control tests as strip lights illuminate Volkswagen Phaeton automobiles at the Volkswagen AG factory in Dresden, Germany, on Thursday, April 9, 2015. German industrial production was bolstered by investment-goods output in February, highlighting improved confidence in the recovery in Europe's largest economy. site_title: 😼 Cliques and bullies: How to get help if you’re being targeted at your workplace
summary: Workplace bullying, harassment, and abuse can be distinguished by intent and actions, with overlaps across the three forms. Common examples of bullying include ostracization, verbal abuse, and assigning difficult tasks to junior employees. Victims often feel disempowered and disheartened. Seeking help from the human resources (HR) department is the first step, as they have grievance-handling procedures and are trained to investigate and protect victims. For severe cases, external organizations like the Tripartite Alliance for Fair and Progressive Employment Practices (Tafep) and the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) can provide further assistance.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
BT

Vietnamese-Australian singer Hanni of the girl's group 'NewJeans' testified that she overheard a manager of another idol group linked to her parent agency instructing members of another girl group to spurn her.

site_title: Thai Airways plans 44 billion baht share sales to exit debt plan
summary: Thai Airways plans to raise up to 44 billion baht (S$1.7 billion) from a share rights offering to exit its debt-restructuring plan, aiming to emerge in 2025. The airline will issue 9.8 billion new shares at 4.48 baht, and creditors will convert 53 billion baht debt into shares. The move is part of the carrier's turnaround since the post-pandemic travel boom, with a new fleet of Boeing and Airbus jets and a strong business outlook.

images.alt_text: Thai Airways has fewer than 10 Rolls-powered 787s but one is currently grounded without engines, according to Chai Eamsiri.
After a years-long bad patch and emerging from a debt rehabilitation exercise, Thai Air is set to be relisted on the stock exchange next year and tap the country's booming tourism
The carrier will offer about 6.81 billion new shares to creditors under a debt-to-equity swap, according to its regulatory filing on Monday.

site_title: OpenAI allows employees to sell US$1.5 billion stock to SoftBank: sources
summary: OpenAI is allowing employees to sell approximately $1.5 billion worth of shares to SoftBank's Vision Fund 2, with stock prices matching the previous round, in a new funding round. Employees have until December 24 to participate. SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son has been seeking a larger stake in the startup after investing $500 million in a $6.6 billion funding round in October, valuing OpenAI at $157 billion.

images.alt_text: Nvidia’s chips have become a prized commodity for the world’s biggest tech companies, which use the components to develop and run AI models.
OpenAI has spoken about the search product with website and app developers such as Conde Nast, Redfin, Eventbrite and Priceline, the report said.
The move comes as OpenAI is stepping up efforts to highlight the positive role in education of its ChatGPT chatbot.

site_title: Current higher yields on Singapore Savings Bonds and Treasury bills unlikely to last: analysts
summary: Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) and Treasury bills have seen a rise in interest rates, with the latest SSB tranche offering a 2.66% first-year interest rate and a 10-year average return of 2.81%. Analysts predict that these yields are unlikely to last, citing economic growth and inflation expectations. Despite this, some experts believe that investors may shift their focus to Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) due to lower financing costs and a resilient economy.

images.alt_text: Generic photos at Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) taken on Dec 1, 2022. To go with financial stories such as inflation, strengthening of Sing dollar, rise in interest rates
Chong Xin Wei
Benjamin Cher

site_title: Sukanto Tanoto’s eldest son buys Fernhill Road bungalow for S$21 million
summary: Andre Tanoto, the eldest son of Indonesian tycoon Sukanto Tanoto, has purchased a Fernhill Road bungalow in Singapore for S$21 million, working out to S$2,549 per square foot. The 8,238 sq ft freehold land area is outside a Good Class Bungalow (GCB) Area, allowing for a new bungalow to be built on the site. Market observers expect Tanoto to develop the site into a new bungalow for his own occupation, given the zone's designation for mixed-landed housing.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
The conservation house in Nassim Road has an expansion garden in front.
The Dalvey Road house was completed recently.

site_title: Apollo backs luxury Florida condo project on Millionaire’s Mile
summary: Apollo Global Management has financed a $307 million construction loan for the luxury condo project Rosewood Residences Hillsboro Beach in South Florida. The project, located on Millionaire's Mile, will feature 92 residences and 11 private boat slips. This is the latest in a series of financing deals secured by Related Group, which has been lining up financing for various projects in the area.

site_title: From craft beer to cask: RedDot BrewHouse expands repertoire to spirits
summary: RedDot BrewHouse, a Singapore-based craft brewery, has expanded its operations to include a distillery, offering two brands of 'Made in Singapore' whisky, gin, and rum. The distillery, which uses stainless steel equipment from China, occupies 3,000 sq ft and features over 100 barrels from the US and Europe. The company's spirits will be marketed under Island Spirits and Hidden Hills brands, with Island Spirits focusing on innovative flavors and Hidden Hills targeting traditional spirits. RedDot aims to stock its liquors in major Singaporean supermarket chains by March 2025 and in its own retail shopfront by then.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Crystalla Huang, Brewer, RedDot Brewhouse.
Brewers generally require about 200 grams of malted grain to brew a litre of beer.

site_title: Nokia gets new telecom contract from Deutsche Telekom, replacing Huawei
summary: Nokia has secured a new contract with Deutsche Telekom to roll out a mobile network using Open Radio Access Network (Oran) technology in over 3,000 sites in Germany. The deal marks Nokia's return as a supplier to Europe's largest network, replacing Huawei equipment in the process. Commercial deployment began in the Neubrandenburg area of Northern Germany, and the contract includes Fujitsu. The Oran-compliant technology promises deep cost cuts by using cloud-based software and equipment from multiple suppliers.

site_title: Euro’s bruising leaves global investors on edge
summary: The euro has slumped by around 3.8% against the US dollar in November, teetering towards the key US$1 mark, due to US President-elect Donald Trump's proposed trade tariffs, eurozone economic weakness, and the escalating Russia/Ukraine conflict. Global investors are divided on the euro's future, with some predicting it could drop further and others expecting it to rise. The euro-dollar rate is highly sensitive to market movements, with rapid shifts affecting multinationals' earnings and growth, and inflation for countries importing commodities and exporting dollar-priced goods.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. one hundred dollar notes are seen in this picture illustration taken in Seoul February 7, 2011. REUTERS/Lee Jae-Won/File Photo
The new twenty dollar bill is seen on the presses at the Bureau of Printing and Engraving in Washington, DC, August 21, 2003.  Photographer:  Dennis Brack/ Bloomberg News.
The RBNZ’s downbeat view of the economy and concern over the impact of potential tariffs under Donald Trump’s administration spurred traders to bet on large rate cuts.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices rise in Oct, ending five-month decline
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices rose 0.6% in October, ending a five-month decline, as interest rate cuts and relaxed mortgage rules boost demand. Despite a 6.8% decline this year, prices have dropped nearly 30% from their 2021 peak. Experts predict a 3% rise in home prices in the fourth quarter, with sales volumes becoming more active after rate cuts and supportive policies.

images.alt_text: hong kong property housing Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg
Companies seeking to list in Hong Kong used to regularly solicit backing from local property tycoons, revered as savvy investors in a city whose wealth was built on real estate.
The state-owned China Mobiler’s Hong Kong unit made an offer in recent weeks for Cheung Kei Center (right), which has been on the market since 2023.
The average living space per person is 64.6 square feet – less than half the size of a New York City parking space.
The city only sold one-third of land plots in public tenders in the first 11 months, a record for failed bids in Hong Kong.
Properties in the luxury Beachfront neighborhood in Repulse Bay, Hong Kong.
