site_title: Chinese driverless-tech firm Pony AI said to raise US$260 million in US IPO
summary: Pony AI, a Chinese driverless-tech firm, raised US$260 million in its US IPO, pricing its American depositary shares at US$13 each. The company, founded in Silicon Valley in 2016, develops self-driving fleets in the US and China, with permits for fully driverless taxi services in major Chinese cities. The IPO was led by Goldman Sachs Group, Bank of America, and Deutsche Bank, and will have an implied market value of US$4.5 billion. The move signals strong investor interest in autonomous-driving technology and Chinese listings in New York.

images.alt_text: Founded in 2016, Pony AI develops and operates self-driving fleets in the US and China.
Founded in Silicon Valley in 2016, Pony.ai develops and operates self-driving fleets in the US and China.

site_title: HSBC loses court challenge against 31.7 million euro EU cartel fine
summary: HSBC lost its court challenge against a 31.7 million euro EU cartel fine, with the General Court upholding the revised fine of 31,739,000 euros. The EU regulators found HSBC, JPMorgan Chase, and Credit Agricole colluded to rig benchmark Euribor rates in 2007. The General Court rejected all of HSBC's arguments, and the bank can now appeal to the Court of Justice of the European Union. This fine is part of a larger trend of EU regulators fining banks billions of euros for manipulating benchmark interest rates and the foreign exchange market.

images.alt_text: Bank of America dropped down to category two from three previously.
FILE PHOTO: A view shows the entrance to a HSBC Bank branch in New York August 1, 2011.  REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton/File Photo
HSBC’s carbon-desk plans were relatively short-lived.
The relaunch of Premier joins similar rollouts in Hong Kong and Singapore, with HSBC eventually planning to offer the new services worldwide.
HSBC has reduced its headcount by more than 100,000 over the past 16 years as a series of CEOs tried to streamline the bank’s sprawling global operations.

site_title: German consumer confidence set to worsen at year-end
summary: German consumer confidence has fallen sharply in the latest poll, slipping 4.9 points to minus 23.3 points, a level last seen in late 2023. The decline is attributed to growing uncertainty in Europe's struggling economy and concerns about employment. The poll, conducted from late October to November 11, also showed a significant decline in consumers' income expectations and a slight fall in their likelihood to make purchases. This marks the fourth consecutive month of pessimism in the German economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk on a shopping street in the southern German town of Konstanz January 17, 2015.REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: People walk on a shopping street in the southern German town of Konstanz January 17, 2015.REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Leaked BYD letter signals China EV price war is set to intensify
summary: BYD has asked suppliers to accept 10% price cuts in January, signaling the intensification of the Chinese electric vehicle (EV) price war. The move comes as the company aims to weather further discounts in the coming year. BYD has so far remained unscathed, with record revenue and income, and has become China's best-selling car brand, selling around 3.2 million plug-in hybrid and EVs this year. The company is on track to sell at least four million units by the end of the year, despite a brutal price war in the world's biggest auto market.

images.alt_text: BYD’s rollout of the Shark 6 hybrid is a potential turning point.
BYD does not sell passenger vehicles in the US but that does not seem to be holding the company back much.
BYD is on track to meet its revised annual sales target of four million vehicles.

site_title: HP, Dell’s weak forecasts spark share sell-off, doubts over PC market recovery
summary: Dell and HP shares fell after the companies forecast quarterly revenue below estimates, sparking doubts over a PC market recovery driven by artificial intelligence-enabled PCs. Dell dropped 11% and HP fell 5%, with Dell's market value set to decline by $11 billion. The companies cited a weak traditional PC demand and slower-than-expected upgrade cycle due to Windows 10's end-of-life. However, Dell's AI server business showed strong revenue growth, and some analysts raised their price targets for both companies.

images.alt_text: PC makers had hoped that new machines touted as better for artificial intelligence workloads would spur demand.
Dell is best known for its computer business but the company has enjoyed a renaissance of investor interest due to its high-powered servers for AI workloads.

site_title: Household debt on the rise but may be cushioned by wage, financial assets growth: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reported that despite rising household debt, most households are likely to weather higher mortgage rates due to growing wages and financial assets. Household financial assets grew 8% on the year, outpacing debt growth, and outstanding home loans rose 1.6% on the year. Stress tests showed that most borrowers could handle mortgage rates of 5.5% with a 10% income loss. The MAS expects risks to the household sector to remain contained due to strong financial buffers.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Most corporates have low debt levels and overall bank credit quality is strong, says MAS in its Financial Stability Review report.
Condo resale volumes are 29.1 per cent higher year on year.
Housing affordability can improve with new homes sold on 50-year leasehold land.

site_title: Vietnam mogul told to refund missing billions to save her life
summary: Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan has been told by prosecutors she must repay an estimated $11 billion to avoid execution by lethal injection. Lan was convicted of embezzling $12.3 billion from Saigon Commercial Bank and bribing officials. If she can return three-quarters of the embezzled assets, her death sentence may be reduced. Lan's lawyer believes she can meet the payback requirement and has secured a potential $400 million loan from overseas investors to help her clear her debt.

images.alt_text: Truong My Lan was also sentenced to life in prison in October after she was convicted on additional charges in a second trial
Vietnam’s bond market came to a virtual standstill in late 2022, following the arrest of real estate tycoon Truong My Lan, who misappropriated about 30 million dong through bond issuance.

Property developer Truong My Lan was found guilty in April of swindling cash from the Saigon Commercial Bank - which prosecutors said she controlled - in one of the biggest corruption cases in history, and sentenced to death.

site_title: Foxconn says global manufacturing footprint to shield it from Trump’s tariffs
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, expects to be less impacted by US President-elect Donald Trump's tariffs due to its diversified global manufacturing footprint. The company has invested in the US, Mexico, and Vietnam, and its business model is based on contract manufacturing, which would make it less susceptible to tariffs. Foxconn's chairman, Young Liu, stated that clients may shift production locations, but the company's global presence would shield it from the impact.

images.alt_text: Veteran diplomat Ted Osius believes the best way for the US to compete for influence in Asean is to lengthen the economic leg of the relationship.
America’s top oil trade groups, meanwhile, said imposing the tariffs would be a mistake - exposing a rare moment of discord between the industry and Donald Trump.
Donald Trump said he would impose the tariffs until China stops the flow of illegal drugs, particularly fentanyl, into the United States.
Real estate owners appear to be celebrating the return of one of their own, a businessman whose desire for a flourishing economy would–they expect–outweigh his less productive instincts.

Many economists have warned that tariffs would hurt growth and push up inflation, since they are primarily paid by importers bringing the goods into the US, who often pass those costs on to consumers.

site_title: Foreign smartphone sales in China drop 44.25% y/y in Oct, data shows
summary: Foreign smartphone sales in China dropped 44.25% year-over-year in October, with 6.22 million units sold, according to data from the China Academy of Information and Communications Technology. This decline was largely attributed to Apple's performance, with the company's iPhone 16 models released in September but not yet available with the AI feature. Overall, China's phone sales increased 1.8% to 29.67 million units in October.

site_title: Gold prices barely move ahead of US inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained largely unchanged on Wednesday, awaiting US inflation data for a possible Federal Reserve rate cut next month. Spot gold was flat at US$2,630.59 per ounce, with investors also monitoring initial jobless claims and GDP figures. The US Federal Reserve is divided on further rate cuts, with a 63.2% chance of a 25-basis-point rate cut in December. Meanwhile, a US-France brokered ceasefire between Israel and Iran-backed group Hezbollah was announced, easing geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Gold is traditionally seen as a safe investment during times of economic and geopolitical uncertainty such as conventional or trade wars.

site_title: CrowdStrike raises annual forecast on steady cybersecurity demand
summary: CrowdStrike raised its annual revenue and profit forecasts, beating third-quarter revenue expectations, driven by growing demand for cybersecurity services amid rising online threats. Several major companies, including AT&T, Ticketmaster, and UnitedHealth Group, have been targeted by online hacking attempts this year. The company attributes its success to its comprehensive cybersecurity services, betting on the increasing investment in cybersecurity solutions to combat online hacking and digital fraud.

images.alt_text: Delta, which has purchased CrowdStrike products since 2022, said the outage forced it to cancel 7,000 flights, affecting 1.3 million passengers over five days.
CrowdStrike expects annual revenue to be between US$3.89 billion and US$3.90 billion, compared with its prior expectations of US$3.98 billion to US$4.01 billion.

The conference marks the first big step by Microsoft to address the issues that affected nearly 8.5 million Windows devices on Jul 19, disrupting operations across industries ranging from major airlines to banks and healthcare.
Last month, a software update from cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike triggered a global tech outage that caused massive disruptions to businesses with Microsoft Windows-based computers.

site_title: Couche-Tard not giving up on bid to acquire 7-Eleven’s owner
summary: Alimentation Couche-Tard remains committed to acquiring Seven & i Holdings, the parent company of 7-Eleven stores, despite a new management buyout proposal valued at around $79 billion. Couche-Tard's CEO Alex Miller stated that the company will be "persistent" in its approach, but has less than $10 billion of balance sheet capacity for more acquisitions. The Seven & i deal is still uncertain, with Bloomberg Intelligence's analyst saying it's "probably not happening."

images.alt_text: Seven & i, owner of the world’s biggest convenience store chain, has rejected a bid of nearly US$40 billion by Canada’s Couche-Tard, which then hiked its offer 20 per cent.
Seven & i Holdings shares were up 9.2 per cent at 2,661 yen (S$23) on Wednesday, compared with a 0.19 per cent rise in the benchmark Nikkei average.
Bloomberg News reported on Wednesday that Seven & i was considering a management buyout, or MBO, worth up to nine trillion yen - above its market cap of 5.7 trillion yen.
The saga is being seen as a key test of whether corporate Japan, long considered impenetrable for inbound mergers and acquisitions, is ready for change.

site_title: Thai factory output down 0.91% y/y in October, seen rising in 2025
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index dropped 0.91% in October from the previous year, falling less than expected. This follows a 1.63% decline in the first 10 months of 2024. The industry ministry forecasts a 1.6% decline for the full year. Car production in Thailand fell 25.13% in October, the 15th straight month, due to weak demand and tightened auto lending by banks.

site_title: Indonesia’s biggest taxi firm bets BYD plant to cut EV prices
summary: Indonesia's largest taxi firm, Blue Bird, aims to have electric vehicles account for 3% of its fleet by 2025 and 20% by 2030. The company plans to source vehicles from BYD's upcoming plant in Indonesia, which is expected to reduce prices. Currently, EVs account for around 1% of Blue Bird's fleet, hindered by high prices. The company hopes the new plant will bring down prices, making EVs more affordable and helping to accelerate its transition to electric vehicles.

site_title: Vietnam PM urges US to lift some high-tech export restrictions
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh urged the US to lift export restrictions on some technology, citing the country's desire to develop satellite communications. Chinh emphasized the need for good relations between the two countries and cooperation on global challenges. Vietnam, a significant US exporter, has a large trade surplus with Washington. The US currently limits Vietnam's access to certain technologies, but Chinh did not mention the threat of up to 20% US tariffs on imports. Vietnam is in talks with US aerospace giant SpaceX to develop satellite communications.

images.alt_text: Bac Ninh has become Vietnam's top FDI attractor, housing key facilities of electronics giants such as Foxconn, Samsung, and Amkor.
Vietnam government would arrange US$5.6 billion a year over the 12-year construction period of the railway, which will mostly carry passengers, but have an option for cargo after 2050.
Vietnam has so far this year raised 133.4 trillion dong from government bond sales, according to data from the Hanoi Stock Exchange.

site_title: PM Wong to make introductory visit to Bangkok on Nov 28
summary: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong is set to visit Bangkok on November 28, marking his fifth introductory trip to South-east Asian capitals since taking office. The visit is expected to promote bilateral cooperation in areas such as education, renewable energy, and food security. Wong will be hosted by Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra and will also meet with King Maha Vajiralongkorn and Queen Suthida. This trip follows previous visits to Brunei, Malaysia, Laos, and Indonesia, and is seen as an opportunity to further strengthen ties between Singapore and Thailand.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
1117 Yy / [MDDI/PMO Photo Release] PM Lawrence Wong attending the APEC Economic Leaders’ Meeting (AELM) Retreat

Building on the work of their predecessors, the new leaders of Singapore and Indonesia are looking towards being able to "write a new chapter" in their bilateral ties and take the relationship to "even greater heights", Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said during an introductory visit to Jakarta.

site_title: Britain’s Nationwide books surprisingly big £2.3 billion gain on Virgin Money deal
summary: Nationwide Building Society has reported a £2.3 billion gain from its acquisition of Virgin Money, exceeding its initial forecast of £1.5 billion. The deal, completed in October, has strengthened Nationwide's position as Britain's second-largest lender, with total assets of over £370 billion. Despite a 43% drop in statutory profit before tax to £568 million, Nationwide increased payouts to its members, reaching a record £1.3 billion in the first half. The lender plans to study Virgin Money's business for 18 months before making significant changes.

images.alt_text: A Nationwide Building Society branch in Middlesbrough, UK, on Thursday, March 7, 2024. Nationwide Building Society has reached a preliminary agreement to buy Virgin Money UK Plc for £2.9 billion ($3.7 billion), in a deal that raises the stakes for consolidation among Britain’s mid-sized lenders. Photographer: Ian Forsyth/Bloomberg

site_title: Malaysia drops 1MDB-related charges against ex-PM Najib and Treasury official
summary: A Malaysian court granted a discharge not amounting to an acquittal for former Prime Minister Najib Razak and former Treasury official due to procedural delays and the prosecution's failure to disclose key documents. The charges related to the multibillion-dollar 1MDB scandal, from which $4.5 billion was allegedly stolen between 2009 and 2014. Najib was previously found guilty of corruption and sentenced to 12 years in prison, but the pardon board reduced his sentence. The court's decision effectively drops the charges, but does not acquit Najib or the Treasury official.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak escorted by prison officers as the jailed politician left the court after court proceedings in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia January 19, 2024. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: Ng Yu Zhi’s billion-dollar nickel trading was ‘pure fiction’, prosecution alleges
summary: Prosecutors allege that Ng Yu Zhi's billion-dollar nickel trading scheme was "pure fiction," claiming he forged key documents to deceive investors. Ng, 37, faces 42 charges of fraudulent trading, cheating, forgery, and money laundering, with 63 additional charges related to the alleged investment fraud being dropped. The scheme allegedly took place between 2016 and 2021, promising investors high profits from trading physical nickel, but prosecutors claim his companies, Envy Asset Management and Envy Global Trading, never bought or sold the metal.

BUSINESSMAN Ng Yu Zhi, who is allegedly involved in a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam, has been slapped with 105 charges.

Investigations show that Envysion's former chief executive officer and directors did not put in place appropriate risk management framework for a fund related to a nickel trading fraud case, says MAS.

site_title: ‘Northern lights’: Vietnam’s industrial hubs shine up north amid surge in foreign investments
summary: Vietnam's industrial hubs, particularly in the northern region, are drawing significant foreign direct investment (FDI) in the manufacturing sector. The area accounts for nearly 60% of Vietnam's manufacturing FDI, with major provinces such as Bac Ninh, Hai Phong, and Hung Yen attracting significant investments from electronics giants like Samsung, Foxconn, and LG. The northern region's improved infrastructure and industrial land availability are key factors contributing to this shift, with rents in the area softening. Despite this, southern provinces like Binh Duong and Dong Nai remain major industrial hubs, with occupancy rates among the top.

images.alt_text: Photovoltaic panels and battery energy storage systems will be installed across more than 320,000 square meters of ready-built factory roofs at London Business Park in Vietnam's northern province of Thai Binh.

Representatives from Singapore businesses touring the YCH SuperPort, a warehouse facility located in Vietnam's northern province of Vinh Phuc. In the first 10 months of 2023, investors from Singapore poured some US$4.65 billion into Vietnam.

SBF held its flagship Singapore Regional Business Forum overseas for the first time in July. At the event in Hanoi, 12 deals were signed between Singapore and Vietnam organisations.

site_title: China investigates defence minister for corruption: report
summary: China has placed Defence Minister Dong Jun under investigation for corruption, according to a report by the Financial Times. This is the third Chinese defence minister to be investigated for corruption in a year, following the removal of Li Shangfu and Wei Fenghe. The investigation is part of a broader crackdown on military corruption, with President Xi Jinping ordering the military to stamp out corruption and strengthen its "war-preparedness".

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese Defence Minister Dong Jun attends Beijing Xiangshan Forum in Beijing, China September 13, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Most Singapore companies able to service debt despite higher interest expense: MAS
summary: Most Singapore-listed companies have maintained a "relatively robust" median interest coverage ratio (ICR) of above two, despite higher interest expenses, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The report found that the debt maturity profiles of companies are stable, and their liquidity buffers mitigate refinancing risk. While externally-oriented and highly leveraged firms may be more vulnerable to interest rate and earnings shocks, the overall resilience of Singapore corporates remains low, with only 16% of firms at risk of such shocks.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Most corporates have low debt levels and overall bank credit quality is strong, says MAS in its Financial Stability Review report.
Food inflation was unchanged at 2.6 per cent, as the prices of non-cooked food and food services rose at a similar pace in September and October.
The Q3 figure brings GDP growth for the first nine months of 2024 to a “better-than-expected” 3.8 per cent, said the Ministry of Trade and Industry.
Singapore’s Straits Times Index, comprising the 30 biggest companies in the city-state, hit a 17-year high on Tuesday, bringing its year-to-date gains to 17 per cent.

site_title: IMF sees Thai GDP growth at 2.7% this year, 2.9% in 2025
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has projected Thailand's GDP growth at 2.7% this year and 2.9% in 2025, driven by planned fiscal stimulus measures and a pickup in public investment. Private consumption growth is expected to remain robust, while private investment is also projected to increase. The Bank of Thailand will review monetary policy on December 18, following a 25 basis point interest rate cut in October, which is seen as a policy recalibration. The IMF advises the authorities to be ready to adjust monetary policy in response to data and outlook-dependent changes.

site_title: Chinese climate experts more confident of early emissions peak
summary: Chinese climate experts are becoming more confident that the country will peak carbon emissions before 2030, with 44% of surveyed experts expecting this to happen by 2025. The increased optimism stems from record clean energy installations and a slowing economy, which have helped stabilize emissions. However, experts warn that China's rapid energy consumption growth limits its ability to quickly reduce emissions and mitigate climate change. To address this, China will need to accelerate renewable energy deployment or guide economic development towards a less energy-intensive direction.

site_title: Hot stock: SingPost climbs 4.5% after talks of potential divestment of Australian business
summary: SingPost's Australian segment logged a revenue of S$574.8 million for the half year ended Sep 30, up 44% from S$398.8 million a year earlier. The company's shares gained 4.5% following "exclusive talks" of the potential sale of its Australian business, which includes fourth-party logistics services and last-mile courier delivery. This move comes after SingPost's restructuring process in May 2023, with analysts viewing the group as "deeply undervalued" at 15.8 times FY2026 estimates.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
ST20240503_202421361534 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the Singapore Post (SingPost) logo on the SingPost Centre building on May 3, 2024.

The Singapore Post board noted that incoming chief financial officer Vincent Yik is expected to lead "the continued transformation of our business, especially with Australia as a key part of our strategy".

site_title: Chinese island plastic pollution turned into artistic omens
summary: Chinese artist Fu Junsheng is using plastic pollution from his island home, Miaodao Archipelago, to create artistic installations highlighting the issue of marine debris. Fu collects debris, including plastic waste from his daily life, and transforms it into sculptures, paintings, and other pieces. His work aims to raise awareness about the global problem of plastic pollution, which affects not only the environment but also human health. Fu's message emphasizes the need for collective action to address this issue, which he believes is tied to daily life.

images.alt_text: The painting will remain on display at the Palazzo Barberini through Feb 23.

Young Jin Yee, co-head of UBS Global Wealth Management Asia Pacific and Country Head UBS Singapore, with Care Corner students and UBS staff volunteers embarking on the

Sotheby’s will sell just over 700 lots for a total presale estimate of roughly US$479 million to US$659 million.

site_title: Elite UK Reit to divest office building Hilden House for £3.3 million
summary: Elite UK Reit has entered a contract to sell office building Hilden House in Warrington, England, for £3.3 million, representing a 6% premium over its valuation. The sale is expected to use net proceeds to repay debt, with no material impact on the Reit's net asset value or distribution per unit for the 2024 financial year.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders eye fresh trade tensions
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday, following a broadly negative day on Tuesday, despite a record-breaking lead from Wall Street. US President-elect Donald Trump's threat to impose tariffs on China, Canada, and Mexico has reignited trade war fears, with investors trying to gauge the economic outlook. Markets are also awaiting the release of the Federal Reserve's preferred gauge of inflation and figures on jobless claims and economic growth. Analysts warn that prices could spike again if the tariffs are imposed, with some predicting a "trade decoupling" by Trump.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent higher at 44,860.31 on Tuesday, its third straight closing record.
Singapore stocks edge lower as tariff concerns weigh on investor sentiment; STI down 0.1%

site_title: Rental rates remain key factor in influencing industrial space location choices: NUS
summary: A survey by the National University of Singapore (NUS) found that 84% of industrial space users consider competitive rental rates the key factor in deciding where to relocate. This outweighs factors such as quality and condition of space, access to workforce and talent, and tax breaks. The survey also found that 78% of respondents believe industrial park landlords need to offer competitive rents to attract firms. Despite a manufacturing sector contraction, the industrial real estate market remains resilient, with a 7.5% year-on-year expansion in Q3.

images.alt_text: Samuel Oh
Vacancy in warehouses rose to 8.9 per cent in Q3, up from 8.7 per cent in the previous quarter.
Total industrial stock stands at 52 million square metres as at end-September 2024.

site_title: Singapore stocks edge lower as tariff concerns weigh on investor sentiment; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.1% lower, mirroring a mixed performance across Asian markets, amid concerns over Donald Trump's tariffs. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.3 points to 3,708.09. Beverage company Thai Beverage was the top gainer, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the biggest loser. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC ended the day mixed. The region's key indices were also mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 tumbling 0.8% and South Korea's Kospi Composite Index falling 0.7%.

site_title: Starbucks workers to get only 60% bonus on worst year since 2020
summary: Starbucks' corporate workers will receive 60% of their overall bonuses for the fiscal year ending September 29, down from the typical 100% due to the company's poor financial performance. Revenue grew less than 1% and consolidated operating income fell about 8%. This reflects the sales woes caused by widespread inflation, long wait times, and inaccurate orders. New CEO Brian Niccol aims to reverse the slump with a plan to make cafes more welcoming and speed up service.

Starbucks has faced pressure from activist Elliott Investment Management, which wants it to commit to reviewing its Chinese business.

site_title: Financial institutions, companies in Singapore have enough buffer to weather shocks: MAS
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) says financial institutions and companies have sufficient buffers to withstand shocks due to their strong balance sheets. Most corporates have low debt levels, while overall bank credit quality is strong. Households have benefited from continued wage growth and an increase in financial assets, cushioning the impact of rising household debt. This suggests that the country's financial system is resilient to economic volatility.

A critical driver of US strength is corporate America’s profit edge: S&P 500 company earnings are expected to rise 9.9 per cent this year and 14.2 per cent in 2025.

site_title: China’s October industrial profits extend decline on weak demand
summary: China's industrial profits declined 10% in October from a year earlier, following a 27.1% slump in September, amid weak demand and a years-long property crisis. Earnings slid 4.3% in the first 10 months, with separate economic indicators showing soft demand, including consumer prices at their weakest in four months and new home prices falling at their fastest pace in nine years. Policymakers have yet to reflate the economy, and investors are waiting for a more direct fiscal stimulus.

The goal is to lower Macnica’s reliance on semiconductors, which account for 90 per cent of its sales.

site_title: Samsung Electronics changes chip chiefs after chairman Lee confronts ‘crisis’
summary: Samsung Electronics has made significant changes to its chip leadership, appointing Jun Young-hyun as co-CEO and giving him control over its struggling memory chip business. Han Jin-man, the head of US chips, has been named president and head of its foundry business. The moves aim to inject impetus into the company's memory and foundry chip units, which have been lagging rivals in the booming AI chip market. The changes come as Samsung's shares have fallen steadily since August due to concerns over its chip supply to Nvidia.

site_title: HP gives lacklustre profit outlook on slow PC market recovery
summary: HP has given a disappointing profit outlook for the current quarter, citing a slow PC market recovery. The company expects earnings of 70-76 cents per share, below analyst estimates of 86 cents. A decline in component costs is expected to improve profitability, but demand remains sluggish. The PC market, which had seen a historic decline after the pandemic, has not seen a significant rebound, with shipments dipping in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: British tycoon Mike Lynch died after his luxury yacht sank in severe weather off the coast of Sicily.
HP's disappointing profit forecast overshadowed the company’s first revenue gain in two years, suggesting an end to a long slump in demand for personal computers.

site_title: Trump plans no exemption for oil imports under new tariff plan: sources
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump plans to impose 25% tariffs on crude oil imports from Canada and Mexico, with no exemptions for oil imports, according to sources. The move has sparked concerns among the US oil industry, which warns that tariffs could hurt consumers, industry, and national security. Top oil trade groups, including the American Fuel and Petrochemical Manufacturers and the American Petroleum Institute, have expressed opposition to the policy, citing potential disruptions to the free flow of energy products across borders and increased oil prices for US refiners.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down 20 cents, or 0.27 per cent, to US$72.81 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: VinFast’s loss narrows, revenue jumps on higher EV sales
summary: VinFast, a Vietnamese electric vehicle (EV) maker, reported a narrowed net loss of 13.3 trillion dong (S$705 million) in the third quarter, a decrease of 14.8% from last year, and revenue jumped 49.3% to 12.3 trillion dong. The company delivered 21,912 cars, a 115% increase from the same period last year, driven by robust deliveries in the domestic market. VinFast plans to start construction of a new plant in Vietnam to produce affordable EVs and aims to meet its 80,000-vehicle delivery target for 2024.

site_title: Scott Bessent may rue the day he became US Treasury secretary
summary: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent faces a challenging tenure as the administration's chief economic spokesperson under President-elect Donald Trump. The Treasury secretary will be tied to Trump's fiscal legacy, including high US debt and deficits, which could lead to fiscal profligacy and market instability. Bessent will also be responsible for defending Trump's trade policies, including tariffs on China, and navigating the complex relationship with the Federal Reserve. The Treasury secretary's role in promoting liberal trade and defending the dollar's global role may also be at odds with Trump's protectionist stance.

summary: Jurong Port has opened a S$200 million shared-services hub for ready-mixed concrete, part of its Integrated Construction Park. The RMC Ecosystem facility enables companies to streamline logistics, cut costs, and improve storage capacity by 75%. The pooling of services will allow sector players to focus on core activities, boosting competitiveness and reducing truck trips by over a million. summary: Huawei plans to transition its smartphones and tablets to its own HarmonyOS Next operating system starting from 2025, effectively dropping Android. The move aims to build a self-sustaining ecosystem, bypassing major US tech providers like Google. This shift is part of Huawei's efforts to reclaim China's premium market share from Apple.

site_title: Adani Group says it lost nearly US$55 billion as US charges sparked rout
summary: The Adani Group, a conglomerate led by billionaire Gautam Adani, has lost nearly US$55 billion in market value since US prosecutors accused its founder and officials of fraud and bribery in a November 20 indictment. The group denies the charges, describing them as "baseless," but has suffered significant repercussions, including international project cancellations, financial market impact, and public scrutiny. Adani officials are only charged with securities fraud, wire fraud conspiracy, and securities fraud, and the group's stocks have surged in response to the statement, piling on over 10% gains in Mumbai.

site_title: South Korea eyes 14.3 trillion won in support for chipmakers in 2025
summary: South Korea plans to provide 14.3 trillion won ($13.8 billion) in financial support to domestic chipmakers in 2025, bolstering the industry amid potential challenges from the incoming Trump administration and Chinese rivals. The move aims to safeguard the growth of the industry, which accounts for roughly a third of South Korea's shipments abroad. The support includes loans from state-affiliated banks and will cover part of the 1.8 trillion won needed to bury power cables underground in chipmaking clusters south of Seoul.

images.alt_text: South Korea is among the top 10 nations recording trade surpluses with the US, making it a prime target for Trump.

Speculation is growing that continued stability in housing markets would allow central bank officials to quicken the pace of rate cuts next year.

site_title: Crypto exchange Kraken shuts down NFT marketplace
summary: Kraken, a major crypto exchange, is shutting down its NFT marketplace, citing a shift in resources to new products and services. The platform, launched in December 2022, has not rebounded strongly from the crypto bear market of 2022. The move comes amid broader changes at the company, including a new CFO and co-CEO, and a reduction in workforce. Kraken plans to launch a new blockchain called Ink, which will allow for decentralized trading and lending of tokens without intermediaries.

site_title: US Fed minutes show officials prefer future rate cuts to be gradual
summary: US Federal Reserve officials prefer future interest-rate cuts to be gradual, indicating a cautious approach to lowering rates as the economy remains solid and inflation slowly cools. The Fed's benchmark interest rate has been lowered to a range of 4.5 to 4.75 percent, and officials are considering a gradual reduction in policy restraint. The neutral rate, a level of policy that neither restricts nor stimulates economic growth, remains unclear, and policymakers are considering a technical adjustment to the overnight reverse repurchase facility.

images.alt_text: By concentrating on the issues facing small, young businesses – as opposed to large, well-established corporations with a lot of lobbyists – the incoming administration could foster innovation and support business formation.

site_title: Dell reports sales that miss estimates on setback for PC market
summary: Dell reported fiscal third-quarter revenue of $24.4 billion, missing analyst estimates of $24.6 billion. The company's personal computer business declined 1% to $12.1 billion, despite a rebound in the PC market. However, sales in Dell's infrastructure unit, including servers, rose 34% to $11.4 billion, beating estimates. The company's AI server business saw significant growth, with orders reaching $3.6 billion and growth across all customer types. Dell's shares dropped 5% in extended trading following the earnings report.

site_title: Hello Kitty stock sinks most since 2014 on share sale plan
summary: Sanrio's shares dropped 17% as the company's president and MUFG Bank plan to sell 25.9 million shares in the open market, citing the need to increase liquidity and unwind cross-shareholdings. The sale comes after Sanrio raised its full-year profit guidance last month. Analysts say the stock may face near-term pressure but expect a long-term positive outlook for the character market and portfolio diversification.

site_title: RBNZ flags another big cut after second half-point move
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) lowered its Official Cash Rate (OCR) by half a percentage point to 4.25%, marking its second rate cut in three months. Governor Adrian Orr hinted at further large cuts in interest rates if the economy evolves as expected, with a 50-basis-point reduction possible in February. The RBNZ aims for a 2% inflation target and expects annual growth to recover to 2.3% in 2026, with inflation accelerating to 2.5% by the third quarter of 2025.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ will publish its decision at 2 pm on Wednesday and governor Adrian Orr will hold a press conference an hour later.
The RBNZ’s downbeat view of the economy and concern over the impact of potential tariffs under Donald Trump’s administration spurred traders to bet on large rate cuts.
BNZ began easing monetary policy in August saying weak domestic demand gave it confidence that inflation was returning towards the middle of its 1 to 3 per cent target.
New Zealand's unemployment rate rose to 4.8 per cent in the third quarter, from 4.6 per cent the previous quarter and just under analyst forecasts of 5.0 per cent.

site_title: Hong Kong tower seized from tycoon ends up sold to a university
summary: Hong Kong Metropolitan University (HKMU) has signed an agreement to buy the Cheung Kei Center, a commercial property in Hong Kong, from China Mobile Hong Kong for over HK$2.6 billion. The building, once owned by tycoon Chen Hongtian, was seized by Hang Seng Bank in 2019 due to loan defaults. The sale comes as high interest rates and a weakening economy in China spur fire sales on Hong Kong properties, with at least HK$2.1 trillion in real estate values erased since 2019.

site_title: Bank of America down a notch on ‘too big to fail’ list
summary: Bank of America dropped from category three to category two on the Global Systemically Important Banks list, a move attributed to stricter regulations. Credit Agricole moved up one level to join BOA in category two. The Financial Stability Board, which monitors the global financial system, published its list of 29 systemically important banks. JPMorgan remains in category four, while Citigroup and HSBC are in category three. The list updates annually and aims to ensure banks can withstand financial crises.

site_title: Philip Ng raises stake in Vitasoy, prompting speculation of takeover
summary: Singapore billionaire Philip Ng raises his stake in Vitasoy to 12.26% from 11.87%, sparking speculation of a potential takeover. CEO Roberto Guidetti says the company is "open" to business collaboration opportunities, which led to a record-high 32% surge in shares. Guidetti did not comment on Ng's intentions, but the increased stake has raised interest in the beverage maker. Vitasoy's profit rose 5% and the company announced an interim dividend, as its shares jumped the most on record since 1994.

summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has named Jamieson Greer his new trade envoy, tasked with rolling out the US president-elect's tariff policy and negotiating trade deals if confirmed by the Senate. Greer, a former chief of staff to US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, has experience in trade policy, including a trade deal between the US, Mexico, and Canada. Trump cited Greer's role in imposing tariffs on China and others to combat unfair trade practices during his first term.

site_title: GM, Ford fall on Trump tariffs seen adding US$3,000 to car prices
summary: US automakers GM and Ford saw their shares plummet as President-elect Donald Trump's proposed tariffs on Mexican and Canadian goods could increase car prices by around $3,000, according to analysts. The tariffs, which could affect $97 billion in auto parts and 4 million vehicles, would be "devastating" for the industry. With many consumers already struggling to afford the almost $50,000 cost of a new car, the added tariffs could further exacerbate the issue.

site_title: Dollar rises after Trump tariff vows jolt Canada and Mexico
summary: The US dollar surged more than 2% against the Mexican peso and reached a four-and-a-half-year high against the Canadian dollar after President-elect Donald Trump vowed to impose tariffs on products from Mexico, Canada, and China. The dollar rose to its highest since July 30 against China's yuan and other currencies fell against it. Trump's comments were seen as a surprise and volatility is more likely under his leadership, with analysts warning that tariffs could set the stage for trade spats and a less damaging outcome only if there is room for negotiation.

site_title: Australia’s monthly CPI holds at 2.1% in October
summary: Australia's consumer price index (CPI) remained steady at 2.1% in October, unchanged from September and below market forecasts of 2.3%. The trimmed mean core inflation rate rose to 3.5%, exceeding the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band of 2-3%. The low inflation rate is attributed to government rebates driving down electricity and rent prices. This data is unlikely to impact monetary policy, with interest rates remaining steady for a year.

images.alt_text: UBS has vaulted back to the upper tier of Australian wealth managers after the merger of the two Swiss banks provided a pathway back into a market it had exited in 2015.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Cheng’s jeweller sees steep revenue fall amid slowdown
summary: Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group, China's largest jeweller, reported a 20.4% revenue drop in the half year ended September, with profit falling 44.4% due to losses from gold loan contracts. The company attributed the decline to a slowdown in mainland China, high gold prices, and weak consumer confidence. Despite this, the group's operating profit rose 4% to HK$6.8 billion and announced a plan to buy back up to HK$2 billion of shares.

site_title: New Zealand GDP grew faster in March year, data revisions show
summary: New Zealand's economy grew 1.4% in the year to March 2024, up from previously reported 0.3% annual average growth, according to revised data. The revisions show stronger growth in farming, forestry, and fishing, as well as in business services and healthcare. Construction also grew slightly, contrary to the previous report of contraction. The revised data suggests a more robust economic performance than initially thought.

site_title: Singapore Post in exclusive talks for Australia business sale
summary: Singapore Post is in exclusive talks for the potential sale of its Australian business, which posted a revenue of S$574.8 million in the half year ending Sept 30, up from S$398.8 million a year earlier. The company's Australian segment includes logistics services, transportation, and warehousing. Singapore Post embarked on a restructuring process in 2023 to bring back capital returns to shareholders and has strengthened its position in the Australian logistics market through acquisitions. No definitive deal has been reached, and negotiations are ongoing.

images.alt_text: ST20240503_202421361534 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the Singapore Post (SingPost) logo on the SingPost Centre building on May 3, 2024.

site_title: BT Branded Podcasts: How Income Insurance is leading ESG investing
summary: BT Branded Podcasts explores the growing trend of income insurance in ESG investing, where investors prioritize financial stability alongside environmental and social considerations. This shift is driven by the need for diversified portfolios and long-term returns. Income insurance, a type of risk management, helps mitigate potential losses while generating stable income. As investors increasingly prioritize ESG factors, income insurance is emerging as a key component of sustainable investing strategies. This trend is expected to continue, offering investors a more stable and resilient approach to long-term wealth management.

site_title: Europe: Stocks trip on Trump tariff hurdle
summary: European stocks fell 0.6% on Tuesday, snapping a three-day winning streak, amid concerns over US President-elect Donald Trump's tariff threat on Canada, Mexico, and China, potentially sparking another global trade war. The Stoxx 600, a pan-European index, dropped 505.90 points, while the auto sector led losses, with Stellantis and Volkswagen among the top losers. Investors are cautious about the impact of tariffs on global inflation and monetary policy easing, with the European Central Bank also expressing concern.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent higher at 44,860.31 on Tuesday, its third straight closing record.

site_title: UK Supreme Court hears case on definition of 'woman'
summary: The UK Supreme Court is considering a case brought by the "For Women Scotland" campaign group, which challenges the definitions of "woman" in the UK's 2010 Equality Act and the Gender Recognition Act 2004. The campaigners argue that these definitions are incompatible, potentially impacting trans rights and access to single-sex spaces. The court's decision could have widespread implications for how the UK defines gender and sex, and may influence the country's gender-recognition process.

images.alt_text: hong kong property housing Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg
Men and women are equal in the workplace, until they aren't

site_title: A better alternative to Trump’s tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs could have devastating consequences for the US and global economy. Raising tariffs would increase the cost of imported parts and components for US firms, leading to higher prices for consumers and a loss of competitiveness for exporters. A better alternative would be a targeted adjustment programme combining retraining opportunities for younger workers and support for older ones, providing more effective and less expensive relief to workers displaced by import competition.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump said he would impose the tariffs until China stops the flow of illegal drugs, particularly fentanyl, into the United States.

Many economists have warned that tariffs would hurt growth and push up inflation, since they are primarily paid by importers bringing the goods into the US, who often pass those costs on to consumers.

site_title: Japan’s top chip distributor eyes acquisitions in China, India
summary: Macnica Holdings, Japan's top chip distributor, is seeking overseas acquisitions to lower its reliance on semiconductors, which account for 90% of its sales. The company aims to raise its market share, particularly in China, South-east Asia, and India, where its presence remains low. Macnica's president, Kazumasa Hara, sees acquisitions as a viable option, with a deal requiring billions of US dollars "very likely." The goal is to expand into other areas, such as cybersecurity, self-driving car networks, and healthcare, and potentially reach a 30% or higher market share by 2030.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed Intel logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The semiconductor industry is cyclical and experienced a tough 2023, with sales dropping by 8.2 per cent to US$526.8 billion. That marked the seventh downturn since 1990.

site_title: Netflix defeats shareholder lawsuit over growth forecasts
summary: US District Judge Jon Tigar dismissed a shareholder lawsuit against Netflix, finding the company's earlier claims about its subscriber growth were not false or misleading. Netflix blamed subscriber losses on account sharing, rising competition, and a Russia service shutdown. The judge ruled the company's statements referred to paid subscribers, not growth certainty, and that no proof existed of Netflix concealing the impact of account sharing on growth. The dismissal is final, preventing the plaintiff from amending his complaint.

Investigators specialising in financial crime and corruption raided Netflix’s offices in central Paris on Tuesday morning.

site_title: Why the public doesn’t buy the idea of a ‘green jobs’ bonanza
summary: Northvolt, a Swedish electric vehicle battery-maker, filed for bankruptcy, casting doubt on the idea that the transition to net zero will be driven by secure "green jobs." Research by Steve Akehurst found that "green jobs" arguments tend to fall flat with the public, but resonate with politicians and elites. This challenges the narrative that green jobs will be a key driver of climate action, particularly in regions that need them. The bankruptcy highlights the challenges of creating sustainable industries and the need for more nuanced approaches to addressing climate change.

Prime Minister Keir Starmer speaking with attendees at the International Investment Summit in London, which brings together some 300 industry leaders to boost investment in the UK, Oct 14, 2024.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at record highs, shrugging off Trump tariff threat
summary: US stocks reached record highs on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing 0.3% higher and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also reaching new records. Despite President-elect Donald Trump's threat to impose tariffs on Mexico, Canada, and China, investors viewed the warning as a bargaining chip, shrugging off concerns about trade protectionism. The Conference Board's consumer confidence index rose to 111.7, boosted by optimism surrounding the labor market, and individual companies such as Best Buy and Amgen also saw gains.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 121.7 points, or 0.27 per cent, at the open to 44,614.89.

site_title: StanChart CEO Bill Winters’ love-hate relationship with trade wars, conflict
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters views trade wars and geopolitical tensions as creating opportunities for businesses to thrive. Despite the risks, he believes the likelihood of these tensions boiling over is low. The bank has reported a stellar third quarter with a pre-tax profit more than doubling to US$1.7 billion. Winters attributes the bank's success to its ability to navigate uncertainty and connect clients despite obstacles. He notes that US President Donald Trump prefers to avoid real conflict, and China is unlikely to escalate the conflict with the US.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Like other major banks attempting to cope with the impact of falling rates, Standard Chartered is in the midst of a cost-savings programme.
The move is likely to speed up transactions at a time when foreigners are showing greater interest in India.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, Elite UK Reit
summary: SingPost is in exclusive talks with a third party for the potential sale of its Australia business, with no definitive deal reached. The company's Australia segment logged a revenue of S$574.8 million for the half year ended September 30. Meanwhile, Elite UK Reit is divesting Hilden House in Warrington, England, for £3.3 million, generating a 6% premium above the property's valuation.

images.alt_text: ST20240503_202421361534 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the Singapore Post (SingPost) logo on the SingPost Centre building on May 3, 2024.

site_title: Computers unleashed economic growth. Will AI?
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) has failed to live up to its promise of rapid economic growth and job displacement, despite predictions made two decades ago. The early adoption of AI has been largely confined to narrow applications within existing operations, such as fraud detection. Factors contributing to the slow progress include underwhelming investment in IT, stagnant prices for computer hardware and software, and a lack of integration of AI into business operations. According to the Census Bureau, only 6% of businesses use AI to produce goods and services, and output and labor-productivity growth remain below pre-1990s levels.

images.alt_text: John Maynard Keynes envisioned a 15-hour workweek.

epa11731962 A Waymo autonomous self-driving Jaguar robotaxi waits for a passenger in Los Angeles, California, USA, 20 November 2024. On 12 November 2024, Waymo opened its autonomous self-driving robotaxi service to anyone in a nearly 80 square mile area of Los Angeles County, marking its largest expansion yet. Waymo, owned by Google parent Alphabet, closed a $5.6 billion funding round in October to expand its robotaxi service across the US.  EPA-EFE/ALLISON DINNER
For much of this year already, AI researchers have been looking at new paths for improving their models that don’t just involve throwing more data and computing power at them.
In an ideal world, Big Tech companies would be more explicit about their endgame. They have a fiduciary duty to their investors after all.

site_title: Economic advice for Trump and Powell: First, do no harm
summary: The US economy is experiencing dynamic growth, with real gross domestic product on track to exceed its pre-pandemic trend for the second year in a row. Strong growth is largely driven by higher productivity and a faster-growing workforce, rather than inflation. The administration and Fed should focus on supporting small, young businesses and fostering innovation, rather than large corporations with lobbyists. Regulating judiciously to support competition and innovation could help extend productivity gains, while high interest rates could slow growth. Protecting the dynamism of the labor market is also crucial to sustaining long-term growth.

site_title: Core portfolio with US equities could mitigate impact of looming ‘seismic changes’
summary: Singapore investors can diversify their US holdings through the Singapore-listed Dow ETF, which offers a gateway to US stocks. Experts warn of a looming "seismic change" in the global market due to potential import tariffs, inflation, and a second Trump administration. Maintaining a core position in US equities and diversifying through actively managed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) can help mitigate risks. Singapore investors can benefit from non-cash avenues such as the Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) and tax savings, but should be cautious of the competitive international capital market.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan

George Ferraz, intermediary relationship manager at global asset manager State Street Global Advisors, was the keynote speaker at “Exploring the Dow: Opportunities and strategies for US equities investments”. The panel discussion was held on Nov 9 at the Singapore Exchange Auditorium.

From left: Geoff Howie, market strategist, Singapore Exchange; Sue Lee, director and Asia-Pacific head of index investment strategy, S&P Dow Jones Indices; Jermyn Wong, head of intermediary, South-east Asia, State Street Global Advisors; and Ben Paul, senior correspondent, The Business Times. They were speaking on a panel titled “Exploring the Dow: Opportunities and strategies for US equities investments” on Nov 9.

site_title: Chinese Courier SF Holding to start trading after HK$5.83 billion Hong Kong IPO
summary: Chinese Courier SF Holding's shares debuted in Hong Kong on November 27 with a HK$5.83 billion (S$1 billion) listing, marking the city's second-largest IPO this year. The company's shares jumped 5.5% in grey-market trading before erasing gains. The deal drew $205 million from cornerstone investors and was backed by entities tied to Hong Kong property investors. The listing comes amid a mixed investor mood, following Beijing's stimulus efforts and concerns over trade tensions. Goldman Sachs, Huatai Securities, and JPMorgan are joint sponsors of the offering.

site_title: Malaysia plans to produce sustainable jet fuel in 2027
summary: Malaysia plans to start producing sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in 2027, with an initial production capacity of one million tonnes per year. The country, the world's second-largest palm oil producer, aims to become a leading SAF producer. The government's National Energy Transition Roadmap sets a SAF blending mandate of 1 per cent, aiming for 47 per cent by 2050. Two companies, EcoCeres Renewable Fuels and Petronas, are constructing SAF refineries with capacities of 350,000 and 650,000 tonnes per year, respectively.

images.alt_text: Used cooking oil the new black gold as it rides biofuel demand, limited supply
A Finnair plane being fueled with sustainable aviation fuel at Helsinki Vaanta Airport in Finland.

site_title: Oil settles lower after Israel agrees to ceasefire deal with Lebanon
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Tuesday, extending Monday's losses after Israel agreed to a ceasefire deal with Lebanon, reducing the oil's risk premium. Brent crude futures fell 20 cents to US$72.81 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 17 cents to US$68.77 a barrel. A ceasefire could lead to reduced sanctions on oil from Iran, potentially increasing oil prices. Meanwhile, OPEC+ nations are discussing a delay to planned oil production hikes, and US President-elect Donald Trump said he would impose a 25% tariff on all products coming into the US, including crude oil.

images.alt_text: The nations doubt that they can go ahead with the 180,000 barrel-a-day increase currently scheduled for January, and may also need to postpone further hikes planned for the following months, amid signs of a global oversupply.
Brent crude futures settled at US$73.01 a barrel, down US$2.16, or 2.87 per cent on Monday.

site_title: Adani Wilmar said to defer stake sale amid US bribery charges
summary: Adani Wilmar, a joint venture between Adani Group and Wilmar International, is delaying a proposed 12% stake sale amid US bribery charges against billionaire Gautam Adani. The company needs to comply with local securities law requiring 25% of ownership to be non-founder within three years of listing by February. The delay comes as the majority owners currently hold 86.8% of the company, exceeding the maximum permissible 75%. The US bribery allegations have made it difficult to proceed with the sale.

images.alt_text: Adani Wilmar's revenue from its core edible oils segment, which contributes 76 per cent to total revenue, grew 21 per cent during the quarter.

site_title: Singapore-listed Dow ETF offers local investors a gateway to US stocks, say panellists
summary: Singapore-listed Dow ETF offers local investors a gateway to US stocks, with the US market performing strongly over the last 10 years due to household and corporate balance sheets being extremely strong. The Dow can be a good diversifier, especially in today's environment where tech companies' performance is uncertain. The Dow is selected based on qualitative criteria, including excellent reputation and sustained growth, and companies need to have a significant impact on the market. Local investors can use a Singapore-listed ETF to invest in the Dow, which offers the ability to use non-cash avenues like the Supplementary Retirement Scheme.

images.alt_text: George Ferraz, intermediary relationship manager at global asset manager State Street Global Advisors, was the keynote speaker at “Exploring the Dow: Opportunities and strategies for US equities investments”. The panel discussion was held on Nov 9 at the Singapore Exchange Auditorium.

From left: Geoff Howie, market strategist, Singapore Exchange; Sue Lee, director and Asia-Pacific head of index investment strategy, S&P Dow Jones Indices; Jermyn Wong, head of intermediary, South-east Asia, State Street Global Advisors; and Ben Paul, senior correspondent, The Business Times.

site_title: Tencent to end Nintendo Switch eShop sales and services in China from 2026
summary: Tencent announced that the Nintendo Switch eShop and online services in China will cease operations by March 31, 2026, and May 15, 2026, respectively. This move affects gamers who purchased the official Chinese version of the console, as many prefer other versions that can connect with consoles outside China. Tencent partnered with Nintendo in 2019 to sell the Switch in China, but the partnership will come to an end in 2026.

site_title: Trump’s threatened tariffs pose a win-lose conundrum for Singapore
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump plans to impose 25% tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada, and an additional 10% on top of existing tariffs on China. This could indirectly hurt demand for Singapore-made goods, but the Republic may benefit from supply chain shifts, with some economists predicting Singapore could emerge as a relative beneficiary. Increased trade tensions may also affect business confidence and investment decisions in Singapore, but front-loading of shipments and potential rerouting of supply chains could mitigate this impact.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

Many economists have warned that tariffs would hurt growth and push up inflation, since they are primarily paid by importers bringing the goods into the US, who often pass those costs on to consumers.
Donald Trump said he would impose the tariffs until China stops the flow of illegal drugs, particularly fentanyl, into the United States.
Donald Trump's announcement fuelled a sell-off across most Asian markets, though Hong Kong and Shanghai advanced in early exchanges.

site_title: When investing, watch for the risks before diving in for rewards
summary: Investors should carefully consider both the potential rewards and risks before making investment decisions. Cyclical industries, such as semiconductors, can experience boom and bust cycles, impacting company performance. Economic risks, like those faced by banks, can also significantly affect investments. Reits (Real Estate Investment Trusts) are subject to occupancy and interest rate risks, while sector-specific risks, like those in telecommunications and cybersecurity, can lead to reputational and financial damage. By acknowledging and managing these risks, investors can gain a more balanced perspective and potentially achieve better investment outcomes over time.

images.alt_text: Supermarket operator Sheng Siong's share price has remained stable, but its business has grown and it has opened eight new stores between end-2020 and June 2024.
Buying a stock is easy; selling is more complicated as your decision may be affected by emotional factors like fear and greed.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 26)
summary: Singapore's industrial production grew 0.4% year-over-year in October, excluding the biomedical sector. Factory output in Singapore rose 1.2% in October, missing expectations of a 2.6% expansion. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) launched three sale sites, including a residential plot at Bayshore Road. Duo was charged with false trading of EuroSports shares under the Securities and Futures Act, which carries a maximum imprisonment of seven years and a fine of up to S$250,000.

images.alt_text: Food inflation was unchanged at 2.6 per cent, as the prices of non-cooked food and food services rose at a similar pace in September and October.

site_title: Affinity buys two South-east Asian companies for US$1.65 billion: sources
summary: Affinity Equity Partners, a Hong Kong-based firm, has acquired two South-east Asian companies for a combined US$1.65 billion. It bought Yupi, a Jakarta-based gummy candy company, for US$1.2 billion, and Golden Fresh, a Malaysian seafood processor, for US$450 million. The acquisitions aim to tap into the region's strong economic growth prospects.

images.alt_text: IHH, which is listed on the Malaysian and Singaporean bourses, said it does not comment on market speculation and will update the market if there are any material developments.

site_title: Thai banks’ bad loans highest in nearly 3 years, but manageable: central bank
summary: Thai banks' non-performing loans (NPLs) rose to 2.97% in September, the highest level in nearly three years, due to a decline in the loan base and higher NPLs from business and consumer loans. However, the banking system remains resilient, and banks continue to manage their portfolios and provide support to debtors. The central bank is monitoring debt serviceability of smaller businesses and households with slower income recovery and elevated debt burden, which could cause a gradual increase in NPLs but remain manageable.

images.alt_text: At the Oct 16 meeting, Thailand's monetary policy committee unexpectedly voted 5-2 to cut the one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 2.25 per cent, the first decrease since 2020. Two members voted to keep the rate steady.
The baht has declined more than 7 per cent this quarter in Asia’s worst performance, as Thailand’s government campaigned for the central bank to cut borrowing costs.

site_title: US firms up US$7.9 billion chips award to Intel
summary: The US government has finalized a $7.9 billion award to Intel, supporting the company's expected $90 billion investment in the US by the end of the decade. This investment will focus on chip production in Arizona, New Mexico, Ohio, and Oregon, aiming to reduce the country's dependence on China and other Asian countries for essential semiconductor devices.

images.alt_text: Intel’s depressed stock price has spurred takeover interest.

site_title: India's Andhra Pradesh state likely to suspend Adani power deal
summary: India's Andhra Pradesh state is likely to suspend a power purchase deal linked to Adani Group due to a US indictment of the group's billionaire founder Gautam Adani over an alleged bribery scheme. The US indictment alleges Adani paid $228 million in bribes to Indian officials to obtain solar power contracts. The decision would be the first by an Indian state government following the US charges. The power supply to Andhra Pradesh was scheduled to start next year, but the suspension is likely to be announced soon.

images.alt_text: The majority owners of Adani Wilmar currently own a combined 86.8 per cent in Adani Wilmar, far above the maximum permissible 75 per cent.

site_title: US new home sales tumble to two-year low in October
summary: US new home sales plummeted 17.3% in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 610,000 units, the lowest level since December 2022. The decline is attributed to rising mortgage rates and disruptions caused by hurricanes, with the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage increasing to 6.72% and inventory reaching a 15-year high of 481,000 units. Economists had forecast a decline but not to this extent, and the sales pace would take 9.5 months to clear the existing supply of houses.

images.alt_text: House prices jumped 0.7 per cent on a month-on-month basis after an upwardly revised 0.4 per cent rise in August.

site_title: Prosecution proceeds on 42 charges against US$1.1 billion nickel-trading scam accused Ng Yu Zhi
summary: Prosecutors in Singapore are proceeding with 42 charges against Ng Yu Zhi, accused of a US$1.1 billion nickel-trading scam, including cheating Vickers Venture Partners founder Finian Tan of US$19.2 million. Ng, 37, faces over 20 years in jail if convicted and has 105 charges against him. The trial, which began on Tuesday, will last over 50 days. Ng's lawyers have changed, and he has had his bail revoked. The prosecution will open its case on Wednesday, with the hearing scheduled to continue after a court vacation.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open higher as investors assess Trump’s tariff threats
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising as investors assessed Donald Trump's tariff threats on top trade partners. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 121.7 points, or 0.27%, at the open to 44,614.89. Despite the decline, the S&P 500 rose 12.7 points, or 0.21%, to 6,000.03, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 54.2 points, or 0.28%, to 19,109.082. Investors are awaiting the release of Federal Reserve meeting minutes and remain optimistic about the market's performance.

site_title: Opec+ begins talks on delaying oil production restart again
summary: Opec+ nations have begun discussing delaying the planned 180,000 barrel-a-day oil production increase in January, amid signs of a global oversupply. The group may also postpone further hikes, potentially for several months. Global oil markets are forecasted to tip into a renewed glut next year, with prices expected to slump from $73 to $60. Traders expect the production increase to be delayed, potentially until the second quarter, due to concerns over a global oversupply. Opec+ nations will meet online on December 1 to discuss oil market stability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D printed oil pump jack is seen in front of displayed OPEC logo in this illustration picture, April 14, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo

site_title: Dow offers investors a chance to diversify in US’ post-election upswing
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average is seen as a potential investment opportunity as the Republican Party is set to take full control of the US government. Historically, the Dow performs better under a fully Republican administration. George Ferraz, intermediary relationship manager at State Street Global Advisors, suggests the Dow can serve as a "good diversifier" for investors' portfolios.

site_title: US monthly house prices rise strongly in September
summary: US single-family house prices rose 0.7% in September, following a 0.4% increase in August. This marks a 4.4% annual gain, matching the revised August figure. The slowdown in growth pace is attributed to rising mortgage rates, which have erased September's decline. The average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rate is just below 7%, following a recent jump. Strong monthly gains were reported in the Mountain, New England, East South Central, and Middle Atlantic regions, with the Middle Atlantic region experiencing the highest annual price gain.

images.alt_text: Real estate owners appear to be celebrating the return of one of their own, a businessman whose desire for a flourishing economy would–they expect–outweigh his less productive instincts.
