Builders have blamed uncertainty over the presidential election for restraining sales recently, along with mortgage rates that rebounded after hitting a two-year low in September.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose five basis points to 6.86 per cent in the week ended Nov 8, the highest since July.
MBA’s gauge of refinancing dropped for a sixth week to the lowest level since May, marking the longest losing streak since April 2022.

site_title: US consumer confidence rises to highest in more than a year
summary: US consumer confidence rose to its highest level in over a year in November, driven by optimism about the economy and labor market following Donald Trump's election victory. The Conference Board's gauge of confidence increased 2.1 points to 111.7, with present conditions rising to an eight-month high and expectations edging to an almost three-year high. Inflation expectations dropped to the lowest level since March 2020, while job market conditions remained favorable, despite some households remaining financially stretched due to elevated interest rates.

images.alt_text: House prices jumped 0.7 per cent on a month-on-month basis after an upwardly revised 0.4 per cent rise in August.

By concentrating on the issues facing small, young businesses – as opposed to large, well-established corporations with a lot of lobbyists – the incoming administration could foster innovation and support business formation.

While wages have grown faster than inflation, the trend has been much less positive since 2019 than it was in the years before. Real median household incomes have fallen since 2019, and the poverty rate has risen.
Home sales jumped 3.4 per cent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.96 million units.
Job growth likely rebounded in November after abruptly slowing last month amid hurricanes and strikes.

site_title: UK to raise £4.25 billion in first debt syndication since budget
summary: The UK's Debt Management Office has successfully syndicated a £4.25 billion bond, the first since the budget in October, with over £65 billion in orders received. The bond is priced at 4 basis points over comparable notes. This follows a one-year high in 10-year UK yields, which rose to 4.59% after the budget announcement. The sale is seen as a sign of strong demand for UK debt, with bookrunners Barclays, Bank of America, Citigroup, and NatWest Markets involved.

site_title: From tweets to trades: Heeding the risks of social media in investing
summary: A recent flash rally in GameStop's stock price highlights the speculative dangers of social media chatter, where algorithm-driven content personalization reinforces investors' views, exacerbating confirmation bias. Platforms like X and Reddit, particularly among younger retail investors, significantly shape market perceptions. To mitigate the impact of confirmation bias and echo chambers, investors should follow diverse perspectives, diversify Reddit communities, seek non-social media sources, and challenge personal beliefs. By adopting these strategies, investors can foster a more balanced and informed decision-making process, essential for navigating complex and rapidly evolving markets.

images.alt_text: GameStop has been struggling with declining sales in its primary business of selling new and used video game discs due to a shift towards digital downloads and game streaming.
The meme stock mania was fuelled in part by investors stuck at home during the pandemic.

site_title: Citigroup slashes promotions as it seeks to overhaul bank, FT reports
summary: Citigroup is cutting year-end promotions by up to 75% as part of its long-term restructuring plan, aiming to reduce its workforce by 20,000 over the next two years. The bank's CEO, Jane Fraser, is implementing a sweeping overhaul to improve performance, cut costs, and simplify its businesses. Managers have been told that around 2,000 employees could get promotions with pay hikes limited to 15%, down from around 8,000 in previous rounds. The move is part of Fraser's efforts to increase accountability, invest in data reporting, and reduce high-risk processes.

site_title: TPG is said in advanced talks to buy Siemens Gamesa India assets
summary: TPG is in advanced talks to acquire the Indian wind energy assets of Siemens Gamesa's Gamesa unit for over $300 million, according to sources. The assets include operation, maintenance, and manufacturing of wind turbines, and other bidders remain interested despite TPG's outbidding. Talks are ongoing, with no final decisions made yet.

site_title: Manchester United posts smaller Q1 loss on cost cuts
summary: Manchester United reported a smaller adjusted net loss of £349,000 (S$591,428) for the first quarter, down from a loss of £8.6 million a year earlier. The club attributed the improvement to cost cuts and favourable exchange rates. Revenue fell 9% to £143.1 million. The club's new owner, British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe, committed £237 million for infrastructure improvements, but the project will likely involve public-private partnerships. Manchester United aims to revitalize the Old Trafford area and improve on-field performance under Ratcliffe's stewardship.

images.alt_text: Manchester United's net loss widened to £113.2 million (US$148.14 million) in the year ended Jun 30, from £28.7 million a year earlier.

site_title: Nvidia shows AI model that can modify voices, generate novel sounds
summary: Nvidia unveiled a new AI model, Fugatto, that can generate music and audio from text descriptions, including novel sounds. The model can modify existing audio and create new sounds, such as transforming a piano line into a human-sung line. Nvidia plans not to publicly release the technology, citing concerns about potential misuse. The move joins other AI technologies, such as those from Runway and Meta, which can generate audio or video from text prompts, raising questions about the ethics of AI-generated content.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A person walks pass a Nvidia logo at Computex in Taipei, Taiwan June 5, 2024. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo

site_title: Singapore-China ties ‘especially valuable’ amid uncertain global environment, says SM Lee in meeting with President Xi
summary: Singaporean Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of bilateral cooperation with China, citing the uncertain global environment. During a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, Lee noted that like-minded countries should work together to develop cooperation for the benefit of their peoples. Xi praised Lee as the Chinese people's "old friend" and good friend, highlighting the value of their relationship. This meeting underscores the growing strategic partnership between Singapore and China.

site_title: Singapore real estate players markedly more upbeat in Q3: NUS poll
summary: Singapore real estate players are more optimistic in Q3, with the Composite Sentiment Index rising to 5.9, above the neutral score of 5.0. This is attributed to easing interest rates and a brighter economic outlook. However, concerns over excessive supply of new properties and a global slowdown are major risk factors in the next half-year, with 67.7% of respondents citing a slowdown as the top potential risk. The survey also shows that some sectors, such as suburban residential and hotel/serviced apartments, are expected to perform better in the future.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Brokered by Edmund Tie & Co, the sale of Thomson View is the largest en bloc deal done in Singapore since the S$890 million sale of Chuan Park got the go-ahead in May 2023.
Together, the three sites potentially yield 1,340 private residential units.
SM Lee (centre, left) meeting He Lifeng, Vice Premier of China's State Council.

site_title: Compelling opportunities in AI, but will return on investment catch up?
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming industries and creating new opportunities for investors, with major tech companies investing heavily in AI research and development. The growth of generative AI, particularly in healthcare, has led to improved productivity and new applications, such as personalized recommendations and predictive maintenance. However, the high cost of GPUs and potential regulatory risks may impact returns on investment. Despite these challenges, long-term returns on invested capital (ROIC) are expected to strengthen as AI adoption grows and new monetizable applications emerge.

images.alt_text: Nvidia’s version generates sound effects and music from a text description, including novel sounds such as making a trumpet bark like a dog.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, November 26, 2024
summary: US President Trump vows to impose 10% tariffs on China, 25% tariffs on Mexico and Canada, amid rising tensions. Meanwhile, Maybank's Q3 net profit rises 7.6% to RM2.5 billion. Global airfares are expected to increase by 5-10% in 2025, according to Amex GBT. The Singapore shares slipped 0.5% amid mixed Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares slip amid mixed Asia markets after Trump threatens tariffs; STI down 0.5%
Donald Trump's announcement fuelled a sell-off across most Asian markets, though Hong Kong and Shanghai advanced in early exchanges.

Maybank's higher earnings comes amid strong growth in non-interest income, led by improved core fees and insurance performance.
The key drivers pushing up airfares include rising wages and staffing shortages.

site_title: Maybank’s Q3 net profit rises 7.6% to RM2.5 billion
summary: Maybank's net profit for Q3 2024 rose 7.6% to RM2.5 billion, driven by strong growth in non-interest income, particularly improved core fees and insurance performance. The lender's profit before tax increased 7.8% to RM3.4 billion, while net operating income grew 7.1% to RM7.2 billion. Maybank plans to leverage advanced digital capabilities and improve customer relationships to drive growth, with its wealth management, bancassurance, and global banking mid-market segments contributing to its growth.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Maybank attributed the performance to strong gains at its insurance segment and operating income, which offset a decline in net interest income.
Alvin Lee, country CEO of Maybank Singapore, says increasing SME support requires a greater risk appetite, but notes that this aligns with positive macroeconomic conditions.
Maybank targets to achieve a return on equity of between 10.5 per cent and 11 per cent for FY2023.

site_title: Macquarie initiates coverage on 11 S-Reits with top picks including data centre plays
summary: Macquarie Research initiated coverage on 11 Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits), naming top picks including data centre plays. The broker favors industrial, retail, and office sectors, which can weather a climate of moderated interest rate cut expectations. Macquarie analysts predict a potential upside of 20-60% for top picks such as CapitaLand Ascendas Reit and Keppel DC Reit, with a yield of around 6% for these counters.

images.alt_text: XX

site_title: Abercrombie & Fitch lifts annual sales forecast on strong holiday demand
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch has lifted its annual sales forecast, expecting fiscal 2024 net sales to rise 14-15% due to strong holiday demand for its namesake label and Hollister brand. The company also named insider Robert Ball as chief financial officer. This follows a strategy of refreshing product lines and focusing on smaller luxuries.

site_title: SingPost should quickly cut borrowings by divesting its non-core properties now
summary: SingPost posted a 97.3% increase in earnings to S$22.6 million for the first half of 2025, but high finance expenses eroded the profit. The group's borrowing costs rose due to additional loans for its Australian business, with non-current borrowings totaling S$886.2 million. SingPost should quickly divest non-core properties, such as the S$1.1 billion SingPost Centre, to reduce debt and bring down interest payments. The company's cash reserves are S$428.4 million, and divesting the real estate could generate profits and cash inflows.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
ST20240503_202421361534 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the Singapore Post (SingPost) logo on the SingPost Centre building on May 3, 2024.
SingPost's property leasing segment largely comprises SingPost Centre, where occupancy rates are up as at end-September compared to end-March 2024.
SingPost also intends to continue seeking opportunities for mergers and acquisitions, and future liquidity options.
SingPost Centre at 10 Eunos Road 8 near Paya Lebar MRT station on Nov 03, 2020. Can be used for stories on mail, postage, post, postman, courier, parcel, envelope, stamp and delivery.
SingPost considers divesting S$1.1 billion SingPost Centre and floating Australian business

site_title: ADB approves US$500 million loan for Philippines’ climate change efforts
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has approved a US$500 million loan to support the Philippines' climate change efforts. The loan aims to accelerate reforms in sectors such as agriculture, natural resources, energy, and transport to make them climate-resilient and low-carbon. The Philippines, ranked as the most at-risk country globally in the 2022-2024 World Risk Index, will utilize the loan to tackle its high disaster risk from earthquakes, cyclones, floods, droughts, and sea-level rise.

images.alt_text: BSP Governor Eli Remolona Jr (centre) sees inflation staying within the 2 to 4 per cent target this month, giving authorities leeway for easing.

The Philippines expects to lose 5.9 billion pesos (S$134 million) in tax revenue from the new law from 2025 to 2028, according to a document prepared by President Ferdinand Marcos Jr's communications office.
The US is among the Philippines’ biggest export markets and sources of investments from abroad.
The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas has delivered two quarter-point cuts since August to bring its key interest rate to 6 per cent.
Inflation had decelerated to 1.9 per cent in September, the slowest since May 2020 and below the central bank’s 2 to 4 per cent target range.

site_title: Finding a haven in selected currencies
summary: Investors are seeking safe-haven assets during market volatility, with the US dollar, yen, and Swiss franc performing well in uncertain times. These currencies offer key safety characteristics, including political stability, economic strength, and low inflation. While there is no "perfect" safe-haven asset, they can add stability to a portfolio and help mitigate weakness in risky assets. A diversified portfolio incorporating safe-haven assets can be a useful tool for investors, but it's essential to assess each incident separately and not wait too long to take profit on gains.

images.alt_text: The new twenty dollar bill is seen on the presses at the Bureau of Printing and Engraving in Washington, DC, August 21, 2003.  Photographer:  Dennis Brack/ Bloomberg News.
Gold premiums in India dipped last week as rising local prices cooled demand, while bullion interest in China and other Asian markets stayed muted.

site_title: Singapore’s rich warm to ultra-luxe hybrid electric vehicles – as they still have traditional engines
summary: Bugatti has unveiled its first plug-in hybrid hypercar, the Tourbillon, priced at 3.8 million euros (S$5.4 million) and capable of reaching 445 km/h. The move follows other ultra-luxury brands like Bentley and Lamborghini, which have also launched PHEV versions of their models in Singapore. Despite the growing popularity of electric vehicles, ultra-luxury buyers prefer PHEVs for their emotional appeal and brand recognition, with some brands pushing back their EV-related targets in favor of PHEVs. The market trend is expected to continue with more PHEV models being launched in the future.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
As PHEV technology improves, it could offer consumers and business owners an alternative to full EVs long into the future, even in Singapore.
Bentley Continental GT Speed PHEV launched in Singapore on Nov 20, 2024
The Yutong C11H plug-in hybrid bus is an example of extended-range electric vehicle technology that is gaining ground in China.
Industry observers attribute the plunge in ultra-luxury car registrations to higher taxes on more expensive cars and reduced rebates that mean higher cost of ownership.
Million Air’s facilities provide private jets with fuelling, hangaring and aircraft servicing at general aviation airports.
A 1955 Ferrari 410 Sport Spider sold for US$12.9 million including fees, the third-highest sale of the weekend.
Like many EVs, the D9 has seamless and strong acceleration, yet it’s preternaturally quiet even for a battery-powered car.
The price tag is well above the average sale price of around 350,000 euros, including extras, for a Ferrari in the first quarter of this year, and many rival luxury EVs.

site_title: Indonesia rejects Apple’s US$100 million investment offer
summary: Indonesia has rejected an Apple US$100 million investment proposal to lift a ban on iPhone 16 sales, citing the company's failure to meet local investment regulations requiring 40% of phones to be made from local parts. Industry Minister Agus Gumiwang Kartasasmita stated that Apple has not invested in production facilities in Indonesia, unlike in other countries, and urged the company to set up a factory in Indonesia to meet the fairness principles.

images.alt_text: An employee of an authorised dealer selling Apple products opens a shop in Jakarta on October 29, 2024. Indonesia has prohibited the marketing and sale of the iPhone 16 model over Apple's failure to meet local investment regulations, according to its industry ministry. (Photo by BAY ISMOYO / AFP)

site_title: Duo charged with false trading of EuroSports shares under Securities and Futures Act
summary: Two individuals, Wong Chow Lin and Gillian Isabel Siow Siang Sok, have been charged with false trading of EuroSports Global shares under the Securities and Futures Act in Singapore. They allegedly traded in shares to push up prices on 77 days between 2017 and 2018, with Wong facing up to 7 years imprisonment and a fine of up to S$250,000. Siow, Wong's trading representative, was charged with aiding Wong in false trading, also carrying a maximum penalty of 7 years imprisonment and a fine of up to S$250,000.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
MAS says: "Chong’s offences have given MAS reason to believe that he will not perform financial advisory and capital markets services honestly.”

site_title: Japan PM Ishiba calls on businesses to offer big wage rises next year
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has vowed to push for significant wage hikes at next year's "shunto" negotiations, following the largest pay hike in 33 years. The country's largest labour union group is seeking a 5% wage increase in 2025, while economists doubt another such bump is realistic. Ishiba also pledged to lay out specific measures to achieve a 42% increase in the average minimum wage by the end of the decade, aiming to offset rising prices and increase spending on welfare.

images.alt_text: Wages are key to how soon the Bank of Japan could raise interest rates again.

site_title: World's oldest man dies at 112: Guinness World Records
summary: John Tinniswood, the world's oldest man at 112, has died in a care home in Southport, England. Born in Liverpool in 1912, Tinniswood attributed his longevity to "pure luck." He lived through both World Wars, held administrative roles in the Royal Army Pay Corps and oil giants Shell and BP, and was a lifelong supporter of Liverpool football club. Tinniswood's family said his last day was surrounded by music and love, and he advised moderation in all things to stay healthy. He holds the record, surpassing the previous record holder, Juan Vicente Perez.

images.alt_text: The former US Army soldier, whose business began with The GI’s Guide to Travelling in Europe at 50 US cents apiece in the mid-1950s, became a household name for any vacationer seeking an affordable trip abroad.

(FILES) French singer Charles Dumont poses during a portrait session at his apartment in Paris on March 19, 2018. Musician Charles Dumont, composer of Edith Piaf's legendary "Je ne regrette rien", died in the night from November 17, 2024 to November 18, 2024 in Paris at the age of 95, his partner Florence announced to AFP. This singer-songwriter, who had also collaborated with Barbra Streisand, died following a long illness at his home. (Photo by CHRISTOPHE ARCHAMBAULT / AFP)

site_title: Singapore’s factory output growth down to 1.2% in October, misses expectations
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 1.2% in October, below the 2.6% expansion predicted by private-sector economists, and excluding the biomedical sector, it grew just 0.4% year-over-year. The biomedical manufacturing cluster drove the slower performance, with pharmaceutical output decelerating to 10.5% growth. Despite this, growth momentum in trade-related sectors is expected to be sustained, driven by the electronics cycle, with some front-loading of exports ahead of potential US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The Q3 figure brings GDP growth for the first nine months of 2024 to a “better-than-expected” 3.8 per cent, said the Ministry of Trade and Industry.
Food inflation was unchanged at 2.6 per cent, as the prices of non-cooked food and food services rose at a similar pace in September and October.
Growth in the electronics sector was held back mainly by the infocomms and consumer electronics segment, even as the computer peripherals and data storage and semiconductor segment pulled ahead.

site_title: Bitcoin retreats from US$100,000 in worst spell since Trump’s win
summary: Bitcoin has retreated from a record high of US$100,000, marking its longest losing streak since Donald Trump's US election victory in 2016. The digital asset dropped 6% over three days, trading at US$94,000 on Tuesday. The decline is attributed to a bout of risk aversion following Trump's vow of additional tariffs on China, Canada, and Mexico. Despite this, analysts remain optimistic about the market, with some predicting a continuation of bullish sentiment into 2025.

images.alt_text: The digital asset fell as low as US$95,776 on Sunday after coming within US$300 of the six-figure milestone on Friday.

site_title: Qualcomm’s takeover interest in Intel is said to cool
summary: Qualcomm's interest in acquiring Intel has cooled due to the complexities associated with acquiring the entire company. Sources familiar with the matter stated that the difficulties made a deal less attractive to Qualcomm. It remains possible that Qualcomm may consider acquiring specific parts of Intel or rekindling its interest in the future.

images.alt_text: Qualcomm is in a protracted legal dispute with Arm, whose technology Qualcomm uses in almost all its flagship products
Arm says that the move is a breach of Qualcomm’s license and is demanding that the company destroy Nuvia designs that were created before the Nuvia acquisition.
Qualcomm’s products dominate the market for mobile devices that use the Android operating system.

A combination of Qualcomm and Intel, whose products are key to the digital framework supporting everyday life, would almost certainly draw intense scrutiny from antitrust regulators in the US and around the world.

site_title: Haidilao operator Super Hi swings back to black with US$37.7 million Q3 net profit
summary: Super Hi International, the operator of Haidilao hotpot outlets, reported a net profit of US$37.7 million for the third quarter, reversing a net loss of US$1.4 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 14.6% to US$198.6 million, driven by business expansion and higher dining-out demand. The company operates 121 Haidilao outlets across 13 countries, with a 14.5% increase in restaurant operations revenue.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Haidilao family gets option to buy S$42m bungalow in Gallop Road
Famous hotpot chain founder buys GCB
Luckin Coffee, with more than 20,000 domestic stores, has only opened about 40 locations in Singapore.
Putien is a brightly lit, family-style Fujian eatery with a cheerful, comfort food vibe that makes you feel right at home.
Haidilao has one of the biggest international footprints among Chinese food and beverage chains.

site_title: Sri Lanka to swap US$12.6 billion of bonds for new notes
summary: Sri Lanka will swap $12.55 billion of defaulted dollar bonds for new notes, a milestone in its debt restructuring efforts. Holders can exchange their existing notes until December 12. The move aims to restore access to international markets and reduce debt servicing repayments by $9.5 billion over a four-year IMF program. The restructuring is a step toward completing the nation's $43 billion foreign debt restructuring, with the IMF considering flexibility in its program as the government unwinds fiscal austerity measures.

images.alt_text: This handout photograph taken on September 25, 2024, and released by Sri Lanka's President Office shows the country's newly elected President Anura Kumara Dissanayake, as he addresses the nation in Colombo. Sri Lanka's new president called on September 25, for restarting talks with the IMF "immediately" over a $2.9 billion bailout that threw a lifeline to his bankrupt country but imposed painful austerity. The change was largely driven by a slowing in non-food price inflation that dipped to minus 2.3 per cent in October from minus 0.7 per cent in September.

site_title: US lawmakers warn Hong Kong becoming financial crime hub
summary: US lawmakers have warned that Hong Kong is becoming a financial crime hub, citing money laundering, sanctions evasions, and the reported funneling of banned technology to Russia. The bipartisan committee has called on Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen to reevaluate Hong Kong's unique trade privileges, which treat the financial hub as distinct from the rest of China, due to the erosion of its semi-autonomy and judicial independence since Beijing's national security law was imposed in 2020.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has been seeking to bring money and rich families to the financial hub through tax concessions and talent programmes, after strong outflows during the pandemics.

site_title: Global airfares set to rise yet again in 2025, Amex GBT says
summary: Global airfares are expected to rise again in 2025, with most routes seeing fare increases, although the size of the increases will vary greatly by region. North America and Europe are forecast to see modest 2% increases, while Asia and Australasia are expected to see rises of around 14%. Rising wages, staffing shortages, and supply-chain disruptions are key drivers of the price increases. Fares may return to pre-pandemic highs, with routes between Europe and Asia seeing significant jumps.

images.alt_text: Airline CEOs are blaming aviation suppliers for cancelled flights and reduced industry capacity.
Airlines and the Biden administration have repeatedly clashed in recent years.

site_title: Accidental talent factory: How ChildAid shapes the stars of tomorrow
summary: ChildAid, a charity concert started by two Singaporean newspapers in 2005, has grown into a platform for young talents to shine globally. Since its inception, the event has raised over $30 million to support disadvantaged children. Notable alumni include pianist Jessie Meng, who became the youngest Steinway Artist at 17, and singer Nathan Hartono, who achieved international success. ChildAid's mission is to provide opportunities for young performers, with a focus on diversity and inclusion. This year's edition, ChildAid 2024, will feature interactive elements, including AI technology, and will be held at the Esplanade Theatre on November 29 and 30.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Singer Amni Musfirah during a preview of the National Day Parade held at the Padang on Aug 3.

site_title: ‘No one will win a trade war,’ China says after Trump tariff threat
summary: China's Embassy in Washington stated that neither the US nor China would win a trade war, following US President-elect Donald Trump's threat to impose 10% tariffs on all Chinese imports to curb the flow of fentanyl into the US. China has taken steps to combat drug trafficking, with progress made in cooperation since an agreement between US and Chinese leaders last year. The Chinese side claims it is working to shut down illicit chemical production and has tightened controls on fentanyl precursors.

images.alt_text: Many economists have warned that tariffs would hurt growth and push up inflation, since they are primarily paid by importers bringing the goods into the US, who often pass those costs on to consumers.

Donald Trump was accused of conspiring to overturn the results of the 2020 election he lost to Joe Biden and removing large quantities of top secret documents after leaving the White House, but the cases never came to trial.
Donald Trump has been a recent and vocal proponent of digital assets such as Bitcoin.

Experts note that President-elect Donald Trump tends to favour bilateral trade agreements and may try to cut deals with individual European countries.

site_title: Nissan falls on report of further production cuts, tariff threat
summary: Nissan shares fell 3.9% after reports the automaker plans to cut production in the US, with plans to build 100,000 fewer vehicles at its Mississippi and Tennessee plants. The move comes as President-elect Donald Trump threatens to impose steep tariffs on US imports from Mexico and Canada, where Nissan has factories. The cuts will affect models including the Frontier, Rogue, and Pathfinder. Nissan shares are down 30% this year, following a decline in profit and an outdated lineup.

images.alt_text: NIssan earlier this month announced a plan to cut 9,000 jobs worldwide after posting worse-than-expected half-year earnings.
Roughly 1,000 US employees are set to leave Nissan by the end of this year as a result of the early retirements.
Britain is likely to miss the 2024 targets set by the ZEV mandate, a trade body warned last month.
Nissan has sufficient liquidity, with over 1.3 trillion yen in cash on a net basis in its automobile business at end-September.

site_title: Trump vows to slap 10% tariffs on China, 25% tariffs on Mexico, Canada
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump announced plans to impose 25% tariffs on goods from Mexico and Canada, and 10% tariffs on imports from China, citing the illegal drug trade and immigration. Economists warn that tariffs would hurt growth and push up inflation, but Trump's inner circle sees them as a bargaining chip to push for more favorable trade terms and bring back manufacturing jobs. The move is expected to have significant implications for global trade and the US economy.

images.alt_text: Experts note that President-elect Donald Trump tends to favour bilateral trade agreements and may try to cut deals with individual European countries.
Stocks and bond yields begin their ascend in early October, when Wall Street expected that Donald Trump would win the US election.

Donald Trump was accused of conspiring to overturn the results of the 2020 election he lost to Joe Biden and removing large quantities of top secret documents after leaving the White House, but the cases never came to trial.
Donald Trump has been a recent and vocal proponent of digital assets such as Bitcoin.
US President Joe Biden meets with US President-elect Donald Trump in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, US, Nov 13, 2024.

site_title: UK shop prices fall less sharply in November: survey
summary: UK shop prices fell 0.6% in the 12 months to November, a less sharp decline than in October, according to the British Retail Consortium. This follows a 0.8% drop in the previous month. Consumer price inflation rose to 2.3% in October, largely due to energy price increases. The Bank of England cut interest rates to 4.75% but warned of potential stronger price growth. Shop price inflation may signal an end to falling prices, with staff costs expected to rise.

site_title: Top Hong Kong court backs housing rights for gay couples
summary: Hong Kong's top court has upheld rulings granting public housing and inheritance rights to married same-sex couples, citing equality provisions in the city's mini-constitution. The unanimous ruling rejected government arguments that same-sex and opposite-sex couples were not comparable in terms of their rights. This is the latest legal victory for Hong Kong's LGBTQ+ community, following earlier rulings in 2023. The court's decision comes after the lower Court of Appeal upheld rulings granting subsidized housing rights and inheritance rights to same-sex couples who married overseas.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong gay dating show aims to break down LGBT+ barriers
Hong Kong court ruling overturns anti-LGBT housing policy

site_title: StanChart is front-runner as dollar settlement bank in India hub
summary: Standard Chartered is set to become the settlement bank for real-time US dollar-denominated trades in India's GIFT City financial hub, according to sources. The Clearing Corp of India will start testing the new model by January, with a rollout planned for April. This move is expected to speed up transactions, particularly as foreigners show increasing interest in India and its sovereign bonds. The development comes as the Reserve Bank of India established a domestic non-deliverable forward market for derivatives settled in US dollars at GIFT City last year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Standard Chartered bank logo is seen at their headquarters in London, Britain, July 26, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Walmart, world’s biggest retailer, will curb diversity efforts
summary: Walmart, the world's largest retailer, is curbing diversity efforts, reversing previous commitments to diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives. The company will stop considering race and gender to boost diversity in supplier contracts, stop collecting demographic data, and curb racial equity training for staff. It will also review its support for Pride events and stop participating in LGBTQ advocacy group rankings. This move joins a growing list of businesses retreating from DEI programs targeted by conservative activists.

images.alt_text: Walmart said in the third quarter total e-commerce sales rose 27 per cent, compared to the 21 per cent in the prior quarter.
Walmart, the world’s biggest retailer, has slashed Christmas imports deeply, shipping at least 340,000 kilos of products described as “Christmas” goods into the US in the 12 months ending Sep 30.
The Waltons have longed ranked at or near the top of the world’s richest families, and currently have a total net worth of more than US$350 billion.

site_title: EV battery maker calls for cheaper EU energy to counter China
summary: LG Energy Solution, the EU's largest EV battery factory owner, urges the European Union to reduce energy costs to boost the strategic industry. The factory, near Wroclaw, Poland, operates at half capacity due to weaker EV demand, and LG Energy calls for priority access to cheap and green energy for key industries. The Polish government's focus on shielding households from high energy costs could hinder the growth of the industry, with LG Energy warning that competing with Chinese firms could be difficult without favorable energy prices.

images.alt_text: LG Energy as been grappling with dwindling orders for batteries as falling customer demand for EVs.
The supplier to carmakers including Tesla and GM has been facing challenges from declining EV sales and lower lithium prices, which are tied to its selling prices.
LG Energy supplies batteries to automakers such as Tesla and General Motors, and has been struggling to improve its earnings this year.
Carmakers are winding back their EV ambitions as demand wanes, leading to lower orders for batteries.

site_title: Vedanta plans to invest US$2 billion in Saudi copper projects
summary: Vedanta plans to invest $2 billion in Saudi copper projects, building a smelter and refinery with a capacity of 400,000 metric tons per year and a copper rod facility producing up to 300,000 tons per year. The investment is a significant boost for Saudi Arabia's efforts to become a global metals and mining hub, with demand for copper expected to jump over the next few years due to decarbonization efforts. Vedanta's CEO notes that copper prices are likely to increase to incentivize new production, and the company plans to partner with local firms to support the kingdom's economic diversification plan.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A bird flies by the Vedanta office building in Mumbai August 16, 2010. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo

site_title: Philippine VP denies assassination plot against Marcos
summary: Philippine Vice President Sara Duterte denied plotting to kill President Ferdinand Marcos, saying her comments about killing him, his wife, and cousin were an expression of "consternation" at the Marcos administration's failures. The country's justice department had issued a subpoena demanding her appearance at a formal inquiry, calling her a "self-confessed mastermind" of the alleged plot. Duterte's comments followed a heated press conference where she named the Marcos couple and her cousin as targets, sparking a government probe and allegations of drug addiction between the two families.

images.alt_text: epa11709043 Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. delivers a speech after signing two new maritime laws during ceremonies at the Malacanang Presidential Palace in Manila, Philippines, 08 November 2024. The Maritime Zones Law identifies the archipelagic baselines and internal waters of the Philippines, while the Archipelagic Sea Lanes Law defines sea lanes that vessels may legitimately take within Philippine waters. The new laws come in the midst of the Philippines’ ongoing territorial dispute with China in several areas of the South China Sea.  EPA-EFE/ROLEX DELA PENA

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding dips over 4% as volumes surge on married deals
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's shares fell 4.2% to S$2.52 in early trade on Tuesday, Nov 26, after 13 married deals totaling 52.8 million shares were executed before the opening bell. The company's share price recovered slightly to S$2.56 by midday, with 76.9 million shares traded. This is the most highly traded company in terms of volume, following a record 259.8 million shares transacted the previous day.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Roche to acquire cell therapy maker Poseida Therapeutics in US$1.5 billion deal
summary: Roche, a Swiss drugmaker, has agreed to acquire US-based cell therapy maker Poseida Therapeutics in a deal worth up to $1.5 billion. Roche will pay $9 per share plus contingent value rights up to $4 per share, with the deal expected to close in the first quarter of 2025. The acquisition aims to boost Roche's development pipeline in complex immune cell therapies against blood cancer. Poseida's portfolio includes allogeneic CAR-T cell therapies and genetic engineering platforms, which will complement Roche's oncology business.

images.alt_text: Roche will manufacture more diagnostic products in China and increase production capacity for medicines.

site_title: Japan competition authorities raid Amazon Japan: source
summary: Japan's Fair Trade Commission raided Amazon Japan's offices on suspicion of violating anti-monopoly laws. Amazon Japan is suspected of pressuring sellers to lower prices in exchange for advantageous placement on its site. This is the second time Amazon Japan has faced regulatory scrutiny, following a 2018 raid on suppliers. The investigation is likely to raise concerns about Amazon's favoritism towards its own brand products.

site_title: Rivian wins approval for US$6.6 billion loan for Georgia plant
summary: Rivian Automotive has received preliminary approval for a US$6.6 billion federal loan to support the construction of its delayed Georgia electric vehicle plant. The facility, built in two phases with annual capacity of 200,000 vehicles, will produce Rivian's midsize platform. The loan, from the Department of Energy's Advanced Technology Vehicle Manufacturing loan programme, is conditional on meeting technical, legal, environmental, and financial conditions. This is the third positive news for Rivian this month, following a settlement with Tesla and increased investment from Volkswagen.

site_title: Why real estate stocks took a hit as developers cheered Trump
summary: Real estate stocks plummeted 2.6% on the day after Donald Trump's reelection, with the largest US homebuilder, D.R. Horton, and commercial real estate services firm CBRE Group falling 3.8% and 4% respectively. Economists worry that an immigration crackdown will shrink the construction workforce, which relies heavily on foreign-born labor. Despite this, real estate owners are optimistic, citing hopes for tax cuts and deregulation, and some believe Trump's policies will benefit the industry. However, economists warn that comprehensive tariffs could slow the economy and dampen hopes for a recovery in home sales.

images.alt_text: Home financing costs are approaching 7 per cent amid strong economic data and Donald Trump’s election win.

site_title: Singapore shares slip amid mixed Asia markets after Trump threatens tariffs; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Tuesday, November 26, amid a mixed Asia market performance after US President-elect Donald Trump threatened to impose an extra 10% tariff on Chinese goods. Maritime vessel maker Yangzijiang Shipbuilding fell 3.8%, while Thai Beverage gained 1.9%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also experienced mixed results. Despite concerns, economists expect sustained growth momentum in trade-related sectors for the rest of 2024.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
STI falls despite Asia gains and RHB upgrading Singapore banking stocks

site_title: Thailand’s exports beat forecast in October, to exceed 2024 target
summary: Thailand's exports exceeded forecasts in October, growing 14.6% annually, beating the 2024 target. The commerce ministry expects strong final-quarter growth, with exports projected to increase by 4% for the year, surpassing the 2% target. Key sectors, including technology and farm products, drove the growth, while a trade deficit of $790 million was recorded in October. The ministry remains optimistic, with plans to discuss trade with the US, despite potential tariffs, and expects to beat its target despite US President-elect Donald Trump's pledge to tariffs on top trading partners.

images.alt_text: Workers inspect cars at BYD's first electric vehicle factory in Rayong, Thailand, July 4, 2024.

Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra said that Thailand must be prepared for investments, particularly in data centres and semiconductors, and emphasized the need to announce to the world that they are ready for future investments.
Exports, a key driver of the Thai economy, rose 11.4 per cent in August from a year earlier while imports were up 8.5 per cent, resulting in trade account surplus of US$2.4 billion.

site_title: Starbucks using pen and paper to track pay after vendor hack
summary: Starbucks is manually tracking employee schedules and pay after a ransomware attack at its third-party software supplier, Blue Yonder Group, disrupted its system. The attack, which occurred on November 21, has affected company-operated stores in the US and Canada, forcing Starbucks to resort to pen and paper methods. The company has assured workers that they will be compensated for scheduled shifts, but pay accuracy may differ from actual hours worked. Blue Yonder has notified affected customers and is working to resolve the issue, although a timeline for resolution has not been provided.

images.alt_text: Starbucks has faced pressure from activist Elliott Investment Management, which wants it to commit to reviewing its Chinese business.
Starbucks’ operations are under scrutiny following a sales slump that led to the abrupt ouster of chief executive officer Laxman Narasimhan.
Some investors are sceptical of Starbucks’ prospects, even with Niccol in charge.
Starbucks is the latest company to shift from carrots to sticks in the ongoing return-to-office battle that has been playing out at workplaces.

site_title: Addvalue seeks at least US$2.1 million from Chinese software company
summary: Addvalue Tech has commenced arbitration proceedings in Hong Kong against Chinese software company Xepic, claiming at least US$2.1 million in damages for the wrongful termination or repudiation of contracts. The company, which specializes in mobile satellite communications, says the dispute is related to the production of field programmable gate arrays-based products and technical services. Addvalue expects the arbitration to have a minimal impact on its financial position and is working closely with its lawyers to enforce and protect its rights.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Singapore Exchange puts issuers that do not meet the criteria on watch list in its efforts to improve the overall quality of listed companies.
A pre-market purchase of 30 million Addvalue shares lifted the stock's share price in early trade on Tuesday.
Addvalue Technologies' initial orders totalling US$1.1 million are expected to be mostly fulfilled within the current financial year, it said.

site_title: Gold falls further on stronger US dollar, easing geopolitical tensions
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $2,621.06 per ounce, their lowest in over a week, due to a stronger US dollar and reports of a potential Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire easing safe-haven demand. The US dollar rose after US President-elect Donald Trump threatened Canada and Mexico with tariffs, reducing gold's appeal. Markets estimate a 55.9% chance of a US Federal Reserve rate cut in December, despite some Fed officials expressing openness to further rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Gold premiums in India dipped last week as rising local prices cooled demand, while bullion interest in China and other Asian markets stayed muted.

site_title: Food inflation in Canada outpaces wage gains, fuels worker angst
summary: Canada's food prices have risen 20% over the past three years, outpacing wage gains of 12%. This disparity has fueled labor unrest, with workers striking over pay demands that reflect their eroded purchasing power. Key labor actions include rail, dock, and postal workers' strikes, with union demands seeking double-digit pay increases. The strikes, partly driven by outdated contracts, have disrupted supply chains and highlighted the growing worker angst in the country.

images.alt_text: Investors have set aside expectations for another unusually large half-percentage-point rate cut by the Bank of Canada next month, after the central bank cut by that magnitude in October.
Transactions surged 7.7 per cent in October from a month earlier to reach the highest level since April 2022, according to data released on Friday (Nov 15) by the Canadian Real Estate Association.
The Port of Montreal is closed after terminal operators shut down operations over a labour dispute with the Canadian Union of Public Employees.

site_title: US-Google face off as ad tech antitrust trial comes to close
summary: The US government alleges that Google controls the auction-style system for online advertising, allowing it to charge higher prices to advertisers and sending less revenue to publishers. Google denies the allegations, arguing that the display ads at issue are just a small share of the ad tech business and that the plaintiffs' definition of the market ignores ads on search results, apps, and social media platforms. A judge is expected to deliver a swift opinion, with the outcome likely to be appealed and potentially go to the US Supreme Court.

US Justice Department demanded Google must promptly and fully divest its Chrome browser to a buyer approved by the government.
Australia is following a number of other countries that have attempted to restrict access to social media for children, with mixed success.
Google is far from the only company trying to keep newer forms of communication out of the courtroom.

site_title: Australian stock exchange targets 2029 for phase two of trading software overhaul
summary: The Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) has set a 2029 timeline for the second phase of its clearing and settlement software overhaul, replacing its ageing all-in-one Clearing House Electronic Subregister System (Chess) software with blockchain-based technology. The project's costs are projected to range between A$270 million and A$320 million. The first release, the clearing service, is expected to be delivered in 2026, with the settlement and sub-register services to follow. The decision comes after extensive industry consultation and was made amid a lawsuit filed by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission over delays.

site_title: URA launches three sale sites at Media Circle, Bayshore Road
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched three residential land parcels under the confirmed list of the 2024 Government Land Sales (GLS) programme. The sites, located at Media Circle and Bayshore Road, offer a 99-year lease period and are part of a total of 5,050 residential plots set to be released. The sites are zoned for residential use with commercial space on the first floor, and their prices have not been disclosed.

In an environment where prices in both the private and public markets appear out of reach for many, extraordinary transactions can create much instability, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Sembcorp clinches 300 MW wind-solar hybrid power project from India’s state-run power producer
summary: Sembcorp Industries has secured a 300 MW wind-solar hybrid power project from India's state-run power producer NTPC. The project, expected to be completed within 24 months, will increase Sembcorp's renewables capacity in India to 5.4 GW. Sembcorp will sell power output to NTPC under a 25-year contract. The project is funded through a mix of internal funds and debt and is in line with the company's business operations, with no impact on earnings per share or net tangible assets.

site_title: EU proposes to sanction Chinese firms aiding Russian war effort
summary: The European Union is proposing sanctions on several Chinese firms accused of aiding Russia's war effort, including the development of attack drones against Ukraine. The EU's executive arm, the European Commission, is also considering restrictions on Russian oil tankers to curb Moscow's ability to circumvent existing measures. The proposals, which require backing from all 27 EU member states, come as Group of Seven foreign ministers are set to pledge "appropriate measures" against countries supporting Russia's war effort.

images.alt_text: Plans to ship cognac in containers and bottle it in China rather than France were discussed by industry body Maisons de Cognac.

The EU launched an anti-subsidy investigation into imports of Chinese-made battery EVs last year and in October voted for tariffs on those vehicles.
BYD’s European registrations jumped 162 per cent in September from a year earlier, to 4,376 vehicles, according to Jato.

site_title: China’s Huawei launches ‘milestone’ smartphone with homegrown OS
summary: Huawei has launched its first smartphone with a fully homegrown operating system, HarmonyOS Next, marking a significant challenge to Apple's iOS and Google's Android in the mobile market. The Mate 70 devices require a complete rewiring of all apps, a key test for the company's new OS. This launch comes after Huawei bounced back from grueling US sanctions, with soaring sales. The company aims to challenge the dominance of Western tech giants, with HarmonyOS Next expected to power the Mate 70 devices.

site_title: Singapore’s private home market closes 2024 on a high; will late-year burst fizzle out?
summary: Singapore's private home market ended 2024 on a high note, with new home sales jumping in November after a record low earlier in the year. However, analysts question whether this momentum will sustain into 2025, citing market-cooling measures and the lack of state land sales. Despite this, sentiment appears to be improving, and prices are not expected to climb much higher next year. The fourth quarter's surge may be a one-time event, and the market's performance in 2025 will depend on various factors, including interest rates and demand for prime projects.

site_title: Barclays to add Singapore as private bank booking centre by 2026
summary: Barclays plans to add Singapore as its second booking centre for private bank operations in Asia Pacific by 2026, marking a return to the wealth hub. The London-based firm currently runs booking centres in six locations, including India, the UK, and Switzerland. The move aims to capture strong global and regional inflows, particularly from China, the Middle East, and other parts of the world. Barclays' private bank client assets and liabilities rose to £202 billion as of September, and the bank expects to quadruple its regional assets by the end of 2028.

Sembcorp Industries awarded a 300 megawatt wind-solar hybrid power project from NTPC in India. The project, funded through internal funds and debt, is expected to have minimal impact on Sembcorp's earnings per share or net tangible assets.

site_title: What would it take for Singapore’s office decentralisation to succeed?
summary: Singapore's push to decentralize commercial offices outside the Central Business District (CBD) faces challenges, despite over three decades of efforts. Despite 66.3% of office space remaining in the CBD, areas like Paya Lebar, Thomson/Novena, and Buona Vista/one-north are gaining popularity due to excellent amenities and transport infrastructure. To succeed, experts suggest that the CBD must decline, and decentralization is more likely to work with a growing population and a sudden spike in the working population. Landlords can encourage decentralization by attracting anchor tenants and offering lifestyle options and incentives.

site_title: PropertyBT: CICT’s big bet on Singapore’s office and retail future
summary: CICT, Singapore's biggest Reit, made a major bet by acquiring 50% of the iconic Ion Orchard mall, aiming to capture the luxury retail market. The trust's CEO, Tony Tan, discusses the strategy to navigate the challenging office supply and demand dynamics in Singapore. Amid a volatile interest rate environment, CICT's move is seen as an opportune buy, with more S-Reits expected to make similar acquisitions.

site_title: Japan’s corporate service inflation steady, keeps alive BOJ rate-hike prospect
summary: The Bank of Japan's services producer price index rose 2.9% in October from a year earlier, accelerating from a 2.8% gain in September. This steady inflation rate reinforces the central bank's view that rising wages are driving price hikes, potentially justifying further interest rate hikes in December. The BOJ will closely watch this data, along with other inflation indicators, at its next policy meeting, with some analysts expecting a rate hike from the current 0.25%.

site_title: US: Dow closes at record as market applauds Trump Treasury pick
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at a record high of 44,736.57 on Monday, following President-elect Donald Trump's pick for Treasury secretary, Scott Bessent. The S&P 500 advanced 0.3% to 5,987.37, and the Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.3% to 19,054.84. Despite initial enthusiasm, gains in equities moderated as investors considered potential tariffs and immigration concerns. Markets are now looking ahead to earnings and economic news before the Thanksgiving holiday.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 89.0 points, or 0.20 per cent, at the open to 44,385.49.

site_title: Trump crypto project gets US$30 million investment from Justin Sun
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's World Liberty Financial has received a $30 million investment from China-born crypto entrepreneur Justin Sun, making him the largest investor in the decentralized finance (DeFi) project. The investment comes after Trump has been a vocal proponent of digital assets, with his sons and others involved in the project. The investment is part of a larger fundraising effort by the project, which aims to raise $300 million at a $1.5 billion valuation.

site_title: Judge grants dismissal of election subversion case against Trump
summary: A US judge has dismissed the election subversion case against Donald Trump, citing a Justice Department policy not to prosecute a sitting president. The case, which alleged Trump conspired to overturn the 2020 election results and remove top-secret documents, was dismissed "without prejudice," allowing it to be revived after Trump leaves office. Special Counsel Jack Smith has also dropped his appeal of a separate documents case against Trump.

site_title: DHL plane crash in Lithuania leaves authorities searching for answers
summary: A DHL cargo plane crashed while landing at Lithuania's Vilnius airport on Monday, killing one person and injuring three others. The cause of the crash is unknown, with German authorities investigating possible sabotage, while Lithuania's officials say there's no indication of it. The incident has raised concerns about the vulnerability of civilian infrastructure in volatile times, with European countries expressing concerns about hybrid incidents. An investigation by the US National Transportation Safety Board is underway, and DHL has launched its own investigation into the crash.

images.alt_text: The incendiary devices were planted at DHL shipping hubs in Leipzig, Germany, and Birmingham, England, Western officials said
FedEx Singapore's Mercedes-Benz eVito 112 fully-electric delivery van can travel up to 321 kilometres on a full charge.

site_title: Opec+ faces an internal foe in 2025 – Kazakhstan
summary: OPEC+ faces an internal challenge in 2025 as Kazakhstan prepares to expand its oil production, potentially exceeding the cartel's quotas. The country's Tengiz oilfield expansion, set to produce 260,000 barrels a day, could boost output to a record 2 million barrels a day. OPEC+ has delayed quota increases, prompting concerns that Kazakhstan may ignore limits, exacerbating the issue. A potential delay until the second quarter could put the Asian country and OPEC+ on a collision course, similar to previous confrontations between members.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures climbed 13 cents, or 0.2 per cent, to US$75.30 a barrel by 0115 GMT, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures were at US$71.38 a barrel, up 14 cents, or 0.2 per cent on Monday.
Global markets still face a glut next year even if the Opec+ alliance refrains from increasing supplies, the International Energy Agency in Paris estimates.

site_title: Zoom gives in-line sales forecast while investors seek more
summary: Zoom Video Communications provided a sales forecast for the current quarter, projecting revenue of US$1.18 billion and adjusted earnings of US$1.29 to US$1.30 per share. The forecast met analyst estimates but failed to impress investors, who were seeking a bigger boost from the company's expanded suite of products. The company has seen a 59% increase in monthly active users of its AI assistant and topped 1,250 customers of its contact centre application. Despite this, Zoom's outlook was little changed, with shares recovering from initial declines.

images.alt_text: The technology industry has long paid workers a large chunk of their compensation in company stock.
The company is focused on offering more tools for business customers, including phone systems, contact centres and an artificial intelligence assistant.
Zoom has turned its focus to business customers.

site_title: Social media firms raise ‘serious concerns’ over Australian U-16 ban
summary: Australia's landmark legislation would ban under-16s from social media platforms, with fines of up to A$50 million (S$43.9 million) for non-compliance. Social media firms, including X, Snapchat, TikTok, and Meta, have expressed "serious concerns" over the rushed passage and lack of consultation, citing potential unintended consequences. The proposed law, which includes robust privacy provisions, aims to prioritize young Australians' well-being and mental health. The government is set to approve the law this week, with a one-year grace period for tech platforms to implement and enforce the ban.

images.alt_text: The Bill was part of a wide-ranging regulatory crackdown by Australia, where leaders have complained that foreign-domiciled tech platforms are overriding the country’s sovereignty, and comes ahead of a federal election due within a year.

The Australian Signals Directorate said in a report on Wednesday over 11 per cent of cyber security incidents last year related to critical infrastructure, including electricity, gas, water, education and transport services.

site_title: British Airways to introduce new first class to A380 jet in 2026
summary: British Airways plans to introduce a new first class on its Airbus A380 double-deckers in mid-2026, featuring a 2-meter long, 93-centimeter wide seat with a cocooned wall separation, 32-inch TV screen, and personal luggage storage. The airline aims to maintain its competitive edge among well-heeled travelers, particularly on the trans-Atlantic route, where it is the only European carrier to offer first class. The move follows other European airlines upgrading their first-class offerings, as they refurbish cabins to extend the life of their long-haul aircraft.

site_title: The return of the techno-libertarians
summary: US President Donald Trump's victory has brought together techno-libertarians, including Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, who believe in dismantling state constraints for efficiency-building and profit-making. They aim to end all constraints on markets, with Musk already seeing significant gains in value for his companies. However, critics argue that this approach has led to the cognitive capture of policymakers and government, with the proliferation of extraterritorial domains and free ports allowing digital titans to escape democracy. Experts warn that techno-libertarianism often peaks before a fall, and investors should be cautious of the risks involved.

site_title: Macy’s says employee hid up to US$154 million in costs over 3 years
summary: Macy's disclosed that an employee hid up to $154 million in expenses through false accounting entries over three years. The company said the responsible employee is no longer with the company, and there is no evidence the errors affected vendor payments or cash position. Macy's delayed its earnings release due to the investigation, which has not identified involvement by any other employee. The incident raises concerns about the company's competence and auditors, and retail analyst Neil Saunders described the preliminary results as "mixed," noting declining sales at namesake stores.

site_title: Buffett gives US$1.14 billion in Berkshire shares to charities
summary: Warren Buffett is donating approximately $1.14 billion of Berkshire Hathaway shares to four family foundations, including the Susan Thompson Buffett Foundation, his children's foundations, and a new charitable trust. As part of his 2010 Giving Pledge, Buffett will convert 1,600 Class A shares into 2.4 million Class B shares and distribute them to these foundations. This move reduces his Berkshire holdings to 206,363, down 57% since his 2006 pledge.

site_title: No regrets: Merkel looks back at refugee crisis, Russia ties
summary: Former German Chancellor Angela Merkel's autobiography "Freedom" defends her 16 years in office, rejecting blame for the current turmoil. Merkel, 70, argues that her calm leadership and openness to Russia and refugees were necessary, despite criticism that her policies fueled the rise of far-right parties and left Germany reliant on cheap Russian gas. She defends her engagement with Russia's President Vladimir Putin and her opposition to Ukraine joining NATO, and rejects criticism for her energy policy decisions. Merkel also writes about the 2015 refugee crisis, saying she "still does not understand" how a friendly face in a photo could encourage people to flee their homeland.

site_title: Intel expects US to shave chip-making grant: sources
summary: Intel expects the US government to reduce a preliminary subsidy of $8.5 billion to build more chip factories, with the final amount likely to be greater than $7.5 billion. This reduction comes weeks after Intel received a separate $3 billion deal with the Pentagon. The expected reduction is not connected to Intel's financial struggles, which have led to a 47% decline in shares this year. The US government's overall chip subsidy package, announced in March, is worth $52.7 billion, with $39 billion going towards subsidies for semiconductor production.

summary: A recent study found that AI chatbot ChatGPT outperformed human doctors in diagnosing illnesses with an average accuracy rate of 90%, while doctors with ChatGPT scored 76% and those without scored 74%. This raises concerns about the potential replacement of human workers, particularly those whose self-worth is tied to their work. However, the author suggests that instead of fearing job loss, people should focus on finding meaning and purpose beyond their work, as AI is likely to improve enough to rival humans in core work components, leading to a redefinition of identity and existence.

summary: Nintendo's new Pokémon game, Pokémon Trading Card Game Pocket, has debuted with $101 million in revenue and 38 million downloads in its first 25 days, surpassing Pokémon Go's $59 million in the same period. However, experts predict it may not match Pokémon Go's long-term success, with Wedbush Securities analyst Michael Pachter stating it's unlikely to reach $1 billion in annual revenue. site_title: Singapore civil servants to get 1.05-months year-end bonus, up from last year’s 0.6-month
summary: Singapore civil servants will receive a year-end bonus of 1.05 months, up from 0.6 months last year, with junior officers also receiving an additional one-time payment of S$600. The bonus is based on an upgraded growth domestic product forecast of 3.5% for Singapore this year. With the mid-year bonus, civil servants will receive a total of 1.5 months in bonuses, with junior officers receiving up to S$850.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to sell New York City Park Avenue office condo to SL Green
summary: Morgan Stanley is selling its 11-storey office condo at 500 Park Avenue in Manhattan to SL Green Realty for approximately $130 million. The 201,411-square-foot property, located at the corner of 59th Street, includes offices and retail space. SL Green sees the deal as a rare opportunity to own an iconic asset, citing Park Avenue's historic low vacancy and high demand for top-tier tenants. This sale follows other recent deals in the area, including JPMorgan Chase's purchase of 250 Park Avenue and Ken Griffin's plans for a 62-storey office skyscraper at 350 Park Avenue.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as Trump’s Treasury selection boosts sentiment
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by optimism over Scott Bessent's nomination as Treasury Secretary in the incoming Trump administration. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 89 points, or 0.20%, to a record high of 44,385.49, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also climbed, with the S&P 500 up 22.9 points, or 0.38%, and the Nasdaq up 136.9 points, or 0.72%. The positive sentiment is seen as a boost to investor confidence ahead of the new administration.

site_title: Chanel family matriarch dies aged 99
summary: Chanel family matriarch Eliane Wertheimer has died at the age of 99. She was the mother of luxury group Chanel's secretive owners, Alain Wertheimer and Gerard Wertheimer, who are the grandsons of the label's co-founder Pierre Wertheimer. The company has paid tribute to her, describing her sons as "owing her everything." Eliane Wertheimer's legacy is tied to the iconic brand, which is known for its creative director Karl Lagerfeld, perfumes such as Chanel No 5, and distinctive quilted handbags.
