site_title: US prosecutors demand Google divest Chrome to end search monopoly
summary: The US Justice Department demanded Google divest its Chrome browser, share data and search results with rivals, and take other measures to end its monopoly on online search. Google must promptly sell Chrome to a government-approved buyer, and may also divest its Android mobile operating system if other remedies fail to restore competition. Google is also prohibited from owning a browser or making payments to default Google search engines for five years. The proposals also require Google to licence search results to competitors at a nominal cost and share user data with rivals.

images.alt_text: Google is far from the only company trying to keep newer forms of communication out of the courtroom.
Bookings for KPMG’s Google Cloud-related services have grown 10-fold over the last two years, Steve Chase says.
Google has not gained “material influence” over Anthropic as a result of the deal, the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) said.
France has been a test case for the rules and after initial resistance Google and Facebook both agreed to pay some French media for articles shown in web searches.
FILE PHOTO: Gemini logo is seen in this illustration taken May 20, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Sri Lanka's president makes U-turn on IMF bailout
summary: Sri Lanka's President Anura Kumara Dissanayake has backed the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) $2.9 billion bailout, reversing his election pledge to renegotiate the deal. Dissanayake cited the fragile economic recovery as a reason to maintain the program, which includes sharply raising taxes, removing energy subsidies, and restructuring state enterprises. The US$2.9 billion loan requires Sri Lanka to implement these measures to rebuild its economy, which shrank 7.8% in 2022. The delayed third review of the four-year loan program is expected to be concluded by this weekend.

images.alt_text: epa11722010 People watch election results displayed on a giant screen at a ballot counting center the day after the parliamentary election, in Colombo, Sri Lanka, 15 November 2024. Polling ended peacefully, with a turnout of 65 percent. More than 17.1 million people were registered to vote to elect 225 members to form a new parliament. According to the latest official results, the Marxist-leaning National People's Power (NPP) alliance, led by President Anura Kumara Dissanayake, is in the lead with more than two-thirds of the seats in Parliament. President Dissanayake dissolved parliament on September 24 after securing victory in the first presidential election since the mass protests and political turmoil triggered by the country's economic collapse in 2022.  EPA-EFE/CHAMILA KARUNARATHNE

site_title: Canada’s Manulife signs C$5.4 billion reinsurance deal to lower risk
summary: Canada's Manulife Financial has signed a C$5.4 billion reinsurance deal with Reinsurance Group of America to transfer risk from its portfolio and free up capital for stock buybacks. The deal covers C$2.4 billion of long-term care reserves, a high-risk business, and will unlock C$800 million of capital for buybacks. This is the company's second reinsurance deal this year, following a C$5.8 billion deal with RGA Life Reinsurance Company of Canada earlier.

site_title: Bracing for Trump tariffs, China’s Xi makes diplomatic push at global summits
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping made a diplomatic push at global summits, contrasting with former US President Donald Trump's "America First" message and presenting himself as a defender of the multilateral global trade order. Xi sought to draw China into the Global South, where it can expand its influence, and build a broader consensus. China is bracing for expected new tariffs from the US, but Xi aims to position China as a stable and reciprocal partner, rather than an unpredictable force. The outreach is urgent for Beijing, which is vulnerable to the US's economic impact and has a sputtering economy.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping looks on during the second session of the G20 Leaders' Meeting in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on November 18, 2024. (Photo by Pablo PORCIUNCULA / AFP)

Chinese President Xi Jinping said China would support global development with eight actions, including building a “high quality” Belt and Road Initiative, his signature foreign policy plan that directs large Chinese investments to infrastructure projects in the developing world.
(From left) Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva shaking hands with China's President Xi Jinping at the G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Nov 18, 2024.

Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer (L) shakes hands with China's President Xi Jinping, ahead of their bilateral meeting at the Sheraton Hotel, on the sidelines of G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil on November 18, 2024. (Photo by Stefan Rousseau / POOL / AFP)
US President Joe Biden and China's President Xi Jinping both agree that human beings, not artificial intelligence, should make decisions over the use of nuclear weapons, according to the White House.

China President Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden, who will hold their last, official face-to-face on Saturday, warned separately of choppy waters as the world braces for the prospect of fresh trade wars after Donald Trump assumes the US presidency in January.
The Malaysian leader’s trip comes as the Muslim-majority country draws closer to Beijing, with Anwar openly criticising the US over its support of Israel.
China President Xi Jinping called for strengthened dialogue to effectively manage differences while sending his congratulations to US President-elect Donald Trump.

site_title: South Korea’s AI chip investor announces plan for share buybacks
summary: SK Square, the holding company of SK Hynix, a leading artificial intelligence chip manufacturer, plans to buy back shares worth 200 billion won (S$192 million) over the next three months. This comes after a London-based hedge fund proposed changes to address the undervaluation of the company, and South Korea's government implemented a "Value-Up" program to boost stock prices.

images.alt_text: SK Hynix has been leading a global race to meet an explosive demand for HBM chips that aid in the processing of vast amounts of data to train AI technology.
SK Hynix, the world’s second-biggest memory chipmaker, reported a 7 trillion won (S$6.7 billion) operating profit for the July-September quarter versus a 1.8 trillion won loss a year earlier.
Activities of global banks and hedge funds have been under the microscope in recent months in South Korea, as authorities boost steps to weed out naked short selling.

site_title: Proptech platform Podium raises S$20.4 million in Series A-1 round
summary: Podium, a proptech platform, raised S$20.4 million in its Series A-1 round led by Autodesk, with other investors including Schindler and Lendlease. The funds will help the company accelerate growth in key markets such as Singapore and Australia. Podium aims to connect developers, designers, and suppliers, addressing challenges like low productivity, high waste, and cost inefficiencies in the built environment. The platform uses automation algorithms to generate detailed building models and designs, with trials showing significant time savings over conventional methods.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Work and play get a green boost

site_title: US indictments scythe US$27 billion off value of India’s Adani Group firms
summary: The Adani Group, led by billionaire Gautam Adani, saw its market value plummet by about $27 billion after US prosecutors charged the conglomerate's chairman in an alleged bribery and fraud scheme. Adani Enterprises closed down 23% in its worst one-day drop since February last year, while other group firms fell between 6% and 19%. The Adani Group dismissed the accusations as "baseless" and vowed to seek legal recourse. The charges come after a US short-seller accused the group of improper use of tax havens and stock manipulation in 2023.

images.alt_text: The logo of the Adani Group is seen on the facade of its Corporate House on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave

site_title: Hyundai unveils big electric SUV in fast-growing market
summary: Hyundai unveiled its first three-row electric SUV, the IONIQ 9, with a range of over 483 kilometers. The vehicle, set to launch in the US and Korea early next year, aims to capitalize on the growing demand for big family cars. With competitors like Lucid, General Motors, and Volvo also launching three-row EVs, Hyundai is seeking to establish itself in the emerging market segment. The IONIQ 9 is priced similarly to its Kia EV9 counterpart, and its high-capacity charging capabilities make it compatible with Tesla's Supercharger network.

images.alt_text: The Hyundai IONIQ 9, a three-row electric SUV is unveiled during a Hyundai event in the Hollywood Hills in Los Angeles, California, U.S., November 20, 2024. REUTERS/Daniel Cole

site_title: Bank of Korea survey shows concerns emerging on US policy change risk
summary: A Bank of Korea survey has shown that 56% of respondents are concerned about US policy changes following the presidential election, ranking second only to elevated household debt. The survey, conducted between October 29 and November 8, reflects South Korea's heavy reliance on exports for economic growth and financial stability. Policy uncertainties may continue until January, weighing on monetary decision-making by the Bank of Korea and other global central banks.

images.alt_text: Bank of Korea Photographer: Jean Chung/Bloomberg

site_title: Singtel makes senior management changes, appoints new chief corporate officer
summary: Singtel has announced senior management changes, effective January 1, 2025. Anna Yip will lead the new International Digital Services unit, replacing her current role, while Mark Chong takes on the role of group chief corporate officer. Chong previously served as deputy chief executive at Advanced Info Services, the telco's Thai regional associate. The changes are part of Singtel's growth plan, Singtel28, which aims to recycle capital and raise dividends.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Singtel Pickering Operations Complex on April 7, 2021.
Singtel's S$0.07 first-half dividend comprises a core dividend of S$0.056 per share as well as a “value realisation” dividend of S$0.014 per share.

site_title: Blackstone invests US$500 million in Lancium AI buildout
summary: Blackstone has invested over $500 million in Lancium, a US-based data centre builder, to support the growing demand for artificial intelligence applications. Lancium plans to build five gigawatts of data centres in West Texas by 2028, utilizing wind- and solar-rich areas and potentially incorporating zero-carbon resources. The investment will help Lancium meet the energy demands of the data centre boom, which is straining power grids due to ageing infrastructure, extreme weather, and soaring demand.

images.alt_text: A sale to Blackstone would be the US asset manager’s biggest real estate deal in Japan and likely the largest purchase by a foreign fund.
Blackstone is one of the world’s largest investors in real estate, with US$336.1 billion in assets in the sector as at the end of June.
Blackstone’s European wealth business currently has offices in London, Paris, Zurich, Milan and Frankfurt.

site_title: China’s healthcare businesses wade into South-east Asia for cost-efficiency, growth
summary: China's healthcare companies are expanding into South-east Asia due to cost-efficiency and growth opportunities. Beijing-based private equity firm GL Capital Group aims to start a fund to support Chinese companies in setting up operations in the region. These companies, mainly small and medium-sized enterprises in medical devices, diagnostics, and pharmaceuticals, can benefit from lower barriers to entry and access to local knowledge and connections. The region's emerging markets are more price-sensitive, making them an attractive location for Chinese manufacturers. The fund will provide capital and knowledge to help these businesses expand globally and tap into the region's growing demand for affordable healthcare products.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

site_title: Bankman-Fried’s ex-deputy Wang avoids prison time over crypto fraud
summary: US District Judge Lewis Kaplan spared prison time for Gary Wang, the last member of FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried's inner circle to be sentenced, after he pleaded guilty to four felony counts of fraud and conspiracy. Wang, who wrote code that helped Bankman-Fried steal $8 billion from customers, received no prison time for his role in the scheme. The judge praised Wang's cooperation with prosecutors and noted his culpability was limited compared to others in the case. Wang apologized for his actions and plans to make amends, citing his unique skill set to help uncover and prevent future fraud.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried is serving a 25-year prison sentence for using billions of US dollars in customer deposits at the FTX crypto exchange.
FTX filed bankruptcy in November 2022 after Bankman-Fried shut down the company’s crypto-trading platform and handed control to insolvency experts.

Caroline Ellison, who ran Alameda Research, departs the US courthouse following her sentencing in Manhattan, New York, Sept. 24, 2024. Ellison, a former top adviser to the cryptocurrency mogul Sam Bankman-Fried, was sentenced to two years in prison for her role in the US$8 billion fraud that led to the implosion of the once high-flying FTX crypto exchange.
FTX has gathered as much as US$16 billion to repay customers by selling assets and filing lawsuits to claw back money paid by FTX before it collapsed.

site_title: Starbucks is said to consider selling stake in Chinese business
summary: Starbucks is exploring options for its Chinese business, including selling a stake, amid pressure from activist Elliott Investment Management. The company has faced challenges from local upstarts like Luckin Coffee and has been gauging interest from domestic private equity firms and Chinese conglomerates. China is Starbucks' second-largest market, generating $3 billion in net revenue in the most recent year. The company's new CEO, Brian Niccol, has vowed to improve Starbucks' physical locations and speed up service times, and is exploring strategic partnerships to drive growth in the market.

images.alt_text: Starbucks’ operations are under scrutiny following a sales slump that led to the abrupt ouster of chief executive officer Laxman Narasimhan.
Some investors are sceptical of Starbucks’ prospects, even with Niccol in charge.
Starbucks is the latest company to shift from carrots to sticks in the ongoing return-to-office battle that has been playing out at workplaces.
Starbucks will report full results on Oct 30.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as Nvidia falls short of hopes, eyes on Trump
summary: Asia markets were mixed on Nov 21, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai in negative territory, while Singapore, Seoul, and Jakarta slipped. Nvidia's earnings report fell short of expectations, despite beating forecasts, leading to a 4% drop in its shares. Bitcoin reached an all-time peak above $95,000 on optimism about US deregulation for cryptocurrencies under incoming President Trump. Investors are also spooked by developments in the Ukraine war and concerns about a potential trade war with China.

images.alt_text: Asia was mostly in the red, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington and Taipei in retreat. Seoul, Manila and Jakarta bucked the trend.

site_title: Home prices set to rise in Hong Kong, Singapore, Australia in 2025
summary: Hong Kong's property prices are expected to rise 10% in 2025, reversing a years-long decline. The city's government has relaxed mortgage rules, and interest rate cuts are lifting prices. Australia's residential prices are projected to gain 7-8%, while Singapore and Japan are expected to see modest growth of 3% and 2%, respectively. Inflation-hedging power and cheaper interest rates will support housing demand, but selective buyers, macroeconomic uncertainty, and unsold inventory may limit further growth.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's gross domestic product expanded 1.8 per cent in the three months ended September from the same period last year.
Hong Kong’s housing market has long had an are-you-kidding-me feel to it.
Hong Kong IPOs have raised about US$9 billion this year, a significant increase from 2023’s level of US$5.6 billion – which was the lowest since 2001.

site_title: China finds US$83 billion worth of gold reserves in Hunan
summary: China has discovered gold reserves worth approximately US$83 billion in Hunan province, according to state outlet Xinhua news. The reserves, found at a depth of over 2,000 meters, consist of more than 40 gold ore veins. China is the world's largest gold producer, accounting for around 10% of global output in 2023, and relies on imports to meet domestic demand due to its significant consumption of 741.732 metric tons of gold in the first three quarters of the year.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.2 per cent at US$2,654.50 per ounce.
Spot gold added 0.32 per cent to US$2,640.19 per ounce by 0323 GMT, its highest since Nov 11.
US gold futures gain 0.5% to US$2,626.30.

site_title: Gautam Adani charged by US over alleged US$250 million bribe plot
summary: US federal prosecutors have charged Gautam Adani, the world's 18th richest person, with helping to drive a $250 million bribery scheme to secure solar energy contracts in India. Adani, along with his nephew Sagar R Adani and Vneet S Jaain, allegedly promised to pay bribes to Indian government officials to win contracts, and concealed the plan from US investors. The indictment also accuses Adani Group's clean-energy arm, Adani Green Energy, of breaking federal laws. The case could take months or years to resolve, and it's unclear how the incoming Trump administration's Justice Department will proceed.

images.alt_text: Adani Power’s move exacerbates the electricity deficit in the country of about 174 million people.
Adani Enterprises got board approval in May to raise as much as US$2 billion through various methods, including share sale to institutions.
Adani's public issue of bonds, which would be India’s second-biggest for the current financial year, will open for subscription on Sep 4 with closing scheduled for Sep 17.
Adani’s empire has been growing at a breakneck pace in the past five years, often by piling on more debt.
Billionaire owner Gautam Adani told investors the group is “well positioned” to capitalise on opportunities in the country’s booming infrastructure sector.

site_title: Volkswagen enters third round of wage talks as strike action looms
summary: Volkswagen is entering the third round of wage talks with unions, with a 10% wage cut demanded to cut costs and boost profits. The negotiations are over wages for 120,000 staff in Germany, employed at six plants. Unions have threatened to escalate the fight with strikes across German sites if a solution is not found within the next 10 days. Volkswagen aims to stay competitive and defend market share against Chinese rivals and declining car demand in Europe.

images.alt_text: The Volkswagen logo is displayed on the Volkswagen power plant on the day when Volkswagen AG and the industrial union IG Metall started talks over a new labor agreement for six of its German plants, in Wolfsburg, Germany, September 25, 2024. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse

site_title: Sinochem may keep bankrupt refineries as auctions draw scant interest: sources
summary: Sinochem Group may retain three bankrupt oil refineries in eastern China after auctions drew little interest from other companies. The refineries, known as "teapots," are smaller and less sophisticated, and their lack of crude oil import quotas makes them unattractive to potential buyers. The refineries' combined crude processing capacity is 3% of national output, and they have accumulated unpaid consumption taxes of around $2.4 billion. Sinochem may retain the refineries by writing down debts to creditors and renegotiating taxes owed, potentially saving thousands of jobs.

images.alt_text: In July, Sinochem had shut two of its three Shandong refineries – Zhenghe and Changyi – for indefinite maintenance amid high crude oil cost and weak Chinese refined fuel market.
Sources tell Reuters that Exxon, majority owner and operator of the JV, has the right of first refusal in the sale.

site_title: McDonald’s readies new US value lineup to entice diners back
summary: McDonald's is launching a new US value platform, called McValue, to entice budget-conscious diners. The new lineup includes an offer to buy one item and get one for $1 and a $5 meal bundle extended until mid-2025. This move aims to restore McDonald's reputation as an affordable fast-food destination, eroded by years of price increases. The company plans to introduce the updated platform in the first quarter of 2025, following two consecutive quarters of declining same-store sales.

images.alt_text: McDonald’s has tried to reassure customers that it’s safe to eat at its restaurants.
The E coli infections have been linked to McDonald’s Quarter Pounders and appear to stem from the slivered onions served on top of the sandwich.
FILE PHOTO: A McDonald's Quarter Pounder hamburger and coke, are seen in an illustration picture taken in New York City, U.S., October 24, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Starbucks shrank retail staff 8% despite hundreds of new stores
summary: Starbucks reduced its US retail workforce by 8% to 211,000 employees as of September 29, despite adding 513 new company-operated stores. This marks the second consecutive year of declining US headcount, with 201,000 employees working in cafes, down from 219,000 in 2023. The company is under scrutiny following a sales slump that led to the ouster of CEO Laxman Narasimhan, and is making efforts to simplify its menu and improve staffing levels. Despite this, staffing levels remain a concern, with workers citing backlogs and low staffing levels.

images.alt_text: Some investors are sceptical of Starbucks’ prospects, even with Niccol in charge.
Starbucks is the latest company to shift from carrots to sticks in the ongoing return-to-office battle that has been playing out at workplaces.
Starbucks’ leadership team has undergone changes since Niccol took over.
Starbucks bought its first company-operated farm, Hacienda Alsacia, in Costa Rica to study disease- and climate-resistant coffee varietals.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nio, Singtel
summary: Singtel announced changes to its senior management to support new business priorities, with deputy chief executive Anna Yip relinquishing her role and veteran Mark Chong appointed as group chief corporate officer. Nio reported a wider net loss of 5.1 billion yuan in its third quarter, with revenue and vehicle sales also declining due to changes in the product mix and lower average selling price.

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield edges up to 3.08%
summary: Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill (T-bill) cut-off yield rose to 3.08%, up from 3.04% in the previous auction. Demand grew, with S$13.7 billion in applications for the S$7 billion on offer, a 1.96 bid-to-cover ratio. The Monetary Authority of Singapore expects to issue up to S$450 billion in government securities, with S$450 billion increase anticipated to be issued as Special Singapore Government Securities to meet the Central Provident Fund's investment needs.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
2024’s Financial Wellness Index score rose by 1 point to 61 points, which OCBC noted is in tandem with economic growth.

site_title: Data centres the standout performers among S-Reits in Q3; analysts have mixed views on the sector overall for Q4
summary: Singapore-listed Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits) reported healthy operational performance in Q3, despite pressure from higher interest rates. Data centre assets stood out as the surprise performers, with Keppel DC Reit renewing a major contract with a positive rental reversion of over 40%. Analysts expect S-Reits to recover more substantially next year due to lower interest rates. However, mixed views exist for Q4, with some analysts expressing concerns about the sector's performance.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
People walk past the People’s Bank of China, the country’s central bank, in Beijing on October 19, 2024. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP)
Proceeds from the placement will be used to partially fund the purchase of two data centres at Keppel Data Centre Campus (above).
CapitaLand Investment's group chief executive Lee Chee Koon (right) with Suchad Chiaranussati, chairman and founder of SC Capital Partners.
Data centre assets have been appealing to investors in recent years for their positive rental reversions as supply remains tight.

site_title: Japan’s Ishiba set to announce 21.9 trillion yen stimulus: NHK
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba is set to announce a 21.9 trillion yen (S$190 billion) economic stimulus package to address inflation, wage growth, and low-income households. The package includes 13.9 trillion yen for general account spending and is expected to have an overall impact of around 39 trillion yen. The plan includes support for sustained wage gains, cash handouts, and investments in the semiconductor and artificial intelligence sectors. Ishiba's minority government has made concessions to the smaller Democratic Party for the People (DPP) to ensure the package's passage in parliament.

site_title: Kioxia market value set at 750 billion yen, Japan chipmaker to receive listing approval: sources
summary: Kioxia, a Japanese chipmaker formerly known as Toshiba Memory, is set to receive listing approval from the Tokyo bourse on November 22, with a market value of approximately 750 billion yen (S$6.5 billion) based on its indicative IPO price. The company, backed by Bain Capital, is targeting a December IPO, offering fundraising options but increasing scrutiny on its financials. Shareholders, including Bain, will sell shares in the IPO, with Morgan Stanley, Nomura, and BofA Securities serving as joint global coordinators.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Bain Capital is displayed on the screen during a news conference in Tokyo, Japan October 5, 2017. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
Kioxia plans to submit a full application in August and list at the end of October, though the timing could be pushed back to December.

site_title: Bitcoin climbs closer to US$100,000 on Trump’s support for crypto
summary: Bitcoin surged to a record high of $97,659 on November 21, fueled by optimism over President-elect Donald Trump's support for cryptocurrency and potential regulatory framework. Trump's transition team is discussing the creation of a White House post dedicated to digital-asset policy, and industry leaders are pitching for a direct line to the president-elect. MicroStrategy Inc. also announced plans to accelerate Bitcoin purchases, while speculators focus on reaching the $100,000 mark, seen as a symbolic validation of the digital asset's utility.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representation of the bitcoin cryptocurrency and a price chart are seen in this illustration taken October 24, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 4.61 points or 0.1% to 3,748.25, following a mixed global equities session. Losers outnumbered gainers 73 to 51, with notable movers including Genting Singapore, Thai Beverage, and Advanced Systems. Local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC also traded up. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3% higher, while the Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX
Chloe Lim

site_title: Social media giants face A$50 million fines under Australia ban
summary: Australia is set to introduce legislation that could fine social media giants up to A$50 million for failing to enforce a ban on children under 16 using the platforms. The bill requires social media companies to prevent children from creating accounts and imposes fines for systematic breaches. Exceptions will be made for messaging apps, online gaming, and health/education services. The legislation aims to create a safer online environment for young Australians, with Communications Minister Michelle Rowland stating the onus is on social media platforms to ensure protections are in place.

images.alt_text: Platforms such as Facebook, TikTok and Instagram would be held responsible for enforcing the age ban and face potentially hefty fines for failing to do so.

(FILES) This picture taken on March 25, 2024, shows the Meta logo  on a smartphone in Mulhouse, eastern France. Meta on Wednesday reported profit of $13.5 billion in the recently ended quarter, beating market expectations and causing the share price to jump. Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, said revenue in the quarter was $39 billion, some 22 percent higher than the same period a year earlier. (Photo by SEBASTIEN BOZON / AFP)
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will introduce the new laws before an election due within the next nine months.

site_title: Dyson dials back Malaysia hairdryer operations, redeploys staff
summary: Dyson is dialling back its hairdryer-related operations in Malaysia, redeploying 47 employees from its advanced manufacturing facility to the global development campus in Johor. The move is part of the company's efforts to streamline its business in the region, although a broader review of its presence in Malaysia is also being considered. Dyson has denied allegations of worker mistreatment and has stated it will continue to invest in Malaysia, manufacturing millions of Dyson machines there every year.

images.alt_text: James Dyson is the UK’s wealthiest resident with a fortune of US$21 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.
Kathleen Pierce, president of Dyson Beauty, pictured with one of Dyson's new range of haircare products.
Dyson was criticised by the United Workers of Electronics and Electrical Industries for giving the labour union short notice of itsretrenchment.
The United Workers of Electronics and Electrical Industries does not know who the affected workers nor their levels.

site_title: Maybank eyes Johor-Singapore SEZ for growth; targets 25% profit contribution from Singapore by 2027
summary: Maybank Singapore aims to increase its loan book by 10-20% within the first year of the upcoming Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone's operation. The bank targets 25% of its group income to come from Singapore by 2027, up from 18% in 2023. To achieve this, Maybank plans to improve financing access for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), particularly those with limited track records, and transform its organization to be leaner and more efficient.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.
Funding Societies group chief executive and co-founder Kelvin Teo says that the tie-up will help extend credit access to businesses facing cash flow management challenges.
A portion of the total funds raised on Maybank Securities' Trade for Good Charity day came from the net brokerage commissions during the trading day.
Alice Tan will also be responsible for integrating Maybank Singapore’s regional strategy.
Vietnam is attracting increasing foreign investor interest, especially as companies diversify supply chains away from China.

site_title: ‘The greatest sneaker show on earth’ set for 2025 reboot in new partnership with SPH Media
summary: Sneaker Con SEA, Southeast Asia's premier sneaker event, is set to return in 2025 after a successful 2024 edition. The event, now in partnership with SPH Media, will be held at Marina Bay Sands Expo and Convention Centre in February 2025, featuring hundreds of vendors, grail finds, and exclusive experiences like The Trading Pit and the 40 for 40 Game Show. Ticket sales begin on November 21, with general admission priced at S$35 and premium tickets at S$55, offering early event access and exclusive merchandise.

site_title: AI’s slowdown is everyone else’s opportunity
summary: Artificial intelligence's growth has slowed, with recent developments showing that generative models aren't improving as dramatically as expected. This slowdown offers a break for businesses to redesign workflows and invest in current AI models, potentially leading to increased productivity. The AI boom has primarily benefited large tech companies, but a pause in market hype could allow for more effective regulation and a shift towards measuring success beyond capability, including safety and fairness. This could ultimately lead to a more sustainable and equitable AI development landscape.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Figurines with computers and smartphones are seen in front of the words "Artificial Intelligence AI" in this illustration taken, February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 flat in volatile trading; real estate weighs
summary: Europe's main stock index, the Stoxx 600, closed flat at 500.49 points amid volatile trading, its fourth consecutive decline. The index touched a three-month low on Tuesday amid investor fears over geopolitical tensions between Ukraine and Russia. Real estate stocks were the biggest drag, falling 0.7%, while automobile stocks declined 1.2%. Investors remain cautious due to geopolitical uncertainty and concerns over US President-elect Donald Trump's administration appointments, including the search for a Treasury secretary.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.4 per cent lower on Tuesday, after falling 1 per cent to its lowest point since Aug 8 earlier in the session.

site_title: Strong US dollar, Trump policies pulling the rug from under some Asian, trade-exposed economies
summary: The US dollar has surged 2.7-3.4% against the Singapore dollar and 3.4-3.9% against the ringgit and yen since Donald Trump's win in the US presidential elections. This has made US dollar-denominated imports cheaper and exports more competitive, but also risks stoking inflation in countries with weaker currencies. Trump's proposed tariffs could further affect Asian export-driven economies, but the net effect depends on the tussle between cheaper exports and punitive tariffs. Asian policymakers are watching the trend closely, with some predicting a stronger greenback and others expecting it to appreciate gradually against the Singapore dollar over the next year.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The baht has declined more than 7 per cent this quarter in Asia’s worst performance, as Thailand’s government campaigned for the central bank to cut borrowing costs.
The yuan, along with other emerging-market currencies, takes a hard hit as the dollar got bolstered by reflation bets on Wednesday (Nov 6).
Against a basket of currencies the dollar held at 106.77, having touched a one-year top of 107.07 on Friday.

site_title: Financial claims surge 45%, led by spike in scam-related claims, says disputes resolution centre
summary: Financial claims surged 44.6% to 2,162, with scam-related claims rising 62.9% to 38% of total claims, according to the Financial Industry Disputes Resolution Centre. The majority of claims (64.2%) were against banks, finance companies, and credit bureaus, with scam-related claims accounting for nearly 60%. Consumers aged 41-50 and 51-60 made up the largest groups of claimants. The centre expects an increased need for dispute resolution services, prompting staff expansion and technological upgrades to handle "greater complexity" in claims.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Fidrec chief executive Eunice Chua said public outreach efforts reached more than 1,100 persons during the period.

site_title: How Google spent 15 years creating a culture of concealment
summary: Google created a culture of concealment in 2008 as it faced antitrust scrutiny and lawsuits. Executives warned employees to avoid speculation, sarcasm, and "hot topics" in emails to minimize the risk of incriminating comments. They instructed employees to "think twice" before writing about sensitive topics and to refrain from commenting before having all the facts. This culture of concealment aimed to protect the company from lawsuits and maintain confidentiality, but it also raised concerns about transparency and free speech within the organization.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk next to a Google logo during a trade fair in Hannover Messe, in Hanover, Germany, April 22, 2024.  REUTERS/Annegret Hilse//File Photo

site_title: US: Target falters on mixed day for stocks
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3% to 43,408.47 on Wednesday, following a mixed session. Investors reacted to Target's weak quarterly results, which led to a 21% drop in the company's market value. Despite this, CEO Brian Cornell expressed confidence in the retailer's fundamentals. Meanwhile, Walmart's positive earnings report boosted investor confidence ahead of the holiday shopping season. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reached fresh records, despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 27.1 points, or 0.06 per cent, at the open to 43,296.05.

site_title: COP29 climate financing target likely to fall short of developing countries’ needs: report
summary: A new report by BMI predicts that the climate finance target for developed countries at the COP29 conference in Baku, Azerbaijan, will likely fall short of the $1 trillion needed annually by 2030 for developing countries. Developed markets face limited fiscal space due to higher debt levels, and ongoing geopolitical tensions, including the US-China trade war and the Russia-Ukraine conflict, may further hinder climate finance negotiations. The report warns that a lack of financing will disproportionately affect emerging markets, exacerbating climate-related risks and undermining global climate policy.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

Opening the last session of the G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro, President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva suggested countries bring forward their targets to reach climate neutrality by 2040 or 2045, instead of 2050 as Brazil and many others have pledged.
One potential success for COP29 is the growing enthusiasm for nuclear power. Six new countries joined a pledge to triple global nuclear capacity by 2050.

Singapore's Ambassador for Climate Action Ravi Menon giving the keynote address at the launch of the COP29 Singapore Pavilion on Nov 12, 2024 at Baku, Azerbaijan.

Super Typhoon Yagi hit northern Vietnam in September. A loss and damage fund would assist developing countries that are particularly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change.
This year’s climate summit in Baku, Azerbaijan, has been dubbed the "finance COP".

site_title: Trump 2.0 a hurdle for S-Reit investors hoping for fast rate cuts
summary: S-Reit investors in Singapore face uncertainty after Donald Trump's re-election, fearing his policies will raise inflationary pressure and slow interest rate cuts, affecting the sector. Trump's win dashed hopes for easing cost pressures, with two-thirds of S-Reits and business trusts ending lower the day after. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts may not materialize as expected, impacting S-Reit investors who had anticipated relief.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan

site_title: New Zealand Treasury sees deeper economic downturn pressuring tax take
summary: New Zealand's economic downturn has been deeper than expected, putting pressure on tax revenues and the government's budget deficit. The Treasury Department's latest forecast downgrade is expected to be published on December 17, with consumer spending remaining weaker than a year ago and companies pessimistic about their trading outlook. This has led to a structural fiscal deficit, with expenditure exceeding revenue, making it harder for the government to balance its books. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to cut interest rates again, adding to downside risks for economic growth and tax revenue.

images.alt_text: The construction slowdown is adding to signs that economic growth has stalled, and that the nation is facing its second recession in less than two years.
BNZ began easing monetary policy in August saying weak domestic demand gave it confidence that inflation was returning towards the middle of its 1 to 3 per cent target.
New Zealand's unemployment rate rose to 4.8 per cent in the third quarter, from 4.6 per cent the previous quarter and just under analyst forecasts of 5.0 per cent.

site_title: KPMG to spend US$100 million on AI partnership with Google Cloud
summary: KPMG will invest US$100 million over four years to enhance its enterprise AI services through a partnership with Google Cloud. This investment will focus on developing AI agents and training KPMG's workforce to work with Google's products. Bookings for KPMG's Google Cloud-related services have grown 10-fold over the last two years, highlighting the growing demand for AI implementation among large businesses.

images.alt_text: KPMG has a presence in “more than 143 countries and territories with over 273,000 partners and employees”.

From left: Chan Yen San, partner and head of professional practice, KPMG in Singapore; Alex Koh, partner and head of audit, KPMG in Singapore; Lee Sze Yeng, managing partner, KPMG in Singapore; Daniel Leung, country manager, ACCA Singapore; Lau Kam Yuen, partner, COO/CFO and head of central services, KPMG in Singapore; and Pulkit Abrol, director of Asia-Pacific, ACCA.
By integrating ESG principles into their operations, charities can garner greater stakeholder support, attract new funds and enhance operational efficiency.
KPMG says United Holdings and its directors has potentially breached several listing rules involving the group's proposed acquisition announced in 2017, among others.

site_title: Nvidia’s AI chip demand still booming but slowing sales growth worries investors
summary: Nvidia reported fourth-quarter revenue slightly above estimates, but fell short of investor expectations, causing its shares to decline 1%. The company is launching its powerful Blackwell AI chips, which will initially weigh on gross margins but improve over time. Despite this, Nvidia's forecast suggests a continued boom in AI chip demand, with investors expressing concerns about slowing sales growth.

images.alt_text: Jensen Huang, co-founder and chief executive officer of Nvidia, in front of a screen displaying the Blackwell computing platform; Nvidia unveiled Blackwell chips in March.
Nvidia’s chips have become a prized commodity for the world’s biggest tech companies, which use the components to develop and run AI models.

Amazon Web Services (AWS) said it will offer credits to use its cloud data centres that it values at US$110 million to researchers who want to tap Trainium, its chip for developing artificial intelligence models.

site_title: Dollar snaps back after three-day slide as investors await cues on Trump policies
summary: The US dollar advanced 0.5% to 106.59 against six major peers, recovering from a three-day slide as investors awaited clues on President-elect Donald Trump's policies. The previous day's boost on geopolitical concerns, fueled by Russia's nuclear threat, proved short-lived. The dollar's rally was driven by expectations of Trump's post-election policies, while the Japanese yen slid as safe-haven demand faded. Market sentiment remains sensitive to news on the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

images.alt_text: The yen jumped 0.5 per cent versus the dollar and 0.8 per cent against the euro, hitting its highest since Oct 4 at 161.50.
Against a basket of currencies the dollar held at 106.77, having touched a one-year top of 107.07 on Friday.

site_title: HSBC shelves plans for trading, financing carbon credits
summary: HSBC has abandoned plans to build a carbon credits desk, citing the market's volatility and repeated allegations of greenwashing. The decision comes as companies such as Delta Air Lines and Google have moved away from the market, focusing instead on reducing their own emissions. The bank had explored entering the market a couple of years ago but ultimately shelved its plans due to concerns over the lack of liquidity and the potential for widespread greenwashing.

images.alt_text: Signage at the HSBC Holdings Plc headquarters building in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, Oct. 25, 2024. HSBC is scheduled to release earnings results on Oct. 29. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: Eurozone banks are vulnerable to US funding squeeze: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) warns that eurozone banks' growing dependence on US dollars and their role as providers of US dollar liquidity to non-banks pose significant risks to the financial system. The use of US dollar repos by eurozone banks has doubled to 1.6 trillion euros, with 17% of their funding now in greenback-denominated assets. The ECB suggests that central banks can mitigate these risks by providing US dollar liquidity through swap lines during periods of market stress.

site_title: Bill Hwang sentenced to 18 years in prison in Archegos case
summary: Bill Hwang, founder of Archegos Capital Management, was sentenced to 18 years in prison for orchestrating a scheme to mislead bank counterparties into providing the firm with billions of US dollars in trading capacity. Hwang orchestrated a scheme to inflate the value of his portfolio until its bubble burst in March 2021, contributing to the demise of Credit Suisse Group and significant losses at Morgan Stanley, UBS Group, and other banks. The judge expressed skepticism about Hwang's claims of modesty, noting his "new apartment in Hudson Yards," and rejected his arguments that his actions did not clearly contribute to the banks' losses.

images.alt_text: Bill Hwang, 60, deserves a lengthy prison term because he led one of the largest securities fraud schemes in history and caused billions of dollars in losses, prosecutors said in a Friday filing.

Bill Hwang  was convicted in July following a two-month long trial in New York of orchestrating a scheme to inflate the value of Archegos’ portfolio by misleading Wall Street banks into buying swaps on certain stocks.

site_title: Nio’s Q3 net loss widens to 5.1 billion yuan on lower vehicle sales
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio reported a widened net loss of 5.1 billion yuan (S$945.5 million) for its third quarter, with loss per share at 2.50 yuan. The company delivered 61,855 vehicles, a 11.6% increase, and attributed the drop in vehicle sales to lower average selling prices. Revenue fell 2.1% to 18.7 billion yuan, with revenue from other sales growing 19.2%. Nio expects to deliver 72,000-75,000 units in the fourth quarter, with revenue growth of 15-19.2%.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Nio to date has only manufactured pure EVs.
Loss per share stood at 2.21 yuan, lower than the 3.70 yuan loss per share for the year-ago period.

site_title: Maybank launches programme to help SMEs level up on sustainability efforts
summary: Maybank launches "myimpact SME" programme to support Singaporean SMEs in accelerating their sustainability journey. The programme, launched with nine partners, offers tailored insights, advisory services, and financing to help SMEs address specific sustainability challenges. The bank aims to empower SMEs to embed sustainability in their operations and reduce environmental impact. The programme also includes initiatives to support women entrepreneurs, such as the "HERpower" programme.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
The loan will be used to refinance an existing S$4 billion seven-year borrowing from August 2019, sources said.

site_title: 1,000 days in, Ukraine conflict may be at beginning of end
summary: Ukraine's conflict with Russia has entered a new phase, with the 1,000-day mark marking the beginning of a potentially decisive 2025. The shift in focus comes from the election of Donald Trump, who has pledged to end the war in a day, and not from on-the-ground developments in Ukraine. Both Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky appear to be preparing for negotiations, with Putin escalating air strikes and Zelensky welcoming US President Joe Biden's decision to allow Ukraine to use long-range missiles inside Russia's territory. Europe is now expected to play a key role in shaping the outcome, with potential funding and grand strategy commitments needed to support Ukraine's future security.

images.alt_text: The change in stance from the outgoing Biden administration was sparked by the arrival of North Korean troops in Russia, with Western intelligence reports suggesting around 10,000 are being deployed, US newspapers said.

site_title: Prabowo says Indonesia can reach net zero emissions before 2050
summary: Indonesia aims to reach net zero emissions before 2050, a decade earlier than initially targeted, according to President Prabowo Subianto. The country plans to retire all coal and fossil-fuel-fired power plants within the next 15 years, replacing them with 75 gigawatts of renewable power plants. Indonesia's current installed power capacity is over 90 GW, with a goal to increase renewable energy to over 50% by 2039. The country's optimism is driven by its abundant sunlight and other renewable sources.

images.alt_text: Indonesian Retailer Association warned that the planned tax hike could hit the retail sector hard
Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto, who has said he will pursue a non-aligned foreign policy, posted a video of his call to Donald Trump made after he arrived from China.

Investment Minister Rosan Roeslani said Indonesia needs additional investment – whether domestic or foreign – worth 13,528 trillion rupiah (S$1.1 trillion) between 2025 and 2029 to reach the 8 per cent growth.

Opening the last session of the G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro, President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva suggested countries bring forward their targets to reach climate neutrality by 2040 or 2045, instead of 2050 as Brazil and many others have pledged.
SCM showcases vendors selling sustainable products.
Although transitioning to net zero may involve upfront capital expenditure, it often leads to significant long-term savings through reduced energy costs.

site_title: Dubai-based family offices now manage over US$1 trillion in assets
summary: Dubai's financial hub, the Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC), now manages over US$1 trillion in assets, driven by the influx of high-net worth individuals. The DIFC is home to over 120 families and 800 family-related structures, with assets totaling over US$1.2 trillion. The UAE's appeal to ultra-wealthy individuals is attributed to its favourable tax regime, low crime rates, and strategic location. The DIFC expects a record number of firms to set up this year, with employee numbers surging by two-thirds since 2019.

images.alt_text: Dubai’s reputation as a choice destination for wealthy families fleeing hostile regimes or wars has surged in recent years, exemplified by the Russian money that flooded in following the invasion of Ukraine.

“Hong Kong is very advanced in so many aspects and has so much to offer in terms of investment opportunities and business expansion,” says Sheikh Ali Al Maktoum, chairman of Family Offices of Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum.

site_title: Oil settles down on strong US supply, losses capped by Ukraine escalation
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures down 50 US cents, or 0.68%, at US$72.81, and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures down 52 US cents, or 0.75%, at US$68.87. Strong US supply and weak demand in China, coupled with worries about the intensifying war between Russia and Ukraine, capped losses. Geopolitical risks, including the use of Western missiles in Russia, kept a floor under prices. Hedge funds held only 50% of summer levels in long positions, despite added geopolitical risk.

site_title: How Chinese is Shein?
summary: Shein, a Chinese fast-fashion giant, is expected to sell around $50 billion worth of clothing globally this year. Despite its headquarters in Singapore and its claim to be "American" by values, most of its employees are in China, where it was founded in 2012. The company's base in China is crucial for its success, particularly for data-driven algorithms that predict customer demand. Shein's proposed IPO in London is also shrouded in uncertainty due to China's government scrutiny, which may impact investors' valuations of the company.

images.alt_text: Shein now has its global headquarters in Singapore and its Europe, Middle East and Africa headquarters in Dublin.

Shein’s rapid growth, fuelled by its low-cost business model of sending parcels to customers worldwide straight from factories in China, has disrupted the budget fashion industry and put pressure on incumbents.
Shein hopes to go public in London in the coming months.
The campaign accuses Shein of exploiting workers, damaging the environment and avoiding tax.

site_title: World leaders seek stability with China as Biden exits stage
summary: World leaders are seeking stability with China as US President Joe Biden exits office, handing power to Donald Trump, who has vowed confrontation with China. Despite a "stable, healthy and sustainable" relationship with the US, China's President Xi Jinping has expressed concerns over human rights, Taiwan, technology competition, cyberattacks, and aid to Russia. The US and China have eased tensions in the past two years, but Trump's return to the White House raises concerns over steeply increased tariffs, potentially damaging the US image abroad and corroding support for alliances.

images.alt_text: World leaders at the G20 summit in Rio did not mention Donald Trump by name but talked in coded terms about the “next administration,” “turbulence” and “change.”

site_title: US: Wall Street opens subdued as Nvidia earnings awaited
summary: US stocks opened subdued on Wednesday, November 20, awaiting Nvidia's quarterly earnings report. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 27.1 points, or 0.06%, to 43,296.05, while the S&P 500 fell 2.6 points, or 0.04%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 16.2 points, or 0.09%. Rising geopolitical tensions between Russia and Ukraine also contributed to the subdued market.

site_title: ISO cuts forecast for 2024/25 global sugar deficit
summary: The International Sugar Organization (ISO) has cut its forecast for a global sugar deficit in the 2024/25 season to 2.51 million tonnes, down from a previous projection of 3.58 million. This change is attributed to lower consumption estimates, resulting in a global surplus of 1.31 million tonnes in the 2023/24 season. Global sugar production in 2024/25 is forecast to total 179.07 million tonnes, down marginally from a prior projection.

site_title: Apple makes US$100 million investment proposal for new plant in Indonesia
summary: Apple has proposed a $100 million investment to build a plant in Indonesia to manufacture accessories and components. The proposal comes after Indonesia banned sales of Apple's iPhone 16 due to the company's failure to meet local rules on components, requiring at least 40% of parts to be locally made. The Indonesian trade ministry will discuss the proposal on Thursday. The move aims to address the ban and potentially resume sales in the country.

images.alt_text: An employee of an authorised dealer selling Apple products opens a shop in Jakarta, Indonesia, Oct 29, 2024. Apple’s previous investment plan of close to US$10 million would have involved the company investing in a factory making accessories and components in Bandung.
Indonesia has exhibited haphazard trade policies before.
It’s illegal to trade Google Pixel Phones in Indonesia, even though an estimated 22,000 units have already entered the country this year through personal shipments or carry-on items, Kontan reported.

site_title: ECB rates clearly headed lower, but prudence needed, says Guindos
summary: European Central Bank Vice-President Luis de Guindos expressed confidence in meeting the 2% inflation target next year, dismissing concerns of undershooting. He stated that interest rates will continue to be reduced further, but with caution due to rising trade tensions and global conflicts. De Guindos emphasized the need for prudence in monetary policy decisions, warning against rushing the process.

images.alt_text: Eurozone third-quarter negotiated pay rose 5.4 per cent from a year ago.
“We need to normalise our monetary policy stance and move to neutral – or even expansionary territory, if necessary.” says Bank of Italy governor Fabio Panetta.

site_title: OpenAI launches free AI training course for teachers
summary: OpenAI has launched a free AI training course for teachers to demystify artificial intelligence and prompt engineering, highlighting the positive role of its ChatGPT chatbot in education. The course, in partnership with Common Sense Media, aims to help teachers harness generative AI to create brand-new humanlike content, such as term papers and science homework. The move follows the launch of ChatGPT in November 2022, which sparked a generative AI craze and made it one of the world's fastest-growing applications.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: OpenAI and ChatGPT logos are seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Ford to cut 4,000 European jobs, blaming EV shift and rising competition
summary: Ford plans to cut 4,000 European jobs, primarily in Germany and the UK, as part of a 14% workforce reduction. The company blames weak demand for electric vehicles, lack of government support, and rising competition from Chinese rivals. Globally, the layoffs represent 2.3% of Ford's workforce. The move is seen as a significant blow to Germany, Europe's largest economy, as Volkswagen threatens to close factories and slash wages. Ford urges the German government to provide more incentives and charging infrastructure to support the shift to electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Workers are prepared to make concessions worth 1.5 billion euros (S$2.12 billion) in savings in the ongoing negotiations, but said this was contingent on Volkswagen ruling out plant closures as well as stakeholder.

site_title: China returns to Pacific with aid and influence push, report shows
summary: China has regained its position as the second-largest bilateral donor to the Pacific Islands, providing $256 million in development support in 2022, a 6% increase from the previous year. Despite a 18% drop in overall development finance to the Pacific Islands, China's aid push is targeting its spending to win influence, with government budget transfers and direct grants used to secure diplomatic support in several countries. This marks a shift from China's previous reliance on loans, with Australia remaining the largest donor.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping said China would support global development with eight actions, including building a “high quality” Belt and Road Initiative, his signature foreign policy plan that directs large Chinese investments to infrastructure projects in the developing world.
Leaders from Pacific Island nations gathered in Tonga Aug 29 for the 53rd Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting in Nuku'alofa.

site_title: ExxonMobil signs non-binding lithium supply deal with LG Chem
summary: ExxonMobil has signed a non-binding lithium supply deal with LG Chem, allowing the oil giant to incorporate the battery parts maker's lithium quality specifications into its design plans for its proposed Arkansas lithium project. The deal, worth up to 100,000 metric tons, is part of Exxon's efforts to build a relationship with a company that can help supply the growing demand for lithium in the electric vehicle battery market. Exxon expects lithium demand to rise despite US President-elect Donald Trump's campaign vow to end the "EV mandate."

images.alt_text: Exxon’s US$8.6 billion profit beats estimate as volume offsets price weakness
FILE PHOTO: The logo of ExxonMobil is seen during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

site_title: HSBC relaunches ‘Premier’ brand in UK in pursuit of wealthy clients
summary: HSBC is relaunching its 'Premier' wealth banking brand in the UK, targeting mass affluent customers with £100,000-£2 million to invest. The fee-free product will offer 24/7 customer service, financial planning tools, and travel benefits. The bank aims to double its British wealth business assets to £100 billion in five years, with plans to expand globally. HSBC will open a new flagship centre in London's Mayfair district and hire hundreds of relationship managers. The move is part of the bank's broader strategy to grow fee income and offset shrinking loan revenue.

images.alt_text: HSBC has reduced its headcount by more than 100,000 over the past 16 years as a series of CEOs tried to streamline the bank’s sprawling global operations.
The revamp addresses investor concerns about HSBC's ability to thrive amid falling interest rates, rising regional competitors, and the growth of fintechs chipping away at its customer base.
Harish Venkatesan, head of corporates and business banking, HSBC Singapore (left) and Kelvin Teo, co-founder and group CEO, Funding Societies.
HSBC currently rents 1.1 million square feet at 8 Canada Square in Canary Wharf and the move back to the City.

FILE — HSBC’s headquarters in London, July 8, 2023. HSBC announced on Oct. 22, 2024, its biggest restructuring in a decade, splitting itself into four divisions, combining some of its commercial and investment banking operations and reshuffling management. (Sam Bush/The New York Times)

site_title: ADIA, GIC in talks to acquire Pye-Barker Fire & Safety minority stake: sources
summary: The Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (ADIA) and Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) are in talks to acquire a minority stake in Pye-Barker Fire & Safety, valuing the company at over $6 billion including debt. The two sovereign wealth funds are discussing purchasing the stake from investors Leonard Green & Partners and Altas Partners, with a deal not yet finalized. Talks could collapse at any moment, and a successful acquisition would mark a significant investment in the fire safety company.

images.alt_text: This year marks the 40th anniversary of the GIC’s presence in the US, and SM Lee said GIC and the US have built a “strong, productive and mutually beneficial partnership” in the last four decades.
The Westquay shopping centre is now wholly owned by Hammerson, a London-based real estate investment trust.
Lulu International Holdings sold 3.10 billion shares, or a 30 per cent stake, at 2.04 dirhams apiece, the top of a marketed range.

site_title: China overtakes Germany in industrial use of robots
summary: China has overtaken Germany in industrial robot use, with 470 robots per 10,000 workers, compared to 429 in Germany. China ranks third globally, behind South Korea and Singapore, which have 1,012 and 470 robots per 10,000 employees, respectively. This shift highlights China's growing automation capabilities and challenges for Germany's economy, which is expected to contract for the second year in 2024. The International Federation of Robotics credits China's heavy investment in automation technology for its increased robot density.

images.alt_text: A man walks past Tesla's humanoid robot Optimus displayed at the World Robot Conference in Beijing, China August 21, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo

site_title: Singapore startups get access to the Nordics with EnterpriseSG’s new Global Innovation Alliance node in Sweden
summary: Singapore technology startups can now tap into Sweden's innovation ecosystem through Enterprise Singapore's new Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) node in Stockholm. The node, launched in November 2024, enables partnerships with corporate giants like Arla Foods and H&M to co-develop, test, and commercialize solutions in areas like agrifood tech and green supply chains. Up to 24 Singapore-based startups will be supported, with access to Swedish government agencies and a structured pathway to vital commercial and research collaborations.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Singapore startups to get a leg up in India, Australia expansions

site_title: China smartphone sales drop 9% y/y over Singles’ Day shopping festival
summary: China's Singles' Day smartphone sales dropped 9% year-over-year, with Apple sales declining by double-digit percentages. Apple's iPhone 16 Pro and Pro Max were the best-selling models. Huawei saw a 7% sales growth, while Xiaomi's sales fell 6%. The decline was attributed to an "abnormally high" number of rival handsets launched around the festival, and a slowing economy.

images.alt_text: In recent years, Apple has started assembling some of its products in India and Vietnam.
Chinese e-commerce giants were similarly coy about actual sales. Both Alibaba Group and JD.com did not disclose sales figures for this year's Singles' Day shopping season.
Workers sort packages for delivery at a JD.com warehouse in Beijing on November 11, known as the Singles’ Day shopping festival in China.
The launch of the Mate XT underscores Huawei’s ability to navigate US sanctions and solidifies its position against Apple in China.
IPhone 16 will not come installed with Apple Intelligence – the much-anticipated AI software that the company has been touting since June.

site_title: Amos Group extends offer closing date to Dec 12
summary: Amos Group, an offshore oil and gas equipment manufacturer, has extended its offer closing date to December 12, marking its second and final extension. The company had initially received a voluntary unconditional general offer of S$0.07 per share in cash from its controlling shareholder, PeakBayou, a private equity fund. Amos Group is likely to delist due to losing its free-float requirement, which could lead to its removal from the stock exchange.

images.alt_text: Generic shots of SGX
Navene Elangovan

site_title: Japan set to approve US$87 billion economic stimulus this week
summary: Japan's ruling coalition has agreed on a draft of a US$87 billion economic stimulus package, clearing a major hurdle for approval. The package, which will provide 30,000 yen to low-income households and 20,000 yen per child, aims to cushion the blow from rising prices. The agreement includes key policy initiatives from the opposition Democratic Party for the People, including raising the basic tax-free income allowance and lowering the petrol tax. The package is expected to be approved by the Cabinet on Friday, with parliament to discuss a supplementary budget next month.

site_title: Eco-conscious dining
summary: Singaporean locavore chefs are creating home/private dining experiences and pop-up kitchens to showcase the richness of local plants and produce, minimizing their carbon footprint. These chefs aim to prove that Singapore can feed itself with local resources, even in the event of a global pandemic. By highlighting the island's food security and self-sufficiency, these culinary enthusiasts hope to inspire Singaporeans to adopt eco-conscious dining habits.

site_title: Eurozone wage growth surges in test for ECB rate cuts
summary: The Eurozone's third-quarter negotiated pay rose 5.4% from a year ago, the highest since the common currency was introduced, complicating the European Central Bank's plans for interest-rate cuts as inflation eases. This surge in pay, particularly in Germany, may dampen expectations for rate reductions in 2025, with the ECB forecasting a sharp slowdown in pay increases in 2025 and 2026. The data also contradicts the ECB's inflation assumption, which is based on a slowdown in salaries, raising concerns about the labor market and wage growth.

images.alt_text: Employees carry out quality control tests as strip lights illuminate Volkswagen Phaeton automobiles at the Volkswagen AG factory in Dresden, Germany, on Thursday, April 9, 2015. German industrial production was bolstered by investment-goods output in February, highlighting improved confidence in the recovery in Europe's largest economy. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg
British average weekly earnings, excluding bonuses, were 4.8 per cent higher in the three months to the end of September than a year earlier.
FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, July 14, 2021. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

Industrial production fell by 2 per cent compared to the previous month, exceeding a 1.4 per cent drop seen in a Reuters poll of economists, even as the previous month’s solid 1.8 per cent growth figure was revised down to just 1.5 per cent.
The overall eurozone economy grew by 0.4 per cent in the third quarter from the previous three months, Eurostat said.

site_title: VW workers threaten historic battle over carmaker's US$18 billion cost cut push
summary: Volkswagen workers are threatening a historic battle over the company's US$18 billion cost-cut push, which includes 10% pay cuts and potential plant closures. The workers, led by the IG Metall union, are prepared to make concessions worth 1.5 billion euros (S$2.12 billion) but only if the company rules out closures and stakeholder involvement. The dispute could escalate into strikes at German sites starting December 1, posing a significant challenge to the carmaker's future.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen aims to launch vehicles in 2027 with technology fine tuned by the JV.

Complex governance structures, misjudged investments in electric vehicles, poor management decisions, sliding revenues from China and Germany’s crippling bureaucracy have all been blamed for the challenges facing Volkswagen.

site_title: Gold gains on softer dollar, widening Russia-Ukraine tensions
summary: Gold prices rose to a one-week high, driven by a softer dollar and escalating Russia-Ukraine tensions, which increased demand for safe-haven assets. Spot gold added 0.32% to US$2,640.19 per ounce, its highest since November 11. The US dollar's recent rally paused, making gold more appealing to buyers holding other currencies.

images.alt_text: US gold futures gain 0.5% to US$2,626.30.

site_title: Condo rents up 0.5% in October; HDB rental market perks up: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's condo rental market stabilized in October with a 0.5% increase, while HDB rental market saw a 2.9% month-on-month rise. The supply crunch in HDB rentals contributed to the increase, with Luqman Hakim predicting potential 2-3% rental growth for the rest of 2024. In contrast, condo rents were 2.8% lower year-on-year, with leasing volumes up 5.3% but lower than the five-year average. Experts attribute the condo market's stabilization to lower borrowing costs and shifting tenant preferences.

images.alt_text: Samuel Oh
Condo rental volumes are 7.7 per cent higher year on year.
HDB rental volumes are 13.4% lower year on year.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Jimmy Lai tells court he championed 'freedom'
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai, founder of Apple Daily, testified in court that his newspaper championed democracy and "freedom" during the 2019 pro-democracy protests. Lai, 76, faces charges of colluding with foreign forces, which could carry a life sentence. His case is one of the most prominent prosecuted under the national security law imposed by Beijing in 2020, with Western countries and rights groups demanding his release. Lai denies seeking foreign interference and insists he opposes violence, but his testimony comes amid concerns about his health and jail conditions.

images.alt_text: Lai, who is set to take the stand in November, is the most high-profile target in Hong Kong’s crackdown on dissent.

site_title: Vietnam says loans will not exceed 30% of US$67 billion cost of rail project
summary: Vietnam's government plans to build a high-speed rail link between its capital and Ho Chi Minh City at a cost of over $67 billion, mostly funded by state loans. Loans will not exceed 30% of the total cost, with the government arranging $5.6 billion annually over 12 years. The project, expected to be approved by the National Assembly by the end of the month, will primarily carry passengers but have an option for cargo after 2050. The 1,541 km line is expected to be operational by 2035.

images.alt_text: Experts in infrastructure funding said it could be difficult for Vietnam to build such a big project on its own.
Chinese Premier Li Qiang will meet Vietnam's leaders this weekend before attending the 'signing ceremony of cooperation documents' between the two countries.
Experts in infrastructure funding said it could be difficult for Vietnam to build such a big project on its own.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, November 20, 2024
summary: Asian shares were mixed ahead of Nvidia's earnings report, while Japan is set to approve a US$87 billion economic stimulus package this week. Keppel DC Reit rose 4.6% after announcing a S$1.4 billion data centre deal and equity fundraising. Equinix plans to build its 6th Singapore data centre with a US$260 million investment.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 81 to 30.
Asia was mostly in the red, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington and Taipei in retreat. Seoul, Manila and Jakarta bucked the trend.
The stimulus package will provide 30,000 yen (S$258.24) to low-income households that are exempt from residential taxes and 20,000 yen per child for households with families.
Proceeds from the placement will be used to partially fund the purchase of two data centres at Keppel Data Centre Campus (above).
Equinix to build 6th Singapore data centre with US$260 million investment

site_title: Top Indian cities post 23% jump in house prices
summary: India's top seven cities, including New Delhi and Mumbai, saw a 23% jump in average house prices to 12.3 million rupees (S$195,777) from April to September. Despite a 3% drop in unit sales, total sales value increased by 18%. Luxury home demand is driving the growth, with wealthy Indians abroad expected to make up almost a fifth of all home sales by 2025. Developers are racing to build new residences to match the rising demand, with DLF tripling new sales bookings to 64 billion rupees in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: epa11492581 Indian Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman attends a press conference in New Delhi, India, 23 July 2024. The Union Budget 2024-25 was presented in the parliament by the country's finance minister. This is the first full budget of the third term of the Narendra Modi government after the elections in 2024. EPA-EFE/HARISH TYAGI

Cargo Ships are docked at the Mumbai Port in India, Sunday September 18, 2005. Indian ports need to double capacity within the next five years to cope with India's rising demand for raw materials while handling increased exports.
Rising food prices have reduced the purchasing power of middle-income households, affecting corporate earnings and hurting growth in India.

site_title: ‘We want to be at the table, we want to have a say’: PM Wong on why platforms like G20 matter
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of regional groupings and international forums like the G20 summit in adapting to the reconfigured global trade landscape. He stressed that countries want to trade with those they feel are friendly to them, and regional groupings reduce dependency and vulnerability. Wong highlighted the significance of Asean and its potential to strengthen Singapore's neighborhood, as well as its connections with other regions. He also underscored the value of participating in international platforms like the G20, which provides insight into global discussions and allows for shaping emerging processes.

images.alt_text: World leaders at the G20 summit in Rio did not mention Donald Trump by name but talked in coded terms about the “next administration,” “turbulence” and “change.”

Opening the last session of the G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro, President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva suggested countries bring forward their targets to reach climate neutrality by 2040 or 2045, instead of 2050 as Brazil and many others have pledged.

Chinese President Xi Jinping said China would support global development with eight actions, including building a “high quality” Belt and Road Initiative, his signature foreign policy plan that directs large Chinese investments to infrastructure projects in the developing world.
(From left) Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva shaking hands with China's President Xi Jinping at the G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Nov 18, 2024.

This handout picture released by the Peruvian Presidency press office shows Peru's President Dina Boluarte and Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong during a bilateral meeting on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in Lima on November 16, 2024.
