site_title: Hot stock: Keppel DC Reit up 4.6% as investors weigh S$1.4 billion data centre deal, equity fundraising
summary: Keppel DC Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, saw its shares surge 4.6% to S$2.29 after a S$1.4 billion deal to acquire two data centers was announced. The trust also raised S$1.1 billion through an equity fundraising exercise, including a private placement and a preferential offering. The deal drew strong demand from investors globally, with a majority being long-only investors and real estate specialists.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Gross proceeds from the equity funding exercise will be used to finance Keppel DC Reit's acquisition of two data centres at Keppel Data Centre Campus (above).
Data centre assets have been appealing to investors in recent years for their positive rental reversions as supply remains tight.
Proceeds from the private placement will be used to partially fund the purchase two data centres at Keppel Data Centre Campus (above).
Equinix to build 6th Singapore data centre with US$260 million investment

site_title: Where AI meets design: Leveraging the unfamiliar as a business differentiator, Design AI and Tech Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: FedEx has partnered with Singapore-based startup QuikBot to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas. The partnership aims to increase efficiency and reduce labor costs. QuikBot's robots will be equipped with advanced navigation systems and can carry packages weighing up to 10 kg. The initial deployment will focus on commercial areas, such as shopping malls and office buildings. The partnership is seen as a step towards expanding FedEx's use of automation in logistics and delivery services. The robots are expected to start operations in Singapore later this year, with plans to expand to other countries in the future.

site_title: Logistics startup Locad raises US$9 million in pre-Series B funding
summary: Logistics startup Locad has secured US$9 million in pre-Series B funding, co-led by Global Ventures and Reefknot Investments. The funding will be used to expand the company's supply chain platform overseas and develop artificial intelligence capabilities. Locad's platform enables brands to store, pack, ship, and track orders in a distributed, end-to-end supply chain as-a-service. The investment round also saw participation from Sumitomo Equity Ventures, Antler Elevate, Febe Ventures, and JG Summit.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Fintech funding in the six largest Asean economies has fallen by less than 1 per cent for the first three quarters of 2024, a significant improvement from the year-ago period.
Locad aims to build what it calls the “region’s largest fulfilment network” over the next five years.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 20)
summary: The Singapore Certificate of Entitlement (COE) for mainstream cars, Category A, dropped by 10% or S$10,000 to S$89,889 in November's second round of bidding. HDB rents rose 0.5% in October, while condo rents increased 0.5% in the same month. Indonesia's central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged at 6% to stabilize the rupiah. Meanwhile, Bentley launched a hybrid electric version of its most powerful road car in Singapore, and Singapore stocks fell 0.4% amid mixed regional market performance.

site_title: Tokyo’s scorching summers focus public anger against tree cutting
summary: In central Tokyo, residents are protesting the removal of 32 ginkgo trees to widen a sidewalk and create a bicycle path, with some even camping out overnight to protect the trees. The trees are part of a larger issue of climate change and greenery in the city, which has seen a decline in tree cover from 9.2% in 2013 to 7.3% in 2022. Residents are also concerned about the lack of consultation in redevelopment projects, leading to public anger and calls for greater consideration of greenery in urban planning.

images.alt_text: XXX

US President Joe Biden speaks after signing a proclamation designating November 17 as International Conservation Day during a tour of the Museu da Amazonia as he visits the Amazon Rainforest in Manaus, Brazil, Nov 17, 2024.

site_title: Vietnam raises US$175.6 million in government bond auction
summary: Vietnam raised US$175.6 million in a government bond auction on November 20, down from US$244 million last week. The country aims to raise US$15.8 billion from government bond sales this year to fund public investments, key drivers of economic growth. The auction saw a lower uptake, with 44.6% of the offer sold compared to 56.4% last week.

images.alt_text: Vietnam has so far this year raised 133.4 trillion dong from government bond sales, according to data from the Hanoi Stock Exchange.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid mixed regional showing; STI drops 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% on Wednesday, November 20, amid mixed regional performance. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,743.64, with gainers outnumbering losers 269 to 235. The Nikkei 225 in Japan dropped 0.2%, while Kospi in South Korea rose 0.4%. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong closed 0.2% higher, while Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index lost 0.3%. The decline was attributed to investor concerns over escalating geopolitical tensions and Nvidia's upcoming earnings report.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
CLI intends to acquire the remaining 60 interest in phases over the next five years and invest at least S$524 million in SC Capital’s fund strategies to support the growth of its platform.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 81 to 30.

site_title: Blackstone nears US$2.6 billion deal for Seibu’s Tokyo Complex
summary: Blackstone is near a US$2.6 billion deal to buy Seibu's Tokyo Garden Terrace Kioicho complex. The sale, which could be completed by the end of this year, would be Blackstone's largest real estate deal in Japan and a significant purchase by a foreign fund. Seibu Holdings is negotiating a price of around 400 billion yen (S$3.44 billion) with the US asset manager, with the option to continue operating the complex. The deal would be one of the most expensive single real estate transactions in Japan.

images.alt_text: A potential deal could value Avery Lodge at S$750 million to S$780 million, says Bloomberg's sources.
Blackstone is one of the world’s largest investors in real estate, with US$336.1 billion in assets in the sector as at the end of June.

site_title: Chinese banks hold lending rates steady after big cut last month
summary: Chinese banks held benchmark lending rates steady at 3.10% for one-year loans and 3.60% for five-year loans, following a major cut last month. The move aligns with economists' forecasts and signals stabilization in the world's second-largest economy. Beijing's stimulus measures, including interest-rate cuts and debt swaps, aim to support growth ahead of President-elect Donald Trump's return, who has threatened to increase tariffs on Chinese shipments. The central bank is likely to roll out further policy easing steps, including a reserve requirement ratio cut, in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Most of that debt is tied to entities known as local government financing vehicles, which borrow on behalf of provinces and cities to finance investment in infrastructure.

site_title: OfBusiness hires Axis, JPMorgan, Citi among banks for 2025 Indian IPO
summary: OfBusiness, a SoftBank-backed Indian shopping website, has appointed five investment banks, including Axis Capital, JPMorgan, and Citi, for its planned US$1 billion initial public offering (IPO) in 2025. The company aims to list in late 2025 despite a recent market correction in India, and remains profitable with a US$72.6 million after-tax profit in its fiscal year. OfBusiness was valued at around US$5 billion in 2021 and exports goods to clients such as Lulu, Costco, and Tommy Hilfiger.

images.alt_text: Solar panels in Gujarat Solar Park. While a boom in Chinese production has partly caused a glut in the global supply of solar panels, Waaree’s fortunes have surged as countries like the US look to reduce their dependence on supplies from Beijing.
A drop of around 10 per cent in the value of the US dollar versus the yen over the period is expected to boost SoftBank’s bottom line.

site_title: UK inflation jumps to 2.3%, underscoring BOE's stance for gradual rate cuts
summary: The UK's inflation rate jumped to 2.3% in October, exceeding market expectations and surpassing the Bank of England's 2% target. The increase was largely driven by a rise in domestic energy tariffs. The BOE expects headline inflation to rise to 2.4% and 2.5% in November and December, and price growth is likely to approach 3% in the second half of next year. The news has led to a cautious stance on interest rate cuts, with investors pricing in a slower pace of rate reductions.

images.alt_text: epa11666753 Shoppers on Oxford Street in London Britain, 18 October 2024. UK retail sales have shown modest growth for September. Retails sales grew by 0.3% in September, a slowdown from the 1.0% increase recorded in August.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Period-care startup Blood takes its corn-based sanitary pads across the region
summary: A period-care startup called Blood has successfully expanded its corn-based sanitary pads across Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia, reaching over 6,000 stores. The company, founded by husband-and-wife duo Caleb Leow and Tan Peck Ying in 2014, initially faced rejection from major retailers due to its small size. Despite this, Blood persevered and has now become a leading period-care brand in the region, offering a unique and sustainable solution to menstrual care.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Xenia Wong founded Sigi Skin when she was 23 and fresh out of university.
From left: Desiree Lim, Eleanor Lim, Daphne Lim and Richard Lim of EDL. The company supplies high pressure laminates, a surfacing material commonly used in furniture and cabinetry.
The company managed to break even in its first year in Singapore, with revenue of S$700,000. It had been set up with a start-up capital of S$250,000.

site_title: Indonesia’s central bank holds rates steady, focuses on foreign-exchange stability
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia (BI), has kept its key interest rate unchanged at 6% amid the rupiah's post-US election slump. The decision, in line with economists' expectations, aims to stabilize the currency. BI governor Perry Warjiyo emphasized the central bank's commitment to safeguarding the rupiah due to evolving global dynamics, including Donald Trump's re-election. Analysts predict BI's room for further rate cuts is becoming increasingly limited, with some expecting the central bank to maintain rates at 5.5% in 2025.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Indonesian Retailer Association warned that the planned tax hike could hit the retail sector hard

The central bank's intervention comes as investors pulled more than US$1.2 billion from Indonesia’s markets this month amid fears that the US president-elect’s “America First” policies will lift US inflation and force the Federal Reserve to temper its rate cuts.

site_title: Bitcoin breaches US$94,000 for the first time
summary: Bitcoin has breached US$94,000 for the first time, more than doubling this year. The record high was driven by reports that Donald Trump's social media company is in talks to buy crypto trading firm Bakkt, fueling hopes of a cryptocurrency-friendly regime under the incoming Trump administration. The news added to existing optimism in the market, which has seen a surge in value to a record high of over US$3 trillion, according to analytics and data aggregator CoinGecko.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has skyrocketed over 32 per cent since Nov 5 to an all time high of more than US$91,000 as traders bet President-elect Donald Trump’s promised support for digital assets would lead to a less restrictive regulatory regime.
Bitcoin has become one of the most eye-catching movers in the week since the election and on Wednesday touched a record of US$93,480 before paring gains.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit’s upsized private placement closes at S$2.09 apiece; equity fundraising totals S$1.1 billion
summary: Keppel DC Reit's private placement closed at S$2.09 apiece, raising S$700 million in gross proceeds. The exercise, which included a non-renounceable preferential offering and sponsor subscription units, was 3.4 times subscribed and drew "strong demand from new and existing unitholders globally." The proceeds will partially fund the purchase of two data centers, with about S$945.2 million going towards this purpose.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Equinix to build 6th Singapore data centre with US$260 million investment
Data centre assets have been appealing to investors in recent years for their positive rental reversions as supply remains tight.

Post-capital reduction, Keppel will be able to effectively manage when and how the legacy assets are monetised.

site_title: China funds slash ETF fees, escalating price war in booming market
summary: China's top ETF fund companies have slashed fees by up to 70% in a bid to intensify price competition in the rapidly expanding US$400 billion market. The move comes as net inflows into China's onshore ETFs have exceeded 900 billion yuan this year, on track to register the biggest inflows over the past decade. The fee cuts are expected to potentially channel new capital into a waning bull market, but will also hurt industry margins. This move is seen as a response to China's chief securities regulator's pledge to encourage index investment and fund industry fee reform.

images.alt_text: The US$9.5 billion iShares China Large-Cap ETF, known by its ticker FXI, saw US$315 million in outflows last week, extending a four-week streak of withdrawals following massive inflows earlier in October.
With billions of US dollars worth of trading volume flowing across the border between Hong Kong and Shanghai and Shenzhen on a daily basis, the stock connect has been a success.
The Shanghai Composite index closed up 2.32 per cent at 3,386.99 points, while the blue-chip CSI 300 jumped 2.53 per cent to 4,044.57 points.

site_title: Conflict in Myanmar sparks surge in Thai property purchases
summary: Thai condominium unit sales to Myanmar nationals tripled to over 1,000 units worth $158 million in the first nine months of 2024, driven by the country's economic turmoil. The surge in foreign property purchases, particularly from Myanmar, provides a boost to Thailand's sluggish real-estate market, which is also facing a decline in sales from Chinese and Russian buyers due to economic woes in their own countries. The junta's efforts to restrict foreign exchange flows have not deterred investors, with some buying properties to avoid keeping money in their war-torn home country.

images.alt_text: Natthapatt Tanboon-ek, chief financial officer at WHA Corp., speaks during the Thailand Focus Forum in Bangkok, Thailand, on Wednesday, Aug. 28, 2024. The conference runs through today. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg

site_title: Dyna-Mac to delist after close of exit offer
summary: Dyna-Mac, an offshore oil-and-gas contractor, will delist from the Singapore Exchange after Hanwha Ocean SG's voluntary unconditional cash offer, acquiring about 95.2% of shares. The offeror, a special purpose vehicle owned by Hanwha Aerospace and Hanwha Ocean, will compulsorily acquire remaining shares. This move satisfies the exchange's free-float requirement, allowing Hanwha to take Dyna-Mac private. The company will delist after the close of offer on Wednesday, November 20.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Navene Elangovan
Hanwha's offer had previously turned unconditional on Nov 5 as to acceptances.
Dyna-Mac main yard in Gul Road. Hanwha Ocean SG's offer for the company remains conditional on the CCCS green-lighting the deal.

site_title: Asean fintech shows resilience amid global downturn: report
summary: Southeast Asia's fintech sector has shown resilience despite a global downturn, with funding in the six largest Asean economies falling by less than 1% in 2024. Singapore and Thailand led the region in terms of funding, with Singapore attracting the most with 62 deals worth US$745 million. Early-stage companies received 60% of the total fintech funding, with payments leading the way, followed by blockchain and banking tech. The sector is expected to benefit from the US Federal Reserve's rate cuts, which may lead to cheaper funding, greater investor appetite, and higher valuations.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
The cryptocurrency sector ranked first in fintech deal volume in South-east Asia, although its share of funding fell from 21% in 2022 to 11% in 9M 2023.

site_title: SpaceX fails to repeat Starship booster catch, as Trump looks on
summary: SpaceX's Starship successfully launched on its sixth test flight, with President-elect Donald Trump in attendance, but failed to catch the booster stage in the launch tower's "chopstick" arms. The Super Heavy first stage made a subdued splashdown in the Gulf of Mexico, citing unmet technical criteria. The test flight aimed to demonstrate precision, but the company cited a system failure that could have spelled catastrophe. The flight marked a quick turnaround between test flights and comes ahead of SpaceX's plans for uncrewed missions to Mars in 2026.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk speaks with U.S. President-elect Donald Trump and guests at a viewing of the launch of the sixth test flight of the SpaceX Starship, in Brownsville, Texas, U.S., November 19, 2024 . Brandon Bell/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Lens on Singapore: A second Trump presidency - A bull or bear run for Asia?
summary: A recent podcast discusses the potential impact of a second Trump presidency on the US economy and Asia. The podcast explores how Trump's policies, such as tariffs, could affect the US dollar and global markets. Experts are analyzed for their views on whether a second Trump presidency would lead to a bull or bear run for Asia, with varying opinions on the potential economic outcomes.

site_title: The new Republican war on science
summary: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has been nominated by Donald Trump as the head of the US Department of Health and Human Services, sparking widespread concern among public health officials. Kennedy's appointment is seen as a reflection of Trump's disdain for scientific consensus and his deregulation agenda. Kennedy has voiced unorthodox and conspiracy-driven views on vaccines, climate change, and other scientific issues, and his appointment may lead to a "Republican war on science" that could undermine the US's global leadership in health and environmental issues.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump attends the America First Policy Institute (AFPI) gala at Mar-A-Lago in Palm Beach, Florida, U.S., November 14, 2024. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo

The Supreme Court ruled this summer that presidents enjoy absolute immunity for “official” acts in office - a landmark decision viewed as unleashing the power of the presidency. Now that Donald Trump has once again become president-elect, cases against him and others are expected to be thrown out.
A U.S. Coast Guard boat patrols outside U.S. President-elect Donald Trump's residence at Mar-A-Lago in Palm Beach, Florida, U.S., November 14, 2024. REUTERS/Carlos Barria

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB upgrades UOB to ‘buy’, lifts price target to S$40.20 on positive 2025 outlook
summary: RHB has upgraded its call on UOB to "buy" and raised its price target to S$40.20, citing a positive 2025 outlook. Analysts expect UOB's Asean-centric portfolio to provide a "hideout" from market volatility and the lender's multi-year investments in platforms and its Citi acquisition to gain traction. UOB's earnings growth is forecast to outperform peers, with a 6% year-on-year growth in profit after tax and minority interests, leading to a 9% dividend growth forecast for FY2025F.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the United Overseas Bank (UOB) signage in Singapore May 3, 2023. REUTERS/Caroline Chia/File Photo
Therese Soh

site_title: Lights, action, melodrama! Silent films get new reel at London haven
summary: A London-based cinema, the Kennington Bioscope, screens rare silent films with live piano accompaniment, celebrating the largely forgotten works from the dawn of cinema. The society, which has been meeting for years, brings together film enthusiasts to experience these classic movies. The venue, now home to the Cinema Museum, was once a 19th-century workhouse where Charlie Chaplin was sent as a child. The screenings showcase the importance of silent films, which influenced later filmmakers, and highlight the rarity of these lost movies, with many considered "shadowy" figures due to the loss of their work.

images.alt_text: (From left) Dwayne Johnson, Lucy Liu and Chris Evans attend the premiere of Amazon and MGM Studios' "Red One" at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Centre in New York City, New York, Nov 11, 2024.
"Venom: The Last Dance" has now taken in US$114.8 million domestically and US$279 million internationally in its three weeks.
'Venom: the Last Dance' has grossed a respectable US$90 million domestically and US$227 million internationally in its two weeks out.
The crime series will be available from Wednesday on the Disney+ platform.
Tom Hanks at the premiere of "Here" during AFI Fest in Hollywood on Oct 25.

site_title: Thailand expects to distribute 140 billion of baht in handouts in Q2 next year
summary: Thailand plans to distribute 140 billion baht (S$5.4 billion) in handouts in the second quarter of 2025 as part of its cash stimulus scheme, aiming to boost the economy to a 3% growth rate next year. So far, 14.5 million recipients have received 10,000 baht payments, with an estimated 45 million expected to participate. The government also expects full-year growth in 2024 to reach 2.8%.

site_title: In bringing workers back to office, employers risk losing something more valuable
summary: Employers mandating a return to office for employees can risk losing valuable workers due to the negative impact on work-life balance and trust. A recent example is Amazon's five-day return-to-office mandate, which prompted 523 employees to sign an open letter in protest. The move may signal distrust and callousness towards employees, potentially leading to resentment rather than increased productivity. Many teams have already found success in hybrid environments, making the benefits of a full return to office marginal.

images.alt_text: Generic image of office worker using his mobile phone.
Janice Heng

site_title: Australia critical infrastructure faces cyber threats: report
summary: Australia's critical infrastructure faces significant cyber threats, with 11% of cybersecurity incidents in 2023 related to critical infrastructure such as electricity, gas, and transport services. State-sponsored actors, including China, Russia, and Iran, are targeting the country's government and businesses using evolving tradecraft. The Australian Signals Directorate attributes cyber incidents to these countries, with China showing a focus on disruptive effects rather than traditional cyber espionage. The government is concerned about the increased focus on critical infrastructure and urges international cooperation to address the threat.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrency Bitcoin are seen in this illustration picture taken in Paris, France, March 9, 2024. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/Illustration/File Photo
Israeli spy software Pegasus can remotely access messages, calls and files on a phone, as well as activate its microphone and camera.
The World Health Organization (WHO) says such attacks on hospitals “can be issues of life and death”.

site_title: Singapore shares climb on Wednesday; STI up 1.5%, led by banks, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.5% on Wednesday, led by gains in local banks and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended at 3,886.98, driven by DBS' breach of S$45 for the first time and OCBC's 4.2% gain. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding climbed 4.4% after BlackRock became its latest substantial shareholder. Maybank analysts highlighted OCBC and UOB as beneficiaries of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone pact.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sink as investors flock to safety amid geopolitical jitters
summary: Europe's main stock index, the Stoxx 600, fell 0.4% on Tuesday, its lowest point in three months, amid escalating geopolitical tensions. Investors sought safer havens as Russia lowered its threshold for a nuclear strike, prompting a risk-off move. Safe-haven assets like gold and the US dollar rose. The Euro Stoxx volatility index reached near its highest levels this month, signaling growing investor anxiety. Consumer discretionary and luxury stocks declined, while banks were the worst-hit sector, slumping 1.4%.

images.alt_text: The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index finished at 18,987.47, up 1.0 per cent on Tuesday.

site_title: Trafigura paid bribes via ‘Mr Non-Compliant’: Swiss prosecutors
summary: Swiss prosecutors have accused Trafigura Beheer BV, the former parent company of Trafigura, of failing to prevent unlawful payments to an Angolan official from 2009 to 2011. The company faces charges alongside former senior executive Mike Wainwright and a Swiss middleman. A 150-page indictment revealed that Trafigura's late founder, Claude Dauphin, was a central participant in the scheme. If convicted, Trafigura could face a maximum fine of 5 million Swiss francs and repayment of US$140 million. The trial is set to begin on December 2.

images.alt_text: Trafigura office building

site_title: Don’t say his name - Trump is the Voldemort of G20 summit
summary: World leaders at the G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro avoided directly mentioning US President-elect Donald Trump by name, instead referring to him in coded terms as the "next administration," "turbulence," and "change." French President Emmanuel Macron made veiled comments about tariffs and climate policies, while UN chief Antonio Guterres praised the US role on climate without mentioning Trump. Officials and diplomats downplayed the significance of Trump's impending return to power, with one saying they would work with him "again" despite his divisive rhetoric and policies.

images.alt_text: Opening the last session of the G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro, President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva suggested countries bring forward their targets to reach climate neutrality by 2040 or 2045, instead of 2050 as Brazil and many others have pledged.

Chinese President Xi Jinping said China would support global development with eight actions, including building a “high quality” Belt and Road Initiative, his signature foreign policy plan that directs large Chinese investments to infrastructure projects in the developing world.
(From left) Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva shaking hands with China's President Xi Jinping at the G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Nov 18, 2024.

Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer (L) shakes hands with China's President Xi Jinping, ahead of their bilateral meeting at the Sheraton Hotel, on the sidelines of G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil on November 18, 2024. (Photo by Stefan Rousseau / POOL / AFP)

(FILES) Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva attends the swearing-in ceremony of new Minister of Human Rights Macae Evaristo at Planalto Palace in Brasilia, on September 27, 2024. Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva canceled his trip to Russia for the BRICS summit after suffering a domestic accident, although he will participate by videoconference, the presidency informed on October 20, 2024. (Photo by EVARISTO SA / AFP)
One potential success for COP29 is the growing enthusiasm for nuclear power. Six new countries joined a pledge to triple global nuclear capacity by 2050.

US President Joe Biden speaks after signing a proclamation designating November 17 as International Conservation Day during a tour of the Museu da Amazonia as he visits the Amazon Rainforest in Manaus, Brazil, Nov 17, 2024.

site_title: Comcast to proceed with plans to spin off its cable channels, sources say
summary: Comcast plans to spin off its NBCUniversal cable television networks, including MSNBC and CNBC, as the company seeks to adapt to the decline of cable TV subscriptions and viewership due to the rise of streaming services. The spinoff would be capitalized by Comcast shareholders and positioned to acquire other cable networks, retaining NBCUniversal's broadcast network, film studios, and Peacock streaming service. The move is expected to generate approximately $7 billion in revenue annually, and Comcast would retain its Xfinity broadband service.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Small toy figures with laptops and smartphones are seen in front of displayed Comcast logo, in this illustration taken December 5, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Resorts World Sentosa gets shortened 2-year licence renewal on ‘unsatisfactory’ tourism performance
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) has received a 2-year licence renewal from the Gambling Regulatory Authority (GRA) due to "unsatisfactory" tourism performance from 2021 to 2023. The evaluation panel deemed areas requiring improvement and recommended a 2026 evaluation. RWS' next evaluation will be based on its ability to develop and promote the integrated resort as a tourist destination. The decision comes after a significant decline in tourism during the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Navene Elangovan
The renewal comes as Resorts World Sentosa expands its resort.
The quarter-on-quarter decline in Genting Singapore’s performance was mainly attributable to lower VIP rolling volume and win rate, said the group.
The loan will be used to refinance an existing S$4 billion seven-year borrowing from August 2019, sources said.
Andrew MacDonald, former chief casino officer at Resorts World Sentosa, has stepped down effective Nov 1, 2024.

site_title: Bentley Singapore launches S$1.5 million hybrid EV version of its most powerful road car
summary: Bentley Singapore has launched the Continental GT Speed PHEV, a hybrid electric version of its most powerful road car, priced at S$1.5 million. The plug-in hybrid can travel 81 km on electric power alone and has a top speed of 335 km/h. The Continental GT Speed PHEV is Bentley's second PHEV to hit the Singapore market, with a four-litre V8 petrol engine, 190 horsepower electric motor, and 25.9 kilowatt-hour battery. It emits 141 g/km of carbon dioxide, making it cleaner than the previous model.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
As PHEV technology improves, it could offer consumers and business owners an alternative to full EVs long into the future, even in Singapore.
The Yutong C11H plug-in hybrid bus is an example of extended-range electric vehicle technology that is gaining ground in China.

BYD's electric vehicle Atto is displayed during the 31st Gaikindo Indonesia International Auto Show (GIIAS) at the Indonesia Convention Exhibition in Tangerang, Indonesia, July 26, 2024. Rho Motion expects this year’s sales in China, the world’s largest EV market, to rise by one third from last year to 10.5 million vehicles, while it sees European sales roughly in line with last year’s 3.1 million units.
The Audi Group said that operating earnings slumped 91 per cent to 106 million euros (S$152 million) in the three months through September.
Million Air’s facilities provide private jets with fuelling, hangaring and aircraft servicing at general aviation airports.
Production of the W1 is limited to 399 vehicles; all of them have been allocated to specific customers.
Global luxury brands are seeking to increase their presence in Korea where spending on personal luxury goods was the world’s highest per-capita in 2022.

site_title: Vietnam’s Techcombank eyes global talent and investors for Asean ambitions
summary: Vietnam's second-largest private bank, Techcombank, is seeking global talent and investors to support its ambitions in the Asean region. CEO Jens Lottner aims to grow the bank's technology, digital, and data roles to 25% of its workforce within five years. The bank has already tripled its data science and IT staff from 500 in 2020 to 1,600, and plans to expand its international presence. Techcombank is positioning itself as a "startup at scale" to navigate potential exit by Warburg Pincus, a strategic investor.

images.alt_text: Techcombank kicks off Vietnam's biggest IPO
Truong My Lan is the chairwoman of Van Thinh Phat (VTP) Group, one of Vietnam’s most influential real estate empires.
Supply has not kept up with the rising population in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City and housing prices are outpacing income growth.
WinCommerce boasts Vietnam's largest network of offline stores with about 3,700 minimarts and supermarkets.
Vingroup's chairman Pham Nhat Vuong had completed his funding commitment of US$1 billion from his personal wealth to VinFast by the second quarter of 2024.

site_title: Seven & i shares soar after report founding family aims to complete buyout this FY
summary: Seven & i Holdings shares rose 9.2% to 2,661 yen (S$23) after a media report indicated the founding Ito family aims to complete a buyout within this fiscal year. The family plans to raise over US$51.7 billion to take the company private through a special purpose company. This move comes as the company faces pressure to convince investors it can enhance value on its own, amid a US$47-billion takeover bid from Alimentation Couche-Tard.

site_title: Oil settles flat as Sverdrup field restart counters geopolitical concerns
summary: Oil prices rose slightly on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures settling at US$73.31 per barrel, up a cent, amid escalating tensions in the Russia-Ukraine war. However, the partial restart of Norway's Johan Sverdrup oilfield limited gains. The US also reported a first use of US ATACMS missiles against Russian territory, prompting a warning from Russian President Vladimir Putin about a possible nuclear strike.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$73.30 a barrel, gaining US$2.26, or 3.2 per cent on Monday.

site_title: Walmart raises annual forecasts, betting on strong holiday shopping
summary: Walmart raised its annual sales and profit forecast for the third consecutive time, citing strong holiday shopping and growing e-commerce sales. The retailer expects fiscal 2025 consolidated net sales to rise 4.8-5.1% and annual adjusted profit per share to be between $2.42 and $2.47. Walmart's US comparable sales rose 5.3% in the third quarter, beating analyst estimates, driven by increased sales of groceries and merchandise online and in-store. The company attributes its growth to upper-income households seeking non-essential merchandise.

images.alt_text: Walmart, the world’s biggest retailer, has slashed Christmas imports deeply, shipping at least 340,000 kilos of products described as “Christmas” goods into the US in the 12 months ending Sep 30.
The Waltons have longed ranked at or near the top of the world’s richest families, and currently have a total net worth of more than US$350 billion.
Walmart is expanding the assortment on its marketplace, which offers merchandise from third-party vendors, to meet customer demand.

site_title: Hennessy staff strike over plans to bottle cognac in China
summary: Around 500 Hennessy staff went on strike in protest of plans to bottle cognac in China to avoid tariffs, which impose over 30% duties on EU imports. The strike follows a discussion by industry body Maisons de Cognac, which proposed shipping cognac in containers and bottling it in China. The move aims to reduce costs, but the strike highlights concerns over the potential impact on the French cognac industry.

images.alt_text: Beijing’s commerce ministry said that authorities have “decided to implement temporary anti-dumping measures in the form of a cash deposit or letter of guarantee” against European brandy products.
The EU launched an anti-subsidy investigation into imports of Chinese-made battery EVs last year and in October voted for tariffs on those vehicles.
BYD’s European registrations jumped 162 per cent in September from a year earlier, to 4,376 vehicles, according to Jato.

site_title: Alibaba sells its first dollar bonds since 2021
summary: Alibaba Group Holding sold its first public dollar bonds in nearly four years, issuing $2.65 billion in three parts, including a 30-year bond priced 1.05 percentage point above comparable Treasuries. The offering is part of a dual-currency transaction to repay offshore debt and repurchase equity. The move comes as Chinese issuers bolster dollar-bond issuance amid the country's fresh stimulus efforts and the Federal Reserve's policy rate cut.

images.alt_text: The 5.5-year bond has an initial price guidance of Treasuries and about 90 basis points, the 10.5-year is Treasuries plus about 115 basis points and the longer-dated bond is Treasuries plus 130 basis points.
With billions of US dollars worth of trading volume flowing across the border between Hong Kong and Shanghai and Shenzhen on a daily basis, the stock connect has been a success.
Alibaba said it would use the cash raised for general corporate purposes including debt repayment and funding share repurchases.

Ant said it will start offering an AI “life assistant” app called Zhixiaobao, which can help people order meals, hail taxis, book tickets and access other functions in Ant’s mobile payments service Alipay, which has one billion users.
Alibaba reported revenue of 236.50 billion yuan (S$43.9 billion) for the second quarter ended Sep 30

site_title: CLI to acquire initial 40% interest in SC Capital Partners for S$280 million
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) has agreed to acquire a 40% stake in Singapore-headquartered real estate investment manager SC Capital Partners for S$280 million, expected to close in Q1 2025. This deal is expected to increase CLI's funds under management (FUM) to S$113 billion and boost its presence in Japan, with trebled FUM in Japan from S$2.9 billion to S$11 billion. CLI will also acquire the remaining 60% interest in SC Capital in phases over the next five years, with a plan to invest at least S$524 million in SC Capital's fund strategies.

Generic shots of SGX

SC Capital set sights on Japanese hotels with US$550m fund

site_title: German wages rose by most in three decades in Q3
summary: Germany's wages rose by 8.8% in Q3, the fastest rate in three decades, according to the Bundesbank. This growth is expected to shape European Central Bank monetary policy, with some analysts predicting a sharp increase in euro-area pay figures. Despite strong wages, the German economy is expected to stagnate in the fourth quarter, while inflation is likely to accelerate due to base effects. The Bundesbank notes that economic weakness persists, with factors such as high uncertainty and low capacity utilization weighing on investment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, July 14, 2021. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: Panetta says ECB rates must move to neutral level to aid growth
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) Governor Fabio Panetta urged the ECB to cut interest rates to neutral or even expansionary territory to aid economic growth, as the bank weighs its next move after three rate cuts this year. Panetta stated that restrictive monetary conditions are no longer necessary and that the ECB needs to normalize its monetary policy stance. The ECB is expected to continue cutting rates, with investors pricing in more moves until the deposit rate reaches 2% mid-next year, potentially stimulating the economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, July 14, 2021. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: Audemars Piguet and Kaws boldly fuse high watchmaking with art
summary: Audemars Piguet has collaborated with artist Kaws on a limited-edition Royal Oak Concept Tourbillon "Companion" watch. The 43mm titanium case features a miniature Kaws' character, Companion, at its core, with hour and minute hands rotating around the edge of the watch. Powered by the Calibre 2979 hand-wound movement, the watch combines technical brilliance with contemporary artistic vision. Only 250 pieces are produced, solidifying the partnership between the watchmaker and artist.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Chroma Forged Technology (CFT) is used in the new AP Royal Oak Concept Split-Seconds Chronograph GMT Large Date.

site_title: Nearly 1 million UK workers are uncounted, think tank says
summary: A UK think tank, the Resolution Foundation, claims that nearly 1 million workers are uncounted in the official labour market statistics, suggesting the actual employment rate may be higher than reported. The think tank estimates the Office for National Statistics (ONS) has underestimated growth in the number of people in work since 2019 by 930,000. This discrepancy complicates the Bank of England's decision on interest rates, as the ONS data shows a lower employment rate than previously thought.

images.alt_text: People walk during heavy rain, as flooding continues in areas of the country, in the Canary Wharf financial district of London, Britain, September 26, 2024. REUTERS/Toby Melville

site_title: Bankers need grit to navigate the shifting energy landscape: DBS’ Kelvin Wong
summary: DBS' Kelvin Wong, head of energy, renewables, and infrastructure, emphasizes the need for grit and curiosity to navigate the rapidly changing energy landscape. With trends shifting towards renewables and grid capacities, Wong notes that augmenting grids and pairing them with long-duration storage solutions are crucial. As a bank, understanding these trends is essential for informed lending, advisory, and risk-taking decisions, with international partnerships and close contact with industry players vital for staying ahead of the curve.

images.alt_text: DBS' managing director and head of energy, renewables and infrastructure Kelvin Wong
Chong Xin Wei

site_title: Shareholders can gain from DBS buying back shares, even at record prices
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest listed bank, has introduced a S$3 billion share buyback program, allowing shareholders to benefit from the return of excess capital. While some may view share buybacks as less desirable than paying dividends, they can help drive long-term share price performance and improve key metrics such as return on equity. DBS has a strong franchise and robust balance sheet, positioning it to benefit from continued inflows of money to Singapore and potential inflationary effects of US President Donald Trump's policies. The bank's disciplined capital management approach is expected to continue under its new leadership, potentially setting a standard for others to emulate.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
DBS shares have continued climbing after Gupta's share sales, closing last week up nearly 1.3 per cent
Singapore banks see upsides to net interest margins (NIMs) during a second Donald Trump term as US president, given that markets expect inflationary policies that may result in higher interest rates.
DBS says its S$3 billion share buyback programme promises to raise earnings per share and return on equity.

site_title: US$3 billion raised by S-E Asia IPOs is lowest in almost a decade: Deloitte
summary: The Southeast Asian IPO market raised a record-low US$3 billion from January to November 2024, with 122 companies going public, down from 163 in 2023. Malaysia led the region with 46 listings, raising US$1.5 billion, and a market capitalization of US$6.6 billion. The market is expected to improve in 2025 due to expected interest rate cuts, which could create a more favorable environment for listings. Regulatory steps and a focus on real estate investment trusts (Reits) in Singapore are also expected to boost the market.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
With billions of US dollars worth of trading volume flowing across the border between Hong Kong and Shanghai and Shenzhen on a daily basis, the stock connect has been a success.
Data centre assets have been appealing to investors in recent years for their positive rental reversions as supply remains tight.

site_title: Cryptoverse: ‘Elation’ as Bitcoin basks in Trump glow
summary: Bitcoin has surged 32% since Nov 5, reaching an all-time high of over $91,000, as traders anticipate a less restrictive regulatory regime under President-elect Donald Trump's administration. The crypto market value has soared to $3.16 trillion, with Ethereum jumping 32% and decentralized finance-focused tokens reaching a five-month high. However, market experts caution that investors could face profit-taking and market pullbacks, with some warning of short-term speculation triggered by the appointment of Trump's US Treasury Secretary.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A bitcoin is seen in an illustration picture taken at La Maison du Bitcoin in Paris, France, June 23, 2017. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Guardiola set to extend stay as Man City boss
summary: Pep Guardiola is set to extend his stay as Manchester City manager by signing a one-year contract extension, according to reports. The 53-year-old coach, who has won six Premier League titles and the club's first Champions League, will see his current deal expire at the end of the season. Guardiola has lost four consecutive games for the first time in his coaching career, but retaining him would be a significant boost to the team's morale. The extension includes an option for another year.

images.alt_text: Pep Guardiola is chasing an unprecedented fifth straight Premier League title with Manchester City, which are now five points behind leaders Liverpool after 11 matches.
Ruben Amorim enjoyed a successful stint at Portuguese club Sporting Lisbon and he will hope to bring that winning feeling back to Manchester United.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, November 19, 2024
summary: Asian markets rallied after the US market bounced back, with Nvidia's focus drawing attention. In other news, Indonesia announced a planned VAT hike amid sluggish demand, causing business uproar. Meanwhile, speculation over a potential merger between StarHub and M1 is expected to be resolved by June 2025, with telcos deferring spectrum payment.

images.alt_text: Across broader markets, gainers outnumbered losers 67 to 25 after 62.8 million securities worth S$65.1 million changed hands.
Tokyo stocks recovered from a soft start to the week, while Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Wellington and Manila shares also gained on Tuesday.
Indonesian Retailer Association warned that the planned tax hike could hit the retail sector hard
The price moves by both StarHub and M1 have not gone unnoticed.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp takes US$1 billion hit on steel unit as outlook darkens
summary: Thyssenkrupp, a German conglomerate, has written down the value of its steel division by $1.06 billion, citing weak demand and Asian competition. This impairment, the second in two years, has driven the company to a $1.5 billion annual net loss. Despite the negative news, Thyssenkrupp's shares jumped 10% as analysts see the impairment as a step towards selling a stake in the troubled steel business. Czech billionaire Daniel Kretinsky, who owns 20% of the company, is expected to raise his stake to 50%.

images.alt_text: The management struggle comes against a background of higher costs and growing imports of cheaper Asian steel, placing the future of Germany’s largest steelmaker further into question.

site_title: Frencken posts 29.3% rise in Q3 profit to S$9.2 million
summary: Frencken, a semiconductor player, reported a 29.3% increase in Q3 profit to S$9.2 million, driven mainly by its mechatronics division's 10.8% revenue growth to S$176.8 million. Revenue rose 7.7% to S$198.6 million, attributed to higher contributions from semiconductor, analytical life sciences, and industrial automation segments. The company remains aware of potential trade restrictions affecting the tech sector but holds a positive outlook for the longer term.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan

Republican presidential nominee and former U.S. President Donald Trump stands with a hard hat at the end of his Make America Great Again Rally in Latrobe, Pennsylvania, U.S. October 19, 2024. REUTERS/Brian Snyder
A report issued by S&P Global Market Intelligence highlights Frencken, UMS and AEM as three out of the five most-shorted stocks in Singapore.
Singapore-listed stocks related to the clean energy sector stand to benefit under an administration led by US presidential candidate Kamala Harris and her running mate Tim Walz, say analysts.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CLI, Keppel DC Reit, Koh Brothers Eco, Frencken, GuocoLand
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) acquired a 40% stake in SC Capital Partners for S$280 million, with plans to invest at least S$524 million in the fund over five years. Keppel DC Reit closed a private placement, upsizing to S$1.1 billion, and its shares resumed trading on Wednesday. Koh Brothers Eco Engineering secured a S$77.6 million contract, boosting its order book to S$585.7 million till 2027. GuocoLand led a top bid for a private housing site, and Frencken Group reported a 29.3% increase in profit to S$9.2 million for the three months ended Sep 30.

site_title: Why Asean should matter to the European Commission
summary: The European Commission should prioritize collaboration with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) due to the region's growing economic and strategic significance. The EU's lack of attention to Asean has created a void that could lead to decreased US involvement in the region. Expanding collaboration across key policy areas, such as trade, digital economy, environment, and energy, is crucial for Europe's interests. The EU should engage with Asean through diplomatic outreach, travel, and improved cooperation to capitalize on the region's dynamic growth and strategic importance.

images.alt_text: Fostering international collaboration may help more green technology diffuse to Asean, particularly for countries lagging in innovative capacity.
Singapore Prime Lawrence Wong made his Asean Summit debut in his current capacity in Vientiane, Laos this October. He was sworn in as the Republic’s fourth prime minister in May.
Malaysia’s Minister of Investment, Trade and Industry Zafrul Aziz says Defa will facilitate e-commerce and enable Asean countries to thrive collectively.
CPOPC is an intergovernmental organisation for palm oil producing countries, including the world’s biggest palm oil producer Indonesia, Malaysia and Honduras.

site_title: Hello Kitty’s looking pretty at 50 – and worth more than ever
summary: Hello Kitty, the iconic Sanrio character, is celebrating her 50th birthday and has become the second-highest-grossing media franchise in the world. Worth over $8.7 billion, Kitty's appeal lies in her expressionless face, allowing fans to project their feelings onto her. Sanrio is diversifying its revenue streams with a partnership with Warner Bros for a live-action/animated movie, which could make her the most valuable media property. The company has also expanded its brand to appeal to a wider age group, including adults, and has seen a resurgence in popularity thanks to the internet and the global trend of kawaii.

images.alt_text: Nintendo’s been expanding into new areas to capitalise on its intellectual property and reduce the ups and downs of an industry hostage to gaming hits.
Patent protection in software typically covers elements of the user experience and Nintendo may have found gameplay mechanics that it believes infringe on its rights.

P2E games are a subcategory of Web3 games that leverage blockchain technology to create secure, tradable tokens. The number of games launched, the increase in market capitalisation and the rise in daily active users in recent months all point to the recovery in the Web3 gaming market.
The Palworld mania has not gone unnoticed by other games makers.
Survival adventure game "Palworld" has sold more than eight million copies since its Jan 18 release.
With higher interest rates, many companies have re-oriented to focus on profit rather than rapid revenue growth.
The San Francisco-based Unity Software is behind a software toolkit used by many video game developers, including the maker of the popular Pokemon Go mobile game (above).

site_title: Investors rush into safe-haven currencies after Kremlin nuclear doctrine
summary: Investors rush into safe-haven currencies, including the US dollar, Swiss franc, and yen, after a warning from Russia over its updated nuclear doctrine. The yen jumped 0.5% versus the dollar and 0.8% against the euro, hitting its highest since October 4. The dollar index rose 0.25% to 106.46, while the euro dropped 0.4% to US$1.0553. Analysts attribute the risk-off move to complacency on geopolitical risks and positioning in the market.

images.alt_text: Against a basket of currencies the dollar held at 106.77, having touched a one-year top of 107.07 on Friday.
In early Asian trade, Hong Kong and Sydney stocks led gains, adding more than one per cent each, while Singapore, Seoul, Wellington and Manila shares also rose.

The dollar has benefited from market expectation that Trump administration policies, including tariffs and tax cuts, could stoke inflation, leaving the Federal Reserve less room to cut interest rates.

site_title: China’s debt clean-up leaves less cash for big building projects
summary: China is diverting funds from new local government special bonds to repay older debt through 2028, as part of a push to improve the finances of cash-strapped localities. The move, which involves using 800 billion yuan from bond sales, will reduce the availability of funds for big infrastructure projects, undermining the government's efforts to revive the economy. This is the first time funds from bond sales are being used to repay old debt, highlighting Beijing's concern over local government debt and its impact on the country's fiscal health.

site_title: Legal documents no longer needed for small claims on a deceased’s CDP assets
summary: Singapore has simplified the claims process for relatives of deceased individuals who died intestate and had assets valued at S$5,000 or less. The change eliminates the need for legal documentation, reducing costs and processing time. Relatives must still fulfill certain conditions, such as obtaining signed letters of consent from other beneficiaries, to minimize the risk of disputes. The new procedure aims to relieve the administrative burden on family members, particularly those facing difficult financial circumstances. The change takes effect on November 19, 2024.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Regulators could help us mitigate risk – but not at expense to the speculative spirit. To do so is to interfere with the normal functioning of the equity markets.
MAS has also rejected CCIAM’s application to become a licensed fund management company, due to the contraventions by CCIAM and Sun.

site_title: The low spark of high-friction trade
summary: Global trade faces challenges due to subdued growth, rising costs, and lower productivity. Shipping costs have surged 300% as container ships take longer routes to avoid the ongoing conflict in the Middle East. This trend is part of a broader increase in trade friction, with over 3,000 new restrictions introduced last year, including export controls, tariffs, and data flow limitations. The rising tensions threaten decades of globalization and accelerate regionalization and balkanization.

images.alt_text: Bank of America’s buildup of advisory work on upcoming mergers and acquisitions is strong, while its pipelines for IPOs “are full and ready to go,” CEO Brian Moynihan told attendees at the Clearing House Annual Conference, New York City, US, Nov 13, 2024..

site_title: US$34 billion asset manager plans to hire in Singapore for climate finance
summary: Mirova, a US$34 billion asset manager, plans to hire in Singapore for climate finance, focusing on blended finance, green bonds, and multi-thematic strategies. The Paris-based unit aims to expand in Asia, particularly in energy transition-related investments, with a goal of tripling annual investments to US$2.3 trillion by 2030. Deputy CEO Guillaume Abel expressed interest in hiring staff for client services and has experience with blended finance projects in Africa, Latin America, and plans to invest in India.

images.alt_text: Companies exploiting gaps between countries’ tax systems cost governments somewhere between US$100 billion and US$240 billion of lost annual revenue, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).

site_title: Trump names China hawk Howard Lutnick as US commerce secretary
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump nominated Howard Lutnick, co-chair of his transition team, as his commerce secretary. Lutnick will lead the country's tariff and trade agenda, with "additional direct responsibility for the Office of the United States Trade Representative." This choice is expected to bring a tougher stance on China, with Trump promising sweeping duties on all imports. Lutnick, chairman and CEO of Cantor Fitzgerald, was originally tipped as a frontrunner for the US treasury secretary position.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has skyrocketed over 32 per cent since Nov 5 to an all time high of more than US$91,000 as traders bet President-elect Donald Trump’s promised support for digital assets would lead to a less restrictive regulatory regime.

Chinese President Xi Jinping said China would support global development with eight actions, including building a “high quality” Belt and Road Initiative, his signature foreign policy plan that directs large Chinese investments to infrastructure projects in the developing world.
FILE PHOTO: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump attends the America First Policy Institute (AFPI) gala at Mar-A-Lago in Palm Beach, Florida, U.S., November 14, 2024. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo
World leaders at the G20 summit in Rio did not mention Donald Trump by name but talked in coded terms about the “next administration,” “turbulence” and “change.”

Opening the last session of the G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro, President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva suggested countries bring forward their targets to reach climate neutrality by 2040 or 2045, instead of 2050 as Brazil and many others have pledged.

site_title: Trump versus the ‘deep state’: Hostile takeover of permanent government
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is placing loyalists in key government positions, potentially undermining the "permanent government" and the "deep state". Trump's picks include ardent Trumpists, such as Vice-President JD Vance and Secretary of Homeland Security Governor Kristi Noem, who share his "America First" agenda. The appointments include Matt Gaetz as attorney-general, Pete Hegseth as Pentagon chief, and Tulsi Gabbard as director of national intelligence, despite concerns over their qualifications and potential impact on the government. This move is seen as a hostile takeover of the permanent government, with Trump seeking to consolidate power and eliminate perceived enemies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump attends the America First Policy Institute (AFPI) gala at Mar-A-Lago in Palm Beach, Florida, U.S., November 14, 2024. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo

site_title: The EU needs a strong clean industrial deal
summary: The European Union needs a strong clean industrial deal to address sector-specific issues, combining decarbonisation with competitiveness and social cohesion. The EU should subsidise strategic supply chains in technological areas where it has a comparative advantage, balancing trade-offs between decarbonisation, competitiveness, and security. To meet its climate goals, the EU must implement the Fit for 55 package, reducing greenhouse-gas emissions by at least 55% by 2030 and 90% by 2040. A clean industrial deal can help the EU tackle its existential challenges, including the natural-gas crisis and social cohesion.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise as falling Treasury yields lift global equities; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.7% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,757.97 points. The rally was driven by falling US Treasury yields, which boosted emerging markets and commodities. Key regional indices also ended higher, with gainers outnumbering losers 297 to 214. Analysts attributed the market's performance to easing Treasury yields, which have fueled cautious optimism among traders and potentially paved the way for a December Federal Reserve rate cut.

Keppel also said it plans to establish a new private fund to own and manage the legacy rigs, as well as attract third party capital.

site_title: GuocoLand-led group tops three bids for Faber Walk site with conservative S$900 psf ppr offer
summary: A GuocoLand-led consortium topped three bids for a 25,795.4 sq m site in Faber Walk with a S$349.9 million offer, translating to about S$900 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). This is slightly above expectations of S$750 to S$850 psf ppr, but below the winning bid for a nearby Clementi plot sold last year. The site is expected to yield 400 residential units with a maximum gross floor area of 36,114 sq m.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Ry-Anne Lim
URA said the 400 sites the Faber Walk site will yield is part of the 5,050 homes that will be released under the second half of the 2024 Government Land Sale programme.

site_title: US housing starts slide 3.1% as hurricanes impact South region
summary: US housing starts declined 3.1% in October to a 1.31 million annualized rate, the slowest pace in three months. Hurricanes Helene and Milton impacted the South, where construction activity dropped 8.8%. Single-family home construction fell 6.9%, while multifamily starts rose 9.6%. Building permits eased 0.6%, and the number of projects under construction slipped nearly 2%. Economists expect only a modest decline in mortgage rates next year, with the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rate expected to fall to 5.9% by the end of next year.

images.alt_text: Builders have blamed uncertainty over the presidential election for restraining sales recently, along with mortgage rates that rebounded after hitting a two-year low in September.

site_title: Asia needs to look inward for growth
summary: Asia's growth outlook is less promising in 2025 due to the potential imposition of US tariffs on China imports, which could spill over to other Asian economies with high exposure to China. The effective tariff rate is expected to rise by 15 percentage points in 2025 and 10 percentage points in 2026, slowing Asia's growth from 4.5% in 2024 to 4.1%. With a less supportive backdrop for trade, Asia will have to look inward to domestic demand as a growth driver.

site_title: Google’s Anthropic AI deal cleared by UK antitrust agency
summary: Google's partnership with AI firm Anthropic has been cleared by the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) after the agency determined that Google did not gain "material influence" over Anthropic. The deal, which includes a $2 billion investment, was reviewed and found to not qualify for a full investigation under merger rules. This decision comes as multiple antitrust cases pile up in Europe and the US, including one that threatens to force Google to sell off its Chrome browser. Anthropic remains an independent company with its freedom to partner with others unchanged.

site_title: Mulberry to cut handbag prices below £1,100 to boost sales
summary: Mulberry, a British luxury goods company, is cutting the prices of its handbags to boost sales. The company's new CEO, Andrea Baldo, aims to sell 60% of its products for less than £1,095, with the flagship Bayswater bag already priced at that level. This move is part of an effort to target customers seeking more affordable luxury goods amid a downturn in demand. The company has also announced plans to cut 85 corporate roles due to declining sales.

images.alt_text: Loss-making Mulberry, known for its luxury handbags and belts, had rejected Frasers’ initial proposal of £83 million, saying it undervalued the company.

site_title: Rent inflation won’t ebb until mid-2026
summary: Rent inflation in the US consumer price index is expected to remain elevated until mid-2026, according to research by the Cleveland Fed. Fewer people are moving and signing new leases, resulting in a lag in capturing turnover in the CPI. This could pose a challenge to policymakers who cite progress on inflation as a key argument for lowering interest rates. Experts warn that rising rent inflation, even if lagged, makes communication more challenging, potentially leading to fewer rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Builders have blamed uncertainty over the presidential election for restraining sales recently, along with mortgage rates that rebounded after hitting a two-year low in September.

site_title: Beijing pledges support for more Chinese listings, bond issues in Hong Kong
summary: Beijing pledges support for Chinese companies to list and issue bonds in Hong Kong, with Vice Premier He Lifeng promising to help Chinese financial institutions expand their businesses in the city. The move comes as Hong Kong's standing as a regional capital markets hub faces scrutiny, with issuance volumes remaining below pre-pandemic levels. Beijing's stimulus measures are gradually taking effect, benefiting Hong Kong's markets, and the city is expected to consolidate its position as a global financial business hub.

site_title: Lula urges G20 leaders to move faster on net zero climate targets
summary: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva urged G20 leaders to accelerate their climate targets, calling for countries to reach net zero emissions by 2040 or 2045, five to 10 years ahead of the current 2050 pledge. This comes as climate disasters become more frequent and intense, with 2024 likely to be the world's warmest year on record. Lula emphasized the need for swift action, stating "there is no time to lose."

site_title: Seven & i founding family aims to raise 8 trillion yen for buyout this year: NHK
summary: The founding Ito family of Seven & i aims to raise over 8 trillion yen (S$70 billion) to take the company private by the end of this financial year. A special purpose company is in talks with Japan's three largest lenders and major US financial institutions to secure the funds. This move comes as the company faces pressure to convince investors it can enhance value on its own and fend off a US$47-billion takeover bid from Canada's Alimentation Couche-Tard.

site_title: Thousands of British farmers protest against 'tractor tax' on inheritance
summary: Thousands of British farmers protested against a proposed 20% inheritance tax on farms worth over $1.3 million, set to take effect in 2026. The tax, dubbed the "tractor tax," would target wealthier estates and the most valuable farms, but farmers argue it will destroy family farms and threaten food production. The protest, which included some driving tractors through central London, has sparked an angry backlash from farmers who claim the Labour government does not understand rural communities.

images.alt_text: The retailers want the UK government to phase the introduction of the new lower earnings threshold for National Insurance, delay the introduction of packaging levies, and revisit and bring forward proposed changes to business rates.
UK workers have been helped by a surge in health-related inactivity that has left sectors from construction to hospitality struggling to fill vacancies.

site_title: Sony in talks to buy media powerhouse behind 'Elden Ring'
summary: Sony is in talks to acquire Kadokawa, the Japanese media powerhouse behind the hit fantasy role-playing game 'Elden Ring', with a potential deal to be signed in the coming weeks. Sony already holds a 2% stake in Kadokawa and a stake in its subsidiary FromSoftware. The acquisition would add to Sony's entertainment portfolio, following its focus on anime and intellectual property. Kadokawa's shares rose 23% following the news, with a market capitalization of around $2.7 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk in front of Sony Corp's headquarters in Tokyo January 22, 2009. site_title: Koh Brothers Eco unit wins S$77.6 million contract for upcoming Toa Payoh development
summary: Koh Brothers Eco Engineering, a CATALIST-listed engineering solutions provider, has won a S$77.6 million contract from Sport Singapore for the upcoming Toa Payoh Integrated Development, a 12-hectare project scheduled for completion in 2030. The 18-month contract involves piling, ground improvement, and earth retaining structure installation. This marks Koh Brothers Eco's first contract with SportSG and is expected to boost its order book to S$585.7 million by 2027.

site_title: China’s Xi announces steps to support ‘Global South’ at G20 summit
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping announced eight measures to support global development at the G20 summit, including a "high quality" Belt and Road Initiative and an "Open Science International Cooperation Initiative" with Brazil, South Africa, and the African Union. Xi emphasized China's commitment to the "Global South" and its role as a reliable partner for developing countries, with imports from these countries expected to reach $8 trillion by 2030. The move aims to counter the growing influence of the Global South in multilateral talks and presents an opportunity for China to strengthen its ties with developing economies.

site_title: UBS launches inaugural Art for All community programme
summary: UBS has launched an inaugural "Art for All" community programme, a 60-meter-long woven tapestry to commemorate Singapore's 60th anniversary in 2025. The tapestry is being made by over 80 Care Corner students and UBS staff volunteers, with the weaving open to public participation during the Art SG fair. The programme aims to make art "accessible to all" and foster sustainable practices, with workshops and talks on art and sustainability to be held throughout the year.

site_title: US semiconductor firm launches initiative in Singapore for power-efficient AI data centres
summary: US-based semiconductor firm Applied Materials has launched an initiative in Singapore, called the Equipment and Process Innovation and Commercialisation (Epic) Advanced Packaging Platform, to accelerate energy-efficient computing technologies. The partnership aims to bring together industry firms to develop and commercialize advanced chip-packaging technologies, focusing on energy-efficient system performance. The initiative encourages alliances between equipment makers, material providers, device companies, and research institutes to drive innovation and commercialization in the field.

site_title: Keep bond duration short; rates may remain higher for longer
summary: The US Federal Reserve struck a cautiously optimistic tone on the labour market in its November meeting, with unemployment rates "edging down" over the past three months. However, it maintained caution on inflation, removing the phrase "greater confidence" regarding inflation moving towards 2%. The Fed is likely to keep interest rates higher for longer due to a resilient labour market and core inflation above 2%. Investors are advised to prefer shorter-duration fixed-income products, which are less sensitive to interest rate fluctuations, amid expected Fed-cut expectations.

site_title: Dubai ruler’s firm eyeing two real estate listings in 2025: sources
summary: Dubai Holding, the investment conglomerate owned by Dubai's ruler, is considering listing its commercial and residential properties separately in 2025. The company is bundling its malls and commercial assets into a potential listed entity and packaging its residential properties into a real estate investment trust (Reit), which is expected to be listed early next year. The move is part of Dubai's efforts to deepen its capital markets, following recent listings of state-owned firms and private companies.

site_title: Johor rejects nearly one-third of 14 data centre applications in Jan-May to protect water, power resources
summary: Johor, Malaysia, has rejected nearly 30% of data centre applications in the past five months to conserve water and power resources. The state's data centre development coordination committee vetted 14 applications, rejecting four due to unsustainable practices and inadequate utilities infrastructure. The committee prioritizes data centres with sustainable practices, job creation, and potential clients. Johor aims to maintain a balance between economic growth and resource conservation, with plans to increase data centre capacity to 2.7 gigawatts by 2027.

images.alt_text: A data center project that Nvidia is building with the energy subsidiary of one of Malaysia's biggest conglomerates in Johor, Malaysia, on Sept 11.

site_title: Thailand to start second stage of stimulus programme in January
summary: Thailand is set to launch its second stage of a stimulus programme in January, distributing 40 billion baht (S$1.55 billion) to 4 million people to boost consumption. The programme aims to support low-income earners and those over 60 who need financial assistance. The second tranche will be transferred by late January, before the Lunar New Year, and will include a suspension of interest and reduced principal payments for borrowers with overdue debts. The government's flagship US$14 billion stimulus programme has already distributed payments to 45 million people.

images.alt_text: Growth has been slow due to low investment and employment as well as high household debt and troubles for smaller businesses, Pichai Chunhavajira says.

site_title: Keppel to take over legacy rigs; plans to establish offshore infrastructure private fund
summary: Keppel will take over 13 legacy rigs held by Rigco following a selective capital reduction exercise. The exercise will cancel all of Rigco's shares not held by Keppel, resulting in Rigco becoming a wholly owned subsidiary of Keppel. Keppel currently holds a 10% equity stake in Rigco, S$139 million in perpetual securities, and S$4.3 billion in vendor notes. Keppel does not intend to re-enter the offshore and marine business.

Seatrium's contract with Japanese construction company Penta-Ocean Construction is expected to be awarded in the first quarter of 2025.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 19)
summary: Resorts World Sentosa's casino licence has been renewed for a 2-year term due to "unsatisfactory tourism performance." The Gambling Regulatory Authority recommended a 2-year evaluation period, with the next assessment in 2026. Meanwhile, Keppel DC Reit is acquiring 2 hyperscale data centers for S$1.4 billion, and DBS, OCBC, UOB, and Maybank are syndicating Singapore's largest loan of S$12 billion to refinance an existing S$4 billion borrowing. WeWork has also given up two prime locations in Singapore amid co-working woes.

site_title: COP29: Singapore and Zambia ink carbon credit deal
summary: Singapore and Zambia have signed a preliminary carbon credit deal, paving the way for bilateral trading of credits aligned with the Paris Agreement. The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) will facilitate the exchange of best practices and knowledge, and both countries will work together to identify potential carbon mitigation projects. The deal is seen as a step towards promoting sustainable development and upholding environmental integrity, with the goal of achieving national climate targets.

site_title: Singapore stocks to benefit from MAS reforms next year: Morgan Stanley
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index, a benchmark for the country's 30 biggest companies, reached a 17-year high, with year-to-date gains of 17%. Analysts at Morgan Stanley predict the market will continue to benefit from the Monetary Authority of Singapore's efforts to boost the equities market, citing low market expectations and a positive impact from US election uncertainty. The index may see a 20% rise in valuations, narrowing the gap with global peers.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks recovered from a soft start to the week, while Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Wellington and Manila shares also gained on Tuesday.

site_title: Jailing of 45 Hong Kong democrats in landmark trial draws criticism
summary: In a landmark trial, 45 Hong Kong pro-democracy activists were jailed for up to 10 years for conspiracy to commit subversion under Beijing-imposed national security laws. The activists, charged with organizing an unofficial primary election in 2020, were accused of plotting to paralyze the government. Western governments, including the US, have criticized the trial as "politically motivated," while the Chinese and Hong Kong governments say the laws were necessary to restore order. The ruling has damaged Hong Kong's democracy movement and tarnished its role as a global financial hub.

site_title: A rising tide, but will it lift all boats?
summary: Singapore's property market experienced a surge in buying activity, with almost 1,500 new homes sold in three weekend launches, marking an 11-year high for monthly sales. The latest condo launches, including Emerald of Katong, Nava Grove, and Novo Place, attracted strong interest, with sales rates ranging from 57% to 99%. The question remains whether this buying momentum will continue, or if it was driven by a fear of missing out. The next slate of projects to be released in the first half of next year will be closely watched for further market developments.

With population growth, lower interest rates and stable supply, private home prices are not headed for a correction and are poised for steady growth instead, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

site_title: Equinix to build 6th Singapore data centre with US$260 million investment
summary: Equinix plans to build its 6th data centre in Singapore, SG6, with a US$260 million investment, expected to open in Q1 2027 and providing 20 megawatts of capacity. The facility will be a nine-storey, sustainable data centre with liquid-cooling capabilities, supporting Singapore's goal of increasing its data centre capacity to 300 MW. This investment aligns with the government's Green Data Centre Roadmap and aims to support the country's digital economy, which contributes 18% to its GDP.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
The pilot DC-CFA exercise was launched last year to facilitate the sustainable building of new data centre capacity.
