site_title: Asian Americans are also shifting to the right
summary: Asian Americans shifted towards the right in the 2024 US presidential election, with 39% backing Republican candidate Donald Trump, despite Vice-President Kamala Harris' South Asian background. This marks a decline in the Democratic Party's hold over Asian American voters, with Harris losing 7 points compared to the 2020 election. The shift is attributed to economic concerns and Trump's appeal to non-white voters, with the Republican candidate winning more black voters than any Republican in 48 years.

images.alt_text: In 2024, 15 million Asian-Americans will be eligible to vote in the presidential race.

site_title: Malaysia’s October exports rise 1.6% y/y, close to forecast
summary: Malaysia's exports rose 1.6% in October, exceeding forecasts, with a trade surplus of RM11.98 billion. Imports grew 2.6% but were weaker than expected. The country's trade surplus is above the poll forecast of RM10.4 billion. This growth is a positive sign for the economy, but it also reflects concerns about the impact of tariffs on trade.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as Russia-Ukraine tensions escalate
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, November 19, 2024, as tensions between Russia and Ukraine escalated, prompting investors to seek safe-haven assets. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 146.3 points, or 0.34%, to 43,243.27. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 23.6 points, or 0.40%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 92.1 points, or 0.49%.

site_title: China tells local funds to stop buying LGFV bonds via Hong Kong link
summary: China has asked its brokerages and banks to suspend purchases of local government financing vehicle (LGFV) dim sum bonds via the Bond Connect, a programme linking the mainland and Hong Kong debt markets. The move aims to contain risks from the debt-laden sector, which has attracted strong demand due to higher yields. The suspension is effective immediately, with no clear timeline for resuming purchases. This is the latest effort by China to manage risks in the LGFV market.

site_title: How to spot a bubble
summary: The US stock market and others worldwide are experiencing rapid growth, raising concerns about a potential bubble. Key indicators include everyone making money, unsustainable growth projections, and assets being bought to sell rather than for intrinsic value. Cryptocurrencies, like Bitcoin, have soared following Donald Trump's US presidential win, with prices nearing all-time highs. Traditional businesses are being overlooked, and investors are prioritizing the next big thing. Trusting instincts and focusing on fundamentals are crucial in spotting a bubble, as the phrase coined by Justice Potter Stewart suggests that it's often an observable fact that cannot be easily defined.

site_title: Financing the next lap of growth
summary: Entrepreneurial companies can choose between going public through an initial public offering (IPO) or tapping private equity firms for funding. Going public offers access to permanent capital, improved brand visibility, and enhanced employee retention, but comes with increased regulatory requirements and pressure to deliver on promises. Private equity firms, on the other hand, provide customized solutions, ease financial burdens, and offer extensive networks for growth. Ultimately, companies must be clear about their motivations and goals to determine the best funding strategy.

site_title: Swiss watch exports fall again amid plummeting demand in China
summary: Swiss watch exports declined 2.8% in October to 2.3 billion Swiss francs, with China's imports plummeting 39% due to a post-pandemic boom slowdown. This marks the second consecutive month of decline, with overall exports falling 2.6% in the first 10 months of 2024. Growth in exports to the US and Japan offset the decline, with US shipments rising 11% and Japan climbing 20%. Expensive watches showed resilience, rising 1.7% in value, while more affordable models declined 21%.

site_title: DBS, OCBC, UOB, Maybank syndicating Singapore’s biggest loan of S$12 billion for Marina Bay Sands
summary: Singapore's Marina Bay Sands is seeking a S$12 billion loan, the largest financing from Singapore, to fund its expansion. DBS, Maybank, OCBC, and UOB are coordinating the loan, which will be syndicated to other financiers and carries a 7-year tenor. The loan will refinance an existing S$4 billion borrowing from August 2019. The terms of the facility have not been finalized and may change as negotiations continue.

Fireworks at the end of National Day Parade 2024 (NDP 2024) National Education Show 1 (NE1) held at the Padang, taken from Bay East Garden against CBD skyline, Gardens by the Bay and Marina Bay Sands on July 13, 2024.

site_title: GetGo drives revenues at a cost as bottom line turns red
summary: GetGo, a Singapore-based ride-hailing company, saw significant revenue growth in 2023, reaching 55% year-over-year. However, the company's bottom line turned red due to increased employee benefits and fleet-leasing expenses. Despite these challenges, GetGo's CEO, Ting Feng Toh, expects the company to hit profitability this year. The company's expansion efforts, including the addition of electric vehicles, aim to support Singapore's Green Plan 2030. GetGo's revenue growth was driven by convenience and operational efficiency, with the company now offering EVs to 10% of its fleet.

site_title: Alibaba delivers initial price guidance on US$5 billion dual-currency bond, term sheet shows
summary: Alibaba has delivered initial price guidance on its $5 billion dual-currency bond. The 5.5-year US dollar tranche is priced at Treasuries plus 90 basis points, while the 10.5-year and 30-year bonds are priced at Treasuries plus 115 and 130 basis points, respectively. The offshore yuan tranche has bonds priced at around 2.9-3.8% for corresponding maturities.

site_title: Apple said to offer US$100 million to undo Indonesia iPhone 16 ban
summary: Apple has increased its proposed investment in Indonesia to nearly US$100 million, a 10-fold increase from its previous offer of around US$10 million, in an attempt to persuade the government to lift its sales ban on the iPhone 16. The ban was imposed due to Apple's lack of domestic content in its products, with the company having invested only US$95 million in Indonesia. The Ministry of Industry is now demanding that Apple alter its investment plans to focus more on research and development for its smartphones in the country, with no final decision yet made on the proposal.

images.alt_text: In recent years, Apple has started assembling some of its products in India and Vietnam.
The device has a roughly six-inch screen and looks like a square iPad and about the size of two iPhones side by side, with a thick edge around the display.
Apple’s App Store, iTunes Store and other media services unlawfully discriminate against European customers based on their place of residence, according to European Commission.

site_title: China consumers remain cautious despite stimulus, BCG says
summary: China consumers remain cautious about spending despite the government's recent stimulus measures, with consumer confidence remaining neutral to slightly negative, according to a Boston Consulting Group report. The report notes that consumers are padding their savings due to future uncertainties, potentially hindering a long-lasting recovery for consumption. While some sectors, such as fresh produce and education, have seen noticeable growth, a full recovery is expected to take more time and possibly further stimulus measures.

images.alt_text: People walk past a lane lined up with restaurants, at a shopping area in Shanghai, China September 28, 2024. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: Arthur Frommer, creator of renowned travel guides, dies at 95
summary: Arthur Frommer, creator of the renowned travel guide series, has died at 95 due to complications of pneumonia. Frommer, a former US Army soldier, began his business with "The GI's Guide to Travelling in Europe" at 50 US cents in the mid-1950s and went on to become a household name for affordable international travel. His guidebooks expanded to 350 titles, selling 2.5 million guides annually, according to a 2010 company statement.

images.alt_text: (FILES) French singer Charles Dumont poses during a portrait session at his apartment in Paris on March 19, 2018. Musician Charles Dumont, composer of Edith Piaf's legendary "Je ne regrette rien", died in the night from November 17, 2024 to November 18, 2024 in Paris at the age of 95, his partner Florence announced to AFP. This singer-songwriter, who had also collaborated with Barbra Streisand, died following a long illness at his home. (Photo by CHRISTOPHE ARCHAMBAULT / AFP)
Jones became one of pop music’s most formidable figures. He collected six of his 27 Grammy Awards for his 1990 album “Back on the Block” and was a three-time producer of the year honoree.

site_title: Europe: Shares stall as real estate stocks weigh
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed 0.06% lower at 502.84 points on Monday, marking its first four-week losing streak in 2-1/2 years. Real estate stocks weighed down the market, while tech shares dipped 0.4% ahead of Nvidia's quarterly results. Energy shares gained 0.8% following a surge in oil prices, and the Basic Resources sector rose 0.6% as copper prices ticked up. Investors await speeches from European Central Bank policymakers and await economic data, with concerns over US trade tariffs and interest rates.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1 per cent to 43,389.60 while the broad-based S&P 500 Index rose 0.4 per cent to 5,893.62 on Monday.

site_title: Gold hits one-week high on softer US dollar; markets await Fed cues
summary: Gold prices reached a one-week high on Tuesday, driven by a softer US dollar, reaching US$2,621.95 per ounce. US gold futures gained 0.5% to US$2,626.30, while spot silver rose 0.3% to US$31.26. The market awaits Federal Reserve comments on the US interest rate outlook, with traders expecting a 25bps rate cut in December. A weaker dollar makes bullion less expensive for buyers holding other currencies, contributing to the price increase.

images.alt_text: Gold posted its biggest weekly decline in more than three years on Friday.

site_title: Thai hotel group Minor plans to halve US$7 billion liabilities with Reit launch as tourism booms
summary: Minor International, a Thai hotel group, plans to halve its $7 billion liabilities by launching a real estate investment trust (Reit) next year. The company, which operates over 500 hotels worldwide, aims to reduce its liabilities by re-deploying some properties and expects a double-digit growth in profit. Minor chairman Bill Heinecke forecasts a strong recovery in tourism, particularly in the Middle East and Europe, with occupancy rates expected to rise. The company's shares rallied 7.8% following the announcement, with Heinecke predicting 45 million foreign tourist arrivals in Thailand next year, surpassing the government's target of 40 million.

site_title: Nestle to cut costs, boost marketing under new CEO
summary: Nestle, a Swiss food giant, plans to cut costs and boost marketing under its new CEO, Laurent Freixe. The company aims to achieve cost savings of at least 2.5 billion Swiss francs by 2027 and increase its advertising and marketing investment to 9% of total sales by 2025. This move is part of a strategy to drive growth and achieve a medium-term organic growth rate of over 4%. The company will also carve out its water and premium drinks businesses into a standalone global unit starting January 1, 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Swiss national flag flies beside a flag of the canton of Bern in front of the logo of Nestle at a plant in Konolfingen, Switzerland September 28, 2020. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Business uproar mounts as Indonesia pushes VAT hike amid sluggish demand
summary: Indonesia is set to increase its value-added tax (VAT) to 12% on January 1, sparking concerns over reduced consumer spending and economic instability. The move has triggered backlash from businesses and consumers, with the Indonesian Retailer Association warning of a severe impact on the retail sector. The government aims to boost tax revenue amid ambitious spending plans, but economists caution that the hike could fuel inflation and deepen pessimism among businesses. The VAT increase is seen as a move that contradicts President Prabowo Subianto's populist image, and his administration faces an uphill battle in balancing fiscal policy with economic stability.

images.alt_text: A shopping mall in outskirt of Jakarta, Indonesia.
Elisa Valenta

site_title: Asia: Markets rally after US bounce as Nvidia comes into focus
summary: Asian markets rallied on Tuesday after a positive day on Wall Street, driven by hopes for more economic stimulus from China and Nvidia's upcoming earnings release. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai saw gains, while Sydney, Seoul, and Singapore also rose. The focus is on Nvidia's earnings, which could steer broader tech market sentiment, and investors are scaling back bets on interest rate cuts. Despite ongoing trade tensions and inflation concerns, optimism over US tax cuts and deregulation continues to influence markets.

images.alt_text: Across broader markets, gainers outnumbered losers 67 to 25 after 62.8 million securities worth S$65.1 million changed hands.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1 per cent to 43,389.60 while the broad-based S&P 500 Index rose 0.4 per cent to 5,893.62 on Monday.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit to acquire 2 hyperscale data centres from sponsor Keppel for S$1.4 billion
summary: Keppel DC Reit has proposed acquiring two hyperscale data centers from Keppel for S$1.4 billion, expanding its assets under management by 36% to S$5.2 billion. The acquisition, expected to be completed by end-2025, will be 8.1% accretive to the Reit's distribution per unit. The deal includes a 49% interest in the joint venture, subscription for new securities, and a call option to acquire the remaining 51% stake. The acquisition is expected to deliver strong positive cash flows and capture potential upside from rental uplifts and capacity expansion.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Post-capital reduction, Keppel will be able to effectively manage when and how the legacy assets are monetised.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 12.35 points or 0.3% to 3,744.9 at the opening of trading on Tuesday, with gainers outnumbering losers 67 to 25. The market saw 62.8 million securities worth S$65.1 million change hands.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Keppel also said it plans to establish a new private fund to own and manage the legacy rigs, as well as attract third party capital.

site_title: Minds opens Regional Hub, revamps model to enhance employability of PWIDs
summary: Minds, a social service agency, has opened the revamped Minds Regional Hub in Hougang, Singapore, marking a shift from a programme-centric approach to a person-centric one. The hub integrates services for employment development, lifelong learning, support and care, and offers personalized services for persons with intellectual disabilities (PWIDs). The revamped model aims to enhance employability and quality of life for PWIDs, allowing them to stay in the community and participate in vocational training, such as crafting terrariums and developing fine motor skills. The new model will be rolled out progressively from April 1, 2025, with plans to expand to 13 renamed hubs by 2027.

Dementia Singapore is holding a fundraising concert featuring Richard Marx on Saturday, two days before the American singer’s 61st birthday.

site_title: UK PM Starmer seeks 'pragmatic' Chinese ties in meeting with Xi
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer sought to establish "consistent, durable" relations with China, pressing for trade, economic, and climate cooperation during a meeting with President Xi Jinping in Brazil. Starmer aims to reboot the UK-China Economic and Financial Dialogue and has expressed interest in broader engagement on science, technology, health, and education. The meeting marks a shift in tone, contrasting with the UK's former robust approach to differences with China.

images.alt_text: Business executives in the UK want British Prime Minister Keir Starmer (right) and his government to step up its diplomacy efforts with the incoming Trump administration in order to avoid a full-scale trans-Atlantic trade war.

site_title: Oil prices rise over 3% on Sverdrup outage, Ukraine war escalation
summary: Oil prices rose over 3% on Monday due to a halt in production at Norway's Johan Sverdrup oilfield and the escalation of the Russia-Ukraine war. Brent crude futures settled at $73.30 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $69.16 a barrel. The halt in production, combined with ongoing repairs at Kazakhstan's Tengiz oil field, tightened global supplies. The Russia-Ukraine war escalation also contributed to the price increase, with the US allowing Ukraine to use US-made weapons to strike Russian forces.

images.alt_text: Lim Oon Kuin has been sentenced to 17 years and six months imprisonment for three cheating and forgery charges.
Brent crude futures settled down US$1.52, or 2.09 per cent, to US$71.04 a barrel on Friday.

site_title: Resorts World Sentosa’s casino licence renewed for shorter 2-year term due to ‘unsatisfactory tourism performance’
summary: Resorts World Sentosa's casino licence has been renewed for a 2-year term, starting February 6, 2026, after being deemed suitable to manage and operate the casino by the authorities. The renewal was granted considering the integrated resort's performance from 2021 to 2023 as a "compelling tourist destination". The decision comes as Resorts World Sentosa undertakes an expansion.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan

Resorts World Sentosa’s highly anticipated new waterfront lifestyle development is planned for a 2030 opening
and is envisioned to set a new benchmark for Singapore and the Sentosa, positioning both as an iconic, must-visit lifestyle hub for international and local visitors.

site_title: British Airways flights delayed due to technical issue
summary: British Airways flights were delayed due to a technical issue affecting some of the airline's systems at London's Heathrow Airport, impacting thousands of passengers. The airline said it did not have a timeframe on when the issue would be resolved. Passengers were unable to file flight plans electronically, and planes were grounded across Europe. Heathrow air traffic control had to manually coordinate inbound flights. The airline's spokesperson stated that flights were operating but experiencing delays as teams worked to resolve the issue. No further information on the number of flights delayed or the extent of the disruption was provided.

site_title: The digital key to success
summary: Anthony Chow, co-founder of igloocompany, has led the company to become a leader in smart access solutions for consumers and businesses, aiming to create a "world without keys." With a vision inspired by his experience as an Airbnb host, Chow expanded igloo's presence in the US and European markets, securing partnerships with major players like Airbnb. The company has grown rapidly, with iglooworks supporting over 2,500 businesses globally. Chow is now focused on expanding igloo's product offerings, including an iglooconnect marketplace and sustainability-focused technologies, while exploring new sectors like eldercare and smart cities.

site_title: Hot stock: ST Engineering gains 4% on strong Q3 revenue showing
summary: ST Engineering's shares rose 4% in early trade after reporting a 14% year-on-year increase in third-quarter revenue to S$2.8 billion. The technology and engineering group also proposed a third-quarter interim dividend of S$0.04 per share. Despite this, Maybank downgraded its call on ST Engineering to "hold" due to the stock's share price run-up in the year to date.

site_title: US news agency AP looks to cut almost one in ten jobs
summary: The Associated Press (AP) is cutting nearly 10% of its workforce, about 8% of its total staff, with less than half impacting the news division. The layoffs, primarily in the US, are aimed at reducing costs amid client cancellations and economic challenges. A "small number" of staff volunteers will receive severance packages, while others will be laid off. The decision, announced in a memo, will be subject to a ratification vote by the News Media Guild union.

images.alt_text: HSBC has reduced its headcount by more than 100,000 over the past 16 years as a series of CEOs tried to streamline the bank’s sprawling global operations.

site_title: Singapore’s public sector emissions down slightly in FY2023
summary: Singapore's public sector emissions decreased by 0.2% to 3,612 kilotonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent in FY2023, primarily due to the Tuas South waste-to-energy plant generating fewer emissions. Despite a slight increase in diesel use and electricity consumption, the decrease in Scope 1 emissions outweighed the rise in Scope 2 emissions. The government expects emissions to continue rising with the completion of key infrastructure projects, but the current level of emissions is 6.8% lower than FY2020 baseline emissions.

site_title: UK retail warns of inflation and job losses from budget, seeks Reeves meeting
summary: UK's biggest retailers, including Tesco and Marks & Spencer, have written to Finance Minister Rachel Reeves, warning that the recent budget will lead to higher prices and job losses. The retailers, who have 3 million direct jobs and 2.7 million more in its supply chain, fear a £7 billion rise in annual costs from 2025 due to increased business rates and packaging levies. They are seeking a meeting with Reeves to discuss their concerns and propose solutions, including phasing the introduction of the new National Insurance threshold and delaying the packaging levies.

images.alt_text: The number of new businesses started in the United Kingdom fell to 316,000 in 2023 from 337,000 in 2022.
UK workers have been helped by a surge in health-related inactivity that has left sectors from construction to hospitality struggling to fill vacancies.

The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said its house price balance rose to +16 from +11 in September, its highest level since September 2022, when the economic plans of former prime minister Liz Truss sent mortgage markets into a spin.
British consumer group Which? said Apple encouraged its users to sign up to iCloud to store photos, videos and other data while making it difficult to use alternative providers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Genting Singapore, Silverlake Axis
summary: Keppel plans to establish a private fund to own and manage legacy rigs, while Genting Singapore's casino licence has been renewed for two years starting Feb 6 next year. Genting Singapore also announced plans for a major expansion by 2030. In contrast, Silverlake Axis will soon be delisted from the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange due to a voluntary unconditional offer. Keppel DC Reit requested a trading halt pending announcements, with its units closing 0.5% lower at S$2.19.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: Philippine central bank signals easing on course after Trump win
summary: The Philippine central bank is on track to ease interest rates further, with Governor Eli Remolona signaling a possible quarter-point reduction in December and cumulative cuts of 100 basis points next year. Remolona stated that inflation is expected to stay within the 2-4% target range this month, providing authorities with leeway for rate adjustments. The move comes despite global uncertainty following Donald Trump's presidential win, but Remolona reiterated that rate reductions will be done in quarter-point increments as part of the easing cycle.

REUTERS/Neil Jerome Morales/File Photo

site_title: WeWork gives up two Singapore prime locations in sign of co-working woes
summary: WeWork is giving up two prime locations in Singapore, a sign of the company's struggles in the market. The two co-working spaces, one in Manulife Tower and another in 83 Clemenceau Avenue, will end operations due to lease non-renewal. Despite being a "priority market," WeWork remains committed to its remaining spaces in Singapore. The decision highlights WeWork's challenges in the Singapore market, which had been considered promising.

images.alt_text: WeWork has been seeking to reshape its portfolio, renegotiating more than 190 leases and exiting more than 170 spots it described as unprofitable.
SoftBank’s close ties with Nvidia and OpenAI have strengthened the company’s position amid a global race to build AI-related infrastructure.
Masayoshi Son aims to go on the offensive again after years of missteps at the Vision Fund, the sovereign wealth fund-backed investment group he set up to bet on startups

Once privately valued at about US$47 billion, WeWork expanded at a breakneck pace but racked up steep losses on its over-extended real estate portfolio before filing for bankruptcy protection in November 2023.

site_title: Two undersea cables in Baltic Sea cut, Germany and Finland fear sabotage
summary: Two undersea fibre-optic communications cables in the Baltic Sea, including one linking Finland and Germany, were severed, raising suspicions of sabotage. The incident, which occurred near Sweden's Oland Island, has sparked concerns over the security of critical infrastructure in the region. Finland and Germany are investigating the incident, which is believed to be the third sabotage in the Baltic Sea in recent years, following damage to a gas pipeline and undersea cables last year. The damage could take 5-15 days to repair.

images.alt_text: Business executives in the UK want British Prime Minister Keir Starmer (right) and his government to step up its diplomacy efforts with the incoming Trump administration in order to avoid a full-scale trans-Atlantic trade war.
Economists have long blamed the debt brake, adopted in 2009, for holding back Germany’s economy, which is expected to shrink this year.

German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, who for now runs a minority government with the backing of the Greens, hopes to secure enough opposition support to pass laws to protect the Constitutional Court from the far-right and to fund Ukraine before leaving office.

site_title: Redefining waste management for a greener Singapore
summary: Chye Thiam Maintenance (CTM) CEO Edy Tan is championing sustainability with innovative material recovery and automated cleaning solutions. The company has made significant strides in deploying Singapore's first driverless road sweepers by the end of 2024, which can operate in high-risk environments, freeing up manpower for specialized tasks and enhancing workplace safety. CTM's materials recovery facilities have become a key pillar in its business model, helping clients meet their sustainability goals. The company's focus on automation and efficiency is part of its vision to redefine waste management for a greener Singapore.

site_title: Greening the Asean economy: From hype to reality?
summary: Asean's transition to a green economy will depend on expanding green sectors such as clean energy, green infrastructure, and sustainable transportation. Despite ambitions to increase clean energy capacity and reduce emissions, Asean's clean sectors remain small and progress is slow. International collaboration and the adoption of green technology are crucial to transform "dirty" sectors and achieve green growth. Nine out of 10 Asean members have set net-zero emissions or carbon-neutral targets, but the region's green economy remains in its infancy.

images.alt_text: Flags of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) at a hotel in Labuan Bajo, May 7, 2023.

site_title: Silverlake Axis to delist after close of voluntary unconditional offer
summary: Silverlake Axis will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after its voluntary unconditional offer closed, with the offeror E2I holding 98.3% of shares. This exceeds the SGX's free float requirement of 10%. As a result, E2I will compulsorily acquire the remaining shares of shareholders who have not accepted the offer, leading to the company's delisting. The offer was made at S$0.36 per share in August and aimed to provide liquidity to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Enterprise technology company Silverlake Axis lost its free float, after obtaining over 90 per cent valid acceptance to privatise.

The two week extension of the offer closing date comes as the total number of shares held by E2I, its concert parties and valid acceptances reached 84.17 per cent of Silverlake Axis’ total number of issued shares as at 6 pm on Thursday (Oct 3)
The offer remains open for acceptance until 5.30pm on Oct 7, unless a later date is announced by E2I.
By its own account, Silverlake Axis serves 40 per cent of the top 20 largest banks in the region

site_title: Goldman Sachs readies plans to spin-out its digital assets platform
summary: Goldman Sachs is planning to spin out its digital assets platform into a new company, allowing large financial firms to create, trade, and settle financial instruments via blockchain technology. The plan, which could take 12-18 months, aims to create an industry-owned platform to facilitate faster and more efficient transactions. Goldman has already partnered with TradeWeb Markets and is exploring new commercial use cases, including secondaries transactions in private digital assets companies and resuming Bitcoin-backed lending activities.

site_title: Bank of England’s Greene reinforces case for cautious interest-rate cuts
summary: Bank of England policymaker Megan Greene emphasized the need for a cautious approach to cutting interest rates, citing stubbornly high services inflation and wage growth. She warned that the risk of cutting rates too early or too aggressively outweighs the benefits, and that policymakers must carefully monitor underlying inflation pressures. Greene's comments come ahead of official inflation data, which is expected to show inflation climbed back above the 2% target last month.

images.alt_text: UK workers have been helped by a surge in health-related inactivity that has left sectors from construction to hospitality struggling to fill vacancies.

British average weekly earnings, excluding bonuses, were 4.8 per cent higher in the three months to the end of September than a year earlier.

site_title: G20 wrestles with wars, ‘turbulence’ in run-up to Trump
summary: G20 leaders met in Brazil to address global issues such as wars in the Middle East and Ukraine, climate change, and tax on the super-rich. Chinese President Xi Jinping warned of "turbulence" as the world enters a new period of change, echoing German Chancellor Olaf Scholz's statement that the world is changing. US President Joe Biden defended Ukraine's sovereignty, but his decision to allow long-range US missiles to strike inside Russia may escalate tensions. The summit also focused on climate finance for developing countries, with UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres calling for $1 trillion a year.

site_title: Blending innovation and tradition into a recipe for success
summary: Dian Xiao Er's founder, Samuel Yik, has been crowned EY Entrepreneur of the Year in the Food and Beverage category for 2024. Yik's strategy of embracing technology has transformed the dining experience for customers and staff, streamlining operations and enhancing service quality. Despite setbacks, including the Sars epidemic and an 18-month government project, Yik's determination and focus on innovation led to the brand's success, with 19 outlets across Singapore. Yik's approach emphasizes the importance of technology, people, and branding, and he advises aspiring entrepreneurs to prioritize these key elements for success in the competitive F&B industry.

images.alt_text: "Working for a startup in a new industry provides numerous opportunities to fine-tune the strategy,” says Neuron Mobility CEO Zachary Wang.
“Our materials recovery facilities have become a key pillar in our business model, playing an essential role in helping our clients meet their sustainability goals,” says CTM chief executive Edy Tan.
Anthony Chow, co-founder of igloocompany, is focused on expanding his company's presence in the US and European markets.
A public listing is a significant milestone – one that would have taken months and years of preparation. The vital question for many companies is if an initial public offering is suitable for them.

site_title: US dollar rises against yen on BOJ caution; euro sell-off pauses
summary: The US dollar rose 0.62% against the yen to 155.12 yen on Monday, after Japan's central banker Kazuo Ueda signaled further monetary policy tightening, but left the timing unclear. The euro steadied after falling to a one-year low, while sterling dropped 2.5% since the US presidential election. The dollar's rise coincides with a surge in 10-year Treasury yields, fueling a 5.4% rise in the dollar index, as investors reassess rate-cut expectations.

images.alt_text: In early Asian trade, Hong Kong and Sydney stocks led gains, adding more than one per cent each, while Singapore, Seoul, Wellington and Manila shares also rose.

The dollar has benefited from market expectation that Trump administration policies, including tariffs and tax cuts, could stoke inflation, leaving the Federal Reserve less room to cut interest rates.
The dollar has been climbing amid rising doubts about how low the Federal Reserve will take its benchmark interest rate next year.

site_title: India's economic growth needs more affordable interest rates, minister says
summary: India's Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman stated that the country's economic growth requires "far more affordable" bank interest rates. This comes amid a surge in retail inflation, largely driven by a jump in vegetable prices, which has dashed hopes of an interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of India in December. Sitharaman emphasized that there is no cause for undue concern and that the government is committed to measures to ensure the economy remains on course, despite persistently high food inflation.

images.alt_text: Cargo Ships are docked at the Mumbai Port in India, Sunday September 18, 2005. Indian ports need to double capacity within the next five years to cope with India's rising demand for raw materials while handling increased exports.

site_title: Canada foiled Iran plot to assassinate former minister
summary: Canada foiled an alleged Iranian plot to assassinate former justice minister Irwin Cotler, who has been a strong critic of Tehran. Authorities tracked two suspects after Cotler received an imminent threat of assassination from Iranian agents. The plot comes after the House of Commons passed a unanimous motion praising Cotler's work in defence of human rights and condemning the death threats against him. Canada has listed Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps as a banned terror group, and Cotler has advocated globally to have it listed as a terrorist entity.

images.alt_text: Transactions surged 7.7 per cent in October from a month earlier to reach the highest level since April 2022, according to data released on Friday (Nov 15) by the Canadian Real Estate Association.
The Port of Montreal is closed after terminal operators shut down operations over a labour dispute with the Canadian Union of Public Employees.

site_title: US homebuilder sentiment reaches seven-month high after election
summary: US homebuilder sentiment has reached a seven-month high in November, according to the National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) and Wells Fargo, with a gauge of housing market conditions climbing three points to 46. Sales expectations and optimism about a Trump administration easing regulatory burdens contributed to the increase. Builders cited uncertainty over the presidential election and rebounding mortgage rates as factors restraining sales. The resale market remains hamstrung by the lock-in effect, and builders are using sales incentives to boost demand.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose five basis points to 6.86 per cent in the week ended Nov 8, the highest since July.
MBA’s gauge of refinancing dropped for a sixth week to the lowest level since May, marking the longest losing streak since April 2022.
The share of first-time home buyers shrunk to 24 per cent, the lowest in data going back to 1981.

The National Association of Realtors (NAR) said on Wednesday (Oct 30) its Pending Home Sales Index, based on signed contracts, rose 7.4 per cent last month to 75.8 – the highest since March – from 70.6 in August.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose 21 basis points to 6.73 per cent in the week ended Oct 25.

A for sale sign is displayed outside of a home for sale on August 16, 2024 in Los Angeles, California. United States real estate industry rules governing agent commissions will change on August 17 as part of a legal settlement between the National Association of Realtors and home sellers. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

(FILES) A maintenance worker sweeps the street in front of a row of new homes in Fairfax, Virginia, on August 22, 2023. The sales rate of new family homes in the US dipped in June, missing analyst estimates amid still elevated interest rates, according to government data released on July 24, 2024. New home sales in June came in at an annual, seasonally-adjusted, rate of 617,000, according to data released jointly by the US census and housing departments. (Photo by Andrew Caballero-Reynolds / AFP)
Home sales fell 1 per cent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.84 million units, the lowest level since October 2010.

site_title: Trump team is seeking to ease US rules for self-driving cars
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's transition team is planning to prioritize a federal framework for fully self-driving vehicles, a move that could benefit Tesla CEO Elon Musk. Current federal rules limit manufacturers to deploying 2,500 self-driving vehicles per year, but a bipartisan legislative measure is being discussed to create federal rules around autonomous vehicles. Trump's team is considering candidates such as Emil Michael and Republican Representatives Sam Graves to lead the Transportation Department, which would need to issue new rules through the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to enable mass adoption of self-driving cars.

images.alt_text: Tesla plans to launch its full self-driving technology in China early next year, pending approval.
Founded in Silicon Valley in 2016, Pony.ai develops and operates self-driving fleets in the US and China.
The company said nearly 300,000 people had joined its waitlist after it started commercial operations in the city earlier this year, signalling strong demand.
Musk appears to have backed into an admission that Tesla dropped its plans for a human-driven US$25,000 car.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as Tesla rises on self-driving optimism
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Monday, with the Dow Jones falling 0.1% to 43,389.60 and the S&P 500 rising 0.4% to 5,893.62. Tesla's share price jumped 1.4% after reports of potential ease in regulation on self-driving vehicles under a potential Donald Trump presidency. Investors are also bracing for Nvidia's earnings later this week. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.6% to 18,791.81.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 13.1 points, or 0.03 per cent, at the open to 43,431.89.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 18)
summary: Lim Oon Kuin has been sentenced to 17 years and six months imprisonment for three charges of cheating and forgery. The sentence was handed down on November 18, 2024.

site_title: China Mobile is said to explore deal for Internet provider HKBN
summary: China Mobile, the world's largest wireless carrier, is exploring a potential deal to acquire Hong Kong broadband provider HKBN, valuing the company at over HK$6.5 billion. State-backed China Mobile has been in talks with HKBN's major shareholders, buyout firms MBK Partners and TPG, and has indicated a willingness to pay at least HK$5 per share. China Mobile has conducted due diligence and is currently negotiating with MBK and TPG over the price of a potential deal, which may be higher than initially offered.

images.alt_text: The state-owned China Mobiler’s Hong Kong unit made an offer in recent weeks for Cheung Kei Center (right), which has been on the market since 2023.

site_title: Spirit Airlines files for bankruptcy protection
summary: Spirit Airlines files for bankruptcy protection amid strong travel demand, citing bloated costs despite losses. The airline's woes were exacerbated by the collapse of its $3.8 billion merger with JetBlue Airways and grounding of aircraft due to engine issues. Spirit's financial struggles worsened its debt situation, ultimately leading to the bankruptcy filing.

images.alt_text: Early-stage discussions between the air carriers involved working out terms that holders of Spirit’s roughly US$2.5 billion of debt would agree to.

site_title: ‘Finance COP’ wrong-foots after fossil fuel backlash in first week
summary: The COP29 climate summit in Azerbaijan faced its worst start in recent years, with criticism of the event's organization and the presence of a large number of fossil fuel lobbyists. Despite some key achievements, including a deal on carbon credit rules and the signing of a pledge to triple global nuclear capacity by 2050, the summit underperformed due to the controversy surrounding the rules and the influence of the fossil fuel industry. The event's failure to deliver on its promise of a "finance COP" has raised concerns about the effectiveness of global climate diplomacy, with the US potentially withdrawing from the Paris agreement under a new administration.

images.alt_text: The main problem is that wealthy countries want to cut emissions while poorer countries mainly want to eradicate poverty through growth that remains largely reliant on fossil fuels.

site_title: G20 summit kicks off with global pact to fight hunger, poverty
summary: The G20 summit in Rio de Janeiro kicked off with a global pact to combat poverty and hunger, backed by 81 countries. Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva launched the alliance, which also includes the African Union and European Union, to address global warming and poverty. However, US President-elect Donald Trump's return to power is expected to shift the global agenda, with trade, climate change, and international security taking center stage. Diplomats struggled to reach a consensus on addressing the escalating Ukraine war, and security in Rio de Janeiro has been strengthened.

images.alt_text: Smoke rises following an explosion, next to the body of a man who threw objects and committed suicide in a blast, outside Brazil's Supreme Court, in Brasilia, Brazil on Wednesday.
The Apec event includes a CEO Summit which brings together well over 1,000 C-level executives, thought leaders and government representatives.

site_title: Health span – the missing piece in retirement planning
summary: A renowned wealth advisor emphasizes the importance of health span in retirement planning. While aging cannot be stopped, delaying the onset of chronic diseases can extend good health years. To achieve this, individuals should focus on five areas: exercise, nutrition, sleep, emotional health, and managing medicines and supplements. By prioritizing these aspects and making intentional decisions, one can increase their health span and live a fulfilling retirement. The author, who has undergone targeted health screenings and implemented a comprehensive health improvement plan, encourages readers to take control of their health and plan for a successful retirement.

images.alt_text: What's important is not so much the achievement of the highest returns, but accumulating enough funds for your non-negotiable life goals and events.
bench, seaside, view

site_title: Link by link: How the region can strengthen its supply chain capabilities
summary: South-east Asia's supply chain capabilities are gaining traction, driven by companies diversifying their supply chains and investing in infrastructure. The region is attracting significant investment from Chinese manufacturers, with FDI reaching US$24 billion in 2023. Countries such as Indonesia, Vietnam, and Malaysia are performing well, with exports growing and infrastructure investments planned or underway. However, a significant gap remains in meeting future trade flows, with McKinsey estimating a US$63.6 billion gap in infrastructure investment needs. Private investors and logistics companies are seen as key players in filling this gap and supporting the region's supply chain diversification efforts.

images.alt_text: Unstable geopolitics and the possible re-emergence of pandemics have created new challenges beyond the usual price-value trade-offs in procurement from a simple focus on just cost, quality and delivery.

site_title: Crypto exchange OKX launches Singapore dollar funds transfer service for local customers
summary: OKX, a cryptocurrency exchange, has launched a Singapore dollar funds transfer service for local customers, facilitated by DBS and utilizing PayNow and Fast and Secure Transfers payment services. This move aims to deepen integration with Singapore's traditional financial system, amid rising interest in cryptocurrencies following Donald Trump's US presidential election victory. The service follows OKX's September receipt of a payments licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore, solidifying its presence in the Asian crypto market.

site_title: The drive to transform urban mobility
summary: Neuron Mobility, a Singapore-based startup, is revolutionizing the global micromobility sector with its innovative solutions. CEO Zachary Wang, a winner of the EY Entrepreneur of the Year award for mobility, has led the company to rapidly grow and partner with cities worldwide. The company recently launched a large-scale deployment of AI-powered cameras on its e-scooters in Melbourne, enabling them to detect footpath riding and improving safety. This forward-thinking approach reflects Neuron Mobility's commitment to safety innovations and its position as a global leader in micromobility solutions.

images.alt_text: “In the cut-throat landscape of the F&B sector, gaining a competitive edge is essential,” says Samuel Yik of Dian Xiao Er.
A public listing is a significant milestone – one that would have taken months and years of preparation. The vital question for many companies is if an initial public offering is suitable for them.
“Our materials recovery facilities have become a key pillar in our business model, playing an essential role in helping our clients meet their sustainability goals,” says CTM chief executive Edy Tan.
Anthony Chow, co-founder of igloocompany, is focused on expanding his company's presence in the US and European markets.

site_title: Investors eye IPO access as Hong Kong stock link turns 10
summary: Hong Kong's stock link with Shanghai and Shenzhen has celebrated its 10th anniversary with billions of US dollars in daily trading volume, but investors are now seeking deeper access to the Chinese markets. The link, initially opened to international investors, has allowed for trading in stocks, bonds, and exchange-traded funds, but has yet to allow access to the primary market or initial public offerings. Key architect Charles Li has stated that opening the primary market was always the ultimate goal.

site_title: TransportBT: Singapore’s EV revolution - emissions, loopholes, and commercial vehicles
summary: Singapore's push towards electric vehicles has seen significant success, particularly in the light goods vehicle sector, with 44% of new van registrations being electric as of September 2024. However, the government's lack of incentives for heavy vehicles has created loopholes, with businesses reclassifying their fleet to avoid penalties. To bridge this gap, supportive policy changes are necessary to align regulatory frameworks with market capabilities, and a collective effort from the government, industry players, and consumers is required for Singapore to fully realize its green transport goals.

site_title: Another S$1.9 billion from major money-laundering case surrendered to the state
summary: Singapore authorities have received an additional S$1.9 billion in assets from a major money-laundering case, bringing the total seized to S$3 billion. The assets, linked to 17 suspects who fled the country, include jewellery, watches, cryptocurrencies, and luxury cars. 15 of the 17 suspects have agreed to surrender their assets, while two remain seized. The police have withdrawn Interpol notices against the 15 suspects in exchange for their immediate surrender, and the two remaining suspects will face the law under the Anti-Money Laundering and Other Matters Act.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Minister of State for Home Affairs Sun Xueling said foreigners convicted in Singapore will be deported to “any country to which their passport or travel document allows them to go”.
Su Jianfeng at an awards ceremony in 2019. He is the last person to be sentenced in Singapore's largest money laundering case, and faces the longest jail term of 17 months.

On Wednesday (Jun 26), Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong announced Singapore’s national asset recovery strategy, as part of the country’s continued efforts to enhance its anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing regime.
Clockwise from top left: The 10 money launderers are Su Baolin, Su Haijin, Chen Qingyuan, Su Wenqiang, Lin Baoying, Zhang Ruijin, Wang Dehai, Su Jianfeng, Vang Shuiming and Wang Baosen.
The assets seized in the S$3 billion money laundering case range from luxury watches to cars.

site_title: Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone: The countdown begins
summary: Singapore and Malaysia are set to sign the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) agreement in December, expected to boost cross-border growth between the two countries. The zone, spanning over 3,500 sq km, will integrate Iskandar Malaysia and Pengerang, covering six districts and driving growth in sectors like aerospace, agriculture, and information technology. The agreement aims to enhance trade, investments, and knowledge exchange between both countries, with proposed incentives including a competitive tax regime and streamlined business approvals.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Brain drain is a major issue for Johor and Malaysia, with many young professionals leaving the country for higher-paying jobs abroad.
The multi-billion dollar Forest City development has faced challenges over the years in attracting attracting both residents and businesses.
The announcement follows a single-family office programme unveiled by the government in September, aimed at attracting wealthy individuals to set up operations in Forest City, Johor.

site_title: Speculation grows over StarHub, M1 merger by June 2025 as telcos defer spectrum payment
summary: Speculation is growing about a merger between telcos StarHub and M1, with both companies deferring payments for their 700-megahertz spectrum until end-June 2025. Analysts believe this may be a tactic to close the deal before the payment fees, which could take negotiations forward. Both companies have seen growth in subscribers, with StarHub increasing its customer base by 83,000 in the past year. Analysts say the merged entity could improve its cost structure and increase cross-selling opportunities, but a deal is unlikely to be sealed solely by the delay in payments.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
PHOTO OF STARHUB
Circles Global is working with a financial adviser as it evaluates a potential sale that could value Circles.Life at a few hundred million US dollars.
Simba's improving fundamentals and balance sheet suggest that it is well-positioned to continue taking market share, says analyst.

site_title: Desperate for cash, Gazans sell clothes plucked from rubble
summary: In Gaza, desperate residents are selling salvaged clothes from destroyed homes to make ends meet, with shortages and war debris creating a thriving trade. The clothes, often salvaged from rubble, are sold to raise cash for basic necessities like flour, as the economy in Gaza's ruined economy struggles. The destruction caused by Israel's military campaign since October 2023 has left an estimated 42 million tons of debris, with the UN estimating it will take 14 years to clean up the wreckage, at a cost of at least $1.2 billion.

images.alt_text: Palestinians inspect the destruction following an Israeli strike in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Dec 1, 2023, as fighting resumed shortly after the expiration of a seven-day truce between Israel and Hamas militants.

UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres talks to the media during a press conference on sidelines of the 43rd Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, 07 September 2023. Indonesia hosts the 43rd ASEAN Summit and related summits from 05 to 07 September

site_title: Xiaomi Q3 revenue soars 30.5% as sales of its first electric car surge
summary: Xiaomi's third-quarter revenue surged 30.5% to 92.5 billion yuan (S$17.2 billion) due to strong sales of its first electric car, the SU7 sedan. Launched in March, the car drew attention with a price tag under US$30,000, beating Tesla's Model 3 in China. Xiaomi has doubled production shifts and launched a premium SU7 Ultra model to meet demand, raising its sales target to 130,000 units for the year.

images.alt_text: Tesla plans to launch its full self-driving technology in China early next year, pending approval.
Xiaomi, which launched its first EV the SU7 sedan last December, has quickly emerged as one of the major EV brands in China.
Xiaomi is now developing more models in its EV lineup to better compete with industry leaders.
Xiaomi started shipping its SU7 EVs in early April after announcing it would price its models competitively against Tesla’s offerings.

site_title: Composer of Piaf's 'Non, je ne regrette rien' dies at 95
summary: Composer Charles Dumont, who wrote Edith Piaf's iconic song "Non, je ne regrette rien," has died at 95. Dumont, a trumpeter by training, collaborated with Piaf and other notable artists, including Barbra Streisand and Dalida. His meeting with Piaf in 1960 led to a fruitful working relationship, resulting in over 30 songs for her. Dumont's contributions to French chanson are being hailed as a "towering figure." He last performed on stage in 2019.

images.alt_text: Jones became one of pop music’s most formidable figures. He collected six of his 27 Grammy Awards for his 1990 album “Back on the Block” and was a three-time producer of the year honoree.

site_title: Neuron Mobility’s Zachary Wang named EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2024 Singapore
summary: Zachary Wang, co-founder and CEO of e-scooter sharing startup Neuron Mobility, has been named the EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2024 Singapore. He will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year awards in June 2025. Wang was chosen for his commitment to sustainability and innovation, and his pioneering work in personal mobility for smart cities. He will compete against 50 other country winners for the world title.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

From left to right: Edy Tan Wei Hock, chief executive officer for Chye Thiam Maintenance and winner in the environmental services category; Samuel Yik, managing director of Dian Xiao Er Group abd winner in the food and beverage category; Anthony Chow, chief executive officer and co-founder of igloocompany and winner in the technology solutions category; Zachary Wang, chief executive officer and co-founder of Neuron Mobility and winner in the mobility category.

site_title: Sri Lanka reappoints Amarasuriya as prime minister
summary: Sri Lanka's President Anura Kumara Dissanayake reappointed Harini Amarasuriya as prime minister, keeping the key finance portfolio for himself. Dissanayake's leftist coalition won the general election, securing 159 seats in parliament, and he named Amarasuriya as prime minister in September. Dissanayake's reappointment of Amarasuriya and Vijitha Herath as foreign affairs minister signals a continuation of his policy, aiming to fight poverty and graft in the country recovering from a financial meltdown.

images.alt_text: epa11722010 People watch election results displayed on a giant screen at a ballot counting center the day after the parliamentary election, in Colombo, Sri Lanka, 15 November 2024. Polling ended peacefully, with a turnout of 65 percent. More than 17.1 million people were registered to vote to elect 225 members to form a new parliament. According to the latest official results, the Marxist-leaning National People's Power (NPP) alliance, led by President Anura Kumara Dissanayake, is in the lead with more than two-thirds of the seats in Parliament. President Dissanayake dissolved parliament on September 24 after securing victory in the first presidential election since the mass protests and political turmoil triggered by the country's economic collapse in 2022.  EPA-EFE/CHAMILA KARUNARATHNE

site_title: Singapore stocks fall after Wall Street sell-off; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% on Monday, November 18, after a sell-off on Wall Street last Friday, amid inflation worries under a second Trump presidency. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,732.55, with 1.1 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion changing hands. Despite this, Singapore Exchange was the top performer, gaining 4.3% or S$0.49 to finish at S$11.91. The market's three-day winning streak was ended, following a broader market trend where gainers outnumbered losers 278 to 260.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Across the broader market, losers equalled gainers at 54 after 23.2 million securities worth S$34.1 million changed hands.
The group posts a 7.4 per cent year-on-year rise in passenger traffic for October 2024.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens subdued with Nvidia earnings, Fed policy in focus
summary: US stocks opened subdued on Monday, November 18, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 13.1 points, or 0.03%, to 43,431.89. Investors await Nvidia's earnings report and the Federal Reserve's policy decisions, which may influence the market. The S&P 500 rose 3.6 points, or 0.06%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 37.8 points, or 0.20%. The subdued opening follows a week of Wall Street's slump.

site_title: Thailand’s Q3 GDP grows 3.0 y/y, fastest pace in two years
summary: Thailand's economy expanded 3.0% in Q3, its fastest pace in two years, beating analyst forecasts. The growth was driven by tourism and exports, key drivers expected to continue supporting the economy next year. The National Economic and Social Development Council forecasts 2.6% growth this year and 2.3-3.3% in 2025. Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira may consider additional stimulus measures, including a second phase of a digital wallet handout scheme.

images.alt_text: A public hearing has concluded and 80 per cent of those who attended agreed with the plan, Thailand's deputy finance minister Julapun Amornvivat said.

Under the kingdom’s existing tax policy, which went into effect on Jan 1 this year, foreign-sourced income is subject to taxation only if it was remitted to Thailand within the same calendar year it was earned.
The consumer index of the University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce increased to 56.0 in October from 55.3 in the previous month, the university said in a statement.

site_title: UK creates new businesses at slowest rate since 2010
summary: The UK saw its slowest rate of new business creation since 2010, with 316,000 new businesses started in 2023, down from 337,000 in 2022. This reduced the 'business birth rate' to 11% and lowered the 'business death rate' to 10.8%. Economists view this as a potential warning sign for long-term economic growth and productivity. The data also showed an increase in 'high growth' employers, with 4.7% of businesses having increased staff numbers by 20% a year for three years.

site_title: Novo Nordisk launches obesity drug Wegovy in China
summary: Novo Nordisk has launched its obesity drug Wegovy in China, the world's second-largest pharmaceuticals market. The price for a month's supply of the starter dose is 1,400 yuan (S$259), with no reimbursement from China's national healthcare insurance. The company aims to make the medicine more affordable through commercial insurance. Wegovy was approved by Chinese authorities nearly five months ago, and strong sales in the US and other countries have propelled Novo's shares to record highs. The move is part of the company's efforts to expand its presence in the Chinese market, where about 180 million adults are obese.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Danish drugmaker Novo Nordisk, Copenhagen, Denmark, September 26, 2023. REUTERS/Tom Little/File Photo
Wegovy and Novo’s diabetes drugs Ozempic and Rybelsus all contain the same active ingredient, semaglutide, and belong to a class of medications known as GLP1 receptor agonists.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing after Wall Street losses as traders weigh US rates outlook
summary: Asian markets swung on Monday after Wall Street losses, with Hong Kong and Sydney leading gains of over 1% each. The sell-off was driven by concerns about US interest rate cuts and the potential for a second Trump administration to impose fresh tariffs on Chinese goods, fueling fears of another trade war. Despite this, some analysts remain optimistic about the outlook for equities, citing reduced uncertainty and improved investor appetite for risk.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers equalled gainers at 54 after 23.2 million securities worth S$34.1 million changed hands.

site_title: Amid fears of global trade war, a UK-US free trade deal would be a win-win for both nations
summary: Business executives in the UK are urging Prime Minister Keir Starmer to step up diplomacy with the incoming Trump administration to avoid a full-scale transatlantic trade war. The US is the UK's largest trade partner, accounting for 18% of total trade and 22% of exports in 2023. A bilateral trade deal could be a win-win for both nations, with US senior economic adviser Stephen Moore suggesting the UK adopt the US model of "economic freedom". However, former World Trade Organization chief Pascal Lamy recommends the UK align with the EU on economic and trade policies.

images.alt_text: (COMBO) This combination of pictures created on November 07, 2024 shows former US President and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump (L) attends a Fox News Townn Hall moderated by US television host Harris Faulkner (out of frame), in Cumming, Georgia, on October 15, 2024, and Prime Minister Keir Starmer (L) looks on during a press conference at the European Commission headquarters in Brussels on October 2, 2024. Keir Starmer has insisted that the UK-US special relationship will "prosper" under Donald Trump but the British prime minister's Labour government has multiple reasons to fear the Republican's presidential comeback. Possible trade wars, Labour ministers' unflattering comments about Trump, and any role for Starmer critic Elon Musk in Trump's administration, would make for a bumpy ride between the allies. Starmer made a first move late on November 6, 2024, phoning Trump to offer his congratulations to the US president-elect as senior government figures played down earlier outspoken comments by Labour politicians. (Photo by Elijah Nouvelage and Nicolas TUCAT / AFP)

site_title: Beijing, Shanghai announce tax breaks to boost ailing property markets
summary: Chinese megacities Beijing and Shanghai have announced tax breaks to boost their ailing property markets. Residents who hold onto properties for over two years will be exempt from value-added taxes, and the standard for levying deed tax on properties over 140 square meters will be raised. The measures aim to revive demand and support housing and stock prices, but analysts say further policy support is needed to tackle consumer confidence and stabilize the economy.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings at a government-subsidized rental housing complex in Beijing, China, on Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024. China promised new measures to support the property sector and hinted at greater government borrowing to shore up the economy, as authorities seek to put a floor under the country’s growth slowdown. Photographer: Na Bian/Bloomberg

site_title: Samsung shares jump on US$7 billion buyback after missing AI boom
summary: Samsung Electronics announced a surprise plan to buy back approximately $9.7 billion worth of its own stock over the next year, causing its shares to surge 7.5% in Seoul trading. The move is seen as a catalyst for the stock, but also raises concerns that it may help the founding family maintain control. This comes amid concerns that the company's memory chip business has fallen behind in the artificial intelligence market, with shares still down 28% this year.

images.alt_text: A Samsung logo is displayed in a supermarket in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, October 29, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic

site_title: Asking prices for UK homes show big November dip but 2025 set for gains
summary: UK home asking prices dropped 1.4% in November, a larger-than-usual decline, but Rightmove forecasts a 4% rise in 2025, its highest prediction since 2021. This follows a typical 0.8% drop and a 1.2% increase from last year. The market's reaction to the finance minister's budget and interest rate cut may be affecting sentiment. Despite this, Rightmove's data suggests the market remains positive, setting the stage for a stronger 2025.

images.alt_text: The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said its house price balance rose to +16 from +11 in September, its highest level since September 2022, when the economic plans of former prime minister Liz Truss sent mortgage markets into a spin.

site_title: HSBC asks hundreds of managers to reapply for jobs in bank revamp
summary: HSBC is revamping its corporate and institutional banking division, asking hundreds of managers to reapply for jobs as part of a broader effort to streamline operations. The move, led by CEO Georges Elhedery, aims to reduce costs and improve efficiency. Senior managers from the commercial banking division will compete against those from the global banking and markets unit for jobs. The shake-up is expected to result in the dismissal of several hundred managing directors and other senior bankers, with changes to the bank's geographical divisions also planned, including the creation of an Eastern regional unit and standalone units for Hong Kong and the UK.

images.alt_text: The revamp addresses investor concerns about HSBC's ability to thrive amid falling interest rates, rising regional competitors, and the growth of fintechs chipping away at its customer base.
Harish Venkatesan, head of corporates and business banking, HSBC Singapore (left) and Kelvin Teo, co-founder and group CEO, Funding Societies.
HSBC currently rents 1.1 million square feet at 8 Canada Square in Canary Wharf and the move back to the City.

site_title: OK Lim sentenced to 17 years and 6 months in prison
summary: OK Lim, a 82-year-old Singaporean businessman, has been sentenced to 17 years and 6 months in prison for three cheating and forgery charges, related to trade financing fraud. The court described the case as "one of the most serious" and stated that Lim's actions damaged Singapore's standing as a bunkering and financial services hub. The charges involved a total of US$2.7 billion and resulted in HSBC suffering US$85 million in unrecovered losses. Lim has accepted a judgment debt of over US$3.5 billion.

site_title: Australia to safeguard cash payments as digital shift grows
summary: Australia will mandate businesses selling essential items such as groceries and fuel to accept cash payments, joining countries like Spain and Denmark. The move aims to ensure people aren't left behind as digital payments grow, with Treasurer Jim Chalmers stating cash can be a "really important lifeline." The new mandate will begin in January 2026, with the government also planning to phase out cheques by 2028.

images.alt_text: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission claims that NAB and its unit AFSH Nominees failed to meet the legal 21-day deadline for responding to 345 hardship applications over a five-year period from 2018 to 2023.
The two supermarkets, Woolworths and Coles stand accused of misleading discount claims on everyday products.
Figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Thursday showed net employment rose 15,900 in October from September, when they jumped by a revised 61,300.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, November 18, 2024
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has vowed to work with former US President Donald Trump, amid warnings of four "red lines" that must be respected. In related news, Samsung shares surged after announcing a $7 billion share buyback, following a disappointing AI boom. Meanwhile, Thailand's proposed global income tax has sparked concerns about an expat exodus, with potential implications for the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Monday.

site_title: Country Garden submits offshore debt restructuring plan to creditors
summary: Country Garden, China's struggling property developer, has submitted a preliminary draft of an offshore debt restructuring plan to major creditor groups, revising its cash flow projection downward. The proposal, which was submitted late last month, aims to avoid liquidation and secure support from key creditors. If successful, the plan could pave the way for the company to seek more time from the court to implement a restructuring plan, potentially averting liquidation.

site_title: After long fight for glory, Nadal leaves with a legacy of memories
summary: Tennis superstar Rafael Nadal is retiring from the sport, set to make his final appearance at the Davis Cup Finals in Malaga this week. With a legacy of 22 Grand Slam titles, Nadal is widely regarded as one of the greatest tennis players of all time, known for his humility, poise, and determination. Despite a long and storied career marked by numerous injuries, Nadal has remained committed to the sport, saying that personal relationships and education are what truly matter to him.

site_title: UOB payment services restored after intermittent issues on Monday
summary: UOB payment services have been restored after intermittent issues on Monday, with customers able to use the bank's internet banking app to make transactions. The disruptions occurred about an hour after the bank reported issues, and customers were asked to use scan-to-pay QR payment during the outage. UOB apologized for the inconvenience and thanked customers for their patience. The bank declined to comment on the reasons for the disruption, which is the second instance of payment service disruptions this year.
