site_title: China EV makers push self-driving as Tesla threat looms
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers are racing to develop self-driving technology as Tesla's full self-driving (FSD) system is set to launch in China early next year. Domestic EV makers, including Xiaomi and Geely Automobile Holdings, are showcasing their advanced driving-assistance services, which can navigate highways and city streets. While Tesla's FSD technology is considered the most advanced, Chinese engineers are confident in their ability to innovate and adapt to unique road conditions and regulatory requirements, promoting competition and innovation in the industry.

images.alt_text: More than 40 per cent of new light goods vehicles registered in Singapore are now electric.
While Tesla is by far the top EV seller in the US, chief executive Elon Musk says the company will be better positioned to deal with the potential pullback of incentives.
Geely said it wants Zeekr and Lynk to form a new energy vehicle manufacturing group with combined annual sales of more than one million units.
Sales of EVs – whether fully electric or plug-in hybrids – reached 1.72 million vehicles worldwide in October, Rho Motion data showed.
BYD does not sell passenger vehicles in the US but that does not seem to be holding the company back much.
Sales in China totalled 2.28 million vehicles last month and increased 3 per cent to 17.99 million for the first 10 months of the year.

site_title: Alibaba aims to raise US$5 billion in dual currency bond deal: sources
summary: Alibaba Group plans to raise US$5 billion through a dual currency bond deal, consisting of dollar and offshore Chinese yuan bonds. The company aims to use the funds for general corporate purposes, including debt repayment and share repurchases. A term sheet shows a 5.5-year, 10.5-year, and 30-year dollar bond, as well as 3.5-year, 5-year, 10-year, and 20-year offshore yuan bonds. The deal is expected to be completed in the coming months, with banks working on the transaction.

images.alt_text: Ant said it will start offering an AI “life assistant” app called Zhixiaobao, which can help people order meals, hail taxis, book tickets and access other functions in Ant’s mobile payments service Alipay, which has one billion users.
Alibaba reported revenue of 236.50 billion yuan (S$43.9 billion) for the second quarter ended Sep 30
Chinese e-commerce giants were similarly coy about actual sales. Both Alibaba Group and JD.com did not disclose sales figures for this year's Singles' Day shopping season.

site_title: Law and disorder as Thai police station comes under monkey attack
summary: Around 200 monkeys broke out of their enclosures in central Thailand's Lopburi town, causing chaos and destruction. The primates rampaged through the town, descending on a local police station, where officers barricaded themselves in. Authorities are working to round up the rogue monkeys, using food to lure them away from residential areas. The town has long struggled with an aggressive monkey population, which has led to clashes with human residents and vandalism. Authorities have tried sterilization and relocation programs to address the issue.

images.alt_text: Long-tailed macaques are seen inside a new cage which was built to temporarily detain monkeys that are captured in Lopburi, Thailand, June 6, 2024. In May, local authorities stepped up the push against unruly monkeys, including boosting sterilisation efforts that began during the pandemic. "Our goal is to neuter all the monkeys, 100 percent of them," local veterinarian Patarapol Maneeorn from the government wildlife department said in September. The monkeys would then be put into a designated area where they will be looked after, he said. Five months after the start of the government's campaign, Lopburi's primate pandemonium has finally come under control, with around 1,600 monkeys in captivity.       REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa            SEARCH "THIRASUPA THAILAND MONKEYS" FOR THIS STORY. SEARCH "WIDER IMAGE" FOR ALL STORIES.

site_title: Gold edges higher after last week’s sharp declines
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $2,571.11 per ounce, rebounding from a two-month low, after last week's biggest weekly decline in over three years. US interest rate cut expectations were limited, and a stronger US dollar made bullion more expensive for other currency holders. Strong US economic data and inflation data reshaped the Federal Reserve's rate cut debate. Spot silver, platinum, and palladium also increased.

images.alt_text: Gold is used as a hedge against inflation but higher rates dampen its appeal as it yields no interest.

site_title: Portcast snags US$6.5 million Series A funding
summary: Portcast, a Singapore-headquartered company, secured US$6.5 million in a Series A funding round led by Susquehanna Asia Venture Capital. The funding will be used to accelerate product innovation and leverage AI capabilities in its transportation visibility platform for international supply chains. New investors Hearst Ventures and Signal Ventures joined existing investors Wavemaker Partners, TMV, and Innoport.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
From L-R: Intudo founding partners Patrick Yip and Eddy Chan.

site_title: Bank of Japan chief sees higher chance of wage-driven inflation
summary: Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda stated that wage-driven inflation is becoming more likely, driven by rising wages as the economy improves. This signals a gradual decrease in the need for interest rate hikes. However, Ueda emphasized the need for vigilance due to external risks, including uncertainty over the US economic outlook and jittery financial markets. The BOJ must remain cautious despite the improving economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Compared with a year earlier, Japan's core orders, a highly volatile data series seen as a key gauge of capital spending in the coming six to nine months, decreased 4.8 per cent, versus an expected rise of 2.2 per cent.
Japanese equities have rebounded from their August drawdown, although they have yet to regain the record highs seen in July.
The slower growth highlights the frailty of Japan’s economy just as there is a growing risk of slowdown in the US and further weakness in China which could weigh on exports.

site_title: Airbnb urges Barcelona to reconsider crackdown on tourism rentals
summary: Airbnb has urged Barcelona's mayor to reconsider a crackdown on tourism rentals, arguing that the measures only benefit the hotel industry and fail to address overtourism and a housing crisis. The company claims that strict limits on new tourist accommodation licences have not been effective, citing data showing long-term rents have soared and the number of short-term rentals has halved. Airbnb argues that policies addressing vacant homes would boost affordable housing supply, and has removed over 7,000 listings from its platform in Barcelona since 2018.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Figurines are seen in front of the Airbnb logo in this illustration taken February 27, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Thailand’s proposed global income tax sparks concerns over expat exodus
summary: Thailand's proposed global income tax, targeting Thai residents with 180 days or longer abroad, has sparked concerns among expat groups and foreign chambers of commerce, potentially impacting foreign direct investment and attracting expatriates. The tax, which could be finalized by 2026, would tax worldwide income, not just remitted income, and could negatively affect wealthy Thais and expatriates. International tax experts say the law could be a major issue for attracting skilled and wealthy expatriates, but incoming FDI appears unaffected. The Revenue Department has yet to provide clarity on the proposed tax law.

images.alt_text: The value of Thai investments in foreign capital markets reached US$106 billion in 2022, according to Bank of Thailand statistics.

site_title: China population set for 51 million drop as pro-birth moves fail
summary: China's population is expected to drop by 51 million, or the size of California, over the next decade due to a declining birth rate. By 2035, the population is projected to reach 1.36 billion, the lowest level since 2012. Policymakers are likely to step up reforms to address the issue, including improving healthcare services and making childcare more affordable. The UN projects the population could shrink to half its current size by 2100, exacerbating economic, pension, and healthcare pressures.

images.alt_text: The birth rate hit a record low last year in China, which has a population of 1.4 billion.

site_title: Trump’s victory represents a historic protest vote, no more and no less
summary: Donald Trump's victory in the US presidential election marks a historic protest vote against big government and big business, reflecting a widespread disillusionment with the economic future. The protest vote, driven by a desire for change and frustration with the current state of the economy, has become a major force in US politics. Trump's win is part of a global trend of anti-incumbency, but one that is specific to developed countries, where leaders are unpopular and trust in institutions is at all-time lows. Trump's mandate should be seen as a firm protest vote, and he will need to address the passions he has unleashed by shifting the balance of power away from big corporations and the rich.

images.alt_text: Voters in Concord, New Hampshire, on Nov 5, 2024. Polling data show that Donald Trump’s supporters were deeply misinformed about most of the campaign’s defining issues. Was this due to bad actors exploiting a broken information ecosystem, or did they reflect an electoral majority that chooses to be misinformed?
America Inc under its brand new CEO Trump feels less like a blue chip and more like a private equity firm: it's a highly leveraged, short-term play with an average hold time of around four years.
How Trump won

site_title: India’s capital shuts schools as smog exceeds 60 times WHO limit
summary: New Delhi's capital shut schools on November 18, 2024, due to severe smog exceeding 60 times the World Health Organization's recommended daily maximum. The smog, composed of PM2.5 pollutants, reached a peak of 921 micrograms per cubic meter, posing significant health risks, particularly for children and the elderly. This move comes as various government initiatives have failed to address the issue, resulting in thousands of premature deaths each year.

images.alt_text: Residents of India's capital, New Delhi choked in a blanketing toxic smog as worsening air pollution surged past 50 times the World Health Organization's recommended daily maximum.
Bangkok was ranked 46th on a global congestion index in 2023. Residents in the city of 10 million people lost about four and a half days to traffic snarls last year.

site_title: ST Engineering Q3 revenue up 14% at S$2.8 billion; interim dividend at S$0.04 per share
summary: ST Engineering's Q3 revenue rose 14% to S$2.8 billion, driven by growth in its defence and public security, as well as commercial aerospace sectors. The company also proposed a third-quarter interim dividend of S$0.04 per share. Revenue from its defence and public security sector increased 18% to S$3.6 billion, while commercial aerospace revenue rose 16% to S$3.3 billion. The company expects this growth to be short-term, but remains committed to its mid-single-digit earnings before interest and tax (Ebit) margin projection for 2024.

site_title: Battery energy storage systems: South-east Asia’s key to renewable energy resilience
summary: South-east Asia can leapfrog traditional energy infrastructure limitations by embracing battery energy storage systems (BESS) as a key solution to meet growing energy demand and reduce reliance on fossil fuels. The region's 80% reliance on finite resources necessitates immediate action to avert an impending energy crisis and detrimental climate change impact. BESS can provide a stable and consistent energy supply, complementing renewable energy sources like solar power and reducing costs for businesses, while enabling scalable modular energy solutions that quickly adapt to evolving needs.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) began trading in negative territory on Monday, down 0.15 points at 3,744.55. The broader market saw 54 losers equal to gainers after 23.2 million securities worth S$34.1 million changed hands. Banking stocks were mostly down, with OCBC up 0.1%, UOB down 0.03%, and DBS down 0.7%. The decline follows losses on Wall Street, where Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments on rate cuts stoked concerns.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

summary:

site_title: Australia regulator sues NAB for breach of financial hardship laws
summary: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) has launched civil penalty proceedings against National Australia Bank (NAB) for breaching financial hardship laws. NAB and its unit AFSH Nominees failed to respond to 345 hardship applications within the 21-day deadline, over a five-year period from 2018 to 2023. This breach of the National Credit Code may result in penalties for the bank.

Westpac reported a 3 per cent decline in profit for the year ended Sep 30, to A$7 billion, due to rising costs and intense competition in the mortgage market.

site_title: Is AI’s meteoric rise beginning to slow?
summary: AI's performance improvements are plateauing despite massive investments by tech giants, raising concerns that breakthroughs in large AI models may slow down. Initially, AI believers expected exponential growth in generative AI capabilities with increased computing power and data. However, companies are now showing signs of plateauing, indicating that delivering on AI's promise may be more challenging than anticipated. This could have significant implications for the development of human-level artificial intelligence.

site_title: How Donald Trump cut into Democrats’ hold on young voters
summary: US President Donald Trump made significant inroads with young voters, particularly those between 18 and 29, in the 2024 presidential election. Trump increased his share of votes among this demographic by 7 percentage points from 2020, with 54% of voters under 30 supporting him. This marked a significant shift for the Democratic Party, which has traditionally relied on young voters. Trump's economic message resonated with young adults struggling with student loans and high costs, and his campaign leveraged social media and influencers to reach this age group, including TikTok and podcasts.

site_title: Frasers Property, Sekisui team up to redevelop Robertson Walk assets into 348 luxury homes for sale
summary: Frasers Property and Sekisui House formed a 51:49 joint venture to redevelop Robertson Walk assets into a mixed-use project featuring 348 luxury homes, retail space, and dining and entertainment options. The 999-year leasehold site will yield a gross floor area of 30,664 square meters and is slated to launch in 2025 with completion by 2028. The project aligns with the Singapore government's rejuvenation plans for the Singapore River Planning Area, attracting homebuyers who value the vibrancy of the area and the tranquility of Robertson Quay.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Frasers Property intends to increase its development exposure in the residential segment, which will offer better risk-adjusted returns.
This is the third site featuring long-stay serviced apartments with a minimum three-month stay – a new rental category introduced last year to help meet rental demand.

Reini Otter, chief executive officer of Frasers Property Industrial, said Frasers Property has focused its investment in industrial & logistics, diversifying outside the residential and hospitality sectors.

site_title: Green leases: Enhancing asset sustainability and landlord-tenant ties
summary: Green leases aim to foster a collaborative relationship between landlords and tenants to reduce environmental impact and promote sustainability. In response to growing climate targets and legislation, 55% of occupiers in the Asia-Pacific region have committed to net zero by 2030. However, a split-incentive challenge between landlords and tenants hinders implementation. Green leases can enhance property values, reduce costs, and create stronger relationships by contractually obliging both parties to focus on sustainability and support each other's performance. Despite slower adoption in Asia-Pacific, the trend is shifting, with 60% of organizations prioritizing green leases, and some frameworks, such as the Singapore BCA toolkit, being developed to support implementation.

images.alt_text: Although transitioning to net zero may involve upfront capital expenditure, it often leads to significant long-term savings through reduced energy costs.

site_title: Biden touts climate legacy in landmark Amazon visit
summary: US President Joe Biden visited the Amazon rainforest in Brazil, promoting his climate legacy and warning that the region will survive if Donald Trump returns to the White House. Biden signed a proclamation designating November 17 as International Conservation Day and announced additional US funding to protect the Amazon. He also stated that the US has hit its target of increasing bilateral climate financing to $11 billion a year. Despite Trump's return, Biden expressed confidence in the US ability to combat climate change, saying "nobody can reverse" the clean energy revolution underway.

images.alt_text: The business executives who invested millions of dollars in Donald Trump's candidacy and now stand to profit from his policies.

site_title: COP29: More policy alignment needed in S-E Asia to unlock potential from new carbon trading rules
summary: The adoption of global carbon trading rules by countries at COP29 has marked a significant milestone for South-east Asia, but observers warn that more policy alignment is needed to unlock the potential of the new carbon crediting regime. The region is expected to become a hub for carbon services, but it will take time for significant financing to flow in. The transition of CDM projects to the new mechanism will open up new demand sources for credits, but a centralized mechanism is needed to facilitate faster trading. Governments and companies must work together to establish clear protocols for credit authorisation and revocation to foster trust and strengthen market integrity.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Established carbon project developers that have had success in developing high-quality carbon projects are eligible to apply for the grant, says the Economic Development Board.
The Saudi carbon trading platform is following guidelines issued by the Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market.
Monday’s deal could allow a UN-backed global carbon market, which has been years in the making, to start up as soon as next year, one negotiator said.

Heightened scrutiny over the environmental integrity of carbon markets and fears of “greenshaming” have stunted the growth of the voluntary carbon market.
This year’s climate summit in Baku, Azerbaijan, has been dubbed the "finance COP".

site_title: Japan’s September machinery orders fall 0.7% month/month
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 0.7% in September from the previous month, contrary to economists' expectations of a 1.9% rise. On a year-on-year basis, orders decreased 4.8%, down from an expected 2.2% increase. The recovery in machinery orders is seen as pausing, but the Cabinet Office expects orders to rise 5.7% quarter-over-quarter from October to December. This indicates a potential slowdown in capital spending in the coming months.

site_title: Data centre Reits could head for IPO on SGX as conditions turn favourable
summary: Data centre Reits could list on the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) in 2025 as interest rates fall, making financing cheaper and increasing investor appetite. Analysts cite rising interest in AI as a driver of the trend, with companies like Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp (NTT) considering a Reit listing. Strong demand for data centre assets, driven by limited supply and significant investments from tech players, also supports the potential listing. However, private equity players and sovereign wealth funds may also be interested in acquiring data centre assets, offering alternative monetization options.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Issuance from Reits would be a much-needed shot in the arm for Singapore’s stock exchange, which is set for its worst year for IPOs in more than a quarter century.
NTT’s global data centres platform is one of the largest in the world, spanning more than 20 countries globally.
The data centre sector as a whole also remains at the mercy of still-high interest rates or potential oversupply, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.

site_title: Favourable outlook seen for Nikkei 225 Index after US election
summary: The Nikkei 225 Index has rebounded from its August drawdown, driven by improved corporate profits, corporate governance reforms, and tax-free investing. Following the US presidential election, the index closed 2.61% higher due to a surge in US Treasury yields, which boosted the USD/JPY currency pair and put downward pressure on the yen. The election is seen as strategically favourable for Japanese equities, with investors potentially increasing fund flows into Japan due to a more cautious stance towards China. A bullish technical outlook suggests a potential appreciation in USD/JPY, which could push the Nikkei 225 Index towards its all-time high.

images.alt_text: With the US presidential election yielding a decisive victory for the Republican party, it is likely investors are seeing the end of this period of short-term market uncertainty.

site_title: Musk and Trump, a bond made in merch
summary: Elon Musk and President-elect Donald Trump have formed a bond over their shared affinity for merchandise, a trait also present in Musk's empire-building and Trump's career. Both have leveraged merch to create and reinforce community, with Musk's brands, including SpaceX, Tesla, and X, and Trump's Trump Company, Mar-a-Lago, and campaign merchandise, fostering a sense of belonging and fealty among fans. The promise of Doge merch, a new government department, has generated excitement among Musk's followers, highlighting the strategic use of merchandise to sell an idea and create a cult of personality.

images.alt_text: (First row from left) Elon Musk, Vivek Ramaswamy, Susie Wiles, Pete Hegseth. (Second row from left) Thomas Homan, Elise Stefanik, John Ratcliffe, Mike Waltz. (From bottom left) Marco Rubio, Lee Zeldin, Stephen Miller, Kristi Noem are all nominees raised by Donald Trump.

site_title: Warner Bros gambles on Hollywood-first strategy for Max in Asia
summary: Warner Bros is launching its Max streaming service in Asia with a Hollywood-first strategy, partnering with local platforms to build loyalty and increase subscribers without heavy initial investments. The company is relying on popular franchises like Harry Potter and Friends to draw viewers, setting it apart from rivals Netflix and Disney. By 2029, Max is expected to bring in over $600 million in revenue from Japan, Australia, New Zealand, and South-east Asian markets, with the first phase of growth coming from partnerships with local streaming platforms and telecom operators.

site_title: Biden allows Ukraine to strike Russia with long-range missiles: US official
summary: US President Joe Biden has authorized Ukraine to use long-range American missiles against military targets inside Russia, a significant policy shift. The decision was made in response to North Korea's deployment of troops to help Russia's war effort, with around 10,000 troops reportedly deployed. The move is seen as a major shift from the outgoing Biden administration, which had previously been hesitant to allow Ukraine to use the powerful Army Tactical Missile System. The authorization is likely to have wider repercussions and lead European allies to review their stances.

site_title: Oil settles down 2% on weaker Chinese demand, uncertainty over Fed rate cut
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Friday as investors worried about weaker Chinese demand and uncertainty over US Federal Reserve interest rate cuts. Brent crude futures settled at $71.04 a barrel, down $1.52, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell to $67.02, down $1.68. China's oil refiners processed 4.6% less crude in October due to plant closures and reduced operating rates, adding to concerns over the country's economic health. The US economy showed signs of a strong start to the fourth quarter, fueling debate over the pace and extent of interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: Opec cut its forecast for global oil demand growth for this year and next.

site_title: New York auction records expected for a Magritte... and a banana
summary: A highly anticipated auction in New York is expected to shake up the stagnant art market, with notable sales including a Claude Monet painting of Water Lilies estimated to fetch over $60 million, Rene Magritte's Empire of Light valued at nearly $100 million, and a banana by Maurizio Cattelan, a commentary on what qualifies as art, potentially selling for $1-1.5 million. The auctions aim to reinvigorate the market, which has slowed since 2023, with sales totaling $2.1 billion in the first half of 2024.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust to acquire 50% of Marina East Water from sponsor Keppel
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) will acquire a 50% stake in Marina East Water from Keppel for S$323 million, expected to be completed by Q1 2025. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to KIT's distribution per unit, with a 0.4% rise in pro-forma DPU for FY2023. KIT's assets under management will grow to S$9 billion, and the trust will own a 50% joint-controlling stake in Marina East Water alongside Keppel.

images.alt_text: The notes are expected to be issued on Nov 19.

site_title: Souring S&P 500 profit outlook a bad sign for stock market rally
summary: US stock market analysts are scaling back their forecasts for corporate earnings growth over the next year, citing uncertainty over Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts, weakness in China's economy, and questions about fiscal policy in Washington. Earnings-revision momentum has slumped into negative territory, and analysts expect the S&P 500 to deliver its second-best period of profit growth since early 2022 in the third quarter. Despite this, the index is still projected to rise over 20% for the year, but its valuation is at its most expensive level since April 2021, raising concerns about a potential reversal.

site_title: Aluminium soars as China scraps tax sweetener that fuelled exports
summary: Aluminium prices surged 8.5% after China scrapped a tax rebate that fueled its decades-long export boom, with the country's semi-finished aluminium exports reaching 5.2 million tonnes in 2023, equivalent to 7% of the global market. The move is seen as a strategic response to trade tensions following Trump's US presidential win, and analysts predict a short-term restriction on Chinese exports. However, limited capacity for output growth elsewhere allows Chinese producers to shift tax costs to overseas buyers, pushing up the London Metal Exchange price.

images.alt_text: Seasonal slowdown in construction activities amid colder weather throughout most of China is impacting steel demand.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: How changes to CPF Act impact your retirement savings
summary: Changes to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Act, passed in October 2024, will close the CPF Special Account (SA) for members aged 55 and above from January 2025. Balances in the SA will be transferred to the Ordinary Account (OA), reducing interest rates. CPF members aged 55 and above can top-up their Retirement Account (RA) up to four times the Basic Retirement Sum, but the top-up limit for this year is three times the sum. The changes aim to eliminate CPF Shielding, a practice that retained higher interest rates and liquidity, and align with investment principles of higher returns requiring lower liquidity.

site_title: ‘Red One’ tops North America box office but could end up in the red
summary: Amazon and MGM's film "Red One" topped the North American box office with estimated ticket sales of $34.1 million, but its high budget of $250 million, including a reported $50 million cost overrun, may hinder profitability. Analysts describe the opening as a "soft start" for a planned Christmas action comedy series. Despite being a crowd-pleaser, the film's opening may not be enough to ensure its financial success.

site_title: Bringing quirky back: Strata commercial property’s unique place
summary: Strata commercial properties in Singapore, encompassing strata office and retail spaces, have carved out a unique niche due to their versatility and accessibility to various investors. With around 200 strata office buildings and 400 strata retail developments, these properties offer a wide range of investment options. Despite limited future supply, demand has been consistent since the pandemic, driven by their affordability and flexibility in accommodating niche users. Strata properties are poised to meet the growing needs of diverse users, including boutique offices, wellness centers, and creative hubs, as consumer preferences shift.

site_title: Trump team backs Hegseth for Pentagon amid report on police probe
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's team stands by Pete Hegseth, his nominee for defence secretary, despite reports of a police investigation into a 2017 sexual assault allegation against him and concerns raised by a fellow Army member over his tattoos. Hegseth has denied the allegations and no criminal charges were filed. Trump's communications director, Steven Cheung, said Hegseth is "high-caliber" and "extremely qualified" for the role, despite the controversy.

site_title: Trump boosters expect big returns on their investments: ‘The shackles are off’
summary: Business executives who invested millions in Donald Trump's candidacy now stand to profit from his policies, including easing federal regulations on artificial intelligence, allowing cryptocurrencies to thrive, and easing antitrust crackdowns on big tech companies. Billionaires like Marc Andreessen, Harold Hamm, and Joe Lonsdale have donated large sums to support Trump, who has vowed to cancel Biden-era rules and regulations that affect their interests. They expect big returns on their investments, with some already seeing significant profits from Trump's election and policies.

site_title: Greenback notches weekly gain as traders reassess rate-cut expectations
summary: The US dollar gained its largest weekly gain in over a month, rising 1.65% against a basket of currencies, driven by market expectations that President-elect Donald Trump's policies could stoke inflation and limit the Federal Reserve's ability to cut interest rates. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's comments that there's no need to rush to lower interest rates prompted traders to reassess their bets on a rate cut. The dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen and euro, while sterling was set for its steepest weekly fall since January 2023.

images.alt_text: The dollar has been climbing amid rising doubts about how low the Federal Reserve will take its benchmark interest rate next year.

site_title: S-Reits remain active in acquisitions and divestments as managers eye growth
summary: SINGAPORE-LISTED real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) have been active in portfolio management activities, with 10 transactions announced in the fourth quarter to date, including five acquisitions and five divestments. S-Reits are seeking to optimize assets and capture growth opportunities, with several managers eyeing the logistics and industrial sectors. The acquisitions and divestments demonstrate the trusts' strategies to expand their portfolios and improve their quality. With interest-rate cuts underway, S-Reits may be able to tap a more conducive environment for deals to take place, providing higher debt headroom to capitalize on opportunities.

images.alt_text: Average monthly visitor arrivals to Singapore in Q3 grew 14 per cent compared to Q2. Chinese visitors rose by 56 per cent, contributing to around two-thirds of the increase in arrivals.

site_title: Singapore e-commerce players report strong Singles’ Day sales
summary: Singaporean e-commerce platforms Shopee and Lazada reported strong Singles' Day sales, with Shopee selling over 100,000 items within the first 11 minutes of the sale. Grocery and travel-related sales saw growth, with RedMart achieving higher grocery sales than in 2023 and Trip.com Singapore's travel bookings tripling. However, Fave, a deals platform, declined to hold a Singles' Day campaign due to dampened consumer demand. Despite this, travel-related spending rose, with flight bookings more than tripling year on year for China and Australia.

site_title: Attika Group eyes expansion into Malaysia, manufacturing sector after IPO
summary: Attika Group, a Singapore-based company, is expanding into Malaysia's manufacturing sector after its initial public offering (IPO). The company's managing director and executive chairman, Steven Tan, holds an 84.6% stake in the company. Following its listing on the Catalist board, Attika's shares have surged, closing 6.8% above its IPO price. Proceeds from the IPO will be used to expand into new markets, build capacity, enhance technology adoption, and diversify into new sectors.

site_title: Sustainable Christmas Market 2024 focuses on being net zero, raises S$350,000
summary: The Sustainable Christmas Market 2024 in Singapore raised S$350,000, exceeding its target, to support underprivileged children and youths. The event, organized by Peace of Art, aimed to promote sustainable living and featured eco-conscious vendors, interactive workshops, and activities. The market was designed to be net-zero, with reused materials, composting, and waste reduction initiatives. The funds will benefit the Singapore Red Cross' Young Hearts programme, providing academic support, enrichment activities, and mentorship to underprivileged children and youths.

site_title: Wave of asset rejuvenation to come in Singapore industrial real estate
summary: Singapore's industrial real estate market is expected to undergo a wave of asset rejuvenation despite a heightened interest rate environment and slower economic growth. The manufacturing sector has seen a pick-up in global demand, with the Manufacturing Purchasing Manager's Index reaching 51 points in September, marking the 13th straight month of expansionary activity. Industrial prices and rents grew 0.5% and 0.3% quarter-on-quarter in the third quarter of 2024, respectively. Underutilized industrial developments are likely to be redeveloped or enhanced to capture new occupier demand.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for November 15, 2024, reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk ships. The Capesize market showed a strong overall performance, with significant rate increases in the South Brazil and West Africa to China routes. Panamax rates were steady, while Ultramax/Supramax rates were mixed, with some routes showing optimism and others remaining patchy. Handysize rates were also steady, but sentiment remained poor. LNG rates declined, with weak demand and limited cargo availability. LPG rates continued to rise, with the US market driving the increase.

site_title: LHN making the most of shared spaces
summary: LHN Limited, a Singaporean real estate manager, is focusing on its co-living business to drive growth and anchor its bottom line. The company aims to recycle capital from its co-living business to fund its "real estate as a service" model. Co-living has contributed S$20 million to the top line in six months, and its segment could make up about two-thirds of revenue in the next three to five years. LHN plans to expand its co-living portfolio, introducing new concepts such as hostels for foreign workers. The company is also scouting for family offices or individual investors to buy older properties, which it can then lease back and manage.

site_title: New Nvidia AI chips face issue with overheating servers, The Information reports
summary: Nvidia's new Blackwell AI chips, unveiled in March, have encountered overheating issues with accompanying servers, causing delays and concerns for customers such as Meta, Google, and Microsoft. The chips, which are 30 times faster than Nvidia's previous offering, overheat when connected together in custom-designed server racks. Nvidia has asked suppliers to change the rack design multiple times to resolve the issue, and the company had initially expected to ship the chips in the second quarter. The overheating problems may affect the timely deployment of the chips, impacting customers' ability to upgrade their data centers.

site_title: At Apec summit under Trump’s shadow, Xi and Biden signal turbulence ahead
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping signaled turbulence ahead as the world braces for the prospect of fresh trade wars after Donald Trump assumes the US presidency in January. Xi warned of "spreading unilateralism and protectionism" and cautioned against "fragmentation of the world economy," while Biden noted a "moment of significant political change" and expressed hope for a "built-to-last" trilateral partnership with Japan and South Korea. The APEC summit, overshadowed by Trump's impending return, focuses on trade and investment for inclusive growth, but uncertainty over Trump's next moves clouds the agenda.

site_title: Debt-saddled Laos struggles to tame rampant inflation
summary: Laos, one of Asia's poorest countries, is struggling to tame rampant inflation, with prices rising 23-31% in 2022 and 2023, and forecasted to reach 25% this year. The country's debt to China has increased to over $13 billion, fueling inflation by devaluing the local currency, which has lost half its value against the US dollar in 2022. The government has raised interest rates and launched a plan to bring inflation below 20% by December, but experts warn that austerity measures will have long-term consequences, and the country may need to restructure its debt.

site_title: Power shifts towards UK workers after wage squeeze on profits
summary: UK workers are gaining more economic power, with the share of wages in the economy reaching its highest level since the early 2010s, surpassing profits. A weak economy has limited firms' ability to pass on higher wages to consumers, instead taking a hit to their margins. This shift in power could comfort the Bank of England as it considers interest rate cuts. Experts say wage growth, driven by pre-pandemic low standards, has been unusually high since the pandemic, and the labour share could be sustained if wage growth remains above pre-Covid levels.

site_title: Bitcoin rises above US$90,000 on Trump euphoria
summary: Bitcoin reached an all-time high of $93,480 on Wednesday, surpassing the $90,000 level, amid speculation that a Trump presidency will benefit cryptocurrencies. The cryptocurrency has risen 32% since the election, with smaller peer ether and alternative token dogecoin also experiencing significant gains. Experts believe a pro-bitcoin administration could lead to legislation allowing US citizens to self-custody bitcoin and potentially make it a strategic reserve asset for the US Treasury, driving further speculation and potential volatility.

site_title: Denmark’s Victoria Kjaer Theilvig crowned Miss Universe 2024
summary: Denmark's Victoria Kjaer Theilvig was crowned Miss Universe 2024, beating over 120 contestants in the pageant's 73rd edition held in Mexico City. The 21-year-old dancer and animal-rights activist is the first Danish contestant to win the title. The first runner-up was Chidimma Adetshina from Nigeria, marking a historic moment for the pageant, which featured women older than 28 for the first time.

summary: SpaceX, led by Elon Musk, is set to launch a tender offer in December to sell existing shares at $135 per share, valuing the company at over $250 billion. The move would make Musk's SpaceX one of the most valuable companies in the world. SpaceX did not comment on the matter.

site_title: Singapore’s office market: A temporary pause or a prelude to a structural decline?
summary: Singapore's office market experienced a slowdown in Q3 2024, with a 7.8% vacancy rate and prime rents remaining flat for two consecutive quarters. The lack of large demand drivers, including tech firms, has contributed to the slowdown. Despite ample supply, market conditions are expected to stabilize, driven by a stronger economic recovery and lower interest rates. New supply from 2025-2027 is expected to be below historical average levels, and redevelopment plans may tighten supply in the long term. While rents are likely to remain under pressure, there is optimism for future growth driven by emerging fields such as AI.

site_title: China suspends popular trading platform Hithink RoyalFlush from adding new clients
summary: China's market watchdog has ordered Hithink RoyalFlush to suspend its investment advisory service unit from adding new clients for three months due to non-compliance with securities rules. The company failed to prevent influencers from offering investment advice without required licenses and providing implicit stock recommendations during live streaming. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) also criticized the company's insufficient compliance control. Shares of Hithink RoyalFlush plummeted 14.3% on Friday.

site_title: Timing of DBS share buyback announcement and its CEO’s share sales was not a good look
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta's share sales after the bank's Q3 2024 earnings report and share buyback announcement raised concerns about the timing of the sale. Gupta sold 300,000 shares, with 100,000 sold on Nov 7 at S$41.7513 and 200,000 sold on Nov 8 at S$42.2023, as DBS shares soared 6.5% on Nov 7 and 1.7% on Nov 8. Critics argue that Gupta's sale sends a contradictory message, but the sale of shares by top executives is also common and may not reflect bearishness. DBS shares continue to climb, despite trading ex-dividend on Nov 14. To address the issue, regulators and companies should consider prohibiting share sales by top executives during share buybacks or requiring companies to disclose valuations at which buybacks make sense.

site_title: Singapore offers to host Apec summit in 2030
summary: Singapore has offered to host the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit in 2030, aiming to promote inclusive growth amid increasing geopolitical rivalry and weakening support for free trade. The last time Singapore hosted an Apec summit was in 2009. The proposal comes as Apec leaders expressed concerns about the decline of globalisation and free trade, with the need for more inclusive growth and cooperation. Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of Apec in fostering ideas and trade, and hopes to facilitate improved US-China ties under the incoming Trump administration.

site_title: Hanwha’s voluntary conditional cash offer for Dyna-Mac turns unconditional in all respects
summary: Hanwha Ocean SG Holdings' voluntary conditional cash offer for Dyna-Mac has been declared unconditional following the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore's assessment that the proposed acquisition would not infringe on the Competition Act. The offer, which had previously turned unconditional on November 5, was satisfied after the regulator's letter to the offeror. This move allows Hanwha to proceed with the acquisition of Dyna-Mac.

site_title: Buyers sweep up almost 1,500 new homes in 3 weekend launches; Emerald of Katong 99% sold
summary: Singapore's new home sales surged with 1,480 units sold over the weekend in a series of six projects. The Emerald of Katong project saw 99% of its 846 units sold, while Nava Grove and Novo Place EC sold 65% and 57% of their units, respectively. The strong sales are attributed to improving market sentiment, lower interest rates, and FOMO among buyers. The sales could lead to a record-breaking 2,200 units sold in November, with some predicting another round of cooling measures. The surge in sales also indicates a build-up of wealth among local buyers and an influx of funds from overseas.

site_title: The global climate process has lost its way
summary: The UN climate summit in Azerbaijan has been criticized for its focus on financial transfers from wealthy countries to poorer ones, which is seen as unrealistic and misguided. Wealthy countries want to cut emissions, while poorer countries want to eradicate poverty through growth reliant on fossil fuels. The West has offered cash for two decades, but most funding was mislabeled development aid. Developing countries now demand trillions of dollars, but this is deemed prohibitively expensive for the West. Instead, the real challenge is to hasten the day poorer countries can switch to green energy, which can be achieved through innovation and reducing the price of green energy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the turbines at Orsted's offshore wind farm near Nysted, Denmark, September 4, 2023. REUTERS/Tom Little/File Photo

The poorer half of the world deserves opportunities to better their lives

site_title: US: Stocks continue decline on rate cut pause prospects
summary: US stocks declined on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.7% to 43,444.99, and the S&P 500 Index dropping 1.3% to 5,870.62. The decline was attributed to concerns over the Federal Reserve's potential delay in cutting interest rates, following comments from Fed Chair Jerome Powell. Pharmaceutical stocks also contributed to the slump, with major firms falling after President-elect Donald Trump's nomination of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to the US Health Secretary position.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 162.9 points, or 0.37 per cent, at the open to 43,587.93.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower on US rate, Trump jitters
summary: European shares dropped 0.8% to close at 4794.85, weighed down by US President-elect Donald Trump's policies and Treasury yields. The decline was exacerbated by concerns over US-China relations and Trump's pick of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. as secretary of health and human services. Pharmaceutical companies, including Novo Nordisk, Sanofi, and GSK, fell 5.3%, 3.3%, and 3.9% respectively. The technology sub-index also dropped 2.7%, while Russia's Gazprom suspended gas deliveries to Austria.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, October 18, 2024.   REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Xi vows to work with Trump team as he meets Biden in Peru
summary: US President Joe Biden met with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) forum in Lima, Peru, for their first talks in seven months. Xi vowed to work with the incoming Trump administration, while Biden expressed concerns over China's military activity around Taiwan and its support for Russia. The two leaders agreed that human beings, not AI, should make decisions over nuclear weapons. However, no breakthroughs were seen on major issues such as trade, cybercrime, and the South China Sea. Xi also denied China's involvement in recent cyberattacks and called for a stable and sustainable China-US relationship.

images.alt_text: This handout picture released by the Peruvian Presidency press office shows Peru's President Dina Boluarte and Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong during a bilateral meeting on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in Lima on November 16, 2024. site_title: Family businesses will lead the way in sustainability: TPC’s Chavalit Frederick Tsao
summary: Family businesses, particularly those in the shipping industry, are poised to lead the way in sustainability, according to Chavalit Frederick Tsao, chairman of TPC. Tsao, who funds OceanX's research mission to Indonesia, believes that family businesses can create significant impact in sustainability. This comes as Singapore aims to ink a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by the end of 2025, highlighting the country's growing focus on environmental sustainability.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Unilever nearly halves expected European job cuts
summary: Unilever has reduced its expected European job cuts by about 500, from 3,200 to 1,700, through savings projects and internal hiring. The company will still make 800 million euros in savings, but will not hire externally. Unilever is spinning off its ice cream business, which will see the creation of 1,000 new jobs, primarily for those affected by job cuts in the rest of the company. The European Works Council has criticized the decision, but Unilever's head of the council has agreed to the new plan.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This photograph taken on August 3, 2007 in Rueil-Malmaison, shows the logo of Unilever at the headquarters of Unilever France. Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch maker of consumer goods and food products announced 02 August 2007 that it would cut 20.000 jobs worldwide, 11 percent of its total workforce, over the next four years. Two million for late payment to suppliers to Unilever France, a multinational company of consumer goods and food products, the Agency for the Repression of Frauds (DGCCRF) said on its website, in Paris, on December 18, 2023. (Photo by Eric Feferberg / AFP)

site_title: Canadian home sales post ‘October surprise’ as buyers flood back
summary: Canadian home sales surged 7.7% in October, the highest level since April 2022, according to data from the Canadian Real Estate Association. This increase is attributed to the Bank of Canada's interest rate cuts, which have drawn buyers back to the market. The benchmark price for a home slipped 0.1% to C$716,800. Policymakers expect the housing market to respond to lower borrowing costs faster than other sectors, with potential for more rate cuts to come.

images.alt_text: Sales and prices in Toronto are closely tracked by economists and realtors as they usually signal a trend that could unfold in bigger cities around the country.
The headline business activity index rose to 50.4 from 46.4 in September, moving above the 50 threshold for the first time since May.

site_title: GM plans to cut 1,000 salaried workers to reduce costs
summary: General Motors plans to cut approximately 1,000 salaried workers globally, primarily in North America, to streamline operations and optimize for speed and excellence in a competitive market. The move aims to ensure the right team structure and focus on top priorities as a business, according to GM spokesman Kevin Kelly. The layoffs are part of the company's efforts to reduce costs and maintain competitiveness.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The new GM logo is seen on the facade of the General Motors headquarters in Detroit, Michigan, U.S., March 16, 2021. .  REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo

site_title: Singapore’s sustainability movement: How communities can make a difference
summary: Singapore's sustainability movement is gaining momentum through grassroots efforts, such as the "Keep Singapore Clean" campaign, which mobilizes communities to take responsibility for keeping their neighborhoods clean. This bottom-up approach complements the government's top-down initiatives, like the "Singapore Green Plan 2030", and has been shown to collectively drive sustainable practices and policy changes. By harnessing the "gotong royong" spirit of collective action and social responsibility, Singapore can further enhance its sustainability movement and create a more environmentally friendly future.

images.alt_text: Harnessing strength, resources to support one another during crisis

site_title: CapitaLand Investment leads buyback consideration tally in 2024 till Nov 13
summary: Nearly 80 primary-listed companies in Singapore have repurchased their shares on-market this year, totaling S$1.03 billion. CapitaLand Investment leads the buyback consideration tally, buying back 126.2 million shares at an average price of S$2.72 per share. Yangzijiang Financial Holding also led the consideration tally for non-STI primary-listed companies, repurchasing 89.6 million shares at an average price of S$0.324 per share. The buybacks are mainly for employee compensation plans and long-term capital management, with the companies aiming to recycle surplus assets and boost return on equity.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of SGX. For stories related to derivatives, liquidity and stock trading.

site_title: Jack Ma-backed Ant Group’s profit up 193% in post-crackdown recovery
summary: Ant Group, backed by billionaire Jack Ma, reported a 193% profit increase in the June quarter, reversing a year-long decline following a government crackdown. The company contributed nearly 2.48 billion yuan (S$460 million) to Alibaba Group Holding's profit, with an estimated 7.5 billion yuan. Ant made significant business overhauls, including expanding its overseas operations and introducing blockchain-based treasury management. The company is awaiting a financial holding company licence, which would help revive its IPO plans.

images.alt_text: For Tencent and Ant, capturing even a fraction of this market would provide substantial growth, yet their strategies reveal differing visions of how to succeed outside China.
FILE PHOTO: A man walks past an Ant Group logo at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China July 8, 2021. REUTERS/Yilei Sun

Ant said it will start offering an AI “life assistant” app called Zhixiaobao, which can help people order meals, hail taxis, book tickets and access other functions in Ant’s mobile payments service Alipay, which has one billion users.
Alibaba reported revenue of 236.50 billion yuan (S$43.9 billion) for the second quarter ended Sep 30

site_title: Trump’s pick of Rubio: trouble ahead for Asean’s economic powerhouse dreams?
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's nomination of Florida Senator Marco Rubio as his secretary of state could disrupt South-east Asia's economic influence, shifting the region's status from a priority for the US to a strategic chess piece in the US-China stand-off. Rubio's past social media posts frame most of his comments about South-east Asia in the context of China, suggesting a defense-heavy approach that overshadows economic and diplomatic relations. The 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) must evolve into a strategic powerhouse prized for its economic potential to remain attractive to American investors.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
Volunteers gather at a room in the Seattle Labor Temple to call voters in swing states leading up to the US Presidential Election.

Chairman John Kim (centre in red, beside the man in black) founded the pro-Trump Strong Republic of Korea-US Alliance in defiance to what he believes are communist threats from China, North Korea and Russia – countries that surround South Korea.

site_title: Bill Hwang should get 21 years for Archegos crimes, US says
summary: US prosecutors recommend Bill Hwang, founder of Archegos Capital Management, receive a 21-year prison sentence for leading a massive securities fraud scheme that caused billions of dollars in losses. Hwang, 60, was found guilty of misleading Wall Street banks into inflating the value of Archegos' portfolio to $36 billion before it collapsed in 2021, causing $10 billion in losses for counterparties. Hwang's lawyers argue for no prison time, citing his age, health, and personal history, but prosecutors say a lengthy sentence is necessary to deter future fraudsters and hold him accountable for his actions.

images.alt_text: Bill Hwang  was convicted in July following a two-month long trial in New York of orchestrating a scheme to inflate the value of Archegos’ portfolio by misleading Wall Street banks into buying swaps on certain stocks.

The trial centered on the implosion of Bill Hwang’s family office Archegos, which inflicted US$10 billion in losses at global banks and, according to prosecutors, and caused more than US$100 billion in shareholder losses at companies in its portfolio.

During an eight-week trial, Archegos founder Bill Hwang was accused of being the mastermind of a scheme that ensnared half of Wall Street and cost banks US$10 billion after he artificially jacked up stock prices.

site_title: Covid-19 was ‘the mother of all challenges’ for real estate industry: CDL’s Chia Ngiang Hong
summary: Former Redas president Chia Ngiang Hong describes the Covid-19 pandemic as "the mother of all challenges" for the real estate industry, transforming the way business is done. To mitigate the spread of the virus, construction sites implemented safe-distancing measures, limiting cross-contact and relying on communication methods. Chia led efforts to raise funds to support migrant and healthcare workers, raising S$852,000 for care packs and gift vouchers. The pandemic also spurred the development of collaborative contracting, with the government announcing amendments to the Standard Consultancy Agreement to balance risks. Chia advocates for industry digitalization, citing the launch of the Real Estate Analytics and Performance Indicators Dashboard.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
For his contributions to the real estate industry, real estate veteran Chia Ngiang Hong was presented with the Redas Lifetime Achievement Award on Friday (Nov 15).

site_title: Musk’s X sues to block California’s deepfake deception law
summary: Elon Musk's social media platform X sued California's "Defending Democracy From Deepfake Deception Act of 2024," claiming the law would lead to widespread censorship of political speech. The law requires large online platforms to remove "materially deceptive" content, which X argues would be an unconstitutional affront to free speech. The complaint states that such censorship would be particularly problematic for speech critical of government officials and candidates. X's challenge comes after a California federal judge temporarily blocked a related measure banning deceptive campaign ads.

site_title: Musk’s political ascendancy stirs hopes for banks that incurred US$13 billion debt  purchasing X
summary: Elon Musk's close relationship with Republican President-elect Donald Trump may boost the prospects of X, a social media platform Musk bought for $44 billion in 2022. Some lenders, including Morgan Stanley and Bank of America, are hoping to offload $13 billion in debt backing the platform, which has seen decreased value due to Musk's sweeping changes and a loss of advertisers. Analysts believe Trump's ties to Musk could benefit the entrepreneur's business ventures, including Tesla and SpaceX, potentially increasing the value of the debt.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk, Chief Executive Officer of SpaceX and Tesla and owner of X looks on during the Milken Conference 2024 Global Conference Sessions at The Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills, California, U.S., May 6, 2024.  REUTERS/David Swanson/File Photo

site_title: Tyson beaten by Youtuber Paul in heavyweight return
summary: Mike Tyson, 58, suffered a one-sided defeat to YouTuber-turned-boxer Jake Paul by unanimous decision in their heavyweight bout in Arlington, Texas. Tyson, who was 58 years old, barely landed a punch, connecting with just 18 of 97 punches thrown, while Paul landed 78 of 278 punches. Paul's superior speed and movement dominated the fight, with Tyson looking every bit of his age. The defeat marks Tyson's controversial return to boxing, following a slap incident during the weigh-in.

images.alt_text: Pep Guardiola is chasing an unprecedented fifth straight Premier League title with Manchester City, which are now five points behind leaders Liverpool after 11 matches.
Ruben Amorim enjoyed a successful stint at Portuguese club Sporting Lisbon and he will hope to bring that winning feeling back to Manchester United.

site_title: US: Wall Street drops at the open after Powell dents rate-cut hopes
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, November 15, 2024, after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell expressed no need to rush interest-rate cuts, causing bond yields to rise and pressure rate-sensitive equities. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 162.9 points, or 0.37%, to 43,587.93. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 36.4 points, or 0.61%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 177.7 points, or 0.93%.

site_title: Issue 125: COP29 carbon deal a potential win for Asia; Singapore’s US$500 million blended finance signal
summary: The 29th edition of the United Nations Climate Summit (COP29) in Azerbaijan has agreed on a framework for a global carbon credit market, a potential win for Asia. The new Article 6.4 standards, which replace the problematic Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) credits market, include rules governing additionality and greenhouse gas removals. Asia, the largest issuer of voluntary carbon credits, is expected to benefit from the new market. Singapore has pledged US$500 million of concessional capital under its Financing Asia's Transition Partnership (Fast-P) blended finance initiative, aiming to mobilize US$5 billion to support climate transition in the region.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim
This year’s climate summit in Baku, Azerbaijan, has been dubbed the "finance COP".

A liberalised energy market, such as the Philippines, is the most efficient and cheap in the long-term, said Valerie Speth, co-lead in Asia-Pacific’s climate infrastructure group at BlackRock.

site_title: Trump’s win cools gold fever but longer-term outlook remains bullish
summary: US President Donald Trump's re-election has led to a decline in gold prices, retreating from all-time highs. Despite this, market watchers remain bullish on the longer-term outlook for gold, citing fundamental drivers such as ongoing conflicts, global protectionism, and the lack of a safe-haven replacement. The strengthening US dollar, bond yields, and confidence in US equities and cryptocurrencies are also contributing to the downward trend. However, experts believe the negative reaction in gold prices is a "near-term phenomenon" and that gold prices could rebound, potentially reaching $3,000 per ounce next year.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
October industrial output grew 5.3 per cent from a year earlier, slowing from September’s 5.4 per cent pace and missing expectations for a 5.6 per cent increase in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Democratic senators ask Pentagon, US attorney general to probe Musk‘s alleged Russia calls
summary: US Democratic senators Jeanne Shaheen and Jack Reed have called for a federal probe into Elon Musk's alleged contacts with Russian officials, including President Vladimir Putin, citing national-security concerns. The lawmakers, who oversee billions of dollars in Pentagon and intelligence-community contracts, want to investigate whether Musk's involvement in these programs poses a risk to US security. They have asked US Attorney General Merrick Garland and the Pentagon's inspector general to look into debarment and exclusion of Musk from contracts due to his reported communications with Russian officials.

images.alt_text: The tender offer would value Elon Musk's SpaceX at more than US$250 billion.
Elon Musk expressed concern that OpenAI is attempting to sarve competitors of AI talent by aggressively recuriting employees with lavish compensation offers.

While Tesla is by far the top EV seller in the US, chief executive Elon Musk says the company will be better positioned to deal with the potential pullback of incentives.

Senator John Thune, newly elected as the next Senate majority leader, grins towards reporters following the vote on Capitol Hill in Washington, US, Nov 13, 2024. Thune emerged victorious over a right-wing challenge from Senator Rick Scott.

site_title: Why Trump’s bid for recess appointments is so unprecedented
summary: President-elect Donald Trump is seeking to make a large number of recess appointments, bypassing the Senate's confirmation process, in an unprecedented move. Trump wants to fill key executive posts immediately, citing long Senate approval times. However, this power is limited by the Constitution, which allows the president to fill vacancies during a Senate recess but requires the appointments to expire at the end of the Senate's next session. The Senate, controlled by Trump's Republican Party, may not agree to recess, and Trump has alternative options, including forcing the Senate to adjourn with the help of the House.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump nominated Pete Hegseth (left) as part of his push to fill major administration posts quickly. Trump’s cabinet picks show that he prizes loyalty over experience and is fuelled by retribution.

Some lenders in the consortium, which included Morgan Stanley and Bank of America, think Elon Musk’s emergence as a close aide to Republican President-elect Donald Trump could boost the prospects of X, sources said.

China President Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden, who will hold their last, official face-to-face on Saturday, warned separately of choppy waters as the world braces for the prospect of fresh trade wars after Donald Trump assumes the US presidency in January.

Last month, the Wall Street Journal reported Elon Musk has had multiple conversations with Russian officials including Putin and his first deputy chief of staff Sergei Kiriyenko, citing unnamed US, European and Russian officials.

Most of Marco Rubio's (right) public remarks made on X regarding South-east Asia are disappointingly in relation to China.

site_title: State carrier Garuda Indonesia appoints new CEO
summary: State-run Garuda Indonesia has appointed Wamildan Tsani Panjaitan as its new CEO, replacing Irfan Setiaputra who served for over four years. Panjaitan, a former acting head of budget Lion Air, aims to enhance the airline's financial performance and improve services quality. President Prabowo Subianto instructed Panjaitan to turn Garuda into a globally renowned airline. The decision was made during a shareholders' meeting on November 15, following Garuda's restructuring of over $9 billion in debt in 2022.

images.alt_text: Despite the almost US$10 billion debt restructuring in 2022 that saw its fleet shrink from about 210 aircraft, Garuda is still struggling to generate a profit amid increased competition with privately-held Lion Mentari Airlines.
SIA first announced plans to enter into a joint venture with Garuda Indonesia  in May 2023.
The tie-up is unlikely to reduce competition, said SIA and Garuda, as they will continue to face “intense” rivalry from low-cost carriers.
A company generally does a debt tender offer to retire its bonds at less than the original face value and by doing so it also reduces the interest costs.

site_title: China’s Alibaba misses quarterly revenue estimates, beats on profit
summary: Alibaba Group Holding reported revenue of 236.50 billion yuan (S$43.9 billion) for the second quarter, missing analysts' estimates of 240.17 billion yuan due to lingering economic uncertainty in China. Despite this, the company beat profit estimates with an adjusted profit of 15.06 yuan per American Depository Share. Alibaba's international e-commerce unit saw significant growth, with revenue rising 29% to 31.67 billion yuan, driven by demand for lower-priced goods from China.

images.alt_text: The last time Alibaba sold standard US dollar notes in public markets was with a US$5 billion multi-part deal in 2021.
Workers sort packages for delivery at a JD.com warehouse in Beijing on November 11, known as the Singles’ Day shopping festival in China.
GoTo Gojek Tokopedia signs agreements with China’s Tencent and Alibaba to develop cloud infrastructure and digital talent in Indonesia.

site_title: Israel inflation steady at 3.5% in October, stays above target
summary: Israel's inflation rate remained steady at 3.5% in October, exceeding the government's target range of 1-3%. Officials attribute the persistence of inflation to war-related supply issues. The Bank of Israel has left interest rates unchanged since January, citing geopolitical tensions, rising price pressures, and looser fiscal policy due to the ongoing conflict with Hamas. The central bankers have warned of potential rate hikes if inflation remains high.

site_title: Managing the surge in medical insurance premiums
summary: Singapore residents face rising healthcare costs with premiums from Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) and riders increasing, with lifetime IP premiums with riders reaching S$842,000. MediShield Life premiums also rose by an average of 22% after enhancements to the national health insurance scheme. Five insurers raised premiums for base IPs, focusing on private hospital plans, while Income Insurance increased premiums across all ward types. Reviewing healthcare needs and preferences, and insurance plans, is essential to navigate the complexities of health coverage while safeguarding financial well-being.

images.alt_text: Medical cost inflation in Singapore is estimated at between 10.67 and 13 per cent annually.

Good money habits empower you to make informed decisions, better handle emergencies, and help you to work towards your financial goals and achieve sustainable financial wellness.

site_title: CSE Global reports higher revenue for Q3 2024, but order intake falls
summary: CSE Global reported a 15.4% increase in Q3 2024 revenue to S$213.9 million, driven by higher revenue from all business segments. The electrification segment rose 22% to S$104.8 million, while the communications and automation segments grew 12.1% and 6.6% respectively. However, order intake fell 57.4% in the electrification segment and 3.3% in the automation segment, due to the absence of major projects secured in Q3 2023, resulting in a 0.7% decline in the order book.

The settlement is expected to have a material adverse impact on the financial position of CSE Global for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2024.

site_title: Alibaba is said to consider offering US$5 billion of bonds
summary: Alibaba Group Holding is considering offering bonds totaling approximately US$5 billion, equivalent to its last public market sale in 2021. The potential debt sale could include US dollar and yuan parts, and its exact nature, whether private or public, is unclear. This comes after the company's record private offering of US$5 billion convertible bonds in May. The move is seen as a way for Alibaba to raise funds, although the company's financial situation remains uncertain due to its founder Jack Ma's reduced influence and the current economic climate.

site_title: Polestar 4 review: A Swede taste of tomorrow
summary: The Polestar 4 is a Swedish-Chinese electric vehicle that reimagines the modern motorcar with a minimalist design, challenging traditional notions of what a car should be. Its unusual proportions produce spatial magic, making it feel roomy despite its sleek design. The car boasts impressive performance, with 544 horsepower and a range of up to 590 km. However, its driving experience is more subdued, and virtual controls on the touchscreen can feel like a chore. The cabin is a delightful place to be, with a serene ride and ample legroom, but parking can be a weird exercise due to its reliance on camera systems.

images.alt_text: While it’s more practical than a Swiss Army knife, the Santa Fe also has character.

site_title: Samsung unveils surprise US$7 billion buyback over coming year
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to repurchase approximately $7.2 billion of its own stock over the next 12 months, marking one of the largest shareholder return programs in the company's history. The buyback will be executed in stages over the coming year. This move comes as the company faces competition in the AI memory chip business. Samsung's shares rose 8.6% following the announcement, despite being down sharply on the year.

site_title: US retail sales slightly above expectations in October
summary: US retail sales rose 0.4% in October, exceeding expectations, driven by low layoffs and strong household balance sheets. The increase was slightly more than forecast, but underlying momentum in consumer spending appeared to slow at the start of the fourth quarter. The upwardly revised 0.8% advance in September also contributed to the growth, as robust consumer spending helped the economy maintain its strong pace of growth last quarter.

images.alt_text: A worker uses a forklift to move a pallet of Constellation Brands Inc. Woodbridge wine in the distribution warehouse at Southern Wine and Spirits Inc. in Louisville, Kentucky, U.S., on Thursday, Jan. 7, 2016. U.S. drinkers are increasingly opting for wine and imported beer over brands like Bud Light, a boon for Constellation Brands Inc. which reported a 22 percent jump in profits for the third quarter. site_title: From ‘cowboy’ times to cooling measures: real estate veteran Chia Ngiang Hong on Singapore’s market
summary: Singapore's real estate sector has become "very orderly, transparent and very reliable" over the past 40 years, according to Chia Ngiang Hong, group general manager of City Developments Ltd (CDL). Chia, who received the Redas Lifetime Achievement Award, says the industry has introduced measures such as the Project Account scheme to prevent developers from going bankrupt and leaving buyers hanging. He suggests the government consider tweaking the formula for calculating the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) payable to developers to prevent them from hoarding unsold units.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Redas re-elects Chia Ngiang Hong for another two-year term as president
Redas seeks longer project sales period for land acquired before latest cooling measures

site_title: Thailand aims to legalise casinos next year in win for global players
summary: Thailand plans to legalize casinos by 2025, aiming to attract foreign investments and collect more taxes, with potential revenue reaching $9.1 billion, making it the third-largest market globally. The country has received interest from big investors with world-class experience, and casinos could be housed within large entertainment venues. The government is working on a bill that will require entertainment complexes to be operated by Thai-registered companies with a minimum paid-up capital of $385 million.

images.alt_text: A public hearing has concluded and 80 per cent of those who attended agreed with the plan, Thailand's deputy finance minister Julapun Amornvivat said.

site_title: CCCS okays Hanwha’s proposed acquisition of Dyna-Mac
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has approved Hanwha Ocean SG Holding's acquisition of Dyna-Mac, stating that the transaction will not substantially lessen competition within Singapore. The regulator assessed the potential supplier-customer relationship between the two companies in the downstream markets for offshore plants, finding no significant impact on competition. Hanwha Ocean made a final offer of S$0.67 per share to Dyna-Mac's shareholders, which was accepted by a substantial shareholder. The acquisition is now unconditional.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Singapore stocks extend gains on Friday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% or 6.54 points to 3,744.7 on Friday, extending two days of gains. The benchmark index was dragged by real estate investment trust CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, which fell 1.9%. Technology service provider Venture Corporation was the top performer, rising 3.1%. Local banks DBS and OCBC ended mixed, while UOB rose 1%. The rally comes as recent stimulus from China has seen equity markets rally spectacularly.

Among the S&P 500‘s 11 major industry sectors, industrials is the biggest decliner with big drags from defense companies.
The development of SummerVille Logistics Center (above) is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2025.

site_title: KKR raises offer for Fuji Soft to 1 yen above Bain’s rival bid
summary: KKR has raised its offer price for Fuji Soft to 9,451 yen (S$81.49) per share, one yen above Bain Capital's rival bid, winning the backing of the Japanese software developer's board. The private equity firm will pay a total of around 637 billion yen (US$4.1 billion) for the company, valuing it at that amount. Fuji Soft's board supports the KKR offer and opposes the Bain bid, following a tender offer that is expected to start next week.

site_title: Rocked but undeterred: Man City’s Guardiola seeks return to winning ways
summary: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola is facing a challenging run of fixtures for his injury-plagued team, which has lost four straight games. The team, led by Guardiola, is now five points behind leaders Liverpool in the Premier League after 11 matches. Guardiola attributes the recent defeats to a lack of form, saying "we are not at our best" and that the team will recover step by step. With a tough schedule ahead, including games against Liverpool, Manchester United, and Juventus, Guardiola must hope that his players return from the international break unscathed to get back to winning ways.
