site_title: Indonesia intervenes as rupiah nears 16,000 per dollar level
summary: Indonesia's central bank intervened in currency markets to support the rupiah, which had weakened towards 16,000 per US dollar. The bank will use triple intervention measures to maintain market confidence, citing a "decent" dollar supply in the market. Investors have pulled over $1.2 billion from Indonesia's markets this month due to concerns over US inflation and Federal Reserve rate cuts. The intervention may prevent Bank Indonesia from easing interest rates at its next meeting, with some economists predicting a delay in rate cuts until December.

images.alt_text: The Indonesian central bank has ample resources to support the rupiah, with its foreign-exchange reserves remaining near a record in September.
Bond market pressures also may arise from Bank Indonesia possibly delaying further cuts to support the rupiah if the currency underperforms.
The rupiah has been under pressure in October as the market lowered expectations for an aggressive Fed rate cut.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 15)
summary: Genting Singapore's Resorts World Sentosa is set to complete a major S$6.8 billion expansion by 2030 to boost visitor numbers amid declining gaming revenue. Ong Beng Seng's lawyers must make representations on his behalf by Nov 29. New private home sales rose in October with major launches, while companies can receive up to S$72,000 in wage support for overseas employees. Singapore stocks extended gains on Friday, with the STI up 0.2%.

images.alt_text: This year marks the 40th anniversary of the GIC’s presence in the US, and SM Lee said GIC and the US have built a “strong, productive and mutually beneficial partnership” in the last four decades.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, November 15, 2024
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that there's no need to rush rate cuts due to a strong economy. Malaysia's economy grew slower in Q3, with consumption rebounding and home prices falling at a slower rate in China. Goodwill Entertainment made its trading debut at S$0.21, 5% above its IPO price. China's home prices fell the fastest in 9 years, but officials see signs of stabilization.

images.alt_text: As at 9.01 am, the Straits Times Index (STI) was down 0.3 per cent or 11.83 points at 3,726.33. Across the broader market, losers outnumbered gainers 66 to 37 after 42.3 million securities worth S$65.8 million changed hands.
Among the S&P 500‘s 11 major industry sectors, industrials is the biggest decliner with big drags from defense companies.
Going into 2025, Bank Negara expects the economy to grow between 4.8 per cent to 5.3 per cent, driven by household spending, expansion in employment and income.
HaveFun Karaoke (above) is run by Goodwill Entertainment.

Photographer: Na Bian/Bloomberg

site_title: US import prices unexpectedly rise in October
summary: US import prices unexpectedly rose 0.3% in October, reversing a 0.4% decline in September, and increasing 0.8% over the past 12 months. Fuel prices rose 1.5%, while food prices fell 1.6% for the third consecutive month. Core import prices, excluding fuels and food, gained 0.4% in October, with a 2.2% year-on-year increase. The unexpected increase in import prices suggests that inflation remains a concern, contradicting forecasts of a decline.

images.alt_text: Consumption is being largely underpinned by low layoffs, with additional help from strong household balance sheets thanks to a stock market rally and high home prices.

site_title: EU sees eurozone growth ticking up in 2025, but risks loom
summary: The European Commission has forecast eurozone growth to accelerate slightly to 1.3% in 2025, up from 0.8% this year, while inflation is expected to ease to 2.1% from 2.4%. Despite the slight growth, the commission warns of growing risks linked to geopolitical tensions, including the impact of US President-elect Donald Trump's policies on global trade. The commission also notes that domestic demand is projected to drive future growth, with investment expected to rebound on the back of strong corporate balance sheets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, July 14, 2021. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: Iron ore slumps on China property concerns, firmer supply
summary: Iron ore futures declined to their lowest level in nearly two months due to weakness in China's property sector, stronger supply, and reduced seasonal steel demand. China's new home prices fell the most year on year since 2015, and property investment declined 10.3% in the first 10 months of 2024. This has led to a 3.09% drop in iron ore prices on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange, with prices falling 6.18% for the week.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings at a government-subsidized rental housing complex in Beijing, China, on Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024. China promised new measures to support the property sector and hinted at greater government borrowing to shore up the economy, as authorities seek to put a floor under the country’s growth slowdown. Photographer: Na Bian/Bloomberg
China finance ministry will expand the eligibility for the 1 per cent deed tax to include apartments up to 140 square metres, up from the previous 90 square metres.
China in the past two months unleashed its strongest package of policies to boost the property market.
Sunac has 15.4 billion yuan (S$2.9 billion) in outstanding onshore debt.

site_title: Yoko Ono is rightful owner of John Lennon’s stolen watch: Swiss court
summary: A Swiss court has ruled that Yoko Ono is the rightful owner of a stolen Patek Philippe watch gifted to John Lennon by Ono in 1980. The watch, valued at 4 million Swiss Francs, was stolen after Lennon's assassination and later sold to an Italian man. Ono discovered the watch had been stolen in 2014 after a Geneva-based company tipped off her lawyer. The court's decision paves the way for the watch's return to Ono, bearing the inscription "JUST LIKE STARTING OVER LOVE YOKO 10·9·1980 N.Y.C".

images.alt_text: Bought from a music store in the band’s birth city of Liverpool, Harrison played the Futurama guitar in the early 1960s when the band performed at the Cavern Club, toured Germany and made their first official records for Polydor.
A Geneva court rules that Yoko Ono (above), wife of the late John Lennon, is the rightful owner of the Patek Philippe watch, and the collector is appealing, according to the court documents.

site_title: Why is it so expensive to build housing in New York?
summary: Building housing in New York City has become increasingly difficult, time-consuming, and expensive due to high demand and limited supply. Just 1.4% of apartments were available last year, driving up rents. The process of obtaining a zoning change, known as ULURP, can add 11-16% to costs, while regulations such as metal piping and elevators in high-rise buildings contribute to higher construction costs. Maintenance and operation expenses, including property taxes, also significantly impact landlords, with estimated costs of $7,500 per unit per year. These factors contribute to the high prices of housing in New York City.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings in New York, US, on Friday, July 12, 2024. President Joe Biden is calling on Congress to pass a form of national rent control for some 20 million apartment units nationwide, a dramatic federal intervention in the housing market on behalf of current tenants. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

site_title: China retail sales pick up speed, beats forecasts in October
summary: China's retail sales expanded 4.8% in October, the fastest clip since February, beating forecasts and offering an encouraging sign for Beijing's efforts to boost the sluggish economy. This growth comes as the country pushes for a 5% national growth target, which most experts believe will be narrowly missed. Officials have introduced measures such as interest rate cuts and debt swaps to stimulate consumption, but challenges persist, including deflationary pressure, a property sector bust, and geopolitically fraught trade disputes.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on August 15, 2024 shows people walking past bubble tea shops at a night market in Hangzhou, in eastern China's Zhejiang province. Sweet, milky and colourful -- bubble tea is wildly popular in China, where people sipping through straws from large plastic cups is a common sight in high streets and shopping malls across the country. (Photo by Jade GAO / AFP) / To go with 'CHINA-ECONOMY-YOUTH-CONSUMERS, FOCUS' by Peter Catterall with Isabel Kua in Beijing

site_title: Landslide win for Sri Lanka president's leftist coalition in snap polls
summary: Sri Lanka's President Anura Kumara Dissanayake's leftist coalition, National People's Power, won a landslide victory in snap parliamentary elections, securing at least 159 seats in the 225-member assembly. The coalition's 61.5% of the vote exceeded a two-thirds majority, vindicating Dissanayake's decision to call polls. The win is seen as a repudiation of establishment parties blamed for triggering an economic crisis. Dissanayake, a self-avowed Marxist, had campaigned on a promise to combat graft and recover stolen assets.

images.alt_text: epa11719859 Sri Lankan President Anura Kumara Dissanayake  (C) leaves a polling station after casting his vote for parliamentary elections at a polling station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, 14 November 2024. Nearly 17.1 million registered voters in Sri Lanka go to the polls to elect 225 members to form a new parliament. Sri Lanka's President Anura Kumara Dissanayake dissolved parliament on 24 September, after securing victory in the first presidential election since the mass protests and political turmoil triggered by the country's 2022 economic collapse.  EPA-EFE/CHAMILA KARUNARATHNE

site_title: Citigroup warns Trump's policies may slow growth in emerging markets
summary: Citigroup warns that US President-elect Donald Trump's trade policies may slow global growth, particularly in emerging markets. Analysts expect emerging market stocks to underperform compared to global peers, with Saudi Arabia and India less exposed to trade risks. Citigroup upgraded Saudi Arabia to "overweight" and lifted South Africa's rating to "overweight", while downgrading India to "neutral" due to stalling earnings growth. The brokerage forecasts emerging market assets to be pressured by US dollar strength and trade policy uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Market watchers note that the fundamental price drivers for gold remain intact despite Trump’s return.

site_title: China's Oct data shows soft economic underbelly, Trump threat looms large
summary: China's October industrial output grew 5.3% from a year earlier, slowing from September's 5.4% pace and missing expectations. Retail sales, however, rose 4.8% in October, driven by the Singles' Day shopping festival. The data suggests China's economy is still recovering, but the return of Donald Trump to the White House poses a significant threat, with tariffs on Chinese goods expected to hike. Policymakers are under pressure to maintain stimulus measures to support the economy, with some economists warning of a potential slowdown in the second half of next year.

images.alt_text: Smoke rises following an explosion, next to the body of a man who threw objects and committed suicide in a blast, outside Brazil's Supreme Court, in Brasilia, Brazil on Wednesday.

site_title: Chinese stocks lead Asia markets’ weekly losses amid China data, Fed signal on rate cuts
summary: Asian markets declined this week, with Japan's Nikkei 225 down 2.2% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index slumping 6.3%, while China's CSI 300 fell 3.3%. US consumer prices showed inflation stayed firm, and the Federal Reserve indicated no hurry to cut interest rates. China's retail sales beat forecasts, but industrial production growth edged down. New home prices fell the fastest in nine years, but officials said they were bottoming out. Despite this, mainland and Hong Kong-listed shares were still muted.

images.alt_text: Over the one-year period ended September 2024, CPFIS funds registered a positive return of 14.7 per cent.
Brokerages said trading activity in Singapore spiked after Trump emerged victorious from the US elections last Tuesday (Nov 5).

site_title: China Mobile in talks to buy Hong Kong tower seized from tycoon
summary: China Mobile's Hong Kong unit is in talks to buy the Cheung Kei Center, a commercial property in Hong Kong once owned by struggling tycoon Chen Hongtian, for a potential HK$3 billion (S$517 million). The property, valued at HK$7 billion in 2022, has been on the market since 2023. The deal aims to be completed by the end of the year, following a downturn in Hong Kong's real estate market. This is part of a trend of Chinese companies acquiring properties in the city.

site_title: New private home sales rise in October, buoyed by major launches
summary: Singapore's new private home sales surged in October, with 738 units sold, a 84% increase from September and a 261.8% rise from the year-ago period. The majority of sales came from two major projects, Norwood Grand and Meyer Blue, which contributed 56.4% of total sales. Experts attribute the market resurgence to improved consumer sentiment, a strengthening economy, and recent mortgage rate reductions, which have enhanced housing affordability. With several projects set to launch before the year-end holidays, market watchers expect October's gains to extend into positive November data.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

The method of distributing sales proceeds is often a contentious issue, particularly for mixed-use developments where expectations on the acceptable range of en-bloc premiums and what constitutes a ‘fair and equitable’ method of apportionment may differ.

site_title: China’s home prices fall fastest in 9 years, but officials see signs of stabilisation
summary: China's new home prices fell 5.9% in October, the largest year-over-year decline since 2015, marking the 16th consecutive month of declines. However, a narrowing monthly rate of declines suggests stabilization in the property sector, with a 0.5% month-on-month drop in October. The government has promised new measures to support the sector and hinted at greater borrowing to shore up the economy.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s housing market has long had an are-you-kidding-me feel to it.
China finance ministry will expand the eligibility for the 1 per cent deed tax to include apartments up to 140 square metres, up from the previous 90 square metres.

site_title: SIA Group passenger traffic rises 7.4% in October
summary: SIA Group reported a 7.4% year-on-year increase in passenger traffic for October 2024, with 3.3 million passengers carried. Cargo loads rose 20.2% and cargo capacity expanded 14.3%. The group's revenue passenger-kilometre reached 12.9 billion, and passenger load factor decreased 1.4 percentage points to 86%. Cargo load factor increased three percentage points to 59.1%. The airline's network covered 127 destinations in 36 countries and territories.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Singapore Airlines planes sit on the tarmac at Changi Airport in Singapore November 16, 2021. REUTERS/Caroline Chia/File Photo
Paige Lim

site_title: Apple could be a major casualty of Trump’s China tariffs
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump plans to impose 60% tariffs on Chinese imports and 10-20% on other countries. Apple, which assembles some products in India and Vietnam, may face significant costs if it passes on tariffs to consumers. The company's average product gross margin could plummet to zero if it absorbs the 60% tariff, leading to sharp price increases in the US. Trump's tariff plans may not compel Apple to repatriate its assembly, as labor-intensive work in the US is not feasible.

images.alt_text: Among the S&P 500‘s 11 major industry sectors, industrials is the biggest decliner with big drags from defense companies.

site_title: Ong Beng Seng’s lawyers to make representations by Nov 29
summary: Billionaire Ong Beng Seng's lawyers have until November 29 to make representations on his behalf in a court case. Ong faces charges of abetting offences under the Penal Code and obstruction of justice related to dealings with former transport minister S Iswaran. The court has set a deadline for the prosecution to respond by December 20 if any representations are received by November 29. Ong's lawyer declined to comment on whether he intends to plead guilty or claim trial.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Ong Beng Seng was charged on Oct 4 with abetting a public servant in obtaining gifts and with abetting the obstruction of justice.

site_title: Peter Viens, new CEO of IReit Global’s manager, aims to diversify assets to attract institutional investors
summary: IReit Global's new CEO, Peter Viens, plans to diversify the trust's assets to attract institutional investors, focusing on Western Europe and retail and hospitality assets. The trust currently has 44 retail and 9 office properties, with most in France and Germany. Viens aims to acquire assets in the Netherlands, Italy, and the UK, and expects a "marginal" decrease in portfolio occupancy. The trust's largest asset, Berlin Campus, will undergo repositioning, with a significant drop in distribution per unit (DPU) expected during the project.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
About 1,200 sq m was vacated in the Parc Cugat Green office building in Barcelona, Spain in Q2 2024.

Louis d'Estienne d'Orves, CEO of IReit Global's manager, says the repositioned asset could benefit from increased rent rates.

site_title: Dip in Singapore consumers’ trust in general insurers and insurance sales staff: report
summary: Singapore consumers' trust in general insurers and insurance sales staff has declined, with trust levels dropping to 73 in 2024 from 75 in 2023. Trust in insurance intermediaries, such as brokers and advisers, fell to 62 points in 2024 from 68 the previous year. The decline in trust is primarily attributed to a decrease in trust levels among consumers aged 20-39, according to the 2024 insurance trust indicator study. Despite the decline, general insurers' trust indicator scores remained within moderate to strong levels.

images.alt_text: Generic photos of Singapore city skyline for stories related to Singapore economy or economic growth.

site_title: Xi inaugurates South America's first Chinese-funded port in Peru
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping inaugurated the US$3.5-billion Chancay mega-port in Peru, marking Latin America's first Beijing-funded port. The port is designed to serve as a hub for Chinese trade, amid US tariff threats that could impact Peruvian exports. Peruvian President Dina Boluarte attended the ceremony, which was overseen virtually by Xi and Boluarte. The port's opening is seen as a symbol of China's growing influence in the region, as it prepares to face off with a new Donald Trump administration.

images.alt_text: China, Latin America have profitable but unequal ties

site_title: SG startups’ love story with the US unfazed by tariff threats
summary: Singapore-based firms have invested heavily in the US, with significant benefits, despite US President-elect Donald Trump's threats to impose 10-20% import tariffs. Firms like Secretlab, IglooCompany, and Castlery have expanded into the US market. The tariffs, which could apply to both finished goods and raw materials, may unwind progress made by these companies. The US is the world's largest consumer market, and many Asian brands view it as a key growth opportunity.

images.alt_text: In recent years, Apple has started assembling some of its products in India and Vietnam.

site_title: PC Partner commences trading in Singapore, opens at S$0.85
summary: PC Partner Group, a Hong Kong-based electronics company, commenced trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) at S$0.85 on November 15, 2024. The company reported a 9-fold increase in H1 net profit to HK$194 million, up from HK$20 million a year ago, driven by increased sales of video graphics cards. The secondary listing marks the company's entry into the Singapore market.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Bitcoin tumble erases US$38b in value as rival cryptocurrency gains
Singapore firms ink deals to ride tech and consumer wave in Guangdong

site_title: Musk escalates Altman legal feud, casts OpenAI as monopolist
summary: Elon Musk has escalated his legal feud with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, alleging the company is trying to corner the market for generative AI and sacrifice safety for profit. A revised lawsuit lists 26 claims and accuses OpenAI of using lavish compensation offers to recruit employees from competitors, and of contracting with the US Department of Defense without a ban on military use. Musk's xAI startup is seeking to compete with OpenAI, which has received billions in investment from Microsoft and others.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk has sought to compete with OpenAI, the current AI leader, most recently valued at US$157 billion.
Elon Musk is likely to serve as a special government employee, the formal designation for individuals outside of government brought in for short periods to lend their expertise.

site_title: Hong Kong expects growth to slow as sluggish demand weighs
summary: Hong Kong's economic growth is expected to slow as sluggish demand weighs, with the city's gross domestic product expanding 1.8% in the three months ended September from the same period last year. The government revised its 2024 growth forecast to 2.5% from a range of 2.5-3.5%, citing weaknesses in exports and consumption. External challenges, including China's slowdown and geopolitical tensions, have contributed to the economic slowdown, with visitor numbers trailing pre-pandemic levels. The government also cut its forecast for headline inflation for 2024 to 1.7%.

images.alt_text: A view of the main street of the North Point district in Hong Kong on November 9, 2024. (Photo by Mladen ANTONOV / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia Q3 growth slows; Bank Negara to allow international banks to issue ringgit bonds
summary: Malaysia's economy expanded at a slower pace of 5.3% year-over-year (yoy) in the third quarter, supported by strong investment and improving exports. The central bank expects the economy to grow between 4.8 and 5.3% in 2025, driven by household spending and expansion in employment and income. To encourage investments, Bank Negara Malaysia has allowed international banks to issue ringgit bonds, making it easier for them to raise funds in the local currency. The ringgit appreciated nearly 15% against the US dollar in the third quarter, supported by the US Federal Reserve's shift towards easing monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng

site_title: UK economy contracts in September in blow to Reeves' growth push
summary: The UK economy contracted by 0.1% in September, slowing growth to 0.1% for the third quarter, a blow to Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves' efforts to boost the economy. This follows a 0.5% growth in the second quarter. Economists had forecast 0.2% growth, and the contraction is attributed to the services sector, manufacturing, and construction sectors. Finance Minister Reeves expressed dissatisfaction with the figures, promising to deliver growth through investment and reform to create jobs and increase people's income.

images.alt_text: Commuters cross London Bridge on their way to work at the City of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 12, 2024. The Bank of England is looking carefully at labor market data to determine the strength of inflationary forces lingering in the economy. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

site_title: Companies can get up to S$72,000 in wage support to send staff abroad
summary: Workforce Singapore's Overseas Markets Immersion Programme (OMIP) provides up to S$72,000 in wage support for Singaporean companies to send employees abroad. Over 100 firms are expected to benefit, with the programme capped at S$16 million. Companies must pay employees a fixed monthly salary of at least S$4,000 and provide a career development plan for each employee. Eligible employees will undergo on-the-job training and gain networking opportunities with international counterparts. The programme aims to empower individuals to take charge of their career health and seize new growth opportunities overseas.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Vietnam (25 per cent), Indonesia (25 per cent), and Thailand (21 per cent) were the top markets of interest.
While 77 per cent of respondents expect to make a profit this year, nearly half anticipate lower profits compared to 2023.

site_title: Why we turn to crosswords in times of crisis
summary: The crossword puzzle has long served as a source of comfort and solace during times of crisis, offering a light-hearted distraction from the struggles of daily life. Introduced in The New York Times in 1941, the puzzle's intellectual labour provides a refined sense of accomplishment, and its ephemeral nature allows it to reinvent itself daily. As a crisis of values often accompanies times of crisis, crosswords help solvers clarify their values and demonstrate what they can do and what they should want, providing a salve for the madness of daily life.

images.alt_text: As many young people discover a love of crossword puzzles – sometimes with the help of these Gen Z-founded resources – they’re finding community within pages of newsprint.

site_title: Resorts World Sentosa’s S$6.8 billion waterfront expansion to open in 2030
summary: Resorts World Sentosa, a major integrated resort in Singapore, plans to expand with a S$6.8 billion project set to open in 2030. The expansion will include two luxury hotels, a waterfront promenade, and a retail, entertainment, and dining podium. The move aims to boost visitor appeal amid slower international arrivals, increased competition, and falling gaming revenue. The project is described as a "must-visit" destination in the global tourism landscape, according to Resorts World Sentosa's CEO, Tan Hee Teck.

images.alt_text: Samuel Oh
The quarter-on-quarter decline in Genting Singapore’s performance was mainly attributable to lower VIP rolling volume and win rate, said the group.
Even though integrated resorts in other parts of the world might not be fully rebranding or repositioning themselves, they are certainly reinvesting and elevating," says MBS COO Paul Town.
Genting Singapore’s Resorts World Sentosa

site_title: US: Wall Street edges higher at the open after PPI data
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 74.2 points, or 0.17%, to 44,032.38, following a broadly in line producer prices data reading. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also edged higher, rising 4.3 and 25.4 points, respectively, at the open. Investors await Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments for clues on interest rate outlook, but the data provided no significant surprises.

site_title: Cordlife posts S$1.6 million Q3 net loss on revenue decline
summary: Cordlife, a Singapore-based cord-blood bank, reported a net loss of S$1.6 million for the third quarter of 2024, a 31% decline in revenue to S$10.1 million due to lower contributions from Singapore. The company resumed its cord-blood banking services in a controlled manner in September after a suspension. For the nine-month period, Cordlife recorded a net loss of S$13.9 million, a 55.1% decline in revenue. The company aims to rebuild its business foundation and regain stakeholder trust.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The arrests of Cordlife's directors and group chief executive are related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding irregular temperatures in its storage tanks.
Cordlife added that further consideration may be made in due course as to whether Zhai, Yiu and Chow will continue to waive their fees after FY24.
Unitholders will vote on the appointment of audit firm PKF at Cordlife's EGM on Nov 14.
Cordlife Group has been receiving sign-ups from new customers since it was allowed to resume collecting new cord blood in a "controlled manner".

site_title: Crypto-heist leader worth billions gets five-year sentence
summary: Ilya "Dutch" Lichtenstein, mastermind behind a 2016 Bitfinex Bitcoin hack, was sentenced to five years in prison for conspiring with his wife to launder stolen cryptocurrency. The hack resulted in the theft of 119,754 Bitcoin worth US$71 million, with 21% successfully laundered. Lichtenstein, a "highly skilled computer expert," used hacking techniques to steal the cryptocurrency and laundered the funds through various methods, including setting up accounts under fictitious identities and buying assets like non-fungible tokens and gold.

images.alt_text: Singapore Fintech Festival panellists spoke about how
US-based Ripple provides enterprise solutions that leverage the cryptocurrency XRP.

site_title: Wars, looming Trump reign set to dominate G20 summit
summary: G20 leaders are set to gather in Brazil for a summit dominated by conflicts in the Middle East and Ukraine, as well as implications of Donald Trump's potential return to the White House. The summit will also touch on climate change and issues championed by President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, such as the fight against hunger and poverty. A failed bomb attack outside Brazil's Supreme Court in Brasilia has heightened security concerns, and the summit will be attended by leaders from China and Russia, who are expected to discuss ways to end the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

site_title: New York’s US$1.5 billion art auction week could favour the brave
summary: New York's US$1.5 billion art auction week is expected to favor sellers, with many consignors deciding to sell amid strong market signals. Sotheby's and Christie's will auction over 700 lots, with Christie's leading in value with an estimated US$583-796 million. The week's sales will feature fresh-to-market artworks, including a highly sought-after Ed Ruscha piece and a Jean-Michel Basquiat work. Sellers are holding back due to a stagnant market, but the upcoming auctions may signal a shift, with fewer but higher-value items on offer.

images.alt_text: The settlement resolves claims that Sotheby’s let at least eight clients cheat New York state from 2010 to 2020 by using “resale certificates” that falsely portrayed them as art dealers entitled to tax exemptions, instead of art collectors.

site_title: Self-driving startup Pony.ai seeks up to US$195 million in US IPO
summary: Pony.ai, a self-driving startup, is seeking up to $195 million in its US initial public offering (IPO). The company, founded in 2016, develops and operates self-driving fleets in the US and China, with a market value of around $4.5 billion. Investment Global and Guangzhou Automobile Group are among the investors interested in purchasing shares. This IPO comes as automotive-related companies lead a modest pickup in Chinese listings, with about $40 billion raised via IPOs in the US this year.

images.alt_text: WeRide has been testing and conducting commercial pilots in 30 cities across seven countries.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank downgrades ComfortDelGro to ‘hold’ on acquisition doubts
summary: Maybank Securities has downgraded its rating on ComfortDelGro to "hold" with a lower price target of S$1.60 due to concerns over the company's acquisition of UK-based Addison Lee, citing a challenging operating and regulatory landscape in the UK. Analyst Eric Ong notes the acquisition marks a shift towards an asset-heavy business model, with relatively low return-on-equity and growth prospects, and may impact free cash flow.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
ComfortDelGro says its latest contract win represents a 30 per cent growth to its Victoria public bus business.
The newly acquired A2B Australian taxi company helped boost Comfortdelgro's earnings for H1 2024.
ComfortDelGro, in a tie-up with Pony.ai, said that it expects autonomous vehicle technology to alleviate global driver shortage.

site_title: The Labubu craze is not just a fad. Singapore businesses are taking notes
summary: Singapore businesses are taking note of the Labubu craze, a phenomenon where blind-box marketing is drawing customers with mystery, surprise, and collectability. The global blind-box toy market reached US$14.3 billion in 2024, with a projected compound annual growth rate of 6% from 2024 to 2031. Companies such as Pop Mart, Kewpie, and Science Centre Singapore are using blind boxes to boost consumer engagement and create buzz around their products. The trend is linked to impulsive buying behavior, raising concerns about further regulations. Non-toymakers are also adopting the blind-box strategy to capitalize on the same psychological triggers as traditional blind boxes.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Blind boxes at Pop Mart Ion Orchard. South-east Asian markets account for 41 per cent of international revenue in the first six months of the year.

The Chinese market for mystery boxes, whose contents are sold undisclosed and which are also known as blind boxes, has grown quickly, contributing to the fast expansion of domestic toymakers such as Pop Mart.
Jackson Aw, chief executive officer, Mighty Jaxx International.

site_title: Tesla, Rivian drop on report Trump wants to end EV credit
summary: US stocks fell after Reuters reported President-elect Donald Trump plans to eliminate the US$7,500 electric vehicle (EV) tax credit, a key component of President Joe Biden's climate bill. Tesla and Rivian shares plummeted 5.8% and 14% respectively, while General Motors and Ford shares declined. Elon Musk, Tesla CEO, supports ending the credit, citing the company's ability to adapt to potential pullbacks. Repealing the subsidy could significantly hinder EV adoption in the US, which has already struggled due to high vehicle prices and spotty charging infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Brokerages said trading activity in Singapore spiked after Trump emerged victorious from the US elections last Tuesday (Nov 5).

site_title: Apps vs alliances: The SEA playbook of rivals Tencent and Ant
summary: Tencent and Ant Group, Chinese fintech giants, are vying for dominance in South-east Asia's fintech market. Tencent's strategy, centered on its messaging platform WeChat, may struggle in the region's interoperable payment networks, while Ant's approach, focusing on partnerships and flexibility, is better suited to the market's needs. Both companies aim to capture a substantial share of the projected $250 trillion in global cross-border payments by 2027. While Tencent's "download-first" model may alienate local users, Ant's partnership-heavy strategy requires balancing local needs with regulatory constraints and growth projections.

images.alt_text: MAS chief Chia Der Jiun says the regulator is  taking “cautious steps”

Singapore-based firms, including gaming chair company Secretlab, smart locks firm IglooCompany, and furniture brand Castlery (above), have made significant investments in the US in recent years and reaped handsome benefits.

site_title: JPMorgan Chase’s Dimon offers a tariff tip as Trump haunts Apec CEO Summit
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon notes that US tariff threats will draw countries to the negotiation table as part of a Trump-backed strategy. Dimon warns that retaliation is possible if the US strengthens itself at the expense of others. The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) CEO Summit in Peru was dominated by discussions of Trump's policies, including new tariff rates, including a 50% levy on Brazil. The summit highlighted the economic implications of Trump's trade policies, with countries seeking options to counter US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Trump has called for lowering the corporate tax rate, which was slashed from 35 per cent to 21 per cent during his first term, to a proposed 15 per cent in his upcoming term.
Trump's tariff fixation partly stems from his belief that America is losing ground in global trade because other countries have much higher tariffs.

site_title: US adds South Korea to foreign-exchange monitoring watchlist
summary: The US Treasury added South Korea to its foreign-exchange monitoring list, along with Japan and Germany, amid rising doubts about the Federal Reserve's interest rate next year. The list aims to monitor currency manipulation that affects US trade. This move comes as the dollar has been climbing due to uncertainties about the Fed's rate decisions. The US Treasury previously designated China as a currency manipulator in 2019, which was dropped after a bilateral trade deal was negotiated.

images.alt_text: The dollar index, which measures the currency against six peers rose 0.38 per cent to 105.83, around its highest since early July.

site_title: En Bloc sales: Address challenges to promote urban renewal
summary: En bloc sales in Singapore can accelerate urban renewal by maximizing land use and revitalizing communities. Despite a healthy pipeline of collective sale launches, interest has shifted towards non-residential sites, driven by growing demand. Measured adjustments to sales proceeds distribution, including financial and regulatory hurdles, can facilitate redevelopment. Addressing contentious issues on en-bloc premiums and apportionment can promote urban renewal and foster a dynamic cityscape.

images.alt_text: The S$810 million offer for Thomson View Condo values the site at S$1,178 psf ppr, after including land betterment charges to intensify the land use and a lease upgrading premium to top up to a fresh 99-year lease.
Core Central Region non-landed home prices have held up, while rising at a slower pace, and median prices have touched new highs.
Generic photo of property landscape

site_title: Japan’s economy slows in Q3 on tepid capex; consumption picks up
summary: Japan's economy expanded by 0.9% in Q3, slower than the previous quarter, due to tepid capital spending. However, stronger-than-expected private consumption supports the central bank's forecast of a solid recovery, driven by higher wages and consumption. This growth is a bright spot amidst concerns of a slowdown in the US and further weakness in China, which could weigh on exports.

images.alt_text: A spike in the price of rice, coupled with the increasing cost of non-ferrous metals, food and oil, pushed up overall wholesale inflation.
Japan’s government plans to submit Bills to fund mass production of next-generation chips, targeting Rapidus and other AI chip suppliers.
Consumer spending, which accounts for more than half the economy, has stayed below pre-pandemic levels.
Wages are key to how soon the Bank of Japan could raise interest rates again.

At the September meeting, the BOJ kept interest rates steady at 0.25 per cent, with Governor Kazuo Ueda signalling it was in no rush to raise borrowing costs further as fears of US recession kept markets jittery and clouded the global economic outlook.
Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, the top bank by assets, said second-quarter profit surged 90 per cent on higher interest rates and the sale of cross-held shares.

site_title: To unlock more global capital, Apac real estate markets need to continue building on transparency
summary: Asia-Pacific's (Apac) real estate markets are poised for a transformative era, with investment volumes surging 82% year-over-year to $38.8 billion in the third quarter of 2024. However, the region still lags behind in transparency, with only 6% of global real estate investment since 2022. To unlock more global capital, Apac must continue building on its transparency, with countries like Singapore, Japan, Australia, and India making significant strides in areas such as sustainability, technology, and data availability. As transparency improves, Apac's economic dynamism and rapidly expanding real estate markets offer a compelling alternative to slower-growing markets, attracting increased international capital and supporting sustainable urban development.

images.alt_text: August saw the closing of a mega S$1.6 billion acquisition by Lendlease and Warburg Pincus, who bought a portfolio of assets comprising business parks and high-tech industrial facilities.
In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.

site_title: China’s asymmetrical tools for new trade war carry global peril
summary: China is expanding its retaliatory tools in case of another trade conflict with the US, potentially wreaking havoc on global commerce and finance. China may consider selling its $734 billion US Treasury holdings, weakening the yuan, restricting critical minerals, targeting US companies, and forming alliances with other nations to counter US policy. These actions could lead to a conflict harder to contain and may not necessarily make China immune from the fallout, given its own economic challenges, including a prolonged property crisis. China's alternatives may exacerbate global tensions and undermine US exporters.

images.alt_text: JD.com said total revenue rose 5.1 per cent to 260.4 billion yuan (S$48.4 billion) in the third quarter.

site_title: Olympics 'above politics' say LA 2028 organisers after Trump win
summary: LA 2028 Olympics organisers say the games will remain "above politics" despite Donald Trump's re-election, with chairman Casey Wasserman stating that the Olympics are about unity, not red or blue. Officials have been in contact with the president-elect's transition team and are confident of working smoothly with the new administration. Despite concerns from Los Angeles city council members about potential restrictions on federal funding, LA28 officials express confidence in continuing a "very good partnership" with federal agencies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The exterior of the Warner Bros. Discovery Atlanta campus is pictured in Atlanta, Georgia, U.S. May 2, 2023.   REUTERS/Alyssa Pointer/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Goodwill Entertainment makes trading debut at S$0.21, 5% above IPO price
summary: Goodwill Entertainment, a karaoke operator, made its trading debut on the Catalist board at S$0.21, 5% above its IPO price of S$0.20 per share. The company raised S$12 million through its IPO, with net proceeds going towards expanding regionally and globally, as well as acquisitions and technology investments. Proceeds will also be used to open a central kitchen and launch craft beers in its microbrewery.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Left: Goodwill Entertainment's live show concept in Bugis. Right: Goodwill Entertainment founder and CEO Flint Lu.
“A lot of existing operators have karaoke rooms only, but we offer multi-entertainment concepts,” said Flint Lu (left), founder, CEO and executive chair of Goodwill Entertainment.

site_title: Sotheby’s settles New York tax fraud case, pays damages
summary: Sotheby's settles a New York tax fraud case by paying $6.25 million and adopting reforms. The settlement resolves claims that the auction house helped at least eight clients cheat the state by using "resale certificates" to avoid sales taxes on art purchases. The New York attorney general accused Sotheby's of intentionally breaking the law, and the company did not admit or deny wrongdoing. The reforms include a new policy on resale certificates and improved employee training.

images.alt_text: A woman wearing an 18th century diamond jewel necklace composed of three rows of diamonds finished with a diamond tassel at each, weighing approximately 300 carats, at a press preview at Sotheby's in Geneva, Switzerland, Nov 7, 2024.

The 2.2 m portrait “A.I. God” by “Ai-Da”, the world’s first ultra-realistic robot artist, smashed pre-sale expectations of US$180,000 when it went under the hammer at London auction house Sotheby’s Digital Art Sale.

Aurélie Vassy, Sotheby’s head of handbag and fashion sales in Europe, holds a Hermès mini Kelly Bags in front of a Claude Monet painting, at the auction house’s new Paris headquarters on Oct 12, 2024.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3,726.33 at open on Friday, as local stocks traded in negative territory amid losses in major markets abroad. Losers outnumbered gainers 66 to 37 in the broader market. Key players included Seatrium down 0.5%, Genting Singapore up 1.3%, and banking stocks such as UOB, DBS, and OCBC trading lower. This follows a similar trend in major US indexes, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite, which closed lower due to Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments on interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Generic of the SGX Centre 1; for use on any SGX related stories.
Therese Soh

site_title: Mean reversion: Has AI abolished gravity for share prices?
summary: US stocks, led by tech giants, have risen 94% over five years to all-time highs. Financial pundits invoke mean reversion, suggesting prices will revert to true value, but experts argue it's impossible to predict when. The S&P 500's price-to-earnings ratio is currently around 38 times, near pandemic-era peaks. Analysts predict earnings will rise, reducing the ratio, but uncertainty and reverse engineering in financial analysis make these projections unreliable. A market crash is likely, but it won't be a "mean reversion event," as true values and underlying factors are constantly changing.

images.alt_text: An AI logo is seen painted on a building like a circuit board in Hangzhou, in China's eastern Zhejiang province on October 30, 2024. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve, testifies at a Senate Judiciary subcommittee hearing on immigration, in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Thursday, April 30, 2009. Greenspan said that illegal immigration makes a "significant" contribution to economic growth by providing a flexible workforce. Photographer: Chris Kleponis/Bloomberg News

site_title: Fed’s Powell says no need to hurry rate cuts with economy strong
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the US economy's recent performance is "remarkably good" and has given central bankers room to lower interest rates at a cautious pace. Powell emphasized the need for a careful approach to future rate reductions, citing uncertainty over the neutral level of rates and the potential impact of fiscal and trade policies. The Fed has shown a willingness to cut rates further if inflation continues to slow, but Powell did not comment on a potential cut at the December meeting, citing the need for assessments of new fiscal and trade policies.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 74.2 points, or 0.17 per cent, at the open to 44,032.38.

site_title: Pathway to power for US Democrats has UK signposts
summary: US Democrats can look to the UK for inspiration as they recover from their presidential election defeat. Historically, the party has rejuvenated itself after major setbacks, as seen in the 1980s after Ronald Reagan and George HW Bush's wins. The UK's Labour Party, led by Tony Blair, also drew from US Democrats following Bill Clinton's 1996 and 1992 wins. This international perspective can help Democrats move forward and regain power, rather than dwelling on past recriminations.

images.alt_text: epa11701727 Supporters gather during a campaign rally hosted by US Vice President and Democrat Party presidential nominee Kamala Harris, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA, 04 November 2024. US Vice President and Democratic Presidential Nominee Kamala Harris is holding an election eve concert and rally in Philadelphia. Election polls show that the presidential race between Harris and Republican nominee former President Donald Trump is extremely close.  EPA-EFE/DAVID MUSE

site_title: India’s top clean energy agency weighs criminal proceedings against Reliance Power
summary: India's Solar Energy Corporation of India (SECI) has sent a notice to Reliance Power, asking why it should not initiate criminal proceedings after the company submitted fake documents for a bid. SECI barred Reliance Power from participating in its clean energy project tenders for three years after finding a fake bank guarantee and its counterfeit endorsement. Reliance Power has lodged a police complaint against the third party that arranged the bank guarantee, amid the company's expansion plans into the domestic and overseas renewable energy sector.

images.alt_text: Anil Ambani, chairman of Reliance Capital Ltd., poses for photographs at the company's annual general meeting in Mumbai, India, on Tuesday, 27 September 2011. Reliance Capital Ltd., an Indian financial services provider, will consider entering the banking industry in India, Ambani told shareholders today. Photographer: Adeel Halim/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** Anil Ambani

site_title: Offer for Broadway Industrial Group turns unconditional
summary: Patec Group has turned its mandatory conditional cash offer to acquire Broadway Industrial Group unconditional, following the acquisition of 197 million shares representing 43.3% of the company's share capital. The offer price remains at S$0.197 in cash per share. As of Nov 14, the total number of shares owned by Patec and its affiliates exceeded 50% of Broadway Industrial's voting rights, triggering the unconditional declaration. The closing date of the offer has been extended to Dec 23.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The offer price is 7.1 per cent higher than the counter's last transacted price of S$0.184 on Oct 25, ahead of the trading halt called for by Broadway Industrial.

site_title: Novo Nordisk is gradually phasing out human insulin pens globally
summary: Novo Nordisk is phasing out human insulin pens globally, replacing them with vials, as the company shifts focus to obesity and diabetes medications delivered in injection pens. The move, driven by booming sales of its new obesity and diabetes medicines, will affect low and middle-income countries where human insulin is commonly used. The company's decision has been criticized by medical charities and advocacy groups, who argue it creates a double standard in diabetes care, with better access to analogue insulin pens for high-income countries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Danish drugmaker Novo Nordisk, Copenhagen, Denmark, September 26, 2023. REUTERS/Tom Little/File Photo

site_title: Real estate owners need to get ahead in the net-zero race. Here’s how
summary: Singapore aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, prompting real estate owners to improve energy efficiency. The country's policies and regulations, such as the Green Mark scheme and carbon tax, encourage sustainable development. The Mandatory Energy Improvement regime, set to kick in in 2025, requires existing buildings to reduce energy consumption to avoid fines. Net-zero buildings offer long-term savings through reduced energy costs and increased asset value. Implementing a road map to net zero requires collaboration from various stakeholders and incorporates sustainability strategies into key performance indicators.

images.alt_text: The Asia Pacific's economic dynamism, coupled with its rapidly expanding and increasingly sophisticated real estate markets, offers a compelling alternative to slower growing, more saturated markets elsewhere.

site_title: A legacy of precision, complexity and art
summary: Vacheron Constantin celebrates 270 years of horological excellence, solidifying its position as a leader in the high art of watchmaking. The brand's legacy is rooted in its mastery of horological complications, with notable creations such as the Les Cabinotiers – The Berkley Grand Complication, boasting 63 complications, and the Métiers d'Art series, featuring exquisite hand-finishing and attention to aesthetic detail. Vacheron Constantin's commitment to innovation and artistry has led to significant advancements in watch production, including the introduction of ultra-thin movements and the creation of ultra-complicated timepieces.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
The roots of Vacheron Constantin’s Fifty-six collection are from the golden age of round elegant timepieces in the 1950s.

site_title: One city, three great artists: Reuniting Leonardo, Michelangelo and Raphael
summary: The Royal Academy in London is hosting an exhibition "Michelangelo, Leonardo, Raphael" that explores the complex relationship between the three artists during the 16th-century Italian Renaissance. The exhibition, which runs until February 16, 2025, showcases their works, including drawings and paintings, to demonstrate the subtle dance of influence between the artists. The show highlights how Michelangelo and Leonardo da Vinci, among others, influenced each other's work, leading to innovative and unique artistic styles. The exhibition also reveals the artists' competitive nature and how it fueled their creativity.

images.alt_text: epa11702593 Royal Academy of Arts staff look over Leonardo da Vinci’s ‘The Virgin and Child with Saint Anne and the Infant Saint John the Baptist (‘The Burlington House Cartoon’) c 1506-08 at the Royal Academy of Arts in London, Britain, 05 November 2024. The exhibit runs from 09 November to 16 February 2025.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Oil settles slightly higher, investors focus on steep draw in fuel stocks
summary: Oil prices closed slightly higher on Thursday, with Brent crude futures rising 28 US cents to $72.56 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising 27 cents to $68.70 a barrel. The gains outweighed concerns about oversupply and demand worries due to a stronger dollar. US fuel stocks fell by 4.4 million barrels, and distillate stockpiles fell by 1.4 million barrels. OPEC cut its forecast for global oil demand growth for this year and next, citing weakness in China and other regions.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up 39 cents, or 0.5 per cent, to US$72.28 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: COP29: Singapore joins EU and China in expanded taxonomy on green financing
summary: Singapore has joined the European Union and China in a new taxonomy on green financing, known as the Multi-Jurisdiction Common Ground Taxonomy (M-CGT), which contains 110 economic activities across eight sectors. The M-CGT aims to improve investor confidence in green financing by establishing a common standard for green activities. The taxonomy is not legally binding, but green bonds and funds that align with its criteria can be considered by cross-border investors. The development of the M-CGT is seen as a milestone in increasing interoperability of different taxonomies and facilitating cross-border green capital flows.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will issue a new category of infrastructure bonds, with the first issuance expected in the fourth quarter of this year.
FILE PHOTO: A view of the Monetary Authority of Singapore's headquarters in Singapore June 28, 2017. Picture taken June 28, 2017. REUTERS/Darren Whiteside/File Photo
Chia Der Jiun, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, speaking at the launch of the Singapore Sustainable Finance Association on January 24, 2024.
Ravi Menon will represent Singapore at international climate action platforms and drive public-private partnerships with local stakeholders.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 jumps as energy and tech lead the charge, positive earnings help
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 1.1% to 507.03 points, driven by strong performances in energy and technology sectors, as well as positive earnings reports. The tech sub-sector gained 3.1% and heavyweight energy stocks advanced 1.7%. Eurozone gross domestic product rose 0.4% in the third quarter, and inflation is on track to reach the ECB's 2% goal. Despite recent gains, European equities remain below last week's levels due to concerns over US tariffs.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.09 per cent lower at 4740.34 points, its lowest level since Aug 13.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, Golden-Agri, ComfortDelGro, Prime US Reit, Cordlife
summary: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, Golden-Agri Resources, ComfortDelGro, Prime US Reit, Cordlife. Key developments include CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's acquisition of a US land parcel for S$94.8 million, Golden-Agri Resources' 18% drop in underlying profit to US$91 million, ComfortDelGro's 15.2% net profit growth to S$57.5 million, Prime US Reit's 42.2% fall in distributable income to US$8.5 million, and Cordlife's S$1.6 million net loss for the quarter.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

site_title: US dollar marches on, Trump trade momentum undimmed
summary: The US dollar surged 0.3% to a one-year high against major peers, fueled by higher yields and President-elect Donald Trump's election victory. The dollar index reached 107, its highest since early November 2023, while the euro slumped to its weakest since November 2023. Higher Treasury yields, inflation, and expected deficit spending are lifting the dollar, with Trump's Republican Party set to control both houses of Congress in January. The benchmark 10-year Treasury yield hit 4.483%, its highest since July.

images.alt_text: The dollar index dipped 0.1 per cent to 105.91, after rising for three straight session.

site_title: Nissan faces record debt bill with 1 year left to fix finances
summary: Nissan faces a record debt bill with a year to fix its finances. The automaker has around $1.6 billion of debt due in 2025, which will increase to $5.6 billion the following year. Despite having sufficient liquidity, Nissan's shares have swung wildly due to concerns about its ability to generate cash and potential debt rating cuts. The company's debt-to-earnings ratio is the highest among Japanese automakers, and its cash flow deficit has raised concerns about its ability to invest in new technologies. A downgrade to junk grade by ratings firms could force Nissan out of investment-grade bond indexes, taking away funds from investors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Nissan booth at the Beijing International Automotive Exhibition, or Auto China 2024, in Beijing, China, April 25, 2024. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
Nissan’s shares climbed as much as 21 per cent on Tuesday (Nov 12) before closing up 13 per cent.

site_title: Reliance, Walt Disney close US$8.5 billion merger of Indian media assets
summary: Reliance Industries and Walt Disney completed a US$8.5 billion merger of their Indian media assets, creating India's largest entertainment player with 120 TV channels and two streaming services. The merged divisions include entertainment, digital, and sports, with separate CEOs for each unit. The deal, which won regulatory approval in August, will compete with Sony, Netflix, and Amazon, and is seen as a significant move in the Indian media landscape.

images.alt_text: Reliance Industries posted a consolidated profit of 165.63 billion rupees (S$2.6 billion) in the quarter ended Sep 30, down 4.8 per cent from a year earlier.
'Deadpool & Wolverine' movie brought in US$1.3 billion at global box offices.
To get the merger over the line, the two companies have offered concessions, including a commitment to not raise advertising rates unreasonably for streamed cricket matches.

site_title: Merck snags Chinese cancer drug for up to US$3.3 billion
summary: Merck & Co has licensed an experimental cancer antibody, LM-299, from LaNova Medicines for up to $3.3 billion. The deal grants Merck exclusive global rights to the bispecific antibody, which targets cancer cells by blocking proteins PD-1 and VEGF. The drug is currently in a phase one trial in China and is expected to close in the fourth quarter. This acquisition bolsters Merck's push into the dual-targeted antibody field, following recent investments in other promising cancer treatments.

images.alt_text: Merck now expects total sales of up to US$64.1 billion for the year, US$300 million less than the top end of the guidance the company provided three months ago.
Merck narrowed expectations for its Life Science business, aiming for annual organic sales growth in a 7-to-9 per cent range from a previously anticipated 7 to 10 per cent.

site_title: Indonesia’s Indosat and GoTo launch local language AI model
summary: Indonesia's Indosat and GoTo launched Sahabat-Al, an open-source large language model ecosystem designed for Bahasa Indonesia and its regional languages. The AI model is built on Nvidia's platform and boasts eight billion and nine billion parameters. The project aims to promote AI sovereignty in Indonesia, enabling the country to harness and control its own data and intelligence. Minister of State-Owned Enterprises Erick Thohir announced plans to expand Indonesia's data centre infrastructure to fuel the growth of the AI industry. The launch aligns with Indonesia's target of achieving 8% economic growth over the next five years.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto, who has said he will pursue a non-aligned foreign policy, posted a video of his call to Donald Trump made after he arrived from China.

site_title: Casual mod-Indian fare at 27 Degrees West
summary: A new restaurant, 27 Degrees West, has opened on Orchard Road in Singapore, offering casual mod-Indian fare. The eatery serves convenient and acceptable dishes with no surprises, including butter chicken, potato aloo dum, and crab thecha thermidor. The restaurant's casual interiors and lunch thali featuring individual dishes from different parts of India are also notable. With a phone number provided, the restaurant is open daily from 12 pm to 11 pm, with extended hours on Fridays and Saturdays.

images.alt_text: Chamoon Hot Pot's upmarket interiors in Scotts Square.

site_title: EU fines Meta 797 million euros over abusive practices benefiting Facebook Marketplace
summary: The European Commission fined Meta Platforms 797.72 million euros (S$1.1 billion) for breaching EU antitrust rules by bundling Facebook Marketplace with its social network Facebook, giving it an unfair advantage. The move comes two years after the commission accused Meta of bundling the services together. Meta will appeal the decision but will comply and work on a solution. The commission found no evidence of harm to competitors and argued that users can choose not to engage with Marketplace.

images.alt_text: Meta, then known as Facebook, overpaid for Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014 to eliminate nascent threats instead of competing on its own in the mobile ecosystem, the FTC claims.
Meta plans to reduce the price of ad-free subscriptions by about 40 per cent for European users.
Meta’s motivation to work with US defence agencies is driven in part by its intention to further establish Llama as a dominant foundation for AI products globally.

site_title: UK government announces ban on new coal mines
summary: The UK government has announced plans to introduce legislation to ban new coal mines, restricting future licensing. Energy Minister Michael Shanks stated that this move will pave the way for a "clean, secure energy system" and create skilled workers. The ban follows Britain's last coal-fired power station's closure in October, making the UK the first G7 country to end its reliance on coal for electricity. The legislation will be unveiled "as soon as possible" to tackle climate change.

images.alt_text: Amin Nasser, President and CEO, Aramco delivers his speech at the Singapore International Energy Week (SIEW) 2024, in the Sands Expo and Convention Centre on Oct 21, 2024.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of Anglo American is seen on a jacket of an employee at the Los Bronces copper mine, in the outskirts of Santiago, Chile March 14, 2019 Picture Taken March 14, 2019. REUTERS/Rodrigo Garrido/File Photo

site_title: US producer inflation edges higher in October
summary: US producer inflation edged higher in October, with the producer price index (PPI) rising 0.2% from September. This follows a 2.4% increase in wholesale prices over the past 12 months. The majority of the increase came from a 0.3% rise in the services index, while final demand goods prices inched up 0.1%. The data could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions, which focus on maintaining maximum sustainable employment.

More than 50 companies set up booths to recruit people from entry-level to management. Open jobs include police officers, food service, security, sales reps, technicians, customer service, IT, teacher assistants, insurance agents, and account executives. site_title: ComfortDelGro Q3 net profit up 15.2% on higher revenue
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-based land transport giant, reported a 15.2% rise in net profit to S$57.5 million for its third quarter ended September 2024, driven by higher revenue in its overseas markets, particularly in the UK and Australia. Revenue rose 18.4% to S$1.2 billion, with public transport and taxi segments contributing to the growth. However, operating costs increased due to the acquisition of A2B Australia, and lower booking volumes under its taxi booking app Zig.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The addition of Addison Lee will extend ComfortDelGro’s London footprint and grow its taxi and private hire network to more than 34,000 vehicles globally.

site_title: LVMH moves Alexandre Arnault to HQ, fueling succession talk
summary: LVMH has appointed Alexandre Arnault, 32, as deputy chief of the company's wines and spirits division, marking a move that fuels speculation about his potential succession to his father, Bernard Arnault. The reshuffle also includes the departure of Chantal Gaemperle, head of human resources and synergies, and the appointment of Maud Alvarez-Pereyre as HR head. The changes come as LVMH struggles with a slowdown in the luxury goods industry, including a 7% decline in organic sales of its wines and spirits division in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: Bernard Arnault’s fortune has been relegated to fifth place on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

Revenue for LVMH was 19.08 billion euros (S$27.2 billion) for the three months ending in September, a 3 per cent fall on an organic basis, stripping out the effect of currencies, acquisitions and divestitures.
The partnership with Formula one, LVMH’s next major push into the sports world after it paid some 150 million euros (S$214 million) to be the premium sponsor of the Paris Olympics, starts in 2025.

site_title: Singapore’s new chapter in the story of transnational commercial justice
summary: Singapore has established itself as a pre-eminent dispute resolution hub for cross-border business, with its international commercial court facilitating transnational trade and investment. The court, part of the Singapore High Court, enables businesses to resolve disputes effectively, even when disputes arise across geopolitical fault lines. This transformation is a result of the court's work and government support, which has ensured the law keeps pace with advancing technology. Singapore's shift to a multipolar world has strengthened its position as a trusted platform for international business dealings.

site_title: SGX RegCo issues trade with caution alert on 9R
summary: SGX RegCo has issued a trade with caution alert on 9R shares due to a high concentration of trades from multiple connected accounts. The shares have surged 48.7% from S$0.039 to S$0.058 between Jun 4 and Aug 14, despite the FTSE Catalist Index's 3.2% decline during the same period. The company announced a loss for the first half of 2024 with negative cash flows, yet its share price remained steady around S$0.058 until Nov 8.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Eurozone employment ticks up, GDP growth figure confirmed
summary: The eurozone economy grew by 0.4% in the third quarter, surpassing expectations, and employment rose 0.2% on the quarter, pushing up the annual growth rate to 1%. This data may ease fears of a recession, despite weak external demand and industry performance. The labour market remains tight, with the unemployment rate holding at a record low 6.3% in September.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 14)
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC marks its 40th anniversary in the US, celebrating a "strong, productive and mutually beneficial partnership" with the country. Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed confidence in the US economy's long-term potential despite increasing challenges. GIC's mission remains unchanged, prioritizing long-term investments amidst a complex geopolitical climate.

site_title: ‘Deadpool & Wolverine’ helps Disney beat earnings forecasts
summary: Walt Disney Co. reported earnings that topped Wall Street's estimates, driven by strong ticket sales from the Marvel film "Deadpool & Wolverine," which brought in $1.3 billion at global box offices. The company projected high single-digit adjusted earnings-per-share growth in fiscal 2025, despite capital expenditures of $8 billion and a decline in operating income at its Experiences and Sports divisions. Disney's streaming services, including Disney+, Hulu, and ESPN+, also delivered profitability for the quarter.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; unemployment rolls shrink
summary: US jobless claims fell to 217,000 for the week ended Nov 9, down 4,000 from the previous week. This marks a reversal of the surge in early October caused by Hurricanes Helene and Milton and a Boeing strike. Historically low layoffs continue to support the economy. Economists predict job growth will regain steam in November, potentially leading to a third interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve next month.

images.alt_text: The so-called core consumer price index – which excludes food and energy costs – increased 0.3 per cent for a third month and 3.3 per cent from a year ago.

site_title: PBOC signals unease with yuan weakness spurred by tariff threat
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) set the yuan's reference rate at 7.1991 per dollar, 445 pips stronger than the average estimate, amid concerns over yuan weakness sparked by a potential US tariff threat. This is the first sign of the authorities showing intolerance of recent dollar/onshore yuan gains. The move aims to deter further yuan weakness, but the "Trump trade momentum" may continue to make the dollar-offshore yuan a better bid on dips.

images.alt_text: The yuan, along with other emerging-market currencies, takes a hard hit as the dollar got bolstered by reflation bets on Wednesday (Nov 6).

site_title: Sri Lanka president expects ‘strong majority’ after snap poll
summary: Sri Lanka's President Anura Kumara Dissanayake expressed confidence of a strong majority in parliament after the snap legislative elections, marking a turning point in the country. Dissanayake took power in September presidential elections, promising to combat graft and recover stolen assets. Two years after an economic meltdown, he aims to press ahead with his platform.

images.alt_text: People gather around readymade clothing stalls to buy clothes ahead of the Sinhala and Tamil New Year festival, in Colombo, Sri Lanka April 11, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte

site_title: NVPC recognises 13 winners at President’s Volunteerism and Philanthropy Awards 2024
summary: The National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) held the 12th edition of the President's Volunteerism and Philanthropy Awards (PVPA) on November 13, recognizing 13 winners across 10 categories for their contributions to the community. The awards, which feature winners from four pillars – City of Good, People of Good, Organisations of Good, and Leaders of Good – aim to inspire more people to engage in volunteerism and philanthropy. Notable winners include Singtel for its inclusivity efforts and Sentosa Development Corporation for its sustainable initiatives, including a carbon-neutral network and accessible tourism programs.

images.alt_text: Singtel's group chief people and sustainability officer Aileen Tan says that the carnival also helps employees understand vulnerable communities better.

President Tharman Shanmugaratnam (right), Jane Ittogi Shanmugaratnam (second from right), Minister for Culture, Community and Youth, Edwin Tong (third from right), awardee Malcolm Chen (second from left) and awardee Mark Yuen (left). Since the awards’ inception in 2012, PVPA has received more than 1,600 nominations and recognised 106 awardees.

site_title: Vietnam’s FPT to receive first large-scale shipment of more than 1,000 Nvidia AI chips in December
summary: Vietnam's FPT will receive its first large-scale shipment of over 1,000 Nvidia AI chips in December, marking a significant step towards providing artificial intelligence cloud services. The shipment includes 127 Nvidia HGX H100 server systems, which will be used to equip FPT's AI facilities in the country. The move is crucial for Vietnam to house more new-generation data centers to serve the increasing deployment of AI infrastructure. FPT's AI factory in Vietnam will be a sovereign cloud based on the Nvidia accelerated computing platform, and the company plans to expand its AI capabilities to other regions, including Taiwan and South Korea.

images.alt_text: FPT, Vietnam’s largest listed tech company, is pushing aggressively into AI and semiconductors to move beyond IT services.
The semiconductor back-end manufacturing sector is currently dominated by China and Taiwan, but Vietnam is among the fastest-growing countries in the US$95 billion segment.
The partnership entails the continuation of operations of VNG's existing 9.6-MW data centre and the establishment of a new facility in Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: Eurozone industrial production falls more than expected in Sep
summary: Eurozone industrial production fell 2% in September, exceeding a 1.4% drop forecast by economists, and marking a further delay in a long-expected recovery. Germany, the bloc's largest economy, suffered the biggest decline, with output down 2.7% from the previous month. The decline, compared to the same month last year, was 2.8%, underperforming economists' expectations. This suggests a more than year-long industrial recession is still deepening, with structural flaws in the eurozone economy hindering a robust recovery.

images.alt_text: Economists have long blamed the debt brake, adopted in 2009, for holding back Germany’s economy, which is expected to shrink this year.

Inflation in the 20 countries sharing the euro currency accelerated to 2 per cent from 1.7 per cent in September mostly on higher food and energy costs, coming above expectations for 1.9 per cent in a Reuters poll of economists.
Gross domestic product in the 20 countries sharing the euro grew by 0.4 per cent in the third quarter from the previous three months, beating expectations for 0.2 per cent.
The overall eurozone economy grew by 0.4 per cent in the third quarter from the previous three months, Eurostat said.

site_title: More Singapore firms saw overseas sales growth in 2024: SBF survey
summary: Nearly 60% of Singapore firms saw overseas sales growth in 2024, up from 57% in the previous year, according to a Singapore Business Federation survey. The top markets of interest for overseas expansion are Vietnam (25%), Indonesia (25%), and Thailand (21%). This growth contributed to 56% of businesses having at least two-fifths of sales from overseas sources, up from 54% in 2023.

site_title: GIC believes in long-term potential of US, even as estimating returns becomes harder: SM Lee
summary: Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong, board chairman of Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, expressed confidence in the long-term potential of the US economy despite estimating returns becoming harder due to a complex geopolitical climate. GIC will continue to invest in climate technology and sustainability, citing opportunities in battery production and school bus electrification. The fund has maintained a strong partnership with the US over the past 40 years, with one-third of its global portfolio currently invested in the country.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong said that the public service has to stay impartial and out of politics.

site_title: Neptune Robotics Adds Singapore to Asia Service Network as Demand for Multi-Port Vessel Cleaning Rises
summary: Neptune Robotics has expanded to Singapore, becoming the first industry player to offer underwater robotic hull cleaning services along the China-Singapore shipping routes, covering more than half of international merchant vessel stops. This move aims to capitalize on rising demand for multi-port vessel cleaning. By entering Singapore, Neptune Robotics strengthens its Asia service network, enhancing its capabilities to support shipowners and operators in the region.

site_title: More Singaporeans invest, but worries persist over overspending, lack of retirement planning: OCBC survey
summary: A survey by OCBC found that more Singaporeans are investing, with 88% of respondents investing, and 26% of their income allocated to investments. However, concerns persist over overspending and lack of retirement planning. Young adults are more likely to overspend, with 27% of those in their 20s doing so. The survey also found that dual-income, no-kids (Dinks) couples are less prepared for retirement, with lower proportions practicing financial virtues and having regular passive income. The Financial Wellness Index score rose by one point to 61 points, in tandem with economic growth.

site_title: Scam syndicates sending foreigners to Singapore to cheat retailers like Apple Store, Best Denki
summary: Scam syndicates are sending foreigners to Singapore to commit credit card fraud, targeting retailers like Apple Store and Best Denki. Victims are recruited via social messaging platforms and then instructed to use a mobile app to make contactless payments for high-value items, which are then sold for cash. Since November 4, at least 10 victims have reported losses of over S$100,000, with the police arresting several suspects and seizing stolen goods. Retailers are warned to be vigilant for suspicious customers making multiple contactless payments, and the police advise them to report any suspicious activities promptly.

site_title: Diabetic Singaporeans not managing the disease as well as they think
summary: A recent survey in Singapore reveals a concerning gap between how diabetic patients think they manage their condition and their actual management. Despite 65% claiming to manage diabetes well, 60% have blood sugar levels above 7%, associated with a higher risk of complications. Nearly all (97%) who claim to manage well also report taking medication regularly. The survey highlights the need for better education on the impact of food, medication, and exercise on diabetes management.

images.alt_text: Diabetes is a treatable condition, but many are unaware they have the disease.

site_title: Australia's Woolworths, Coles face class action over dodgy discount claims
summary: Australia's top supermarkets, Woolworths and Coles, face a class action lawsuit alleging misleading discount claims on everyday products. The lawsuit, launched by Gerard Malouf & Partners, claims the retailers promoted illusory discounted pricing, with customers potentially entitled to up to A$1,300 in refunds. The class action aims to recover the price difference between the alleged discounted prices and the original prices, which were subject to price hikes. The lawsuit tightens pressure on the sector reeling from a cost-of-living crisis.
