site_title: More than just putting food on the table
summary: FairPrice Group launched A Full Plate, Singapore's largest food donation drive, to support underprivileged individuals and families in need of nutritious food. The initiative aims to raise S$1 million and provide groceries and hot meals to over 600,000 beneficiaries. The company's Start Strong, Stay Strong programme also teaches preschool children about nutrition and food circularity, while other initiatives like the Cheers Breakfast Club and IMperfect Fellas promote healthy eating and reduce food waste. The goal is to empower Singaporeans with access to nutritious food and make every day a little better for those they serve.

site_title: Vodafone back in profit as nears UK merger with Three
summary: Vodafone reported a net profit of nearly 1.1 billion euros (S$1.6 billion) in the six months to the end of September, reversing a loss of 346 million euros from the same period last year. The company is nearing a merger with Three, its UK operations rival, as it returns to profit.

site_title: Apple gets EU warning to stop geo-blocking on app, iTunes Stores
summary: The European Commission has warned Apple to stop geo-blocking on its App Store, iTunes Store, and other media services, potentially violating consumer protection rules. Apple's geo-blocking practices unlawfully discriminate against European customers based on their place of residence, blocking users from downloading apps and using payment cards issued in other countries. Apple has one month to respond to the findings and propose remedies. This comes after the company faced its first-ever fine under the Digital Markets Act for failing to allow app developers to steer users to cheaper deals.

images.alt_text: The move follows a warning to Apple in June that it must give developers effective means to steer users away from its App Store or face future penalties.

site_title: Aga Khan emerald fetches record US$9 million in Geneva auction
summary: A 37-carat square emerald, once owned by the Aga Khan, sold for nearly US$9 million at a Christie's auction in Geneva, setting a new record for the world's most expensive green stone. The emerald, created by Cartier in 1960, was originally commissioned as a brooch for British socialite Nina Dyer and later auctioned off to raise money for animals. The sale surpassed the previous record held by a Bulgari emerald, previously owned by Elizabeth Taylor. The rare emerald is expected to resurface only once every five or six years.

site_title: US oil industry urges Trump to ditch Biden climate policies
summary: The US oil industry has urged President-elect Donald Trump to scrap many of President Joe Biden's climate policies, citing threats to jobs, consumer choice, and energy security. The American Petroleum Institute, the nation's top oil and gas trade group, has requested Trump's administration to repeal vehicle emissions standards, lift a pause on liquefied natural gas export permits, and work to repeal a methane emissions fee from drilling operations. The group made these requests in a policy document shared with the media.

site_title: Daim Zainuddin: 1938 - 2024
summary: Former Malaysian finance minister Daim Zainuddin, 86, died on November 13, 2024, after being admitted to hospital in October. Daim served as finance minister twice, from 1984 to 1991 and 1998 to 2001, and was credited with steering Malaysia out of recessions during his tenure. A lifelong scholar, he obtained a PhD from Universiti Malaya in 2019. Daim's close relationship with former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and his criticism of Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim contributed to Anwar's sacking in 1998. Daim's wealth was estimated to be substantial, with interests in various public-listed companies and a seized tower in Kuala Lumpur.

images.alt_text: Mahathir Mohamad on Nov. 1. Photographer: Sanjit Das/Bloomberg
Daim Zainuddin served as Malaysia's finance minister from 1984 to 1991 and from 1999 to 2001 under former premier Mahathir Mohamad.

site_title: Keppel Reit prices A$50 million floating rate green notes due 2027
summary: Keppel Reit priced A$50 million floating rate green notes due 2027, with net proceeds to be used for refinancing projects meeting its green financing framework criteria. The Series 008 Notes will bear interest at a floating rate based on the Bank Bill Swap reference rate plus an agreed spread, payable quarterly. The notes are expected to be issued on Nov 19 and mature the same day in 2027.

site_title: US election points to growing public alienation
summary: The 2024 US presidential election saw a record 40% of eligible voters not participating, with "Did Not Vote" accounting for a larger share than Donald Trump's and Kamala Harris's individual votes. This trend is part of a growing public alienation, with dissatisfaction with dominant parties and lack of confidence in third-party alternatives. The decline in turnout, particularly among young voters and low-wage Americans, may be attributed to issues such as inflation and policy towards the Palestinians. The election highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of US society's divisions, moving beyond a two-party system, and engaging with disenchanted voters to revitalize democratic life.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s divestments could help it buffer against higher-for-longer interest rate scenario
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust (Clas) has announced several divestments, including the sale of Citadines Mount Sophia Singapore and Citadines Karasuma-Gojo Kyoto, to unlock S$500 million in value and maintain a strong position against higher interest rates. The proceeds from the sale of Citadines Mount Sophia Singapore will be used to acquire lyf Funan Singapore at a lower entry yield of 4.7% compared to Citadines Mount Sophia's 3.2%. Clas' divestments are part of its long-term strategy to focus on higher-yielding acquisitions, and the trust is expected to continue its portfolio reconstitution strategy in a hot market for hospitality assets.

Standard at Columbia, an asset in CapitaLand Ascott Trust's US portfolio. Its managers expect the US market to be supported by limited new supply of hotel rooms going forward.

site_title: Europe: China jitters, earnings drag Stoxx 600 to three-month low
summary: Europe's main index, the Stoxx 600, plummeted 2% to a near three-month low on Tuesday, weighed down by concerns over US-China relations and downbeat earnings. The decline follows a 1% jump on Monday. China-related assets struggled globally, with metal prices and luxury firms hit hard. Earnings reports from companies like Bayer and Brenntag also contributed to the decline, while some sectors, such as technology and healthcare, fared better.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.9 per cent to 43,910.98 while the broad-based S&P 500 slipped 0.3 per cent to 5,983.99 on Tuesday.

site_title: BT Branded Podcasts: Asian wealth management - succession planning strategies
summary: BT Branded Podcasts released a podcast on Asian wealth management focusing on succession planning strategies. The podcast aims to provide general information only and does not accept liability for any loss arising from reliance on it. Experts and financial institutions like UOB are featured, emphasizing the importance of seeking professional advice for independent guidance. The podcast is available on various platforms, including Telegram, and covers topics such as market trends, financial products, and investment strategies. It is designed to educate and inform listeners on wealth management and succession planning.

site_title: Boustead Singapore posts 34% higher H1 profit of S$36 million
summary: Boustead Singapore reported a 34% increase in net profit to S$36 million for the first half of FY2025, driven by higher gross profit and interest income. Revenue declined 20% year-over-year to S$295.2 million. The company attributed the earnings boost to a reversal of impairment loss and higher interest income, despite larger overhead expenses.

site_title: Amazon offers free computing power to AI researchers, aiming to challenge Nvidia
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) is offering free computing power to researchers using its Trainium chip, a custom artificial intelligence chip, to challenge Nvidia's popularity among AI developers. The move aims to attract large customers who use rented computing power and make small tweaks that can add up to significant gains. AWS plans to make 40,000 first-generation Trainium chips available and will offer credits valued at $110 million to researchers. The company hopes to gain attention for its AI chips by providing direct programming access, unlike Nvidia's approach using Cuda software.

summary: Cortina's net profit for the first half of 2025 fell 10% to S$27.8 million, driven by higher operating expenses that outpaced revenue growth of 5.5%. The luxury watch retailer attributes the costs to the expansion of new stores. Despite this, Cortina expects to remain profitable in the coming year, barring unforeseen circumstances. Competitor The Hour Glass also reported a 20% decrease in earnings for the same period.

site_title: Man Group plans job cuts as it reviews budget, talent needs
summary: Man Group, the world's largest publicly traded hedge fund, plans job cuts in low single-digit percentage terms as it reviews its staffing needs and annual budget. The cuts will mainly focus on operations, middle office, and technology roles. The firm's headcount has grown to 1,787 full-time employees, up from 1,274 five years ago, but still expects to continue growing its staff numbers. The move comes as the firm faces a challenging market for asset gathering, with investors focusing on costs and reassessing their allocations.

site_title: COP29: EDB launches grant to support early-stage carbon projects
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) has launched a grant scheme to support early-stage carbon projects generating Article 6-aligned carbon credits. Established carbon project developers with success in developing high-quality projects are eligible to apply, with the goal of addressing financing gaps and spurring project development and investment. The grant will provide support for feasibility studies, including carbon stock assessments and financial analysis. The pilot phase aims to catalyze growth in Singapore's carbon services and trading ecosystem, developing a supply of high-quality carbon credits to support the city-state's climate ambitions.

site_title: US dollar roars with Bitcoin as Trump trades shine; euro and yuan slump
summary: The US dollar rose to a four-month peak against major peers, reaching 105.83, driven by investor optimism over the incoming Trump administration. Bitcoin extended its record rally, reaching a new all-time peak of $89,982. The euro and yuan slumped to seven-month and three-month lows, respectively, amid concerns over potential Trump tariffs on Europe and China. The dollar index's rise was attributed to a "regulatory tailwind zone" under Trump, with a pro-crypto SEC and hawkish foreign policy officials expected to shape the regulatory environment.

site_title: What will Trump’s victory mean for the climate?
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's victory is expected to harm the US climate and environmental policies, particularly in the electric vehicle (EV) and renewable energy sectors. Trump plans to eliminate tailpipe-emissions rules on "day one," but EVs have proven to be more efficient and environmentally friendly. Trump's policies will likely harm US competitiveness, as China and other countries continue to lead the green industrial expansion. The Trump administration's efforts to halt the low-carbon transition may be futile, and the US will likely lag behind other countries in the adoption of clean technologies.

The trade-weighted US dollar index reached its highest since Jul 2, up 4.9% in the fourth quarter. Regional indices, including Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi, also fell. site_title: Netflix’s ad-supported tier hits 70 million users
summary: Netflix's ad-supported tier has reached 70 million monthly active users globally, nearly doubling from six months earlier, as customers seek more affordable options. The plan, priced at US$6.99 per month, now accounts for more than half of all new sign-ups in regions where it's available, surpassing the cheapest plan without commercials.

site_title: Driver kills 35 people in ramming attack on crowd in China
summary: A 62-year-old Chinese driver, upset over his divorce settlement, rammed his car into a crowd at a sports centre in Zhuhai, killing 35 people and injuring 43. Authorities initially delayed disclosing the incident, sparking outrage on social media. The driver, Fan, was captured and hospitalized for self-inflicted wounds. Police say the attack was unrelated to the nearby airshow. President Xi Jinping has demanded severe punishment for the perpetrator, amid concerns about violent crime in China.

site_title: Nissan surges most since 2009 after activist Effissimo takes 2.5% stake
summary: Nissan shares surged 13% on Tuesday, the largest gain in 15 years, after activist investor Effissimo Capital Management took a 2.5% stake in the Japanese automaker. Effissimo, managed by Yoshiaki Murakami's disciples, has a history of shaking up companies like Toshiba, which led to CEO resignation in 2021. Nissan's shares have plummeted since announcing job cuts and production capacity reductions, but the activist investor's involvement has sparked speculation of structural reforms.

site_title: US companies storm debt markets after risk premiums plunge
summary: Companies across the US are flooding the debt market after risk premiums plummeted following the US presidential election and Federal Reserve meeting. Banks, including Citi and Goldman Sachs, are selling investment-grade bonds, with 13 firms issuing deals on Tuesday, the busiest day since September 4. High-yield companies, such as Trans-Oil Group and Xenia Hotels, are also launching sales. Borrowers are taking advantage of low borrowing costs, with average US high-grade bond spreads at 74 basis points, the lowest level since 1998, and junk yields at 7.12%.

site_title: Shopify delivers upbeat holiday forecast as AI draws customers, shares surge
summary: Shopify delivered an upbeat holiday forecast, with gross merchandise volume (GMV) jumping 24% to $69.72 billion in the July-to-September period. The company's focus on AI-powered tools attracted more merchants ahead of the holiday season, sending shares up 25%. Shopify topped market expectations for third-quarter revenue, with projected fourth-quarter sales growth above estimates, and its shares reached their highest levels in nearly three years.

images.alt_text: Shopify built its business by making it easy for small businesses to quickly set up online stores.
As part of the agreement, PayPal’s wallet will also integrate with Shopify Payments.
Shopify reported a 21 per cent jump in second-quarter revenue to US$2.05 billion, compared with analysts’ average estimate of US$2.01 billion.

site_title: Investment implications of AI’s huge appetite for energy
summary: Big Tech companies are investing heavily in nuclear, solar, and wind power to meet the increasing demand for electricity driven by the growing use of artificial intelligence (AI). The US Department of Energy estimates that data centres will consume 4.6-9.1% of US electricity generation by 2030. In response, companies like Amazon, Google, and Microsoft are partnering with nuclear power operators to build new nuclear reactors and restart existing ones to power their data centres. This shift is expected to benefit independent power producers, nuclear power operators, and companies involved in data centre infrastructure.

site_title: Sea stays above water, posts US$153.3 million Q3 profit
summary: Sea, a gaming and e-commerce company, reported its second consecutive profitable quarter in Q3 2024, with a net profit of US$153.3 million, beating analyst estimates of US$128.6 million. Revenue rose 30.8% to US$4.3 billion, reversing a US$144 million loss in the same quarter last year. Sea's chairman and CEO Forrest Li attributed the improvement to "improved profitability while getting back to high growth."

site_title: Singapore to introduce stockpiling framework, tougher penalties for food safety breaches
summary: Singapore is introducing a stockpiling framework and tougher penalties for food safety breaches under the new Food Safety and Security Bill, which aims to strengthen the country's food safety regime and measures to improve food security. The bill introduces a minimum stockholding requirement, extends food safety legislation to cover donations and free distribution, and raises maximum penalties for non-compliance. Local farms will also need to develop farm management plans to mitigate risks to food safety. The bill is expected to be debated in Parliament in January.

site_title: Saudi Arabia kicks off carbon trading to unlock financing
summary: Saudi Arabia has launched its Regional Voluntary Carbon Market exchange, starting with the auction of over 2.5 million tonnes of carbon credits. The platform aims to fund climate projects globally and support Saudi Arabia's net-zero goals, following guidelines from the Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market. The credits will be generated from renewable energy projects and clean cooking stoves, excluding those from polluters. The platform is targeting to become one of the largest voluntary carbon markets in the world by 2030.

site_title: Vietnam parliament sets 6.5%-7% GDP growth target for 2025
summary: Vietnam's parliament set a 6.5-7% GDP growth target for 2025, above this year's 6-6.5% target. The country aims to keep inflation at 4.5% in 2025. This annual target, similar to China's, reflects the government's economic goals. Vietnam also expressed a desire to exceed its growth target of 7-7.5% for 2025, indicating confidence in the country's economic prospects.

site_title: Opec again cuts 2024, 2025 oil demand growth forecasts
summary: OPEC has cut its forecast for global oil demand growth in 2024 and 2025, citing weaker growth in China, India, and other regions. The producer group now expects a 1.82 million barrels per day increase in 2024, down from 1.93 million bpd forecast last month. OPEC also lowered its 2025 demand growth estimate to 1.54 million bpd from 1.64 million bpd. The revisions reflect the challenge facing OPEC+, which is facing a backdrop of falling prices and a slowdown in global demand.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, November 12, 2024
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, with a focus on China amid US President Donald Trump's team selection. The Thai baht lagged behind peers due to concerns over central bank autonomy. site_title: More Singapore Savings Bonds, T-Bills to be issued as government raises borrowing limit to S$1.515 trillion
summary: Singapore's government has raised its borrowing limit to S$1.515 trillion, from S$1.065 trillion, to fund its debt needs. The increase is expected to last until 2029, with over 60% of the S$450 billion increase going towards meeting the investment needs of the Central Provident Fund (CPF). The move aims to support the growth of the corporate and retail debt market, as well as meet demand for high-quality liquid assets from financial institutions.

site_title: Why I go light on insurance
summary: A Singaporean writer, Leslie Yee, shares her decision to forego buying insurance policies, instead opting to save and invest for a nest egg. She believes that focusing on physical and mental health, staying economically active, and building financial reserves can provide adequate protection against unforeseen events. Yee notes that insurance premiums can be prohibitively high and that public hospitals are well-equipped and staffed, offering high-quality care. She advocates for a more frugal approach to managing personal finances, mirroring Singapore's approach to building financial reserves.

site_title: US small-business optimism rose in the weeks before the election
summary: US small-business optimism rose in October, with the National Federation of Independent Business sentiment index reaching 93.7, the highest reading since early 2022. The index rose 2.2 points, driven by a seven-point improvement in outlook for business conditions. Businesses cited inflation and labor quality as top problems, but reported fewer job vacancies, with 46% finding qualified applicants. The trend may ease with lower corporate tax rates proposed by Trump. This marks the smallest share seeing lower sales in almost a year.

The company reported a net loss of about 4.2 billion euros in the third quarter, with write-downs on assets also affecting earnings. Despite this, Bayer confirmed its 2024 sales targets and lowered its outlook for operating earnings to between 10.4 billion and 10.7 billion euros.

site_title: Misinformation decided the US election
summary: A Reuters/Ipsos poll found that Donald Trump's supporters were deeply misinformed about key issues such as violent crime rates, inflation, the stock market, and border crossings. Those who were misinformed broke for Trump by significant margins, while those who understood the facts favored Kamala Harris. The article suggests that Trump's supporters may be genuinely fearful for the country's future, but the widespread misinformation could be attributed to bad actors exploiting a broken information ecosystem.

site_title: India’s retail inflation surges to 14-month high in October as vegetable prices soar
summary: India's retail inflation surged to a 14-month high in October, reaching 6.21%, driven by a jump in vegetable prices. This exceeds the central bank's tolerance band for the first time in over a year and dashes hopes of an interest rate cut next month. Rising food prices have reduced purchasing power, affecting corporate earnings and growth in the country. The Reserve Bank of India is likely to delay an interest rate cut despite changing its monetary policy stance to 'neutral' from 'withdrawal of accommodation'.

site_title: Germany set for Feb 23 election: sources
summary: Germany is set to hold fresh elections on February 23, 11 weeks after Chancellor Olaf Scholz's governing coalition collapsed. The elections are aimed at securing enough opposition support to pass laws protecting the Constitutional Court from the far-right and funding Ukraine before Scholz's departure. A compromise has been reached on the election timing, with sources indicating the confidence vote could come in mid-December, allowing Scholz to pass key legislation. The elections come amid an economic crisis and new diplomatic challenges following Donald Trump's US election victory.

site_title: Investors yank cash from China ETFs following Trump victory
summary: US investors pulled $315 million from the iShares China Large-Cap ETF (FXI) and $280 million from the iShares MSCI China ETF (MCHI) last week, extending a four-week streak of withdrawals following Trump's election victory. The outflows were driven by concerns over potential tougher tariffs and stimulus measures that failed to reassure investors about China's ability to weather the coming storm. Other emerging-market funds also took a hit, with the iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ex China ETF recording its largest loss on record.

summary: Singapore has committed US$500 million as concessional capital to support the Financing Asia’s Transition Partnership (Fast-P) initiative, a blended-finance program aimed at accelerating Asia's green transition. The government will match dollar-for-dollar the concessional capital raised by other partners, potentially reaching a total of US$1 billion. This move is part of the country's voluntary commitment to climate finance, and it aims to crowd in commercial capital and other sources of finance to support Asia's transition to a low-carbon economy.

summary: DBS Foundation's inaugural Impact Beyond Summit highlighted Singapore's ageing society, shifting the narrative from intervention to preparation and prevention in healthcare efforts. The foundation announced a deployment of S$88 million to new initiatives, focusing on vulnerable communities and improving the "living spans" of low-income and underprivileged individuals. The initiatives aim to enhance access to essential needs, foster inclusion, and promote financial resilience through financial literacy programs and upskilling. The summit also explored the role of technology in ageing, with experts discussing the potential of AI to improve healthspan and enhance care services.

site_title: Millions of German metalworkers win hefty pay hikes
summary: Nearly 4 million German workers in the electrical and metalworking sectors will receive a 5.5% pay increase over two years, averting fresh strikes. The agreement, reached after 18 hours of talks, was struck by the IG Metall union with employers at a time when Germany is struggling economically and is set to hold early elections next year. The deal aims to mitigate worker discontent and avert potential labor disruptions, providing a boost to the country's ailing economy.

summary: The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has fined Metro Bank £16 million for failing to adequately monitor over 60 million transactions (£51 billion) for money laundering risks between 2016 and 2020. The bank's automated system failed to work, leaving a gap in its defense against financial crimes. Since identifying the issues, Metro Bank has remediated the flaws. The bank's performance forecasts for the year remain intact, despite the fine.

The move aims to overhaul the country's multi-billion-dollar state-owned assets, but experts warn that transparency and insulation from political influence are crucial to its success, citing the 1MDB scandal in Malaysia as a cautionary tale. summary: China's two biggest e-commerce players, Alibaba and JD.com, reported robust growth during Singles' Day, despite concerns about consumer malaise in the country's economy. Alibaba saw a 50% increase in paid 88VIP members, JD reported a 20% increase in customers, and Xiaomi set a record for total sales at 31.9 billion yuan. site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 12)
summary: Singapore is introducing legislation to entrench anti-discrimination in the workplace, three years after a promise made by then-prime minister Lee Hsien Loong. The proposed law would prohibit adverse employment decisions based on five sets of protected characteristics, including race, gender, age, disability, and sexual orientation. If passed, the law would introduce penalties for non-compliance and aim to establish non-discriminatory workplace norms.

site_title: Vietnam’s Vingroup and its founder pledge 85 trillion dong in funding to VinFast
summary: Vietnam's Vingroup and its founder, Pham Nhat Vuong, pledged 85 trillion dong (approximately $3.7 billion) in funding to VinFast, the company's loss-making electric vehicle unit. The move aims to reduce VinFast's reliance on external capital for growth, providing the necessary financial resources for sustainable growth.

site_title: German investor morale falls, rattled by Trump and coalition collapse
summary: German investor morale declined to 7.4 points in November, down from 13.1 points in October, according to the ZEW institute. The decline was attributed to uncertainty caused by Donald Trump's US election win and the collapse of Chancellor Olaf Scholz's government. Analysts had expected a reading of 13. This decline in sentiment index and economic assessment worsened to minus 91.4 points in November from minus 86.9 the previous month. The collapse of the government and Trump's election raise concerns for Germany's economy, which has been skirting recession.

site_title: The Hour Glass posts 20% fall in earnings for H1 2025 to S$61.4 million
summary: The Hour Glass, a luxury watch retailer, reported a 20% decline in earnings to S$61.4 million for the first half of FY2025, and a 3% drop in revenue to S$540.3 million. Higher operating expenses, driven by increased advertising and promotional activities, and depreciation of assets, negatively impacted profitability. Despite the challenging luxury watch market due to macroeconomic uncertainties and geopolitical tensions, the company expects to remain profitable for FY2025 and declared an interim dividend of S$0.02 per share.

site_title: Not the ‘right solution’ to mandate full portability for IP insurance: Minister of State Rahayu
summary: Minister of State for Health Rahayu Mahzam stated that mandating full portability for Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) is not a suitable solution for policyholders. She cited that full portability is not an international best practice and that countries implementing portability typically establish a risk equalisation fund, requiring significant national resources. Policyholders unhappy with changes in coverage terms, facing claim difficulties, or struggling to afford premiums are the main drivers for portability. The government will instead ensure MediShield Life covers policyholders with pre-existing conditions.

site_title: UK grocery inflation edges higher again: Kantar
summary: UK grocery price inflation rose to 2.3% in the four weeks to Nov 3, up from 2% in the previous period, according to Kantar data. Sales increased 2% year-on-year to £11.6 billion. Prices are rising fastest in chilled soft drinks and chocolate, while falling in items like toothbrushes and sparkling wine. UK supermarkets warn tax rises will be inflationary, following the recent government budget.

site_title: AstraZeneca lifts 2024 revenue and profit forecast after Q3 beat
summary: AstraZeneca has lifted its 2024 revenue and profit forecast for the second time in less than four months, driven by resilient demand for its cancer and rare diseases medicines. The company reported core earnings per share of US$2.08 on total revenue of US$13.57 billion for the third quarter, beating analyst estimates. AstraZeneca also announced a US$3.5 billion investment in its US research and manufacturing footprint by 2026, including expansions in Maryland, Texas, and California. The company's shares rose 2% after the announcement, despite recent market unease over its business in China amid investigations.

summary: Baidu unveiled new AI applications, including a text-to-image generator and a no-code app builder, at its annual conference. site_title: Saudi Arabia needs to build 115,000 homes a year to hit demand
summary: Saudi Arabia needs to build 115,000 homes annually for the next six years to meet demand from a young population and reach a 70% homeownership rate by 2030, according to Knight Frank. The country's housing demand is driven by a growing population, with 45% of citizens under 20, and rising household formation. To achieve its target, the government will need to increase housing supply significantly, with the National Housing Company aiming to build 200,000 homes by 2025.

summary: Saxo Singapore appoints Mahesh Sethuraman as its new CEO, aiming to drive the next phase of growth for the firm. site_title: China plans to slash homebuying taxes in fiscal stimulus push

This move is part of the government's fiscal stimulus push, following a 10 trillion yuan debt swap for local governments. Economists call for more support to meet China's 5% economic growth target, which President Xi Jinping reiterated. The plan aims to reignite investor expectations for large-scale stimulus to boost domestic demand and combat deflation.

summary: Gold hovered near a one-month low at $2,622.89 per ounce as investors awaited US economic data and Federal Reserve comments on interest rates. site_title: China urges lifting domestic demand with new Trump term in sight
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission urged the government to bolster domestic demand, citing the need to strengthen the economy amid external shocks and uncertainty over US President-elect Donald Trump's second term. The move comes as China's economy faces challenges, including a sluggish domestic consumption and reliance on exports. The commission emphasized the importance of technological self-reliance and supply chain resilience to boost the economy, and predicted that domestic demand will dominate the economy cycle in the coming period.

site_title: OpenAI and rivals seek new path to smarter AI as current methods hit limitations
summary: Artificial intelligence companies, including OpenAI, are shifting away from the "bigger is better" approach to large language models, which has plateaued in recent years. Instead, researchers are exploring alternative techniques, such as "test-time compute," that enhance existing models during inference. This approach allows models to dedicate more processing power to challenging tasks and could lead to breakthroughs in human-like reasoning and decision-making. Companies like OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google DeepMind are working on these new techniques, which could reshape the AI arms race and alter the competitive landscape for AI hardware.

site_title: Bankers see Asia deal drought easing as Hong Kong IPOs pick up
summary: Bankers in Asia are seeing signs of a recovery in initial public offerings (IPOs) with Hong Kong IPOs raising about $9 billion this year, a significant increase from 2023. China is gaining renewed focus from global investors, and India and Japan also have solid pipelines. Despite risks such as volatile markets and regulatory hurdles, dealmakers are optimistic that next year will see an improvement in IPOs, driven by China's economic stimulus and growing demand from investors.

site_title: UK regular pay grows at slowest pace in two years, pointing to lower inflation
summary: UK average weekly earnings excluding bonuses rose 4.8% in the three months to September, the slowest pace in over two years, suggesting inflation pressures may ease. site_title: Median rentals, volume of caveated deals for shophouses dip in Q3: Huttons Asia

site_title: Locals move to protect Chile’s giant desert geoglyphs scarred by off-roaders
summary: Chile's giant desert geoglyphs, over 1,000 years old, are being permanently damaged by off-road vehicles. The site, once a bustling area for trade and commerce, has been scarred by motorcycle and off-road vehicle tracks. Local residents and authorities are working together to preserve the site without restoring it to its former glory, to serve as an example of what not to do with heritage sites. The goal is to stop further damage and raise awareness of the site's importance to future generations. Physical barriers may be needed to protect the ancient geoglyphs.

site_title: Vatican unveils AI services for St Peter’s Basilica ahead of Jubilee
summary: The Vatican has unveiled AI services for St Peter's Basilica ahead of the 2025 Jubilee celebrations. The new experiences include a virtual tour of the basilica's Renaissance-era architectural treasures and enhanced tours for visitors. A 3D model of the basilica was created using drones, cameras, and lasers, with AI algorithms piecing together the data. The digital replica and exhibitions are available on a new interactive website, aiming to broaden access to knowledge and preserve the site for future generations. The project was developed with tech firm Microsoft and Iconem, and Pope Francis emphasized the importance of using AI ethically.

site_title: Shell wins appeal against landmark Dutch climate ruling
summary: Shell has won an appeal against a landmark climate ruling in the Netherlands, which ordered the oil and gas company to cut its absolute carbon emissions by 45% by 2030. The appeals court dismissed the ruling, stating that it was unclear if demands on Shell to reduce emissions caused by its products would help the fight against climate change. The court ruled that Shell has a responsibility to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, but did not set a specific target. Shell's CEO welcomed the decision, saying it was "the right one for the global energy transition."

summary: Nestle and Procter & Gamble (P&G) are investigating palm oil sourcing after a green group, Rainforest Action Network (RAN), reported that palm oil from an illegally cleared wildlife reserve in Indonesia may have entered their supply chains. The reserve, home to endangered species, has lost 2,609 hectares of forest since 2016, with palm trees growing on 645 hectares. Both companies have suspended sourcing from mills accused of deforestation, with Nestle saying 96% of its palm oil supply was "deforestation-free" by the end of 2023.

site_title: Strengthening governance to unlock the potential of carbon markets
summary: A new meta-standards framework has emerged to strengthen governance in the voluntary carbon market, aiming to address environmental integrity concerns and "greenshaming" practices. Independent governance bodies, such as the Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market, are setting quality standards for carbon credits. Regulatory oversight, like that by the Commodities and Futures Trading Commission, is also being introduced. The convergence of voluntary and compliance carbon markets may help harmonize standards and reporting requirements, but policymakers must strike a balance between oversight and encouraging innovation and ambition.

summary: Thailand's baht has declined over 7% this quarter, the worst performance in Asia, amid concerns over the central bank's autonomy. images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 1.1 per cent higher on Monday, with most sectors and regional bourses ending in positive territory.

site_title: Intudo raises US$125 million across two funds, notable investors include Black Kite Capital
summary: Intudo, a venture capital firm focused on Indonesia, has raised US$125 million across two funds. The firm's assets under management now exceed US$350 million. Intudo Ventures IV will invest in Indonesian startups with defensive moats, while a natural resources and renewable energy fund aims to onshore supply chains in Indonesia. Notable investors include Black Kite Capital and Orient Growth Ventures. Intudo's founding partners believe Indonesia can create outsized value for investors and businesses by focusing on its strengths.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Singapore High Court orders winding-up of embattled Qoo10; liquidators appointed
summary: The Singapore High Court has ordered the winding-up of Qoo10, an online marketplace, due to nearly 76 billion won (S$72.4 million) in unpaid debt. Korea Culture Promotion (KCP), which operates culture portal sites and issues culture gift certificates in South Korea, sought to wind up Qoo10 over unpaid debt. The court appointed liquidators from AAG Corporate Advisory to manage Qoo10's affairs. This decision comes after Qoo10's subsidiaries filed for corporate rehabilitation in the Seoul Bankruptcy Court and MAS suspended Qoo10's payment services in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The company will be allowed to make payments to fulfil outstanding claims, but cannot take on new payment obligations, said MAS.
The police said on Sep 12 that reports were lodged against Qoo10 and Qxpress and that they are investigating.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CICT, FHT, Riverstone, Food Empire, Lendlease Global Reit
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust divested 21 Collyer Quay for S$688 million, with net proceeds to be used for debt repayment, capital expenditure financing, and investments. Frasers Hospitality Trust reported lower income available for distribution due to higher finance costs and tax expenses. Food Empire's revenue rose 11.4% year-on-year, while Riverstone Holdings' net profit increased 21.8%. Lendlease Global Reit's committed portfolio occupancy rose to 89.5%, while Asian Pay TV Trust's profit fell 36.4% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
CMG20240409-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / 拍Capitaland外观 [Amoy St]
Singapore stocks rise despite tepid regional sentiment; STI up 0.4%

site_title: New Zealand’s sputtering economy highlighted by concrete slump
summary: New Zealand's economy is experiencing a slowdown, with a 9.3% drop in concrete production to its lowest level in nine years. This decline is contributing to signs of economic stagnation and a possible second recession in less than two years. Home-building approvals have also plummeted to an almost six-year low, and most firms in the building industry expect profits to fall due to reduced demand. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to cut interest rates to ease the economic contraction.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign for New Zealand's Fletcher Building Ltd adorns a crane at a construction site in the New Zealand city of Auckland, June 25, 2017. Picture taken June 25, 2017.       REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Japan unveils US$65 billion plan to aid domestic chip industry
summary: Japan's government has unveiled a $65 billion plan to support the domestic chip and artificial intelligence industries through subsidies and financial incentives. The plan, which will provide up to $86.6 billion by 2030, targets chip foundry venture Rapidus and other suppliers of AI chips. The government expects the plan to have an economic impact of around $160 trillion yen, with a focus on mass production of cutting-edge chips on the northern island of Hokkaido.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending, which accounts for more than half the economy, has stayed below pre-pandemic levels.
Wages are key to how soon the Bank of Japan could raise interest rates again.

At the September meeting, the BOJ kept interest rates steady at 0.25 per cent, with Governor Kazuo Ueda signalling it was in no rush to raise borrowing costs further as fears of US recession kept markets jittery and clouded the global economic outlook.
The final au Jibun Bank Service purchasing managers’ index dropped to 49.7 in October from 53.1 in September, according to an index publisher S&P Global Intelligence.

site_title: MicroStrategy’s US$2 billion Bitcoin buy is largest since 2020
summary: MicroStrategy, a publicly-traded corporate holder of Bitcoin, has made its largest purchase since 2020, buying approximately 27,200 Bitcoin for around $2.03 billion. The purchase, made between October 31 and November 10, surpasses the firm's previous record of 29,646 Bitcoin set in December 2020. MicroStrategy's CEO Michael Saylor initially invested in Bitcoin as a hedge against inflation, and the firm has since used proceeds from stock sales and convertible debt to leverage its buying power. This purchase solidifies MicroStrategy's position as the second-largest corporate holder of Bitcoin.

images.alt_text: MicroStrategy now holds around 244,800 Bitcoin, valued at around US$14 billion. That is about 1 per cent of all the Bitcoin ever issued.

site_title: Trump ramps up transition moves with key appointments
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has begun assembling his cabinet, making key appointments for various positions, including chief of staff, border czar, UN ambassador, EPA administrator, and treasury secretary. Trump has chosen Susie Wiles as White House chief of staff, Tom Homan as border czar, Elise Stefanik as UN ambassador, and Lee Zeldin as EPA administrator. Other contenders for treasury secretary include Scott Bessent, John Paulson, Larry Kudlow, Robert Lighthizer, and Howard Lutnick. Linda McMahon is seen as the frontrunner to lead the Department of Commerce, while Richard Grenell and Robert O'Brien are potential candidates for secretary of state. Mike Waltz is considered a contender for defense secretary, and Mark Green and Chad Wolf are potential candidates for homeland security secretary.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7 per cent, to 44,293, the S&P 500 rose 0.1 per cent, to 6,001 and the Nasdaq Composite was little changed at 19,298 on Monday.

Under the US Constitution, the Senate must vote to approve nominations made by the president for senior executive positions, such as cabinet posts, and judicial appointments. A constitutional clause however allows for presidents to bypass a Senate vote if the chamber is in an extended recess.

site_title: Oil falls on Chinese stimulus disappointment, supply outlook
summary: Oil prices fell over 2% on Monday, settling at $71.83 a barrel for Brent crude futures and $68.04 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude futures. The drop was attributed to China's latest stimulus plan failing to meet demand growth expectations and supply outlook, with non-Opec crude supply expected to rise by 1.4 million barrels per day in 2025. The US dollar index also rose, making commodities denominated in the US currency more expensive for holders of other currencies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A pumpjack brings oil to the surface  in the Monterey Shale, California, April 29, 2013.   REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson/File Photo##########lull30##########
Brent crude futures dropped 19 cents, or 0.3 per cent, to US$73.68 a barrel by 0104 GMT while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures were at US$70.13 a barrel, down 25 cents, or 0.4 per cent.

site_title: Trump to appoint former ICE director Tom Homan as US ‘border czar’
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is set to appoint former ICE director Tom Homan as the country's "border czar" starting January 20. Homan will prioritize deporting immigrants who pose safety and security threats, as well as those working at job sites. Trump has promised mass deportations, with his vice-president estimating one million people could be removed per year. Immigrant advocates have warned that the effort would be costly, divisive, and inhumane, leading to family separations and devastating communities.

images.alt_text: A demonstrator in Israel calling for the release of hostages in Gaza. Various sources say Donald Trump wants to see the war in Gaza end and the hostages there freed before he assumes office in January.
America Inc under its brand new CEO Trump feels less like a blue chip and more like a private equity firm: it's a highly leveraged, short-term play with an average hold time of around four years.

Chairman John Kim (centre in red, beside the man in black) founded the pro-Trump Strong Republic of Korea-US Alliance in defiance to what he believes are communist threats from China, North Korea and Russia – countries that surround South Korea.

Investors are still trying the gauge paths for global interest rates and the dollar under a new Trump administration. Trump's tariff plans are likely to take a disproportionate toll on some larger emerging markets, such as Mexico and China.
Bitcoin has now more than doubled from the year’s low of US$38,505 and was last at US$81,572 having earlier touched a record high of US$81,899.

site_title: Will COP29 reach consensus on more funds for climate finance?
summary: Developing countries require trillions of dollars in climate finance to meet their goals and compensate for loss and damage from climate change. Despite agreements to provide $100 billion by 2020, actual funding has consistently fallen short. In 2022, developed countries finally met the target, providing $116 billion, but still lag behind actual requirements. The lack of consensus on climate finance remains a contentious issue at COP29, with the developing world seeking a higher level of support to address the impacts of climate change.

images.alt_text: The ADB has set a long-term cumulative climate finance lending target of US$100 billion between 2019 and 2030.
This year’s climate summit in Baku, Azerbaijan, has been dubbed the "finance COP".

site_title: US opens probe into 1.4 million Honda vehicles over engine issues
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has opened a probe into 1.4 million Honda vehicles due to serious engine issues. The probe follows a 2023 recall of 249,000 vehicles with a 3.5-liter V6 engine, which could cause engine failure. The investigation, covering 2016-2020 model year vehicles, aims to determine the severity of the issue and whether vehicles not included in the recall should be covered. Honda has cooperated with the NHTSA and reported 1,450 warranty claims related to the recall.

images.alt_text: Honda has also slashed jobs and paused production at three of its plants in China, according to local media reports.

Honda's long-awaited electric van, the N-VAN e:, is set to go on sale in Japan on Thursday (Oct 10), and the automaker expects to launch premium EVs under its 0 series in markets such as North America from 2026.
To move towards electrification, Honda will reduce the production of petrol cars.
Honda said quarterly operating profit totalled 484.7 billion yen (S$4.4 billion) in the April-to-June period.

site_title: BlackRock targets money-market fund business in new ETF push
summary: BlackRock is launching two new exchange-traded funds (ETFs) targeting money-market investors, expanding an experiment that began with the Texas Capital Government Money Market ETF in September. The iShares Government Money Market ETF and the iShares Prime Money Market ETF, both filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, aim to bring ETFs to a traditionally conservative market. This move follows the widespread adoption of ETFs by individual investors due to their ease of shifting in and out of rapidly. The rollout is expected to significantly expand the experiment, which has seen record assets in traditional funds.

images.alt_text: BlackRock has been on an acquisition spree this year as it looks to become an all-in-one platform for investors by integrating public and private markets.
BlackRock is putting portions of about 300 first-lien loan positions into the deal, slated to be among the largest ever transfers of private credit into a so-called continuation fund.
BlackRock received approval to set up its regional headquarters in Riyadh, allowing it to expand operations across the Middle East.
BlackRock is seeking to replicate its dominant scale in stock and bond markets in private assets.

site_title: Australia’s consumer, business sentiment lift as inflation ebbs
summary: Australia's consumer and business sentiment have improved, with the National Australia Bank survey showing a seven-point increase in business confidence in October. This is the highest level since early 2023, reflecting ebbing inflation pressures. The survey also found conditions remained unchanged, with jobs, sales, and profitability unchanged. Analysts expect the next move in interest rates to be a reduction, driven by the improvement in inflation pressures.

images.alt_text: The Australian Bureau of Statistics reported the balance on goods held at A$4.609 billion (S$4 billion), compared with a surplus of A$5.284 billion in August.
The Reserve Bank of Australia kept rates at a decade-high of 4.35 per cent, where they have been for the last year, and reiterated it was not ruling anything in or out on future policy.
Australia's consumer price index rose 0.2 per cent in the third quarter, under forecasts of a 0.3 per cent increase.

site_title: Harris appears with Biden for first time since election loss
summary: US President Joe Biden and Vice-President Kamala Harris attended a wreath-laying ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery, marking Harris's first public appearance since conceding the presidential election to Donald Trump. The event comes as Democrats face internal discussions over their election loss, with some blaming Biden's decision to run again at 81. Biden hailed serving as commander-in-chief as the "greatest honour" of his life, while Harris's appearance signals a return to normalcy after a brief period of introspection.

images.alt_text: A demonstrator in Israel calling for the release of hostages in Gaza. Various sources say Donald Trump wants to see the war in Gaza end and the hostages there freed before he assumes office in January.

site_title: Grab returns to profit in Q3, raises 2024 revenue forecast
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing giant, reported a turnaround in Q3 earnings, turning a profit of $15 million, compared to a loss of $99 million in the same period last year. The company raised its 2024 revenue forecast to $2.76-$2.78 billion, a 4-5% increase from its previous guidance. Group-adjusted Ebitda improved 224% year-over-year, driven by increases in net finance income and lower share-based compensation expenses.

images.alt_text: From (L-R): Ng Chee Meng, Secretary-General of NTUC and Yee Wee Tang, Managing Director, Grab Singapore at the launch of the GrabBenefits 2.0

site_title: FTX sues Binance and its former CEO for US$1.8 billion
summary: FTX is suing Binance and its former CEO, Zhao Changpeng, for $1.8 billion, alleging that $1.76 billion was "fraudulently transferred" by FTX management to Binance. The lawsuit centers on Binance's sale of its FTX stake in 2021, which FTX's Alameda Research division funded using insolvent tokens. The transaction is being challenged as it should not have been allowed to proceed due to Alameda's financial situation.

images.alt_text: Tigran Gambaryan, an executive of Binance, sits as he waits to face prosecution for tax evasion and money laundering at the federal high court in Abuja, Nigeria.
Binance has been losing market share since March 2023, as it’s grappled with regulatory actions and increased scrutiny worldwide.
Former chief executive Zhao Chanpeng was sentenced to four months jail earlier this year.
Richard Teng career includes stints as a senior regulator at the Monetary Authority of Singapore as well as at the city-state’s SGX stock exchange.
Binance returns to a changed competitive landscape in India.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit posts 89.5% committed occupancy portfolio for Q1 FY2025
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit posted a committed portfolio occupancy of 89.5% for Q1 FY2025, up from 89.1% in the previous quarter. New leases were signed for Building 3 of the Sky Complex property in Milan, Italy. The retail portfolio stood at 99.9% with a positive rental reversion of 11.4% and a tenant retention rate of 90%. The Reit manager plans to strengthen the tenancy mix and bring in new offerings to rejuvenate the malls, despite high occupancy rates.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Sky Complex in Milan is fully leased to satelitte television platform Sky Italia under a triple net lease structure in which all operating expenses are borne by the tenant.
Kelvin Chow, LReit's chief executive officer, says the Reit is looking at assets in the eastern part of Singapore for acquisition.

site_title: Morgan Stanley’s PE arm to sell HVAC firm to Goldman Sachs Alternatives
summary: Morgan Stanley's private equity arm is selling its HVAC business Sila Services to Goldman Sachs Alternatives, a private equity unit, for an undisclosed amount. Sila, which provides residential HVAC services, was initially invested in by Morgan Stanley in 2021 to capitalize on the growing demand in the sector. The deal follows a 6.9% year-over-year increase in HVAC dealmaking, driven by busier construction activity and stringent environmental regulations. Sila's management team will retain a minority stake in the company and continue to lead the business.

images.alt_text: Rival JPMorgan became first sizeable foreign bank to fully own a futures unit in China in 2020.
Goldman Sachs' third-quarter profit jumped 45 per cent, with its stock traders recording their best quarter in more than three years.
Client assets at retail brokerage Charles Schwab and the wealth arms of the six largest US banks surged US$5 trillion in the 12 months through September.

site_title: MediShield Life amendment Bill seeks to expand measures for recovering premiums, support new models of care
summary: The Singapore Parliament has passed the MediShield Life Scheme (Amendment) Bill, which aims to expand measures for recovering premiums and support new models of care. The bill updates the current legislation to broaden the range of care settings covered and introduces a new framework to empower the minister for health to approve, suspend, or revoke providers' status as approved medical institutions. The government will also provide S$4.1 billion in subsidies and MediSave top-ups over three years to cushion the impact of rising healthcare costs. The bill aims to keep the insurance scheme sustainable by discouraging policyholders from defaulting on their premiums.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Medical cost inflation in Singapore is estimated at between 10.67 and 13 per cent annually.
Active ageing is not just a buzzword, but an increasingly pressing imperative as Singapore's demographic changes mean that healthcare costs will only keep rising.

The MediShield Life Council recommended reductions in the proration factors that apply to higher class wards, to prevent cross-subsidisation of private bills by subsidised bills. MediShield  Life is designed to cover large bills in public hospital B2/C wards.
To ease the impact, the government is introducing a S$4.1 billion support package, with MediSave top-ups and premium subsidies benefiting over 90 per cent of Singaporeans.
The latest review, conducted by the 11-member MediShield Life Council, is chaired by former Nominated Member of Parliament Fang Ai Lian.
Health Minister Ong Ye Kung notes that the latest adjustments will help patients cope with rising outpatient costs.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 jumps on defence stocks prospects, data in focus
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed 1.1% higher on Monday, its best day in six weeks, driven by defence stocks as investors await higher military spending in Europe under a Donald Trump US presidency. Defence stocks jumped 3.5-5.8%, with Leonardo, Hensoldt, and Saab leading gains. The market also received a boost from Wall Street's record-breaking rally. Key economic data, including Euro zone inflation and employment figures, is scheduled for release later this week, with the European Central Bank's minutes also due out on Thursday.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7 per cent, to 44,293, the S&P 500 rose 0.1 per cent, to 6,001 and the Nasdaq Composite was little changed at 19,298 on Monday.

site_title: Judge to rule on throwing out Trump hush money conviction
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump may receive a reprieve if Judge Juan Merchan decides to dismiss his conviction in a New York criminal case, potentially due to the Supreme Court's recent ruling on presidential immunity. Trump was convicted of 34 felony counts in May for allegedly manipulating business records to cover up a sexual encounter with a porn star ahead of the 2016 election. If the case is dismissed, Trump will avoid sentencing on November 26 and could face opposition or delay from his legal team, who would argue that it would interfere with his role as commander-in-chief.

site_title: UK business closures surge after budget hit to employers
summary: UK business closures surged by 64% in the week ended Nov 8, with at least 1,022 companies filing to shut down, compared to 621 the previous year. The increase is attributed to the Labour government's reduction of tax breaks and increase of levies on owners. Chancellor Rachel Reeves will address businesses this week, aiming to promote economic growth and free trade, amidst a slowdown in the UK economy and rising consumer reluctance to spend.

site_title: WealthBT: Building a resilient investment portfolio
summary: WealthBT discusses building a resilient investment portfolio, offering general information on key strategies and concepts. The podcast aims to provide listeners with practical advice on managing risk and increasing returns. Key takeaways include diversifying assets, setting clear goals, and regularly reviewing portfolios. Experts emphasize the importance of professional advice and encourage listeners to consult with financial advisors before making investment decisions. The podcast is designed for general information purposes only and is not intended to provide personalized investment advice.

site_title: China says to impose anti-dumping measures on EU brandy
summary: China will impose "temporary anti-dumping measures" on European brandy imports, effective Friday, amid a trade standoff with the EU. The measures follow China's announcement of provisional tariffs on EU brandy imports last month, which Brussels described as "political." The EU had imposed tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles over unfair competition claims, prompting China's investigation into EU brandy imports. The move deepens the trade tension between Beijing and Brussels.

images.alt_text: The EU launched an anti-subsidy investigation into imports of Chinese-made battery EVs last year and in October voted for tariffs on those vehicles.
BYD’s European registrations jumped 162 per cent in September from a year earlier, to 4,376 vehicles, according to Jato.
Europe’s relationship with China is being buffeted by worsening trade tensions, as the EU seeks to target what it says are unfair subsidies and other support that Beijing provides to its companies.
“Faced with this development, the French authorities cannot abandon us and leave us alone to deal with Chinese retaliation that has nothing to do with us”, BNIC said.
Importers of brandy originating in the EU will, as of Oct 11, have to put down security deposits mostly ranging from 34.8 to 39 per cent of the import value.

site_title: New York judge pauses proceedings in Trump hush money case
summary: A New York state judge, Justice Juan Merchan, has paused further action on President-elect Donald Trump's conviction related to a hush money payment to a porn star until at least Nov 19. The decision comes due to the US Supreme Court's July ruling that presidents are immune from prosecution involving their official acts. Trump's lawyers argued that the case should be dismissed to avoid interfering with his presidential duties, and Manhattan DA Alvin Bragg's office agreed to pause proceedings to consider the implications of Trump's election victory. Sentencing was initially set for Nov 26.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump's unique role as president makes it unlikely that he will face legal consequences in criminal cases brought against him, at least while he is in office.

site_title: Call for more children reveals India’s north-south divide
summary: Regional leaders in southern India, including Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh, have called for more babies to counterbalance the dominance of northern states in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) revenue-sharing formula. The southern states fear that the formula, based on population size, will further entrench the north's dominance and reduce their representation in parliament. The next Finance Commission, set to be published in October 2025, will consider a new population census that could alter parliamentary representation, fueling concerns of a widening north-south divide in India.

images.alt_text: Mohan Kuppusamy

The protests – the biggest such in India in recent years – at the South Korean group’s plant near Chennai has disrupted operations, with over 1,000 of the 1,800 workers demanding higher wages and union recognition.

site_title: Bitcoin surge triggers billions in losses for crypto short traders after Trump win
summary: Bitcoin surged to a record high above $82,000 following US President-elect Donald Trump's win, boosting crypto prospects. Traders who bet against MicroStrategy, a major corporate backer, lost over $1.2 billion between Nov 6 and Nov 8. The surge in bitcoin prices also led to significant losses for crypto short traders, with losses totaling over $6 billion this year. Investors expect a more favorable regulatory framework under Trump's presidency, which may lead to increased demand for cryptocurrencies.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has now more than doubled from the year’s low of US$38,505 and was last at US$81,572 having earlier touched a record high of US$81,899.

site_title: To remain credible, Singapore International Energy Week must remain an ‘open platform’ for different perspectives: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the need for the Singapore International Energy Week to remain an "open platform" for diverse perspectives to address the complexities of the energy transition. This comes after remarks made by Saudi Aramco's CEO Amin Nasser at the conference, which sparked a parliamentary question. Gan stressed that there is no single solution to energy transition and encouraged the sharing of different perspectives to tackle this challenge.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Amin Nasser, President and CEO, Aramco delivers his speech at the Singapore International Energy Week (SIEW) 2024, in the Sands Expo and Convention Centre on Oct 21, 2024.

(FILES) This picture shows a worker standing on the uploading dock of Cavaou LNG (Liquefied Natural Gas) terminal in Fos-sur-Mer, June 22, 2023, while the tanker boat "Lalla Fatma N'Soumer" arrives full of LNG ready to be delivered. Planet-heating methane released from fossil fuels rose to near record highs in 2023 despite technology available to curb this pollution at virtually no cost, the International Energy Agency said on March 13, 2024. The Paris-based organisation said the production and use of fossil fuels resulted in close to 120 million tonnes of methane emissions in 2023, a small rise compared with 2022. (Photo by CLEMENT MAHOUDEAU / AFP)
The energy transition will need to be made affordable for developing countries, said Amin Nasser, Aramco president and CEO.

site_title: Lui Che Woo, casino tycoon who hit jackpot in Macau, dies at 95
summary: Lui Che Woo, a Hong Kong casino tycoon and founder of Galaxy Entertainment Group, has died at 95. He was estimated to have a net worth of US$14.5 billion, making him one of the richest people in Hong Kong. Woo's vision and leadership led to the company's development and success, and he is remembered as a key figure in Macau's casino industry.

images.alt_text: Macau's gross gaming revenue reached 20.8 billion patacas (S$3.4 billion) for the month, according to data released by the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau.

site_title: UOB cuts 2023 financed emissions in most ‘dirty’ sectors except steel
summary: UOB, Singapore's third-largest lender, has released a progress report on its decarbonisation targets for six high-emitting sectors. The bank aims to lower emissions intensities by 2050 and cease financing new upstream oil and gas projects from 2023. In 2023, financed emissions decreased in four sectors, but increased in the steel sector, which still has lower emissions than a global reference pathway. The power sector saw the largest drop, with emissions intensities decreasing by 37% compared to a regional net zero pathway. UOB expects emissions intensity to improve in the real estate, construction, and automotive sectors.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Countries like India and Brazil have optimal natural conditions, such as high solar irradiance and strong wind currents, which can make renewable projects highly productive.

As South-east Asia stands at this critical crossroads between rising emissions and the opportunity to make a green leap, the course of action taken by Singapore’s private sector, along with governments and other stakeholders in the coming months and years will determine the region’s climate trajectory.

site_title: Tesla fans go all in driving US$300 billion rally on Trump win
summary: Tesla's stock price has surged 39% since the Nov 5 election, adding over $300 billion to its market capitalization. The stock closed up 9% at $350 on Nov 11, driven by investors' confidence in a second Trump term bringing windfalls to the electric vehicle maker. Tesla's stock is considered a "momentum" stock, where gains and losses quickly snowball with sharp changes in investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: The Tesla logo is seen through a charging station outside a store of the electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China January 4, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo

site_title: A Brics alternative to the dominance of the US and the dollar
summary: The 16th annual Brics summit in Kazan, Russia, marked the bloc's continued push for an alternative global financial structure, with a focus on establishing a Brics currency backed by 40% gold and 60% local currencies. This move aims to challenge the US dollar's dominance, with potential implications for investors and the global economy. Despite the bloc's growing economic influence, with combined GDP exceeding 35% of world GDP, the project's success remains uncertain due to disparate member goals and the significant hurdles it must overcome.

images.alt_text: The annual Brics Summit was hosted in the Russian city of Kazan this year, under President Vladimir Putin's helm.
Russia's President Vladimir Putin at the Brics summit in Kazan on Oct 24, 2024.

epa11679350 Russian President Vladimir Putin (C) speaks during a plenary session in the outreach/BRICS Plus format at the BRICS summit in Kazan, Russia, 24 October 2024. The BRICS summit takes place from 22 to 24 October.  EPA-EFE/MAXIM SHEMETOV / POOL

site_title: Nestle's KitKat signs Formula 1 deal as CEO Freixe seeks broader appeal
summary: Nestle's KitKat brand has signed a global sponsorship deal with Formula 1, set to run from 2025 to 2028. The deal aims to increase KitKat's global reach and appeal to younger shoppers. Advertising and events will be featured at Formula 1 racetracks and pit lanes, with chocolate wrappers to be branded with Formula 1 logos. Nestle will also give away hundreds of race tickets. New CEO Laurent Freixe seeks to broaden KitKat's appeal as part of the company's marketing strategy.

images.alt_text: Nestle’s factory in York churns out 200,000 KitKat bars every hour.

site_title: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta sells S$12.6 million worth of shares as DBS hits all-time high
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta sold 300,000 shares on November 7 and 8, netting him S$12.6 million. The sale reduced his holdings to 1.9 million shares. DBS shares hit an all-time high of S$42.75 after Singapore banking stocks rallied following strong Q3 earnings results. Other major banks, including UOB and OCBC, also saw significant gains. Gupta's transactions come amid a bank rally, with DBS shares surpassing the S$40 mark.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Singapore expands eligibility, adds higher BEPS 2.0-compliant tax rate for corporate incentive scheme
summary: Singapore has expanded its Development and Expansion Incentive (DEI) scheme, adding a 15% tax rate tier for large multinationals affected by the global minimum effective tax rate of 15% under Pillar Two of the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) 2.0 initiative. The updated scheme aims to ensure its tax incentives remain relevant to companies with different circumstances and needs. Non-headquarters service companies will now be eligible for up to 40 years of DEI award tenure, while the government will prescribe projects for Investment Allowance (IA) via regulations.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah said in Parliament that it is in Singapore’s interest to impose the two new top-up corporate taxes, rather than cede the taxes to other jurisdictions.

site_title: Deconstructing Trump’s foreign policy
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's foreign policy may differ from the conventional wisdom of a radical global America-first agenda, as he pursued diplomatic detente with North Korea and brokered peace between Israel and Arab countries. Trump's first term reflected realpolitik considerations, focusing on national interests and transactional relationships with China and Iran. His foreign policy was characterized by unpredictability, with the real question being who was the last person he spoke with before making decisions. Two schools of thought, traditional Republican internationalists and a "China-first" approach, are expected to dominate the foreign policy debate in the next Trump administration.

images.alt_text: The prospect that Trump will be president again is impossible to ignore. For liberals, this fact inspires dread. And for good reason.
How Trump won

site_title: ABN Amro puts 3 billion euros of infrastructure loans up for sale
summary: ABN Amro is selling a portfolio of 3 billion euros (S$4.25 billion) of infrastructure loans to private credit funds, as the Dutch lender reduces its stake in the loans from 40.5% to 30%. The sale is part of ABN Amro's efforts to offload non-core assets and is being arranged by Morgan Stanley. The move comes as the Dutch government, ABN Amro's largest shareholder, plans to reduce its equity stake in the bank.

images.alt_text: The logo for ABN Amro Bank NV is seen displayed outside the company's headquarters in Amsterdam, Netherlands, on Monday, May 21, 2012. Rising popularity of anti-bailout parties has raised the chances of a Greek euro exit, ABN Amro says in a note yesterday. Photographer: Jock Fistick/Bloomberg

site_title:
Going into new Trump era, risky emerging market 
bonds keep luring traders
summary: Investors are flocking to emerging market junk-rated dollar debt as they seek protection from potential sell-offs in global rates under a new Trump administration. These bonds have handed investors a 14.5% gain year-to-date, with some countries like Argentina, Sri Lanka, and Pakistan poised for further gains. Fundamentals are improving in some emerging nations, and investors see attractive double-digit returns, despite potential risks from Trump's tariff plans and geopolitical fallout. High-yield corporate bonds are also attracting attention, offering higher spreads and attractive valuations.

images.alt_text: With a median age of just 29.8 years, Asean’s demographic advantage contrasts sharply with the ageing populations of developed economies like Japan and much of Europe.

site_title: Paris agreement climate goals ‘in great peril’, warns UN
summary: The UN's World Meteorological Organization (WMO) warns that the Paris climate agreement's goals are in great peril, citing a record-breaking decade of warming and extreme weather events. 2024 is on track to break new temperature records, with the period from 2015 to 2024 set to be the warmest decade ever recorded. The WMO chief, Celeste Saulo, sounded the "red alert," urging the world to act swiftly to avoid catastrophic climate change.

images.alt_text: The male emperor penguin on the beach in the small town of Denmark in Western Australia. Its motivation for the much longer trip was almost certainly food, says Prof Dee Boersma.
