The ADB has set a long-term cumulative climate finance lending target of US$100 billion between 2019 and 2030.

Workers are seen near the South Luzon Thermal Energy Corporation power plant south of Manila, Philippinrd on October 8, 2024. A liberalised energy market, such as the Philippines, is the most efficient and cheap in the long-term, said Valerie Speth, co-lead in Asia-Pacific’s climate infrastructure group at BlackRock.
The COP29 negotiations will be held in Azerbaijan as the world continues to emit increasing levels of planet-heating fossil fuels.

Fishermen dragging a boat on the dry bed of Lake Aleixo during what the national disaster monitoring agency Cemaden has already called Brazil's worst drought since at least the 1950s, near Manaus, Amazonas State, Brazil, Oct 29, 2024.

Donald Trump intends to end the offshore wind industry “on day one,” arguing it is too expensive and poses a threat to whales and seabirds, a dramatic policy reversal after his first administration supported offshore wind development.

site_title: UK universities face funding ‘crunch’ as foreign students go elsewhere
summary: The UK's universities are facing a funding "crunch" due to a decline in foreign student visa applications, which has dropped by 5% and 16% between July and September last year. Foreign students pay higher fees, with £31,000 per year compared to £9,250 for British students. The decline is attributed to visa restrictions imposed by the previous Conservative government, which has made the UK a less attractive study destination. Universities are experiencing budget deficits and have welcomed foreign students to fill the gap, with some lowering admission criteria.

images.alt_text: At some stage, domestic tuition fees will need to be reset and indexed to inflation – as unpalatable as that choice may be, given the already high levels of UK student debt.

site_title: Asian-American voter patterns in US elections hint at political shifts and trends to watch
summary: US President Donald Trump secured a second term in office despite losing the battleground state of Virginia, where his campaign had made a last-minute push. Unprecedented support from Latino voters and notable shifts among Asian-American voters signal trends worth watching. The Asian-American community, which has been the fastest-growing demographic of eligible voters, showed a slight shift towards the Republican Party, with Trump losing the Asian-American vote to Kamala Harris by 38% to 56%. The Strong Republic of Korea-US Alliance, a pro-Trump organization founded by South Korean-American Chairman John Kim, demonstrated the growing influence of Asian-American voters in US politics.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
Volunteers gather at a room in the Seattle Labor Temple to call voters in swing states leading up to the US Presidential Election.

site_title: Chinese Vice-Premier Ding Xuexiang meets President Tharman, PM Wong
summary: Chinese Vice-Premier Ding Xuexiang met with Singapore President Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Prime Minister Lawrence Wong during a two-day visit to the country. Ding co-chaired the 20th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation and held separate meetings with Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong. The meetings aimed to strengthen bilateral cooperation and promote economic ties between China and Singapore. Ding was also hosted to a welcome dinner by Gan, where he was served a traditional Singaporean dish.

site_title: Amazon developing driver eyeglasses to shave seconds off deliveries: sources
summary: Amazon is developing driver eyeglasses to guide delivery drivers through their routes and at each stop, aiming to shave seconds off deliveries. The glasses would display turn-by-turn navigation and directions to packages, freeing drivers from handheld GPS devices and allowing them to carry more packages. If successful, the project could reduce delivery costs and support margins, as Amazon faces increased competition from Walmart. However, the technology is still in development, and Amazon has had trouble making a battery that can last a full shift, and gathering complete data on each house could take years.

images.alt_text: Workers who are consistently not in compliance have been told they will be “voluntarily resigning” and locked out of company computers.
Amazon and other big cloud-computing companies, desperate for power to support their growing operations.
As Big Tech races to grow its data centres needed to expand technologies, locating centres directly on power plant sites has become an attractive option to power up quickly.
Amazon reassures investors with cloud growth, cost-cutting

site_title: Euro hits lowest in 6½ months vs dollar on tariff worries
summary: The euro fell to its lowest level in 6½ months against the dollar, dropping 0.6% to US$1.0657, amid worries about possible US tariffs that could hurt the euro area's economy. The US dollar index rose 0.45% to 105.44, driven by concerns about Trump's trade policy. Analysts expect higher tariffs to boost inflation and put upward pressure on the dollar. The euro's sensitivity to US tariffs is evident, with a report suggesting Trump's trade policy hawk, Robert Lighthizer, could weaken the currency.

images.alt_text: A bus driver counts U.S. dollar bills after migrants board a bus bound for the border with Costa Rica, as part of their journey to the U.S. border, at the migrant reception center in the village of Lajas Blancas, Darien Province, Panama, November 8, 2024. REUTERS/Enea Lebrun

site_title: Temasek-backed GenZero and Trafigura to invest US$100 million in Colombian carbon project
summary: GenZero, a Temasek-backed decarbonisation investment platform, and Trafigura have jointly invested US$100 million in the Brujula Verde reforestation carbon project in Colombia, doubling the project's size. The project restores land degraded by cattle grazing, farming, and forest fires by planting over 24 million mixed-species trees. The first lot of carbon credits is expected in late 2025, with plans for direct revenue to be shared with local communities. The project aims to generate carbon credits under international standards, including the Gold Standard and Verra, and is in talks with the Colombian government to explore eligibility for a framework allowing credits to be transferred to another country.

site_title: China’s October new lending tumbles more than expected despite policy support
summary: China's new lending in October fell short of expectations, with 500 billion yuan (S$92.5 billion) extended, down from September's 500 billion yuan and a year earlier's 738.4 billion yuan. Despite policy support, economists attribute the decline to weak corporate financing demand due to poor profitability. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has reaffirmed its supportive monetary policy stance, but analysts question the effectiveness of recent measures in boosting economic activity.

images.alt_text: China’s gold holdings stood at 72.8 million troy ounces at the end of last month.
Chinese banks are grappling with liquidity strains as stepped-up policy loosening has caused an erosion of savings.
The PBOC chief’s comments amid a highly anticipated session of the NPC Standing Committee in Beijing this week.

site_title: Riverstone Q3 earnings rise 21.8% to RM72.2 million
summary: Riverstone Holdings reported a 21.8% increase in net profit to RM72.2 million for the third quarter of 2024, driven by increased production volume and higher average selling prices. Revenue rose 33.9% to RM298.4 million, with the company adding six new cleanroom production lines to cater to the growing demand from the semiconductor and electronics sector. The gross profit margin declined marginally, and the operating profit margin fell 2.7 percentage points. The board recommended an interim dividend of RM0.04 per share, with a total dividend payout ratio of 82%.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

The United States Trade Representative’s (USTR) final revisions to China tariffs, under which tariffs for China-made medical and surgical gloves will be brought up to 50 per cent by 2025 and 100 per cent by 2026, have market watchers optimistic on Malaysia's glove making sector's prospects.
Wong Teek Son, founder and CEO of Riverstone Holdings, says the company is well-positioned to meet the growing demand of gloves.

site_title: Japan’s stimulus package to include price relief steps
summary: Japan's new economic stimulus package, ordered by Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba, will include cash handouts to low-income households, with increased funding for disaster preparedness. The package will also boost the size of handouts based on household size, including children. The draft plan aims to streamline disaster registration and expedite air conditioning installations at schools for emergency shelters. The package may be modified to include opposition party proposals, including tax allowances and reduced energy prices, as negotiations with the ruling coalition continue.

images.alt_text: Japan will hold elections next year for the less-powerful upper house, where the ruling coalition’s slim majority could also be at risk if PM Shigeru Ishiba cannot revive public trust in his administration.

site_title: Indonesia gives small, medium businesses six-month window for loan write off
summary: Indonesia has introduced a six-month loan forgiveness window for small and medium businesses with bad debts of up to 500 million rupiah, aiming to boost economic growth. The policy, signed by President Prabowo Subianto, allows state lenders to fully write off bad debts of certain micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs), major contributors to Indonesia's GDP. The move is expected to open new loan opportunities for affected MSMEs and prevent state banks from being charged with creating losses. The policy will run until May 2025 and is part of the government's plan to lift annual economic growth by 3 percentage points.

images.alt_text: Investment Minister Rosan Roeslani said Indonesia needs additional investment – whether domestic or foreign – worth 13,528 trillion rupiah (S$1.1 trillion) between 2025 and 2029 to reach the 8 per cent growth.

site_title: German commercial property prices drop but show some stabilisation
summary: German commercial property prices dropped 4.7% in the third quarter from last year, but showed stabilization with a 0.7% increase from the second quarter. This marks the second consecutive quarter-on-quarter rise, but the market remains uncertain due to a weak economy and geopolitical risks. Experts caution that prices may move sideways in the coming quarters and that a sustainable upturn is not yet imminent, with VDP's CEO Jens Tolckmitt stating it's "too early to talk about the start of a sustainable upturn."

site_title: Singapore stocks rise despite tepid regional sentiment; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,739.47, driven by gains from UOB, which jumped 2.7%. Despite the market's uptick, regional sentiment weakened, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and South Korea's Kospi falling 1.5% and 1.2%, respectively. The decline in China's National People's Congress Standing Committee's economic support may have contributed to the tepid market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
At their respective third quarter results briefings, management of the three banks said they will look at the market and adjust accordingly, but did not explicitly mention plans to cut rates.
While the decline in net profit is in line with the lower revenue, Venture Corp notes it has a “robust" net profit margin of 8.8 per cent.
Singapore Airlines Q2 profit falls 59% to S$290 million on weaker operating performance

site_title: White truffles, Italy’s gold, are menaced by climate change
summary: Italy's prized white truffles, known as the "gold of Italy," are facing a significant threat due to climate change. Rising temperatures, drought, and deforestation are weakening the natural habitat of the fungus, leading to a 30% decline in areas dedicated to white truffles over the past three decades. Experts warn that if action is not taken, the truffle could become extinct. To combat this, a "Save the Truffle" association has planted over 700 truffle trees in the Langhe hills, but more needs to be done to protect this culinary treasure.

images.alt_text: Croatia's truffle hunters seek habitat protection amid climate change

site_title: BYD closing in on Ford deliveries after besting Tesla on revenue
summary: BYD surpassed Tesla in quarterly revenue for the first time as an electric vehicle company, selling a record half a million vehicles in October. This momentum puts BYD nearly on par with Ford's year-to-date sales and analysts expect it to continue. BYD now has a shot at beating Ford in terms of annual shipments this year, which would cement its position as a top 10 automaker globally.

images.alt_text: BYD is on track to meet its revised annual sales target of four million vehicles.
BYD hailed the Atto 3 as one of the safest models when it was awarded a maximum five-star rating by Euro NCAP in 2023.
BYD is bulking up in Europe even as other Chinese electric-vehicle manufactures slow their advance.
BYD sold 51,203 vehicles in Brazil during the first nine months of 2024, an increase of more than 700 per cent from the same period last year.

site_title: Singapore broadens scope of mutual legal assistance for cross-border crime under new law
summary: Singapore has broadened the scope of its mutual legal assistance for cross-border crime under a new law, allowing law enforcement agencies to enforce foreign confiscation orders and take evidence from individuals under foreign investigation. The amendments aim to improve Singapore's ability to support complex international investigations and secure convictions. However, Minister of State for Law Murali Pillai emphasized the importance of not blindly acceding to every request, citing safeguards to ensure assistance is provided only in meritorious cases.

The amendments in the Bill therefore “seeks to give effect” to certain recommendations of FATF.

site_title: A penguin finds itself on an Australian beach, after travelling more than 3,000 km
summary: A male emperor penguin, approximately 3,380 km from its Antarctic home, was spotted on a beach in Denmark, Western Australia. The penguin, likely seeking food due to record-low sea-ice levels in Antarctica, waddled onto the beach and interacted with locals, showing no signs of distress. The penguin was removed from the beach and is being cared for at a wildlife rehabilitation center, where it is expected to receive treatment for malnourishment. This is the furthest north an emperor penguin has been recorded.

images.alt_text: Truffle hunter Carlo Marenda walking with his dog Buk along a Langhe vineyard to search for white truffles in Treiso, near Alba, northwestern Italy.

site_title: Avarga receives S$0.25 per share offer from its executive chairman
summary: Avarga's executive chairman Tong Kooi Ong has made an unconditional mandatory general cash offer of S$0.25 per share to take the company private. The offeror, special-purpose vehicle TKO, has acquired 183.2 million shares, increasing Tong's control to over 50% of total issued shares. The offer represents a 22% premium over the last traded price and gives shareholders an exit opportunity to realise their holdings in cash at a premium.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Dyna-Mac main yard in Gul Road. Hanwha Ocean SG's offer for the company remains conditional on the CCCS green-lighting the deal.
Amos Group, listed on the Singapore Exchange, in September had received a voluntary unconditional general offer of S$0.07 cents per share in cash from its controlling shareholder, PeakBayou.
Boards and investors should scrutinise the work of IFAs, and push them to justify their views and recommendations.

site_title: Thai panel picks government’s candidate for central bank board chair: govt sources
summary: A Thai panel has selected former Finance Minister Kittiratt na Ranong as the central bank's board chairman, despite concerns over government influence. The selection comes amid opposition from hundreds of economists and former central bank governors, who warned of potential political interference. Kittiratt has been a critic of the current governor and has backed the government's repeated demands for interest rate cuts. The selection needs to be endorsed by the finance minister, Cabinet, and king, and is likely to be approved.

images.alt_text: The Thai government’s nomination of former Finance Minister Kittirat na Ranong (pictured), a ruling party loyalist and staunch critic of BOT Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, has sparked concerns over the central bank’s independence.
Bank of Thailand has nominated Kulit Sombatsiri, who has previously worked at the energy and finance ministries, and academic Surapon Nitikraipot.
A market in Bangkok. A surprise rate cut earlier this month and an agreement between BOT and the finance ministry to retain inflation target at 1 to 3% for next year have helped cool tension.

At the Oct 16 meeting, Thailand's monetary policy committee unexpectedly voted 5-2 to cut the one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 2.25 per cent, the first decrease since 2020. Two members voted to keep the rate steady.

site_title: Chip equipment maker ASMPT ends takeover talks with potential suitor
summary: ASMPT, a Hong Kong-listed chip equipment maker, has ended takeover talks with a potential suitor without disclosing the company's identity. The talks, which were first reported in October, were led by global investment firm KKR, which was exploring options for ASMPT's China operations due to regulatory and geopolitical risks. ASMPT's shares rose initially but declined over 20% following the news. The "reverse CFIUS" regulations, set to take effect in January 2025, have restricted US investments in China, further complicating KKR's potential deal.

images.alt_text: A spokesperson for TSMC declined to comment beyond saying it was a “law-abiding company...committed to complying with all applicable rules and regulations, including applicable export controls.”

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, November 11, 2024
summary: Asian stocks dropped as China's support plan for the market fell flat, while bitcoin hit a record high. The Bank of Japan hinted at caution on a potential rate hike in December, with no clear indication of a December rate hike. Vietnam has ordered e-commerce platforms Temu and Shein to register with the government or risk being blocked.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Monday.
Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.6%
Hong Kong stocks led losses on Monday, shedding more than two per cent, while Shanghai stocks was also down, along with Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta.
The lack of a clear steer on the likelihood of a rate hike in December or January will keep BOJ watchers guessing over the timing of the central bank’s next move.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 11)
summary: Singapore proposes an anti-scam law allowing police to restrict bank transfers for individuals 'reasonably believed' to be targeted by scammers. The proposed law aims to strike a balance between public protection and personal responsibility. The existing simplified insolvency programme is set to cease on Jan 28, 2026, and the government is considering greater flexibility when assessing bids for GLS sites. Additionally, the government will study engaging telcos other than Singtel to provide emergency hotline services following an islandwide disruption on Oct 8.

site_title: Vietnam says Temu, Shein must register with government or be blocked
summary: Vietnam's government has ordered Chinese online retailers Shein and Temu to register with the government by the end of November to continue selling in the country. Failure to comply will result in blocking of their internet domains and apps. The move aims to curb deep discounting and potential counterfeit item sales, which have expressed concerns from the government and local businesses. Vietnam's deputy trade minister, Nguyen Hoang Long, stated that the ministry has already worked with both Shein and Temu on licensing matters.

images.alt_text: Shein logo and its web shop are seen in this illustration taken, May 16, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
Shein now has its global headquarters in Singapore and its Europe, Middle East and Africa headquarters in Dublin.

In August, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said average selling prices were falling because customers were trading down to cheaper items and buying more essential goods, and that sales of bigger ticket items like computers and electronics were growing “more slowly” than in a robust economy.
Shein has disrupted the fast-fashion industry with its low-cost model and rapid growth.
Shein’s possible initial public offering could help rebuild momentum in London after a string of defections from its stock markets.

site_title: Government to study engaging telcos other than Singtel to provide emergency hotline services
summary: The Singapore government plans to study engaging telcos other than Singtel for emergency hotline services, following a recent islandwide disruption to Singtel's fixed line voice service on Oct 8. The disruption affected the 995 and 999 lines, but there was no public feedback about SCDF or police failing to respond to urgent incidents. Preliminary investigations showed a technical issue led to the disruption, and Singtel is held to a high level of reliability through the government's regulatory framework. The government will consider additional resiliency measures, including telco diversity, to ensure emergency services are not affected by single telco failures.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

Optus has been struggling to repair its reputation since a cyber attack in September 2022 that affected data of more than a million customers and triggered nationwide calls called for tougher privacy rules.
The heavy trading of Singtel shares comes after the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission filed court proceedings against Optus Mobile over allegations of inappropriate sales conduct.
The disruption on Oct 8 lasted for more than three hours before services progressively resumed in the evening.
As Singapore pushes further to enhance the security and resilience of local digital infrastructure, perhaps the government ought to relook its fibre broadband regulatory regime as well.
There were more than 2,500 reports as at 3.10pm on service outage website Downdetector.

site_title:
China approaches record US$1 trillion trade 
surplus to world’s ire
summary: China's trade surplus is projected to reach a record $1 trillion this year, fueled by a surge in exports and a decline in imports. The surplus, which has grown 16% from 2023, has generated pushback from countries like the US, Europe, and South America, leading to increased tariff barriers. The Trump administration is likely to impose tariffs that would reduce exports to the US. China has responded by promising more support for companies, but the growing imbalance in global commerce risks provoking economic tensions.

images.alt_text: Property and infrastructure spending have been the bedrock of steel consumption in China for decades.

site_title: Australia’s HMC Capital to list data centre trust worth A$4 billion
summary: Australia's HMC Capital will proceed with the initial public offering (IPO) of its data centre business, Digico Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit), valued at A$4 billion. The Reit will have 13 data centres and 586 customers, with HMC Capital investing A$500 million for a 19% stake. The IPO, set for December 16, will be the largest in Australia this year, following HMC's acquisition of iseek for A$400 million, which pushed its shares to a record high.

images.alt_text: In Malaysia, which is set to emerge as the largest data centre hub in South-east Asia, the energy capacity is expected to more than treble.
As Big Tech races to grow its data centres needed to expand technologies, locating centres directly on power plant sites has become an attractive option to power up quickly.
KKR started investing in data centres about five years ago.
Hundreds of billions of dollars are being poured into the construction of data centres in the rece to support e er-larger AI models.

site_title: America Inc and its new CEO
summary: US President Donald Trump's re-election has led to a shift in America Inc, making it feel more like a private equity firm than a blue chip company. The country's highly leveraged and short-term nature, with an average hold time of around four years, has raised concerns. This is partly due to the 2010 Supreme Court ruling allowing unlimited corporate spending on campaigns. The outcome has led to Trump's leadership being viewed as an asset to be bought and sold, with implications for the country's direction and future.

images.alt_text: How Trump won

View of the White House as the sun sets the day after the Presidential election, in Washington, DC on November 6, 2024. Donald Trump won a sweeping victory on November 6, 2024 in the US presidential election, defeating Kamala Harris to complete an astonishing political comeback that sent shock waves around the world. (Photo by Ting Shen / AFP)
Trump's campaign is proposing a second, much bigger hike in tariffs; lavish tax cuts; a labour-supply shock in the form of mass deportations; and attacks on the independence of the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Calls to relax EU bank capital rules to grow after Trump win
summary: The European Union and the UK face pressure to delay or soften planned bank capital requirements due to Donald Trump's victory, potentially easing US competition. The rules, set to be implemented simultaneously, aim to safeguard against future crises, but countries have chosen varying timeframes, prompting complaints from banks. The European Banking Federation expects EU and UK regulators to consider a pause or changes to the rules.

images.alt_text: The regulatory shift could bring some relief to investors after a year in which some bank stocks were weighed down by concerns over deteriorating loans.

site_title: COP29 talks stall from start with fight over agenda
summary: COP29 climate talks in Baku have stalled due to disagreements over the agenda, with developing countries pushing for a significant increase in climate finance to help them prepare for worsening climate impacts and transition away from fossil fuels. The talks, which are meant to agree on new funding, are complicated by disagreements over who will pay, who can access the funds, and how much will be offered. The US, which is no longer committed to the Paris agreement under Donald Trump's re-election, is seen as a major obstacle to progress, with China also rejecting proposals to expand the donor pool to include other rich nations and top emitters.

images.alt_text: The ADB has set a long-term cumulative climate finance lending target of US$100 billion between 2019 and 2030.

site_title: Bank of Japan hints at caution on rate hike with no clear December hint
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) hinted at caution on raising interest rates, with no clear indication of a December or January hike. Board members discussed the need for careful consideration, citing uncertainty over the US economy's future course. Over 80% of surveyed economists expect a rate move by January, but the BOJ's decision is still uncertain, with some members suggesting a potential rate hike after assessing US economic developments.

images.alt_text: At the September meeting, the BOJ kept interest rates steady at 0.25 per cent, with Governor Kazuo Ueda signalling it was in no rush to raise borrowing costs further as fears of US recession kept markets jittery and clouded the global economic outlook.

The BOJ's decision on Jul 31 to raise interest rates to 0.25 per cent helped reverse the yen's downtrend, which had fallen to a 38-year low of 161.96 per US dollar on Jul 3 despite multiple rounds of intervention earlier in 2024.

site_title: SoftBank expected to book 287 billion yen profit on IPOs
summary: SoftBank Group is expected to report a 287 billion yen (S$2.5 billion) quarterly profit, boosted by successful portfolio company listings and a stronger yen. The company's robust balance sheet and management's bullish stance on artificial intelligence (AI) are also driving new investment momentum. Analysts anticipate an investment gain of US$3.9 billion for the quarter, with SoftBank's IPOs of Indian companies generating US$0.9 billion and US$1 billion. The company's efforts to manufacture AI chips and invest US$500 million in OpenAI are also being closely watched.

site_title: Singapore proposes anti-scam law to let police order restrictions on bank transfers
summary: Singapore's government proposes a new anti-scam law that allows police to issue restriction orders on bank transfers for individuals who are "reasonably believed" to be targeted by scammers. The Protection from Scams Bill aims to strike a balance between protecting the public and maintaining personal responsibility. This move comes as scam cases rose to 46,600 in 2023, nearly five times the figure in 2019, with many victims being manipulated into voluntarily transferring money to scammers. The proposed law is part of efforts to better protect scam targets who may not believe they are being scammed.

site_title: Singapore’s membership in international bodies must be based on national interests: Vivian Balakrishnan
summary: Singapore's foreign affairs minister, Vivian Balakrishnan, emphasized that the country's membership in international bodies should be based on national interests. He noted that multilateral platforms like the East Asia Summit allow Asean to play a key role, and Singapore may need to say no to other states, even close partners or global superpowers, to protect its interests. Balakrishnan's comments come as Asean and Asia-Pacific countries align with security and economic blocs dominated by major powers, and Singapore seeks to maintain its centrality in regional affairs.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
PM Wong congratulates US president-elect Trump, looks forward to enhancing bilateral relations

Under then-president Trump’s watch, Singapore and the United States had extended their Defence Partnership Agreement, while both countries continued to advance their trade and investment flows in a productive manner, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said.

The positive steps made by Asean and those taken with its external partners come at an important time amid the current geopolitical landscape, said PM Wong at a media wrap-up in Laos.

site_title: Buddhist Bhutan to build ‘mindfulness city’ to woo investment, create jobs
summary: Bhutan, a Himalayan kingdom known for its concept of gross national happiness, plans to build a "mindfulness city" called Gelephu Mindfulness City (GMC) to attract investment and create jobs. The city, spanning over 2,500 sq km, will promote walking and cycling, green spaces, mindfulness-based education, and eco-tourism. The project aims to create 150,000 jobs in the first 7-10 years and over 1 million when completed. Bhutan has launched a fixed-term deposit programme to raise funds and has set a goal of attracting $100 million in investments over 10 years.

images.alt_text: Former Changi Airport Group (CAG) and Surbana Jurong chairman Liew Mun Leong (left) has been appointed as CEO of Bhutan's Gelephu Mindfulness City, while former CAG CEO Lee Seow Hiang (right) has been appointed as a board member.

site_title: Montreal port locks out dockworkers, adding to Canada’s supply-chain woes
summary: The Port of Montreal has been locked out by the Maritime Employers Association after 1,200 union members rejected a 20% pay raise over six years. The lockout will disrupt the port's operations, which handle nearly C$400 million of goods daily, and follows a separate labour dispute on Canada's west coast. The dispute has already disrupted an estimated C$800 million of activity per day. The Montreal Port Authority has asked the government to intervene, while Canadian Labor Minister Steven MacKinnon expressed concerns over the lack of urgency in negotiations.

images.alt_text: The government has resisted calls to interfere in collective bargaining in other disputes, other than offering mediation.

site_title: Top UBS banker in Australia sees role helping ultra-rich invest abroad
summary: UBS expects Australian ultra-rich to invest abroad as their assets grow and they seek diversification. Anthony Sweetman, UBS's Australasia joint country head, notes a continued growth in wealth and demand for wealth services in Australia. The bank's shares reached a high since 2008 last week, driven by trading and cost control progress after integrating Credit Suisse. Sweetman also anticipates more foreign direct investment in Australia, citing the country's attractive growth outlook and demographics.

images.alt_text: UBS is working to raise funds for a US$300 million debt swap for Barbados, which will focus on funding climate-resilient infrastructure.
UBS is pushing ahead with the integration of Credit Suisse.
After the deal, Amex will become the sole owner of Swisscard, with Credit Suisse customers transferring to the existing UBS credit card platform.

site_title: Hamptons lowers UK home price forecast on Labour budget measures
summary: Hamptons International has lowered its UK house price forecast for 2026 to 3.5% due to high interest rates and taxes. The revised forecast reflects a "fragile" and "lacklustre" economy, with Labour's budget measures potentially halting the housing recovery. Tax increases, including employer national insurance contributions and stamp duty on second homes, are expected to slow transactions and hold back house prices. The broker also warns that mortgage costs may remain higher for longer, affecting the housing market's recovery.

images.alt_text: Halifax said average house prices hit a record high of £293,999 (S$504,823), edging past a previous peak of 293,507 in June 2022.

site_title: UK’s Direct Line to cut 550 jobs amid motor insurance woes
summary: Direct Line Insurance Group is cutting 550 jobs, about 5% of its global workforce, due to its underperforming motor insurance arm. The company has been implementing aggressive price hikes to mitigate rising claim costs but has also lost 71,000 own-brand motor customers. CEO Adam Winslow said the turnaround strategy is positive but acknowledges early stages of turnaround are more work. The layoffs will deliver £50 million in cost-savings and the company is working to launch its Direct Line motor insurance brand on price comparison websites.

images.alt_text: The revamp addresses investor concerns about HSBC's ability to thrive amid falling interest rates, rising regional competitors, and the growth of fintechs chipping away at its customer base.

site_title: Greater flexibility needed when government assesses bids for GLS sites
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) should reassess its bidding process for Government Land Sales (GLS) sites to ensure adequate supply across various property segments. Rejection of top bids for sites in Marina Gardens Crescent and Jurong Lake District may signal to developers to avoid bidding unless willing to pay high prices, potentially reducing participation and causing over-stretching in land bids. A more flexible approach, accepting top bids except for outrageously low ones, could promote a stable property market and mitigate the risk of supply shortages.

site_title: Hedge funds shorting Tesla just lost more than US$5 billion
summary: Hedge funds that shorted Tesla have lost over $5.2 billion since the 2024 US presidential election, as the company's shares have surged 30% in the past four months. This is partly due to Elon Musk's endorsement of the president-elect, Donald Trump, and the resulting boost to Tesla's stock price. Despite this, hedge fund manager Per Lekander expects Tesla to feel the sting of Trump's anti-climate policies, which could lead to the elimination of subsidies and government incentives.

site_title: Healthcare specialist Benjamin & Joseph Joins SAS IoT Partner Ecosystem
summary: Benjamin & Joseph, a medical billing innovator, has joined the SAS IoT Partner Ecosystem. This collaboration aims to reduce healthcare costs through the development of SAS' Sherlock AI-driven solution. The partnership addresses errors in medical billing, a significant global concern, and seeks to make medical bills compliant and error-free. SAS' IoT analytics will power Benjamin & Joseph's solution, enabling scalable and transparent AI-driven billing practices.

site_title: China’s ‘Singles Day’ shopping spree in spotlight as spending flags
summary: China's Singles Day shopping spree, a major online shopping event, wrapped up on November 11, with analysts watching for signs of consumption rebound. Despite Beijing's efforts to boost activity, sluggish domestic consumption remains a top issue, with policymakers facing challenges in achieving a full post-pandemic recovery. Analysts expect "solid growth numbers" from this year's event, with sales projected to reach over $222 billion, but warn that promotional campaigns can have negative repercussions on profit margins and brand perception.

images.alt_text: Property and infrastructure spending have been the bedrock of steel consumption in China for decades.

site_title: SIA expects passenger yields to further moderate
summary: Singapore Airlines' net profit for the second quarter of FY2025 plunged 59% to S$290 million, more than halving from the previous year. The airline expects passenger yields to continue moderating due to rising industry capacity and competition. Yield declines were observed across all routes and customer segments, including economy and business class. Despite the decline, the airline remains optimistic, citing a strong outlook for travel demand.

site_title: Trump demands Senate bypass votes to confirm appointees
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is demanding that Republican lawmakers allow him to appoint key officials without a Senate confirmation vote, bypassing the Senate's power to block his administration. Trump's threat comes as the Senate is in the process of choosing its new leader, and he claims that Senate votes can take years to make decisions. Trump has stated that he will use recess appointments to get his nominees through, but Senate Republicans have expressed support for this move, with three senators stating they will do "whatever it takes" to get Trump's nominations through.

site_title: Gold subdued as investors await US data, comments from Fed officials
summary: Gold prices remained nearly flat at $2,683.78 per ounce as investors awaited US economic data and comments from Federal Reserve officials. The upcoming release of key economic data sets, including the US consumer price index, producer price index, and retail sales, is expected to influence the interest rate path. Traders anticipate a 65% chance of another 25-basis-point interest rate cut in December, boosting the appeal of zero-yield bullion.

images.alt_text: The prospect of rate cuts is underpinning gold’s record rally this year.

site_title: Philippines’ Marcos signs tax reform law to lure foreign investment
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. signed a tax reform law to attract foreign investment, lowering corporate income tax rates to 20% and granting more fiscal incentives to qualified companies. The law aims to boost foreign direct investment, which was $6.2 billion in 2024, compared to $159.7 billion in Singapore. The Philippines expects to lose $134 million in tax revenue from 2025 to 2028. The law also includes measures to help firms cope with high power costs and allows for remote work incentives.

images.alt_text: The US is among the Philippines’ biggest export markets and sources of investments from abroad.

site_title: New Bill seeks to simplify, lower costs for company insolvency
summary: Singapore is introducing a revamped Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution (Amendment) Bill to simplify and lower costs for company insolvency. The existing Simplified Insolvency Programme will cease on January 28, 2026, and the new Bill aims to make the application process simpler. The bill modifies two processes under the insolvency programme: simplified debt restructuring and winding-up programmes. The changes are expected to benefit more companies and make the process more efficient. The bill is set to be debated in Parliament and is expected to bring about significant improvements to the country's insolvency process.

site_title: China’s economic rescue plan leaves commodities stuck on pause
summary: China's economic rescue plan, announced with a $1.4 trillion bailout to refinance local government debt, fell short of expected stimulus measures to boost domestic demand. The plan focuses on restructuring debt, freeing up funds for projects, but does not directly address consumption. Raw materials such as copper, iron ore, and crude oil prices fell, while base metals like copper and aluminum may benefit. The economy's matured sectors, such as steel, are unlikely to see significant boost, and structural headwinds from demographics and urbanization may limit the impact of any stimulus.

site_title: Delivery Hero to list Talabat business in Dubai in December
summary: Delivery Hero's Middle East business, Talabat, will list on the Dubai Stock Exchange in mid-December, offering 15% of its shares. The IPO is expected to be one of the UAE's largest this year, with Delivery Hero retaining a majority stake. Talabat plans to pay a minimum dividend of US$100 million in April 2025.

site_title: Booking.com could cut jobs as part of reorganisation plan
summary: Booking.com may cut jobs as part of its reorganisation plan, a review of its organisational structure aimed at improving efficiency and customer-centred innovation. The company employed around 23,600 people as of 2023, and no firm decision has been made on job cuts. The review is specific to Booking.com and not its other brands, with changes expected to include modernising processes, systems, and procurement. Booking Holdings expects to provide more details on the reorganisation in due course, following a 13.6% jump in operating expenses for the third quarter.

Booking's forecast is likely to reignite concerns over a broader slowdown in consumer spending on travel, even though the company’s second-quarter results were solid.

site_title: 696 out of Chuan Park’s 916 units sold on launch weekend at average of S$2,579 psf
summary: Singapore's Chuan Park condo development sold 696 out of 916 units on its launch weekend, with an average price of S$2,579 per square foot (psf). The strong performance is attributed to a lack of new projects in the area and a large pool of potential buyers looking to upgrade. The majority of buyers, 93%, were Singaporeans, while 7% were permanent residents and foreigners. The development is expected to obtain its temporary occupation permit in December 2027.

Chuan Park moves over 60% of units during weekend; Union Square Residences sells about 20% on Saturday

site_title: South Korea state-run think tank sees need to loosen monetary policy
summary: A South Korean state-run think tank has recommended loosening monetary policy due to the country's slowing inflation trend, now at a near four-year low of 1.3% in October. The Korea Development Institute suggests adjusting the degree of restrictiveness in monetary policy to prevent prolonged deflation. This comes after South Korea's central bank cut interest rates for the first time since mid-2020, providing relief to households facing high borrowing costs. The think tank's advice is seen as the views of the finance ministry, and its recommendation may influence the central bank's future policy decisions.

site_title: Oil slips as US storm threat eases, China stimulus disappoints
summary: Oil prices declined on Monday, with Brent crude futures dropping 19 cents to $73.68 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling 25 cents to $70.13 a barrel. The decline followed China's stimulus package, which disappointed investors seeking fuel demand growth. The lack of direct fiscal stimulus suggests policymakers are waiting for the next US administration's policies, shifting market focus to the upcoming Politburo meeting and Central Economic Work Conference.

site_title: New Zealand inflation expectations inch up, stay near 2% target
summary: New Zealand's two-year ahead inflation expectations rose to 2.12% in the fourth quarter, remaining near the midpoint of the central bank's 1-3% target. One-year ahead expectations eased to 2.05%, while the five-year view climbed to 2.24%. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) eased monetary policy in August, citing weak domestic demand, and is expected to lower the Official Cash Rate (OCR) again by 50 basis points on November 27.

site_title: Telemedicine regulations remain valid, no review needed despite MaNaDr case: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Health Minister Ong Ye Kung stated that existing telemedicine regulations remain valid, with no need for review, following the revocation of MaNaDr Clinic's licence. The regulations, coupled with public feedback, enable swift action against offenders. The Healthcare Services Act and Singapore Medical Council guidelines continue to apply to telemedicine, and enforcement measures have proven effective. Ong's statement aims to reassure that the current laws and standards are sufficient to govern the telemedicine industry.

site_title: Toyota aims to ramp up China production in a strategy pivot: sources
summary: Toyota aims to increase vehicle production in China to 2.5 million per year by 2030, a significant increase from its current production of 1.75 million. This strategic pivot contrasts with other global automakers, including Japanese ones, that are scaling back or pulling out of China. Toyota plans to bring its sales and production operations closer together, transferring development responsibility to China-based staff and incorporating local partners' know-how into its cars. This move aims to improve efficiency and speed up product development in China, where domestic electric vehicle makers have gained ground on legacy automakers.

site_title: ADB increases climate finance after US, Japan give world’s first sovereign guarantees
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has increased its climate finance lending target to $100 billion between 2019 and 2030, with the US and Japan providing the world's first sovereign guarantees to underwrite risk for existing loans. The guarantees, worth up to $1.7 billion, will allow the ADB to lend more for climate-related projects, with the first beneficiary being a project in Pakistan to generate sustainable aviation fuel from cooking oil. The move aims to ramp up climate finance available to developing nations ahead of the UN's COP29 climate summit.

images.alt_text: The COP29 negotiations will be held in Azerbaijan as the world continues to emit increasing levels of planet-heating fossil fuels.

site_title: Bangladesh faces reduced power supplies even after Adani payment
summary: Bangladesh is facing reduced power supplies despite making a partial payment to Adani Power, which cut supplies after overdue payments exceeded $850 million. The payment, valued at $170 million, was received by Adani Power, easing pressure from lenders. However, the partial payment does not resolve the crisis, and Adani Power will not halt supplies until talks with lenders are completed. The power shortage increases the risk of blackouts, adding to Bangladesh's financial crisis and potential discontent among the nation.

site_title: No reason not to cut rates in December as of now, ECB’s Holzmann tells paper
summary: The European Central Bank's Robert Holzmann stated that as of now, there is no reason to not cut interest rates in December. However, the decision will be based on data available in December. This comes after the ECB cut interest rates for the third time this year in October, with four sources suggesting a fourth cut in December unless economic data improves.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop as China support plan falls flat, bitcoin hits record
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Monday, with Hong Kong stocks shedding over 2% and Shanghai, Tokyo, and other regional markets following suit. China's plans to support its economy fell short of expectations, failing to announce new growth-boosting measures. Despite this, US stocks continued to rise, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Misinformation fears mount over second Trump term
summary: Donald Trump's election victory has raised concerns about the spread of misinformation, particularly on vaccines and climate change, with his expected cabinet picks likely to challenge the scientific community. False claims aired during the campaign have ricocheted across the internet, with social media influencers amplifying them. Experts warn that tactics to contain misinformation, such as fact-checking and moderation, are not working, and that Trump's administration may legitimize conspiracy theories and undermine democratic institutions. The upcoming four years are expected to be marked by a fresh wave of misinformation, posing a threat to public health and the integrity of democratic processes.

site_title: Shakeup of Indian airlines boosts competition, business seats
summary: India's airline market is undergoing significant changes with two major developments. Vistara, owned by Singapore Airlines, will cease operations and merge with Air India, expanding the combined entity's fleet to 210 jets and 470 on order. Meanwhile, IndiGo, the market leader, is introducing business-class cabins on select routes, aiming to expand its premium offerings and challenge Air India's dominance. The moves are expected to boost competition and improve the quality of services in the market, but may also lead to disruption and changes in customer expectations.

site_title: Bitcoin soars above US$82,000 as Trump win boosts crypto prospects
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's victory has boosted crypto prospects, with Bitcoin surging above US$82,000. The digital-asset industry spent over US$100 million backing crypto-friendly candidates. Trump's campaign promises to create a strategic Bitcoin stockpile and appoint regulators enamoured with digital assets have contributed to the surge. site_title: US ordered TSMC to halt shipments to China of chips used in AI applications: source
summary: The US ordered Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) to halt shipments of advanced chips to Chinese customers used in AI applications starting Monday, November 11. The Department of Commerce imposed export restrictions on certain sophisticated chips, including those used in AI accelerator and graphics processing units (GPU), due to a violation of export controls. TSMC, a law-abiding company, will suspend shipments to affected clients, including Chinese chip designer Sophgo. This move comes amid concerns about the inadequacy of export controls on China and follows similar actions by the US against Nvidia and AMD in 2022.

The gains followed mixed results from US and European markets, where major indices such as the Dow Jones and Stoxx 600 Index registered declines. site_title: If I won the lottery, I wouldn’t tell anyone but there would be signs
summary: A windfall of unexpected wealth can significantly impact an individual's financial future. To make the most of it, they should assess their financial health, including debt levels and emergency funds. Wealth advisory firms advise individuals to pay down loans and build up their Central Provident Fund (CPF) special account, which offers a 4.14% interest rate. They can also consider investing in low-cost instruments, such as globally-diversified exchange-traded funds, or split their funds into two tranches to invest at different times. Ultimately, individuals should identify their risk appetite and balance it with financial security, avoiding both excessive risk-taking and conservative investing that may lead to missed opportunities.

summary: "Venom: The Last Dance" continues to dominate the North American box office, earning an estimated $16.2 million on a slow weekend. The horror film, starring Tom Hardy, has now taken in $114.8 million domestically and $279 million internationally in its three weeks, solidifying its position as a box office powerhouse. Bali attracted nearly three million foreign visitors in the first six months of this year, with tourists spending an average of $1,625 per visit. The move has sparked debate, with some fearing it could hurt tourism-reliant locals and others welcoming the effort to protect the island's environment.

site_title: Thai Airways navigates some turbulence on flight to recovery
summary: Thai Airways International, once ranked among the world's top airlines, is set to exit its rehabilitation program and relist on the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) by mid-2025. The airline filed for bankruptcy protection in 2020 due to decades of mismanagement, corruption scandals, and questionable plane purchases tied to its former status as a state enterprise. Thai Airways has made progress, reporting a profit of 28.2 billion baht in 2023 and continuing to show modest profits in 2024, despite facing increased expenses and operational challenges. The airline plans to double its fleet from 77 to 150 planes in 10 years, capitalizing on Thailand's booming tourism sector.

China's direct investment liabilities dropped $8.1 billion in the third quarter, and $13 billion for the first nine months of the year. US President-elect Donald Trump's second term may further weigh on investment, while Chinese companies are increasing their overseas assets, with outbound investment rising sharply.

site_title: China sets yuan fix at weakest since 2023 amid US tariff risk

China's onshore yuan was little changed, and the PBOC may attempt to reset the yuan at a new equilibrium after incorporating tariffs risk, smoothing out volatility during a US tariffs announcement.

site_title: Cordlife says directors committed to waive fees for FY24; defends choice of auditor ahead of EGM
summary: Cordlife's directors have committed to waiving their fees for the financial year 2024, amid an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Nov 14 to appoint new auditors and approve directors' fees. Non-independent non-executive directors Zhai, Yiu, and Chow will not receive directors' fees, while Chen Xiaoling, redesignated as group executive director, will receive her remuneration. The company defended its choice of auditor PKF-Cap after KPMG declined reappointment.

Unitholders will vote on the appointment of audit firm PKF at Cordlife's EGM on Nov 14.

site_title: Chuan Park moves over 60% of units during weekend; Union Square Residences sells about 20% on Saturday
summary: Chuan Park, a 916-unit condo, saw over 60% of its units sold over the weekend, with 75 units of Union Square Residences sold at Havelock Road on Saturday. The condo's strong performance is attributed to the lack of new projects in the Lorong Chuan area for years, drawing in buyers from nearby established residential areas. The average selling price of Chuan Park's units is over S$2,500 psf, while Union Square Residences' units were priced at S$3,200 psf on average. The sales indicate a strong demand for luxury condos in Singapore.

site_title: What would North Korean soldiers do in Ukraine?
summary: North Korea has deployed around 10,000 soldiers to support Russia's efforts in the Ukraine conflict, with the soldiers reportedly trained in artillery, drones, and infantry operations. US intelligence suggests they will be used in frontline operations, but analysts question their effectiveness and ultimate objectives. South Korean analysts believe the soldiers may be part of special forces, while others consider them cannon fodder. The deployment raises questions about North Korea's combat capabilities, language barriers, and organisational structure, with experts warning that the soldiers' limited experience and cumbersome chain of command may hinder their effectiveness.

site_title: India says oil prices would have rocketed without its Russian imports
summary: India's oil minister, Hardeep Singh Puri, stated that global oil prices would have skyrocketed if the country hadn't bought oil from Russia following the Ukraine war. India, the world's third-largest oil importer, has become the top buyer of discounted Russian sea-borne oil, accounting for two-fifths of its September crude imports. Puri emphasized that India will buy oil from wherever its companies get the best rates, highlighting the country's efforts to keep prices in check.

site_title: US farmers gird for trade wars on Trump tariff pledges
summary: US farmers are bracing for potential trade tensions with China under President-elect Donald Trump, who has threatened higher tariffs on Beijing. The 2018-2019 trade war with China resulted in over $27 billion in US agricultural export losses, with soybeans accounting for nearly 71% of the losses. Trump's proposed tariffs could further impact US farmers, who are still recovering from the previous trade war. The USDA estimates that agriculture and related industries contribute 5.6% to the US GDP and employ 2.6 million jobs.

site_title: Far East Orchard reaps the rewards of its growth strategy
summary: Far East Orchard (FEOR) has reported a significant growth in earnings and revenue, more than doubling to S$16.9 million and 4.5% respectively, in the first nine months of its latest financial year. The group's focus on student housing and hospitality has driven this growth, with earnings and revenue increasing from S$7.6 million and 76.3% of full-year revenue in FY2023. FEOR aims to grow its lodging platform to 25,000 rooms and 5,000 beds by 2025, with plans to expand into other accommodation types and services.

Far East Orchard said that the group’s PBSA portfolio’s reservations stood at 92 per cent for the academic year commencing September 2024, reflecting “strong continued demand” for student accommodation.

site_title: Fonterra to assess IPO as one option for consumer unit sale
summary: Fonterra Cooperative Group will proceed with the sale process for its global consumer businesses, considering both an initial public offering (IPO) and a trade sale. The company aims to achieve a significant capital return for its farmer shareholders, with a valuation report suggesting the businesses could be worth NZ$3.4 billion. Fonterra has received "meaningful buyer interest" and will test the terms and value of both options before seeking farmer shareholder support. A final decision will be based on which option results in optimal long-term value.

site_title: Wall Street bets on new riches ahead in markets all-in on Trump
summary: Wall Street is experiencing a buying frenzy as investors predict a surge in assets following Donald Trump's return to the presidency. Over $2 trillion was added to equities in five sessions, with small-cap companies surging 9% and Bitcoin hitting a fresh record. The everything-boom has fueled a credit bonanza, with more than $20 billion flowing into funds on Wednesday alone, as investors become increasingly bullish on the market. This optimism has led to a market rally, with stocks and crypto experiencing significant gains.

site_title: Trump win boosts demand for credit, with spreads at 1998 low
summary: US President Donald Trump's election win has boosted demand for credit, with average US investment-grade bond spreads narrowing to 75 basis points, the lowest level since May 1998. Analysts attribute this to a swift election resolution and higher Treasury yields, further fueling robust demand for credit. Experts note that spreads have not been this low in the careers of most professionals, indicating a favorable market environment for investors.

site_title: Trump’s threat of renewed tariffs could hit China hard and slash global growth, analysts warn
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced plans to increase tariffs on Chinese goods, which could send shockwaves through global supply chains and slow trade growth. Analysts warn that this could shave 0.5 percentage point off China's economic performance, potentially straining its already challenged economy. The tariffs could also impact Asean's trade flows and heighten economic uncertainty in the region, with some predicting adverse effects on China's growth and trade relationships in the near term.

site_title: Hong Kong finance chief sees growth near lower end of forecast
summary: Hong Kong's economic growth is expected to be near the lower end of its forecast range of 2.5-3.5% for this year, according to Financial Secretary Paul Chan. The city's economy grew 1.8% in the three months ended September, marking the weakest pace in five quarters due to slower exports and spending. The government will announce full-year economic projections and finalised third-quarter GDP data on November 15.

site_title: St Luke’s ElderCare to raise S$30 million for Community Transformation Fund to benefit seniors
summary: ST LUKE'S ElderCare aims to raise S$30 million for the Community Transformation Fund, benefiting over 45,000 seniors over five years. The fund will support initiatives in six areas: innovate, mentor, programme, advocate, connect, and train. The funds will be used to enhance care models, adopt advanced technology, and create thematic hubs for seniors to engage in activities. The goal is to meet the increasing needs of Singapore's ageing population, with one in four citizens expected to be 65 and above by 2030.

site_title: Elon Musk’s net worth tops US$300 billion in wake of Trump victory
summary: Elon Musk's net worth has surpassed $300 billion for the first time in almost three years, following President-elect Donald Trump's victory. Musk's Tesla stock has jumped 28% since Tuesday, increasing his wealth by $50 billion. Trump has expressed support for Musk's businesses, including Tesla and SpaceX, and has floated the idea of Musk serving as efficiency czar in his administration. Musk's fortune is now the highest in history, surpassing his previous record of $340.4 billion in 2021.

summary: SIA Engineering resumes buybacks after reporting H1 FY2025 results, with a total consideration of S$3.4 million over five trading sessions from Nov 1 to 7. Institutions booked a net institutional outflow of S$141 million, with Reits and financial services experiencing the most net outflow, while real estate (excluding Reits) and industrials sectors saw the most net inflow.

site_title: SGX Cares’ charity run, futsal events raise S$2.25 million for beneficiaries
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) raised approximately S$2.25 million for underprivileged children, families, seniors, and persons with disabilities through its charity run and futsal events, SGX Cares Bull Charge. The funds, the highest in recent years, will support beneficiaries such as Awwa, Autism Association (Singapore), and Fei Yue Community Services. The charity run, held at Marina Barrage, attracted 4,500 participants, and the futsal event raised S$137,000, demonstrating the "spirit of giving and solidarity" among corporate partners.

site_title: Heat, air pollution, disease: How climate change affects health
summary: Climate change poses a growing threat to human health, with record-breaking heat, extreme weather events, air pollution, and the spread of infectious diseases. The World Health Organization warns that climate change is "making us sick" and urgent action is a matter of life and death. Heat-related illnesses have increased by 167% since the 1990s, with 700 deaths and over 40,000 cases of heat stroke reported in India. Air pollution affects nearly 99% of the world's population, linked to seven million premature deaths annually. The changing climate also increases the risk of infectious diseases, such as dengue and malaria, as mosquitoes and other vectors expand their habitats.

site_title: US dollar on track for weekly gain after Trump election win
summary: The US dollar index jumped to a four-month high on Wednesday before dipping, and is on track for a weekly gain, following Donald Trump's election as US president. Analysts expect Trump's policies, including trade tariffs and lower taxes, to boost growth and inflation. However, uncertainty over policy implementation remains, leading to market volatility. The dollar index is up 0.58% on Friday and is poised for a 0.68% weekly increase.

site_title: Even at a time like this, slow and steady works in the stock market
summary: The US stock market continues to boom despite concerns about the potential impact of a second Trump presidency. Investors are advised to adopt a slow and steady approach, rather than reacting to short-term market fluctuations. Historically, long-term investors have fared well in the US market, regardless of the timing of their investments. A recent analysis suggests that even investors who invested at the peak of the market have still achieved significant returns, highlighting the importance of diversification and a long-term perspective. As the new administration brings changes to the market, investors are encouraged to stay the course and continue to invest in a diversified portfolio.

site_title: Bolivia eases rules on gold holdings as liquidity crunch bites
summary: Bolivia's central bank has relaxed rules on national gold reserves, allowing it to report its holdings twice a year to access more liquidity. The move aims to address a fuel shortage and high inflation amid an economic crisis. The bank must now report its gold holdings on November 5 and May 5, rather than the usual annual reporting date. This flexibility may enable the bank to drop below the required 22-ton minimum, but it did not confirm plans to sell any gold holdings. The change comes as the country faces a foreign currency shortage and escalating inflation.

DBS, OCBC, and UOB management said they will monitor interest rates to ensure their mortgage rates stay competitive, but did not explicitly mention plans to cut rates. The move comes as foreign banks try to stay competitive in the market.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for November 8, 2024, reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk vessels. The Capesize market improved, with the BCI 5TC index rising to $19,210, driven by robust demand and active trading in the Atlantic and Pacific basins. In contrast, the Panamax market struggled, with rates eroding due to limited demand and charterer dominance. The Ultramax/Supramax market also saw downward pressure, with rates remaining under downward pressure. The Handysize market faced downward pressure, with rates generally dipping below previous levels. The Clean market saw tonnage remain plentiful for MEG LR2 vessels, while MR and VLCC markets experienced downward pressure. The Suezmax market struggled, with rates falling in West Africa and the Middle East. The Aframax market declined, with rates falling in the North Sea and the Atlantic.

site_title: China, Indonesia seal US$10 billion in deals focused on green energy and tech
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto signed US$10 billion in deals during the Indonesia-China Business Forum in Beijing, focusing on green energy, tech, and biotechnology. The agreements include collaborations in new energy vehicles, lithium batteries, and the digital economy, as well as partnerships on global energy transition and industrial chains. The deal aims to improve regional stability and set an example of cooperation over confrontation, with Indonesia committed to supporting Chinese investors and introducing visa measures to facilitate more business interactions.

site_title: Asia, the world’s economic engine, prepares for Trump shock
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's protectionist policies and proposed tariffs could destabilize the global economy, particularly in Asia, which is the world's economic engine. Trump has vowed to slap 60% tariffs on all Chinese goods, but analysts question the feasibility of such high tariffs. A trade war could lead to a "China+1" strategy, with production shifting to countries like Vietnam, Indonesia, and India. However, experts warn that China's competitive advantage in terms of price, scale, and quality is difficult to reproduce, which could lead to a "loss of efficiency" and increased prices, ultimately harming global growth.

site_title: What Trump can do to workers’ Biden-era gains
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's victory is expected to undermine Biden-era gains for workers, reversing historic union contracts and labour protections. Trump's administration, filled with management-side attorneys, is likely to push for deregulation and eliminate safeguards protecting workers. This could include defanging the National Labour Relations Board, eliminating public-sector unions, and loosening labour laws. As a result, workers may need to rely on state and city-level policies to secure gains, while the Trump-appointed Supreme Court could further erode worker protections.

site_title: Female artists set to dominate MTV Europe Music Awards
summary: Taylor Swift, Charli XCX, and Billie Eilish are expected to dominate the 2024 MTV Europe Music Awards, with 10 of the 11 artists with the most nominations being women. Swift is nominated in seven categories, including Best Artist, following the release of her 11th album, The Tortured Poets Department. The ceremony, hosted by Rita Ora, will take place in Manchester, England, on November 10.

site_title: Egyptians exhume the dead as historic cemetery partially razed
summary: Egyptian authorities have partially razed a historic cemetery in Old Cairo to build new roads and bridges, leaving thousands of graves demolished and families with remains exhumed. The City of the Dead, a UNESCO-listed World Heritage site, has been under demolition since 2020. Families, including architect Ahmed el-Meligui, whose grandfather was recently reinterred after being buried 20 years ago, have expressed grief and pain at the destruction. The Egyptian government claims the demolition is necessary for public interest, but critics argue it is a cultural and historical loss.

site_title: Could the bond market stymie Trump’s economic plans?
summary: US bond investors are concerned that the Federal Reserve may lower interest rates despite robust economic growth, potentially fueling inflation. This could temper President-elect Donald Trump's economic plans, which include escalating tariffs and tax cuts, that some fiscal hawks believe could increase the federal deficit and worsen debt. A spike in Treasury yields, with a 70 basis point jump in the 10-year Treasury note, has raised alarm bells among investors, who may push yields higher unless Washington shows fiscal restraint.

site_title: US: S&P 500 breaks 6,000 level as Trump and Fed-fueled rally advances
summary: The S&P 500 briefly broke the 6,000 level and closed with its biggest weekly percentage gain in a year, driven by Donald Trump's election victory and expectations for favorable business policies. A 25 basis point interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve also supported stocks. The Dow Industrials and Nasdaq notched their best weekly percentage gains since early 2023, with the Nasdaq reaching record closing highs for three straight sessions.

site_title: Chicago plans US$1.5 billion bond refinancing in early December
summary: Chicago plans to refinance $1.5 billion in debt through a municipal bond sale in early December, replacing $850 million in general obligation bonds. The deal, which includes a debt buyback process, is expected to save the city $110 million. The refinancing comes as interest rates have risen following the Federal Reserve's rate cut. Pricing for the bond sale is expected to occur in the first week of December, with benchmark 10-year muni yields having risen over 12 points since the refinancing plan was announced.

site_title: Europe: Shares log third week of declines on China, tariff jitters
summary: Europe's benchmark Stoxx 600 closed down 0.6% on Friday, marking its third consecutive week of declines, as China's 10 trillion yuan debt package failed to impress investors. Metal prices retreated, weighing on miners such as Rio Tinto and Glencore. Investors are also concerned about tariffs under a Trump presidency, which hurt economic growth. Defensive sectors like real estate and healthcare performed better.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.7 per cent higher on Thursday, powered by a 2.2 per cent bounce in the tech sector, recouping losses from the previous session.

site_title: Gold logs biggest weekly fall in over five months on dollar strength
summary: Gold prices plummeted 0.8% to $2,684.03 per ounce, marking the largest weekly decline in over five months, due to a stronger dollar and rising interest rate expectations following Donald Trump's victory. This is the latest blow to gold's record rally this year, which has been driven by the prospect of rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Gold prices climbed more than 1 per cent in the previous session, recovering losses suffered after Donald Trump won the US presidential race.

site_title: Bain nears deal to acquire Blackstone’s Avery Lodge
summary: Bain Capital is nearing a deal to acquire Blackstone's Singapore worker dormitory firm Avery Lodge, valued at S$750 million to S$780 million. The deal, expected to be finalized soon, reflects increased investor confidence and economic stability in Singapore, which has seen a 24% rise in transactions this year.

In contrast, China's latest economic stimulus packages failed to boost oil prices, as deflationary pressures on the Chinese economy remain a significant drag on the market. site_title: Authorities probing bigoted text messages that spread alarm across US

Authorities are taking the reports seriously and are aware of the offensive and racist messages.

site_title: Can transformative businesses such as AI reward most investors over time?
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) companies, including Alphabet, Amazon, Meta, and Microsoft, have collectively spent over $600 billion on AI since 2020, but none have yet made a profit. Historically, transformative businesses like automobiles and aviation have proven difficult to predict as winners, with investors often overpaying for stocks. A lesson from these industries is that the key to investing success lies in a company's competitive advantage and durability, rather than its impact on society or growth potential. AI companies' high valuations and uncertain long-term prospects raise questions about their potential to reward investors over time.

images.alt_text: The question for investors is whether they want to grow their money quickly or slowly, while bearing in mind the degree of difficulty and chances of success for each approach.

site_title: How Trump won
summary: Donald Trump has won the US presidential election, securing both the Electoral College and popular vote. His victory is attributed to a nihilistic voter base, craven Republican politicians, and the support of enablers such as Fox News and tech billionaires. Trump's supporters believe his exaggerations prove he is a man of the people, disregarding policy expertise and threats to democracy. The author suggests that a significant chunk of Trump's base wants to see institutions destroyed, and many share his worst instincts, including racism, misogyny, and vulgarity.

site_title: South Korea says North is disrupting GPS for planes, boats
summary: North Korea is causing GPS disruptions for South Korean airplanes and boats, according to the South Korean Defense Ministry. The disruptions began on November 8, affecting dozens of commercial airplanes and several boats. The move is seen as another provocation from the Kim Jong Un regime, which has also been sending balloons across the border this year, dumping trash and propaganda leaflets. The incident comes amid high tensions between the two Koreas and North Korea's involvement in Russia's war against Ukraine.

site_title: China consumer prices rise at slower rate in October
summary: China's consumer inflation rate slowed to 0.3% year-on-year in October, down from 0.4% in September, according to official data. The slowdown comes as authorities seek to boost domestic activity amid a property crisis weighing on confidence. The data also showed factory-gate prices slid 2.9% year-on-year in October, extending a deflationary run that began in late 2022. Despite Premier Li Qiang's confidence in hitting a 5% growth target for 2024, China's economy has seen its slowest expansion in a year and a half.

images.alt_text: Overall food inflation climbed 3.3 per cent in September from a year ago, while the cost of fresh vegetables surged 22.9 per cent.
Food prices in China jumped 2.8 per cent on year in August from an unchanged outcome in July, while non-food inflation was 0.2 per cent, easing from 0.7 per cent in July.
The consumer price index climbed 0.5 per cent from a year earlier, data from the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) on Friday (Aug 9) show.

site_title: Washington financed Colombia's purchase of Pegasus spy software
summary: The US financed Colombia's purchase of Israeli spy software Pegasus for $11 million in 2020, without informing then-President Ivan Duque. The software, which can remotely access phone messages and files, was used to investigate drug traffickers. Colombian President Gustavo Petro denounced the purchase, saying it could be used to intercept communications by politicians and activists. The US had previously terminated the program before Petro took power in 2022, but the official denied any use of Pegasus for spying on politicians. Strict protocols were implemented after the purchase.

images.alt_text: The agreement says the rapidly growing spyware market raises concerns over its impact on national security and human rights, as well as expands the “potential pool of state and non state actors with access” to powerful spying tools.

site_title: UMS Integration Q3 profit slumps 32% to S$10.4 million
summary: UMS Integration, a semiconductor manufacturer, reported a 32% decline in Q3 profit to S$10.4 million due to higher expenses and depreciation. Revenue fell 9% to S$64.9 million, mainly due to weaker global chip demand. However, the company secured new orders from a major customer in Malaysia and plans new product introductions, indicating a promising outlook for the semiconductor industry.
