site_title: Snow seen on Mount Fuji after record absence
summary: Snow finally fell on Mount Fuji on November 6, after a record absence, marking the latest arrival of snow since comparable data became available in 1894. The snowcap's formation typically begins on October 2, but this year it was delayed due to warm weather, beating the previous record of October 26. The Japan Meteorological Agency has not yet announced a new record due to cloud cover at its monitoring station, but photographs from different points around the mountain show a dusting of snow on its peak.

images.alt_text: The town’s struggle with unruly tourists made international headlines as record numbers of tourists headed to Japan over the summer, creating some opposition among locals.
Views of Mount Fuji, a Unesco World Heritage Site, are a real estate selling point in Japan.

site_title: Decision to amend Insurance Act to halt Allianz-Income deal made by PM with Cabinet: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong made the decision to amend the Insurance Act to halt the Allianz-Income deal, a move initially announced by the government in October. Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam clarified that the decision was made by PM Wong and the Cabinet, not just Shanmugam. The deal between German insurer Allianz and local insurer Income was called off due to concerns about its structure and the insurer's ability to continue its social mission. Shanmugam denied overestimating his role in the decision-making process, stating that he was a conduit for former NTUC Income CEO Tan Suee Chieh's views.

site_title: UK economy risks big hit under Trump tariffs plan, think tank says
summary: A UK think tank, National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR), warns that the country's economy could be severely impacted if US President Donald Trump imposes sweeping import tariffs. Growth is expected to slow to 0.4% in 2025 under this scenario, with inflation rising 2-3 percentage points over two years. This could hinder the UK government's plans to boost spending through increased borrowing, and would be a setback for Prime Minister Keir Starmer's promise to turn the economy into the fastest-growing in the G7.

images.alt_text: S&P Global said services businesses’ input costs rose at the fastest pace in three months in October, as did their prices, which had risen by the smallest amount in 43-months in September.
Spending on essential items fell 2.2 per cent, the biggest drop since April 2020, led by spending in supermarkets.
James Dyson is the UK’s wealthiest resident with a fortune of US$21 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

FILE PHOTO: Britain's Secretary of State for Business and Trade and President of the Board of Trade Jonathan Reynolds walks outside Number 10 Downing Street in London, Britain, July 9, 2024. REUTERS/Chris J. Ratcliffe/File Photo

site_title: Singapore to expand autonomous minibus studies with public bus operator
summary: Singapore plans to study and deploy autonomous minibuses on public roads without a driver, starting with a public bus operator partner. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will purchase minibuses to test their safety and reliability. The goal is to address manpower challenges in logistics and public transport sectors, where drivers are hard to hire. Autonomous minibuses could eventually operate without a safety driver, paving the way for fully driverless vehicles in the future.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

Visitors to Sentosa will be able to use their mobile phones to book an autonomous shuttle bus ride to take them to popular destinations such as the Siloso and Tanjong beaches. The shuttle bus service, which was officially launched at an event on 20 Aug 2019, is part of a three-month trial of four such autonomous vehicles (AVs).
In the short term, robots can reduce onsite manpower needs, especially for repetitive and laborious tasks within manufacturing facilities.
A driverless car by Apollo Go, Baidu's robotaxi service, drives past another Apollo Go robotaxi parked on the side of a road in Wuhan, China July 19, 2024.
Sats, SIA Engineering Company and Changi Airport Group have signed a memorandum of understanding to develop autonomous buses for airport staff.
WeRide, known for autonomous taxis, vans, buses and street sweepers, aims to raise as much as US$119.4 million in the IPO.
The company has been investing heavily in developing its own advanced driver-assistance system (Adas) by hiring thousands of engineers since last year.
A demonstration of the cognition level of Horizon Robotics' Journey processor onboard a vehicle.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei ends at 3-week high as markets await US election outcome
summary: Japan's Nikkei index surged 2.61% to a 3-week high at 39,480.67, driven by gains in chip and defense stocks ahead of the US presidential election outcome. The dollar's strength against the yen also boosted Japanese exporters' earnings. Japanese technology stocks rose, with Advantest and SoftBank Group jumping 8% and 5.13%, respectively. Defence stocks, such as IHI and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, also rose, with IHI surging 19.28%.

images.alt_text: Across the region, major indices were mixed at Tuesday’s close, with the Straits Times Index ending up 0.3 per cent or 9.57 points at 3,581.61.

site_title: Toyota keeps profit outlook despite weakness in Japan, China
summary: Toyota Motor maintained its annual profit outlook despite reporting a decline in quarterly operating profit, citing signs of recovery from domestic scandals and major recalls in the US. The company's global car sales took a hit due to low demand, while output cuts were caused by regulatory probes and recalls. Toyota trimmed its sales volume forecast for the fiscal year to 10.85 million units, but plans to return to an annual production pace of 10 million units during the second half. The company's CEO pledged to sell 1.5 million battery EVs annually by 2026, despite walking back previous promises.

images.alt_text: Toyota continues to lose ground in the biggest passenger-car market, where domestic firms dominate in a field saturated by battery EVs
The firms are currently looking to have a working system ready by 2028 and provide it to other automakers.
Carmakers have been at the vanguard of efforts to automate more assembly line processes to trim labour costs and bolster worker safety.
Toyota entered Formula One with their own team in 2002 but never won a race despite having one of the sport’s biggest budgets.

site_title: Thai inflation stays below central bank target for fifth month
summary: Thai inflation remained below the central bank's target for a fifth consecutive month, increasing pressure on the Bank of Thailand (BOT) to continue rate cuts to boost price gains. The consumer price index rose 0.83% in October, missing analysts' expectations, and core inflation remained stable at 0.8%. The BOT is expected to extend its surprise rate cut, with the government seeking more stimulus to boost the economy, which has lagged its neighbors.

images.alt_text: The government is targeting export growth of 2 per cent this year, with the value of shipments expected to reach a record high of US$290 billion.

At the Oct 16 meeting, Thailand's monetary policy committee unexpectedly voted 5-2 to cut the one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 2.25 per cent, the first decrease since 2020. Two members voted to keep the rate steady.
The country’s growth rate has lagged the pace of expansion of its neighbours, growing at an average of less than 2 per cent in the past decade.

site_title: Aramco cuts oil prices to Asia for December after Opec+ delay
summary: Saudi Arabia lowered oil prices for Asia buyers in December, cutting the premium for its flagship Arab Light crude grade by 45 US cents a barrel. The move follows the Opec+ alliance's delay in production increases, aiming to prop up the market amid sluggish demand growth and a global glut. The decision aims to support oil prices, which have struggled due to a fragile economic outlook, with Brent crude trading around US$75 a barrel this week.

site_title: US stock futures, greenback rally in anticipation of second Trump presidency
summary: US stock futures, the greenback, and Asian indexes rallied ahead of a potential second Trump presidency. With 276 electoral votes, Trump is on track to win the presidency, surpassing the 270 needed. The dollar index rose 1.5% due to Trump's vow to impose tariffs, which could push up inflation and interest rates. S&P 500 futures surged over 1% and the 30-year Treasury bond yield rose to 4.6%, testing 2024 highs. Bitcoin also reached a record high, and Trump Media & Technology shares gained 10% in after-hours trading.

images.alt_text: Republican presidential nominee and former U.S. President Donald Trump at the end of his Make America Great Again Rally in Latrobe, Pennsylvania, U.S. October 19, 2024. REUTERS/Brian Snyder

site_title: Bank Indonesia ready to stabilise rupiah as Trump leads
summary: Bank Indonesia is ready to stabilize the rupiah, which has slumped 0.6% to 15,828 against the US dollar, its weakest level in nearly three months, amid Donald Trump's early lead in the US presidential election. The central bank will deploy its triple intervention to target the FX spot, domestic non-deliverable forward, and secondary government bond markets to mitigate volatility. A Trump presidency could lead to higher tariffs, complicating the monetary policy easing path for emerging markets, and prompting some economists to expect a rate pause at Bank Indonesia's upcoming meeting.

images.alt_text: Bond market pressures also may arise from Bank Indonesia possibly delaying further cuts to support the rupiah if the currency underperforms.
The rupiah has been under pressure in October as the market lowered expectations for an aggressive Fed rate cut.
The Indonesian central bank has ample resources to support the rupiah, with its foreign-exchange reserves remaining near a record in September.

site_title: Honda still optimistic about sales despite weak second quarter
summary: Honda has raised its full-year sales guidance to 21 trillion yen despite a weak second quarter, with operating income forecast at 1.4 trillion yen. The Japanese carmaker's shares fell 8.2% after missing analyst estimates. Honda has also slashed jobs and paused production at three plants in China and reported a 14.8% decline in global sales in September. The company may consider adjusting its electric vehicle goals if demand continues to wane, according to CEO Toshihiro Mibe.

images.alt_text: Honda's long-awaited electric van, the N-VAN e:, is set to go on sale in Japan on Thursday (Oct 10), and the automaker expects to launch premium EVs under its 0 series in markets such as North America from 2026.
To move towards electrification, Honda will reduce the production of petrol cars.
Honda said quarterly operating profit totalled 484.7 billion yen (S$4.4 billion) in the April-to-June period.

site_title: Singapore, China companies and authorities ink 15 MOUs to further growth, partnership
summary: Singapore and Chinese companies, along with authorities, signed 15 memorandums of understanding (MOUs) worth over S$60 million at the 7th Singapore-China Trade and Investment Forum. The agreements cover areas such as cross-border trade solutions, construction technology, education services, and healthcare. The forum, attended by over 300 business leaders, aims to boost trade and cooperation between the two countries. The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) sees the platform as a useful avenue for growth opportunities and bilateral partnerships, with a focus on helping Singapore companies expand in China and Chinese partners establish a presence in Singapore and ASEAN.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stresses the importance of the 10 Asean member states maintaining their openness amid the global trade tensions.
In the latest quarterly OCBC SME Index, Singapore's transport and logistics industry’s score rose to 51.2 in Q3, up from 50.6 in Q2.

site_title: Bringing laminates into the limelight
summary: Singapore-based interior design materials supplier EDL has seen significant growth, averaging 14% annual topline growth from FY2020 to FY2024. The company's second-generation leadership, led by directors Daphne, Eleanor, and Desiree Lim, has rebranded to appeal to savvy homeowners, who now directly visit their factory to learn about products. EDL's market perception has shifted, with laminates being seen as a high-quality, durable, and easy-to-maintain option. The company has expanded its product categories, created a fabrication division, and opened new offices in Malaysia and Indonesia, with plans for a fourth office in Penang by 2025.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The products do not contain ingredients such as Vitamin E, retinoids and glycolic acids, which can have harmful side effects, says managing director Quinn Chen.
Over the past year, digital marketing agency Prizm Group has seen a 65 per cent increase in enquiries by Singapore brands about marketing on Xiaohongshu.

site_title: Brookfield in talks with banks to refinance Shanghai towers
summary: Brookfield Asset Management is in talks with banks to refinance a US$700 million loan backing its 2019 purchase of a Shanghai office tower complex. The financing package could include an offshore loan of over US$900 million, while Brookfield has secured a 15-year onshore loan of 2 billion yuan from Bank of China. The refinancing comes amid China's real estate slump, with office vacancies rising to 21.5% in the third quarter. The move aims to address the risk posed by the ongoing economic slowdown and swelling supply.

images.alt_text: The Bethel solar farm in Connecticut, where 2,916 solar panels were installed, reducing annual carbon dioxide emissions by 934 metric tons. PHOTO: BROOKFIELD

site_title: Gold falls as Trump’s decisive election win drives up US dollar
summary: US President Donald Trump's decisive election win drove up the US dollar, causing gold prices to fall by 1.3% to US$2,707.70 an ounce. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index climbed 1.6%, while silver, platinum, and palladium also retreated. A stronger dollar makes bullion pricier for buyers, reducing short-term risk for investors. Analysts see a long-term bullish impact due to US inflationary pressures and currency weakness in China.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was flat at US$2,734.71 per ounce.

site_title: Singapore dollar weakens against US dollar, with the greenback gaining on most currencies as election wraps up
summary: The Singapore dollar weakened against the US dollar, with the greenback gaining around 1.5% against the Singapore dollar, trading at 1.333. This followed a global trend where the US dollar strengthened against the euro, Australian dollar, and yen, rising 1.7% against the yen and 2% against the euro. The US dollar index jumped nearly 1.7% to 105.22, driven by early trading on the first day of US polls.

images.alt_text: Supporters of Democratic Presidential nominee Kamala Harris gather for an election night watch party at Howard University on Election Day in Washington, DC, Nov 5, 2024.

site_title: Manulife US Reit’s portfolio occupancy falls to 77% in Q3
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a portfolio occupancy of 77% in Q3, down from 78.4% in the previous quarter, following the divestment of an office property in Sacramento, California, for US$117 million. The Reit's gearing stands at 54.3% and aims to maintain an optimal hedge ratio of 50-80% as it repays debts. Despite a challenging environment for selling office properties, the manager remains optimistic about the US office sector, citing interest-rate cuts and signs of buyers becoming more active in some submarkets.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
MAS wants to subject all S-Reits to a minimum ICR of 1.5 times, and an aggregate leverage cap of 50 per cent.

Manulife US Reit’s Peachtree asset in Atlanta, US. The Reit's adjusted distributable income for H1 FY2024 is down 27.8 per cent year on year after accounting for higher finance expenses incurred due to higher interest cost.
The divestment of 400 Capitol Mall (above) is expected to complete within the fourth quarter of 2024.

site_title: Altcoins become crypto’s biggest risk trade as US election draws to a close
summary: US presidential election nears, drawing attention to altcoins as potential biggest winners or losers. Bitcoin has gained over 65% this year, while altcoins like Doge and Solana have seen significant jumps, with Doge doubling in 2024. A Trump win is expected to benefit the crypto industry, while a Harris win could lead to increased regulatory crackdown. Market experts anticipate short-term volatility and potential price swings, with some traders hedging against a Harris win while others make bullish bets on Trump.

images.alt_text: Stablecoins are digital tokens designed to keep a constant value.

Open interest on crypto derivatives exchanges – an indicator of market activity – hit an all-time high of US$43.61 billion on Tuesday, as per data provider Coinglass.

site_title: STI climbs on news of imminent Trump win in US election
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% or 21.38 points to 3,602.99, driven by gains in ST Engineering and local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB. Regional indices were mixed, with Nikkei 225 up 2.6% and Kospi down 0.5%. Experts expect muted market reaction to the US election, citing historical performance trends, with the mid-cycle often being muted. The real drivers of the market are seen as the state of the economy and monetary policy cycle.

site_title: Trump wins North Carolina, Georgia, narrowing Harris’ possible path to victory
summary: US President Donald Trump has won the battleground states of North Carolina and Georgia, narrowing Democratic nominee Kamala Harris' possible path to victory. Trump secured 246 Electoral College votes, while Harris had 182, with a total of 270 needed to claim the presidency. The outcome remains uncertain in five other states, and Trump's wins indicate strength across broad swaths of the country, particularly among Hispanic voters and those concerned about the economy.

images.alt_text: epa11704289 Supporters of Democratic Presidential nominee Kamala Harris gather for an election night watch party at Howard University on Election Day in Washington, DC, USA, 05 November 2024. Trump and Democratic presidential candidate US Vice President Kamala Harris, as well as for candidates in Senate and Congressional races.  EPA-EFE/SHAWN THEW

site_title: Asia: Markets rise with dollar, bitcoin as early US results roll in
summary: Asian markets rose with the dollar and bitcoin on Wednesday as traders await the US presidential election outcome, with bets increasing on Donald Trump's victory. The dollar jumped against peers, and bitcoin surged to a March record. Markets in Tokyo, Sydney, and Shanghai rose, while Hong Kong fell. Analysts expect a Trump victory to boost the dollar and Treasury yields. The FBI warned of bomb threats in US states, but none were deemed credible.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 ended 0.1 per cent higher on Tuesday, with most regional markets closing in the green.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 1.0 per cent higher at 42,221.88 on Tuesday.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment’s 9M revenue holds steady at S$2.1 billion
summary: CapitaLand Investment reported a 2% decrease in real estate investment business revenue to S$1.42 billion for the first nine months of 2024, mainly due to divestments in India, Australia, and France. However, its fee income-related business revenue grew 6% to S$845 million. The company met its annual S$3 billion capital recycling target for FY2024, with a near-halving of balance sheet assets. Shares closed 1.4% higher at S$2.91.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
International Tech Park Chennai is an asset owned by CLI. CLI is positive on the growth of the logistics market in South-east Asia amid a limited supply of prime assets in key locations.
CapitaLand Investment received a four-star rating for the standing investments benchmark, a decline from its five-star rating last year.
Club Med is known for its all-inclusive resorts offering a range of leisure activities from fine dining and massages to yoga, scuba diving, and baby gym classes.

site_title: GM recalls some Chevrolet Bolt electric SUVs for a second time
summary: General Motors is recalling 107 Chevrolet Bolt electric SUVs for the 2020-2022 model years due to a risk of catching fire. The recall is related to a software glitch that may fail to notify drivers of defective battery parts. This is the second recall for the Bolt, with a previous recall affecting 142,000 models. The move comes as GM shifts away from a one-type-fits-all battery strategy for its electric vehicles. The company aims to install needed software to resolve the issue as quickly as possible.

site_title: Return-to-office debate: Amazon CEO denies full in-office mandate is ‘backdoor layoff’
summary: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy denied that the company's plan to require employees to be in-office five days a week is a "backdoor layoff" or a cost-cutting measure. The policy, set to begin on January 2, aims to strengthen Amazon's culture and was not driven by city leaders or a desire to reduce costs. Workers who fail to comply may be "voluntarily resigning" and locked out of company computers. Despite concerns about commuting times and efficiency, Jassy said the company is committed to supporting employees with benefits such as commuter benefits and subsidized parking.

images.alt_text: Amazon and other big cloud-computing companies, desperate for power to support their growing operations.
As Big Tech races to grow its data centres needed to expand technologies, locating centres directly on power plant sites has become an attractive option to power up quickly.
Amazon reassures investors with cloud growth, cost-cutting

In August, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said average selling prices were falling because customers were trading down to cheaper items and buying more essential goods, and that sales of bigger ticket items like computers and electronics were growing “more slowly” than in a robust economy.

site_title: Vietnam records US$2 billion trade surplus in October
summary: Vietnam recorded a trade surplus of US$2 billion in October, down from the previous month, as imports grew at a faster rate than exports. Shipments abroad rose 10.1% year-over-year, while imports increased 13.6%. For the January to October period, exports rose 14.9% to US$335.6 billion and imports increased 16.8% to US$312.3 billion.

site_title: Ravi Menon unveils GFTN board to lead Singapore fintech ecosystem and ‘serve a greater purpose’
summary: Former Monetary Authority of Singapore managing director Ravi Menon has unveiled the Global Finance & Technology Network (GFTN) to lead Singapore's fintech ecosystem. The board will be guided by an international advisory board, aiming to drive greater synergies within the global finance and technology communities. Menon described GFTN as a "milestone in the global fintech movement" and a "next phase" in Singapore's fintech journey.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
One key programme at SFF is The Founders Peak, a platform for start-up founders to connect and exchange insights through activities like mentorship sessions and masterclasses.
Discussions from previous editions have led to initiatives in cross-border payments, asset tokenisation and green finance.
Ravi Menon will chair the board of directors of the Global Finance & Technology Network established by the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Bank of Japan saw positive economic signs even as it signaled pause: September minutes
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) kept interest rates steady at 0.25% in September, despite positive economic signs, due to global market uncertainties. Governor Kazuo Ueda signaled a pause in raising borrowing costs, citing fears of a US recession. Policymakers agreed the economy was making progress in meeting conditions for rate hikes, with many seeing wages as a key driver of inflation. A slim majority of economists expect the BOJ to forgo a rate hike this year, with most predicting one by March.

images.alt_text: The final au Jibun Bank Service purchasing managers’ index dropped to 49.7 in October from 53.1 in September, according to an index publisher S&P Global Intelligence.

site_title: Prudential posts 11% rise in 9-month new business profit
summary: Prudential, an Asia-focused insurer, recorded a 11% rise in new business profit for the first nine months of fiscal 2024, reaching US$2.3 billion. This growth was driven by its multi-channel distribution model, with broad-based profit growth in Greater China, Asean, and Africa. Annual premium equivalent sales rose 7% to US$4.6 billion, with growth in Hong Kong, mainland China, and Thailand, but moderating in Taiwan. The insurer expects 2024 new business profit growth of 9-13%.

Singapore life insurers' capital buffers are expected to stay strong in the months ahead. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

Australia’s property sector is growing as a source of deals for private credit lenders as commercial real estate transactions rebound and local banks become more risk adverse to property exposure after regulators last year imposed stricter capital rules for development and construction loans.

Meanwhile, Singtel's shares rose 1.3% after a report revealed a China state-linked hacking group breached the telco giant in June, potentially testing for future cyberattacks.

site_title: Super Micro slips on sales outlook that falls short of estimates
summary: Super Micro Computer reported a sales forecast that fell short of analysts' estimates, with revenue expected to be $5.5 billion to $6.1 billion in the current quarter. The company missed an August deadline to file its annual financial report and has seen its auditor, Ernst & Young, resign due to concerns over governance and transparency. The shares dropped 10% in extended trading, with the company unable to predict when it will file its delayed financial statements.

images.alt_text: Scrutiny has intensified on Super Micro since former employee, Bob Luong alleged earlier this year in federal court that the company had sought to overstate its revenue.

site_title: Musk now says it’s ‘pointless’ to build a US$25,000 Tesla for human drivers
summary: Elon Musk appears to have admitted that Tesla dropped plans for a human-driven $25,000 electric vehicle, stating that building such a car would be "pointless" unless it was fully autonomous. This admission comes six months after Reuters reported Tesla scrapped plans for the affordable EV. Musk's comments contradict earlier statements, and the move may have contributed to Tesla's stock recovering some losses after the initial report.

images.alt_text: Gruenheide, Tesla’s only European gigafactory, employs around 12,000 staff.
Tesla shipped 68,280 Model 3 sedans and Model Y sport utility vehicles last month, down 5.3 per cent year on year and a sharp 23 per cent contraction from September.
This is not Tesla’s first foray into solar asset-backed securities.
Prices of raw materials used to make EV batteries have been falling and Tesla has said its costs will decline as a result this year, with the effect diminishing over time.

site_title: HSBC already fears new downsized London HQ will prove too small
summary: HSBC is two years away from relocating to a smaller City of London headquarters, but executives are concerned the space may not be big enough. The bank initially signed for 570,000 square feet but has since exercised its option to take the entire 1.1 million square feet it currently rents at 8 Canada Square. HSBC may consider leasing additional space or taking up space in another building to meet its needs, as companies are challenging pandemic-era projections of shrinking office footprints.

site_title: Nvidia rides AI wave to pass Apple as world’s largest company
summary: Nvidia surpassed Apple as the world's largest company, with a market capitalization of US$3.43 trillion, after its shares rose 2.9% to US$139.93. The company has soared over 850% since 2022, driven by the growing demand for artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure. Analysts expect Nvidia's revenue to more than double in its current fiscal year, with AI plays contributing significantly to the company's growth. The AI boom is expected to continue, with Nvidia benefiting the most, according to industry experts.

summary: Japan's service sector activity contracted in October due to weaker sales, with the final au Jibun Bank Service Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping to 49.7 from 53.1 in September. This marks the first time the PMI has fallen below the 50.0 threshold separating expansion from contraction since June. Business confidence also slipped to its lowest level since March 2022, citing labor shortages.

site_title: Great Eastern posts 52% higher Q3 profit of S$273.4 million
summary: Great Eastern posted a 52% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$273.4 million for Q3 FY2024, driven by contributions from its insurance business and favorable investment performance. Total weighted new sales fell 7% to S$390.8 million, primarily due to lower single premium sales. The company's new business embedded value increased 7% to S$176.9 million.

site_title: PBOC head vows to boost China countercyclical monetary measures
summary: China's central bank chief, Pan Gongsheng, pledged to maintain an accommodative monetary policy stance and increase countercyclical adjustments to support the country's economic growth. He emphasized the need for strengthening regulatory oversight to prevent financial-system risks. The comments come ahead of the National People's Congress (NPC) Standing Committee, where investors are watching for signs of new stimulus to revive the world's second-largest economy.

images.alt_text: Pan Gongsheng Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Europe: Shares edge higher with US election in spotlight; AstraZeneca sinks
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 ended 0.1% higher on Tuesday, driven by gains in the industrials sector. However, healthcare shares declined 2% following a report on AstraZeneca's China unit being implicated in a large insurance fraud case. The US presidential election, with Republican Donald Trump as the frontrunner, also had a significant impact on the market. Analysts predict a positive outcome for Trump, which could benefit US domestic equities but harm European and international equities.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 1.0 per cent higher at 42,221.88 on Tuesday.

site_title: New Zealand Q3 unemployment hits 4-year high, more rate cuts coming
summary: New Zealand's unemployment rate rose to 4.8% in the third quarter, a near four-year high, as employment dropped by 0.5% and job participation rate fell to 71.2%. The rate increase is consistent with the view that inflation pressures are easing, leading to expectations of more interest rate cuts from the Reserve Bank of New Zealand. The central bank has already cut rates by 75 basis points and markets predict another 50 basis points cut at its next meeting on November 27.

site_title: Paramount gave up on Warner Bros merger after months of talks
summary: Paramount Global abandoned its merger talks with Warner Bros Discovery after months of discussions, according to a regulatory filing. The decision was reportedly influenced by lower-than-expected financial results in May 2023. Paramount had initially explored a merger with at least 12 alternative bidders, including Warner Bros. The company ultimately agreed to a merger with Skydance Media in July. The filing provides insight into Paramount's failed attempt to find a buyer or partner, highlighting the challenges faced in the merger process.

site_title: Nintendo’s next console will play current Switch games
summary: Nintendo's next console will be compatible with current Switch games, addressing concerns about the company's ability to sustain its past success. The new console will also support online gaming services, with further details to be released later. The announcement comes as the Switch faces declining sales and profit forecasts, with Nintendo cutting its full-year profit and sales expectations. The company's stock rose 4.7% following the announcement, and analysts see the move as a positive step for investors and users.

images.alt_text: Nintendo's struggled to maintain sales of game hardware and software as consumers await an announcement on a successor for the seven-year-old Switch.

site_title: Record high US$15.9 billion spent on US election campaigns
summary: The 2024 US presidential election has become the most expensive in history, with total contributions reaching $15.9 billion. Vice-President Kamala Harris led fundraising among the Democratic candidates, directly raising over $1 billion, while Donald Trump's campaign raised $382 million directly. The largest donors included Timothy Mellon ($197 million) and major supporters like Elon Musk, Richard Uihlein, and Kenneth Griffin. Meanwhile, $10.5 billion has been spent on campaign ads, with Harris and Trump campaigns spending $2.6 billion and $993 million, respectively.

site_title: Germany’s Deutsche Bank pumps 51.1 billion rupees into India operations
summary: Deutsche Bank has infused 51.1 billion rupees (S$807 million) into its Indian operations to support growth plans, increasing the capital at its branches to nearly 300 billion rupees, a 33% increase from 2023 levels. The move comes as the Indian economy is expected to grow at 7.2% in the financial year ending March 2025, attracting foreign lenders to expand operations in the country.

site_title: BT Future of Finance: Revolutionising ASEAN connectivity - UOB’s digital banking innovations
summary: Singaporean bank UOB is revolutionizing ASEAN connectivity through its digital banking innovations. The initiative aims to enhance financial integration across the region. UOB's digital banking innovations focus on streamlining transactions and improving access to financial services. The move is seen as a step towards promoting economic growth and development in ASEAN. By leveraging technology, UOB hopes to increase financial inclusion and provide more opportunities for businesses and individuals in the region.

site_title: Trump votes and says this will be his last campaign
summary: Former US President Donald Trump cast his ballot in the presidential election, stating it may be his last campaign, regardless of the outcome. Trump expressed confidence in his team and believed the election should be fair, but also raised concerns about voting machines and ballot counting. He urged supporters to avoid violence, despite his own past rhetoric on the matter. Trump's wife, Melania, declined to comment on whether she voted for him.

site_title: Perplexity raising new funds at US$9 billion valuation: source
summary: Perplexity, a search startup backed by Amazon founder Jeff Bezos and chip designer Nvidia, is raising new investment valued at US$9 billion, according to a source. The company, which provides information by searching the internet, will receive US$500 million in funding led by venture capital firm Institutional Venture Partners. This new funding round comes as investors are drawn to artificial intelligence companies, following the success of OpenAI's ChatGPT. Perplexity has previously raised US$73.6 million in Series B funding, valuing the company at US$520 million.

images.alt_text: Unlike ChatGPT or Anthropic’s Claude, Perplexity’s tool provides up-to-date answers that often include links to source materials, allowing users to verify information.

site_title: FLCT posts 5.7% drop in H2 DPU to S$0.0332 despite higher revenue
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) reported a 5.7% drop in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0332, despite an 8.4% increase in revenue to S$230.6 million. The full-year DPU declined 3.4% to S$0.068. Higher property expenses and financing costs attributed to increased interest rates and borrowings drove the decline. Despite this, FLCT's core logistics portfolio showed strength, with 94.5% portfolio occupancy and a weighted average lease expiry of 4.2 years.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares began trading on Wednesday, November 6, 2024, in positive territory, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.5% or 18.37 points at 3,599.98. The STI was influenced by overnight gains in international markets, particularly in the US, where Wall Street stocks ended higher on the day of the presidential election. Gainers outnumbered losers 77 to 32, with MM2 Asia being the most actively traded counter by volume.

site_title: Russia plotted to put incendiary devices on cargo planes, officials say
summary: Russia plotted to put incendiary devices on cargo planes, targeting Western Europe and potentially the US, according to Western officials. The plot, orchestrated by Russia's military intelligence agency, involved planting devices at DHL shipping hubs in Germany and England, setting off fires with minimal damage. The operation is believed to be an escalation of Russia's sabotage efforts against Western adversaries, aimed at inflicting damage on the West for its support of Ukraine's military.

images.alt_text: The move is the latest step in a so-far unsuccessful push to clamp down on the flow of microchips, machine tools and advanced electronics via third countries that continue to supply Russia’s defense-industrial base.

site_title: Coupang falls after disappointing retail sales in third quarter
summary: Coupang's stock fell 8.9% in late trading after reporting retail net sales that missed Wall Street's expectations, totaling $6.14 billion, below estimates of $6.24 billion. Despite a strong beat on other metrics, including 27% net revenue growth, the disappointing sales overshadowed the company's progress. Coupang's sales growth remains in the double-digit range for the seventh consecutive quarter, driven by its food delivery business. The company's stock has climbed 66% this year, aided by its first full year of profit in 2023.

site_title: Oil prices steady ahead of US election results
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Tuesday, with Brent crude settling at $75.53 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $71.99 a barrel, ahead of the US presidential election results. A storm in the Gulf of Mexico and a weakening US dollar also contributed to the price increase. Analysts expect the election outcome to be uncertain, potentially leading to market volatility.

site_title: How digital banking drives regional connectivity
summary: Digital banking is driving regional connectivity in Southeast Asia, generating over $100 billion in revenue in 2023. The Asean region leads the world in digital payment adoption, contributing two-thirds of global digital wallet spend. Digital banking enhances financial inclusion, supports cross-border trade, and fosters regulatory harmonization, creating opportunities for economic integration and growth. With a population of over 675 million, the region's potential for the digital economy is vast, and digital banking is poised to play a significant role in its development.

site_title: US: Stocks push higher in Election Day session
summary: US stocks rose on Election Day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1.0% to 42,221.88, the S&P 500 up 1.2% to 5,782.76, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.4% to 18,439.17. Despite uncertainty surrounding the presidential election, forecasters say the economy has held up, with stocks in consumer discretionary and industrial sectors leading the gains. Large tech equities, including Netflix, also advanced, while Boeing dropped 2.6% following a machinist union's acceptance of its contract offer.

site_title: Serving new economy businesses with future-focused payment and trade solutions
summary: HSBC has introduced services to support new economy businesses with global ambitions, particularly in the tech sector. The bank partnered with Multiplier Technologies, a platform that enables companies to hire and manage employees globally. HSBC's global reach and understanding of complex payment landscapes met Multiplier's stringent requirements, providing invaluable support. The partnership has been instrumental in Multiplier's success, according to Co-Founder and Chief Product Officer Vamsi Krishna, enabling the company to deliver its vision of a world without limits for businesses to access global talent.

site_title: Banks tout all-night US credit trades as election results come in
summary: Banks are preparing for late-night US credit trades as the presidential and legislative elections conclude, with JPMorgan's derivatives trading desk set to be staffed all night for CDX trading. The bank expects a Republican sweep to benefit sectors such as banks, industrials, and transportation, while a Democratic victory would be beneficial for sectors like utilities and capital goods. Pricing in US fixed-income markets is closely resembling the 2016 Trump victory, with average investment-grade bond yields at 83 basis points over Treasuries and risk premiums on junk bonds widening to 279 basis points.

site_title: Apple to face first EU fine under bloc’s Digital Markets Act
summary: The European Union is set to impose its first fine under the Digital Markets Act on Apple, following a warning in June that the company must give developers effective means to steer users away from its App Store. The fine, potentially up to 10% of Apple's global annual sales, comes after Apple failed to comply with the rule. This marks an escalation of a clash between regulators and Apple over the dominance of its App Store. The fine could be accompanied by periodic penalty payments until Apple complies with the law.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has exhibited haphazard trade policies before.
Apple’s US$3,499 Vision Pro headset, released in February, is seen as too cumbersome and expensive to become a mainstream product.

The company’s largest purchase to date was the US$3 billion acquisition of Beats in 2014.

site_title: Digital assets have wide range of benefits and harmonising regulations is key to wider adoption
summary: Regulators are crucial in implementing measures to shield consumers from market manipulation and fraud in digital assets. Harmonizing regulations is key to wider adoption, with Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Hong Kong leading the way. Digital assets offer numerous benefits, including increased efficiency, diversification, and higher returns, but public acceptance remains a challenge. Regulators must provide clear, consistent frameworks to guide businesses and investors while fostering innovation, and international collaboration is necessary to harmonize standards and facilitate cross-border transactions.

site_title: Yum Brands reports surprise fall in global sales amid KFC’s struggles in US
summary: Yum Brands reported a 2% fall in worldwide same-store sales, driven by KFC's 5% decline in US same-store sales for the third consecutive quarter. The company attributed the decline to sluggish demand in the US and choppy international sales, particularly due to boycotts related to Israel's war in Gaza. In contrast, Taco Bell's US same-store sales rose 4% for the 11th consecutive quarter.

images.alt_text: KFC parent Yum Brands reported a profit of US$1.35 per share for the quarter ended Jun 30, edging past estimates of US$1.33.
Consumers are relying on cheaper, home-cooked meals instead of eating out as fast food prices have risen over the past year, hurting traffic at Burger King and others in the restaurant industry.

site_title: Apollo assets reach US$733 billion with boost from wealth clients
summary: Apollo Global Management reported a 16% increase in assets under management to $733 billion, driven by a boost from wealthy clients. The firm posted adjusted net income of $1.13 billion, beating analyst estimates, and saw asset management fees rise 10% year-over-year. Apollo aims to raise at least $150 billion for its global wealth business by 2029, exceeding its 2023 total capital raised from wealthy individuals.

images.alt_text: Apollo is targeting to raise at least US$150 billion for its global wealth business by 2029.
Blackstone has more than US$90 billion of investment-grade private credit assets, up roughly 40 per cent from a year ago.
Under chief executive officer Pat Gelsinger, Intel has been working on an expensive plan to remake itself and bring in new products, technology and outside customers.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as Americans head to polls
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Tuesday as voting began in the presidential election, with traders anticipating volatile trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 40.9 points, or 0.10%, to 41,835.49, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased. Market sentiment is influenced by the uncertain outcome of the election, which may impact investor confidence and trading decisions.

site_title: Ferrari’s core profit rises 7%, helped by product mix, personal touches
summary: Ferrari reported a 7% increase in core earnings for the third quarter, driven by a richer product offer and strong demand for personalization. The luxury sports car maker attributed a 60 million euro positive contribution to the quarterly result from new high-end models and limited series sales. Ferrari confirmed its full-year forecasts, including Ebitda reaching at least 2.5 billion euros, and expects shipments in the fourth quarter to be above last year's level.

images.alt_text: The hybrid butterfly-door F80 is a highlight in Ferrari’s model roll-out strategy aimed at keeping its wealthy customers engaged, as it prepares to launch its first and so far highly secretive purely electric car at the end of next year.
Ferrari has recently unveiled a new factory in Italy where it will build the company’s first all-electric super-car as well as other hybrid models.

site_title: How Prudential is harnessing AI to shape the future of life and health insurance for every customer
summary: Prudential Singapore is harnessing artificial intelligence (AI) to provide personalized insights and support for customers and financial representatives. AI can analyze customer data to offer tailored recommendations, improve efficiency in underwriting and claims processing, and automate policy document processing. The insurer is also using AI-powered chatbots, such as PRUChat and Grace, to offer seamless customer experiences. Prudential is committed to responsible AI adoption, adhering to principles of fairness, ethics, accountability, and transparency. The company has launched the Prudential AI Lab, a global hub for accelerating AI development and adoption, to shape the future of life and health insurance.

site_title: SingPost’s H1 profit rises 97.3% to S$22.6 million; declares higher interim dividend of S$0.0034 per share
summary: SingPost's net profit for the first half of the year rose 97.3% to S$22.6 million, driven by revenue growth in its Australia and Singapore segments. The company's group revenue increased 20% to S$992.4 million, with earnings per share (EPS) excluding distributions to perpetual securities holders rising 181.5%. SingPost declared a higher interim dividend of S$0.0034 per share, representing an 89% year-on-year increase. The company attributed revenue growth in its Australia and Singapore segments to the consolidation of Border Express and a postage rate increase in Singapore.

site_title:
DBS doubles down on financial wellness to
tackle Asia’s ageing needs
summary: DBS Bank is doubling down on financial wellness to tackle Asia's ageing needs, with a focus on enabling more retail individual investors to plan earlier and invest more. The bank aims to quadruple the number of customers who can access its financial advice and solutions in Asia by 2027. DBS is leveraging AI and technology to provide personalized insights and advice, and has launched Asia's first retirement portfolio that automatically calibrates asset allocation and allows investors to automate their drawdowns. The bank believes that financial literacy, investment affordability, and economic sustainability are key to bridging the financial gap, and will use open banking architecture and "fractionalisation" to empower individuals to better understand their financial health and plan their finances holistically.

site_title: Bank Negara Malaysia set to manage market volatility, monitoring US election
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia is closely monitoring the US presidential election and prepared to manage market volatility. The country's diversified economy and strong fundamentals are expected to provide buffers against external uncertainties. Malaysia's central bank noted that the US election could affect financial markets, but its economic structure and growth prospects are expected to mitigate any impact. The bank will continue to closely monitor global developments to ensure orderly market conditions.

site_title: Transforming the banking experience with generative AI
summary: OCBC bank is leveraging generative AI (GenAI) to transform the banking experience, with the potential to add $200-340 billion in value to the global banking sector annually. The bank's AI Lab unit, established in 2018, has expanded to use GenAI across revenue generation, productivity improvement, and risk reduction. OCBC has rolled out a GenAI chatbot, OCBC GPT, which assists employees with writing, research, and ideation, and is also integrating specific AI tools with key functions within the bank. The bank plans to use GenAI to improve customer satisfaction, decision-making, and employee experience, with a goal of enabling customers to interact with banks using conversational language and receive personalized service.

site_title: What’s next for financial services in AI and tech
summary: Financial services in AI and tech are rapidly evolving, offering opportunities and risks. Industry leaders from DBS, UOB, Prudential, HSBC, and OCBC emphasize the importance of balancing innovation with precautions to protect customer interests. They highlight the benefits of AI in providing personalized experiences, increasing transparency, and identifying potential ESG risks. However, they also stress the need to guard against biases in algorithms, protect sensitive data, and develop robust governance frameworks to maintain trust. By striking a balance between automation and human oversight, financial services can leverage AI responsibly and effectively.

site_title: Amos Group loses free float, extends offer closing date to Nov 21
summary: Amos Group, a Singapore-based offshore oil and gas equipment manufacturer, has lost its free float after its controlling shareholder, PeakBayou, extended its S$0.07-a-share privatisation offer to November 21. The offer represents a 32.1% premium over Amos' last traded price and a 55.6% premium over the volume-weighted average price (VWAP) per share for the past month. As the offeror and parties acting in concert hold more than 90% of shares, trading in Amos Group's shares may be suspended by the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading.

site_title: Thomson Reuters reports higher third quarter revenue
summary: Thomson Reuters reported higher than expected third-quarter revenue of $1.72 billion, driven by increased spending on generative AI investments. The company is allocating more than $200 million for AI investments in 2024, up from $100 million in 2023. Thomson Reuters now has approximately $10 billion to spend on potential acquisitions through 2027. The company's adjusted earnings per share was reported at 80 cents.

images.alt_text: Thomson Reuters' operating profit fell 50 per cent to US$415 million, falling short of expectations of US$463 million.
The New York Times now has a total of 11.1 million subscribers, including print and digital, meeting forecasts.

site_title: Is political polling broken?
summary: US presidential polls face credibility concerns due to non-response bias, as a small percentage of respondents often dominate the sample, introducing bias and misrepresenting the views of the broader electorate. Pollsters rely on statistical adjustments, but it's unclear if these adjustments accurately account for demographic disparities. To restore confidence in polling, experts suggest diagnosing non-response bias more accurately, using tools such as comparing polls with typical respondents to those that incentivize participation. This approach can help identify potential issues and improve the accuracy of election forecasts.

site_title: Can India become a developed economy by mid-century?
summary: India aims to achieve developed-country status by 2047, but achieving this goal will require key structural reforms and streamlining regulations. The country's education system, labour laws, trade policies, and regulations are major weaknesses that must be addressed. Conservative estimates suggest India's per capita income growth needs to outpace China's by 3.5 percentage points each year to meet the target. The government must overhaul its education system, relax labour laws, and promote trade and exports to sustain growth momentum over the next two decades.

images.alt_text: India must exploit its strengths, including its human resources, which give the country the capacity to diversify and upgrade the economy over time.

India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has highlighted economic growth as one of his biggest achievements in election rallies and has “guaranteed” making the economy the third largest in the world from fifth now if he wins a third term in a row as polls predict.
Singapore's long-term urban planning and contingency plans for different scenarios are relevant for India as it plans its future.

site_title: Hugo Boss seeks to grow in China despite weak demand
summary: Hugo Boss delays 2025 revenue and profit targets due to weak demand in China, where a property slump and job insecurity have impacted consumer spending. Despite this, the company aims to expand its limited exposure to China and build brand visibility. Hugo Boss plans to focus on bigger stores and investing in social media platforms like TikTok to deliver a better customer experience. The company remains cautious given the uncertain near-term outlook for consumer sentiment in the region.

images.alt_text: The luxury sector is grappling with weaker sales and margin pressures as inflation-hit shoppers cut back spending on designer fashion.

site_title: Canada posts higher-than-expected trade deficit in September on lower prices
summary: Canada posted a higher-than-expected trade deficit of C$1.26 billion in September, its seventh consecutive monthly deficit, primarily driven by a 1.5% decline in the value of lower exports to major countries, mainly due to lower prices of crude oil and other commodities. In volume terms, exports rose 1.4%. The trade deficit was led by a fall in exports to countries other than the US, its largest trading partner.

images.alt_text: The headline business activity index rose to 50.4 from 46.4 in September, moving above the 50 threshold for the first time since May.

Rents across Canada have been setting records in recent years as a surge in immigration boosted demand.

site_title: Tesla increases wages for staff at German gigafactory by 4%
summary: Tesla has raised wages for all employees at its German gigafactory by 4% starting from November, affecting around 12,000 staff. This hike comes a month after the company announced permanent jobs for 500 temporary workers. The move does not involve German union IG Metall, which has criticized working conditions at the site. The increase is seen as a positive step for the company, although the reasons behind the wage hike are not specified.

This is not Tesla’s first foray into solar asset-backed securities.
BYD is on track to meet its revised annual sales target of four million vehicles.
Prices of raw materials used to make EV batteries have been falling and Tesla has said its costs will decline as a result this year, with the effect diminishing over time.

site_title: Walmart, other US retailers import fewer Christmas goods ahead of tepid holiday season
summary: Walmart, the world's biggest retailer, has significantly reduced Christmas imports, shipping at least 340,000 kilos of "Christmas" goods into the US in the 12 months ending September 30. This is a sharp decline from the prior year, when Walmart imported over 1.9 million kilos of Christmas products. The reduced imports are attributed to an expected tepid holiday season, with some retailers adopting a cautious approach ahead of the festive period.

images.alt_text: The Waltons have longed ranked at or near the top of the world’s richest families, and currently have a total net worth of more than US$350 billion.

site_title: Banking on AI for a smarter future
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming the financial services industry, enabling deeper client relationships, greater financial inclusion, and enhanced trust. While efficiency and automation are AI's immediate impact, its true potential lies in empowering customers with personalized financial guidance and institutions with insights to make better decisions. However, balancing personalization with trust is crucial, as AI algorithms can sometimes feel impersonal. Successful deployment of AI hinges on integrating its tools into a broader, relationship-driven service model that enhances trust, rather than diminishing it. Financial institutions must also address the ethical considerations of AI use, ensuring transparency, accountability, and bias-free decision-making.

site_title: Canada’s services PMI shows return to growth in October
summary: Canada's services sector economy expanded for the first time in five months in October, according to S&P Global Canada services PMI data. The headline business activity index rose to 50.4 from 46.4 in September, surpassing the 50 threshold for the first time since May. This indicates a return to growth in the sector, driven by increased new business volumes and improved confidence in the outlook.

images.alt_text: The S&P Global Canada Manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) rose to 51.1 in October from 50.4 in September, its highest level since February 2023.
Canada’s economic growth has slowed under the weight of high borrowing costs, which have throttled business investments and output and consumer demand.
Rents across Canada have been setting records in recent years as a surge in immigration boosted demand.

site_title: Trump vs Harris: US voters head to polls as turbulent campaign concludes
summary: US voters cast ballots in the highly polarized presidential election between Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Kamala Harris, with the outcome uncertain despite billions in spending and months of campaigning. The candidates' visions for the country are sharply different, with Harris urging Americans to come together and warning of a second Trump term threatening democracy, while Trump employed dark rhetoric and made false claims about widespread fraud. The winner may not be known for days, with slim margins in key states expected. History will be made regardless of the outcome, with Harris becoming the first woman, Black woman, and South Asian American to win the presidency.

images.alt_text: Regardless of who wins the presidency, investors should look beyond short-term volatility and focus on long-term secular trends.
Their closing arguments mirrored, in tone and in substance, the competing visions they have offered a deeply divided nation.

site_title: Achieving more efficient and compliant cross-border payments
summary: Global cross-border payment flows are projected to surge from almost US$150 trillion in 2017 to over US$250 trillion by 2027, driven by Asia's digitally savvy middle class. To achieve seamless global payments, three mindset shifts are necessary: co-opetition between commercial banks and fintechs, the continued indispensable role of commercial banks, and fostering a global level playing field. Co-opetition can be seen in initiatives such as Project Nexus, which standardizes domestic instant payment systems, while commercial banks can collaborate to route client payments through each other's networks. Harmonizing payment regulations and standards across jurisdictions is also crucial.

site_title: When GenAI meets sustainability
summary: Genetic Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) can be harnessed to provide sustainability solutions, driving sustainable sourcing in supply chain management by analyzing vast datasets. As the COP29 climate conference approaches, companies are expected to be scrutinized for progress in fighting climate change. Integrating sustainability into core business strategy can create economic value while positively impacting people, society, and the environment, known as value-led sustainability. This approach is crucial as the 2030 deadline for limiting global warming draws closer.

site_title: US September trade deficit widest in over two years
summary: The US trade deficit widened to its largest in over two years in September, increasing 19.2% to $84.4 billion. Imports rose 3.0% to $352.3 billion, driven by consumer products and electronics, while exports slipped 1.2% to $267.9 billion. The surge in imports came ahead of the year-end holiday season and amid concerns about the US presidential election. The expanded deficit is a concern for the Federal Reserve, which may consider rate cuts to mitigate its impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: The US central bank is bound to cut rates by a quarter-of-a-percentage point to a range of between 4.5 per cent and 4.75 per cent to at the conclusion of their two-day meeting on Nov 7.
Walmart, the world’s biggest retailer, has slashed Christmas imports deeply, shipping at least 340,000 kilos of products described as “Christmas” goods into the US in the 12 months ending Sep 30.

site_title: UK budget watchdog adopting 'trust but verify' approach to finance ministry
summary: The UK's Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) has shifted its approach to the finance ministry from "trust" to "trust but verify" due to inaccurate spending forecasts provided by the previous Conservative government. The OBR found large upward pressures on day-to-day spending and unusually high spending from emergency reserves were not disclosed. Finance minister Rachel Reeves attributed a US$29 billion black hole to the previous government, which she had to address with tax increases. The OBR will now request more detailed breakdowns of spending forecasts from the finance ministry.

images.alt_text: Spending on essential items fell 2.2 per cent, the biggest drop since April 2020, led by spending in supermarkets.
S&P Global said services businesses’ input costs rose at the fastest pace in three months in October, as did their prices, which had risen by the smallest amount in 43-months in September.

site_title: IPhone maker Hon Hai’s October sales growth slows on weak demand
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry, a major manufacturing partner for Apple, reported October sales of NT$804.9 billion (S$33.2 billion), a 8.6% increase. This is the company's slowest monthly sales growth since February, raising concerns about demand momentum for AI infrastructure and iPhones. Analysts expect 15% sales growth in the current quarter, but the tepid sales growth supports Apple's weak forecast for the holiday quarter.

site_title: UK's Queen Camilla suffering from chest infection, Buckingham Palace says
summary: Queen Camilla, 77, is resting at home due to a chest infection, Buckingham Palace announced. No further details about her illness have been given. The Queen is advised to take a short period of rest by her doctors, forcing her to cancel planned engagements this week.

site_title: Italy puts ITA-Lufthansa deal on hold due to price dispute
summary: Italy's Treasury has put on hold a minority stake sale in ITA Airways to Lufthansa due to a 10 million euro price dispute. The deal, worth US$354.02 million, was approved by the EU in July. Lufthansa had agreed to cede flight slots to rivals as part of the contract, but the Italian economy ministry wants to revise the price. The Treasury will not "undersell" ITA, a source said, amid concerns over the airline's financial stability. The sale was expected to boost Lufthansa's presence in the southern European market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 5)
summary: Retail sales in Singapore excluding motor vehicles declined 1.4% from the year-ago period and 0.2% from the previous month on a seasonally adjusted basis. Singapore's retail sales grew 2% in September due to strong motor sales. Stamford Tyres chairman Sam Chong Keen stepped down amid a board reshuffle. CapitaLand Investment raised S$261 million for its South-east Asia and India private funds. The digital economy in South-east Asia is expected to reach US$122 billion in 2024, with a growing focus on profitability. Singtel was breached by Chinese state-sponsored hackers in a telecom attack.

site_title: Singapore logistics sector expects steady growth as hub role strengthens
summary: Singapore's logistics sector is expected to experience steady growth in the coming months, driven by its role as a key transhipment hub in South-east Asia and supported by the economic resilience of the Republic and its trade partners. The transport and logistics industry's score rose to 51.2 in Q3, up from 50.6 in Q2, driven by strong performance in logistics services and demand for transportation due to increased manufacturing and factory output. The industry is also benefiting from supply chain diversions and early shipments prompted by global events, such as new tariffs on Chinese goods and potential US port strikes.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The quarterly index, which tracks the health and performance of SMEs, rose to 50.8 in Q3 from 50.2 in Q2.
The strike by members of the the International Longshoremen’s Association shut down more than 30 ports on the US East and Gulf coasts.

site_title: Audi Group profit slumps on China weakness, plant restructuring
summary: Audi Group reported a 91% slump in operating earnings to 106 million euros in the third quarter, primarily due to waning luxury spending in China and a plant restructuring in Brussels. Deliveries of the Audi brand fell in Europe, China, and the US, amid intensifying competition. The company is facing cost-cutting measures, including potential factory closures and layoffs, as it pursues a cost-cutting strategy to remain competitive in the market.

site_title: US presidential elections: The expected impact on assets
summary: US presidential elections may impact assets, regardless of the outcome. A Republican sweep could benefit tax-sensitive sectors such as energy, transportation, and financial services, while a Democratic win may favor industries like healthcare, semiconductors, and clean energy. Markets may react with short-term volatility, but investors should focus on long-term secular trends. A Republican victory could lead to a flattening of US Treasury yield curves, while a Democratic win may result in a relatively flatter curve and lower yields. Investors should look beyond election outcomes and focus on trends like the rise of artificial intelligence for sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: US Vice President Kamala Harris has clinched the Democratic presidential nomination and is enjoying a super-charged wave of popularity and donations.

site_title: Quantum computing: banking’s next revolution
summary: Quantum computing is poised to revolutionize the banking industry with its ability to perform calculations at speeds much faster than traditional computing. This technology holds promise for personalized banking solutions, tailored financial products, and enhanced cybersecurity. The financial sector can leverage quantum computing for predictive modeling, portfolio management, and safeguarding against quantum attacks. The breakthrough also enables the development of quantum networks, ensuring digital privacy and security, and unlocking algorithmic power to create opportunities.

site_title: SIA Engineering Q2 profit up 10.2% at S$35.6 million; declares S$0.02 dividend per share
summary: SIA Engineering reported a 10.2% increase in Q2 profit to S$35.6 million, driven by healthy demand for maintenance, repair, and overhaul services amid an increase in air travel. Revenue rose 22% to S$307.5 million, and the company declared an interim dividend of S$0.02 per share. Despite challenges including supply-chain issues and elevated costs, the group's operating profit reversed from a loss in Q2 FY2024 and increased by 8.9% in the first half.

Analysts told The Business Times that the move is believed to maintain SIA’s competitive edge in premium travel.

site_title: PM Wong on introductory visit to Jakarta to meet Prabowo
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong is on a two-day introductory visit to Jakarta, Indonesia, to meet newly sworn-in President Prabowo Subianto. This is PM Wong's second trip to the Indonesian capital in two weeks and his third official visit since taking office in May. The visit aims to strengthen bilateral ties and enhance cooperation in areas such as renewable energy, food security, and human capital development. PM Wong is accompanied by a delegation of senior ministers, marking the first official visit by a foreign leader to Indonesia under the new administration.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Indonesia's new President Prabowo Subianto taking the oath of office; he has already begun work on a free lunch programme that was a key plank of his campaign.

site_title: Political protest and the university
summary: University presidents and governing boards struggle to respond to campus protests over political issues, as seen at Columbia University on the one-year anniversary of Hamas' Oct 7 attack. Protests have become deeply divided, with pro-Palestinian students demanding divestment and pro-Israel students arguing about safety. Some top administrators have resigned, and a new policy at Harvard states that universities will no longer issue official statements on public matters unless they directly threaten academic freedom.

images.alt_text: Joseph S Nye
A protest march at the University of California Los Angeles (UCLA), May 28, 2024. Progressives do not always grasp the obvious that people’s right to personal safety comes first.

Protests at the University of California, Berkeley, during a graduation ceremony on May 11, 2024. More than a dozen universities struck agreements with protesters that effectively conceded to some of their demands. Already, the agreements are under fire from all sides.

site_title: Burger King parent Restaurant Brands misses sales estimates on muted demand
summary: Restaurant Brands, parent company of Burger King, missed quarterly sales estimates due to weak demand in the US and international markets. Consumers are opting for cheaper, home-cooked meals instead of eating out as fast food prices have risen, hurting traffic at Burger King and other restaurants. Same-store sales at Tim Hortons grew 2.3%, while Burger King declined 0.7%, below last year's 6.6% rise. Net income was US$357 million, down from US$365 million in the prior year, and total revenues fell short of analyst expectations.

site_title: European banks’ commercial real estate exposures ‘visibly deteriorating,’ ECB finds
summary: European banks' commercial real estate exposures are "visibly deteriorating," according to a study by the European Central Bank. The banks have approximately 1.3 trillion euros in outstanding loans to commercial real estate investors, with credit quality worsening due to rising non-performing loans. Smaller, specialized banks with larger exposures may experience stress, while the sector is deemed too small to threaten the banking system's solvency. The study also highlights the risks associated with lending to real estate investment funds, which have already seen 5.7% of their loans sour.

site_title: South Korea fines Meta for illegal collection of user data
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, has been fined US$15.6 million by South Korea's Personal Information Protection Commission for illegally collecting and sharing sensitive data of nearly 980,000 domestic users. The data included information on users' religious beliefs and same-sex relationships without explicit consent. The commission ordered Meta to establish legal grounds for processing sensitive information and implement safety measures. This decision highlights the need for foreign operators to comply with South Korea's Protection Act regarding the processing of sensitive information.

images.alt_text: Meta’s motivation to work with US defence agencies is driven in part by its intention to further establish Llama as a dominant foundation for AI products globally.

site_title: Study finds wealthy people are happier. And there is no ‘happiness plateau’
summary: Wealthy individuals are generally happier than those with lower incomes, with no apparent "happiness plateau" beyond a certain threshold of wealth. Research by economists and psychologists has found that average life satisfaction strongly correlates with per capita national income, with each doubling of income associated with a nearly one-point increase in life satisfaction. A recent study of over a million real-time reports of experienced well-being found that real-time well-being rises linearly with income, and that truly wealthy individuals are significantly happier than the highest earners in the ordinary income group.

images.alt_text: Good money managers who have survived calamities understand that risk control is the most important aspect of their business.. As an investor the most important aspect of building your portfolio is having sufficient diversification.
It has been well-established that using gross domestic product, which values goods and services produced in an economy, as a metric to measure quality of life is woefully inadequate.

site_title: UK services sector lost steam in lead up to the budget, PMI shows
summary: The UK services sector experienced a loss of momentum in the lead-up to the new government's first budget in October, according to a survey by S&P Global. Business activity grew at its weakest rate in 11 months, and employment declined for the first time since December. The S&P Global UK Services Purchasing Managers Index stood at 52, down from 52.4 in September, indicating the slowest pace of increase since November 2023.

images.alt_text: Spending on essential items fell 2.2 per cent, the biggest drop since April 2020, led by spending in supermarkets.
James Dyson is the UK’s wealthiest resident with a fortune of US$21 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

The S&P Global UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index sank to 49.9 in October from 51.5 in September, below an initial estimate of 50.3 and just below the 50 level which divides growth from contraction in the survey.
UK's housing market had been gaining momentum on the back of cooling mortgage costs, with mortgage approvals rising to its highest in more than two years in September.
The Resolution Foundation says that real household disposable incomes per person are set to grow by an average of just 0.5 per cent a year over the next five years.

Traders slightly trimmed expectations for easing from the BOE in the wake of the budget, pricing in around an 85 per cent chance of a quarter-point cut at next week’s meeting, from around 93 per cent before the budget.

site_title: Tyre maker Michelin to close two French plants by 2026
summary: Michelin to close two French tyre factories by 2026, affecting 1,250 jobs. The closures are due to overcapacity in the tyre market, with increased competition from Asian producers. The company will support affected employees with early retirement or internal transfers, and provide support for finding new jobs. This move follows Michelin's previous plant closures in Germany and a revised annual profit forecast due to a slowdown in the auto market.
