Michelin's sales fell 4.2 per cent year on year to 13.48 billion euros in the first half of 2024.

site_title: Norway speeds ahead of EU in race for fossil-free roads
summary: Norway has set the most ambitious electric vehicle (EV) objective in the world, aiming for only zero-emission private new cars to be sold from next year. The country, a major oil and gas producer, has seen 43% of its cars in one suburb being electric, with residents making the switch due to environmental concerns. The move is part of Norway's efforts to become the first country free of fossil fuel-powered cars, a goal that could be achieved in the near future.

images.alt_text: China’s formal complaint raises the risk of greater tit-for-tat confrontation in a relationship valued at US$806 billion in bilateral merchandise trade in 2023.

site_title: Dollar slips as forex traders prepare for US election outcome
summary: The US dollar slipped against a basket of currencies as traders prepared for the presidential election outcome, with the euro rising 0.17% to US$1.08955 and the pound up 0.2% at US$1.2987. Options volatility soared after recent polls indicated a close election, with traders hedging against potential price moves. Analysts expect a possible victory for Democrat Kamala Harris, which could lead to a decline in the dollar, while a win for Republican Donald Trump could boost it. The Federal Reserve's interest rate decision on Thursday may also impact markets.

images.alt_text: The dollar index eased to 103.65, its lowest in two weeks against a basket of currencies.

site_title: Tax fraud investigators search Netflix offices in Paris and Amsterdam: source
summary: Tax investigators in France and the Netherlands raided Netflix's offices in Paris and Amsterdam, respectively, as part of a preliminary investigation into tax fraud laundering. The French investigation, launched in November 2022, involved the PNF, a unit notorious for pursuing high-stakes white-collar probes. The raids, which did not imply criminal charges, were part of a months-long cooperation between French and Dutch authorities. Netflix had previously settled a tax dispute with Italy and employed staff in Paris, but details of the investigation are unclear.

images.alt_text: Netflix has resisted pressure from filmmakers and their representatives, arguing that it can deliver a huge audience at home without theatres.
Netflix has ramped up its sports content in recent years.
Netflix has been trying to shift investor attention away from subscriber sign-ups to other metrics, including revenue growth and profit margins.
Shares in Netflix soared almost 340 per cent from a May 2022 low to their record high earlier this month.

site_title: Greenland eyes tourism takeoff with new airport runway
summary: Greenland is set to welcome more tourists with the opening of a new international airport runway in Nuuk, the capital city. The upgrade, expected to take effect on November 28, will allow for larger planes to land, boosting the tourism sector. However, concerns have been raised about the potential strain on the island's infrastructure and fragile ecosystem. Local residents are cautiously optimistic, but some warn that a full-scale tourism boom may take time and requires careful planning to ensure the island's resources can sustain the influx of visitors.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, November 5, 2024
summary: Asian markets experienced mixed trading on Tuesday, with caution building ahead of the high-stakes US election. The Indian stock market was cast in a negative light due to a record foreign exodus. Meanwhile, foreign banks in Singapore lowered home loan rates to as low as 2.45%. The Singapore shares opened lower, with the STI down 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumbered gainers 77 to 50.
Across the region, major indices were mixed at Tuesday’s close, with the Straits Times Index ending up 0.3 per cent or 9.57 points at 3,581.61.
Global funds pulled out more than US$10 billion on a net basis in October, helping drive the benchmark stock index towards a so-called technical correction.
Property analysts reckoned that falling mortgage rates may boost homebuyers' confidence, leading to more home sales.

site_title: Yen is first of many Japanese assets set to pivot on US election
summary: The outcome of the US presidential election has significant implications for Japan's currency, the yen. A victory for Kamala Harris is expected to support the yen, while a win for Donald Trump could boost the Tokyo stock market and put the yen at risk. The risk of a contested result and heightened volatility is likely, with investors and analysts predicting multiple scenarios for the trajectory of Japanese assets. A Harris win could lead to a strengthening yen, while a Trump victory could bolster the US economy, but also pose a risk to Japanese exporters.

images.alt_text: Japan’s public debt, at twice the size of its economy, is the largest among major nations due to huge spending packages delivered in the past and the rising social welfare costs for a rapidly ageing population. REUTERS

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts get more bearish on Wilmar, cutting their price targets for the stock
summary: Analysts have cut their price targets for Wilmar International due to the company's Q3 earnings report, which showed a 19% decline in net profit to US$254.4 million. Despite increased sales volumes, margins tightened due to lower contributions from its China business and sugar division. Maybank Securities lowered its price target to S$3.17, while CGS International Securities trimmed its target to S$3.47, citing "subdued" profitability and a high base effect from elevated sugar prices. A potential sale of its Adani-Wilmar stake may also result in one-off gains.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Wilmar International HQ at 28 Biopolis Road. The group is cautiously optimistic for a satisfactory performance for the rest of the year.

site_title: Harris, Trump conclude historic campaign with duelling rallies
summary: US presidential candidates Kamala Harris and Donald Trump concluded their historic campaign with duelling rallies on November 4, mirroring their competing visions for the nation. Harris declared the nation "ready for a fresh start" while Trump urged supporters to reject "weakness, incompetence, decline, and decay." The rallies capped a flurry of campaigning in battleground states, with surveys showing a deadlocked race nationwide. Harris's campaign expects a close outcome, with results potentially taking days to be finalized.

images.alt_text: Both Kamala Harris and Donald Trump lack the specifics to meet their promises.

site_title: Reasons to invest in Singapore banks
summary: Singapore's top three banks, including DBS, have achieved substantial earnings growth over the past two years, driven by an elevated interest rate environment. Despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts, Singapore banks have demonstrated a strong capacity to sustain earnings, with year-to-date share price growth ranging from 13 to 29.4%. The banks are expected to maintain dividend yields of 5-6% over the next two years, making them attractive investment options.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect the banks will continue to post stable results as strong wealth management fees will likely offset the impact of lower NIMs across the three banks.

site_title: Saudi Aramco reports 15% drop in Q3 profit but maintains dividend
summary: Saudi Aramco reported a 15.4% drop in Q3 profit to US$27.6 billion, due to lower crude prices and weaker refining margins. Despite this, the company maintained its generous dividend of US$31.1 billion, with US$10.8 billion in performance-linked payouts. The Saudi government, which holds nearly 81.5% of Aramco, relies heavily on the company's payouts, with the Public Investment Fund (PIF) also benefiting from dividends as part of its Vision 2030 economic agenda.

images.alt_text: State producer Saudi Aramco has increased the official selling price of its main Arab Light crude grade by 90 US cents to a premium of US$2.20 a barrel against the regional benchmark for buyers in Asia.

site_title: Record foreign exodus casts a pall over India’s stock market
summary: Foreign investors pulled out over $10 billion from India's stock market in October, driving the benchmark NSE Nifty 50 Index towards a technical correction. This marks a record foreign exodus, which could act as a drag on near-term stock performance. Despite this, domestic institutions have purchased shares worth over $50 billion this year, supporting the market. Strategists expect some more weakness in Indian stocks heading into the year-end, with the Nifty potentially falling to around 23,500.

images.alt_text: To meet growing demand, firms took on many more workers than in September. Hiring increased for an eighth consecutive month.
IQAir has rated New Delhi the world’s most polluted capital for four years in a row, but poor air quality is a common winter problem across South Asia.

site_title: Indonesia aims to cancel US$550 million in small businesses’ debts
summary: Indonesia plans to cancel up to $728 million in small businesses' bad debt, aiming to boost lending and growth in the country's largest economy. The government will pass a regulation allowing state-owned lenders to forgive troubled loans, with the goal of reaching 8.7 trillion rupiah. The move is part of the government's plan to drive GDP growth to 8% and is expected to benefit millions of small businesses unable to access loans due to complicated regulations. Policymakers are still discussing the types of loans that can be forgiven, which will affect the final figure.

site_title: Boeing strike ends as workers accept new contract
summary: Boeing's largest union has accepted a new contract, ending a 7-week strike that halted most jet production. The 59% vote in favor of the 4-year contract includes a 38% pay rise and a 4% bonus, meeting the union's demand for a 40% wage increase. The deal also includes a bump to company matching contributions for 401(k) plans and a promise to build the next airplane in the Seattle area. The strike, which cost Boeing $100 million daily, has provided welcome relief for the company, which has faced setbacks since a 737 MAX door panel blew off mid-air in January.

images.alt_text: Boeing this week raised about US$23.5 billion in an expanded capital raising in an effort to shore up its balance sheet and stave off a potential credit rating downgrade to junk.

site_title: Singapore stocks up ahead of US polls; STI continues edging up
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) edged up 0.3% to 3,581.61 points, driven by regional indices ahead of the US presidential election. Jardine Matheson was the top gainer, while Genting Singapore was the top loser. The US dollar regained footing, and volatility is expected to increase after the election. Market strategist Yeap Jun Rong expects economic fundamentals to take over once policy uncertainty clears, potentially leading to opportunities for dip-buying.

site_title: Philippines inflation matches estimate, gives room for rate cuts
summary: The Philippines' inflation rate quickened to 2.3% in October, matching market expectations, but remained within the central bank's target range of 2-2.8%. This allows the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas to sustain its easing cycle, with the benchmark interest rate recently reduced by 25 basis points to 6%. The central bank is unlikely to make further half-point cuts unless the nation's economic growth slows down.

site_title: China stocks end at 4-week high as Premier expresses confidence in economic recovery
summary: China's stocks closed at a four-week high on Tuesday, November 5, after Premier Li Qiang expressed confidence in the country's economic recovery. The Shanghai Composite index rose 2.32% to 3,386.99 points, while the blue-chip CSI 300 jumped 2.53% to 4,044.57 points. Recent data showed signs of improvement, including a private survey indicating China's services activity expanded at the fastest pace in three months in October. Premier Li stated that authorities have fiscal and monetary tools to meet this year's growth target.

images.alt_text: The need for CSRC approval has also affected the listing plans of firms that agreed to merge with special-purpose acquisition companies in Hong Kong.
China's Premier Li Qiang speaks during the opening ceremony of the China International Import Expo in Shanghai, China, Nov 5, 2024.
The Caixin/S&P Global services purchasing managers’ index (PMI) grew to 52.0 in October from 50.3 the previous month.
The Chinese economy has lost steam since the second quarter as a prolonged property market downturn and ballooning local government debt dented growth momentum.

site_title: Judge rules Pritam Singh has case to answer to: Key points on Day 10 of WP chief’s trial
summary: Singapore Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh has opted to give evidence before the court after a judge ruled he has a case to answer to both charges against him. Deputy Principal District Judge Luke Tan found the prosecution's case to be sufficiently strong in relation to both charges, which allege Singh lied to Parliament's Committee of Privileges (COP) in November 2021. Singh will present his defense either by taking the stand or choosing to remain silent, following the prosecution's decision to proceed with the case.

site_title: Contradictory signals from Nasdaq and gold
summary: Investors should remain vigilant for potential trend changes in the markets, despite recent pullbacks in the Nasdaq. Contradictory signals from the Nasdaq and gold markets suggest a temporary volatility rather than a new downtrend. The US presidential election in November is expected to be a significant factor in market volatility, with potential disruptions from contested ballots. Meanwhile, other markets are seeing growth, such as the Shanghai Index, which was triggered by China government policy announcements. Investors must consider the impact of government policies and elections on market trends.

images.alt_text: Regardless of who wins the presidency, investors should look beyond short-term volatility and focus on long-term secular trends.

site_title: Pacific International Lines adds five more LNG dual-fuel vessels in latest renewal process
summary: Pacific International Lines (PIL) has ordered five more liquefied natural gas (LNG) dual-fuel container vessels, with a capacity of 9,000 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEU), to be delivered in 2027 and 2028. The vessels will incorporate digital features with artificial intelligence and Internet of Things, enabling task automation and real-time monitoring. PIL aims to replace up to half of its fleet with modern ships in the next decade, with 18 newbuild vessels ordered since 2022. The new vessels will also feature optimized cargo stowage, bio-methane capability, and energy-saving features.

images.alt_text: Samuel Oh
Lars Kastrup, chief executive of PIL, says the new vessels contribute to the company's decarbonisation goal.

site_title: Former TPG partner’s real estate startup bets big on UK housing
summary: GREYKITE, a UK real estate startup co-founded by former TPG partner Michael Abel, has invested £750 million in single-family rental homes. The fund, managed by Greykite and Gatehouse Investment Management, has secured its first acquisition from homebuilder Persimmon, comprising 11 sites in the Midlands, Yorkshire, and the North East. This investment follows a trend of institutional investors, including Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, Kennedy Wilson, and Hines, entering the sector due to soaring mortgage costs and a lack of new development, driving rising rents.

site_title: Amazon still backs Talen nuclear deal after regulator rejection
summary: Amazon remains committed to building a data center adjacent to a Pennsylvania nuclear plant after the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (Ferc) rejected a deal to power the facility. The rejection of Talen Energy's request may set back efforts by major tech companies to gain quick access to nuclear energy for their growing data centers. Amazon's spokesperson stated that the company intends to proceed with the project, emphasizing its commitment to carbon-free energy solutions.

site_title: China gives Morgan Stanley approval to launch local futures unit
summary: Morgan Stanley has received final approval to launch a futures business in China through a newly established unit, becoming the second major US entrant in the derivatives market. The firm, wholly owned by Morgan Stanley, was listed as a licensed institution by the China Securities Regulatory Commission on November 1. This approval allows the US bank to serve domestic clients or cater to offshore investors under China's qualified institution programme, following rival JPMorgan Chase's 2020 move.

site_title: Welcome to a post-election inward-looking America
summary: A potential Donald Trump or Kamala Harris presidency in the US would likely lead to a more isolationist and protectionist America. Trump plans to pursue an aggressive economic nationalist agenda, including tariffs on foreign imports, and abandon the US role in promoting a free-trade system. Harris would likely continue the Biden administration's geo-economic strategy, emphasizing state direction in trade policies and a focus on China. Both candidates challenge the principles of globalization and internationalism, with Trump reassessing US military commitments and Harris potentially reevaluating US commitments to Ukraine.

site_title: Nintendo sees bigger profit fall on faltering Switch demand
summary: Nintendo has slashed its full-year profit outlook due to declining demand for its Switch console, citing a 10% reduction to 360 billion yen (S$3.1 billion). The company now expects to sell only 12.5 million Switch units this fiscal year, down from a previous forecast of 13.5 million. The decline in demand is attributed to the Switch's age and the release of sleeker updates from rivals Sony and Microsoft. Nintendo is instead focusing on capitalizing on its intellectual property through various products and services.

images.alt_text: Nintendo is one of the Japanese gaming companies the Saudi government has been buying up stakes in, part of the kingdom's push to lower its reliance on oil.

site_title: China state-linked group accused of hacking SingTel, Bloomberg News reports
summary: A China state-linked group, known as Volt Typhoon, is accused of hacking into Singapore Telecommunications (SingTel) in June as part of a global campaign targeting telecom companies and critical infrastructure operators. Investigators believe no data was exfiltrated and no services were impacted. China's Embassy in Washington denies knowledge of the incident, stating they oppose and combat cyberattacks. The breach is seen as a test by China for future cyberattacks on US telecom firms, highlighting the growing range of suspected Chinese cyberattacks targeting critical infrastructure overseas.

The disruption on Oct 8 lasted for more than three hours before services progressively resumed in the evening.

site_title: Tiny homes face the axe in Hong Kong, leaving many families worried
summary: Hong Kong's government plans to impose minimum standards on subdivided homes, potentially leading to the eviction of 30,000 of the city's poorest residents. The policy aims to improve living conditions, but experts warn it may raise rents and displace families. The average living space per person in Hong Kong is 64.6 square feet, less than half the size of a New York City parking space. The move is seen as part of Beijing's efforts to address the city's housing shortage, which contributed to the 2019 anti-government unrest.

images.alt_text: In late February, Hong Kong removed all additional stamp duties for foreign and second-home buyers, as well as on those selling flats within two years of buying them.
Student accommodation has emerged as one of the few remaining bright spots in Hong Kong’s prolonged property downturn.

site_title: Sunac proposes four debt-restructuring options to mainland China creditors: source
summary: Sunac China Holdings, a Hong Kong-listed property developer, proposes four debt-restructuring options to mainland China creditors to cut its onshore debt by more than half. The options include a debt-to-equity swap, redeeming bonds at a discount, accepting repayment from the sale of a land parcel, and replacing existing notes with new ones. The plan aims to address the company's 15.4 billion yuan (S$2.9 billion) in outstanding onshore debt, which is part of China's struggling property development industry.

images.alt_text: Sunac is one of the few large real estate companies to pull off a debt restructuring.
Sunac became the first major Chinese builder to reorganise its offshore debt late last year.
Sunac China primarily attributed the potential loss, its third half-year loss in a row, to a substantial decline in recognised revenue due to the market downturn, among other unspecified causes.

site_title: Indonesia’s Q3 GDP growth at 4.95% y/y, slightly slower than Q2
summary: Indonesia's Q3 GDP growth was 4.95% y/y, slightly slower than Q2. The manufacturing and construction sectors contributed to growth. Analysts expected 5.00% annual growth, but the actual figure met expectations. The finance minister had previously predicted 5% growth, citing household consumption and investment. Geopolitical tensions, including rising tensions in the Middle East, may impact growth in 2024, which is expected to be around 5.1%.

site_title: China must open up further to combat rising unilateralism: premier
summary: China's Premier Li Qiang emphasized the need for the country to open up further to combat rising unilateralism globally. He announced plans to upgrade free trade zones and explore investment agreements with other countries, particularly in sectors like telecommunications and healthcare. China aims to meet its growth target this year, citing positive economic developments and available fiscal and monetary tools. The China International Import Expo, which began on November 5, features over 3,500 exhibitors from 152 countries and international organizations, showcasing China's efforts to boost its free trade credentials.

site_title: StanChart partners with Wise for faster FX in Asia and Middle East
summary: Standard Chartered has partnered with Wise to offer faster and lower-cost international money transfers in Asia and the Middle East through Wise's payments platform. The lender will integrate Wise's foreign exchange infrastructure to allow money movements in 21 currencies over the coming months. This integration builds on an existing relationship between StanChart and Wise's Hong Kong-based digital bank Mox. Wise's platform has already facilitated cross-border payments instantly, with 65 licences globally and a growing revenue stream from its Wise Platform business arm.

images.alt_text: StanChart is reviewing relationships with clients that have just one lending relationship with the bank in order to prioritise higher-returning customers.
Like other major banks attempting to cope with the impact of falling rates, Standard Chartered is in the midst of a cost-savings programme.
StanChart’s personal loan book had an outstanding of 41 billion rupees (S$640 million) as of Sep 30.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit Q3 distributable income falls 7.8% to 20.8 million euros
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) reported a 7.8% year-on-year decline in distributable income to 20.8 million euros for the third quarter ended September. The manager attributed the fall mainly to divestments and higher interest costs. Despite this, distributable income for the first nine months of FY2024 was up 4.1% quarter on quarter, reflecting the "stabilisation" of the portfolio.

Manulife US Reit’s Class-A Peachtree building in Atlanta in US.

site_title: Chinese builder Kaisa puts Hong Kong headquarters up for sale
summary: Chinese developer Kaisa Group Holdings is selling its Hong Kong headquarters office, the 30th floor of The Center, for over HK$500 million (S$84.8 million). This sale comes as the company faces continued financing woes after defaulting on dollar debt in 2021 and China's housing crisis. Kaisa has offered the space to secure a loan in 2023 and previously sold a floor in the same building in 2021 to settle debt. The sale is part of Kaisa's efforts to ease funding pressure ahead of a court hearing to seek creditor vote on its debt overhaul plan on Dec 19.

site_title: Typical US homebuyer more likely to be older, single and a woman
summary: The median age of a typical US homebuyer has reached an all-time high of 56, with many young people locked out of the housing market. The share of first-time homebuyers has shrunk to 24% and the median age of a first-time buyer is 38, a decade older than in the 1980s. High prices and borrowing costs have created a bifurcated housing market, favoring repeat buyers and richer households, with the median income of a first-time buyer increasing by $26,000 to $97,000 in two years.

site_title: Stamford Tyres chairman Sam Chong Keen steps down amid board reshuffle
summary: Stamford Tyres chairman Sam Chong Keen has stepped down, with wife Dawn Wee taking over as executive chairman. Christopher Tan, a former SPH journalist, has been appointed as a non-executive independent director, effective December 1, 2024. Wee brings extensive knowledge of the tyre industry and longstanding relationships with stakeholders, while Tan's appointment enhances the independent element of the board and provides a different perspective. The changes took effect on November 1, 2024.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
For over 50 years, Wee was at the helm of Stamford Tyres, which grew from a family-run business to a multinational operating in 11 countries.
Stamford Tyres' H1 revenue fell 1.4 per cent to S$95.6 million on lower sales in the South-east Asia and export markets.

site_title: World’s first wooden satellite, developed in Japan, heads to space
summary: Japan has launched the world's first wooden satellite, LignoSat, into space on a SpaceX mission. Made from honoki, a type of magnolia tree native to Japan, the satellite is designed to demonstrate the use of timber in lunar and Mars exploration. The 50-year plan aims to plant trees and build timber houses on the moon and Mars, with the satellite set to stay in orbit for six months to test its durability and radiation resistance. The use of wood in space could minimize environmental impact and potentially replace traditional metal satellites, which may be banned in the future.

Vietnam’s government said last year that SpaceX was interested in providing the country with its low-Earth orbit satellite service.

site_title: Chinese red tape leaves billions of US dollars of deals in limbo
summary: Chinese regulatory approval requirements are hindering US dollar deals worth billions, according to Bloomberg data. Mergers and acquisitions (M&A) in 2024 are expected to be the worst in over a decade, with IPOs in Hong Kong raising less than a fifth of the amount four years ago. Obtaining approvals has become increasingly difficult over the past few years, making it challenging for companies to carry out transactions. This regulatory hurdle is affecting firms' listing plans, particularly those merging with special-purpose acquisition companies in Hong Kong.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 2% in September, propped up by strong motor sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales grew 2% year-over-year in September, exceeding private-sector economists' estimates of 1.8% growth, driven by strong motor sales. Excluding motor vehicles, sales declined 1.4% from the year-ago period. Key sectors showing growth included motor vehicles, with a 29.6% increase, and food and beverage services, which rose 1.6% year-over-year. Despite this, some categories, such as wearing apparel and footwear, experienced significant declines.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The increased sales in motor vehicles corresponded to a higher Certificate of Entitlement quota, Singstat notes.

site_title: A battle royale for the homebuyer dollar
summary: Singapore's property market is experiencing a surge in sales, with a record-breaking 3,500 new units launching in November. Developers are confident in the market's recovery, with two projects already bringing forward their launch dates. Executive condo projects have sold well, offering an affordable alternative to private property. However, concerns about affordability and land prices are growing, with a new record set for EC land prices. The government is advised to release more EC sites to meet bullish demand and to consider selling sites in prime areas.

images.alt_text: Michelle Low

With population growth, lower interest rates and stable supply, private home prices are not headed for a correction and are poised for steady growth instead, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
In an environment where prices in both the private and public markets appear out of reach for many, extraordinary transactions can create much instability, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.3% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 10.08 points at 3,561.96. The decline was attributed to overseas markets ending lower, particularly in the US, where stocks retreated ahead of the presidential election. Banking stocks were also down, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB losing 0.6%, 0.5%, and trading flat, respectively. The market's decline was largely due to anticipated volatility and tech losses outweighing gains in shares of oil and banks.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
The Stoxx 600 closed 0.3 per cent lower, with tech shares dropping 1.1 per cent to lead sectoral declines.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.6 per cent lower at 41,794.60 on Monday.

site_title: Mizuho buys minority stake in climate-focused investment firm for US$20 million
summary: Mizuho Bank has acquired a minority stake in climate-focused investment firm Pollination for US$20 million. The investment aims to accelerate Pollination's growth, including its investment strategy and decarbonization projects, and expand its reach in key markets. Mizuho Bank will also support Pollination's clients in developing and implementing decarbonization and nature strategies, enhancing its ability to support sustainable growth.

site_title: Apple explores push into smart glasses with ‘Atlas’ user study
summary: Apple is exploring a push into smart glasses with an internal study, code-named "Atlas," which involves gathering feedback from employees on current smart glasses products. The initiative aims to develop a product that users can "love," and additional focus groups are planned. This move follows Meta Platforms' entry into the smart glasses market, and Apple's own Vision Pro headset, released in February, was deemed too cumbersome and expensive to become mainstream. The study is being led by Apple's Product Systems Quality team, part of the hardware engineering division.

site_title: Apple to offer extra Indonesia investment to remove iPhone ban
summary: Apple has proposed investing $10 million in a factory in Indonesia to produce iPhone accessories and components, in an effort to lift a ban on sales of its latest iPhone model. The investment would be made in partnership with local suppliers and aims to meet Indonesia's 40% domestic content requirement for smartphones. The move comes as the Indonesian government pressures international companies to boost local manufacturing, with similar tactics used under previous administrations. The proposal is still pending approval from the Ministry of Industry, which may impact other companies considering similar investments in Indonesia.

site_title: UK consumer spending slowed before last week’s Budget, retailers say
summary: UK consumer spending slowed in October, with a 0.6% annual growth rate, the weakest rise since July, according to the British Retail Consortium. Spending on essential items fell 2.2%, the largest drop since April 2020, mainly due to supermarkets. This decline was attributed to uncertainty in the lead-up to the October 30 Budget and rising energy bills, deterring shoppers. The data also showed softer growth in consumer spending, with September's 2% growth rate being the strongest since July.

images.alt_text: James Dyson is the UK’s wealthiest resident with a fortune of US$21 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: Cautious Asian markets inch higher ahead of high-stakes US election
summary: Asian markets edged up slightly on Tuesday ahead of the US presidential election, with the Straits Times Index closing up 0.3% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rising 2.1%. Despite uncertainty over potential policy shifts, China's economic meeting and positive data on the services sector lifted Chinese stocks. Analysts expect volatility in the lead-up to the election results, with some predicting a Trump win could lead to higher interest rates and a Harris win may see fixed income outperform. Markets are likely to take cues from US markets, with a Republican sweep potentially putting pressure on bond yields and inflation.

site_title: Meta opens its AI models to US defence agencies and contractors
summary: Meta has granted approval for US government agencies and defence contractors to use its artificial intelligence (AI) models, called Llama, for tasks such as data analysis and cyber defence. The move is driven by Meta's intention to establish Llama as a dominant foundation for AI products globally and support the US government's safety and security. Meta's AI models are available to over a dozen US agencies and contractors, including Lockheed Martin and Booz Allen Hamilton Holding, with the exception of projects related to military, warfare, or espionage.

site_title: Thai exports could grow above 2% this year, shippers’ group says
summary: Thai exports are expected to grow above 2% this year, surpassing a previous forecast, according to the Thai National Shippers' Council. The value of shipments is expected to reach a record high of US$290 billion. Exports rose 1.1% in September and 3.9% in the January to September period, with a potential exchange rate loss in the fourth quarter due to the baht's appreciation. The council's chairman, Chaichan Chareonsuk, considers the exchange rate in the fourth quarter to be manageable, at a rate of 33.5 to 33.8.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit’s H1 DPU rises 0.4% to S$0.0467 on rental growth
summary: Aims Apac Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) for the first half of 2025 rose 0.4% to S$0.0467, driven by rental growth across its logistics and warehouse, and industrial segments. Revenue and net property income (NPI) also increased by 7.7% and 5.1% respectively. The Reit's portfolio occupancy stood at 95% as of end-September 2024, with a 16.9% portfolio rental reversion rate. Despite an enlarged unit base following an equity fundraising exercise, the Reit's manager expects consistent DPU growth and overall distributions to unitholders.

Russell Ng, CEO of the manager of Aims Apac Reit, at its flagship property at 20 Gul Way.

site_title: Revenue for South-east Asia’s digital economy to hit US$122 billion in 2024; profitability an increasing focus
summary: South-east Asia's digital economy is forecast to reach US$122 billion in 2024, with profitability expected to reach US$11 billion, up from US$4 billion in 2022. E-commerce accounts for the bulk of digital economy revenue, growing to US$35 billion in 2024. Singapore is a major digital wealth hub, but other countries in the region are expected to feature more prominently in the future, according to Bain's Florian Hoppe. This growth is driven by increasing focus on profitability in the digital economy sector.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Revenue is set to outgrow the rate GMV by 1.7 times in South-east Asia's digital economy.
E-commerce is expected to drive the digital economy growth in Singapore as GMV is forecasted to hit US$30 billion in 2025.
Investors surveyed by Bain say the exit environment is becoming much tougher.

site_title: Adani pushes Bangladesh for US$850 million unpaid electricity bill
summary: Bangladesh's power generation unit, Adani Power, is seeking to recover over $850 million in unpaid electricity bills from the country. The company, which supplies electricity to Bangladesh, has reduced its supply by half and may cut off power entirely on November 7 if the debt is not paid. Bangladesh's current administration is expediting payments to Adani Power, aiming to repay around $700 million as soon as possible. The move exacerbates the country's electricity deficit, which is already 1,500 megawatts short daily.

images.alt_text: Adani’s empire has been growing at a breakneck pace in the past five years, often by piling on more debt.
Billionaire owner Gautam Adani told investors the group is “well positioned” to capitalise on opportunities in the country’s booming infrastructure sector.

site_title: Gold flat ahead of US election and Fed meeting
summary: Spot gold remained flat at $2,734.71 per ounce ahead of the US presidential election and the Federal Reserve policy meeting. Investors refrained from taking big bets, while US gold futures edged lower by 0.1%. The outcome of the US presidential race is uncertain, with Democratic candidate Kamala Harris and Republican candidate Donald Trump nearly tied in opinion polls. The Fed is expected to cut interest rates, with nearly a 100% chance of a 25 basis point reduction.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered a safe investment during economic and geopolitical turmoil due to its ability to store value; it thrives in a low interest rate environment.

site_title: Meta to extend ban on new political ads after US election
summary: Meta will extend its ban on new political ads until later this week, following the US election, to prevent the spread of misinformation. The ban will remain in place until then, affecting new ads, but previously served ads with at least one impression before the ban will continue to run with restricted editing options. Meta asserts it needs sufficient time to effectively challenge claims in political ads during the election's last stretch.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, CapitaLand Investment, NetLink NBN Trust, Aims Apac Reit, Dyna-Mac
summary: Singapore Airlines plans to spend S$1.1 billion to retrofit its Airbus A350 fleet and refresh offerings by 2030 to stay competitive. CapitaLand Investment secured a S$261 million capital commitment from Mitsui OSK Lines for its private funds. NetLink NBN Trust's distribution per unit rose 1.1% to S$0.0268 for the first half of 2025, while Aims Apac Real Estate Investment Trust's distribution per unit increased 0.4% to S$0.0467. Cromwell European Reit's net property income grew 7% year-over-year to S$45.5 million. Dyna-Mac's takeover offer was declared unconditional, with Hanwha Ocean SG accepting a controlling stake.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Analysts told The Business Times that the move is believed to maintain SIA’s competitive edge in premium travel.
NetLink says the global political and economic outlook remains uncertain. The company will continue to monitor the evolving macro environment and respond with appropriate measures.

site_title: China’s services activity picks up as conditions improve: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity expanded at its fastest pace in three months in October, according to the Caixin/S&P Global services purchasing managers' index (PMI) at 52.0. This matched the official PMI released last week, indicating that Beijing's big stimulus push is helping improve business conditions. The expansion separates from contraction on a monthly basis, suggesting a turnaround in the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Shein now has its global headquarters in Singapore and its Europe, Middle East and Africa headquarters in Dublin.
Housing in Ningbo, China Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
China’s formal complaint raises the risk of greater tit-for-tat confrontation in a relationship valued at US$806 billion in bilateral merchandise trade in 2023.
The Chinese economy has lost steam since the second quarter as a prolonged property market downturn and ballooning local government debt dented growth momentum.
The property sector was long a key driver of growth, but is now mired in a sea of debt.

site_title: OpenAI in talks with California to become for-profit company
summary: OpenAI is in talks with California regulators to transform its non-profit structure into a for-profit business. The company, valued at $157 billion, holds valuable intellectual property in its proprietary ChatGPT chatbot and related AI technology. Discussions are ongoing with the California attorney general's office, and the Delaware attorney general has also been in communication about the potential change. The process involves regulators scrutinizing how OpenAI values its intellectual property.

images.alt_text: Examples shown on the OpenAI website closely resembled search results on Google and Google Maps.
OpenAI has dropped the ambitious foundry plans for now due to the costs and time needed to build a network.
Bain is also investing in establishing an OpenAI Center of Excellence, which will be led by a team of the consultancy.
OpenAI has also agreed to give users news summaries with attribution.

site_title: Commerzbank looks to free up capital to fend off UniCredit
summary: Commerzbank CEO Bettina Orlopp is seeking to free up capital to fend off a potential takeover by UniCredit. She plans to reduce risk-weighted assets (RWA) growth by using more significant risk transfers and potentially cutting low-yielding clients, freeing up regulatory capital for shareholder distributions or investments. The move aims to convince shareholders that Commerzbank is a compelling investment case on its own, and Orlopp has indicated that she expects her strategy to lift the bank's share price.

images.alt_text: Berlin was taken aback by UniCredit’s swoop to build a large stake in state-backed German bank Commerzbank, a move the Italian bank says could lead to a merger.
The details are the fullest account yet of contact between Germany and UniCredit before the Italian bank swooped to buy a large stake in Commerzbank.
UniCredit has amassed a 9 per cent stake in Commerzbank and said it planned to buy more shares if it received regulatory clearance.

site_title: Elite UK Reit’s 9-month DPU rises 3.9% on higher distributable income, tax savings
summary: Elite UK REIT reported a 3.9% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.13 pence for the nine months ended September, driven by higher distributable income and tax savings. The Reit's portfolio occupancy rate rose to 93.9%, while borrowing costs declined by 20 basis points to 5%. Distributable income increased 2.8% year-over-year to £14 million. The Reit manager attributed the growth to refinancing, hedging, and asset management efforts.

images.alt_text: One of Elite Commercial Reit's properties in Cardiff, Wales. The Reit's Q1 DPU is down on an enlarged equity base, among other factors.
Funds from the facilities will be used to refinance the Reit’s existing loans.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment raises S$261 million for South-east Asia, India private funds
summary: CapitaLand Investment has secured S$261 million in capital commitments from Mitsui OSK Lines for its South-east Asia and India private funds. The capital will increase funds under management to over S$2 billion and accelerate deployment of logistics investments. The funds will focus on smart logistics infrastructure in the region, driven by growing demand from multinational corporations and local companies. The investments are seen as positive for the logistics market in South-east Asia, with limited supply of prime assets in key locations.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
CapitaLand Investment ventured into India 30 years ago with the development of its first IT park, International Tech Park Bangalore (above).

The investment management arm of CapitaLand Group has obtained a licence from the International Financial Services Centres Authority or IFSCA to run a fund management company at the country’s newest financial hub.
Treacy will stay on as senior advisor to CLI's group CEO.
Ion Orchard, whose tenants include luxury brands, could benefit from the rejuvenation of Orchard Road.
Ascott China's tie-up comes on the back of rising demand for apartment hotels.

site_title: Recent US economic data points to a concerned Fed opening the door to series of rate cuts
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates by a quarter-of-a-percentage point to a range of 4.5-4.75% at its meeting on November 7, as economic data points to a slowing economy and recent inflation data suggests the post-pandemic bout of inflation is officially dead. The stock market is closely watching the Fed's decision, which could have as much or more impact as the outcome of the US presidential election. The Fed's statement and press conference will provide clarity on its preferred path, with economists expecting a series of rate cuts if the economy continues to slow.

images.alt_text: Brent futures were up US$1.98, or 2.7 per cent, at US$75.08 a barrel on Monday.
The Fed’s two-day rate meeting begins on Wednesday, and is expected to result in a quarter percentage-point rate cut the following day.
The dollar index eased to 103.65, its lowest in two weeks against a basket of currencies.

site_title: Trump supporters gather in Michigan for US election finale
summary: Supporters of former US President Donald Trump gathered in Grand Rapids, Michigan, for his final campaign rally before Election Day. Despite rain and long lines, attendees expressed confidence in Trump's inevitable victory, citing concerns over immigration, inflation, and abortion. Many also expressed skepticism about a Kamala Harris win, with some sharing concerns about alleged ballot machine irregularities and the impact of youth gender transitions. Trump's claims of election fraud have been repeatedly debunked, but concerns about the legitimacy of a Harris presidency remain.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.6 per cent lower at 41,794.60 on Monday.
Chocolate bars with the faces of the 2024 US presidential candidates Kamala Harris and Donald Trump on display at a store in John F Kennedy International Airport, New York.
The dollar index eased to 103.65, its lowest in two weeks against a basket of currencies.

site_title: Is the US election really so close?
summary: US polls show a nearly deadlocked presidential race between former President Donald Trump and Vice-President Kamala Harris, with razor-thin margins in key battleground states. FiveThirtyEight reports a 47.8% tie in Pennsylvania, near-identical numbers in Nevada, and one-point differences in Wisconsin, Michigan, and North Carolina. These margins may not accurately reflect the outcome of the election, potentially leading to a close and contentious result.

Hiring over the previous two months was weaker than previously thought, indicating the labour market is still softening beyond the temporary factors.

site_title: BT Mark to Market: The big takeover - Hanwha’s high-stakes move on Dyna-Mac Holdings
summary: Hanwha Ocean and Hanwha Aerospace, a South Korean conglomerate, has made a high-stakes takeover offer for Dyna-Mac Holdings. The acquisition is being facilitated by a special purpose vehicle, and its impact on minority shareholders remains unclear. The deal is part of a broader trend of private equity investments in the region. Details of the offer and its implications for Dyna-Mac's minority shareholders are still being analyzed, and the outcome is yet to be determined.

images.alt_text: Boards and investors should scrutinise the work of IFAs, and push them to justify their views and recommendations.
Dyna-Mac's offshore floating production, storage and offloading (FPSO).
PHOTO: Adobe Stock

site_title: Crypto firms including Robinhood, Kraken launch global stablecoin network
summary: A consortium of financial technology and cryptocurrency companies, including Robinhood, Kraken, and Galaxy Digital, has launched a global stablecoin network called the Global Dollar Network. The network aims to accelerate the usage of stablecoins worldwide, backed by the US dollar, and promote economic benefits to its partners. The stablecoin, USDG, will be issued by Paxos and governed by a committee of representatives from the network's partners. The move comes as crypto players anticipate US officials warming to digital assets, and faces competition from existing players Tether and USD Coin.

images.alt_text: Circle has also struggled to keep pace with the growth of its much larger rival.
Stablecoins can drive financial inclusion, enabling anyone with a blockchain wallet to make and receive payments.
Circle’s Dante Disparte proposes governments build regulatory “airports”, where fintechs can land and expand capabilities.
Stablecoins are typically designed to track the value of currencies or assets such as US dollars one-for-one.

site_title: Sun Life profit beats expectation on strength in Canada, US
summary: Sun Life reported a better-than-expected third-quarter profit, driven by strong growth in its domestic and US businesses. Underlying earnings from Canada rose 11% to C$375 million, while US earnings jumped 18% to C$219 million. The company's US dental business faced headwinds due to Medicaid renewals, but assets under management jumped 13% to C$1.5 trillion. Sun Life's underlying net income was C$1 billion, beating analyst expectations of C$1.70 per share.

images.alt_text: Tan brings extensive global experience to Sun Life Canada, says Sun Life.

site_title: South Korea’s inflation cools to slowest pace since 2021
summary: South Korea's inflation slowed to 1.3% in October, the lowest pace since early 2021, as consumer prices moderated for the third straight month. The Bank of Korea, despite a recent interest rate cut, is expected to hold its rate unchanged on November 28. This easing trend provides scope for the central bank to accelerate its policy easing campaign next year if economic momentum slows. The data comes as the country faces economic uncertainties, including a cooling export rally and weak private spending.

images.alt_text: SK Innovation, parent of South Korea’s largest refiner SK Energy, said the July-to-September quarter operating loss for its refining business was 616.6 billion won (S$592.2 million), its largest loss since the fourth quarter of 2022.

Outbound shipments from South Korea rose 4.6 per cent from a year earlier to US$57.52 billion, compared with gains of 7.5 per cent the month before and 6.9 per cent tipped in a Reuters poll of economists.
Predicting growth for 2025 has become more complicated as exports fell in real terms last quarter, Rhee Chang-yong says.

site_title: Canada proposes sharp cut in oil and gas sector emissions by 2030
summary: Canada has proposed a draft regulation to cap greenhouse gas emissions from the oil and gas sector at 35% below 2019 levels by 2030, as part of its efforts to reduce emissions by 40-45% by 2030. The move has been met with opposition from the industry, which claims it will lead to production cuts and job losses. The regulations will create a cap-and-trade system to incentivize cleaner production processes, with penalties for non-compliance. The Canadian government hopes to motivate producers to invest profits in decarbonization, with a focus on cutting methane pollution and a proposed oil sands carbon capture project.

images.alt_text: IQAir has rated New Delhi the world’s most polluted capital for four years in a row, but poor air quality is a common winter problem across South Asia.

CMG20240718-ChanBK01/陈斌勤/

Brent futures were up US$1.98, or 2.7 per cent, at US$75.08 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: New Zealand central bank says financial system remains resilient
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), stated that the country's financial system remains resilient despite an economic downturn. The RBNZ's semi-annual Financial Stability Report noted that debt servicing costs are nearing their peak and beginning to decline, with advertised mortgage rates falling over the past six months. Banks expect a slight increase in nonperforming loans, but levels remain below those seen in previous recessions. Risks to the financial system remain contained.

images.alt_text: New Zealand’s central bank has cut the official cash rate by 75 basis points since August as it assessed that inflation had returned to its target band of 1 per cent to 3 per cent and was nearing the 2 per cent mid-point.
The RBNZ aims to keep inflation around the 2 per cent midpoint of its target band.
ASB expects the RBNZ to cut the Official Cash rate by a further 50 basis points at its final decision of the year on Nov 27, with more reductions forecast for next year.
New Zealand’s economy has stalled, unemployment is rising and house prices are falling as the prolonged period of high borrowing costs curbs demand.

site_title: Australia’s central bank keeps cash rate at 4.35%, as expected
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) maintained its cash rate at a decade-high of 4.35% as expected, citing the need to remain vigilant to upside risks to inflation. The central bank reiterated it's not ruling anything in or out on future policy, with markets indicating a scant chance of a rate cut this year. Core inflation remains sticky at 3.5%, and the RBA expects it to slow slightly to 3.4% by year-end. The RBA has held its policy steady for a year, aiming to bring inflation to its target band of 2-3% while preserving employment gains.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Anglo American is seen on a jacket of an employee at the Los Bronces copper mine, in the outskirts of Santiago, Chile March 14, 2019 Picture Taken March 14, 2019. REUTERS/Rodrigo Garrido/File Photo
PwC Australia has overhauled its leadership and sold its government services unit
Apollo is targeting to raise at least US$150 billion for its global wealth business by 2029.
Chris Ellison of Minerals Resources in a press conference after their AGM in Perth. November 16th, 2023 (Photo by Trevor Collens / Australian Financial Review via Getty Images)
Westpac reported a 3 per cent decline in profit for the year ended Sep 30, to A$7 billion, due to rising costs and intense competition in the mortgage market.
The RBA is focusing on underlying inflation as government rebates are suppressing the headline figure.

site_title: At final Harris rally, a mix of enthusiasm and worry over US election
summary: US Vice-President and Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris held her final campaign rally in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, amidst a highly divided and anxious electorate. Supporters expressed enthusiasm for Harris, while also fearing a possible return of Donald Trump to the White House. Concerns over Trump's alleged normalization of racism and misogyny were echoed by many, with some fearing a second Trump presidency would lead to the erosion of democratic checks and balances. The election is seen as a choice between stability and chaos, with many voters, including those from marginalized communities, hoping Harris will deliver shared prosperity.

images.alt_text: Former President Donald Trump with Elon Musk during a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, Oct 5, 2024. Tesla CEO Musk has already given away US$16 million to registered swing state voters who qualified for the giveaway by signing his political petition.

Supporters of former US President Donald Trump gather outside the venue of a planned campaign rally in Grand Rapids, Michigan, Nov 4, 2024.

site_title: AIG’s profit beats estimates on strong underwriting, investment returns
summary: American International Group (AIG) reported a profit beat for the third quarter, driven by strong underwriting and investment returns. The insurer's general insurance net premiums written rose 6% to $6.4 billion, with a combined ratio of 88.3% on an adjusted basis. This signifies that AIG earned more from premiums than it paid out in claims. The company's strong performance helped it sail past Wall Street estimates, demonstrating the insurance industry's resilience to economic vagaries.

images.alt_text: AIG spun off Corebridge in 2022 and has been paring its interest.
AIG says net premiums written in its general insurance arm for the quarter ended June grew 10 per cent to US$7.5 billion.
Insurers have reaped the benefits of growing hopes of a soft landing and a still-tight labour market that has revived spending on insurance policies.
Logo for Aviva plc, a British insurer.

site_title: CICT’s Q3 net property income rises 5.4% to S$289.8 million
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) reported a 5.4% increase in net property income to S$289.8 million for its third fiscal quarter, despite the absence of income from Gallileo in Frankfurt. Revenue grew 1.7% to S$397.9 million. The top-line growth was apparent across all asset classes, contributing to a 5.4% year-to-date increase in net property income to S$872.1 million.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Gross proceeds from the equity fundraising are intended to fund a proposed acquisition of a 50 per cent interest in Ion Orchard mall.
With ION Orchard in its fold, CICT will have a property portfolio worth S$26.4 billion
The new private placement units are expected to be issued on Sep 12.
The proposed acquisition is expected to be completed in Q4 of 2024.

site_title: Fox Corp beats revenue estimates on robust political advertising
summary: Fox Corp beat revenue estimates for the first quarter, with $3.56 billion in revenue and an 11% increase in advertising revenue to $1.33 billion. The boost was attributed to record political advertising and strong growth at its ad-supported streaming platform Tubi, ahead of the US presidential election. Fox's shares rose 3.5% in premarket trading. CEO Lachlan Murdoch credited the success to record political advertising and Tubi's strong growth.

site_title: Nelly Korda clinches first Rolex Player of the Year award
summary: Nelly Korda, 26, has clinched her first Rolex Player of the Year award, finishing the season with six victories and three top-10 finishes, including her second major title at the Chevron Championship. She becomes the second consecutive American to win the award, following Lilia Vu, and the first since 1993-94. Korda will accept the award and the ANNIKA Major Award at the Rolex LPGA Awards programme on Nov 20.

images.alt_text: A bird's eye view of Sentosa Golf Club's world-renowned Serapong course, which has played host to dozens of local and international tournaments over the years.
Spectators at the Singapore Turf Club during the final Singapore Derby event in July 2024. The venue will stage its final races on Oct 5.
Woods has not played competitive golf since missing the cut at the Open Championship in July.
A bird's eye view of the SICC's Bukit golf course, which will turn 100 on Aug 31, 2024.
A group of 70 golfers, including labour chief Ng Chee Meng, played a final round at the Marina Bay Golf Course on Jun 30, 2024.
Golf courses in Singapore lease government land, leaving them vulnerable to changes in planning goals.

site_title: Uber proposes cut to New York City driver base pay on lower gas prices
summary: Uber is proposing a 6.1% reduction in New York City driver base pay rate due to falling petrol prices, citing a rate of $1.277 per mile, down from the current $1.36. The company also suggests a 3% annual inflation cap or the Consumer Price Index rate, whichever is lower, for future adjustments. This move comes as the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission prepares changes to the driver minimum wage rule.

images.alt_text: Uber has been investing into new areas across both its ride-hailing and delivery businesses in the US and internationally, where the company said it has seen stronger growth.
Tesla has been under pressure to justify its high valuation and prove it can lead the industry in autonomous vehicle technology.
Uber since June has announced at least seven partnerships and investments related to autonomous vehicles.
WeRide was granted the UAE’s first national licence for self-driving cars in July 2023 and operates the largest robotaxi fleet in the Gulf state.

site_title: Employee stock option plans gain traction among founders despite lack of understanding: study
summary: Employee stock option plans (Esops) have gained popularity among founders, with 78% of startups offering such plans to employees in 2024, up from 59% in 2021. More startups are offering Esops to all employees, with one in three startups now offering such plans to all staff. However, a lack of understanding among founders remains a concern, with less than 30% having a deep grasp of Esops' deeper topics. Founders cited building culture and ownership as the biggest reasons for offering Esops, while talent retention was a growing concern.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

Where the valuations of companies have come down, some previously issued options may be “underwater” or unattractive. This tends to reduce employee confidence in equity compensation in what is already an uncertain period. Companies need to carefully consider aspects such as including size and timing of the corrective action, impact of setting a precedent, impact on other stakeholders i.e. dilution.

site_title: The futile search for a US dollar rival
summary: The Brics summit in Kazan, Russia, aimed to challenge the US dollar's dominance in global trade and finance by promoting the use of Brics members' currencies. However, the proposal faces significant hurdles, including the need for balanced trade between countries and the lack of trust in the stability of a new currency. Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's plan to launch a common currency with Argentina has stalled, and the feasibility of a Brics currency is uncertain. The US dollar's role as a global reserve currency is not guaranteed, but its value is underpinned by credible institutions, making it difficult for alternative currencies to gain traction.

images.alt_text: Russia's President Vladimir Putin at the Brics summit in Kazan on Oct 24, 2024.
20 years on, dreams of euro rivalling dollar persist

site_title: Marriott trims 2024 profit forecast on sluggish China domestic travel demand
summary: Marriott International has cut its annual profit forecast due to weak domestic travel demand in China, where room revenue growth is expected to be negative for the full year. Despite strong group and international demand, severe weather and restricted pricing power have weighed on domestic performance. The company now forecasts adjusted profit between $9.19 and $9.27 per share, down from previous estimates. System-wide RevPAR in Greater China fell 7.9% in the third quarter, and the company expects a 6.5% increase in net rooms additions in 2024.

images.alt_text: KKR plans to convert its newly acquired hotels in Japan into properties under Marriott International’s midscale brand, Four Points Express by Sheraton.
FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen at the Marriott Marquis hotel in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., March 23, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: US: Stocks retreat in election eve session
summary: US stocks declined on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.6% to 41,794.60, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also dropping 0.3% each. Markets are anticipating volatility ahead of the US presidential election, which could impact tax and trade policy, and individual sectors. Analysts predict the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates on Thursday, while a Chinese stimulus package meeting is also expected to influence markets.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 53.32 points, or 0.13 per cent, at the open to 41,998.87.

site_title: Shein’s European entity reports 68% sales growth in 2023
summary: Shein's European entity, Infinite Styles Ecommerce, reported a 68% sales growth in 2023, reaching €7.7 billion (S$11 billion). The entity's after-tax profit more than doubled to €99.5 million, while gross profit increased to €314 million. The company's European headquarters in Dublin, which also covers subsidiaries in Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, and Poland, saw tax payments rise to €18.4 million. Shein's global headquarters is in Singapore, and the company is working towards an initial public offering in London, valued at €66 billion last year.

images.alt_text: In August, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said average selling prices were falling because customers were trading down to cheaper items and buying more essential goods, and that sales of bigger ticket items like computers and electronics were growing “more slowly” than in a robust economy.
Shein has disrupted the fast-fashion industry with its low-cost model and rapid growth.
Shein’s possible initial public offering could help rebuild momentum in London after a string of defections from its stock markets.

Shein’s rapid growth, fuelled by its low-cost business model of sending parcels to customers worldwide straight from factories in China, has disrupted the budget fashion industry and put pressure on incumbents.

site_title: Palantir raises 2024 revenue forecast again on robust AI adoption; shares surge
summary: Palantir raised its 2024 revenue forecast for the third time, citing strong government spending and rising demand for its AI software services. The company's shares surged 8% in extended trading, increasing by over 140% this year. The data analytics company benefits from a boom in GenAI technology as businesses adopt its AI platform for testing and evaluating AI-related scenarios.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gemini logo is seen in this illustration taken May 20, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US factory orders fall a second straight month in September
summary: US factory orders fell 0.5% in September, marking a second straight month of decline. This drop follows a downwardly revised 0.8% decrease in August. In contrast, non-defence capital goods excluding aircraft, a measure of business spending plans on equipment, rose 0.7% in September. Factory orders were unchanged from a year earlier, indicating a lack of significant growth in the US manufacturing sector.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as tech losses offset bank, oil gains
summary: European shares declined 0.3% on Monday, led by a 1.1% drop in tech shares. Gains in bank and oil stocks, however, offset the losses. The Stoxx 600 closed down, with banks rising 0.7% and energy stocks gaining 0.4% due to Opec+'s decision to delay output increases.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.6 per cent lower at 41,794.60 on Monday.

site_title: KPMG to lay off less than 4% of US audit workforce: source
summary: KPMG plans to lay off less than 4% of its US audit workforce, approximately 330 people, according to a source. This move aims to align the firm's size, shape, and skills to the market. KPMG, along with Ernst & Young, Deloitte, and PricewaterhouseCoopers, is part of the Big Four accounting firms. The layoffs follow previous cuts in 2023 and 2024, driven by economic headwinds and historically low attrition.

site_title: Pennsylvania judge allows Elon Musk’s US$1 million voter giveaway
summary: A Pennsylvania state judge allowed Elon Musk's $1 million daily giveaway to swing state voters to proceed, despite allegations it was an "illegal lottery." Musk's America PAC gave away $16 million to registered voters who signed a petition pledging to support free speech and gun rights. The contest was initially blocked by Philadelphia's top prosecutor, but Judge Angelo Foglietta denied the bid, saying the rules were "hazily defined." The decision comes with one day left before the US presidential election between Democratic Vice-President Kamala Harris and Republican Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: In response to the rampant spread of misinformation during the previous US presidential election, tech firms are maintaining heightened scrutiny this year.
Supporters of former US President Donald Trump gather outside the venue of a planned campaign rally in Grand Rapids, Michigan, Nov 4, 2024.
Major polling outlets show Vice-President Kamala Harris and former president Donald Trump virtually deadlocked but these razor-thin margins may not tell the whole story.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.6 per cent lower at 41,794.60 on Monday.
Chocolate bars with the faces of the 2024 US presidential candidates Kamala Harris and Donald Trump on display at a store in John F Kennedy International Airport, New York.
The dollar index eased to 103.65, its lowest in two weeks against a basket of currencies.
