(Photo by ANGELA WEISS and CHARLY TRIBALLEAU / AFP)
The US dollar declined against all its Group-of-10 peers.
The property sector was long a key driver of growth, but is now mired in a sea of debt.
Elon Musk, who has donated more than US$100 million to support Trump, has extensive business interests in China.

site_title: New York Times tops estimates as digital subscribers grow
summary: The New York Times reported third-quarter earnings beating analysts' expectations with 45 cents a share, exceeding forecasts. The company added 260,000 digital subscribers, reaching 11.1 million total subscribers, meeting forecasts. Revenue totaled $640.2 million, exceeding expectations of $640.9 million. The increase in digital subscribers is attributed to the months leading up to the 2024 Presidential Election.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man speaks on his mobile phone in front of the New York Times building in New York City May 21, 2009.  REUTERS/Joel Boh (UNITED STATES MEDIA)/File Photo

New York Times added 300,000 digital subscribers, compared with 210,000 in the first quarter. The company now has a total of 10.84 million subscribers, including print and digital, compared with forecasts for 10.74 million.

site_title: Foreign banks in Singapore slash home loan rates to as low as 2.45%
summary: Foreign banks in Singapore have slashed home loan rates to as low as 2.45%, with rates ranging from 2.45% to 3.5% according to recent data. This marks a significant drop from fixed mortgage rates of up to 4.25% at the start of 2023 and 3% at the beginning of this year. However, market watchers suggest that lower rates may not be the primary factor in driving homebuyers towards purchases in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Hongkong Land's crown jewel is its Hong Kong Central portfolio.
The Fed has continued unwinding its balance sheet.

The National Association of Realtors (NAR) said on Wednesday (Oct 30) its Pending Home Sales Index, based on signed contracts, rose 7.4 per cent last month to 75.8 – the highest since March – from 70.6 in August.

site_title: Return to office: The writing is on the wall of your cubicle
summary: Amazon's corporate employees will return to a five-day workweek in the office starting January 2025, up from three days a week. Despite some 523 AWS employees issuing an open letter protesting the policy, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy has stated that nine out of 10 employees are excited about the change. The move follows similar trends among other companies, such as Goldman Sachs and PwC, which are also pushing for employees to return to the office. As the world's second-largest private employer, Amazon's decision is seen as a significant shift in the remote work landscape.

images.alt_text: Joyce Hooi
FILE PHOTO: A logo for Amazon Web Services (AWS) is seen  in Paris, France, March 20, 2024. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo/File Photo
BT

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as US polls, Fed decision loom large
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday, November 4, amidst a volatile week with the presidential election and a potential Federal Reserve rate cut looming. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 53.32 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Market participants are cautious ahead of the election and Fed decision, which may impact interest rates and the economy.

site_title: Foreclosures in China soar, threatening to choke off bank profits
summary: China's foreclosure rate soared 43% last year, with thousands of apartments seized and listed for auction, as the country's housing market continues to struggle. The increase piles pressure on banks, which face losses from unpaid loans and are now being urged to lend more to real estate developers. The Chinese government's economic stimulus measures aim to stimulate the market, but experts warn that the banks' financial health is at risk. Foreclosures are largely confined to second homes, and many homeowners are able to pay off their mortgages or make large down payments, reducing the impact on the financial system.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured in Tianjin, China August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
The Chinese economy has lost steam since the second quarter as a prolonged property market downturn and ballooning local government debt dented growth momentum.

site_title: Indonesia growth may slow most in year on manufacturing slump
summary: Indonesia's economic growth may have slowed to 5% in the third quarter, the slowest pace since last year, due to a manufacturing slump and weaker domestic demand. The decline in overseas demand and influx of cheaper imports have led to factory closures and job cuts, with nearly 60,000 layoffs reported in October. The country's growth stands out among the fastest in Southeast Asia, but the cracks in its manufacturing sector could jeopardize employment and consumer spending, critical to its $1 trillion economy.

images.alt_text: Under a rule introduced last year, natural resource exporters must retain for three months in the domestic financial system 30 per cent of their proceeds for every custom document for exports worth at least US$250,000.
Indonesian workers take part in a rally to repeal the omnibus law and demand higher wages in Jakarta on October 24, 2024. (Photo by JUNI KRISWANTO / AFP)
Indonesia's October headline inflation rate was 1.71 per cent, easing from 1.84 per cent in September and close to the median forecast of 1.68 per cent by analysts in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Singapore Airlines to invest S$1.1 billion in retrofitting Airbus A350 fleet
summary: Singapore Airlines plans to spend S$1.1 billion retrofitting its 41 Airbus A350 fleet with new cabin products, including upgraded business-class seats, premium-economy class, and economy-class cabins. The retrofit program aims to maintain the airline's competitive edge in premium travel, with the introduction of a first-class cabin on ultra-long-range aircraft and a refreshed in-flight entertainment system. The program is expected to be completed by 2030, with the first retrofitted aircraft entering service in 2026.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Chong Xin Wei
There were 249 passengers and 17 crew members on board the Boeing 777-300ER.
CAG says that North Asia continues to lead its passenger traffic this quarter.
From Sunday (Oct 27), Singapore Airlines and Air India will increase their weekly scheduled codeshare services to 56 from 14.
Elbe Flugzeugwerke wants to tap the A380 market as airlines re-deploy the aircraft.

site_title: US CEOs fired more quickly over low stock prices this year, report says
summary: US companies are firing CEOs more quickly when their stock prices are low, with 42% of S&P 500 companies and 45% of Russell 3000 companies replacing CEOs this year having underperforming stock returns. This trend is attributed to increased investor scrutiny and pressure from corporate activists. Despite this, traditional recruiting patterns remain unchanged, with companies favoring company veterans and insiders. The number of female CEOs has also increased, reaching a historical high of 9.5% in the S&P 500.

images.alt_text: The 56-year-old Kaufmann presided over a roughly 18 per cent stock price climb over his tenure.
Fresh leadership is now brewing at Starbucks.

The median pay for a FTSE-100 company CEO rose 2.2 per cent to £4.19 million last year, think tank the High Pay Centre said, though it added CEO pay growth had slowed compared with the previous two years.

site_title: Are Indian stocks still worth buying?
summary: India's stock market is on track to reach $10 trillion in capitalization, driven by a strong economy, improving corporate sector, and growing domestic investor interest. Despite concerns over valuations, experts believe prices are justified due to a healthy macro backdrop, increasing corporate efficiency, and attractive valuations. India's economy is more efficient, with a lower fiscal deficit and controlled inflation, and corporate earnings are expected to grow in the mid-teens. Domestic investor flows have accelerated, providing structural support to the market.

images.alt_text: India’s benchmark Nifty 50 index has declined about 5 per cent from its record high hit in the last week of September.

Asia’s financial markets stand on the front line of what could be a wild ride when votes are tallied and in the months ahead since the region is an export powerhouse and shares and currencies are sensitive to changes in US trade policies.

site_title: China appeals to WTO over EV tariffs imposed by European Union
summary: China has lodged a complaint with the World Trade Organization over the European Union's tariffs on Chinese electric vehicle imports, citing "trade protectionism in the name of countervailing." The EU has defended the tariffs as a by-product of an investigation into Chinese government subsidies, while China claims the EU's ruling lacks factual and legal foundation. The dispute escalates tensions between the two powers, valued at $806 billion in bilateral merchandise trade in 2023. China urges the EU to correct its "illegal practices" and maintain global electric vehicle supply chain stability.

images.alt_text: The EU launched an anti-subsidy investigation into imports of Chinese-made battery EVs last year and in October voted for tariffs on those vehicles.
BYD’s European registrations jumped 162 per cent in September from a year earlier, to 4,376 vehicles, according to Jato.

site_title: BP venture eyes investment to make green jet fuel in Argentina
summary: BP's venture, Pan American Energy Group, is considering a significant investment to produce sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) at its refinery outside Buenos Aires, Argentina. This move aims to support the global aviation industry's efforts to reduce its carbon footprint. The project would require a substantial upgrade to the Campana oil refinery, and a final decision has not been made. The Argentine government has offered tax incentives and a favorable business climate to encourage energy projects, including refineries with investments of at least $200 million.

site_title: SG60 an opportunity for Singaporeans to reflect on shared values, renew commitment to country: PM Wong
summary: Singapore will celebrate its 60th year of independence in 2025 with a series of events, including the SG60 theme of "Building Our Singapore Together," which aims to connect Singaporeans, reflect shared values, and renew commitment to the country. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of community-led innovation and grassroots initiatives, with plans to launch community innovation spaces and a community innovation hackathon. Key SG60 events include ONE Countdown, Chingay, and the National Day Parade, with a focus on promoting multiculturalism, resilience, and openness.

site_title: Oil jumps nearly 3% after Opec+ delays output hike, US election in focus
summary: Oil prices surged nearly 3% on Monday as Opec+ delayed its plans to increase output by 180,000 barrels per day. The decision, made on Sunday, extends the group's output cut of 2.2 million barrels per day for another month in December. Brent futures rose $1.98, or 2.7%, to $75.08 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose $1.98, or 2.85%, to $71.47 a barrel. The announcement casts doubt on Opec+’s commitment to returning supply at all in 2025, but the group remains positive on oil demand in the short and long term.

images.alt_text: Saudi's total spending came to 339 billion riyals in the third quarter as it continued to spend heavily on its Vision 2030 transformation programme.
Eight members of Opec+, agreed on Sunday to delay a planned December oil output increase by one month due to weak demand in China and rising supplies.
Brent rose as much as 2 per cent to more than US$74 a barrel.

site_title: Saudi Arabia posts 30 billion riyals Q3 deficit as lower oil prices weigh
summary: Saudi Arabia posted a Q3 budget deficit of 30 billion riyals (S$10.5 billion) due to lower oil prices, despite spending heavily on its Vision 2030 transformation programme. Total spending reached 339 billion riyals, while total revenue was 309 billion riyals, with oil revenue at 191 billion riyals. The kingdom is reviewing spending to prioritize projects and address the deficit. Oil output is expected to rise next year, driving a rebound in economic growth, with the non-oil sector now making up over 50% of GDP.

images.alt_text: BlackRock received approval to set up its regional headquarters in Riyadh, allowing it to expand operations across the Middle East.
PIF said the deals aim to spur “two-way capital flows through both debt and equity”, among other things.

The offices of the King Abdullah financial district in Riyadh. Known as the Future Investment Initiative, the deal strengthens ties between Brookfield and the kingdom’s wealth fund, which manage about US$1 trillion in assets each.

site_title: The science behind why we are bad at saving for retirement
summary: Singaporeans expect to start planning for retirement at age 35, but many fall prey to inertia, with 19% of SRS funds in cash earning 0.05% interest. A quarter of Singaporeans have yet to start planning, citing immediate financial needs as the top reason. The global retirement savings gap is expected to increase to $400 trillion by 2050, according to the World Economic Forum. Cognitive biases and psychological pitfalls hinder long-term financial decisions, making it challenging to overcome inertia and plan for retirement.

images.alt_text: At the POSB Mini Mart, kids could also visit a series of interactive ATMs to learn about money management skills via gamified experiences.
Syfe is also exploring opportunities to support businesses, particularly SMEs, such as through cash management solutions.

site_title: A choice between stability and chaos
summary: The 2024 US presidential election pits Donald Trump's leadership style, which escalates societal tensions, against Kamala Harris's promise of stable policymaking. Trump's personality and leadership are designed to exacerbate tensions, while Harris offers predictability and equanimity. The election's central paradox lies in the choice between stability and chaos, with Trump's authoritarian control potentially delivering unprecedented social disorder and Harris providing the predictability needed for US businesses to thrive. The outcome will determine the health of America's governing institutions and the country's ability to address complex global challenges.

images.alt_text: US vice president Kamala Harris at a campaign rally at the Michigan State University campus on Nov 3, 2024 in Lansing, Michigan..
Democratic presidential nominee US Vice President Kamala Harris at a campaign rally in Reno, Nevada, US, Oct 31, 2024.

site_title: South-east Asia’s green leap needs support from Singapore’s private sector
summary: South-east Asia is at a critical crossroads between rising emissions and the opportunity to make a green leap, with the course of action taken by Singapore's private sector and governments determining the region's climate trajectory. As the consumer class is expected to more than double over the next 30 years, the region will see increased consumption of resources, but this can be mitigated with an immediate, coordinated response. A green leap requires support from the private sector to reduce emissions and promote sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: The bulk of Singapore’s public-sector green bonds is earmarked for clean transportation.
A zero carbon economy could hardly be counted as a victory for the path towards net zero if it comes at the expense of the livelihoods of local communities.
Among the Asean nations that have set net-zero goals, Singapore and Vietnam have made the most progress in reducing greenhouse gas emissions over the past year.
A green planet is good for business

site_title: US dollar drops to two-week low as investors take profit on ‘Trump trades’
summary: The US dollar dropped to a two-week low on Monday as investors took profit on "Trump trades" ahead of the US presidential election, which could have wide-ranging implications for the global economy. The dollar index eased to 103.65, while the euro jumped 0.7% to US$1.0906. Investors are positioning for a potential interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve, with a 98% chance of a quarter-point cut expected this week. The outcome of the election is uncertain, with Democratic candidate Kamala Harris and Republican Donald Trump remaining almost tied in opinion polls.

images.alt_text: The euro was down 0.40 per cent against the dollar at US$1.084.

FILE PHOTO: Japanese 10,000 yen notes are spread out next to U.S. 100 dollar bills at Interbank Inc. money exchange in Tokyo, in this September 9, 2010 picture illustration. REUTERS/Yuriko Nakao/File Photo
The dollar index has risen more than 3 per cent so far in October, putting it on pace for its best month since September 2022.

site_title: Google is winning the AI search wars
summary: Google continues to dominate the AI search market despite the emergence of rival products from Apple and OpenAI. Apple launched its AI-powered Siri assistant, and OpenAI integrated web search into its ChatGPT chatbot, while Meta executives announced plans to expand its own AI search capabilities. Google has responded by adding AI Overviews to its search engine and releasing a standalone chatbot, Gemini. Despite the competition, Google's search dominance and unique insight into web results are expected to remain secure, with its audience slow to switch to new AI-powered search platforms.

images.alt_text: Examples shown on the OpenAI website closely resembled search results on Google and Google Maps.

site_title: NetLink NBN Trust posts 1.1% increase in H1 DPU to S$0.0268
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a 1.1% increase in half-year distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0268, despite a 8.3% decline in net profit to S$48.5 million. Lower Ebitda and higher depreciation and amortization contributed to the net profit drop. Revenue was down 0.2% to S$204.8 million, while Ebitda fell 3.8% to S$143.5 million. The company remains cautious about the global economic outlook and will continue to monitor and respond to changes.

images.alt_text: Samuel Oh
NetLink Trust's company vehicle. NetLink Trust has become the fibre network operator of the Next Gen NBN, in place of OpenNet Pte Ltd, since 1 October 2014.
Both Ebita and revenue dropped 2.4% and 2.9% respectively in Q1 compared to the corresponding period a year ago.

site_title: MaNaDr’s low prices could have encouraged too-brief teleconsultations: doctors
summary: The Singaporean government has revoked the licence of MaNaDr Clinic, a telemedicine platform, for delivering brief and potentially unethical consultations. Doctors say the platform's low prices, from S$8.20, may have incentivized them to prioritize volume over quality, leading to reduced takings and prioritizing short consultations. The Ministry of Health (MOH) has referred 41 doctors to the Singapore Medical Council for possible inquiries into professional misconduct, citing the clinic's inability to deliver outpatient services in a clinically and ethically appropriate manner.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
On Oct 24, MOH said it intended to revoke MaNaDr Clinic’s licence.
MOH has referred 41 doctors providing teleconsultations at the clinic to the Singapore Medical Council for potential professional misconduct.
Saxenda is approved for individuals with a BMI above 30, as well as those with a BMI over 27.5 who have chronic conditions like high blood pressure or high cholesterol.
MoneyHero and MaNaDr continues the trend of woe among Singapore's Nasdaq-listed companies.

site_title: Ryanair cuts passenger growth target amid Boeing jet delays
summary: Ryanair has cut its passenger growth target for fiscal 2026 to 210 million, down from 215 million, due to delivery delays from Boeing. The airline now expects nine aircraft originally planned for the fiscal third quarter to arrive in the following three months. CEO Neil Sorahan stated that the outlook is "highly dependent" on Boeing ending the strike and production ramping up quickly. This could leave Ryanair 10 aircraft short for the peak summer season.

images.alt_text: Ryanair has filed more than two dozen challenges over the billions of state aid doled out by EU nations to carriers – winning some cases in the bloc’s lower court over subsidies for the likes of Lufthansa and Air France-KLM.

site_title: China’s lawmakers review Bill to raise local government debt ceilings
summary: China's lawmakers reviewed a bill to raise local government debt ceilings, aiming to replace existing hidden debt. The move comes as the Chinese economy has lost steam due to a prolonged property market downturn and ballooning local government debt, denting growth momentum. The bill is closely watched as it could alleviate investment and economic growth pressures.

images.alt_text: The property sector was long a key driver of growth, but is now mired in a sea of debt.
Foreigners can now also make strategic investments through tender offers other than private placements or transfers-by-agreement.
Changes proposed by China's top legislative body will require annual progress reports on debt management work from the cabinet and local governments, spokesperson Huang Haihua said.
The value of new-home sales from the 100 biggest real estate companies rose 7.1 per cent from a year earlier to 435.5 billion yuan (S$80.9 billion), reversing from a 37.7 per cent slump in September.
Low wages, high youth unemployment and a feeble social safety net leave China’s household spending below 40 per cent of GDP, or about 20 percentage points behind the global average.

site_title: Opec actions increasing volatility and hampering new investment in oil and gas, Eni CEO says
summary: Opec+ agreed to delay a planned December oil output increase by one month due to weak demand in China and rising supplies, increasing energy market volatility. This decision, made by eight Opec+ members, has hampered investment in new oil and gas production, according to Eni CEO Claudio Descalzi. Descalzi expects high volatility in energy markets to extend into 2025, posing challenges for investment and supply in the industry. Oil prices rose over 2.5% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Brent rose as much as 2 per cent to more than US$74 a barrel.
Global markets still face a glut next year even if the Opec+ alliance refrains from increasing supplies, the International Energy Agency in Paris estimates.
Brent futures were up 29 US cents, or 0.4 per cent, to settle at US$73.10 a barrel.

site_title: Temasek-backed CIX to feature carbon ratings on trading platform
summary: Climate Impact X (CIX), a Temasek-backed carbon trading platform, is introducing carbon ratings on its trading platform, enabling users to make more informed decisions on their trades. BeZero Carbon, a carbon ratings agency, will provide project-level assessments, rating projects from "AAA" to "D" based on their likelihood of delivering on their carbon credit claims. This move aims to build high-integrity carbon markets and equip users with tools to understand the relationship between price and quality in carbon credit liquidity.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Posed photo of a pair of hands holding a seedling in soil.
New CEO of Climate Impact X, Choo Oi-Yee
CIX plans to expand its voluntary carbon markets trade database
Mizuho will invest in Climate Impact X, joining its founding shareholders DBS Bank, SGX Group, Standard Chartered and GenZero, a decarbonisation investment platform founded by Temasek.

site_title: Indonesia weighs switching Garuda CEO as part of turnaround plan
summary: Indonesia is considering a change in CEO at Garuda Indonesia, the national flag carrier, as part of a turnaround plan to boost profitability. Acting CEO of Lion Air, Wamildan Tsani Panjaitan, and Garuda's CFO, Prasetio, are leading candidates. A new CEO could be appointed by mid-month, amid plans to expand the fleet to 150 aircraft and increase international flights. Despite a US$10 billion debt restructuring in 2022, Garuda is still struggling to generate a profit due to increased competition with privately-held Lion Mentari Airlines.

images.alt_text: SIA first announced plans to enter into a joint venture with Garuda Indonesia  in May 2023.
The tie-up is unlikely to reduce competition, said SIA and Garuda, as they will continue to face “intense” rivalry from low-cost carriers.

site_title: M&G buys stake in European property firm as it bets on turnaround
summary: British insurer and asset manager M&G has acquired a 65% stake in European real estate investor BauMont, as it prepares to buy up more commercial property in anticipation of a market recovery. The deal will allow M&G to expand its real estate business internationally and bolster its private markets arm, overseeing £73 billion of assets. BauMont will invest independently, but have access to M&G's support functions, and plans to "selectively" buy offices in London and Paris, targeting a market that is adjusting to higher borrowing costs and entering a new cycle of growth.

images.alt_text: Blackstone’s European wealth business currently has offices in London, Paris, Zurich, Milan and Frankfurt.

site_title: Anglo-American to sell stake in Australian steelmaking coal mines for US$1.1 billion
summary: Anglo American is selling its 33.3% stake in Jellinbah Group's Queensland-based coal mines for US$1.1 billion to Zashvin, an Australian electric power generation facility operator. This sale is part of the company's restructuring efforts after fending off a US$49 billion takeover from BHP Group in May. Anglo American will retain a 33.3% stake in the joint venture, while Japanese conglomerate Marubeni retains the remaining 33.3% stake. The sale is expected to be completed in the coming months.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 4)
summary: Singapore Airlines plans to invest S$1.1 billion in retrofitting 41 Airbus A350-900 long-haul and ultra-long-range aircraft with newer cabin products. The retrofit will increase the aircraft's passenger capacity to 258 seats, including 42 in business class, 24 in premium economy, and 192 in economy. The upgrade aims to enhance the airline's fleet and improve passenger experience.

images.alt_text: In the manufacturing sector, a majority of the respondents say they will not implement a four-day work week in their organisations.

site_title: GLP’s cancelled bond sale trains spotlight on long-term finances
summary: Asian logistics operator GLP cancelled its first US dollar bond sale since 2021, citing insufficient demand to reach its desired pricing. The company cited a record coupon above 10% and has significant business in China's faltering economy. Despite announcing a key deleveraging move, investors remain cautious about GLP's long-term financial health and its ability to manage maturities, with its US dollar bond prices in the secondary market indicating a low probability of call events.

images.alt_text: GLP’s Cajamar II facility in Sao Paulo, Brazil.
The upfront payment consists of US$1.8 billion in cash and approximately US$1.9 billion in Ares Class A common shares.
As of the end of 2023, GLP had around US$2.2 billion of cash and cash equivalents, according to its latest financial statement.

site_title: Thai SCG halts operations at US$5.4 billion Vietnam petrochemical complex
summary: Thailand's SCG suspends operations at its US$5.4 billion Long Son Petrochemicals complex in Vietnam after just one month due to low margin. The chemicals industry faces challenges with high inventory and destocking. SCG expects the industry to remain challenging into fiscal year 2025, with the resumption of operations dependent on global demand dynamics.

site_title: Singapore stocks edge up on eve of US elections following regional trend; STI rises 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% to 3,572.04, following a regional trend. The market saw 1.1 billion shares worth S$925.7 million change hands, with advancers outnumbering decliners 262 to 247. DBS was the only local bank to end higher, while Hongkong Land was the top gainer, rallying 7.1% after unveiling a new business strategy.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 67 to 50.

site_title: Nvidia’s Jensen Huan asked SK Hynix to bring forward supply of HBM4 chips by six months, SK’s chairman says
summary: NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang asked SK Hynix to accelerate the supply of HBM4 chips by six months to meet growing demand for AI technology. SK Hynix initially targeted second-half 2025 delivery, but will now provide the chips faster. Nvidia commands over 80% of the AI chip market, highlighting strong expectations for the new chips. This request underscores the company's aggressive push for AI technology advancements.

images.alt_text: Nvidia has emerged as a cornerstone of the global semiconductor industry, thanks to the essential role its chips play in powering generative AI technologies.
South Korea’s largest company has so far missed the lion’s share of profits stemming from surging AI-related demand.
Nvidia’s stock market value briefly touched US$3.53 trillion, while that of Apple was US$3.52 trillion, according to data from LSEG.
Nvidia said it was rolling out the new small language model, dubbed Nemotron-4-Mini-Hindi-4B, with four billion parameters, for firms to use in developing their own AI models.

site_title: America on edge: How voters are dealing with election stress
summary: Voters across the US are experiencing high levels of anxiety ahead of the presidential election on Tuesday, with many fearing unrest and division if their preferred candidate loses. Some are seeking distractions, such as reading, exercise, or spending time in nature, while others are trying to disengage from the election. A Reuters/Ipsos poll found that 74% of registered voters are concerned about extremist violence if they disagree with the election results, with Democrats more likely to express this concern. The election has sparked worries about the country's future and the potential for lawsuits, court hearings, and violence.

images.alt_text: Voters mark their ballots during early voting at a polling location at the Ellen M. Bozeman Government Center in Arlington, Virginia, US, on Saturday, Oct. 26, 2024. A federal judge in Virginia on Friday halted what she concluded was an unlawful, systematic purge of names from the state's voter rolls ahead of the Nov. 5 presidential election, in a win for the Biden administration. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

former US President and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump (L) arrives to speak at a campaign rally at the PPL Center in Allentown, Pennsylvania, on October 29, 2024, and US Vice President and Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris (R) speaks during a campaign rally in Charlotte, North Carolina, on November 2, 2024. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS and CHARLY TRIBALLEAU / AFP)

site_title: Thailand delays naming Bank of Thailand chair as dispute drags on
summary: Thailand has delayed naming its new central bank chairman as opposition mounts against the government's bid to appoint a former finance minister, Kittiratt Na-Ranong, citing concerns over government interference. The Bank of Thailand's selection panel has postponed its meeting until Nov 11 to consider all aspects of the selection process. This comes amidst a simmering dispute between the government and the central bank over monetary policy and inflation targets, with the BOT chair selection becoming the latest flashpoint.

images.alt_text: A market in Bangkok. A surprise rate cut earlier this month and an agreement between BOT and the finance ministry to retain inflation target at 1 to 3% for next year have helped cool tension.

At the Oct 16 meeting, Thailand's monetary policy committee unexpectedly voted 5-2 to cut the one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 2.25 per cent, the first decrease since 2020. Two members voted to keep the rate steady.
Thailand’s government, central bank to keep inflation target for 2025

site_title: Malaysia’s Petronas to halt local NGV fuel supply next year on declining demand
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas plans to halt domestic retail supply and sale of natural gas for vehicles by July next year due to declining demand. The move aims to ensure road user safety. Only 0.2% of registered motor vehicles in Malaysia are fueled by natural gas vehicles (NGV), with many in aging condition and spare parts unavailable. Transport Minister Anthony Loke stated that these issues pose a safety risk, potentially leading to injury or death.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, November 4, 2024
summary: Asian markets rose ahead of the US election and a Chinese stimulus meeting, with the US dollar falling as some Trump trades are pared. Oil prices jumped over 1% on a delayed Opec+ output hike. Genting Singapore shares rose nearly 2% after the RWS casino chief stepped down. The STI index rose 0.5% at Monday's open.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 67 to 50.
Markets rose across Asia, with Hong Kong and Shanghai among the best performers, while Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Wellington and Jakarta were also well up.
Brent rose as much as 2 per cent to more than US$74 a barrel.
Andrew MacDonald, former chief casino officer at RWS, was issued a persona non grata notice in August.

site_title: New York Times tech workers go on strike
summary: The New York Times Tech Guild, representing over 600 workers, went on strike on November 4, 2024, amid negotiations over pay increases, pay equity, and return-to-office policies. The guild rejected a 2.5% annual wage increase and minimum 5% pay increase for promotions, while management maintained its in-office work requirements. The strike began with daily protests outside the company's headquarters, with the guild stating they "have left us no choice but to demonstrate the power of our labour."

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man speaks on his mobile phone in front of the New York Times building in New York City May 21, 2009.  REUTERS/Joel Boh (UNITED STATES MEDIA)/File Photo

site_title: MAS to drive digital assets trading, announces plans for more tokenisation
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is driving the adoption of asset tokenisation in the financial services industry, with plans to build commercial networks for payments, capital raising, and secondary trading of tokenised assets. The central bank has reached an "inflexion point" in asset tokenisation, with greater momentum but limited industry-wide scale, according to Deputy Managing Director Leong Sing Cheong. MAS is launching initiatives to support industry efforts, including a wholesale central bank digital currency and standardized frameworks for tokenization in fixed income markets.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
US-based Ripple provides enterprise solutions that leverage the cryptocurrency XRP.

site_title: Country Garden sales slump abates after China property stimulus
summary: Country Garden Holdings reported a 31% decline in contracted sales for October to 4.3 billion yuan (S$798 million), a moderation from a 41% drop in September. China's stimulus measures, including reduced borrowing costs and relaxed buying curbs, may have helped improve the sales slump. The company's sales still lag peers, but the improvement may temporarily ease investor concerns over its liquidity. Country Garden is in talks with creditors for a debt overhaul and has missed a target date for restructuring plan key creditor support.

site_title: Money launderer Su Baolin’s former Sentosa Cove plot sold for S$22 million
summary: A plot in Sentosa Cove once owned by Cambodian money launderer Su Baolin has been sold for S$22 million, a price of about S$1,125 per sq ft. The 1,816.3 sq m site, with unblocked views of the sea and Central Business District, has a 99-year leasehold tenure. The sale sets a new benchmark price for seafront-facing land in Sentosa Cove, with the buyer expected to pay an additional S$16 million or more to build a new bungalow.

site_title: China’s Nio plans to sell its first hybrid car overseas only: sources
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio plans to launch its first hybrid model, the Firefly, in 2026, exclusively for overseas markets including the Middle East, North Africa, and Europe. The hybrid vehicle aims to address trade barriers and charging infrastructure challenges faced by Chinese firms selling EVs abroad. The model will not be sold in China, where Nio will continue to offer only EVs with battery-swappable technology. The launch is seen as a strategic move to boost sales in Europe's mass market.

images.alt_text: Hot stock: Nio rises 17.4% on news of strategic investment in China unit

A staff member hands an umbrella to a man outside a store of Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Nio at the company's manufacturing base in Hefei, Anhui province, China June 28, 2024. REUTERS/Ellen Zhang
Beijing has dismissed the EU’s anti-subsidy probe as protectionist and has been in intensive talks with the EU to explore alternatives to tariffs.

site_title: Bitcoin traders brace for fierce price swings as clock ticks to US vote
summary: Bitcoin traders expect volatile price swings after the US presidential election on November 5, with a 30-day gauge of implied swings hitting its highest level since August. The options market signals potential 8% moves in either direction, compared to 2% on a normal day. A week ago, Trump's lead over Harris in betting markets lifted Bitcoin to a record high, but his odds have since dropped, pushing the token lower. Market speculators are bracing for potential market volatility in the aftermath of the election.

images.alt_text: Open interest on crypto derivatives exchanges – an indicator of market activity – hit an all-time high of US$43.61 billion on Tuesday, as per data provider Coinglass.

site_title: UAE’s Adnoc to deploy autonomous AI in the energy sector for the first time
summary: UAE's Adnoc to deploy autonomous AI in the energy sector for the first time, marking a significant milestone in the use of agentic artificial intelligence. The partnership with G42, Microsoft, and AIQ aims to enhance the industry's efficiency and performance. CEO Sultan Al Jaber stated that agentic AI will analyze vast amounts of data, identify operational improvements, and speed up seismic surveys, increasing production forecast accuracy by up to 90%. This move is part of the UAE's efforts to diversify its economy and strengthen its international clout through the development of advanced technologies.

images.alt_text: Adnoc said it would launch a 62 euros-per-share voluntary public takeover offer for all shares in Covestro.
FILE PHOTO: Logos of ADNOC are seen at Gastech, the world's biggest expo for the gas industry, in Chiba, Japan, April 4, 2017.    REUTERS/Toru Hanai

site_title: South Korean refiners’ losses deepen in Q3, margins set to improve in Q4
summary: South Korean refiners reported significant losses in the third quarter due to declining oil prices and inventory-related losses, with SK Energy's refining business posting its largest loss since 2022. However, the company expects margins to recover in the fourth quarter with peak winter demand and refinery run cuts in Asia. Refiners such as S-Oil and Hyundai Oilbank also reported large quarterly losses, but some expect improved margins in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: South Korea's top refiner SK Energy's main refinery is seen in Ulsan, about 410 km (256 miles) southeast of Seoul, February 25, 2009. REUTERS/Jo Yong-Hak (SOUTH KOREA)/File Photo

Asian refiners have been particularly jittery in recent days about rising tensions between Israel and Iran’s proxies as the region takes the bulk of exports from the Persian Gulf producer, which amounted to 1.7 million barrels a day last month.
In July, Sinochem had shut two of its three Shandong refineries – Zhenghe and Changyi – for indefinite maintenance amid high crude oil cost and weak Chinese refined fuel market.

The sites are coming up for sale as Big Oil faces shareholder pressure to trim portfolios to focus on assets with the best returns, while also offloading or cleaning up major polluting businesses like refineries.

site_title: Oil prices jump over 1% on delayed Opec+ output hike
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Monday after Opec+ delayed a planned December output hike by one month due to soft demand and rising supply outside the group. Brent futures increased by 1.61% to $74.28 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose by 1.73% to $70.69 a barrel. The delay means Opec+ will extend its 2.2 million barrel-per-day cut for another month, potentially supporting prices.

images.alt_text: Global markets still face a glut next year even if the Opec+ alliance refrains from increasing supplies, the International Energy Agency in Paris estimates.

site_title: Vietnam real estate tycoon seeks to overturn death sentence
summary: Vietnam real estate tycoon Truong My Lan is appealing her death sentence for massive fraud, which she received in April for embezzling $12.3 billion from Saigon Commercial Bank. In a second trial, Lan and 33 co-defendants were convicted of laundering $23 billion in stolen assets and misappropriating $30 trillion from investors. The High People's Court in Ho Chi Minh City will review her appeal until November 25, as 47 other defendants will also have their verdict appeals heard during the same hearing.

images.alt_text: Truong My Lan Photographer: Maika Elan/Bloomberg

site_title: India to revamp power demand forecasting for better planning
summary: India is revamping its power demand forecasting to ensure generation capacity matches actual demand and maintain grid stability. The Central Electricity Authority plans to update its forecasting methods every two years, with more frequent forecasts to account for extreme weather events. This overhaul is necessary due to changing power usage patterns, increased use of intermittent renewable energy, and frequent extreme weather events. The government is seeking cooperation with weather agencies to access better environmental data and improve forecasting accuracy.

images.alt_text: An electronic ticker board indicates stock figures at the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) in Mumbai, India, on Thursday, Fab. 1, 2018. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government ended a tax break on equity investments as it taps the stock market boom to boost its coffers. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Gold necklaces are displayed inside a jewellery showroom in Kolkata, India, July 23, 2024. REUTERS/Sahiba Chawdhary/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Release more exec condo sites to meet bullish demand
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has drawn five bidders for a 99-year leasehold executive condominium (EC) site in Tampines Street 95, with Sim Lian's S$465 million top bid. The site can yield around 560 homes, and prices may reach S$1,600 psf or more, potentially stretching buyer affordability. New EC homebuyers face a minimum occupation period (MOP) of five years, allowing for greater flexibility in buying and selling private homes. With lighter resale restrictions, ECs may appeal to buyers who want to rent out spare rooms or sell their homes after the MOP.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
The plot in Tampines has a site area of 22,488.9 sq m and a maximum gross floor area of 56,223 sqm. It can potentially yield 560 housing units.
More than 35,000 applicants for 8,573 new flats in HDB’s October BTO exercise

site_title: Pakistan central bank cuts key rate by 250 bps to 15%
summary: The State Bank of Pakistan cut its key policy rate by 250 basis points to 15% for the fourth consecutive reduction since June, aiming to revive the sluggish economy. The move comes as inflation eases, averaging 8.7% in the current financial year. The International Monetary Fund expects inflation to average 9.5% for the year ending June. This is the total cuts of 700 bps in under five months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) is pictured on a reception desk at the head office in Karachi, Pakistan July 16, 2019. REUTERS/Akhtar Soomro/File Photo

site_title: Foxconn subsidiary seeks US$80 million Vietnam investment for integrated circuits
summary: Foxconn's subsidiary Shunsin plans to invest US$80 million in northern Vietnam to produce integrated circuits, with an annual capacity of 4.5 million units. The plant, located in Bac Giang province, will focus on producing and processing electronic components for export to the US, EU, and Japan. The investment is part of Foxconn's existing US$3.2 billion investment in Vietnam since the 2000s, with most manufacturing plants located in northern provinces of Bac Ninh and Bac Giang. Operations are expected to begin in December 2026.

images.alt_text: Taiwanese businesses have invested billions of US dollars in China since the country began landmark economic reforms four decades ago.

Foxconn, the world’s largest contract electronics manufacturer and better know as Apple’s biggest iPhone assembler, has been benefiting from the artificial intelligence boom given it also makes servers.

Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision Industry Co is considering buying a majority stake in Sharp Corp's loss-making LCD business for up to 200 billion yen (S$2.4 billion), Japan's Mainichi newspaper said on Monday, without citing any sources.
Hon Hai Precision Industry, also known as Foxconn, reported sales rose 20.2 per cent to NT$1.85 trillion for the three months ended September from a year earlier.

site_title: Eurozone manufacturing slump shows signs of stabilising in October, PMIs show
summary: The Eurozone manufacturing sector showed signs of stabilisation in October, with the final Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 46, a 28th consecutive month of contraction. Demand eased, and production dropped at a slower pace than the previous month. New orders, a measure of demand, bounced to a four-month high, but still signalled a decline. The data suggests the recession in the manufacturing sector did not deepen further, and factories reduced prices at the fastest rate since April, justifying the European Central Bank's ongoing policy-easing cycle.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product in the 20 countries sharing the euro grew by 0.4 per cent in the third quarter from the previous three months, beating expectations for 0.2 per cent.
Among other economic data, the eurozone's third-quarter gross domestic product report this week could shape the rate path on both sides of the Atlantic.
Germany is the prime culprit as its industrial giants grapple with costlier energy and soft Chinese demand.
ECB president Christine Lagarde emphasized the need for caution, noting that upcoming data will provide insights into the state of the economy and both overall and underlying inflation.

The latest economic data is likely to have tilted the balance within the ECB in favour of a rate cut, with business activity and sentiment surveys as well as the inflation reading for September all coming in slightly lower than expected.

site_title: Tesla China shipments slip 5% in october after bumper quarter
summary: Tesla shipped 68,280 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles in October, a 5.3% year-over-year decline, following a record quarter for China shipments. The US electric vehicle maker's profit remains higher, with $2.2 billion in net income in the third quarter. Strong competition from BYD, a homegrown Chinese champion, contributed to the decline, but Tesla remains more profitable. Retail passenger vehicle sales are expected to rise 8.2% year-over-year in October, with new-energy car sales up 58% from last year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tesla China-made Model 3 vehicles are seen during a delivery event at its factory in Shanghai, China January 7, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Singapore life insurers have healthy capital buffers to withstand shocks
summary: Singapore's nine key life insurers have healthy capital buffers, with most exceeding the 150% capital adequacy ratio (CAR) requirement. This surpasses the typical level of 100% and demonstrates the insurers' ability to withstand sudden shocks. Insurers such as Tokio Marine Life and Manulife have taken management actions to strengthen their capital positions, while others like Great Eastern have maintained healthy CAR levels above the minimum statutory requirement. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's risk-based capital framework has contributed to the insurers' strong capital buffers.

site_title: American music supremo Quincy Jones dies at 91
summary: Quincy Jones, a renowned American music supremo, has died at the age of 91. Known as "Q," he had a 65-year music career as a trumpeter, bandleader, arranger, composer, producer, and winner of 27 Grammy Awards. Jones collaborated with iconic artists such as Michael Jackson, producing three landmark albums that changed the landscape of American popular music. He also co-produced the film "The Color Purple" and the television show "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." Jones' legacy as a trailblazer in music and film continues, with his work remaining a testament to his universal hipness and influence on American music.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: 2018 Governors Awards - Arrivals - Hollywood, California, U.S., November 18, 2018 - Quincy Jones. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni/File Photo

site_title: Police search PwC Sydney office amid tax scandal investigation
summary: Police searched PwC Sydney office amid an ongoing investigation into the firm's tax scandal, which began in 2023. The investigation focuses on individuals who have left the firm, and police were examining files at the site. PwC Australia has overhauled its leadership and sold its government services unit since the scandal broke. The firm is cooperating fully with the investigation, which is part of a broader inquiry into confidentiality breaches and ethics breaches across the industry and government.

site_title: Australia’s Westpac annual profit down as costs overshadow margin bump
summary: Westpac, Australia's second-largest mortgage lender, reported a 3% decline in annual profit to A$6.99 billion due to increased costs from a technology overhaul outweighing an improved loan margin. Despite this, the bank upped its final dividend and extended a share buyback. The result is seen as a positive sign ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's expected interest rate cuts in February, which would ease upward pressure on costs and make it easier for borrowers to service debt.

images.alt_text: Westpac will see new CEO Anthony Miller commencing his role from Dec 16, 2024.

site_title: UK’s richest man says ‘spiteful’ tax hikes will kill off growth
summary: UK billionaire James Dyson, the country's wealthiest resident, has criticized Chancellor Rachel Reeves' tax hikes, calling them "spiteful" and stating they will "kill off" growth and entrepreneurship. The 20% tax grab, including an inheritance tax clampdown, will disproportionately affect small businesses, Dyson said. He believes the new Labour government's fiscal plans are aimed at detesting the private sector and stifling individual aspiration and economic growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Britain's Secretary of State for Business and Trade and President of the Board of Trade Jonathan Reynolds walks outside Number 10 Downing Street in London, Britain, July 9, 2024. REUTERS/Chris J. Ratcliffe/File Photo

The S&P Global UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index sank to 49.9 in October from 51.5 in September, below an initial estimate of 50.3 and just below the 50 level which divides growth from contraction in the survey.
UK's housing market had been gaining momentum on the back of cooling mortgage costs, with mortgage approvals rising to its highest in more than two years in September.
The Resolution Foundation says that real household disposable incomes per person are set to grow by an average of just 0.5 per cent a year over the next five years.

site_title: Malaysia stocks regain mojo in 2024, driven by property, tech and Sarawak-focused sectors
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia stocks have shown resilience in 2024, driven by sectors such as property, technology, and Sarawak-focused companies. The FBM KLCI has risen over 10% year-to-date, with key players like HeiTech Padu, Notion VTec, and Sime Darby Property delivering impressive returns. The property sector has rebounded post-pandemic, while tech stocks initially led gains but have since lost momentum. Analysts credit government initiatives, foreign investments, and a surge in data centre projects for the sector's performance. However, some sectors, such as plantation and telco companies, have faced challenges. A persistent weak ringgit could benefit export-driven sectors, while a correction is expected due to the ringgit's steep appreciation.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Muhamad Umar Swift, the chief executive officer of Bursa Malaysia, is confident that the exchange will hit its target of 42 new listings for 2024.
After a lacklustre performance in 2023, Bursa Malaysia’s initial public offering (IPO) market has gained momentum in 2024 and growing stronger.
Bursa Malaysia is known for its physically-delivered crude palm oil contract, as South-east Asia produces the bulk of the world’s supply.

Generic pix of the ticker tape at the SGX Centre 1, located in Shenton Way, on April 22, 2024. A ticker is a symbol, a unique combination of letters and numbers that represent a particular stock or security listed on an exchange. Trades are executed based on a company's ticker symbol, which is recorded in the exchange's trading system.
Market watchers believe that dual-listings are not an ideal scenario, and that companies will have to justify the costs of such a move over time.

site_title: Only Harris will deliver shared prosperity
summary: Vice-President Kamala Harris has proposed an economic plan that prioritizes shared prosperity, encouraging science, and funding new business in all parts of the country. In contrast, Donald Trump's protectionist policies, including higher tariffs, would hinder innovation and create fewer jobs. Harris's plan supports technology-driven job creation, modernizing traditional sectors, and investing in cutting-edge technologies like AI and clean energy. Trump's approach, on the other hand, would benefit the few at the expense of the many, potentially destabilizing global trade and national security. Harris's plan is seen as a more coherent and effective approach to generating shared prosperity.

images.alt_text: Democratic presidential nominee US Vice President Kamala Harris at a campaign rally in Reno, Nevada, US, Oct 31, 2024.
Trump vs Harris: A visual summary

“A lot of companies in the Chinese Internet space have been beaten down a lot and I think over the next few months just based on the announcements we will have more clarity in policy around them,” Sipahimalani said. “In some of those cases there’ll be very attractive opportunities to invest in them.”

site_title: Gold steadies as investors brace for US election and potential rate cuts
summary: Gold prices held steady at $2,738.29 per ounce on Monday as investors awaited the US presidential election and potential interest rate cuts. Spot gold edged up 0.1% from the previous day, while US gold futures remained flat. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates this week, with a 98% chance of a quarter-basis-point rate cut. The outcome of the US presidential election, which pits Democratic candidate Kamala Harris against Republican Donald Trump, could significantly influence gold prices, which thrive in low interest rate environments.

images.alt_text: Bullion marked a monthly rise of 4.15 per cent in October and hit a record high of US$2,790.15 in the previous session.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Genting Singapore, City Developments, Keppel Reit, Oxley
summary: Genting Singapore's Resorts World Sentosa chief casino operator Andrew MacDonald stepped down, citing a ban from Marina Bay Sands premises for allegedly poaching high-rollers. City Developments Ltd acquired a Shanghai mixed-use site for S$853.7 million, increasing its pro-forma net gearing by 3.3%. The companies also saw shares rise: Genting Singapore's shares ended trading up 1.2%, while City Developments Ltd's shares rose 0.4%.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

site_title: India hands out fines to owners of polluting vehicles, building sites
summary: India's capital, New Delhi, has been rated the world's most polluted capital for four years in a row. Authorities have handed out fines to nearly 60,000 vehicle owners and over 7,500 construction sites for violating pollution rules, amid a slump in air quality over the past three weeks. The Central Pollution Control Board rated the conditions as "very poor" with a score of 373. This move aims to address the worsening air quality, a common winter problem across South Asia.

images.alt_text: According to the lawsuit, Pepsi and Coca-Cola should be required to pay penalties for engaging in unfair and deceptive business practices.

A National Environment Agency (NEA) officer conducting checks on a Malaysian-registered vehicle using a probe which measures exhaust emissions. Drivers of vehicles found to be emitting excessive exhaust fumes will be fined. This vehicle was found with an extremely high index of 91 HSU (Hartridge Smoke Unit).
Penalties for pollutive light commercial vehicles push buyers to switch to heavier vehicles instead

River Thames in Henley-on-Thames, Britain, Aug 29, 2024. Four decades after privatisation, calls to nationalise the water industry have swept across England and Wales amid sewage spills and rising household bills. Only 37 per cent of Europe’s surface water bodies achieved “good” or “high” ecological status, a measure of aquatic ecosystem health, an EEA report said.

site_title: The huge risk in seeking ‘safety’
summary: Investors in the Straits Times Index (STI) near record highs are often swayed by "safety" products that promise both growth and capital preservation. However, these schemes are misleading, as growth and capital preservation cannot coexist in the short term. True capital preservation means eliminating volatility, which is impossible, and can lead to missing out on growth. A long-term perspective is necessary, and investors should consider equity portfolios with diversification to reap positive inflation-adjusted returns despite occasional short-term negativity.

images.alt_text: Few expected energy stocks to flounder as they did in 2023, after riding skyrocketing oil prices to 2022 outperformance.
America’s election will be a rising tide lifting most boats, says the writer.
bundle, jute rope, newspaper

site_title: China’s DeepRoute.ai raises US$100 million as smart driving adoption speeds up
summary: Chinese autonomous driving technology developer DeepRoute.ai has raised US$100 million from an automaker to bolster mass adoption of its systems on vehicles in China. CEO Maxwell Zhou expects nearly 200,000 cars to be equipped with its advanced assisted driving system by the end of 2025, up from about 20,000 now. The system is comparable to Tesla's Full Self-Driving and aims to gain a head start in China's autonomous driving market.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration plans to issue a proposed rule that would bar Chinese software in vehicles in the United States with Level 3 automation and above, which would have the effect of also banning testing on US roads of autonomous vehicles produced by Chinese companies.

site_title: Blackstone in advanced talks to acquire shopping centre owner Retail Opportunity: sources
summary: Blackstone is in advanced talks to acquire Retail Opportunity Investments Corp (Roic), a US shopping center owner with a market value of $3.4 billion. If successful, the deal could be finalized in the coming weeks, with Blackstone likely to prevail over rival suitor Bain Capital. Roic has seen a 13.8% increase in same-space new leases and a 11% rise in shares this year, making it an attractive target for buyout firms.

images.alt_text: Blackstone has more than US$90 billion of investment-grade private credit assets, up roughly 40 per cent from a year ago.
The firm’s market capitalisation now stands at US$195 billion, with its stock reaching an all-time closing high of US$159.71 on Oct 16.
Blackstone's distributable earnings climbed 5.5 per cent to US$1.28 billion from a year earlier, buoyed by its lending arm.
Blackstone will develop the buildings by installing cooling machines and cable connections with the aim of leasing them to companies who will install computer servers.

site_title: US dollar falls, bond futures gain as some Trump trades are pared
summary: The US dollar fell 0.5% against its Group-of-10 peers, its largest decline since late September, as investors pared their bullish bets on a Republican victory in the US elections. This shift was prompted by weekend polling data suggesting Democratic candidate Kamala Harris might be ahead in some swing states. Treasury futures rose, while emerging market currencies, such as the Mexican peso, advanced. Investors are re-evaluating their "Dollar Trump Trade" wagers, with some analysts predicting a binary reaction: a Trump win would likely strengthen the dollar, while a Harris victory could weigh on it.

site_title: Changi Airport Group loses appeal to have tax break for S$270m spent on assets like runways
summary: The Changi Airport Group (CAG) has lost an appeal to claim a tax break for S$270 million spent on assets such as runways, taxiways, and aprons at Changi Airport. Justice Choo Han Teck ruled that the assets were structures, not tools of trade, and therefore not eligible for capital allowances. The decision was made after CAG claimed capital expenditure on the assets in 2011, 2012, and 2013, but the Comptroller of Income Tax denied the claims. The High Court upheld the decision, stating that the assets' primary function was as structures, not apparatus used for trade.

site_title: India’s factory growth accelerates in October: PMI
summary: India's manufacturing growth accelerated in October, rising to 57.5 from 56.5 in September, as firms took on more workers to meet growing demand. This marks a rebound from three months of deceleration and suggests a better business outlook. The improvement in operating conditions is attributed to a broadening economy, according to HSBC's chief India economist, Pranjul Bhandari. The increase in PMI is seen as a positive indicator for the country's manufacturing sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers inspect brand tags on apparel ready for packaging at a textile factory of Texport Industries in Hindupur town in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, India, February 9, 2022. Picture taken February 9, 2022. REUTERS/Samuel Rajkumar/File Photo

site_title: More public EV fast chargers deployed under tender by LTA subsidiary
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) subsidiary EV-Electric Charging (EVe) has deployed the first of 60 public fast-charging stations for electric vehicles across 60 HDB car parks and JTC industrial premises. The stations, launched on November 4, are part of a tender awarded to charging point operators Volt Singapore and CDG-Engie. Senior Minister Amy Khor emphasized the need for high-mileage drivers to have access to fast chargers, with the LTA committing to supporting the deployment of these stations.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Proton eyeing to bring forward the launching date of the first EV, Proton e.Mas by end-2024, from its initial plan in 2025.
The Yutong C11H plug-in hybrid bus is an example of extended-range electric vehicle technology that is gaining ground in China.
BYD offers three models and now has more than 30 showrooms.
As PHEV technology improves, it could offer consumers and business owners an alternative to full EVs long into the future, even in Singapore.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise ahead of US election, Chinese stimulus meeting
summary: Asian markets rose on November 4, driven by a positive lead from Wall Street and data showing fewer US jobs created than expected. Investors are anticipating a potential Federal Reserve interest rate cut following the US presidential election, which is too close to call between Democratic Vice-President Kamala Harris and Republican candidate Donald Trump. Chinese leaders are meeting to discuss a stimulus package, which experts believe could be influenced by the election outcome.

images.alt_text: Tokyo’s Nikkei fell 2.1 per cent on Monday as a stronger yen clouded the outlook for Japanese exporters.

site_title: Blackstone targets new European markets in global wealth push
summary: Blackstone plans to enter at least two new European markets next year to tap growing demand among the well-off. The company's European wealth business currently has offices in London, Paris, Zurich, Milan, and Frankfurt, and has grown its private wealth assets globally to around $250 billion. Blackstone's wealth products have a minimum investment threshold of $10,000 to $25,000 and are designed for retail investors. The company aims to expand its business by launching new semi-liquid funds in credit and infrastructure, and has promoted a new chief operating officer for Europe.

images.alt_text: Blackstone is one of the world’s largest investors in real estate, with US$336.1 billion in assets in the sector as at the end of June.
Blackstone has more than US$90 billion of investment-grade private credit assets, up roughly 40 per cent from a year ago.
The firm’s market capitalisation now stands at US$195 billion, with its stock reaching an all-time closing high of US$159.71 on Oct 16.
Blackstone's distributable earnings climbed 5.5 per cent to US$1.28 billion from a year earlier, buoyed by its lending arm.

site_title: SPH Media cuts 10% of tech employees in restructuring move in bid to stay sustainable
summary: SPH Media, a Singapore-based media group, has cut 10% of its tech employees as part of a restructuring effort to remain competitive and sustainable. The move comes after a division-wide exercise to adjust team sizes and scope. Affected employees will receive comprehensive severance packages, career coaching, and counseling support. The tech division will be restructured into three departments: CTO office, IT, and product and engineering, with a focus on streamlining operations and finding opportunities for resource optimization.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Government to continue providing funding to support SPHMT's transformation.
The future of SPH Media - it isn't enough to be trusted
SPH completes transfer of media business to CLG
BT Explains: Keppel's bid to take SPH private

site_title: Value-unlocking moves will enliven market more than any new SDRs, Catalist listings
summary: Singapore's Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched new Hong Kong SDRs, offering local investors access to top Hong Kong stocks, including Alibaba, Tencent, and HSBC, at lower minimum investment amounts. The new listings may boost market vibrancy, but new Catalist listings, such as Food Innovators and Goodwill Entertainment, may struggle to win over investors. Meanwhile, Hongkong Land's pivot to focus on generating recurring income and value-unlocking may have a more significant impact on the market's long-term performance.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Hongkong Land chief financial officer Craig Beattie (left) and chief executive officer Michael Smith announced the group's new business strategy on Oct 29.

Japanese food operator Food Innovators Holdings runs restaurants in Japan, Singapore and Malaysia. CEO Kubota Yasuaki said: "If we are listed in Singapore, we will be known to a lot of people in Asia (and) our credibility will also increase."
Tendon Kohaku, a Japanese restaurant serving rice bowls, is one of the brands under Food Innovators Holdings' portfolio.
The company is expected to list on the Singapore Exchange Catalist board on Nov 8.

Singapore is the worst performing market for South-east Asia for IPOs this year, with just one IPO in the first three quarters of the year. Cancer treatment provider Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine Holdings’ (SIAMH) Catalist listing in February raised gross proceeds of S$26.2 million or net proceeds of S$21.7 million.
“A lot of existing operators have karaoke rooms only, but we offer multi-entertainment concepts,” said Flint Lu (left), founder, CEO and executive chair of Goodwill Entertainment.
EVs at the BYD showroom in Singapore on Alexandra Road.

site_title: Deliveroo launches shopping service, but food delivery still the mainstay: Singapore GM
summary: Deliveroo launched a shopping service in Singapore, allowing customers to order beauty products, flowers, pet food, and other retail items for delivery within an hour. The service is not aimed at competing with e-commerce platforms, but rather to meet customers' needs and provide an additional channel for merchants to reach more customers. Deliveroo has partnered with brands such as Lush, Xpressflower, and Pet Lovers Centre, and plans to use machine-learning to help customers browse products based on occasions. The service is not expected to divert resources from the food-delivery business, with Deliveroo remaining committed to food delivery.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

Deliveroo Singapore launches Deliveroo Editions 2, their second state-of-the-art, delivery-only kitchen in Singapore, on 23 April 2018. Located at CT Hub in Lavender, Deliveroo’s second Editions site marks the anniversary of the first, and extremely successful, Editions site in Singapore, underlining Deliveroo’s rapid growth across the country. Editions kitchens allow restaurants to expand, create new brands and reach new customers without needing a high street presence.
Deliveroo’s Editions site at Alice@Mediapolis in One-North – which spanned over 3,000 square feet – had opened in March 2019 to much fanfare.

Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation for the year is expected to be in the upper half of the company’s previous outlook for £110 million to £130 million, Deliveroo said.

site_title: ‘Venom’ dances on, again leading North America box office
summary: "Venom: the Last Dance" leads the North American box office for the third consecutive weekend, earning an estimated $26.1 million. The film has grossed $90 million domestically and $227 million internationally in its two weeks out. The animated film "The Wild Robot" rose to second place, while horror film "Smile 2" and religious thriller "Conclave" took third and fourth spots respectively. New film "Here" from director Robert Zemeis, underperformed with a $5 million opening, prompting critics to say it needs to connect emotionally to succeed.

images.alt_text: In the latest installment of "Venom", Tom Hardy reprises his role as a disgruntled journalist who morphs into a terrifying alien with huge jagged teeth - and what has been described as a Gene Simmons tongue.

site_title: All aboard the AI-data centre gravy train
summary: The data centre sector is experiencing significant growth, with Reits like Keppel DC Reit and Digital Core Reit posting positive earnings despite high interest rates and potential oversupply. The sector is driven by the increasing demand for AI and computing power, with Goldman Sachs predicting a 160% growth in data centre power demand by 2030. Meanwhile, ultra-rich individuals are seeking new tax-friendly destinations, with Singapore poised to attract a significant influx of foreign investors, including those from the UK, which is abolishing the non-domiciled tax status of 74,000 super-wealthy residents.

images.alt_text: Joyce Hooi
While the Monetary Authority of Singapore might yet produce bold changes to revive the market, its review group’s recommendations will only be out later next year.
A tale of two kinds of Chinese consumers emerged last week, as updates from LVMH and Sasseur Reit gave us a glimpse of what to expect beyond the Great Wall, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.
China’s common prosperity policy was revived in a big way in 2021 with various regulatory measures curtailing the growth of certain industries, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.

site_title: China urges France to get EU to arrive at palatable EV trade solution
summary: China is urging France to pressure the European Commission to find a mutually acceptable solution to the EU's anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese-made battery EVs, which has hindered China-EU auto industry cooperation. The EU launched the investigation last year and voted for tariffs on Chinese EVs in October. China has also launched investigations into European pork and dairy imports and imposed anti-dumping measures on EU brandy imports. China hopes France will take an active role in resolving the issue to restore cooperation between the two industries.

images.alt_text: BYD’s European registrations jumped 162 per cent in September from a year earlier, to 4,376 vehicles, according to Jato.
Europe’s relationship with China is being buffeted by worsening trade tensions, as the EU seeks to target what it says are unfair subsidies and other support that Beijing provides to its companies.

A vehicle assembly line at an auto plant in France. The Europeans should realise that the reason for surging Chinese imports is their own plan to phase out sales of vehicles with internal combustion engines by 2035.
While German automakers still control nearly 15 per cent of the Chinese market, that’s down from a quarter before the pandemic and worse yet, their share of EVs is less than 10 per cent.

site_title: Indonesia volcano eruption kills 10, sets houses aflame
summary: A volcano in eastern Indonesia's Lewotobi Laki-Laki erupted overnight, killing at least 10 people and forcing authorities to evacuate several villages. The volcano, a 1,703-metre twin volcano on the island of Flores, spewed fireballs and ash, with residents describing flaming rocks hitting their homes. The alert level was raised to its highest level, and buildings near the volcano were covered in thick ash. The cause of the eruption is not specified, but the incident highlights the risks of volcanic activity in Indonesia, a country prone to volcanic eruptions.

images.alt_text: A handout picture taken and released by Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation on April 17, 2024 shows Mount Ruang releasing hot lava and smoke in Sangihe Islands as seen from Sitaro, North Sulawesi on April 17, 2024.
