The ad is running ahead of Harris' visit to Southern Nevada on October 31.   Ethan Miller/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Ethan Miller / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
X launched its Community Notes feature last year, which allows users to comment on posts to flag false or misleading content.

FILE PHOTO: Tesla CEO and X owner Elon Musk speaks as Republican presidential nominee and former U.S. president Donald Trump looks on during a rally at the site of the July assassination attempt against Trump, in Butler, Pennsylvania, U.S., October 5, 2024. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo

site_title: Nvidia to take Intel’s spot on Dow Jones Industrial Average
summary: Nvidia is set to join the Dow Jones Industrial Average index, replacing Intel after a 25-year run. The shift marks Intel's struggles in the chipmaking market, particularly in the generative AI sector, where Nvidia has dominated. Intel's shares have declined 54% this year, while Nvidia's have risen over two-fold. The move is seen as a blow to Intel's reputation and could impact its share price further, as it will no longer be included in exchange-traded funds tracking the index.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s largest company has so far missed the lion’s share of profits stemming from surging AI-related demand.
Nvidia’s stock market value briefly touched US$3.53 trillion, while that of Apple was US$3.52 trillion, according to data from LSEG.
Nvidia said it was rolling out the new small language model, dubbed Nemotron-4-Mini-Hindi-4B, with four billion parameters, for firms to use in developing their own AI models.
Nvidia’s CEO Jensen Huang acknowledged that there was a design flaw in Blackwell led to a low yield, attributing the issue entirely to Nvidia's responsibility.

site_title: Ed Sheeran beats copyright appeal over ‘Thinking Out Loud’ song
summary: Ed Sheeran's 2014 hit "Thinking Out Loud" did not illegally copy Marvin Gaye's 1973 classic "Let's Get It On", a US appeals court ruled. The 2nd US Circuit Court of Appeals upheld a lower-court judge's dismissal of a lawsuit from Structured Asset Sales, which owns rights to Gaye's song. The court agreed that the musical elements Sheeran allegedly copied were too common to merit copyright protection and that his song was not similar enough to Gaye's to have infringed on SAS' copyright.

images.alt_text: Musician Ed Sheeran smiles while standing with his legal team after winning his copyright infringement case in New York, May 4, 2023.

site_title: Fed reverse repo use declines to lowest in more than three years
summary: The Federal Reserve's overnight reverse repurchase agreement facility saw a record low of $155 billion in deposits, marking the first time below $200 billion since May 2021. This decline follows a steep reduction from a record $2.55 trillion in December 2022, attributed to elevated funding rates luring cash away from the central bank. The 4.8% interest rate offered by the facility has contributed to the shift.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve Building stands in Washington April 3, 2012. REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo
Details of the September inflation numbers showed lingering price pressures in both goods and services.
Fed policymakers said they do not believe the labour market need slow further to continue to make progress on bringing down inflation.

site_title: US job growth slows sharply in October; unemployment rate unchanged at 4.1%
summary: US job growth slowed sharply in October with a 12,000-job increase, down from the revised 223,000 jobs added in September. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 4.1%. The slowdown was attributed to disruptions from hurricanes and strikes by aerospace factory workers. Despite the slowdown, the labor market remains on solid footing ahead of the November 5 election.

images.alt_text: Firms announced 55,597 layoffs last month, down 23.7 per cent from the 72,821 announced in September, outplacement firm Challenger, Gray and Christmas said.
Details of the September inflation numbers showed lingering price pressures in both goods and services.
Continuing claims, a proxy for the number of people receiving benefits, fell to 1.86 million in the previous week.

(FILES) People shop at a grocery store on August 14, 2024 in Rosemead, California. UThe headline rate of US consumer inflation eased more than expected last month, according to government data published on September 11, 2024, bolstering expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates next week. A rate cut by the independent US central bank would act to boost demand in the world's largest economy. That would give the Democratic party some good economic news to run on going into the final stretch of the 2024 presidential elections. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 jumps 1% as banks lead market rebound, US election in focus
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 1.1% on Friday, marking its biggest one-day gain in five weeks, as banks led a market rebound. The index still logged a weekly decline, with the banking sector gaining 2.3% and food & beverages falling 1.8%. Investors are cautious ahead of the US presidential election, which may impact European markets. Economic data and corporate earnings also influenced the market, with some analysts expecting the European Central Bank to cut interest rates by 50 basis points by December.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 1.2 per cent lower on Thursday, falling to its lowest level since mid August.

site_title: Boeing bankers grab up to US$300 million in capital raise fees
summary: Boeing raised about $23.5 billion in an expanded capital raising effort, shoring up its balance sheet and potentially avoiding a credit rating downgrade. The deal, involving a $18.5 billion common share sale and $5 billion of depositary shares, earned four banks, including Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan, up to $75 million each as lead joint bookrunners. This accounts for 80% of the total fee pool shared among 20 banks. The sale is one of the largest ever by a public company, and it comes as equity market issuance cools ahead of the US election.

site_title: Tesla sells US$499 million of debt backed by solar equipment loans
summary: Tesla sold US$499 million of debt-backed bonds secured by solar equipment loans, marking its first foray into solar asset-backed securities. The five-tranche deal, launched by Deutsche Bank, was oversubscribed and received investment-grade designations from Fitch Ratings. The bonds carry a 4.83% coupon and were backed by high-credit-score customers. The deal highlights Tesla's growing solar business and its ability to tap into the debt market.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk has cultivated a reputation as a bombastic tweeter, who freely shares his opinion on politics, business and conspiracy theories.
Prices of raw materials used to make EV batteries have been falling and Tesla has said its costs will decline as a result this year, with the effect diminishing over time.
Alcon said it had refused a request from Warner Bros to use images from the firm for Tesla’s Oct 10 live-streamed cybercab unveiling.
Many of the attendees cited their interactions with Optimus as a standout feature of the Tesla showcase.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher, boosted by Amazon
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Friday, driven by Amazon's strong earnings, which outweighed concerns about Apple's weaker China sales. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 106.4 points, or 0.25%, to 41,869.82, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased. Despite a sharp reduction in US jobs growth in October, investors remained optimistic, with Amazon's earnings providing a boost.

site_title: Canadian manufacturing PMI rises to 20-month high in October
summary: Canada's manufacturing sector experienced a 20-month high in October, with the S&P Global Canada Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 51.1 from 50.4 in September. Production and employment increased, with output rising to 52.2 and employment at 52.1, its highest level since April 2023. The data suggests a strengthening economy, which may support the Bank of Canada's decision to move towards a more neutral monetary policy stance.

images.alt_text: Canada’s economic growth has slowed under the weight of high borrowing costs, which have throttled business investments and output and consumer demand.
Rents across Canada have been setting records in recent years as a surge in immigration boosted demand.

Condominiums stand along the shore of Lake Ontario in this aerial photograph taken above Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Monday, Oct. 2, 2017. Toronto housing prices fell for a fourth month in September as sales remained sluggish, particularly in the detached-home segment that has borne the brunt of the correction in Canada's biggest city. Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg

site_title: 'Brat' named word of the year by Collins dictionary
summary: The Collins Dictionary has named "Brat" as its 2024 Word of the Year, inspired by Charli XCX's hit album of the same name. The word now represents a confident, independent, and hedonistic attitude, rather than a term for a misbehaved child. Charli XCX, who popularized the term, describes a "brat girl" as someone who is messy, party-loving, and unapologetic, reflecting a cultural phenomenon that has resonated globally.

images.alt_text: “kamala IS brat,” British artist Charli XCX (right) posted in approval of Kamala Harris, a sign-off the Harris campaign quickly embraced.

site_title: US: Stocks rise as market eyes Fed decision after weak jobs data
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, November 1, driven by strong Amazon earnings and weak jobs data that may lead to a Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.7%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.4% and 0.8%, respectively. Amazon surged 6.2% after reporting stronger-than-expected results, and Boeing jumped 3.6% after a union endorsed a new contract proposal. Analysts expect cautious trading ahead of the US presidential election on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 106.4 points, or 0.25 per cent, at the open to 41,869.82.

site_title: Temasek, Republic-backed blockchain fund eyes raising US$100 million
summary: Temasek, a Singaporean state-owned investment company, is backing a blockchain venture capital fund called Superscrypt alongside New York-based fintech firm Republic, as they aim to raise up to $100 million. The process is ongoing, and Temasek's involvement comes after the firm wrote down a $275 million investment in the now-defunct FTX exchange in 2022. This move marks a shift for Temasek, which had previously avoided backing crypto exchanges due to regulatory uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Gibran Huzaifah, ceo and co-founder eFishery (left) and Kuek Yu Chuang, deputy chief executive officer at SPH Media during a panel session at Tech in Asia Conference in Jakarta 23 October 2024
Phil Inagaki, chief investment officer of Xora Innovation, says it takes more than a PhD to build a deep tech company.
Temasek’s excellent investment portfolio transparency provides greater visibility over market values and dividend income from investments, notes Moody's Ratings.

site_title: Mutant Ape Planet NFT fraudster avoids prison in investor scam
summary: A French national, Aurelien Michel, 26, avoided prison for defrauding thousands of NFT buyers in a $2.9 million scam. Michel pleaded guilty to wire fraud conspiracy and was sentenced to one month in prison, already served, and fined $15,000. He was also ordered to forfeit $1.4 million. Prosecutors argued that Michel's losses were overstated, and the judge noted that buyers received "something of value" from the NFTs, making it unclear how much they lost. This case is one of only three US criminal prosecutions over alleged NFT marketing fraud.

images.alt_text: The NFT artwork "#20149" by Mutant Ape Yacht Club displayed inside CryptoBar P2P in Tokyo. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg
Inflation, high interest rates and political instability made the wealthiest clients become more cautious with art purchases and take more time deciding on potential acquisitions.
The US SEC and the crypto industry have locked horns in recent years over their divergent views on whether crypto assets classify as securities and should be regulated similarly.
The NFT sale is happening while sales of nonfungible tokens continue to be weak.

site_title: Boeing gains on optimism that lengthy strike is nearing an end
summary: Boeing's shares rose 4.5% after the International Association of Machinists (IAM) union leaders endorsed the company's fourth proposal for a four-year contract, offering a 38% pay increase, a $12,000 signing bonus, and boosted retirement savings. The deal, set to be voted on November 4, aims to end the eight-week strike crippling the company's jetliner manufacturing. Analysts believe the offer is enough to win a majority of votes needed to ratify the new contract, potentially clearing the way for new CEO Kelly Ortberg to move forward with plans to rebuild Boeing's culture and improve factory quality.

images.alt_text: The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers District 751, which represents more than 33,000 workers who went on strike on Sept 13 in the Seattle area, have endorsed the contract, and scheduled a vote on Monday.
Earlier this month, Boeing raised US$21 billion to bolster its weakened finances and avoid a credit rating downgrade to junk.
The company on Wednesday received clearance from the US SEC to sell as much as US$25 billion of equity and debt.
Boeing’s new chief executive officer Kelly Ortberg is assessing the company’s portfolio to raise cash, weed out under-performing units and rescue a company in crisis.

site_title: Exxon’s US$8.6 billion profit beats estimate as volume offsets price weakness
summary: ExxonMobil reported a US$8.6 billion profit in its third quarter, beating Wall Street's estimate, despite a 5% year-over-year decline. The company's oil and gas output rose 25% to 4.6 million barrels a day, driven by its acquisition of Pioneer Natural Resources. Exxon's US$1.92-a-share profit topped expectations, and the company raised its quarterly dividend by 4%. Despite weak margins on petrol and diesel, Exxon's chemical business saw profits rise to US$893 million.

images.alt_text: Chevron said it earned US$2.51 per share for third quarter, compared to analysts’ estimates of US$2.42.
TotalEnergies’ adjusted net income was US$4.07 billion in the quarter, down from US$6.45 billion a year earlier.
BP profit slumps to near four-year low as oil demand sags

site_title: Japan political turmoil a risk for BOJ December hike, former board member says
summary: Japan's ruling coalition lost its majority in a snap election, sparking concerns that the Bank of Japan (BOJ) may delay its next interest rate hike until January. Former BOJ board member Takahide Kiuchi predicts the yen's depreciation could increase the probability of a rate hike in December, but January is now a more likely option. Kiuchi expects the BOJ to reach a terminal policy rate of around 0.75% by mid-2025, with the government potentially intervening in the currency market to support the yen.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan (BoJ) governor Kazuo Ueda attends a press conference after a two-day monetary policy meeting at the BOJ headquarters in Tokyo on April 26, 2024. The Bank of Japan kept its ultra-low interest rates unchanged on April 26 and stopped short of signalling another hike, pushing the yen to a fresh 34-year low against the dollar. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)
Japan's business investment is picking up, and firms’ assessment on the current business conditions is improving.

The Bank of Japan is widely expected to hold short-term rates at 0.25 per cent at Thursday’s policy meeting but signal its resolve to keep hiking borrowing costs if Japan makes progress in durably achieving its 2 per cent inflation target.
The new downgraded forecast follows a similar cut to the outlook in July, but is still above private-sector forecasts for 0.5 per cent growth.

site_title: Oil prices settle up slightly on Iran worries, but prices down for week
summary: Oil prices rose slightly on Friday due to concerns over a potential retaliatory strike by Iran against Israel from Iraq, but record US output weighed on prices. Brent futures settled at $73.10 a barrel, up 29 US cents, or 0.4%, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 23 US cents, or 0.3%, to settle at $69.49. Despite the brief increase, oil prices declined for the week, with Brent down 4% and WTI down 3%.

images.alt_text: WTI crude oil futures jumped US$2.15 or 3.13 per cent to US$70.76 after settlement at 3.22 pm EDT on Thursday.

site_title: Investigations against CEO Ching related to Venetian corruption probe considered concluded: Oxley
summary: Oxley Holdings' CEO Ching Chiat Kwong's involvement in a corruption investigation in Italy is considered concluded, with no charges brought against him. Ching's purchase of Palazzo Papadopoli was conducted through public tenders and is deemed above board. No notification of an investigation was received by Ching, and the company has not been charged with any wrongdoing. The Italian contractor's allegations, which included favours granted by the mayor of Venice to developers, remain unproven.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
The company attributed the net losses to impairment losses, finance costs and lower revenue recognised from the group’s property development projects.

site_title: UK Business Minister admits tax hikes may hit hiring and pay growth
summary: UK Business Minister Jonathan Reynolds acknowledged that tax hikes may hinder hiring and pay growth, but defended Chancellor Rachel Reeves' budget as maintaining the UK's global competitiveness. The tax changes include a rise in employer national insurance contributions and an increase in the minimum wage. Reynolds accepted that the pressure on businesses could affect recruitment and pay, but emphasized the UK's competitive market position.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves speaks on stage at the Britain's Labour Party's annual conference in Liverpool, Britain, September 23, 2024. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo

Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer, before presenting her budget to parliament. The budget is a make-or-break moment for both Reeves and new Prime Minister Keir Starmer, as they try to recover from a polling slump since their Labour Party won power in July.

site_title: Singapore co-living players eye overseas markets for growth
summary: Larger co-living operators in Singapore are expanding into overseas markets, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region and Southeast Asia. Companies like Habyt and Ascott are pushing their brands into cities such as Kuala Lumpur, Penang, Bali, and Cebu City, in addition to established markets like Tokyo and Sydney. This expansion is driven by the growth of the local customer base and the potential for emerging markets like India. Despite stiff competition, operators believe that these regions offer promising opportunities for growth.

images.alt_text: LHN managing director Kelvin Lim noted that Coliwoo’s product is now similar to traditional serviced apartments. He spoke to BT at Coliwoo Orchard in Mount Elizabeth Link, which used to operate as Fraser Residence Singapore.

site_title: Fed seen on course for rate cuts after weak jobs data
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates next week, with traders pricing a 99% chance of a quarter-point rate cut to 4.5-4.75%. The decision comes after a weak jobs report showed 12,000 new jobs added in October, short of economists' expectations. The unemployment rate remains at 4.1%, indicating a strong labor market despite the temporary weakness. The Fed is unlikely to deliver another half-point interest-rate cut, as seen in September.

images.alt_text: Nonfarm payrolls increased by 12,000 jobs last month after surging by a downwardly revised 223,000 in September.
Details of the September inflation numbers showed lingering price pressures in both goods and services.

site_title: No Signboard former chairman, CEO Lim Yong Sim fined S$420,000 for price rigging
summary: No Signboard's former chairman and CEO Lim Yong Sim was fined S$420,000 for price rigging after pleading guilty to three charges of false trading. He made multiple trades to artificially inflate the company's share price, causing a 27% increase, and then purchased more shares to cushion the fall after the company announced a loss. The false trades were carried out using GuGong's account, with Lim also purchasing shares above the company's share buyback mandate. The case was referred to the police by the Singapore Exchange.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

Formerly called No Signboard, food and beverage player Bromat on Mar 28 issued S$4.5 million of convertible redeemable preference shares to Gazelle, with the instrument convertible into 145 million shares.
No Signboard will rename as Bromat.
Gazelle Ventures’ cash offer for No Signboard closes with 0.5022% valid acceptances

site_title: Abbott, Reckitt unit defeat claims in baby formula trial
summary: A US jury has cleared Abbott Laboratories and Reckitt Benckiser Group's Mead Johnson unit of responsibility for causing necrotising enterocolitis in a premature infant. The verdict, delivered in under a day, marks the first victory for the companies in over 1,000 similar cases. Abbott and Reckitt previously lost trials, including one that resulted in a $495 million verdict against Abbott in July. The companies contend their formulas do not cause the bowel disease, citing a recent report by federal regulators that found no conclusive evidence.

images.alt_text: Illinois resident Margo Gill, who brought the case against Abbott, alleged that the company failed to warn that its formula could cause a potentially deadly disease called necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in premature babies.

site_title: From tennis to basketball to football, Singapore’s sports calendar lights up with major events
summary: Singapore's sports calendar is set to host several major international events, including the World Aquatics Swimming World Cup, Tour de France Prudential Singapore Criterium, and Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon. The Harlem Globetrotters will also perform in Singapore, and the Asean Championship football tournament will take place in December. The Singapore Tennis Open, featuring top female tennis players, will be held from January 27 to February 2. Notable events include Mark Cavendish's final Tour de France Criterium and the return of the cycling great after an 18-year professional career.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Manchester City and Spain midfielder Rodri and Barcelona player Aitana Bonmati pose with their trophies after winning the Men's and Women's Ballon d'Or 2024 awards in Paris, France, Oct 28, 2024.
Adidas' currency-neutral quarterly sales rose 9 per cent to 946 million euros (S$1.4 billion) in Greater China, up from 870 million euros a year earlier.
Seven-time F1 world champion Lewis Hamilton attended the TeamViewer Experience Day event in Singapore where he gave insights into life as a professional racer.

site_title: Chinese researchers develop AI model for military use on back of Meta’s Llama
summary: Chinese researchers have developed an AI tool, ChatBIT, using Meta's Llama 13B large language model to gather and process intelligence for military operations. The tool was fine-tuned for dialogue and question-answering tasks in the military field and outperformed some other AI models. Meta's Llama models are publicly available, but the company has restrictions on their use, including for military purposes. The development of ChatBIT raises concerns about China's military capabilities and its potential to narrow the technology gap with the US. Meta has denied any unauthorized use of its models by the Chinese military.

images.alt_text: In 2023, ByteDance, which owns short-video sensation TikTok and its Chinese version Douyin, saw its total revenue surpass Tencent.
Meta’s key AI products include several large language models used to power chat bots, an AI assistant built into its various social apps, and AI-powered smart glasses.

site_title: 10-year average return on Singapore Savings Bond picks up to 2.81%
summary: Singapore's 10-year average return on the Singapore Savings Bond (SSB) has increased to 2.81%, the highest offered since the September issuance. The latest tranche, set to be issued in December, offers a first-year interest rate of 2.66% and is available for application until November 26. The increase comes after the November tranche saw record-low yields for 2024.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
A total of S$92.2 million was applied within individual allotment limits and this amount was fully allotted.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, November 1, 2024
summary: Asian markets declined, with US jobs data suggesting a potential rate cut. Oil prices rose for a third day, while gold prices climbed. The outlook for Japanese exporters remains uncertain. The US jobs data may influence the direction of interest rates, and investors are awaiting the release of US payrolls data.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 83 to 50.
Tokyo’s Nikkei fell 2.1 per cent on Monday as a stronger yen clouded the outlook for Japanese exporters.
WTI crude oil futures jumped US$2.15 or 3.13 per cent to US$70.76 after settlement at 3.22 pm EDT on Thursday.

site_title: Amazon reassures investors with cloud growth, cost-cutting
summary: Amazon reported strong third-quarter results, with total revenue increasing 11% to $158.9 billion, exceeding estimates. The company's cloud division, AWS, regained momentum, while online retail and advertising revenue also grew. Amazon expects to devote $75 billion to capital expenditures in 2024, mostly for technology infrastructure, driven by demand for AI services. The company's operating profit was $17.4 billion, beating average estimates. Amazon's efforts to cut and reallocate costs appear to be paying off, putting the company on a sounder footing.

images.alt_text: In August, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said average selling prices were falling because customers were trading down to cheaper items and buying more essential goods, and that sales of bigger ticket items like computers and electronics were growing “more slowly” than in a robust economy.
Amazon posted net sales of US$158.9 billion for the quarter ending Sept 30, up 11 per cent from the same period last year, with net profit up to US$15.3 billion.

site_title: Chevron beats quarterly profit expectations on higher production
summary: Chevron reported a quarterly profit of US$2.51 per share, beating analyst estimates, driven by higher oil and gas production and cost cuts. The company's adjusted profit fell 15% from the same period last year, while oil production rose 7%. Chevron plans to optimize its portfolio, reduce operating costs, and move its headquarters to Texas. The company also disclosed pending sales of oil properties worth approximately US$8 billion, expected to close this quarter.

images.alt_text: BP profit slumps to near four-year low as oil demand sags
TotalEnergies’ adjusted net income was US$4.07 billion in the quarter, down from US$6.45 billion a year earlier.
Cnooc said net income rose to 36.9 billion yuan (S$6.8 billion), from 33.9 billion yuan last year.
Chevron is also acquiring Hess for US$53 billion, a deal that would boost its presence in South America.
Chevron’s announcement of the Hess deal followed ExxonMobil’s US$60 billion purchase of US shale giant Pioneer Natural Resources, which closed in May.
Chevron joins a long list of California emigres that includes Oracle, Hewlett Packard Enterprise and Tesla.
Chevron reported earnings of US$4.4 billion, or US$2.43 per share, in the quarter, compared with US$6 billion a year before.

site_title: Maganomics is coming for Asia, but it may not be as bad as feared
summary: A second Trump administration could significantly impact Asia's economy due to his proposed tariffs on Chinese goods and imports from other countries. However, it's unlikely that these tariffs will be fully implemented, as Trump views them as a negotiation strategy. Instead, he'll focus on reindustrialising the US, which may benefit some Asian economies, such as Vietnam and Singapore, by offering lower interest rates, weak currencies, and reduced regulations. Others, like China and India, will face pressure to honour trade deals and commit to purchasing more US products.

images.alt_text: “A lot of companies in the Chinese Internet space have been beaten down a lot and I think over the next few months just based on the announcements we will have more clarity in policy around them,” Sipahimalani said. “In some of those cases there’ll be very attractive opportunities to invest in them.”
Trump vs harris

site_title: Ruben Amorim named as new Manchester United manager
summary: Manchester United has appointed Ruben Amorim as its new manager, replacing Erik ten Hag. Amorim, 39, won two Primeira Liga titles with Sporting Lisbon and will join the club on November 11 until 2027. He was described as "one of the most exciting and highly rated young coaches in European football" by the club. Amorim will take charge of the team after a 2-1 defeat by West Ham left United 14th in the Premier League, and his first game will be away at Ipswich on November 24.

images.alt_text: Manchester United are looking at two options – either redeveloping Old Trafford stadium or building a new one on adjacent club-owned land.
Manchester United's net loss widened to £113.2 million (US$148.14 million) in the year ended Jun 30, from £28.7 million a year earlier.
The task force was set up to focus on discussions over building a new 100,000-capacity stadium rather than redeveloping Old Trafford.
“Erik ten Hag has left his role as Manchester United men’s first-team manager,” the club said in a statement.

site_title: Ringgit’s weakness won’t last: Bank Negara Malaysia
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia stated it will manage any excessive ringgit volatility and looks beyond short-term currency dynamics. The currency, which fell 5.8% against the US dollar in October, remains the best performer in emerging markets this year due to domestic demand and investments from tech giants. Strong economic growth, positive prospects, and structural reforms will provide enduring support to the ringgit. The central bank is ready to provide liquidity as needed and encourages state-linked firms to repatriate overseas income to help shore up the currency.

images.alt_text: CMG20240415-HengYY02 / 王彦燕 / 拍马币 Malaysia Ringgit bills [SPH] tags: 兑换率, Singapore’s strong exchange rate，currency

site_title: Hong Kong September retail sales fall 6.9%
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales fell 6.9% in September from a year earlier, marking a seventh consecutive month of decline. The sales dropped to HK$29.57 billion, with a 10% decline in August and a 11.7% drop in July. The decline is attributed to a change in consumption patterns and is expected to continue affecting the retail sector.

images.alt_text: Home sales in Hong Kong have picked up after the government loosened mortgage rules to allow lower down payments earlier this month.
Newly released government figures show that private consumption had weakened.
Hong Kong’s government is trying to prop up the struggling residential property market by lifting all additional stamp duties for foreign and second home buyers in February.
The city is also winning back wealthy Chinese by rolling out the red carpet for the rich while rival Singapore scrutinises foreign money.
Housing demand in Hong Kong has lost steam since May after a short-lived bounce when all property purchase curbs were lifted in February.

site_title: Japan's rising minimum wage likely to push up inflation, BOJ says
summary: Japan's rising minimum wage is expected to drive inflation, mainly through higher services prices, according to the Bank of Japan. The average minimum wage is set to rise 5.1% in 2025, with significant increases for low-level areas. The BOJ sees this as a positive sign that inflation will sustainably reach its 2% target, indicating confidence in raising interest rates from near-zero levels.

images.alt_text: Japan’s public debt, at twice the size of its economy, is the largest among major nations due to huge spending packages delivered in the past and the rising social welfare costs for a rapidly ageing population. REUTERS

site_title: UK factory activity shrinks slightly for first time since April, PMI shows
summary: UK factory activity contracted slightly in October for the first time since April, according to the S&P Global UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index, which fell to 49.9 from 51.5 in September. The contraction was driven by fewer new orders and reduced optimism ahead of the Labour government's first budget. The manufacturing sector saw slower growth in input costs and modestly rising selling prices, while overall output edged up. Demand weakened for consumer and intermediate goods, and foreign demand for British manufactured goods declined.

images.alt_text: UK's housing market had been gaining momentum on the back of cooling mortgage costs, with mortgage approvals rising to its highest in more than two years in September.
The Resolution Foundation says that real household disposable incomes per person are set to grow by an average of just 0.5 per cent a year over the next five years.

FILE PHOTO: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves speaks on stage at the Britain's Labour Party's annual conference in Liverpool, Britain, September 23, 2024. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo

site_title: Evelyn Tao, wife of 3AC’s Zhu Su, sells Dalvey Road bungalow for S$51 million
summary: Evelyn Tao, wife of 3AC co-founder Zhu Su, has sold her Dalvey Road bungalow for S$51 million, working out to S$3,276 per square foot. The buyer is a member of the Karim family behind Musim Mas, and the property, located near the Singapore Botanic Gardens, was built recently. This sale follows a separate deal for a GCB in Fifth Avenue, also bought by a member of the Tan family, for S$47 million.

site_title: Chua Hsien Yang to head Keppel Reit’s manager from Jan 1
summary: Keppel Reit has announced that Chua Hsien Yang will become its chief executive from January 1, 2025, replacing current CEO Koh Wee Lih. Koh Wee Lih will take on the role of managing director of business development at Keppel. Chua, who joined Keppel in 2008, previously served as CEO of Keppel DC Reit Management from 2014 to 2021. The appointment is effective from January 1, 2025.

site_title: US manufacturing drops to 15-month low in October
summary: US manufacturing activity dropped to a 15-month low in October, with the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing PMI falling to 46.5, the lowest level since July 2023. The decline was attributed to a Boeing factory worker strike, which halted production of the 737 MAX and other planes. Despite this, goods spending increased at its fastest pace in 1½ years in the third quarter, and the survey's forward-looking new orders sub-index rose to 47.1.

site_title: UBS senior banker who pioneered ESG debt swaps leaves firm
summary: A senior banker at UBS, Ramzi Issa, who pioneered debt-for-nature swaps, has left the firm after a year in his role. Issa, former global head of credit investor products structuring at Credit Suisse, is among a group of former Credit Suisse bankers at UBS. UBS is working on a US$300 million debt swap for Barbados, focusing on climate-resilient infrastructure, marking its first foray into this market. The move reflects Issa's expertise in sustainable credit products, which he helped build at Credit Suisse.

site_title: Singapore, Canada funds mull backing US$1.8 billion asset shuffle
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) and Canada's largest pension fund, CPPIB, are in advanced talks to invest in PSG Equity's US$1.8 billion asset shuffle, a continuation fund designed to extend the life of the investments. This deal could be one of the largest in private equity history. Evercore is advising on the investment, and GIC is discussing partnering alongside CPPIB.

site_title: Japan's Mitsui raises full-year profit forecast to US$6 billion on LNG business, asset sales
summary: Mitsui, a Japanese trading house, raised its full-year net profit forecast to $6 billion due to a stronger outlook for its liquefied natural gas (LNG) business and asset sales. The company expects lower profits from its mineral and metal division amid weaker iron ore and metallurgical coal prices. Mitsui will focus on growth drivers such as LNG, mobility, healthcare, and protein, and aims to further strengthen its existing and new businesses.

summary: CDL acquires a 51% stake in a 27,994 sqm mixed-use development site in Shanghai's Xintiandi area for 4.6 billion yuan. The site can yield up to 77% of the permissible gross floor area for residential use, with 19% for commercial purposes and 4% for public amenities. site_title: The Mini in the middle
summary: Mini's new Aceman model combines quirky charm with peppy performance, marking the brand's shift towards electric vehicles. With five doors and five seats, the Aceman offers ample space, despite its compact size. The interior features a massive OLED screen and a spacious boot that can expand to 1,005 liters. As Mini's first all-electric model, the Aceman signals the brand's commitment to sustainability, offering a balance of performance and practicality.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Nov 1)
summary: A majority of manufacturing respondents (84%) said they won't implement a four-day work week, citing higher costs and the need for round-the-clock operations. A Singapore public-private task force proposed 27 recommendations to improve business competitiveness, including enhanced grants and flexibility with foreign workers. GIC-backed Coda Payments received an in-principle nod for a major payment institution licence, while SMI Vantage is delisting without an exit offer due to difficult financial conditions.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB raises Sheng Siong price target to S$2 on earnings growth momentum
summary: RHB Securities has raised its price target for Sheng Siong to S$2 from S$1.88, citing the supermarket chain's earnings growth momentum, attractive valuation, and strong cash flow generation. Sheng Siong's third-quarter earnings beat estimates, driven by better margins and a larger store network, with net profit rising 12.6% year-on-year. Analyst Alfie Yeo expects a more positive earnings outlook, driven by contributions from newer outlets and better gross margins, and has lifted earnings forecasts for FY2024 to FY2026 by 6% each.

site_title: Universal Music sales beat estimates on subscription growth
summary: Universal Music Group reported revenue of $3.1 billion in Q3, beating estimates with 8.2% growth in subscription income. The company aims for over 7% compounded revenue growth through 2028 driven by subscription and superfan monetization. This surpasses analyst forecasts of $2.83 billion. The company's shares rose 5.6% in Amsterdam following the results.

images.alt_text: Universal Music Group announced that the new operation, headquartered in Shenzhen, will focus on marketing and artist management, with the aim of developing local artists across the Greater Bay Area.

site_title: China stimulus gives manufacturing, housing a shot in the arm
summary: China's economy has shown tentative signs of recovery, with manufacturing and housing sectors experiencing a boost after the government's recent stimulus push. Factory activity ended five months of contraction in October, exceeding analyst expectations, and home sales rose for the first time this year. The Caixin manufacturing purchasing managers index rose to 50.3, while residential property sales jumped 73% in October. However, economists caution that the recovery is still uncertain, citing concerns over slowing global demand and potential deflation. The US presidential election and its impact on trade policies also pose a risk to China's growth outlook.

site_title: ‘It’s Time!’ Mariah Carey reflects on 30 years as queen of Christmas
summary: Mariah Carey celebrates 30 years since the release of her iconic Christmas song "All I Want for Christmas Is You," which has become one of the longest-charting singles in any genre, spending 65 weeks on Billboard's Hot 100. The song, written by Carey and Walter Afanasieff, was initially met with skepticism but has since become synonymous with the holiday season, selling 18 million copies and cementing Carey's role as the "Queen of Christmas." Carey is now preparing for a 21-date holiday tour, teasing new music, and declaring "It's time" for the holiday season, which she officially marks on November 1.

site_title: Japan cuts growth forecast again for current fiscal year on weak exports
summary: Japan's government lowered its GDP growth forecast for the current fiscal year to 0.7% from 0.9% in July, citing weaker exports and fragile economic recovery. This is the second cut to the forecast this year, with the next fiscal year's growth projection remaining at 1.2%. The move highlights growing pressure on the economy from cooling global demand and domestic consumption, prompting the government to pledge a large spending package later this year to support households and the broader economy.

summary: Macau's gaming revenue soared to a new high in October, reaching 20.8 billion patacas ($3.4 billion), driven by a 6.6% year-on-year increase during China's Golden Week holiday. The city saw a 20% increase in visitor arrivals, with nearly 142,000 tourists per day, mostly from the mainland. However, Macau faces regulatory challenges, including a crackdown on capital outflows and money laundering, and its leader has signaled a shift towards diversifying the economy.

site_title: Reality check on 4-day week: 95% of Singapore employers say ‘no’
summary: A poll by the Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) found that 95% of employers in Singapore are unlikely to implement a four-day work week, citing reasons such as higher costs, need for round-the-clock operations, and inability to increase productivity. Only 18% of respondents said they would implement a four-day work week, with some citing improved employee well-being as a reason. The manufacturing sector was the most opposed, with 84% of respondents saying they would not implement the shorter work week.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
About two in 10 employers here said they are willing to offer more flexible work hours on Fridays, and a similar proportion were open to a 4½-day work week.

site_title: Samsung will account for half of South Korea’s economic growth
summary: Samsung Electronics is expected to contribute about half of South Korea's economic growth this year, according to Bloomberg Economics. The company's significant impact on the global semiconductor industry is driving this growth, with Samsung being South Korea's largest company, accounting for 8% of manufacturing output and 17% of the main stock index. This rebound from a 2023 slump that shaved 1.2 percentage points from Korea's GDP growth highlights the major implications of Samsung's troubles on the country's economy and consumption.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s largest company has so far missed the lion’s share of profits stemming from surging AI-related demand.
Samsung is holding a conference call on Thursday after it releases detailed third-quarter earnings.

site_title: Indonesian labour unions expect higher wages after court ruling
summary: Indonesian labour unions welcomed a Constitutional Court ruling that ordered changes to labour laws, including the establishment of sectoral minimum wages and clearer rules on outsourcing. The ruling, which was part of a petition challenging the Job Creation law, is expected to lead to higher minimum wages next year. The changes, which include specifying jobs that can be outsourced, are seen as a victory for workers and a protection of their basic needs. The government has vowed to abide by the ruling and issue a new manpower law within two years.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's October headline inflation rate was 1.71 per cent, easing from 1.84 per cent in September and close to the median forecast of 1.68 per cent by analysts in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Hot stock: Singtel shares fall nearly 2% in heavy trading as investors weigh Optus lawsuit
summary: Singtel shares fell nearly 2% in heavy trading following the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission filing court proceedings against its subsidiary Optus Mobile for allegations of inappropriate sales conduct. The Australian watchdog is seeking penalties, consumer redress, and costs from Optus. The heavy trading led to Singtel's shares hitting a low of S$2.90, the lowest price recorded since August 2024.

site_title: Ubisoft orders miss estimates after weak Star Wars sales
summary: Ubisoft reported a 36% decline in net bookings to 352.3 million euros (S$506.6 million) in the second quarter of 2025, missing analyst estimates. The decline was attributed to production delays and weaker-than-expected sales, which weigh on the company's turnaround plan. This falls at the lower end of Ubisoft's recently cut guidance, with the company expecting net bookings of approximately 380 million euros for the quarter, down from 626 million euros last year.

images.alt_text: Ubisoft's share price is at a 10-year low following disappointing sales of recent games such as Skull and Bones and Star Wars Outlaws.

site_title: Japan’s largest pension fund GPIF has worst loss since 2020
summary: Japan's largest pension fund, GPIF, posted its largest quarterly loss since 2020, with a 3.6% loss in the three months through September. The fund incurred losses in three major asset classes, including foreign stocks and bonds, Japanese equities, and only domestic debt generated a positive return. The yen's rebound erased gains on overseas securities, while domestic stocks declined. This result may indicate that GPIF will not increase its stock holdings to boost overall returns next year.

site_title: GIC-backed Coda Payments gets MAS’ in-principle nod for major payment institution licence
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has granted an in-principle approval to GIC-backed payment firm Coda Payments for a major payment institution licence. The licence allows multiple transactions without threshold limits, enabling the company to expand its services. Founded in 2011, Coda Payments offers channel, platform, and payment solutions to gaming industry giants and internet technology companies. This is one of three licences available under the Payment Services Act 2019, with the company expected to apply for a full licence following the in-principle approval.

site_title: Global growth remains resilient in 2025; economies expected to benefit from Fed rate cuts: Allianz chief economist
summary: Global economic growth is expected to remain resilient in 2025, driven by China's stimulus efforts and the US Federal Reserve's anticipated rate-cutting cycle. Despite projected US growth of 1.7%, global growth is forecasted at 2.8% due to the expected rate cuts. The US presidential election will be a key influence on inflation, growth, and trade, with a Kamala Harris win potentially triggering recession concerns and a Donald Trump win leading to higher inflation. Structural reforms are also needed to revive the Chinese economy in the long term.

site_title: What the US presidential election means for China and the rest of Asia
summary: The outcome of the US presidential election is unlikely to significantly alter the trajectory of America's relations with China, according to analysts. China and the West have been on a "fairly specific and predictable" path, making it unlikely that a change in US leadership will drastically shift the balance of power. Analysts expect trade policies to differ slightly depending on whether Donald Trump or Kamala Harris wins, but overall, the relationship between the US and China is expected to remain relatively stable.

site_title: China property developer Yuzhou to raise US$14.4 million via rights issue
summary: China property developer Yuzhou Group plans to raise US$14.43 million through a rights issue to settle fees from its offshore debt restructuring. The company, one of the many affected by China's real estate market slowdown, is consolidating shares and changing trading lot sizes as part of the restructuring. Yuzhou's offshore debt is approximately US$6.7 billion, and the company is close to completing the restructuring. The move aims to reduce outstanding indebtedness while allowing creditors to participate in future returns.

images.alt_text: The debt proposal by Yuzhou, with US$6.8 billion in offshore liabilities, is one of a handful announced so far by developers hit by the property sector’s debt crisis.

site_title: China plans to tighten scrutiny of government debt
summary: China's top legislative body proposes changes to tighten scrutiny of government debt, requiring annual progress reports on debt management work from the cabinet and local governments. The moves aim to step up supervision of local government debt.

site_title: An unlikely winner in the office real estate slump? A dance troupe.
summary: The Paul Taylor Dance Company, a prominent dance institution, has expanded into a new headquarters in midtown Manhattan, filling a nearly three-story office building. The move was made possible by a quirk in real estate law, allowing the company to purchase the space as leasehold condominiums. The 30-year payment plan and lack of property taxes benefit both parties. This is a rare example of a dance troupe securing substantial real estate in one of the world's most expensive markets, joining companies like Alvin Ailey American Dance Theatre and Mark Morris Dance Group.

site_title: Amazon’s plan to tackle Temu, Shein? Sell more toothpaste
summary: Amazon reported third-quarter revenue and profit that beat Wall Street expectations, driven by increased shopping frequency and a mix of low-priced and higher-ticket items. The company's push to offer everyday essentials like toothpaste is helping to offset lower average selling prices, but it faces competition from rivals like Shein and Temu, which offer rock-bottom prices on goods shipped from China. Amazon's market share in apparel has eroded, but its local warehouse network is helping to offset the impact of lower prices.

site_title: Singapore public-private task force calls for enhanced grants, flexibility with foreign workers
summary: A Singapore public-private task force, Alliance for Action (AfA), has released 27 recommendations to enhance business competitiveness, focusing on labour, land use, and regulations. The proposals include expanding foreign worker grants, increasing flexibility in hiring foreign workers, and streamlining solar-energy project approvals. The task force aims to improve business competitiveness and is set to review each recommendation with the relevant ministries and agencies.

site_title: A timeless celebration
summary: A Lange & Sohne celebrated its iconic Lange 1 watch's 30th birthday with a special exhibition at Orchard Ion, featuring a curated collection of Lange 1 models. 30 BT readers were invited to the event, where they received an exclusive tour of the exhibition, including a master craftsman's demonstration of engraving and hands-on experience with four limited edition Lange 1 watches. Each attendee took home a gift bag filled with premiums from A Lange & Sohne and BT Club. The event marked a milestone in the Lange 1's timeless elegance and exquisite craftsmanship.

site_title: Macro funds can make waves with exposure to global shipping
summary: Macro investors are looking beyond traditional assets to diversify their portfolios, with a focus on global shipping. The Baltic Dry Index (BDI), which measures freight rates for major sea routes, offers exposure to the commodities value chain and has more than tripled since early 2023. The BDI is influenced by factors such as trade policies, geopolitical tensions, and macroeconomic conditions, making it a unique barometer for global trends. By investing in freight futures or shipping funds, macro investors can gain exposure to the shipping market and potentially achieve alpha, offering a fresh perspective on the shifting global economy.

site_title: Asia: Markets start momentous month on cautious side, US payrolls awaited
summary: Asian markets began a potentially significant month on a cautious note, with Tokyo's Nikkei falling 2.1% due to a stronger yen affecting Japanese exporters. Investors await US payrolls data and the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with a rate cut largely expected. Oil prices rose 2% to nearly $74 a barrel on reports of a potential Iranian retaliatory strike against Israel. Markets are also closely watching the US presidential election and trade talks between the US and EU.

site_title: Falcon Energy to delist on Nov 15
summary: Falcon Energy to delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on November 15, after being ordered by the High Court in April to wind up due to multiple failed restructuring attempts. The company had previously attempted to restructure three times but was unable to meet its obligations. Shares have been suspended from trading since January 2019. The decision comes after the company's liquidators filed an application to delist the company in September.

site_title: Singapore’s labour productivity up 2.4% a year since Industry Transformation Maps roll-out: MOF
summary: Singapore's labor productivity has increased by 2.4% annually since the rollout of Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs) in 2016, driving wage growth in those sectors. Real median gross monthly income for full-time employed residents in ITM sectors rose 1.9% per annum. The government's initiatives, such as the Progressive Wage Model, contributed to the narrowing wage gap between lower- and higher-wage workers. The country's economy grew at an annualized rate of 2.6% from 2019 to 2023, and Singapore remains competitive despite the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Michael Bloomberg: Why I’m voting for Kamala Harris
summary: Michael Bloomberg, founder of Bloomberg LP, has endorsed Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris, citing her policy positions and personal integrity. He disagrees with Harris on some issues but believes she is the better choice. Harris supports reproductive rights, comprehensive immigration reform, gun safety measures, and climate change action, while opposing Trump's plans to deport millions, undermine gun safety, and ignore climate change. Bloomberg also criticizes Trump's personal integrity, citing his refusal to accept defeat, shameful behavior towards immigrants and White supremacists, and reckless governance style. Bloomberg urges undecided voters to join him in voting for Harris.

site_title: Indonesia’s October inflation eases, but core rate at 15-month high
summary: Indonesia's October inflation rate eased to 1.71%, close to analysts' median forecast of 1.68%. This marks the lowest headline rate since October 2021. However, the core inflation rate, excluding government-controlled prices and food, rose to 2.21%, the highest in over a year, surpassing expectations.

Despite an estimated 22,000 units entering the country through personal shipments or carry-on items, trading the phones remains illegal. This follows a similar ban on iPhone 16 devices in the country, after Apple failed to meet its investment commitments. The move aims to promote local content and protect the domestic market.

site_title: UK house prices barely rose in month before Budget, lender says
summary: UK house prices rose 0.1% to £265,738 in October, below economists' forecast of a 0.3% gain, according to Nationwide Building Society. This brings prices 2.4% higher than last year, but below the all-time high in 2022. The housing market had been gaining momentum due to cooling mortgage costs, but the recent Budget has raised concerns about consumer sentiment and potential price increases. Economists expect housing market activity to strengthen gradually as affordability constraints ease.

The Resolution Foundation says that real household disposable incomes per person are set to grow by an average of just 0.5 per cent a year over the next five years.

site_title: SMI Vantage seeks to delist without exit offer, citing ‘difficult financial conditions’
summary: SMI Vantage, a cryptocurrency mining-as-a-service company, is restructuring and plans to delist from the Singapore Exchange without an exit offer. The company cited "difficult financial conditions," including a net current-liability position of US$937,000 and limited access to cash. Its controlling shareholders have committed not to recall loans totaling US$10.6 million. The company will cancel expansion initiatives and reduce central overheads to US$400,000. Minority shareholders will be able to vote on the delisting resolution at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Reading – the everyday luxury that opens hearts and minds
summary: A personal essay by author Enuma Okoro reflects on the importance of reading and its role in shaping one's life. Okoro notes that reading can be a luxury, but it offers access to knowledge, expanding one's sense of agency and possibility. The essay also touches on the historical control of reading materials, citing examples of artworks featuring women reading, such as Madame de Pompadour's 1756 painting, which depicts her surrounded by books. Okoro argues that reading can be a source of power, allowing individuals to contemplate new perspectives and ways of being in the world.

site_title: Investors should not fear a stock market crash
summary: Investors should not fear a stock market crash, as shares are more like bonds than realized, with falling valuations increasing expected returns. Since October 2023, the S&P 500 index has risen over 40%, with peers in Europe, Japan, and Canada experiencing similar gains. Central banks have cut interest rates, boosting corporate profits and driving stock markets near all-time highs. With fears of high inflation and low interest rates largely vanished, investors can take a long view, making stocks a less risky investment.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs predicts that, even in 2075, America’s equity market will be almost as big as China’s and India’s combined.

Investors often sell their stocks when they are expensive. They move into cash hoping to buy the stocks back when they become cheap again. But it may be a very long wait. Meanwhile, expensive stocks continue to outperform.

site_title: Sony sues CBS over ‘dismal’ Jeopardy, Wheel of Fortune revenue
summary: Sony Pictures Television sued CBS Studios over revenue from its popular game shows Jeopardy! and Wheel of Fortune, claiming CBS made over $1 billion in profit from a 35-year distribution agreement but failed to maximize revenue. Sony alleges CBS's "dismal performance" is due to layoffs and a lack of aggressive revenue generation. The complaint seeks unspecified damages, citing instances where CBS entered into longer licensing deals in Australia and New Zealand, pocketing over $3.6 million.

site_title: With US election days away, Republicans and Democrats battle in court
summary: US presidential candidates Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are embroiled in a surge of pre-Election Day lawsuits from both parties, with Republicans claiming "election integrity" and Democrats alleging attempts to subvert the process. The Republican National Committee has filed over 130 cases, mainly targeting swing states, while Democrats have countered with dozens of suits seeking to protect mail-in voting and increase ballot drop boxes. The lawsuits may set the stage for potential claims of election irregularities if Trump loses, and some experts warn that the legal efforts are designed to create a grievance structure for the former president.

images.alt_text: The Nov 5 election may not deliver an immediate clear outcome but worse, a contested transfer of power may yet play out over months.

site_title: Nomura profit beats estimates as outlook clouded by scandals
summary: Nomura Holdings reported a net income of 98.4 billion yen, more than doubling from the previous year, in the three months ended September 30. The earnings beat analyst estimates, driven by strong results across its wealth management, trading, and investment banking businesses. However, the firm's reputation is clouded by scandals, including market manipulation and a former employee's arrest on suspicion of robbery and attempted murder. Despite this, Nomura's second-quarter results were described as "very strong" by its CFO, and the firm continues to pursue a long-term plan to make its wholesale division self-funding.

site_title: Japan must avoid issuing debt to fund fresh spending: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged Japan to fund additional spending plans within its budget, rather than issuing more debt, due to its high public debt of twice the economy. The IMF's director, Krishna Srinivasan, stated that Japan's fiscal house needs to be consolidated amid interest rate hikes by the central bank. Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has pledged a large-scale spending package, but has not specified how it will be funded. The IMF's warning comes as Japan's rapidly ageing population and rising social welfare costs contribute to its massive public debt.

summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.8% at the opening of trading on November 1, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 28.72 points to 3,530.16. The broader market saw losers outnumber gainers 83 to 50, with 117.9 million securities changing hands. Beverage maker Thai Beverage was the most actively traded counter, falling 4.7% to S$0.505.

site_title: UK car outlook worsens after eight straight months of declining production
summary: UK car production slumped 15% in October, marking the eighth consecutive month of decline, with the industry's trade group warning of further deterioration. AutoAnalysis has lowered its 2024 and 2025 projections by 12% and 16% respectively. The UK government has pledged support for the industry, including a review of regulations, amid concerns over electric vehicle sales mandates and the impact of plant closures. Output is now forecast to reach 910,805 cars and light vans this year, down from nearly one million.

site_title: Hot stock: Olam surges to record high on potential agribusiness stake sale
summary: Olam Group's shares surged to a record high after Saudi Agricultural & Livestock Investment Company (Salic) made a non-binding indicative offer for the group's remaining stake in Olam Agri, valued at about US$4 billion. Salic currently holds a 35.4% minority stake in Olam Agri after investing US$1.24 billion in the unit. Olam Group emphasized that no definitive terms or formal legal documentation have been agreed upon, and there is no certainty that a sale will proceed.

site_title: South Korea’s October export growth slows to seven-month low
summary: South Korea's export growth slowed to a seven-month low in October, with outbound shipments rising 4.6% from the previous year to US$57.52 billion. This marks the smallest increase since March and misses market expectations, indicating cooling global demand. The slowdown puts further pressure on the country's stuttering economic recovery, despite the 13th straight month of annual growth.

site_title: Asia: Most markets drop, dollar gains as Trump fires tariff warning
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's announcement of imposing huge new tariffs on China, Mexico, and Canada sparked a sell-off across most Asian markets, with the dollar rallying in response. Hong Kong and Shanghai advanced in early exchanges. The move dampened optimism for a more moderate trade policy and raised concerns of another trade war with China, potentially reigniting US inflation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Wilmar, First Reit
summary: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission filed court proceedings against Singtel's subsidiary Optus Mobile over allegations of inappropriate sales conduct. The commission is pursuing penalties, consumer redress, a compliance program, and costs from Optus. Meanwhile, Wilmar International reported a 19% drop in its third-quarter net profit due to weaker contributions from China operations and a sugar division. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss for the second half of the year.

site_title: Gold holds steady as traders wait for key US economic data
summary: Gold prices held steady on Friday, edging up 0.1% to $2,746.30 per ounce, as traders await the US payrolls report and the US presidential election. The metal marked a 4.15% monthly rise in October and hit a record high of $2,790.15. US consumer spending increased in September, putting the economy on a higher growth trajectory, while unemployment filings fell last week. Traders anticipate nearly a 94% chance of a Fed rate cut next week, supporting the labor market.

images.alt_text: bullion - An employee handles one kilogram gold bullions at the YLG Bullion International Co. headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, on Friday, Dec. 22, 2023. site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after subdued pre-holiday shift on Wall Street
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday, with Hong Kong and Shanghai edging down amid speculation of fresh stimulus measures from Beijing. Despite a negative lead from Wall Street, investors welcomed a drop in Treasury yields and steady US inflation data. Futures markets suggest a 2/3 chance of a 25-basis-point rate cut by the Federal Reserve in December. The US stock market ended in the red ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday, while Treasury yields slipped, weighing on the dollar.

site_title: Yakiniku that makes the cut at Ushiyama
summary: Ushiyama Yakiniku, a new restaurant in Singapore's Holland Village, serves premium wagyu in a cozy setting. The eatery uses Ohmi wagyu, one of Japan's top three wagyu types, sourced from a farm in Shiga prefecture. Prices range from $38 to $168 for various cuts, including zabuton, chuck flap, and boneless short rib. The restaurant also offers a variety of side dishes, such as spicy beef soup, garlic fried rice, and wagyu curry rice, which are the stars of the show. With a rating of 7, Ushiyama is a must-visit for those who appreciate high-quality wagyu.

site_title: Jo Malone’s favourite time of the year
summary: Jo Malone, renowned British perfumer, shares her love for Christmas and plans for the festive season. She reminisces about her favorite Christmas memories in Whistler and London, where she celebrates with candlelight, simple dinners, and singing carols. This year, she'll spend Christmas with her family in London, hosting a dinner party with friends and young people. Malone also reflects on her personal growth, her upcoming adventure in education, and her desire to support causes she believes in, stating she's grateful for the opportunities she's had and is excited for the future.

site_title: ‘Disrupt Health Impact Fund’ Closes First Deal, Investing in ‘DiaMonTech’, Non-Invasive Glucose Measurement Startup
summary: Disrupt Health Impact Fund has invested in DiaMonTech, a German startup that develops non-invasive glucose measurement technology. The device, called D-Pocket, can accurately measure glucose levels in 30 seconds using a finger prick. This technology addresses a critical need for diabetic patients, particularly in Thailand, where 5.2 million people live with diabetes. The investment aligns with the fund's goal to capitalize on the growing demand for self-care medical devices, driven by an aging global population and increasing life expectancies. The fund aims to invest in 15 healthcare DeepTech companies in the next 3-5 years.

site_title: UBS targets rich women as return to Australia strategy shapes up
summary: UBS is returning to wealth management in Australia after a nearly 9-year absence, tapping into the Credit Suisse franchise it acquired. The Swiss bank is targeting rich women and family offices, with a focus on the growing high net worth market in the country. With over US$30 billion in managed wealth, UBS aims to grow its presence in Australia as part of its Asia-Pacific expansion goals, competing with foreign players like Morgan Stanley and domestic firms like Shaw and Partners.

site_title: Microsoft faces broad antitrust investigation from US FTC
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has launched a broad antitrust investigation of Microsoft, focusing on its cloud computing, software licensing, and cybersecurity businesses. The inquiry, led by outgoing FTC Chair Lina Khan, seeks information on Microsoft's business practices, including bundling of software with cloud services and cybersecurity offerings. This renewed scrutiny comes over 25 years after the government previously sued Microsoft for similar conduct. The FTC's concerns include Microsoft's significant market power, cybersecurity failings, and its role as a top government contractor.

site_title: Charles Schwab eyes spot crypto trading once regulations change
summary: Charles Schwab is considering offering spot cryptocurrency trading once US regulations allow it, according to CEO-elect Rick Wurster. The move is expected to come after President-elect Donald Trump takes office, which is seen as a more favorable regulatory environment. Schwab currently offers crypto-linked exchange-traded funds and crypto futures, and Wurster supports clients who wish to invest in crypto despite not planning to do so himself. The company's AI capabilities are also expected to have a significant impact on the wealth-management business.

site_title: Asean is fast positioning itself as a key actor in the global balance of power
summary: Asean, a bloc of 10 Southeast Asian countries, is positioning itself as a key actor in the global balance of power due to its robust economic growth, strategic location, and demographic advantage. With a median age of 29.8 years, Asean's youthful population fuels domestic demand and makes it an increasingly important consumption hub. The region's economic growth is driven by foreign direct investment, digital transformation, and its role in global supply chains. Despite challenges, Asean's influence is growing rapidly, and it stands poised to be a central actor in shaping the future of global geopolitics and economics.

site_title: India to offer up to US$5 billion in incentives for electronics production, weaning off China
summary: India plans to offer up to $5 billion in incentives to encourage domestic electronics production, aiming to reduce reliance on China. The new scheme, expected to be launched in 2-3 months, will incentivize production of key components like printed circuit boards to improve domestic value addition and deepen local supply chains. India's electronic production has more than doubled to $115 billion in 2024, making it the world's fourth-largest smartphone supplier.

site_title: ABR Holdings managing director continues to grow interest
summary: Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks from Nov 15 to 21, resulting in a net institutional outflow of S$38 million. Reits and consumer cyclicals led the net institutional outflow, while financial services and industrials led the net institutional inflow. Meanwhile, Hongkong Land's interim management statement showed underlying profit increased due to more build-to-sell completions in China, while investment property contributions declined slightly. Key executives, including Ang Yee Lim of ABR Holdings and Pek Kok Sam of Southern Alliance Mining, acquired shares in their respective companies, with Lim increasing his stake in ABR Holdings to 53.59% and Sam acquiring 127,400 shares at S$0.41 per share.

site_title: How to avoid a share buybacklash
summary: DBS' recent $3 billion share buyback has reignited debate on the practice, with some viewing it as "paper manipulation" and others arguing it's a way to return capital to shareholders. To mitigate backlash, companies can consider the following: 1) maintaining a mix of dividends and buybacks, 2) carefully timing share buybacks, and 3) being transparent about executives' share sales. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta has reassured investors that the bank will use a combination of these methods to return capital. The bank still has $3-5 billion in excess capital, and its share price has risen to a record high.

site_title: Safe-haven gold on track for weekly gain
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Friday, poised for a weekly gain, driven by safe-haven demand due to escalating geopolitical concerns. Spot gold rose to a one-week high, while US gold futures edged down. The US jobless claims dropped to a seven-month low, indicating job growth rebounded after disruptions. Russia's response to Western sanctions, including a hypersonic missile strike, also contributed to the safe-haven demand.

site_title: COP29 braces for new deal after poorer nations reject climate offer
summary: Developing countries rejected a US$250 billion annual climate action commitment by wealthy nations, prompting fierce bargaining at the COP29 talks in Azerbaijan. The offer was met with criticism, with some nations demanding at least US$500 billion, while experts suggest developed nations should triple their pledge to US$100 billion by 2030. The talks are on the brink of collapse, with no final draft acceptable to all, and a deal unlikely before the closing session later on Saturday.

site_title: Biden to attend Trump inauguration even though Trump skipped Biden’s
summary: US President Joe Biden will attend Donald Trump's inauguration in January, despite Trump skipping Biden's inauguration in 2021. The decision is seen as a commitment to democratic values, with Biden viewing it as an important demonstration of honor. This move comes after Biden provided Trump with a smooth transition, despite Trump repeatedly describing Biden as a threat to democracy. site_title: South Korea’s early export figures show return to growth
summary: South Korea's early export figures show a return to growth, increasing 5.8% in the first 20 days of November compared to the same period last year. The country's trade surplus with the US widened to $798 million, despite concerns over the potential impact of a new US administration under Donald Trump, who has pledged universal tariffs and aims to increase duties on China and other countries. Economists predict a potential decline in Korean exports to the US by up to 55% by 2028 if Trump's tariffs are implemented.

site_title: US finalises US$1.5 billion chips award to GlobalFoundries
summary: The US government has finalized a $1.5 billion grant to chipmaker GlobalFoundries, supporting its domestic semiconductor manufacturing investments under the Chips and Science Act. This award aims to boost US production, increasing domestic manufacturing capacity and national security. The grant is part of a larger $13 billion investment by GlobalFoundries over the next 10 years, expected to generate 1,000 manufacturing jobs. The move follows a preliminary agreement announced in February and comes before President-elect Trump's expected return to office.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle as traders weigh geopolitical tensions
summary: Asia's stock markets fell on Wednesday as investors weighed the prospect of escalating tensions in the Russia-Ukraine war and Donald Trump's second presidency. The war burst back into focus after Moscow vowed to react "accordingly" to Kyiv's use of a US-made long-range missile. Meanwhile, Nvidia's upcoming earnings are expected to provide insight into the tech sector and AI demand, which have driven markets to record highs this year.

site_title: IMF cuts South Korea’s growth outlook as trade headwinds grow
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) lowered its forecast for South Korea's economic growth to 2% in 2025 and 2.2% in 2024, citing rising headwinds including a slowdown among trading partners, geo-economic tensions, and rising commodity prices due to Mideast conflicts. The IMF also noted uncertainty around the outlook, with risks tilted to the downside. This decision echoes growing concerns among economists, with risks including a slowdown among South Korea's export-reliant economy and the potential impact of global economic tensions.

site_title: Putin hints at strikes on West in ‘global’ Ukraine war
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin warned of potential strikes on Western countries in a defiant address to the nation, amid escalating tensions in the Ukraine conflict. Putin said Russia would retaliate if Ukraine's allies allow Kyiv to use Western-supplied weapons to strike targets on Russian territory. The US and UK have given permission for Ukraine to use these weapons, which Putin hinted were capable of unleashing a nuclear payload. The conflict has intensified with Russia test-firing an intermediate-range missile at Ukraine, and Ukraine firing US and UK-supplied missiles at Russian territory.

Other cornerstone investors include the family of New World Development chairman Henry Cheng, Oaktree Capital Management, and China Pacific Insurance Group. The move is seen as a vote of confidence in the market, with analysts noting that the presence of local tycoons can help drum up interest from other high net worth individuals and Hong Kong retail investors.

site_title: UK lawmakers plan to ask Elon Musk to give evidence on summer riots
summary: UK lawmakers plan to invite Elon Musk to testify in parliament about X's role in spreading disinformation during the UK's summer riots. The House of Commons' Science, Innovation and Technology Committee has been probing the platform's involvement, as Musk is an active user of the platform. Musk will be asked to provide evidence to the committee, which has been investigating how social media companies and search engines contribute to the spread of harmful content.

site_title: Mainstream car COE drops S$10,000 in largest price fall of 2024; Cat A now under S$90,000 for first time since June
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) price for mainstream cars in Singapore dropped by 10% in November, reaching S$89,889, the largest decrease for 2024. Category A, which applies to cars with engines up to 1,600cc, also saw its first price below S$90,000 since June. In contrast, Category B, for larger and more powerful cars, slipped 2.7% to S$105,081. The drop is attributed to a surge in COE availability, with 20,000 additional COEs to be released in February 2025, and slower retail demand.
