A National Environment Agency (NEA) officer conducting checks on a Malaysian-registered vehicle using a probe which measures exhaust emissions. Drivers of vehicles found to be emitting excessive exhaust fumes will be fined. This vehicle was found with an extremely high index of 91 HSU (Hartridge Smoke Unit).
Land Transport Authority (LTA) did not reveal specifics on the time frame of the additional COEs, nor on individual COE categories.
COE premiums recede slightly from highs seen in early October.

site_title: Take a long-term view and position portfolios for opportunities
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has secured a "clean sweep" victory with a Republican majority in both the Senate and House of Representatives. His policy proposals, previously considered too radical, now have a higher likelihood of being implemented. Trump plans to implement tax cuts, reduce industry regulations, and impose high tariffs on foreign goods, particularly China. This may boost the US economy in the short term but raise inflation concerns and impact global economies. US stocks, particularly financials and cash-rich companies, may benefit, while euro area and emerging-market Asian stocks face increased trade tariffs risks.

images.alt_text: Geoff Howie and Dr Joseph Liow explain the impact of a second Donald Trump administration on inflation, stock prices and elections in Singapore.
Short-term losses are inevitable. What matters is whether your portfolio recovers.

From left: Geoff Howie, market strategist, Singapore Exchange; Sue Lee, director and Asia-Pacific head of index investment strategy, S&P Dow Jones Indices; Jermyn Wong, head of intermediary, South-east Asia, State Street Global Advisors; and Ben Paul, senior correspondent, The Business Times.

site_title: IMF warns Asia retaliatory tariffs could undermine growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that retaliatory tariffs in Asia could undermine economic growth, raise costs, and disrupt supply chains. The IMF forecasts global economic growth at 3.2% for 2024 and 2025, weaker than its projections for Asia. The region's growth is expected to be 4.6% this year and 4.4% next year, but "tit-for-tat" tariffs could disrupt growth prospects and lead to longer, less efficient supply chains. The IMF Asia-Pacific director, Krishna Srinivasan, notes that escalating trade tensions pose an acute risk to Asia's economic prospects.

site_title: Singapore downgrades 2024 export forecasts again on weaker-than-expected recovery
summary: Singapore has downgraded its 2024 export forecasts for non-oil domestic exports (NODX) to "around 1 per cent" year-over-year, from 4 to 5 per cent, due to a weaker-than-expected recovery in volatile segments like pharmaceuticals and ships. The country also lowered its total merchandise trade forecast to "around 5 per cent", from 5 to 6 per cent. Despite this, Enterprise Singapore forecasts NODX to grow by 1 to 3 per cent in 2025, in line with the World Trade Organization's projections.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
NODX performance had spent a large part of H1 in negative territory and returning to positive growth in July. Since then however, it spent the next three months in decline.
The commodities sector is particularly susceptible to the disruption of trade and economic partnerships.

site_title: Indonesia considering another tax amnesty programme, lawmaker says
summary: Indonesia is considering a new tax amnesty program, its third in the past decade, amid concerns it could encourage tax avoidance. The move comes after two previous programs uncovered over $340 billion in unreported assets. Lawmakers plan to discuss the proposal with the government, despite criticism from President Joko Widodo's administration that it could lead to more tax evasion. The new program would offer lower-than-normal tax rates to taxpayers who disclose unreported assets, while authorities would penalize those who do not participate.

images.alt_text: The central bank's intervention comes as investors pulled more than US$1.2 billion from Indonesia’s markets this month amid fears that the US president-elect’s “America First” policies will lift US inflation and force the Federal Reserve to temper its rate cuts.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 end higher after early weakness
summary: US stocks finished higher on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index up 1.0% to 18,987.47, and the S&P 500 climbing 0.4% to 5,916.98. The tech-rich Nasdaq led the gains, driven by Nvidia's expected results, while other tech giants like Netflix and Tesla also advanced. However, the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.3% to 43,268.94, amid early weakness and concerns over the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders watch as a screen shows U.S. President Donald Trump on his daily White House coronavirus briefing on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., March 18, 2020. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo

site_title: A taste of Kyoto at Zeniya
summary: A kaiseki restaurant in Kyoto, Zeniya at Shangri-La Hotel, is serving premium produce from the region until November 30. The restaurant is collaborating with Japanese importer Livlon to showcase Kyoto's heirloom vegetables, seafood, and Miyabi wagyu. The menu features dishes such as Kyoto Miyabi wagyu served shabu-shabu style and warabi mochi dusted with matcha and black bean powder. This promotion aims to spread the word on the quality of Kyoto's produce and ingredients, which have earned the region the nickname "Kyoyasai" or "Kyoto vegetables".

site_title: Looking for gems in Asean’s multi-dimensional equities landscape
summary: Thailand's tourism industry is experiencing a resurgence, boosting local businesses and stimulating economic growth, as the country nears pre-pandemic levels. The US Federal Reserve's rate reduction cycle and China's policy stimulus signal a change in market dynamics, creating opportunities for emerging investments. Asean's diverse and attractive investment landscape is gaining traction, with sectors like convenience chain stores, international medical services, and manufacturing showing potential for growth. The region's stable political outlook, currency appreciation, and relative valuation make it an attractive investment window for long-term investors.

images.alt_text: Within Asean, equities' performance is varied, with Vietnam leading the way with a 14.1 per cent year-to-date gain.
With a median age of just 29.8 years, Asean’s demographic advantage contrasts sharply with the ageing populations of developed economies like Japan and much of Europe.

site_title: Making advance directives while healthy helps to mitigate risks
summary: A recent nationwide study in Singapore found that the prevalence of dementia among those 60 and above has dropped to 8.8% from 10% about 10 years ago. The study also found a decrease in stroke prevalence and the proportion of seniors unaware of their dementia diagnosis. Financial risks for seniors unaware of their memory loss are significant, with higher fees and interest charges due to payment delinquencies. Making advance directives, such as a lasting power of attorney, advance medical directive, or advance care planning, can mitigate these risks and ensure that one's values and desires are fulfilled.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
The importance of end-of-life planning
Millennials, who have typically grown up in smaller families, stand to inherit a larger sum of wealth from their parents.

site_title: India’s trade deficit widens more than expected in October
summary: India's trade deficit widened to $27.1 billion in October, exceeding economists' forecasts of $22 billion. Imports grew 3.9% to $66.3 billion, while exports rose 17.3% to $39.2 billion, driven by the Hindu festival season. The widening deficit may pressure India's currency, prompting the central bank to intervene in the foreign exchange market.

site_title: Seoul apartment prices drop for first time in nine months
summary: Seoul apartment prices dropped 0.01% in September, marking the first decline in nine months, according to the Korea Real Estate Board. This slowdown in housing prices supports the Bank of Korea's policy pivot last month and may lead to an acceleration of monetary easing next year. The Bank of Korea is expected to hold its interest rate unchanged, but speculation suggests officials may quicken the pace of rate cuts due to continued stability in housing markets.

site_title: Singapore NODX disappoints further, with October exports down 4.6%
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 4.6% year-over-year in October, disappointing economists who had forecast a 4% growth. Non-electronic shipments declined 6.7% year-over-year, while electronic shipments grew 2.6% year-over-year. Exports to Singapore's top 10 markets declined overall, with China's exports contracting 22.3% year-over-year. Despite this, most economists maintain their full-year gross domestic product growth forecasts, with some downgrading their NODX outlook.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
CMG20230113-LongKH02/龙国雄/Pasir Panjang Terminal [Pasir Panjang Ave] #PSA # Container #集装箱 #港口 #

site_title: XPeng forecasts upbeat fourth quarter revenue as new launches improve demand
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker XPeng forecasts upbeat fourth-quarter revenue above Wall Street estimates, driven by a refreshed product line-up and improving domestic market demand. The company expects revenue of 15.3-16.2 billion yuan, beating analysts' average estimate of 14.77 billion yuan. XPeng delivered over 10,000 units of its mid-sized sedan, MONA M03, in October, and unveiled its P7+ executive sedan, which received over 31,000 pre-orders. The company expects to deliver 87,000-91,000 vehicles in the fourth quarter, up 44.6% from a year ago.

images.alt_text: Sales fell 1.1 per cent from the same month a year earlier to 1.92 million vehicles, data from the China Passenger Car Association showed.
People sit in a MONA M03 electric vehicle (EV), displayed outside the venue of XPeng's launch event, in Beijing, China August 27, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo
Volkswagen’s Chinese partner is in the initial stages of selecting a site in the European Union as part of its future plan to localise production, CEO He Xiaopeng says.

site_title: Prime US Reit Q3 distributable income falls to US$8.5 million
summary: Prime US Reit's distributable income for Q3 fell to US$8.5 million, down from US$14.7 million the previous year, due to lower contributions from properties Waterfront At Washingtonian and 101 South Hanley, as well as the absence of One Town Centre's contribution after its divestment in July 2024. Revenue and net property income also declined to US$34.1 million and US$18 million, respectively.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
One Town Center in Florida was divested in July.

site_title: Singapore tech firm Circles is said to weigh sale of digital arm Circles.Life
summary: Singapore-based tech firm Circles Global is considering the sale of its digital telecom services provider Circles.Life, valued at a few hundred million US dollars, according to sources. Circles plans to retain its software-as-a-service platform and has partnerships with telecom operators in 15 countries. The company, backed by private equity firms Warburg Pincus and others, is working with a financial adviser to evaluate the potential sale. No final decisions have been made, and the process is private.

images.alt_text: Abhishek Gupta, Co-founder of Circles.Life, will now take on a non-executive role.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit to develop logistics property in US for S$94.8 million
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit will develop a logistics property in the US, Summerville Logistics Center, at an estimated total cost of S$94.8 million. The project is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2025 and will be financed through internal resources and/or existing debt facilities. The Reit holds a 95% interest in the joint venture with PTLI, the property's developer, and the remaining 5% is held by PTLI.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Maybank's upgrade is premised on CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's defensive characteristics, exposure to growth verticals and reasonable valuations.
Clar's portfolio rental reversions rose to 14.4 per cent in the quarter, from 11.7 per cent a quarter ago.
Net proceeds from the divestment of 21 Jalan Buroh are estimated to be S$102.9 million.

site_title: China’s Jan-Oct government land sales revenue down 22.9% year on year
summary: China's government land sales revenue declined 22.9% year on year for the first 10 months of 2024, with a 24.6% drop in the first 9 months. This decline is attributed to reduced land acquisitions by cash-strapped developers. To alleviate debt burdens, the government introduced a 10 trillion yuan debt relief package and will use local government special bonds to increase land reclaim and redevelopment, focusing on residential and commercial sites.

site_title: The F&B sector’s woes could undermine the resilience of suburban malls
summary: Suburban malls in Singapore, which have historically been resilient, may face challenges if the food and beverage (F&B) sector continues to decline. F&B accounted for 37.5% of FCT's retail portfolio gross rental income and 30.2% of total net lettable area as of September. However, the sector is facing woes, with 2,465 F&B businesses closing in the first nine months of 2024, a 20% increase from the previous year. This could lead to falling demand for physical spaces and rising resistance to high rentals from an under-pressure F&B sector, potentially impacting suburban mall landlords' rental revenue.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
PHOTO: In the first nine months of 2024, 2,465 F&B businesses ceased operations. Restaurant Uni Gallery closed in August this year.

site_title: Trump election boosts UK inflation risks, Bank of England's Mann says
summary: Bank of England official Catherine Mann says Trump's election as US president may boost UK inflation risks due to global economic volatility. Mann believes global shocks, not domestic pressures, often drive excess inflation in Britain. She advises keeping interest rates on hold until inflation risks dissipate. Mann cites trade fragmentation and financial market fragmentation as factors that contribute to underlying inflation pressures. The Bank of England should ensure these pressures do not manifest in the inflation rate.

images.alt_text: UK bonds tumbled last week as traders worried the government’s increased spending in the coming years will fan inflation and limit the BOE’s ability to ease monetary policy.

site_title: What Trump’s picks suggest about how his presidency will go
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has made several unconventional Cabinet picks, signaling a tighter, more authoritarian approach to governance. He chose Pete Hegseth as defense secretary, despite controversy over his Charlottesville comments, and Tulsi Gabbard as director of national intelligence, despite her past criticism of the US. Trump also selected Matt Gaetz as attorney-general, amid allegations of sex trafficking. These choices reflect Trump's loyalty to his base and willingness to punish perceived disloyalty, but may face challenges in the Senate. Other picks, including Marco Rubio as secretary of state and Mike Waltz as national security adviser, align with Trump's "Make America Great Again" agenda.

images.alt_text: Marcio Rubio was a key sponsor of the 2021 Uyghur Forced Labor Prevention Act, which bans the import of all goods from the northwestern Xinjiang region unless companies offer verifiable proof that production did not involve such a violation.
According to multiple US media, Donald Trump has picked Florida Senator Marco Rubio (right) as his secretary of state.

site_title: SEA’s digital dragons roar back, but don’t get singed
summary: South-east Asia's e-commerce firms have shown resilience despite financial sobriety, with growth in digital sales and a strong online presence. Super apps have emerged as a dominant force, with companies like Sea and Shopee driving growth through their diversified services. The region's e-commerce landscape is expected to continue evolving, with a focus on improving operational efficiency and expanding into new markets.

images.alt_text: Joyce Hooi
Beyond the knee-jerk US equity euphoria, there is disquiet as election uncertainty is replaced by uncertainty about everything else, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.
The data centre sector as a whole also remains at the mercy of still-high interest rates or potential oversupply, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.
While the Monetary Authority of Singapore might yet produce bold changes to revive the market, its review group’s recommendations will only be out later next year.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit unveils S$1-billion unit placement,  preferential offer to fund purchase of data centres
summary: Keppel DC Reit plans to raise S$1 billion through a private placement and preferential offer to fund the purchase of two data centers. The private placement will raise S$600 million, while the preferential offer will raise S$300 million. The manager intends to declare an advanced distribution of S$0.04063 to S$0.04103 per unit. The gross proceeds will be used to finance the acquisition of the data centers.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
The proposed acquisition will expand the Keppel DC Reit's assets under management by 36 per cent to S$5.2 billion.
Post-capital reduction, Keppel will be able to effectively manage when and how the legacy assets are monetised.
The trust says the purchase is expected to be accretive to its distribution per unit, with pro-forma DPU for FY2023 rising 0.4 per cent.

site_title: Creative offices – blending design and fun
summary: Three boutique creative studios, This Humid House, Studio CHS, and Cream Pie, have transformed their workplaces into inspiring spaces that showcase their brand's aesthetic and personality. Each studio has a unique design, incorporating elements such as vintage furniture, oil paintings, and traditional Japanese masks. The offices feature private meeting rooms, fully equipped kitchens, and fun touches like disco balls and oversized winter melons. These spaces aim to make going to the office an enjoyable experience, encouraging employees to return to the workspace.

images.alt_text: The main living areas (left), the pool and the porous wall of breeze blocks (right) blurs the boundaries between indoor and outdoor spaces, lending layers and shifting perspectives.

site_title: Companies like DBS, ST Engineering are buying back their shares. Are there downsides?
summary: Several Singaporean companies, including DBS, UOB, and ST Engineering, have launched share buyback schemes to boost earnings per share and return capital to shareholders. These schemes can indirectly reward existing shareholders and improve a company's return on equity. However, critics argue that share buybacks may indicate a company's lack of profitable investment opportunities, inefficient cash management, or limited growth potential. Additionally, companies should be cautious when buying back shares at high valuations, especially if they borrow to finance the scheme.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
DBS says its S$3 billion share buyback programme promises to raise earnings per share and return on equity.
Singapore banks see upsides to net interest margins (NIMs) during a second Donald Trump term as US president, given that markets expect inflationary policies that may result in higher interest rates.

site_title: Singapore looks to Asean neighbours for green power to meet carbon goals
summary: Singapore aims to increase the share of imported green electricity from Asean countries to one-third of its power demand by 2035, driven by growing demand for clean energy and limited land for energy storage. The country seeks to decarbonize its power sector, which accounts for 40% of its total carbon emissions, to meet its climate goals, including achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. Singapore has already imported green electricity from Laos and Malaysia, and plans to work with Chinese companies on low-carbon fuels, including hydrogen and ammonia.

images.alt_text: The Asia Pacific's economic dynamism, coupled with its rapidly expanding and increasingly sophisticated real estate markets, offers a compelling alternative to slower growing, more saturated markets elsewhere.

site_title: At a glance: The proposed Workplace Fairness Legislation
summary: Singapore's Parliament has tabled the Workplace Fairness Bill, which aims to prohibit adverse employment decisions based on protected characteristics such as age, nationality, and disability. The legislation, set to be debated in January 2025, will strengthen protections, set out processes, and expand enforcement actions. It will cover hiring, employment duration, and firing, and exemptions will be made for genuine occupational requirements. Smaller firms will be initially exempt, with a review to come. If passed, the legislation is expected to take effect from 2026 or 2027.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

site_title: Tuan Sing to redevelop Melbourne properties with Grand Hyatt hotel asset
summary: Tuan Sing has submitted a town planning application for a major mixed-use redevelopment of its properties in Melbourne, Australia, spanning 84,500 square meters. The project, led by Grand Hotel Group, aims to transform the site into a "dynamic luxury retail and food and beverage precinct" while preserving historic character. The redevelopment is envisioned to set a new benchmark for adaptive reuse in Melbourne and will continue to support business operations for tenants.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Higher operating costs at Opus Bay, Tuan Sing's township project in Batam, contributed to the group's H1 loss.
Hyatt Regency Perth will no longer be a Hyatt-managed hotel ahead of its planned repositioning and rebranding.
The acquisition is part of Tuan Sing's broader growth strategy to expand its hospitality business in Singapore and the region, says the company.
Sime Darby Centre, owned by Tuan Sing. The property company reports higher revenue from all three segments of its business.

site_title: Wavemaker Partners raises US$30 million in new fund, rebrands
summary: Wavemaker Partners, a venture capital firm, has raised US$30 million in its new fund, Wavemaker Growth Opportunities Fund, targeting US$60 million for the final close. The fund focuses on supporting startups in the enterprise, deep tech, and sustainability sectors in South-east Asia, particularly in Series B funding rounds. The firm aims to bridge gaps startups face as they scale, with plans to invest in 8-12 companies, and strengthen its existing portfolio. Wavemaker Growth will be led by founding partners Paul Santos, Shiv Choudhury, and Koh Xue.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
CNV offers digital transformation software-as-a-service products and marketing services targeting enterprises in Vietnam, among others.
Staple co-founders Ben Stein (left) and Joshua Kettlewell intend to channel the startup's fresh funds toward market expansion and other uses.
The Wavemaker Impact team aims to lower the global carbon budget by 10 per cent by 2035.

site_title: Yoma’s H1 net loss deepens to US$11 million on forex headwinds
summary: Yoma Strategic posted a net loss of US$11 million for the first half of 2024, widening from a US$2.5 million loss in the previous period due to revenue declines and higher finance costs. Revenue fell 14.7% to US$95.2 million, but grew 35% in kyat terms. The company attributes the decline to a 55% depreciation of the Myanmar kyat. Despite this, revenue from its F&B segment grew 44.8% in kyat terms, driven by strong consumer demand in its KFC and YKKO businesses.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
News agency The Irrawaddy reports that Yoma's former executive chairman, Serge Pun, is facing two additional charges.
Serge Pun stepped down as executive chairman of Yoma in July, handing the role over to his other son Melvyn Pun.
Executive chairman Serge Pun's meetings with authorities has no impact on the group's financials, says Yoma.
Executive chairman Serge Pun has been meeting and cooperating with relevant authorities, says Yoma Strategic.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's PIF to sell 2% stake in STC in potential US$1.1 billion deal
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) plans to sell a 2% stake in telecom company STC, potentially raising up to $1.1 billion. The 100 million-share offering will be determined through an accelerated book building and will not generate any proceeds for STC. PIF will retain a 62% stake in the company after the sale.

site_title: StarHub’s Q3 earnings rise 11.1% to S$40.4 million
summary: StarHub reported a net profit of S$40.4 million for Q3 2024, a 11.1% increase from the previous year. However, revenue fell 5.8% to S$575.2 million due to timing issues in the cybersecurity services segment. The company attributes the decline to revenue recognition timing, but notes that other segments, such as enterprise managed services and broadband businesses, saw revenue growth. Mobile postpaid subscribers rose to 1.7 million, but average revenue per user (Arpu) fell to S$30 due to fewer plan subscriptions and lower value-added services revenue.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Simba's improving fundamentals and balance sheet suggest that it is well-positioned to continue taking market share, says analyst.
About 80 per cent of the reports were about issues with users' mobile internet.
StarHub has declared an interim dividend of 3 cents per share for H1, compared to an interim dividend of 2.5 cents per share in the corresponding year-ago period.

site_title: BNP cuts 10% of China dealmaker jobs after 2022 expansion
summary: BNP Paribas has cut about 10% of its China-related headcount, affecting around 10 jobs, amid a sluggish market for deals. The layoffs, announced last week, primarily impact staff in equity underwriting and corporate banking divisions, as the bank shifts its focus to mergers. This marks the first headcount reduction since the bank expanded its China investment banking team in 2022, adding over 20 dealmakers. The cuts are part of BNP's broader strategy to focus on corporate banking in China.

images.alt_text: The French bank was charged last week with violating local capital markets law, said sources, who requested anonymity discussing a private matter.
China’s National Financial Regulatory Administration (NFRA) has approved the creation of a joint venture between BNP Paribas and Volkswagen Financial Services.
FILE PHOTO: A BNP Paribas sign is pictured on a building of the bank in Geneva November 26, 2014.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A BNP Paribas sign is pictured on a building of the bank in Geneva November 26, 2014.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: US bank CEOs express confidence in deals, consumer finances
summary: US bank CEOs expressed confidence in dealmaking and consumer finances, citing strong advisory work on mergers and acquisitions and full pipelines for initial public offerings. KeyCorp CEO Christopher Gorman noted a 30% increase in consumer bank accounts since the pandemic, indicating a healthy economy. US banks expect increased demand for loans as interest rates fall and the incoming Trump administration prepares to take office. Loan demand is expected to rise, potentially leading to a revival of loan growth across the industry.

images.alt_text: The so-called core consumer price index – which excludes food and energy costs – increased 0.3 per cent for a third month and 3.3 per cent from a year ago.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose five basis points to 6.86 per cent in the week ended Nov 8, the highest since July.

The European Central Bank (ECB) building is pictured prior to a news conference following the meeting of the governing council of the ECB in Frankfurt/Main, Germany, on September 12, 2024. With inflation slowing and the economic outlook darkening, the European Central Bank is expected to cut interest rates again on September 12, 2024 but is unlikely to give much away about its next moves. (Photo by Daniel ROLAND / AFP)

site_title: Australia nears deal with ANZ to stop bank closures in the Pacific
summary: Australia is nearing a deal with ANZ Group to maintain the bank's nine Pacific hubs, including Fiji and the Cook Islands, in a move to counter China's growing influence in the region. The deal would prevent bank closures in the Pacific, where many countries are losing access to international payments. The agreement comes after Australia and the US discussed solutions to the issue, and follows China's expansion into the region through financial and defense deals with Pacific island states. The terms of the deal have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: ANZ is also contending with an investigation by the nation’s securities regulator into the trading of government bonds.
ANZ will consolidate its operations into a single unit, led by a new executive team overseeing the bank’s capability centre, property, and procurement teams.
The hit to ANZ Group's profit will result in a 2 basis point reduction to its level 2 common equity tier 1 capital - a measure of its spare cash - in its second half results.

site_title: Quarz pares stake in Sabana Reit as Volare adds
summary: Swiss group Volare has acquired 22.5 million shares of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) from activist investor Quarz Capital for S$7.8 million. The deal increases Volare's deemed interest in the trust to 19.79% and bumps up its holding to about 222.6 million shares. Quarz's deemed interest has fallen to 12.3% from 14.3%, with its holding trimmed to about 138.8 million shares. The shares were sold at about S$0.35 apiece.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue

site_title: Malaysia Airlines head Izham to stay on after contract extended
summary: Malaysia Airlines CEO Izham Ismail will remain at the helm for another year after his contract was extended. Initially set to retire at the end of 2024, Izham, a 63-year-old former pilot, has navigated the airline through significant challenges, including the disappearance of MH370 and the shooting down of MH17. He oversaw the airline's turnaround, resulting in its first annual profit in a decade last year. The extension will see Izham continue serving as CEO and managing director of Malaysia Aviation Group.

site_title: India's toxic smog hides Taj Mahal, delays flights
summary: India's capital, New Delhi, was engulfed in toxic smog, exceeding 50 times the World Health Organization's recommended daily maximum, causing flight delays and obscuring iconic landmarks like the Taj Mahal and Golden Temple. The smog was attributed to high pollution, humidity, becalmed winds, and a drop in temperature. The city of Lahore in neighboring Pakistan was ranked the world's most polluted in winter. The smog's impact on daily life was evident, with residents choking and flights delayed. Officials blamed the pollution on dust, emissions, and smoke from fires in India's farming states.

images.alt_text: The Taj Mahal amid heavy smog conditions in Agra, India, Nov 23, 2023. Despite an improvement in air quality in South Asia in 2022, the region continues to breathe the world’s most-polluted air, with its residents losing more than 3.5 years of life expectancy on average, the annual Air Quality Life Index warned.
No country met WHO air quality standards in 2021: data

site_title: Singapore proposes law to entrench non-discriminatory workplace norms, introduce penalties
summary: Singapore is introducing a law to entrench non-discriminatory workplace norms, requiring companies to implement dispute resolution processes and prohibiting adverse employment decisions based on protected characteristics such as age, nationality, sex, and disability. The Workplace Fairness Bill, part of the new Workplace Fairness Legislation, aims to "preserve and entrench" existing workplace-fairness norms and introduces penalties for employers who flout the rules, including formal directions, administrative fines, and court-imposed fines. The law is expected to take effect from 2026 or 2027, with exemptions for smaller firms initially.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Age was still the most common form of discrimination in the workplace, affecting 2.6 per cent of employees in 2023.

site_title: Canada adds fewer jobs than expected in October, wages rise
summary: Canada added fewer-than-expected 14,500 jobs in October, with wages of permanent employees rising 4.9% annually, as the economy struggles to absorb a rapidly increasing population amid high interest rates and inflation. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 6.5%, hovering near a 34-month high. Business investment and hiring have been muted, despite record immigration fueling the labour force growth, leading to a steady decline in the employment rate.

images.alt_text: Canada has banned the TikTok app from government-issued devices, saying it presents an unacceptable level of risk to privacy and security.

The September data was its seventh straight monthly trade deficit, primarily led by a fall in value of lower exports to major trading countries other than its biggest trading partner the US, Statistics Canada said.
The headline business activity index rose to 50.4 from 46.4 in September, moving above the 50 threshold for the first time since May.

site_title: Indonesia's Mount Lewotobi erupts again, government to widen restricted zone
summary: Indonesia's Mount Lewotobi Laki-laki erupted at least three times on November 9, spewing an ash column 9 km high, following a big eruption that killed nine last Sunday. Authorities are widening the restricted zone from 8 km to 9 km southwest of the crater to ensure public safety. As of Friday evening, 10,700 people have been evacuated from villages near the crater, with efforts ongoing. The volcanology agency continues to monitor the situation, with eruptions and ash emissions expected to continue.

site_title: Global luxury sales to fall 2% in 2024, among weakest years on record: Bain
summary: Global luxury sales are expected to fall 2% in 2024, marking one of the weakest years on record, according to consultancy Bain & Company. A 20-22% sales drop in China, fueled by economic uncertainty and currency fluctuations, is a major contributor to the decline. The industry's customer base has shrunk by 50 million over the last two years, with brands shifting to higher price bands and consumers opting to forgo purchases. Luxury spending on experiences is expected to increase this year, while personal luxury goods sales are forecast to grow 0-4% in 2025.

images.alt_text: The Submariner, produced for more than 70 years, was designed for deep-sea divers, though it’s now more often seen on wrists of Wall Street or City of London traders.
LVMH’s sales in the region that includes China fell 16 per cent in the third quarter, more than its 14 per cent drop in the previous three months.
Frederic Grangie, head of the watch and jewellery division at Chanel, said “2025 and 2026 will be complicated years” for the luxury industry.

Comparable sales at Gucci, which makes up the bulk of Kering’s profit, slumped 25 per cent in the third quarter from a year earlier.

site_title: Trump returns to the White House to meet Biden
summary: US President Joe Biden met with President-elect Donald Trump in the Oval Office at the White House on November 13, marking the first time Trump returned to the White House since winning the election. The meeting aimed to discuss the transfer of power and potential policy differences, despite Trump's criticism of Biden and Biden's portrayal of Trump as a threat to democracy. The transition process is partially stalled due to disagreements over agreements and access to government officials, facilities, and information.

site_title: Injection of 20,000 COEs not linked to potential rollout of distance-based charging: Chee Hong Tat
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat stated that the planned injection of up to 20,000 additional Certificates of Entitlement (COEs) is not linked to distance-based road pricing. The COE increase is part of the government's car-lite vision, which aims to manage traffic congestion without causing gridlock. The LTA assessed the potential impact of the COE increase, but no decision has been made on implementing distance-based charging.

COE premiums recede slightly from highs seen in early October.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies tainted by SEC suits surge after Trump victory
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) Chair Gary Gensler's likely departure following Donald Trump's victory has sparked a rally in cryptocurrencies, with tokens associated with projects like Uniswap and Polygon surging 38% and 20% respectively. This is attributed to optimism about anticipated regulatory easing under the new administration, which may ease the regulatory crackdown on the digital asset industry. As a result, Ether, the second-largest cryptocurrency, has also seen a 21% price increase, while US Ether exchange-traded funds (ETFs) remain underperforming due to regulatory uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The SEC has often touted its success in court in obtaining judgments that align with its view that decades-old securities laws apply to the upstart digital asset class.
Bitcoin’s more than 60 per cent advance in 2024 has topped traditional assets such as global stocks and gold.
The largest cryptocurrency by market value has gained more than 65 per cent this year.
Stablecoins are digital tokens designed to keep a constant value.

site_title: Sats Q2 profit trebles to S$69.7 million, declares S$0.015 dividend per share
summary: Sats, an in-flight caterer and ground handler, reported a 214% increase in Q2 profit to S$69.7 million, driven by business volume growth, rate increases, and a revenue catch-up. Revenue rose 14.1% to S$1.5 billion, while expenditure grew 9.9%. The company declared a dividend of S$0.015 per share and expects positive momentum into the next quarter as demand for travel and cargo reaches its peak.

Citi wrote that season-sensitive containerised cargo such as Christmas toys and decoration will likely switch to air transportation if they are affected by US port strike, and it recommended buying  ground-handler Sats.

site_title: Food Empire’s Q3 revenue up 11.4% on strong showing across Asia markets
summary: Food Empire's Q3 revenue rose 11.4% to US$118.9 million, driven by strong growth in Asia markets, particularly South-east Asia with a 23.2% increase. Vietnam was the fastest-growing market, attributed to intense marketing efforts. The company is well-positioned for future expansion in Asia, with diversification into ingredients manufacturing and investments in production capacity. Despite ongoing market challenges, Food Empire remains optimistic about its growth prospects.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The group is locating the new facility in Vietnam as the country is one of the world’s largest producers of robusta coffee beans.

site_title: Desperate for tourists, Hong Kong doles out incentives to woo visitors from mainland and beyond
summary: Hong Kong is offering various incentives to attract tourists, including free or discounted public transport, museum admission, and discounted movie tickets, to boost its economy. The city saw a 40% year-on-year increase in visitors in the first nine months of 2024, with 32.6 million arrivals. Mainland Chinese tourists, in particular, surged into Hong Kong during the recent Golden Week holiday, with 1.2 million setting foot in the city. Despite encouraging results, Hong Kong's economy still faces challenges, including weaker consumption and the ongoing slowdown in China. The government has announced new measures to boost spending, including lowering liquor tax and promoting tourism from beyond the mainland.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's government released a forecast in August saying this year's growth would be in the range of 2.5 to 3.5 per cent.
Goldman Sachs has been regrouping in the nation as global investors signal renewed interest in the economy.
While rents and prices tend to move in tandem in most housing markets, Hong Kong’s economic and demographic changes in recent years have led to a divergence.

site_title: Indonesia confident palm oil production can be increased to meet biofuel demand
summary: Indonesia's chief economic minister, Airlangga Hartarto, expressed confidence in increasing palm oil production to meet the country's rising demand for energy, driven by the expansion of the mandatory biodiesel blend to 40% by 2025. The government aims to increase palm oil production from 11 million tonnes to 13.9 million tonnes and further to 50% in 2028. Replanting efforts are also underway to meet the higher demand, with a goal of replanting 180,000 hectares annually, but the program has been behind schedule.

images.alt_text: CPOPC is an intergovernmental organisation for palm oil producing countries, including the world’s biggest palm oil producer Indonesia, Malaysia and Honduras.
Malaysia has an estimated 450,000 small-scale producers, contributing to about 27 per cent of the country’s total palm oil cultivation.
The EU was Indonesia’s fourth-biggest export market in 2023 and the bloc receives 11.5 per cent of its palm oil exports.
Smallholders are reluctant to cut ageing trees and replant as it can take four to five years for new trees to bear fruit, compared with around six months for soybeans.

site_title: Funding Societies secures third credit facility from HSBC, taps latter’s US$1 billion Asean war chest
summary: Funding Societies, a digital finance platform, secured its third credit facility from HSBC, with the amount not disclosed. The facility, under HSBC's Asean Growth Fund, is expected to increase Funding Societies' reach in financing micro, small, and medium enterprises across Asean. The total funding commitment now exceeds $100 million, following a partnership that began in 2022. The new facility will enable Funding Societies to explore scalable debt financing for growth and profitability, further expanding its operations in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Funding Societies group chief executive and co-founder Kelvin Teo says that the tie-up will help extend credit access to businesses facing cash flow management challenges.
Last year, the Singapore Exchange mandated climate reporting for listed companies and the Monetary Authority of Singapore launched a portal for companies to report ESG data.
HSBC previously launched a US$200 million new economy fund in November 2021 for early-stage startups in Singapore.

site_title: OpenAI’s ChatGPT back up after brief outage
summary: OpenAI's popular chatbot ChatGPT experienced a brief outage, affecting thousands of users, before being restored. The outage, lasting about half an hour, was resolved by 4:34pm PT, with a small number of users facing issues until 5pm. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman acknowledged the issue, stating the company is "much, much better at reliability than we used to be" but still has work to do.

site_title: Singapore stocks outperform regional peers post US election: Analysts give their take
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.1% on Thursday, outperforming regional peers, as investors viewed the Singapore dollar and local stocks as a "relative safe haven" amid uncertainty following the US presidential election. Analysts attribute the STI's performance to the banking sector, which led the gain, and the expectation of a more gradual rate-cutting process from the US Federal Reserve. The Singapore market is seen as less affected by tariffs, with most constituents unrelated to export regulations.

site_title: Thailand may see record tourist arrivals in 2025, Agoda CEO says
summary: Thailand is poised to surpass its pre-pandemic record of 39 million foreign tourist arrivals in 2025, according to Agoda CEO Omri Morgenshtern. The country has already seen a surge in tourist arrivals this year, with over 29 million visitors, and is on track to meet its full-year target of 36.7 million. Agoda attributes the optimism to Thai government's visa waiver schemes and increased flight capacity, as well as the country's reputation as a "repeat visitor destination."

images.alt_text: Tourists visit the Grand Palace in Bangkok, Thailand, Aug 6, 2024. The Thai government expects 36.7 million foreign visitors this year, compared with a record of nearly 40 million tourists in 2019, before the pandemic.

site_title: Trump’s US election win prompts calls for Indian firms to be cautious on forex risks
summary: The Indian rupee plummeted to an all-time low of 84.3625 to the US dollar after Donald Trump's expected re-election as US president, prompting calls for Indian firms to manage their forex risks more prudently. The rupee's volatility is expected to increase, with HDFC Bank warning of a higher risk of larger moves over the coming months. Indian companies, accustomed to the rupee's narrow range, will need to adjust their foreign exchange risk management strategies, with some experts recommending option hedges and forwards to mitigate near-term risks.

site_title: Thailand declares extra holidays to spur tourism-reliant economy
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved two additional holidays in 2025 and a five-day holiday in 2026 to boost tourism, supporting the country's economy, which accounts for 12% of its GDP and nearly 20% of jobs. The holidays will encourage longer trips during long weekends, aligning with the government's plan to designate 2026 as the "Year of Tourism and Sports". This move follows the country's recovery from the pandemic, with 30 million tourists visiting so far this year, on track to meet the 36.7 million target.

images.alt_text: Tourists visit the Grand Palace in Bangkok, Thailand, August 6, 2024. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa
More than 29 million tourists have visited the country so far this year, on course to meet Thai government’s full-year target of 36.7 million.
The baht has declined more than 7 per cent this quarter in Asia’s worst performance, as Thailand’s government campaigned for the central bank to cut borrowing costs.

site_title: HDB resale prices continue rising in October while transaction volume falls: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.3% in October, with mature estates increasing 0.1% and non-mature estates 0.5%. The overall price increase was 9.8% from the same period last year. Demand for larger flats, such as executive flats, drove the growth, with prices rising 1.8% for these units. However, transaction volumes fell 2.7% due to increased competition from new BTO flats and high resale prices, potentially impacting affordability. Experts predict further growth in resale prices, with some forecasting a 3-4% increase in 2024.

images.alt_text: Samuel Oh
A vast majority of resale flats transacted during the latest quarter were at a price “much lower" than S$1 million, says HDB.

site_title: Japan, Korea deals drive Asia-Pac commercial real estate investment to highest since 2022
summary: Asia-Pacific commercial real estate investment volumes surged to $38.8 billion in Q3, the highest quarterly level since 2022, driven by lower debt costs and interest in Korea. Singapore investors were the most active in cross-border deals, while Korea and Japan saw significant investments, with rental growth expected to stay positive in Seoul. The largest office transaction in Korea was the sale of The Asset for $814 million, while Singapore posted $4.4 billion in deals, a 118% increase from the year-ago period.

site_title: Five economic areas the incoming US president needs to tackle
summary: The US presidential election has highlighted the need for a new administration to address five key economic areas: maintaining growth while repositioning the economy, managing high budget deficits and rising debt, resisting excessive use of economic tools, restoring credible American leadership, and improving communication. Both Kamala Harris and Donald Trump lack specific policy details to meet their promises, which could impact the country's economic exceptionalism and global growth. The new administration must develop a comprehensive plan to tackle these challenges and avoid creating additional holes in the public finances.

site_title: Hanwha’s offer for Dyna-Mac turns unconditional on acceptances; closing date extended to Nov 20
summary: Hanwha Ocean SG's voluntary conditional cash offer for Dyna-Mac has been declared unconditional as of acceptances, with over 554 million shares tendered, representing 44.45% of total issued shares. The offer's closing date has been extended to Nov 20, following the acceptance of shares by Hanwha Aerospace and its controlling parties. The deal remains conditional on a merger control condition, requiring a favorable decision from the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore.

site_title: Straits Trading Company makes bold move in Malaysia with Penang’s Straits City project
summary: Straits Trading Company, a Singapore-based developer, is launching Straits City in Butterworth, Penang, Malaysia, a 40-acre mixed-use project with a gross development value of RM4.3 billion. The development aims to transform the area into a vibrant, sustainable urban community with retail, residential, office, and leisure spaces. CEO Eric Teng expects the project to attract investment and drive growth in Malaysia's northern corridor, particularly in the tech industry. With a completion timeline of 2038, Straits City is seen as a key player in Penang's Vision 2030 plan to become a "World-Class Tourist Destination".

site_title: Indonesia expected to grow up to 5.05% in Q3, led by strong demand, investment
summary: Indonesia's economy is expected to grow at 4.9-5.05% in Q3, driven by robust demand and increasing investment, according to economists. The growth is seen as a solid foundation for newly inaugurated President Prabowo Subianto's ambitious 8% average growth target over his next five years. However, geopolitical tensions and market volatility pose risks to the economy, with the looming US elections and potential trade barriers affecting investor confidence. Foreign direct investment in Indonesia grew 19% in Q3, driven by the mining and metal refining sectors.

Headquartered in Sukaharjo, Central Java, Sritex has long supplied high-street brands like H&M and Forever 21 while also producing military uniforms for NATO

site_title: Volvo Cars October sales rise 3% year-on-year
summary: Volvo Cars reported a 3% year-on-year increase in October sales to 61,686 cars, driven primarily by an increase in electric and plug-in hybrid model sales in Europe, where sales rose 21% to 30,167 cars. Globally, sales of fully electric and plug-in hybrid models increased 40% and accounted for 48% of cars sold. In contrast, sales in the US declined 17% and in China decreased 10%.

site_title: Malaysia maintains key rate at 3%, expects sustained growth
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, has maintained its benchmark interest rate at 3% as of November 6, 2024. This decision was widely expected and is expected to continue until at least 2026. The central bank cited the country's firm recovery and low inflation as reasons for the decision, despite potential volatility from the US elections. The ringgit has depreciated 2.8% against the US dollar in the past month but has still appreciated 7% year-on-year. Economists expect the country's economic growth to continue, with forecasts ranging from 4.8-5.3% in 2024 and 4.3% in 2025.

Ringgit remains the best performer across emerging markets this year as economic growth surpassed analysts’ estimates, driven by domestic demand and investments from tech giants.
The ringgit movement remained volatile in the first six months due to persistent strength of the US dollar

site_title: Retail vacancy rate improves further to 10-year low of 6.5%; foreign F&B operators hold up rents
summary: Singapore's retail vacancy rate has dropped to a 10-year low of 6.5% in the third quarter, according to Savills Singapore. This improvement is attributed to a stable suburban market and healthy demand for prime retail spaces. However, Savills director Alan Cheong warns that the trend may not last due to falling or negative margins, which could lead to more operators exiting the market than foreign players entering.

site_title: Bitcoin leaps to record high as traders lean towards Trump victory
summary: Bitcoin surged 7% to a record high of US$75,060, topping March's peak, as investors leaned towards Donald Trump's potential victory in the US presidential election. This optimism is driven by expectations of a softer line on cryptocurrency regulation under Trump's return to the White House. Smaller cryptocurrency ether also jumped 7.5%. The market views a Trump win as a positive for crypto innovation and speculation.

site_title: Steamboat gets new meaning at Chinese hotpot eatery Chamoon
summary: Chamoon Hot Pot, a high-end Chinese hotpot eatery, has opened in Scotts Square, Singapore, offering premium ingredients and individual hotpot portions. The S$149 set features A4 wagyu, kurobuta pork, prawns, and abalone, with signature truffle-matsutake broth and tomato-papaya broth said to be good for the skin. Despite a steep price tag, the experience is enjoyable, with impeccable service and a unique, upscale atmosphere. However, the food is merely adequate, making the overall experience worth the price for its unique ambiance and attentive service.

site_title: Hot stock: Genting Singapore shares rise nearly 2% after RWS casino chief steps down
summary: Genting Singapore shares rose nearly 2% after Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) casino chief Andrew MacDonald stepped down, effective November 1, to pursue personal interests. MacDonald had previously been banned from Marina Bay Sands premises for alleged attempts at poaching high-rollers. The announcement comes after MacDonald left MBS in July 2021 and joined RWS in September 2022.

site_title: German parts maker Schaeffler to cut 4,700 jobs on auto woes
summary: German parts maker Schaeffler plans to cut 4,700 jobs across 10 locations in Europe, with 2,800 positions eliminated and 3,700 remaining, as the company aims to save US$316 million per year by 2029 due to a downturn in the car industry. This move follows similar job cuts by peers, including Robert Bosch and ZF Friedrichshafen, amid weaker sales in China and Europe, and intensifying competition from China in the EV market.

site_title: POSB steps up financial literacy efforts for youths, families in the heartlands
summary: POSB held a financial literacy event, "Your Neighbourhood Carnival," in Yishun, attracting 800 attendees. The event aimed to promote financial literacy among children and families through interactive experiences, such as gamified ATMs and budgeting activities. POSB plans to expand its financial literacy outreach programs, reaching 50,000 students, and partner with organizations like the People's Association and National Library Board. The initiative is part of POSB's Support Our Heartlands program, which aims to strengthen retirement readiness and promote financial literacy in communities.

site_title: South Korea weighs buying more US oil and gas if Trump wins
summary: South Korea is considering a plan to boost energy imports from the US if Donald Trump wins the election, amid concerns over a potential trade surplus with America. Officials in Seoul have been holding meetings with businesses and think tanks to discuss post-election strategies, including urging companies to increase US oil and gas purchases. The move aims to mitigate the impact of a potential 10% tariff on all imports and 60% tariff on Chinese goods, which could harm South Korea's economy.

site_title: Malaysia targets family offices managing more than RM500 million amid regional wealth boom
summary: Malaysia aims to attract family offices managing RM500 million to RM1.2 billion in assets to establish operations in Forest City, Johor, with the goal of generating RM40 million to RM110 million in local investments. The move, part of a broader initiative to revitalize Forest City, is expected to create economic opportunities and boost the country's economy. To qualify, family offices must meet specific investment and expenditure requirements, including paying a minimum monthly salary of RM10,000 and committing 10% of AUM to local investments.

site_title: Apple accused by NLRB of deterring employees from discussing pay equity
summary: The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) has accused Apple of deterring employees from discussing pay equity and forcing an engineer, Cher Scarlett, to quit after she circulated a wage survey. The complaint is the third in a month, alleging Apple restricted employee discussions on social media and workplace messaging app Slack. Apple denies the claims, stating it is committed to maintaining a positive and inclusive workplace. An administrative law judge will hold an initial hearing in June, with the possibility of a settlement or trial.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust’s hit by sudden jump in Aussie tax rate serves as a cautionary tale
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust's Australian subsidiary, FHT Australia Trust, will face a higher effective tax rate of 37.5% due to a share-swapping deal between two substantial shareholders of Frasers Property. The trust's distributable income is estimated to be reduced by S$1.3 million for FY2024, and a deferred tax liability of approximately S$22 million will be recognized. The loss of FHT Australia Trust's status as a managed investment trust may result in the capital support of strategic investors being lost, serving as a cautionary tale for S-Reits operating in Australia.

site_title: Single leverage limit, additional disclosures imposed on all S-Reits: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has introduced stricter rules for Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits), setting a minimum interest coverage ratio (ICR) of 1.5 times and an aggregate leverage limit of 50% with immediate effect. S-Reit managers will also have to disclose their plans to manage leverage and ICR levels in their financial and annual reports, starting from March 31, 2025. The changes aim to standardize leverage limits and promote prudent borrowing, while offering operational flexibility to Reits.

site_title: Challenges posed by the rise of passive investing
summary: Passive investing has gained popularity over the past 20 years due to its success rate being lower than active fund managers. The US has seen a significant shift away from active funds to passive investments, mainly attributed to the low success rate of US equity managers. This rise of passive investing raises concerns about market efficiency, liquidity, and corporate governance. Experts warn that increasing passive ownership may lead to hidden costs, such as decreased market efficiency and potential negative consequences for corporate governance.
